title: Can Fifth Avenue Be Saved?
description: There is an urban disease in New York called Sixth Avenueism. It is an expensive new kind of blight created by land values and zoning. A creeping redevelopment wasteland of anonymous office buildings and vacuous plazas chases out most of the things a city needs for service and pleasure. The livingor deadexample of the trend, Sixth Avenue, properly known as the Avenue of the Americas, is the definitive demonstration of the failure of New York's revised zoning code a decade after it was passed.

title: FLORIDIANS DOWN SQUIRES, 136128
description: SALEM, Va., Feb. 28 (AP) The Floridians staged a 20.5 run in the first period and then held, off several scoring surges by the Virginia squires for a 136128 American Basketball Association victory today.

title: The American Way in Asia as seen by Robert Osborn
description: In his State of the World Message, President Nixon sought to demonstrate a nonhostile disposition toward China. There were amiable references to a dialogne with Peking, and the possi bility of China's playing a construc tive role in the family of nations. But Washington would continue to oppose, the seating of Peking's dele gation in the U.N. at the expense of Taipei's representation, and we stand by our 1954 treaty with the Republic of China on Taiwan. In sum, no change.

title: Arts Abroad
description: STOCKHOLMStarting in the early nineteen  sixties, they used to tell a story that, better than lengthy desprip tions, told how builders and bulldozers have transformed Stockholm.

title: SABRES TRIUMPH; 3 FOR ATKINSON
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 28 (UPI)  Steve Atkinson scored three goals for the first time and the Buffalo Sabres tallied three times in the last 1 minute 39 seconds tonight to beat the Minnesota North Stars, 52.

title: Israeli Watchman, 59, Is Released by Arabs
description: ROSH HANIKRA, Israel, Feb. 28Shmuel Rosenwas ser, the night watchman who was abducted by Arab guer rillas While making his rounds in Metullab, a settle ment near the Lebanese bor der, on Dec. 31, 1969, was returned to Israel today.

title: Dixie Howell in Hospital
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 (AP) Millard (Dixie) Howell, whose passes to Don Hutson helped Alabama defeat Stanford, 2913, in the 1935 Rose Bowl game, re turned to a Hollywood hospital today for cobalt and nutritional treatment, his wife, Peggy, dis closed. The 58yearold Howell underwent surgery for removal of a tumor two years ago and returned to the hospital for an other operation last Jan. 11.

title: Personal Finance
description: You may be too young to really care, but on the other hand, you may be one of the 27.5 million working men and women of the United States building up pension plan benefits for that lucky day in the future when you can look forward to retire ment.

title: And, Now, the Instant Courtroom
description: Administrative Judge David Ross of the Criminal Court system disclosed yesterday that he had established in stant courtrooms to speed the judicial process.

title: India Starts Voting in 10Day Poll
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 28The people of India, the world's largest democratic electorate, start voting tomorrow in their most significant national elec tion since they gained inde pendence from the British in 1947.

title: Shop Talk
description: Felice Mortner and Rolene Schliff were college room mates (Syracuse '53), Soon after graduation, they each got married and moved to the sub urbsa split level house in West Caldwell, N. J., for Mrs. Mortner, a Colonialstyle place in Wood mere, L. I., for Mrs. Schliff.

title: $50,000 in War Relics Stolen
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Feb. 28 (AP)  Burglars ransacked the War Memorial Museum of Virginia last night or early to day, carting off $50,000 worth of war relics, including a num ber of operable automatic weapons. The police said a complete list of items taken from the museum was not avail able, but machine guns, pistols, rifles, bayonets, banners, uni forms, flags and insignia were reported missing.

title: Sports of The Times
description: At dinner one night last week, an old and presumably dear friend of Al McGuire said: You could probably make good case for Al being everything that's wrong with the American system. On the other hand, you could make good case for him being everything that's right. Across the table, McGuire, who visualizes himself as a man in the pits, not in the clouds, had no time for such philosophy.

title: AT HOME ABROAP
description: LONDON, Feb, 28Try to imagine an American Federal law authorizing the Attorney General to deport any alien whose presence he declared would hot be conducive to the public good. Imagine further that the ac cused alien would have no right to a statement of reasons a hearing or access to the courts.

title: Young Conductors Join To Lead Philharmonic
description: Since young assistant con ductors with big orchestras sel dom get a chance to take over the, podium in publicMichael Tilson Thomas of the Boston Symphony having been a nota ble exceptionit was nice of the New York Philharmonic to turn its Saturday night concert over to its 197071 assistants.

title: HARKEN TRIUMPHS FOR HUNTER TITLE
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., Feb. 28Bernie Traurig rode Har ken to the regular working hunter championship at the closing session, of the fiveday Winter Haven Hunter and Jumper Charity horse show today.

title: Five Brokerage Concerns Are Punished by N.A.S.D.
description: Five brokerage houses and 13 persons have been disciplined by the National Association of Securities Dealers, the self regulatory organization for the overthecounter market, after it found violations of its rules of fair practice.

title: ILYA LOPERT DIES; FILM OFFICIAL, 65
description: PARIS, Feb. 28Ilya Lopert, an American film producer and executive who headed the Euro pean operations of United Art ists until about two years ago, died at the American Hospital here yesterday. He was 65 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent move to hike the first class domestic postal rate from 6 cents to 8 cents may prove more harmful than beneficial. The Post Office has, since 1958, raised its firstclass postal rate three times, totalling a 100 per cent increase in thirteen years.

title: Nicklaus Wins P.G.A. Crown 2d Time
description: NORTH PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28Jack Nicklaus, as one of the game's great players, fo day achieved what no other golfer had done. With a final round of 73 for an aggregate of 281, the 31yearold bomber won the Professional Golfers' Association championship for the second time.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The following is a list loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Mrs. King Takes Final
description: WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 28 (UPI)  Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., defeated Rosemary Casals of San Fran cisco today to win the national women's indoor tennis cham pionship.

title: NEWARK TEACHERS PRESS THEIR STRIKE
description: NEWARK, Feb. 28 (UPI) A mass rally of striking Newark teachers voted today to con tinue their walkout into its fifth week.

title: News Analysis
description: SAIGON, South. Vietnam, Feb. 28  The South Vietnamese thrust against enemy supply routes in Laos is entering its crucial stage, in the view of authoritative American military sources here.

title: L.I. Prisoner Hanged
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., Feb. 28A 20yearold inmate of the Nassau County Jail was found hanged by a bedsheet tied to a cell door at 8:10 P.M. yesterday. The prisoner, Patrick Ctuellette of Uniondale, L. I., had been arrested Friday and charged with the armed rob bery of a Dairy Barn store on Uniondale Avenue and Hemp stead Boulevard Wednesday.

title: PANACEA IS RULED LIPTON CUP VICTOR
description: MIAMI, Feb. 28Panacea, a Class B boat, was declared to day the overall winner of yes terday's muddled Lipton Cup yacht race after a committee disallowed a sea of protests.

title: Mrs. Thesieres Triumphs
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 28 Mrs. Terry Thesieres of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., defeated Miss Marigold Edwards of Pitts burgh, 1515, 15.8, 159, today to capture the 39th United States women's squash racquets singles championship at Jadwin Gymnasium. Mrs. Thesieres, the American senior in the tourna ment, hit 24 winners with her backhand, accounting for more than half her points.

title: MIRIAM CRAIG
description: Miriam Craig, a former actress, in private life the wife of Jack Shor, vice president for public relations of Clairol, Inc., died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital, apparently of a heart attack. She was 54 years old and lived at 271 Central Park West.

title: Rio de Janeiro Rains Kill 96
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 28 (Reuters)The death toll here and in Rio de Janeiro State was put at 96 today after several days of heavy rain.

title: Nixon Returns to Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House by helicopter this afternoon after an over night stay at Camp David, Maryland. Mr. Nixon will fly to Des Moines tomorrow to press his revenuesharing plan in a speech to the Iowa Legislature and will meet later with the Governors of Iowa, Missouri, Wisconsin and Illinois before returning here tomorrow night to honor the Apollo 14 astro nauts at a White House dinner.

title: GRAHAM CLAYTOR, UTILITY ENGINEER
description: ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 28  W. Graham Claytor, who re tired as executive vice presi dent of the American Electric Power Company in 1962, died today at the age of 84.

title: Red Cross Month
description: Today is the opening of Red Cross month across the country. In proclaiming the month in New York City this morning, Mayor Lindsay will present a cita tion to the vol unteers of the American Red Cross in Greater New York.

title: NEW HAVEN BEST
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 28  A silver buff cocker spaniel, who walked into the ring with a record of one best in show, doubled her winning production in just 10 minutes today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Feb. 22 letter by Frank Gervasi demonstrates an ignorance of the situation in the Middle East or is an overt attempt to mix apples and or anges by implying criticism of the Arab states because they are not de mocracies.

title: Jawboning Television
description: Television, the one American art form under direct Federal regulation, sometimes looks like an anomaly in search of a program. In this respect the role of the Fed eral Communications Commission during its bold phases has been to push and prodin short, to jawbone the broadcasters into putting quality on the air.

title: Germans Finish 1, 2
description: FALUN, Sweden, Feb. 28 (UPI)GertDietmar Klause and Gerhard Grimmer took the first two places for East Germany today in the 30kilometer cross country race in the interna tional Swedish ski games. Hannu Taipale of Finland was third and Vyatyeslav Vedenin of the Soviet Union fourth. Klause won in 1 hour, 51 min utes, 39 seconds.

title: U.S. MOVES TANKS TO SEAL FRONTIER TO ENEMY IN LAOS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Feb. 28United States tanks and other armored units moved to the South VietnameseLao tian border today to prevent a possible eastward movement of a North Vietnamese tank force that supported the enemy as sault on a contested hill six miles inside Laos.

title: Celler Asks a Civilian Draft Of Young Men and Women
description: Representative Emanuel Cel ler suggested yesterday that men and women 18 to 22 years old be drafted into a universal service corps to help meet the nation's peacetime needs.

title: Fire Kills Two Children
description: ROOSEVELT, L. I., Feb. 28 Two small children were burned to death when a fire of un known origin destroyed a 1 story dwelling at 10 Hansom Place shortly before midnight last night. The house was oc cupied by Linda McCants and her sister, Rose McCants, their children and seven other adults. The dead are Felicia, 2, and Dawn, 8 months. Three others were taken in the Fire Depart ment ambulance for treatment for smoke inhalation and lacer ations.

title: DECISION ON PREMIER DELAYED IN NORWAY
description: OSLO, Feb 28A decision on The future of Norway's coall tion Government was post poned until tomorrow after a Cabinet meeting tonight. It has been expedted that Premier Per Borten and coalition Cabi net would resign to be replaced by a new nonSocialist govern ment.

title: The Panthers: Dead or Regrouping
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 28 They are seldom seen out in the streets now, passing out their leaflets, selling the party newspaper.

title: Chess: Unusual Perception Marks  Hill's Victory Over Coleman
description: A strong veteran expert, Bernard Hill of the Queen's Club, defeated Jack Coleman during the recent club cham pionship in a game of un usual perception.

title: ExAlbanian Envoy Seized With Revolver on Plane
description: Port Authority policamen; searching an American Airlines plane at Kennedy International Airport last night after receiv ing a telephoned bomb threat, arrested a former Albanian diplomat after finding a 38 caliber revolver in his suitcase. No bomb was found.

title: DROUGHT PARCHES
description: LISBON, Feb. 28A drought, now in its third year, has had a catastrophic effect on Portugal's Cape Verde Islands.

title: France's Mood Growing Uneasy
description: PARIS, Feb. 28France is in political, economic and so cial transition, and demon strations by farmers, strikes by miners and other work ers, agitation by students and controversy within the Gov ernment majority have con verged to create an air of disquiet.

title: ISRAELI COMPANY YOUNG AND LIVELY
description: Manhattan's loss is America's gain. Strangely and sadly, the delightful Israel Folk Company played only two days. Saturday and Sunday, at the remote 46th Street Theater in Brooklyn and now has scooted off on a na tional tour. As seen last night, with a skimpy but responsive audience, the group was de lightful. The 16 dancers, the musical ensemble of five and the vocal and instrumental spe cialists were young, neat and exuberantly professional for two hours in a potpourri di rected by Gano Ichiel.

title: Bucks Down Celtics
description: BOSTON, Feb. 28 (AP)Lew Alcindor, held to 8 points in the first half tonight, came back in strong fashion and led the Mil waukee Bucks to a 11199 vic tory over the Boston Celtics. Alcindor scored 18 points in the last half as the Bucks over came a 5950 halftime deficit.

title: Karen Balzer Betters Mark In 50Meter Indoor Hurdles
description: EAST BERLIN, Feb. 28, (Reuters)Karen Balzer of East Germany bettered her own world's best mark for the 50 meter hurdles today with a time of 6.7 seconds in an inter national meet.

title: Saijo Retains Title, Beating Crawford In 15Round Fight
description: UTSUNOMIYA, Japan, Feb. 28 (UPI)  Shozo Saijo of Japan retained his World Boxing Association feather weight title tonight for the fifth time by outpciinting Frankie Crawford of Los Angeles in a 15round battle.

title: Nixon Pushing Old Plan to Sell Federal Airports Near Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28On Page 51 of the new Federal budget submitted by President Nixon to Congress last month, under the heading Of Selected Economies and Reforms, is a singleline entry that reads, sell national capital airports.

title: SPANISHAMERICANS TOTAL 9.2 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI)  About 9.2 million per sons living in the United Stares  6.5 (million of them native born Americans  identify themselves as being of Spanish origin, the Census Bureau re ported today.

title: Dream Plans a Stay At Brooklyn Academy
description: Peter Brook's production of A Midsummer Night's Dream, now being performed at the Billy Rose Theater for a limited run, will be pre sented at the Brooklyn Acad emy of Music for 15 perform ances starting March 16.

title: Irish, Dayton: Two Problems AtLarge
description: Notre Dame or Dayton for an atlarge, berth to the Na tional Collegiate Athletic As sociation basketball tourna ment? Maybe both.

title: New Radar Trainer Designed to Curb Collisions at Sea

Thomas F. O'Callaghan, pres ident of the International Or ganization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.

title: HELPFUL POLICEMAN HURT BY ATTACKERS
description: An offduty patrolman was hurled through a plateglass window early yesterday by two men and, a third that they were apparently attacking.

title: Havana Denounces Seizure Of Fishing Boats Off Florida.
description: MIAMI, Feb. 28The Havana radio today described the seiz ure last week of four Cuban fishing boats, charged with fishing illegally in United States waters, as another pirate aggression against Cuba.

title: Unused Inflation Curb
description: Whenever the White House worries about runaway inflation in construc tion wages, which is practically every time the dollar is in trouble, the reply of the hardhats is always predictable: It's unfair to make a big jibing of our high hourly wage scales. Seasonal wage patterns and bad weather keep us off the job so much that our annual earnings aren't much different from those of auto or steel workers.

title: Eastman Dillon Realigns Officers and Incorporates
description: Eastman Dillon, Union Secur ities & Co., a leading invest ment banking and brokerage house, announced its incorpora tion over the weekend, effec tive today. The concern's new name is Eastman Dillon, Union Securities & Co., Inc.

description: Jorge Mester conducted Puc cini's La Bohme for the first time with the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater Saturday afternoon.

title: Stars Set Back Chaparrals On Robbins's Shot, 125123

JACOB L. TALMON Professor of Modern History Hebrew University Jerusalem, Feb. 25, 1971

title: Article 1  No Title

description: NEW AMERICAN REVIEW NUMBER 11. Edited by Theodore Solotaroff. 240 pages. A Touchstone Book. Simon & Schuster. Paperback, $1.95.

title: Harold Braverman Dead at 57; Led B'nai B'rith Bias Crusade
description: Harold Braverman, a lawyer and national director of the discriminations department of the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith, died Saturday of arteriosclerosis in University Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 201 East 36th Street.

title: Narcotics Raids on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 (UPI)A series of narcotics raids in four bay area cities netted today what Federal agents said may amount to $2 million in heroin, 10 suspects and an arsenal of small arms. The raids were conducted in Newark, Fresmont, Hayward and Union City, all in southern Alameda County.

title: There's a Time, They Say, to Let People Die
Hotel Thefts Up Sharply Across Nation
description: A hotel room can mean bed for the traveler or tourist in a strange City. But, increas ingly, hotel rooms are becoming just another place where one can be robbed.

title: Durham Demanding a Referee Who Can Control Ali
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 Aware of Muhammad Ali's theatrics, Joe Frazier's man ager, Yancey Durham, de manded today a referee who can keep control of next week's world heavyweight championship fight at Madi son Square Garden.

description: INZELL, Germany, Feb. 28 (UPI)Mrs. Attje KuulenDeel stra of the Netherlands won the Golden Skate international women's speed skating meet to day. Diane Holum of North brook, Ill., was second.

His filibuster had not quite killed the super sonic transport airplane, but it had severely threatened the project's advance by putting a threemonth tether on Govern ment funding of it.

title: Carrier Model Brings $3,500
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 28 (UPI) A 33foot model of the Japanese aircraft carrier Kaga featured in the film Tora, Tora, Tora was sold for $3,500 today at a 20th Century Fox studios auction. The fourday sale with 2,000 props dating back 43 years, grossed $364,480.

title: Duquesne Defeats Niagara For 20th Triumph, 9969,
description: PITTSBURCH, Feb. 28 (UPI) Duquesne defeated Niagara, 9969, today before 7,521 fans at the Civic Arena for its 20th victory in 23 games.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mozart Ensemble Plays Pilgrims and Pioneers
description: The Mozart Festival Orches tra is not likely to be mistaken for a crack chamber group, but it sounded more cohesive at Town Hall Saturday after noon than it has at most of its previous New York con certs.

title: Man in the News
description: TORONTO, Feb. 28Wil liam G. Davis, who will be sworn in as the 18th Premier. of Ontario tomorrow, re called the other clay that he watched the inauguration of President Nixon from a frontrow box. Asked who had invited him, he insisted that he did not remember.

title: Cruelty at Sea
description: A Federal indictment has been filed against three shipping companies and two African export firms for allegedly shipping wild animals from Kenya to the United States in an inhumane manner. Some twenty animalsincluding a giraffe, gazelles and zebrasdied because they were confined to cramped, unheated cages on the open deck of a freighter which encountered heavy rain and cold weather during a 33day crossing.

title: Numbers Called Harlem's Balm
description: Through a fictional character in Simple & the Numbers, the black poet Langston Hughes fo cused on the special relation ship between the numbers racket and many black Ameri can communities this way:

title: Sammis, Gray Win Again
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 28 Jesse Sammis 3d and Gordon Gray of the Field Club of Greenwich, the national cham pions, defended their Green wich doubles platform tennis championship today by defeat ing Robert Kingsbury of Fox Meadow Tennis Club, Scars dale, N.Y., and John Mangan, Manursing Island Club, Rye, N.Y., 46, 64, 75, 46, 62, in the final.

title: BENEDETTI RECITAL AT BEST IN CHOPIN
description: Evangeline Benedetti, a mem ber of the New York Philhar monic's cello section, plays in a freely expressive style and with an extraordinarily large, only piece on her Carnegie Re cital Hall program yesterday afternoon that really responded to this romantic treatment was the Chopin Cello Sonata.

title: Can the Senate Act?
description: The pattern of voting in the Senate on the recurrent attempts to break the existing filibuster makes clear the necessity for a change in rules. The initial attempt last month failed, 48 to 37, which was well short of twothirds. A later vote was 50 to 36, again short.

title: Plantier, 14, Takes Honors In Swim at Lawrenceville
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 28Gary Plantier, 14yearold freshman at Pennsburg, Pa., school, was selected the out standing swimmer last night at the 71st annual eastern inter scholastic championships at Lawrenceville School.

title: EDUCATION BOARD BOWS TO PROTESTS AND PUTS OFF CUTS
description: The Board of Education yes terday put off cutting $40mil lion in school services after community boards, unions and parent organizations said they unanimously opposed any re duction.

title: FRANK ARANOW
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 28 Frank Aranow, a trial lawyer in New York from 1908 until his retirement, died yesterday at his home, 115 E Cross Road. He was 87 years old.

title: Actionby Big Four Sought On Mideast as Talks Stall
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 28  United Nations offi cials and some Big Four rep resentatives moved with unex pected speed today to clear the way for. Big Four action on the stalled ArabIsraeli peace talks.

title: Franulovic Wins Tiebreaker
description: MACON, Ga., Feb. 28 (UPI) Zeljko Franulovic of Yugo slavia won the singles cham pionship in the Macon inter national tennis tournament to day by beating Ilie Nastase of Rumania, the topseeded for eigner, in a fifthset tiebreaker game. The scores were 64, 75, 57, 36, 76.

title: I.R.A. Official Beaten
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 28 (AP)  A political organizer of the Irish Republican Army who had been kidnapped from his home was found early Sunday beaten and bleeding beside a country road.

title: Sporting Club' Opens
description: Never, never have the good old days of Hollywood seemed so golden, at least lately, as with the unreeling of a new something-or-other titled "The Sporting Club" at the Coronet. What is this thing about?Apparently, a rustic hunting lodge in Michigan, where a group of guzzling high-livers from the city are holding a reunion, is supposed to signify structural America. Toward the end, the building is dynamited (after repeated hints that the Vietnam War is undermining things). The club members, men and women, stagger around in the ruins to a thunderous soundtrack rendition of "Battle Hymn of the Republic."Earlier, 20 minutes or so, there was a smaller-scale dynamiting of a new dam, at which a rally of war veterans and American Gothic types is being held. Hoping, praying that was the end, I reached for my shoes. No such luck.But the picture finally does end, after more hints, in a wallow of sex and violence (the facade of America?). As the color camera whips around in a frenzy of half-shadows, the braying club members strip down for a mass orgy. And we guarantee you've never seen such a repulsive array of flabby, middle-aged blubber.Studiously plunked down and magnified in a naturalistic, woodsy setting, the stilted, elliptical dialogue, the heavy stylization of the performances and the insistently pointed direction of Larry Peerce (of "Goodbye, Columbus," believe it or not), render it a plodding artificial bore.Lorenzo Semple Jr. has adapted the source, a novel by Thomas McGuane, which a reviewer for this newspaper said "almost put him to sleep." History repeats itself.

title: Bridge: New Order Takes Over Today At Contract League Offices
description: A new regime begins un obtrusively today at the headquarters of the Ameri can Contract Bridge League in Greenwich. Richard Gold berg of Stamford, N. Y., takes over from Easley Black wood as executive secretary of the national organization, which has almost 100 full time employes.

title: CALLS FOR STEEL CONTINUE STRONG
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28 De mand for steel was strong last week but not strong enough to satisfy, sales officials.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: MARCH 1, 1971

title: 55 Swedes Protest to Soviet
description: STOCKHOLM, Feb, 28 (Reu ters) Fiftyfive prominent Swedes, including two winners of Nobel Prizes, Arne Tiselius and Par Lagerkvist, have sent the Soviet Government a pro test against what they term a new wave of persecution of Soviet Jews.

title: GAIN BY CHURCHES SETS A NEW LOW
description: Church membership in the United States increased 0.03 per cent in 1969the smallest gain in modern timesaccord ing to the 1971 edition of the Yearbook of American Churches, published today by the National Council of Churches. The increase in, 1968 was 1.6 per cent.

title: Panel to Study Change in Pollution Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  When the Senate Subcommit tee on Air and Water Pollution begins hearings two weeks from tomorrow on new water quality legislation, it will inquire close ly into the meaning and pos sible effect of seven words in President Nixon's bill.

title: ChienChung Scores 282 To Win Philippines Open
description: MANILA, Feb. 28 (UPI) Nationalist China's Chen Chien Chung shot a twounderpar 70 today for 282 to win the Philippines open championship by six strokes.

title: JULES R. TIMMINS, 82, BEGAN IRON PROJECTS
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 28Jules R. Timmins, a leading figure in the great iron ore development of Labrador, died here Friday in a hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: Certificate Immobilization Is Foremost BASIC Goal
description: The Banking and Securitiet Industry Committee (BASIC) has identified immobilization of the stock certificate and other securities as its most signifi cant goal, according to the BASIC yearend report released over the weekend.

title: Foyt Wins $207,000 Race;
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Feb. 28 (AP) A. J. Foyt held off a dramatic, racelong challenge from Rich ard Petty and Buddy Baker to win the first Miller 500 stock car race at the Ontario Motor Speedway today.

title: Ryan Wins 5Mile Run
description: Howard Ryan of the New York Athletic Club won the 10th annual Bob Preston Me morial fivemile run around Yankee Stadium yesterday. Ryan was clocked in 25 minutes 5.2 seconds. He finished 70 yards ahead of Don Rowe, clubmate. Charles Kaczorek of the Millrose Athletic Associa tion was third.

title: Unwanted U.S. Dollars Sharpen European Monetary Difficulties
description: PARIS, Feb. 28The monetary conflict between the United States and Europe is growing sharper as unwanted dollars pour into European central banks and aggravate the difficulties the European au thorities are having in curbing inflation.

title: CURRIER CAPTURES STRATTON SLALOM
description: STRATTON MOUNTAIN, Vt., Feb. 28  Dave Currier and Steye Murphy, freshmen room mates at Dartmouth, finished first and second, respectively, today in the New England Kan dahar on Tamarack Trail.

title: Bench Signs Contract With Reds for $80,000
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 28 (UPI) Johnny Bench, the Cincin nati Reds' catcher, signed a oneyear contract today for an estimated $80,000double the amount he received last year.

title: LIVINGSTONE GROUP JOINS LINHART TRIO
description: Bluegrass, country and West ern, folk music and rock were all part of the musical fare at the McBurney Young Men's and Young Women's Christian As sociation, 215 West 23d Street, Sunday afternoonthe first two provided by the reconsti tuted Livingstone Cowboys, the last two by Buzz Linhart's trio.

title: Firkusny Exceeds His Own Enviable Standards
description: Rudolf Firkusny made his New York debut 30 seasons ago, and during that time prob ably not many musicians have performed at or near the sat isfying level of the Czechborn pianist. Sunday afternoon's re cital in the Hunter College As sembly Hall found Mr. Firkusny playing above even his own enviable standard. He got around the keyboard as im pressively as ever, but never with perfunctory brilliance; he made music every moment of the way.

title: ROYALS DEFEATED
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (UPI) Bill Cunningham and Wally Jones combined for 52 points today as the Philadelphia 76ers defeated the Cincinnati Royals, 131121, in a National Basket ball Association game at the Spectrum.

title: Unser First in Argentina
description: RAFAELA, Argentina, Feb 28 (UPI)  Al Unser, driving an EagleFord, registered an easy victory today in a $75,000 United States Auto Club race for Indianapolis cars that was marred by a fiery accident and rain.

title: Lots of U.S. Cash Is Described As Only Way to Save Rolls Jet
description: LONDON, Feb. 28 (Reuters) The RollsRoyce RB211 engine project will be saved only if the Americans are prepared to back it financially, Lord Carrington, Britain's Minister of Defense, said here today. And he warned that it would need a lot of money.

title: College Building on a Base of Hope
description: Every day carpenters, electri cians, masons, plumbers and steelworkers are working around the 480 students at Hostos Community College.

title: Liechtenstein's Male Electorate Refuses to Give Women the Vote
description: GENEVA, Feb. 28  Male voters in the tiny mountain principality of Liechtenstein, sandwiched between Switzer land and Austria, narrowly re jected women's suffrage today.

title: A British Soldier Is Burned to Death In Attack in Ulster
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Monday, March (Reuters)A gang in a Roman Catholic area killed a British military policeman today by throwing a gasoline bomb at him and setting him ablaze.

title: Rome's First Divorce Won
description: ROME, Feb. 28 (UPI)A civil court judge today decreed the first divorce in Rome since Italy's new divorce law went into effect last December. Jus tice Giuseppe Amatucci issued a decree dissolving the mar riage of Efisio Saco and Maria Manunta.

title: Egypt Seizes Narcotics
description: CAIRO, Feb. 28 (UPI)The Egyptian police today seized two tons of hashish and mor phine stored on the deserted Red Sea island of Hamata, of ficials said.

title: Pistons Edge Hawks
description: ATLANTA Feb. 28 (UPI)  Bob Lanier converted a 3point play with 40 seconds remaining to earn the Detroit Pistons a 106105 victory over the At lanta Hawks tonight.

title: NATIONALS DOWN ELIZABETH, 1 TOO
description: Randy Horton scored after 17 minutes of an evenly played contest in which both teams missed many chances. Garret son Sacko of Elizabeth failed three times while alone in front of an empty goal.

title: Fulbright Hopes to Force Nixon's Advisers to Testify
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Senator J. W. Fulbright, criti cizing what he termed the total breakdown of communication between Congress and the Ad ministration on Vietnam, said today that he would submit a bill to compel the Secretary of State and other officials to ap pear before Congress to explain the Administration's policies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Prof. Paul A. Reynolds of Wesleyan University [letter Feb. 22] attempts to defend Dr. M. T. Mehdi by advancing arguments which he himself did not make. Dr. Mehdi did not argue that Israel was not a democracy: he argued that Israel was not a democracy be cause it was a sacral society, unlike the U.S.A. For that reason I wrote my reply, because Dr. Mehdi's credentials on American religious history are as suspect as his opinions on Israel.

title: Egypt Accuses Israel
description: CAIRO, Feb. 28 (Reuters) Egypt tonight accused Israel of closing the doors on a peace settlement by refusing to with draw from the occupied ter ritorles. An official spokesman, quoted by the semiofficial Middle East News Agency said that Cairo today received from its United Nations envoy a copy of the Israeli reply to Dr. Jarring's proposals.

title: NO HAZARD FOUND IN MERCURY IN AIR
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28The state Environmental Conservation De partment said today that pre liminary studies it had made of the amount of mercury in the air indicated that it was negli gible and not a health hazard.

title: Judge Challenges Memory Of Casey, S. E. C. Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 28The Federal judge who tried one of the lawsuits in which William J. Casey was a defendant says that Mr. Casey's version of three key aspects of the trial is at variance with the judge's own memory.

title: Sabol Takes Pro Slalom
description: SNOQUALMIE PASS, Wash,, Feb. 28 (UPI)Spider Sabich re gained the lead in earnings on the International Ski Ra cers Association circuit yesterday with a victory in the slalom portion of the $15,000 Rainier Cup competition.

title: Israeli Cabinet Meets
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 28 (Reu ters)The Israeli Cabinet met today to discuss the vital ques tion of withdrawal from Arab territory, and political sources said that a confrontation with Washington on the issue now seemed inevitable.

title: Odds on Numbers Favor Banker
description: In the illegal numbers game, a player bets any amount from a penny up on any three numbers from 000 to 999. The winning number is taken from such sources as the last three numbers of the Federal Reserve System's totals or the last three digits of the total parimutuel handle at a race track.

title: Dog Owners May Have to Clean Up After Pets
description: The city's Environmental Protection Administration is considering several methods to alleviate the problem of dog leavings on city streets and sidewalks.

title: Tully Recital Given
description: The selection of a recital program can often be as reveal ing about a musician as the per formances themselves. Richard Goode demonstrated the point at Tully Hall Saturday night by playing four solid Teutonic masterpieces, warmly expres sive works but also music rippling with intellectual sinew.

title: Pension Funds Lead Rise In Institutional Trading
description: The increasing role of insti tutional investors in the stock market was clearly demonstrat ed in a report issued over the weekend by the New York Stock Exchange.

title: FigureSkating Queen Hailed by Peers
description: LYONS, France, Feb. 28  Beatrix Schuba, world cham pion, was booed again to day. She was booed last night when she won the women's figureskating title and she was booed today during the exhibition program at the Palais des Sports.

title: America's Moral Egocentrism
description: LONDONTo the distant observer a puzzling feature of American his tory in the last ten years has been the absence of ordinary political op position to the Vietnam war and the other vast American operations in Southeast Asia.

title: TV: Queen of Spades in Miniature
description: If you must risk shrink ing an opera down to the size of a television screen, what better gamble than Tohaikov sky's Queen of Spades? National Educational Televi sion's Opera Theater last night presented the melo drama known to operagoers as Pique Dame on Channel 13, in a tightly edited English language version produced and conducted by Peter Her man Adler, an experienced hand at opera telescoping. All things considered, Mr. Adler and his director, Kirk Brown ing, walked away from the table winners.

title: Polish Consumers Will Begin to Pay Lower Food Prices Today
description: WARSAW, Feb. 28Poland's hardpressed consumers were given the details today of what their leaders have said is the biggest concession they can afford: restoration of lower food prices. The change takes place tomorow.

title: William L. Rich Dead at 70; Led Stevedoring Concerns
description: LITTLE SILVER, N.J., Feb. 28William L. Rich Sr., former president of Standard Termi nals Stevedoring Inc., of New York, and former chairman of Seaboard Stevedoring Corpora tion, died today in Ivy House, a nursing home in Middletown. He was 70 years old and lived at 115 Winding Way.

title: Theater: Survival of St. Joan, Rock Opera, Opens
Pros Drop 7th in Row
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 28 (AP) Larry Cannon and Tom Work man teamed for 60 points to night to pace the Denver Rockets to a 118111 victory over Memphis. The loss was the Pros' seventh straight. Cannon made 33 points, most of them on driving layups.

title: St. Sebastian's Church Here Ordered Closed on March 31.
description: Parishioners at the Roman) Catholic Church of St. Sebas tian sat in sorrowful silence yesterday as a Franciscan priest told them that their church would be closed down March 31. Later, the parishioners de cided to protest the action by picketing the chancery office.

title: SHORTRUN TAXIS DUE AT KENNEDY
description: A 60day experiment de signed to improve the availabil ity of taxicabs for air travelers from Kennedy Airport to near by communties will go into effect today.

title: CORPORATE BONDS
description: The corporate bond market faces a record amount of new financing this week, and it's confident that it can handle this heavy load without push ing interest rates higher.

title: Rioters Battle Police In a Second Revolt In an Italian City
description: L'AQUILA, Italy, Feb. 28 Rioters led by neoFascists fought with the police in this chilly city in the mountains 50 miles northeast of Rome today in another of Italy's communal revolts.

title: Albert Sets Retirement
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) House Speaker Carl Albert, 62yearold Democrat of Okla homa, says he intends to retire from public office not later than eight years from now. He ex pressed that intention in a taped interview for the new Ask Congress television program tonight, on station WPIXTV, New York.

title: 14 Rothko Works Adorn New Chapel in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 28A Than religious center, lik ened in beauty and religious importance to the Sistine Chapel in Rome and the Matisse Chapel in France, opened there this weekend.

title: GLOBAL MONITORING OF POLLUTION URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) The American Chemical So ciety recommended today the creation of an international network of 20 to 30 stations to monitor global air pollution.

title: Wringer Washers Seen Likely As Target of Safety Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Products widely used by low income families, such as wringer washers, will be among the first likely targets of proposed man datory Federal safety standards if authorizing legislation is passed by Congress.

title: Clark Wins Squash Racquets
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Feb. 28 Chris Clark of Stony Brook defeated Larry Hilbert of Ford ham, 1115, 1714, 1613, 1817, today in the Stevens Tech metropolitan squash racquets final.

title: ARCHBISHOP HOPEFUL AFTER SOVIET TALKS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 28, (Reuters)  The Most Rev. Agostino Casaroli, the first Vatican diplomat to make an official visit to Moscow, said today that he had opened a dialogue with Soviet officials on the position of Roman Catholics in the Soviet Union.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Times is right in urging that the Legislature address itself promptly to the problem of the permanent gov ernance of the public school system. However, I would disagree with your suggestion that the best alternative to an undesirable citywide election of the board is an appointed board, even under improved procedures.

title: Caledonian Club No 2 Rink Beats Ardsley for Medal
description: ARDSLEYONHUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 28The New York Cale dopian Curling Club No. 2 rink, skipped by Kenneth Cooper, de feated Ardsley Curling Club No. 1, skipped by Robert Whit man, 137, today in the 12end final of the Eddison Medal bon spiel at Ardsley Country Club.

title: E. German Sledders Win
description: BERLIN, Feb. 28 (UPI)East German sledders were awarded the senior prizes in the Mitropa Cup international bobsled races today at the Oberwiesenthal course. A snowstorm caused cancellation of todays races as the titles were decided on the basis of yesterday's three runs. Harald Ehrig and AnnaMaria Mueller were the individual winners.

title: TOPICS HEATING UP AT LATIN AID BANK
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28An, extraordinary meeting of the InterAmerican Development Bank, second to the World Bank in international financing oper ations, will convene here to morrow to install a controver sial new president and discuss the admission of new members to the $6billion institution.

title: Miss Devlin to Join Protest
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 28 (UPI)  Bernadette Devlin, the 22yearold Member of Parlia ment and militant Roman Catholic from Northern Ireland said tonight that she intended to join planned demonstrations against President Nixon while he is here tomorrow to meet with four Middle Western Gov ernors. Miss Devlin was in Des Moines for a speech at Drake University.

title: Car Pollution Stirs U.S.European Friction
description: EINDHOVEN, the Nether landsThe new American law requiring virtually pollution free automobiles within five years has become a point of friction between the United States and Europe.

title: Nixon Aides Reported to Debate Setting Of a Definite Date for Ending 'War Role
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 There is said to be a subtle but intensive debate in the upper ranks of the Government about whether President Nixon should now commit himself to the def inite termination of American involvement in the Indochina war.

title: Lakers Rout Cavaliers
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb 28 (UPI)The Los Angeles Lakers put on a 283 burst in the first half and then toyed with the Cleveland Cavaliers en route to a 10790 victory tonight before a Forum crowd of 17,017.

title: Sadat Assures Palestinians: No Separate Peace With Israelis
description: CAIRO, Feb. 28  President Anwar elSadat assured appre hensive Palestinian leaders to day that the United Arab Re public would never agree to separate peace with Israel. He pledged not to abandon the cause of more than a million Palestinian refugees and to co operate in a common effort with Jordan and Syria to recover ter ritories occupied by Israel in the 1967 war.

title: Stockhausen Primes Audience With Explanations
description: As with the Stockhausen concert last Thursday at the New York Philharmonic, yes terday afternoon's at Tully Hall brought out the young. Every seat was taken, every variety of clothes and facial adornment could be seen, and the audience response was extremely interesting.

title: CARL C. ISAACSON
description: Carl C. Isaacson, president of Isaacson Steel Erectors, Inc., Farmingdale, L. I., died yesterday of a heart attack in Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park. He was 65 years, old and lived at 20942 Whitehall Terrace, Queens Vil lage, Queens.

title: Tokyo Airport Plan Delayed
description: NARITA, Japan, Feb. 28 (Reuters)  The Japanese au thorities today ordered a fur ther postponement until Tues day of attempts to dislodge farmersand students blocking completion of Tokyo's second international airport here.

title: F. T. C. Aide Backs Identification Plan For Sellers at Door
description: City and Federal regulations to require doortodoor sales men to disclose at once that they are trying to sell specific goods and services, instead of first posing as pollsters, wel comers or demonstrators, was endorsed yesterday by a Fed eral Trade Commission official.

title: Penney Is Broadening the Scope of Its Operations
description: The J. C. Penney Company, which some years ago shifted to full departmentstore oper ation after being known for decades as a softgoods chain, is in the throes of an important evolution in diversification. Penney is opening discounttype stores with food departments, operating drug stores and a consumerfinance company and will soon also have separate restaurants and a chain of greeting card shops.

title: CRITICISM OF HOOVER BY AGENTS ALLEGED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI) Senator George S. McGovern made public today an anony mous letter on Federal Bureau of Investigation stationery and purportedly from 10 F.B.I. agents charging that the agency had lost effectiveness because its agents must spend so much time polishing the image of J. Edgar Hoover.

title: BARRAGE BY KINGS ROUTS SEALS, 83
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 28 (UPI)  Gilles Marotte, a de fenseman, and Ross Lonsberry, a wing, each tallied twice to day, pacing the Los Angeles Kings to an 83 National Hockey League victoryover the skidding California Golden Seals.

title: MyungWhun Chung Heard With the Little Orchestra
description: MyungWhun Chung, first prize winner of WQXR's fifth annual Young Artists' Competi tion for Pianists, is the young est musical member of the tal ented Chung family. His sisters, KyungWha (violin) and Myung Wha (cello), are already well established soloists, and the three have previously appeared here together as a trio.

title: SOVIET DENOUNCES ISRAEL'S POSITION
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 28  The Soviet Government said today that Israel's latest refusal to withdraw her forces from all Arab territory occupied in 1967 had set back the chances for peace and had aggravated the Middle East situation.

title: Advertising:
description: The job title, of general manager at Batten, Baron, Durstine & 0sborn, unused since 1964, has been bestowed upon Donald A. Wells, an executive vice president.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The false nuclear alert on the morning of Feb. 20 may have been more than a human error. It was a timely warning of the abyss towards which we are perilously and rapidly drifting.

title: Simon Blumenthal Dead at 91; Oldest Stock Exchange Member
description: Simon B. Blumenthal, the old est member of the New York Stock Exchange, who was as sociated for 66 years with that organization, died Saturday at his home, 200 East 66th Street. He was 91 years old.

title: Castillo Winner
description: MONTERREY Mexico, Feb. 28 (UPI)  The world ban tamweight champion, Chucho Castillo of Mexico, scored sixthround knockout over countryman, Felipe Ursua, in a nontitle fight tonight be fore 15,000 fans in the bull ring.

title: Ecologists Battle Catholic Land Plan
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 28  A rolling tract of land containing a virgin forest become the battleground here between per sons stressing ecological argu ments end those citing the con tinning demands of an urban society.

title: 18 Arrested at Church As Squatters Are Ousted
description: About 20 welfare families that moved into a Harlem church last. Wednesday after occupying an uncompleted apartment house on West 90th Street were ousted from the church yesterday after disrupt ing a communion service. Eigh teen persons were arrested on charges that included disturb ing the peace, trespassing and resisting arrest.

title: Shop Talk
description: From a distance that outsized frankfurteronalroll, the hamburgeronabun and the piece of cherry pie look good enough to eat. Up close these pop art pillows are dashing enough in their velvet or linen covers to sit in living or family room or amusing enough for children's rooms.

title: 2 U.S. Wrestlers Ousted, One Gains at Soviet Meet
description: TIFLIS, U.S.S.R., Feb. 28 (AP)Two Americans were eliminated and another ad vanced by a disqualification today in an international free style wrestling meet.

title: Advertising:
description: If you want to talk to someone in the advertising business who thinks 1971 is, going to be a banner year, talk to Richard Kelliher, president of Mutual Transit Sales.

title: PROBLEMS LOOM IN U.S. PAYMENTS
description: Major problems for the dol lar could develop in world money markets unless the United States succeeds in re ducing the deficit in its inter national balance of payments, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York warned yesterday in its annual report for 1970.the average of $1,065billion for the gross national product that the Nixon Administration has set for a target is not great, the Federal Reserve bank here believes. The bank rejects the notion of a forced draft ex pansion in the money supply designed to produce such rate of growth in the overall output of goods and services.

title: Football Players on Snowmobiles: After Spills, They Prefer Safety Blitzes
description: INCLINE VILLAGE, Nev., Feb. 28Some of the rough est players in professional football were thrown for a painful loss today when they came to grips  handlebar grips  with snowmobiles.

title: BRUINS TURN BACK MAPLE LEAFS, 43
description: BOSTON, Feb. 28 (AP)  The Boston Bruins built an early lead on goals by Eddie Westf all, Ken Hodge and Wayne Carleton in the first 8 minutes and held on today for a 43 National Hockey League victory over the To ronto Maple Leafs.

title: WAGNER LEADS MASS BY CHORAL SOCIETY
description: Bach's Mass in B minor can be an exalting experience even a terrifying one, in its tower ing concentration.

title: Condors Beat Pacers, 113.110
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28 (AP) John Brisker scored 33 points to lead the Pittsburgh Condors to a 113110 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight. It was the Condors' fifth triumph in six games.

title: Chance Likes His Chances With Mets
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28  Dean Chance, who manages a halfdozen prize fighters when not pitching for the New York Mets, cast two votes today  for Joe Frazier next Monday night and for the Met's next Octo ber.

title: Detroit Imposes a Limit On Places to Fill'er Up
description: DETROIT, Feb. 28  De troit, the child of the motor car, has committed the thankless act, sharper than a serpent's tooth. It has, in ef fect, temporarily banned the building of any new gasoline stations.

title: Kennedy, in Visit to Carolina, Cites Calhoun But NotSherman
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb.28  Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts made a speech here Wit night that in cluded 41 typewritten lines of praise tof john Calhohn, South Carolina's Most favorite son.

title: PENGUINS BEATEN
description: DETROIT, Feb. 28 (UPI) Serge Lajeunesse finally scored his first National Hockey League goal in his 45th game tonight as the Detroit Red Wings beat the slumping Pit tsburgh Penguins, 42.

title: State Transportation Unit Gets
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28  Regu lation of privately owned pub lic transportation becoines a function of the State Depart ment of Transportation tomor row.

title: UnionManagement Conference in Coal Industry Is Dissolved
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The National Coal Peaky Con ference, a unionmanagemeatt organization formed 12 years ago to protect the coal Industry, was formally broken up today.

title: Mr. Heath's Immigration Bill
description: The British Government's bill to set up additional curbs on immigrants from Commonwealth countries would carry out a specific pledge by Prime Minister Heath's Conservative party in the 1970 election cam paign.

title: Ethridge, Tully Triumph
description: Jim Ethridge of the Green wich Field Club and William Tully of the New York Athletic Club captured the Tom Byrne senior doubles invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday at the New York A.C. They defeated Ed Hahn of the New York A.C. and Cal MacCracken of the Princeton Club, 1512, 159, 159.

title: Salant, C.B.S.'s Man Behind. Selling of the Pentagon
description: The Pentagon's problems now include a Harvard honor grad uate who separated the philoso phies of the Romantic poets by analyzing their verse on the subject of the moon. He is the wiry and skinny Richard S. Sal ant president of the Columbia Broadcasting System News Di vision, who authorized the doc umetitary on The Selling of the Pentagon.

title: RANGERS CAPTURE 5TH STRAIGHT, 42
description: In a game halted 18 times be cause of holes in the ice, the Rangers lost another top de fenseman last night, but gained a victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Scribner, After 6 Months, Is Still Controversial
description: When Dr. Harvey B. Scrib ner took over six months ago today as the first Chancellor of the city's newly decen tralized school system, he found, he said later, that the betting at headquarters was that I wouldn't last 17 days.

title: Amoco Trinidad Finds Oil
description: The Amoco Trinidad Oil Company has announced what it describes as a major oil and gas discovery 22 miles off the east coast of Trinidad. It said the discovery appears to be comparable to another field off the Trinidad coast which is being developed by Amoco Trinidad.

title: CAR ACCIDENT LEADS TO MAN'S SHOOTING
description: An offduty policeman shot and killed a 32yearold Bronx auto assembler shortly before midnight Saturday following minor auto collision at Empire Boulevard and Troy Avenue in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: NEW WEEKLY BIOGRAPHICAL SERV ICE, The New York Times Biographical Edition. Profile of today's newsmakers In In a looniest edition. Write: The New York Times, Library Services, Box PP480, 220 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Texan Named to Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)  Carlos D. Conde, a Texas newsman, will become director of publications and information for the United States Commis sion on Civil Rights, Howard A. Glickstein, director of the com mission, announced today. Mr. Conde, who is 34 years old, will be the highestranking MexicanAmerican in the civil rights agency.

title: Neediest Cases Drive Finishes With $1,055,877.91, a Record
description: The 59th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended yesterday with contributions totaling $1, $55,877.91, a record, from 14, 988 donors. The amount is nearly $69,000 above the pre vious high of the 57th appeal and more than $102,000 above the amount received last year.

title: Deputy Sheriff Slain in Jail
description: WACO, Tex., Feb. 28 (AP) A sheriff's deputy was shot to death today when several pris oners attempted unsuccessfully to escape from the McLennan County jail. The victim was Bobby Mayo, 39 years old, chief jailer, who had rushed to the aid of another jailer jumped by the wouldbe oscapers.

title: Knicks, Paced by Frazier, Conquer Bullets, 110104
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 28  In a game that Walt Frazier termed lust like the play offs, the Knicks took another impressive step toward clinch ing the Atlantic Division cham pionship of the National Bas ketball Association today by striding away from the Balti more Bullets in the final three minutes for a 110104 victory at Civic Center.

title: Colonels Defeat Cougars
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 28 (UPI)  The Kentucky Colonels scored 14 straight points early in the second half to build a 19 point lead, then held off the Carolina Cougars in the final minutes for 122113 victory to day.

title: Bryan Resigns F.C.C. Post
description: Ashbrook P. Bryan, chief of the office of network study of the Federal Communications Commission, said yesterday he was resigning his post to be come a hearing examiner for the Maritime Commission in Washington on March 15. He had been the chief architect of the long and controversial ef fort to force the television net works to surrender a portion of prime evening time to give independent producers access to the home screen. A cutback in network control of prime hours becomes effective Oct. 1.

title: U.S. Terms Adviser's Call For Nuclear Ban Not Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (Reuters)  United States offi cials said today that William C. Foster, a member of, a presi dential advisory panel on dis armament, expressed personal views and not the Government's in advocating a ban on under ground nuclear weapons tests without onsite inspections.

title: COOPER BOWS HERE WITH FRENCH HORN
description: No instrument is more fiend ishly precarious than the French horn, which probably is why French horn recitals are so rare. One took place at Carnegie Re cital Hall Friday night, serving as the New York debut of Clarence Cooper. Mr. Cooper is associate principal horn player of the Denver Symphony and teaches at Metropolitan State College in that city.

title: Catholic Schools Today: Challenged and Changing
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28  Every morning when there is school, John Miller and his sis ter Alicia trudge uphill for two icy miles to the nearest Roman Catholic high school. There used to be a school right in the neighborhood, but the dio cese closed it down.

title: RAILROADS PRESS CONTRACT TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The railroads and the United Trans portation Union pressed nego tiations into the night as Secre tary of Labor James, D. son expressed the opinion that there was no immediate strike threat.

title: Young Wife Fulfills Herself as a Robber:Barbara Loden's Film Opens at Cinema II ' Wanda' Improves With Its Turn to Action
description: Barbara Loden's Wanda is a passive, rather stupid young woman from the Pennsylvania coal country who one day leaves her husband and her children, and wanders off into a series of minor misfortunes until, by curious accident, she finds herself the accomplice of a small-time thief who aspires to rob a bank. With the thief, a middle-aged aspirin freak and a most uncivil man, she achieves a kind of hopeful, noncommunicative rapport. And in the climatic bank attempt, a superb sequence, she displays a degree of mere competence that must count for the high point in a life almost wholly given over to lows.I think it worth remembering that "Wanda," which opened yesterday at Cinema II, is a crime melodrama, and not simply a study of its protagonist. It is to the acceptance of the demands and the freedoms of such melodrama that it owes the best of its many virtues."Wanda" must rank as that cinematic rarity, a movie that really does get bettermuch betteras it goes along. Once it finds its action, which takes a while, it seems willing to subordinate character to action. Such subordination suggests a classic arrangement of dramtic priorities. And Miss Loden's film, by the time you are through with it, has, rather surprisingly, some of the look of classical moviemaking.Surprisingly, because "Wanda" has on the surface all the earmarks of a certain depressed, modish naturalism that with many lesser filmmakers is supposed to stand for truth and invariably takes the place of beauty. The eroded, semi-industrial landscape, the grainy blown-up 16mm print that makes everything look just a bit worse than it is, the mostly nonprofessional cast that specializes in lacunae in the dialogueall seem pretty familiar. That is, until things begin to move, which is just about when Wanda meets her Mr. Dennis. He happens to be burglarizing a bar, when she drops by to use the John and cadge a free beer. Then the film begins to look tight and tough and very economical.The film's technique (handheld camera; sharp cuts with no fades or dissolves) then appears necessary and exciting. And the performances begin to seem necessary too. All the non-actors in the early part of "Wanda" greatly embarrass Miss Loden, who is at pains never to steal a scene from them. But with the excellent Michael Higgins, who, with glasses and steel-gray hair, looks like certain late photographs of James Joyce, and who is highly professional, enough changes so that she has her role as well as her reticence, and she becomes freer, more varied, more interesting to watch.As the credits indicate, "Wanda" is very much Miss Loden's work. It would be hard to imagine better or more tactful or more decently difficult work for a first film. I suppose it is significantly a woman's film in that it never sensationalizes or patronizes its heroine, and yet finds her interesting and not (as it might have) just interestingly dull.But I like it best because it seems at home with its idioms, close to its action, opening up only rarely (during a model airplane meet, in the fatal bank job) and to moments of genuine insight and not admiration-begging cinematic claptrap. Wanda is a small movie, fully aware of its limits, and within those limits lovely.

title: Board of Education Meets On Financial Crisis Today
description: The Board of Education will meet today to decide its next move in the budget crisis that is threatening a $40million re duction in teaching services and school programs.

title: Capitol Rich in History Where Bomb Exploded
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 Within yards of where a bomb exploded early today, British soldiers swarmed up a narrow stairway and set fire to the Capitol in 1814.

title: BOND PRICES SLIP; TRADING DRIES UP
description: The bond markets, which had hoped to move this week's rec ord volume of new corporate issues with a certain amount of dispatch, ran into heavy going yesterday.

title: QUESTION RAISED ON CASEY'S FIRM
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The Securities and Exchange Commission has forwarded to Congress the details of a case in which William J. Casey's law firm may have helped a client illegally withhold information from the public. But Mr. Casey himself, so far as has pres ently been ascertained, was apparently not directly in volved, the S.E.C. said.

title: Malaysia Is About to Amend Constitution to Declare Discussion of Racial Issues a Crime
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 1  The Government of this eightyearold nation is on the verge of amending its Con stitution to make it a crime to talk about racial issues.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Loews Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Herbert A. Hofmann as presi dent of Loews Hotels and Bernard Myerson as pres ident of Loews Theatres, two of its divisions. The appointments to the newly created positions are effective immediately. Mr. Hofmann, who joined the company in 1951, has been senior vice president in charge of the Loews Hotels division, which oper ates 15 major hotels in the United States, the Baha mas and England. Mr. Myerson, who joined the company in 1963, has been executive vice presi dent in charge of Loews Theatres, which operates 114 motion picture theaters across the country.

title: West Berlin Court Begins Trial of 3 Radical Leftists
description: BERLIN, March 1  Three radicals went on trial here to day, amid extreme security pre cautions, charged with a num ber of criminal acts.

title: States Press to Regulate Snowmobiles
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 28 With more than 1.5 million snowmobiles churning about this year in the nation's snow belt states, new efforts are being made to control their use, limit their noise, and educate their drivers on how not to kill themselves.

title: HIGH COURT RULING FAVORS HAYWOOD
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas cleared the way today for Spencer Hay wood to finish the season with the Seattle SuperSonics of the National Basketball Association.

title: Pennsylvania Halts Paying On Bills in Financial Crisis
description: HARRISBURG, March 1 (AP)  Pennsylvania halted pay ments today to private con cerns providing vital services, and a financial crisis  with political, strings attached  threatened to make Thursday a payless payday for 70,000 state employes.

title: Times Man Named Photographer of 70 By a Press Group
description: Barton Silverman of The New York Times has been named 1970 Photographer of the Year by the New York Press Photog raphers Association, which an nounced the winners in its 35th annual competition yesterday.

title: Tighter Curbs oh Lobbyists Are Urged by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Tighter controls on the ac tivities and spending of lob byists were proposed today in legislation backed by the House Ethics Committee.

title: Pope Sets Up a Peace Study
description: ROME, March 1 (AP)Pope Paul VI has set up a committee to study peace problems, the Vatican announced today.

title: The First Black Dealer In New Cars Is Closing
description: DETROIT March 1The nationt's first black new car dealer is going out of busi ness.

title: Egypt Appeals to Big 4
description: CAIRO, March 1  Amid an emerging sense of gloom over the stalled efforts for an Arab Israeli settlement which seemed to be flourishing until a week ago, the United Arab Republic appealed today to the Big Four to save the situation before the expiration of the Suez Canal ceasefire.

title: Where Capitol Bomb Exploded and Damaged Rooms
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The bomb that exploded in the Capitol building early to day was placed in a lavatory on the building's ground floor, indicated by a cross on the diagram above.

title: Barasch Gets Westbury Post
description: WESTBURY, L.I.,Lew Ba rasch, a promoter at Roosevelt Raceway for the last 25 years, has been named public rela tions director for the harness racing track.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times
description: VANDENBERG. By Oliver Lange. 332 pages. Stein and Day $6.95.

title: RUSSIANS VANDALIZE U.S. NEWSMEN'S CARS
description: MOSCOW, March 1  The cars of two American news men were vandalized today in apparent retaliation for dam age done to vehicles belonging to Soviet diplomats in Wash ington.

title: World Trade Grew in '70
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  World trade showed another large increase by value in 1970, but higher prices accounted for an unusually large portion of the increase, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Many people have been surprised by the dis closures in Senator Ervin's subcommit tee of all the institutionalized snooping that goes on every day all around us Nobody in our neighborhood is among the surprisees, however. In our neigh borhoodadmittedly, this is Washing tonalmost everybody is in the snoop ing business, or the gumshoe game, as we call it when we all get together on a bugged wire for a beer after a hard day's eavesdropping.

title: Ira Kapenstein, Democratic Aide, Dead
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 Ira Kapenstein, deputy chair man of the Democratic Nation al Committee, a former Gov ernment official and newspaper man, died of cancer today in George Washington University Hospital. He was admitted last week with what was described initially as a virus infection. He was 35 years old.

title: Hester Warns Teamster Strike Could Close N.Y.U. Downtown
description: A warning that the Washing ton Square campus of New York University might have to be closed within the next few days if the weather turns cold and striking members of Team ster Local 810 continue to pre vent fuel oil deliveries was is sued yesterday by James H. Hester, president of the school.

title: A Videotape Is Used to Present Evidence in Criminal Case Here
description: A videotape film purportedly showing a defendant trying to sell forged checks and stolen stock certificates was shown before a Supreme Court Jus tice yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mitchell Named to Pilot Boston U. in Basketball
description: College Sports Notes

title: HEAD START AIDE ARRESTED HERE
description: The administrator of the Coney Island Held Start ofice was arrested yesterday on charges of illegally receiving welfare payments while collect ing $10,800 a year for work in the preschoolchildren's pro gram.

title: G.I.'s Deny Blast Charge
description: MADISON, Wis., March 1 (AP)  Three soldiers charged in connection wtih a series of explosions last July at Camp McCoy, Wis., entered pleas of not guilty today before Judge James Doyle of U. S. District Court. The G.I.'s are Stephen G. Geden of Milton, Mass. Dannie E. Kreps of. Inglewood, Calif., and Thomas M. Chase of Glen Rock, N. J.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Eddie Brannick first got the job, he was the envy of every kid in New York. Life was far more simple in our village in those days because this was back near the turn of the century. Existence was so parochial that few cared what happened in the rest of the world. The biggest news each day, so proclaimed in eightcolumn, frontpage headlines in the late edition of every afternoon newspaper, was how the New York Giants fared in their baseball game.

title: EDIE SEES 3% RISE FOR 1971 OUTLAYS
description: Business spending for new plant and equipment will rise a scant 3 per cent this, year to $83billion from $80.6billion in 1970, Lionel D. Edie & Co., Inc., predicted yesterday.

title: To End the School Strife
description: Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner and the school system's administrators are facing each other with an increasing hostility that interferes with both the routine manage ment of the schools and the urgent process of reform. Both sides have contributed to the conflict. It is time to put an end to it by dealing rationally with the facts behind it.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PARIS, March 1 (AP)  Gasoline prices rose nearly a cent, for regular and about a Cent and a half for premium today because of the agreement last month in Iran by Western oil companies to pay Persian Gulf producers higher prices. A gallon of gasoline in France now costs 79 cents for regular and 86 cents for premium.

title: Seton Hall Beats L.I.U.
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., March 1Ken House and Rog Kindel paced Seton Hall to a 9475 vic tory over Long Island Univer sity tonight, the Pirates' 10th against 15 losses.

title: Goldwater and Buckley Due at Conservative Fete
description: Senator Barry M. Goldwater of Arizona, the 1964 Republi can candidate for President, and Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, will head the speakers at the Conservative party's vic tory banquet tomorrow night at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Japan's Student Army Disbands
description: TOKYO, March 1  The Shield Society, the private army of university students formed by the author Yukio Mishima, has announced its dis solution, three months after its founder's spectacular ritual suicide.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CLAYTON RAWSON, MYSTERY WRITER
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., March 1  Clayton Rawson, mystery story writer, editor, and magician under the stage name of The Great Merlini, died today in United Hospital, Port Chester. He was 64 years old and lived at 219 North Barry Avenue.

title: Park Ave. Malls Losing Fences In City Beautification Program
description: The city has started pulling down the iron fences around the center islands on Park Avenue from 46th to 96th Street in a facelifting operation to be completed by midsummer.

title: Zindel's Miss Reardon Had Lengthy Evolution
description: Paul Zindel's new play, And Miss Reardon Drinks a Little, is about three school teaching sisters who are locked in the suffocating em brace of their family. Anna (Julie Harris), the youngest, is on the brink of insanity. Catherine (Estelle Parsons), the middle one, is an ob scene nasty witness to her mother's death and her sis ter's madness. Ceil (Nancy Marchand), the oldest, has survived by cutting herself loose.

title: Congo Protestants Seek Own Style of Unity
description: KINSHASA, the CongoCon golese Protestants, still sharply divided by ecclesiastical differ ences inherited from European missionaries, are seeking unity on the basis of a strictly Afri can brand of ecumenism.

title: Atlanta Airport Renamed
description: ATLANTA, March 1 (UPI) Atlanta Airport was renamed William B. Hartsfield Airport today in memory of the Mayor who helped found the field. The Atlanta Board of Aldermen unanimously agreed to rename the airport in memory of Mr. Hartsfield, who died last week. He was Mayor from 1939 to 1961.

title: Mercer Plans to Stress Base Hits Over Homers
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1 Two Oklahomans, Mickey Mantle and Bobby Murcer, showed up in the New York Yankee training camp today, and with Fritz Peterson and Whitey Ford already on the premises, the conversational pace picked up.

title: MAYOR SIGNS BILL FOR 50% CAB RISE, BEGINNING TODAY
description: A bill raising taxicab fare rates by about 50 per cent was signed into law yesterday by Mayor Lindsay. The new rates go into effect at 6 A.M. today.

title: International Utilities Corp.
description: TORONTO, March 1 (Cana dian Press)The International Utilities Corporation reported yesterday that its 1970 net in come rose to $33,475,000, or $2.42 a share, from $33,070, 000, or $2.61 a share, a year ago.

title: AMEX PRICES GAIN AS VOLUME WANES
description: The American Stock Ex change ended slightly higher yesterday in comparatively light trading.

title: Hofstra Takes Finale
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 1 Hofstra ended its basketball season tonight with a 7356 victory over Adeiphi. Rich Link led the winners with 18 points. Hofstra won 18 of 26 games, including the last five.

title: A BOMB DAMAGES THE NEW SCHOOL
description: A 12inch pipebomb exploded outside the New School for Social Research early yester day morning, shattering win dows and rousing nearby resi dents. No one was injured.

title: BRITISH REAFFIRM PERSIAN GULF PLAN
description: LONDON, March 1The Con servative Government, revers ing its position, today adopted its predecessors' plan to end Britain's historic role in the Persian Gulf area this year.

title: Notre Dame Official Asks Incorporation Of Women's College
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 1 The Rev. James T. Burtch aell, University of Notre Dame provost, has proposed the com plete incorporation of St. Mary's College, an allgirl school, into the University of Notre Dame.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTROL DATA FACES I.B.M. COUNTERCLAIM
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yes terday that it had filed a coun terclaim against the Control Data Corporation and its sub sidiary, the Commercial Credit Company, alleging violations of the antitrust laws.

title: American Airlines Is Replacing Some Seats on 747 With a Bar
description: American Airlines, which, like most airlines, has com plained of a shortage of passen gers lately because of the nations sluggish economy, said yesterday that it was taking 40 of the seats out of its Boeing 747 jumbo jets.

title: LEADER OF IRELAND CONDEMNS VIOLENCE
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 1 (AP)The Prime Min ister of the Irish Republic and a Roman Catholic bishop today condemned the wave of guer rilla violence here.

title: RIOTS IN L'AQUILA ENTER FOURTH DAY
description: ROME, March 1The police today moved armored vehicles, including half a dozen person nel carriers, into L'Aquila, a mountain city 50 miles north east of here, where rioting con tinued for the fourth consecu tive day.

title: Stage: Long Wharf Takes Wry Looks at Marriage
description: NEW HAVENThe Long Wharf Theater goes from strength to strength. This season, alone it has given us a fine production of a Maxim Gorky classic, the American premiere of Marguerite Du ras's House Without Doors, and now a new doublebill by Robert Anderson, Solitaire Double Solitaire.

title: BUCKS ROUT 76ERS FOR 16TH IN A ROW
description: MILWAUKEE, March 1 (UPI)  Lew Alcindor and Oscar Robertson each scored 29 points tonight to lead the Mil waukee Bucks to a 127103 National Basketball Association victory over the Philadelphia 76ers and their 16th straight. The Bucks were now two games short of the league rec ord for consecutive victories set last year by the New York Knicks.

title: Boorish Rebuff to Chile
description: In his State of the World address, President Nixon said it would be his policy to keep open the lines of commu nication with the Marxist Government of Chile. We will not be the ones to upset traditional relations, he said We are prepared to have the kind of relationship With the Chilean Government that it is prepared to have with us.

title: NIXON SHIFTS PLAN ON TEACHER CORPS
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 After extended Interpol debate, the Administration has decided not to include the Teacher Corp in its initial proposal for a new merged volunteer serv ice agency, knowledgeable of ficials disclosed today.

title: West German Scientists in Israel Working Hard and Harmoniously
description: REHOVOT, IsraelMy wife and I understood that prejudice against us would exist, Said Dr. Fritz Nader of Heidelberg University, a 30yearold West German chemist, recalling his doubts about working in Israel. But we were afraid about the childrenthat they might not understand.

title: Advertising:
description: The OffTrack flatting Cor Poration has chosen the ad vertising and public relations people it will WM to reach the black and Spanishspeek ing markets.

title: U.S. Bids Soviet Resolve Issue of Berlin Access
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 United States officials urged the Soviet Union today to help resolve the deadlocked Issue of access between West Germany and West Berlin.

title: A Record for the Neediest
description: Economic recession, coupled with inflation, has made this a particularly difficult winter; and yet donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have set a record for the fifty years of this annual appeal. Readers have given the extraordinary total of $1,055,877,91.This is the first year the total has surpassed one million dollars.

title: Boston U. Is Seeded No. 1 For E.C.A.C. Title Hockey
description: Boston University has been seeded No. 1 and Clarkson College No. 2 for the quarter finals of the 10th annual East ern College Athletic Conference hockey championships opening next Tuesday, The Associated Press announced yesterday.

title: TV: Of War and Hostages but Lacking Persuasion
description: Creative figures in the per forming arts  dramatists, lyricists, composersdeserve the minimum amenity. Some of their contributions, writ ten while either too young or too old while caught in middle age trauma  warrant the kindness of going unremem bered, small slips gently Con signed to the darkness of hu man frailty.

title: DEFICIT EXPECTED IN HOSPITAL FUNDS
