description: Controller Abraham D. Beame predicted yesterday that the new Health and Hospitals Cor poration would exhaust its funds long before the end of its first fiscal year on July 1.

title: Democratic Senator's Plan Defines WarMaking Power
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Senator Thomas Eagleton in troduced a resolution today de signed to define Congressional and Presidential war  making powers.

title: East Pakistanis Demonstrate
description: DACCA, East Pakistan, March 1 Demonstrators demanding independence for East Pakistan rampaged through the streets today to protest the announce ment that the meeting of the National Assembly had been postponed.

title: Penn Central Asks For Higher Fares On 2 of Its Lines
description: The Penn Central applied for fare increases on its Harlem and Hudson lines yesterday, the first day that regulation of fares was shifted from the Pub lic Service Commission to the state transportation depart ment.

title: A Poet's Wilderness
description: In 1914, when he was a young reporter on The Times, Joyce Kilmer published a volume of verse, Trees and Other Poems. Its title poem has become a popular classic. Four years later, Kilmer was killed on a battle field in France.

title: Injuries to Defensemen Again Worry Rangers
description: About Pro Hockey

title: Environmental Chief Asks Building of 2 Model SST's
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  The Nixon Administration's chief environmental officer said today that concern about pol lution from a large fleet of supersonic transports could and should be divorced from the immediate question of develop ing two SST test models.

title: Essex Urges Court To Open Way to Jail 3 Newark Teachers
description: NEWARK, March 1The Es sex County Prosecutor's Office moved today to have three of ficials of the Newark Teachers Union begin serving a six month jail sentence that was stayed last week on condition that they ask their membership to end their monthlong strike.

title: NO YACHTS START RACE TO NASSAU
description: MIAMI, March 1One hun dred yachts sailed for daylight today as, the 176mile race from Miami to Nassau began under the darkness of a squall off Miami Beach.

title: RAY AUSTRIAN, RAN PICTURE DECORATOR
description: Ray Austrian, founder and president of The Picture Deco rator, Inc., 740 Madison Ave nue, and a former advertising man, died here Sunday, ap parently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived at 177 East 75th Street.

title: When a Poet Is in Charge of a Day Care Center
description: It is 8:30 on a rainy Monday morning, and in the face of the poet, who is tall and broadshouldered and wears a blue knit sailor'S cap pulled jauntily forward above thinrimmed tortoise shell glasses, there is vitality and light: something both sacerdotal and seafaring.

title: LAVER CONQUERS ROCHE BY 63, 75
description: LONDON, March 1 (AP) Rod Laver beat Tony Roche, 6.3, 75, and Yugoslavia's Nikki Pilic ousted Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., 46, 63, 64, in the semifinals of the $30,000 Rothman's international indoor tennis tournament tonight. The first prize is $7,800.

title: U.S. Rebuffs Soviet on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The United States today re buffed a Soviet effort for imme diate Big Four action to bring pressure on Israel to negotiate concessions, and it urged Mos cow to stop what it called propaganda exchanges on the Middle East.

title: A RULING IS UPHELD ON DUMPING RULE
description: The J. C. Penney Company's campaign against secrecy in the Treasury Departatent's adminis trative handling of the Anti dumping Act of 1921 suffered a setback yesterday.

title: A Sad Day for English Justice
description: LONDONWhen Reginald Maudling was appointed Home Secretary in the incoming Conservative Government last June, the liberal sigh of relief was almost deafening. He had a reputation as the most moderate and civiliied of Edward Heath's leading colleagues. The individual outlook of a Home Secretary can shape or reshape the outlook of his departments. And the country had been promised, or threat ened with, a complete overhaul of the law governing immigrants and aliens.

title: OIL NEGOTIATIONS ARE BEGUN IN LIBYA
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, March 1 (AP) Western oil companies and the Libyan Government began negotiations today on Libyan demands for sharply increased oil revenues.

title: Mrs. Ruth M. Thompson, An Early WAC Officer, 57
description: Mrs. Ruth Morton Thomp son, a member of the first of ficer class of the Women's Army Corps, died Sunday in the Veterans Administration Hospital, atfer a long illness. She was 57 years old and lived at 10 East End Avenue.

title: Tokyo and Peking Renew Trade Accord for a Year
description: TOKYO, March 1 (Reuters) Japan and Communist China today renewed a trade agree ment for another year, the Kyodo News Agency reported.

title: 4,400 G.I.'s Withdrawn From Vietnam in Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 1 (AP) The United States command said today that American troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 4,400 men last week and also an nounced the phasing out of 16 more Army units that will reduce the strength by an additional 3,280 men.

title: N.C.A.A. PAIRINGS CONCERN PHELPS
description: At the FordhamMarquette game last week, a local coach pointed out: That Digger Phelps is involved with the two but college teams in the East. He coaches Fordham and be fore that he helped recruit and coach Penn into the power house it is.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION UP 2.1% LAST WEEK
description: Steel production rose by 2.1 per cent last week, compared with output the week before. Partly because of hedgebuying against the possibility of a steel strike next summer, pro duction has advanced in eight of the last nine weeks.

title: Burlington Northern Unit
description: ST PAUL, Minn., March 1 (UPI)  Burlington Northern, Inc., said today it would begin construction this spring of a 250acre, computer controlled freight car classification yard in northern Minneapolis at a cost of over $30million. Plan ning of the yard, which will be the company's largest mar shaling yard, has been under way since the merger that created Burlington Northern, last March.

title: POLES PLAN A LAW AGAINST PARASITES
description: WARSAW, March 1 Poland's leadership Is prepar ing a law against social par asites, meaning persons who have no visible means of sup port.

title: Denies CoverUp Charge
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)  Cal. Oran K. Hender son denied today that he had deliberately tried to cover up the Mylai incident, as the Army has charged. In a statement is sued by his lawyer, he said obstructionist tactics by some Army officers had hurt his ability to defend himself during pretrial investigations.

title: BELLE RICHARDSON, FORMERLY OF TIMES
description: TENAFLY, N.J., March, 1 Mrs. Belle Sloane Richardson of 1 Byrne Lane, wife of Cecil H. Richardson, formerly makeup editor for The New York Tithes, and herself a for mer executive secretary to all managing editors of the news paper from Carr C. Van Anda to Turner Catledge, died today in Riverdell Hospital, Oradell, after a heart attack. She was 65 years old.

title: Marks Set by New York Life
description: The New York Life Insurance Companythe fourth largest insurer in the country  dis closed yesterday that the bank ruptcy of the Penn Central Transportation Company re sulted in an unrealized loss for the giant insurer of more than $20million on that transaction.

title: A Summary of Actions Taken Yesterday by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Advertising
description: Faced with a loss of earn ings in December, 1989, the Anierican Can Company scrapped its corporate ad vertising program And with it, naturally, went the job title, director of corporate advertising and services, and the man who held, it.

title: STOCKS RISE A MT AS TRADING FALLS
description: The stock market scored a small gain yesterday, just about recovering the loss registered on Friday.

title: NOTRE DAME TOPS DAYTON, 83 TO 82
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 1 (UPI)  Dayton missed three fieldgoal attempts in the last 11 seconds tonight, enabling Notre Dame to post an 8382 basketball victory.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Oslo Government to Issue Statement Today on Crisis
description: OSLO, Norway, March, 1 (Reuters)Norway's coalition Government said tonight it would make a statement tomor row in the Storting, or parlia ment, about a political crisis that seems almost certain to result in the resignation of Pre mier Per Borten.

title: THURMOND CLARKE, A RETIRED JUDGE, 68
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1 (AP)  Thurmond Clarke, who retired Sept. 1 as chief United States district judge for the Central California district, died yesterday at the age of 68.

title: KILLING OF WITNESS DELAYS THEFT TRIAL
description: A 23year old man slain in Queens Saturday night was to have testified as a prosecu tion witness in a post office burglary case scheduled for trial yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn.

title: Mets Planning to Stress. More Hits Over Pitching
description: ST. PETETISBURGH, Fla., March 1Nobody knows ex actly when the New York Mets switched, but late in the nineteensixties they started to search for hitters to help their young pitchers. Now they have half a dozen homegrown swingers in training who represent the chief change from the team's past and the chief hope for its future.

title: Phone Rate Hearings To Start on March 16
description: ALBANY, March 1  The State Public Service Commis sion ordered hearings to be gin here on March 16 on the New York Telephone Com pany's request for a 29.1 per cent rate increase, which would produde $391million annually, in additional reve nue.

title: Liccioni and Carol Neblett Sing In City Opera's New Louise
description: Charpentier's Louise is a mixture of sadness, comedy and sociology (if you can ap ply that last term to a con flict based on the ways of life of the workingman and the artist). And of course, it is a love story.

title: Sammy Price Plays the Blues, Recalling BoogieWoogie Era
description: Sammy Price, who played piano at Barney Josephson's famous Greenwich Village nightclub, Cafe Society, in the nineteenforties, has joined Mary Lou Williams, another graduate of Cafe Society, in providing music, at Mr. Jo sephson's current restaurant, the Cookery, University Place at Eighth Street.

title: FAIRLEIGH DOWNS DARTMOUTH, 5348
description: Fairleigh Dickinson made its debut in Madison Square Garden a success last night by defeating Dartmouth, 53 48, before a sparse crowd of 4,198.

title: SAIGON RESERVES MOVE WESTWARD TO LAOS BORDER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 2South Viet namese troop reinforcements, assembled in the northeastern corner of South Vietnam, were moving westWard to the Lao tian border yesterday.

title: MILLS BILL UNITES 2 WELFARE IDEAS
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  A welfare bill that would cou ple the concept of President Nixon's family assistance plan with a first step toward Fed eral assumption of the states welfare costs is taking shape in the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Shoreline Bill Offered
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)Legislation aimed at pro tecting the nation's shorelines from erosion was introduced by 21 members of the Senate to day. The bill would authorize up to $6million over five years for the Army, Corps of Engi neers to develop, test, operate and evaluate new erosion con trol methods.

title: Market Place: Turning Around National Screw
description: When Monogram Industries acquired National Screw of Cleveland three years ago, Martin Stone, Monogram's chairman, said he was confi dent about turning that com pany around.

title: For Exotic Filipino Foods, 9th Ave. Is the Place
description: Ninth has always been an avenue of many nations with food shops representing Italy, Greece, France and Spain stretched out from 34th to 57th Street.

title: STORM KING PLAN ASSAILED BY CITY
description: New York City told the Federal Court of Appeals here yesterday that it had mis takenly believed the Cornwall, N.Y., pumpedstorage hydro electric project would reduce air poliution here.

title: From a Bronx Copter Pilot's Diary: Laos Is Far Worse Than Cambodia
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 1Clarence J. Romero Jr. of the Bronx, a 20year old warrant officer, has the most dangerous job in the air war over Laos. He pilots a tiny light observation heli copter (L.O.H.) at treetop level, waiting to draw fire.

title: FLAMINGO STAKES DRAWS FIELD OF 11
description: MIAMI, March 1 (UPI)  Eleven 3yearolds, headed by His Majesty and Jim French, were entered today for the 40th running of the Flamingo Stakes Wednesday at Hialeah Park. It is the first $100,000 added race of the year for Triple Crown hopefuls.

title: Bulls Extend Streak to 7
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M., March 1 (AP)The Chicago Bulls won their seventh game in a row, tonight overcoming a shakey first quarter and defeating the Cincinnati Royals, 9894.

title: SILVER FUTURES SHOW PRICE RISE
description: Silver traders, who have suf fered the doldrums of low prices for quite a white found something cheering yesterday. The price of the May de livery broke through an im portant chart point on the up side of $1.63, which en couraged some additional buy ing. It closed at $1.64 2/10 an ounce after being half a cent higher during the session.

title: A Mother's. Rights to Child Challenged
description: ALBANY, March 1  The State Court of Appeals was asked today to order a rehear ing a 9monthold girl who has been ordered returned to her natural mother.

title: City Directs Mediators to Help Resolve Union Pay Parity Issue
description: Arvid Anderson, impartial chairman of the city's Office of Collective Bargaining, said yesterday that he had directed the three mediators in the uni formed services' contract dis putes to begin efforts immedi ately to resolve the issue of pay parity for the city's patrol men.

title: GEORGE SPATTA 78 MACHINERY MAKER
description: George Spatta, president from 1945 to 1963 and chair man until 1968 of the Clark Equipment Company, Buchanan, Mich. died Sunday at his home in Chicago. He was 78 years old.

title: Bomb in Capitol Causes Wide Damage
description: WASHINGTON, Match 1A bomb, apparently planted by a group or person protesting against the Vietnam war, ex ploded early this morning in the Senate wing of the Capitol, causing extensive damage but no injuries.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON DECLINE SHARPLY
description: The London Stock Exchange dropped sharply yesterday. Dealers reported a flow of selling but almost no buying.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Icebreaker Frees Herself
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The Coast Guard icebreaker Staten Island is proceeding to ward Australia under her own power after striking an un charted pinnacle off the Mac Robertson coast of Antarctica, the Navy reported today. The Staten Island was heading for Australia's Mawson Statio when she went aground.

title: CITY SELLS LAND TO FREEPORT, L.I.
description: FREEPORT, L.I., March 1 About 30 acres of land owned by New York City in this South Shore village was acquired by the village today for $1.3mil lion.

title: Pothole Superintendent
description: Exactly fourteen months ago a City Hall spokesman conceded that, as a result of unusual weather condi tions, the pothole situation had become critical. Now, after a new round of announcements about the annually unusual weather, a state of crisis has again been admitted to exist.

title: Young Germans Feel Less Guilt on Jews
description: BONN, March 1In a parlor game of Middle East and brink manship politics being played out by students here, realism and naturalness toward Israel have been displayed, suggesting that young West Germans are losing their guilt feelings to ward Jews and, therefore, the sympathy that has kept Bonn's special relationship with Is rael alive.

title: Million Strike in Britain To Protest UnionCurb Bill
description: LONDON, March 1  More than a million industrial work ers stayed off their jobs today in a political strike.

title: Orantes Wins at Hampton
description: HAMPTON, Va., March 1 (AP)  Eighthseeded Manuel Orantes of Spain easily de feated Gerald Battrick of Bri tain, 63, 63; in the first round of the United States indoor ten nis tournament tonight: The tournament differs from the United States indoor open held at Salisbury, Md., recently.

title: Apollo 14 Astronauts Defend Value of Manned Space Program
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The Apollo 14 astronauts react ed strongly today to suggestions that the manned space pro gram be cut back and that men be replaced by machines in future explorations of the solar system.

title: The Pilot's Mother Expects Him Home
description: Warrant Officer Romero's mother, Mrs. Lydia Bloom, of 1710 Seward Avenue, the Bronx, said last night she was unaware that her son had been keeping a diary, but not surprised. He's always been explicit about the things he believed in, she said, add ing:

title: Queens Board Shouted Down In Dispute on Shimer School
description: A meeting of the District 28 School Board in Queens broke up in pandemonium last night when members of the audience shouted down board members.

title: Mrs. Nixon Hope to Better Quality of Life the World
description: DESMOINES, Iowa, March 1 (UPI)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said, today that she hoped to make a determined effort to improve the quality of life in the United States and the world while she was First Lady.

title: U.S. Officials Seeking Ways to Keep Government Buildings Open While Protected
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  In the aftermath of the bomb explosion in the Capitol early this morning, Congressmen and Federal officials began to strug gle today with the dilemma of protecing Government build ings without limiting public access to them.

title: J. C. Penney's Etate Is Estimated at $35Million
description: James Cash Penney, founder of the J. C. Penney Department store chain, left an estate worth about $35million it was dis closed yesterday, with the filing of his will in probate at Sur rogate Court.

title: Marquette Wins No. 36
description: OMAHA, Neb., March 1 (UPI)  Unbeaten Marquette had anxious moments against Creighton University tonight but came from behind several times and won, 6661. It was the 24th victory this season for the Warriors and 36 without a loss over two seasons.

title: Building Contracts In January Showed Decrease in Value
description: The total value of con struction contracts awarded throughout the country last January, nearly $4.5billion, was 9 per cent below the contract value in January, 1970, and was 11 per cent below the figure for last De cember, the F. W. Dodge di vision of the McGrawHill Information Systems Com pany reported yesterday.

title: Marijuana Seized, 4 Jailed
description: BEAUFORT, S. C. March 1 (UPI) The authorities seized nearly $1.2million worth of marijuana today after a routine search of two vehicles stopped for a minor traffic offense. Ar rested and held on $20,000 bond each were Peter Reccardi, 19 years old, David P. Rubin, 28, Leon Tabory, 45, and Frederick S. Sobel, 20. They were believed to be from New York and Cali fornia.

title: HAEFLIGER SINGS SCHUMANN SONGS
description: If art is nothing but artifice that has died and gone to heavenarid you'll find more Meaningless definitions in al most any book on esthetics then the lieder recital at its best should be one of music's sublimest experiences. When the singer is a fabulous artificer such as Ernst Haefliger, the Swiss tenor, and his program is pure Schumann, the odds against being disappointed mount rather fast.

title: City Accuses 18 Officers Of Queens Jail Brutality
description: The city's Corporation Coun sel recommended yesterday that 18 employes of the Department of Correction, including an as sistant warden, be charged with using excessive force in evacu ating inmates last Oct. 5 from the Queens House of Detention after rioting there had ended.

title: UMass Clinches Title
description: DURHAM, N. H., March 1 (AP)Massachusetts survived a scare and clinched the Yankee Conference championship to night with a 6360 victory over New Hampshire.

title: MacLeish, at 78, Talks of New Play
description: The elderly whitehaired man, looking more like a re tired banker or State De partment official than a three time Pulitzer Prizewinner, was holding up remarkably well under the hot lights of his third television interview as he leaned forward to catch the reporter's question.

title: Brazil Storm Toll Is 130
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 1 Reports from the neighboring state of Rio de Janeiro today raised the total number of deaths in torrential rains over the weekend to more than 130. Four hundred were reported missing.

title: Big Note Issue Set By Bank of America
description: The Bank of America, the na tion's largest bank, announced yesterday plans to sell a $100 million issue of seven and one half year capital notes.

title: Japanese Plan on Textiles Criticized by Hollings
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)  Senator Ernest F. Hollings, an avowed protection ist, said today that the reported plan by Japan to impose self restraints on textile exports to the United States without establishing specific categories of items for control won't do the job.

title: HumanWave Tactics Noted
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 1 (Reuters)The deputy commander of United States forces in Vietnam said today that the North Vietnamese, using humanwave tactics in Laos, had forced South Vietnamese troops into the heaviest fighting of the Indochina war.

title: MOHAWK LINE GAINS EXTENSION ON DEBT
description: Mohawk Airlines, Inc., an nounced yesterday that it had received from its senior lenders an extension until March 15 for payment of about $2.7mil lion on its senior notes to banks and a manufacturer that were originally due Jan. 1.

title: I.O.S. Said to Name Vesco as Chairman
description: GENEVA, March 1Robert L. Vesco, president of the In ternational Controls Corpora tion of Fairfield, N. J. was be lieved to have tightened his hold on Investors Overseas Services by taking over the chairmanship of the financial group's parent company.

title: Nuclear Power Plant Back After New Mishap
description: The nuclear power plant whose return to service after a ninemonth shutdown was happily announced by the Consolidated. Edison Com pany Feb 10 has had another mishap, shutdown and then recovery.

title: Giants and Jets Shuffle Coaching Aides
description: Alex Webster, becoming more forceful in his role as head coach of the Giants, com pleted the revision of his staff yesterday by adding one assist ant, promoting another and dropping two others.

title: U.S. Weighing Decision
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1  George H. Bush, on his first day as the United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that the United States was weighing a decision on whether to join the three other major powers in a public statement that would put pressure on Israel to withdraw from occupied areas.

title: Bill Rates Show a Sharp Drop At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Treasury bill rates declined sharply again at today's auc tion from previous week's levels to their lowest average discount rates since September 1963, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: NEW RIOTING FLARES IN COLOMBIAN REGION
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 1 (UPI)  New student dis orders flared briefly today in the troubled Department Del Valle, where eight persons were killed and 47 injured Friday in studentpolice clashes.The Presidential Palace re ported the new outbreak but said order was quickly restored under a state of siege pro claimed after Friday's riots.

title: LEGISLATURE GETS CONSUME' BILLS
description: ALBANY, March 1Governor Rockefeller submitted to the State Legislature today an ex tensive package of consumer protection bills that would re quire unit pricing in supermar kets, allow pharmacists to sub stitute less expensive generic drugs in prescriptions, and tighten controls over credit agencies.

title: Ali's Talkathon Leaves Almost Everyone Speechless
description: MIAMI, March 1Muham mad Ali, selfproclaimed pre dictor, poet and prophet not to mention pugilist of un limited vocal capacity  talked it up today. The for mer heavyweight champion of the world, also known as Cassius Clay, was on a radio program that he thought was a conference set up, with Joe Frazier talking from his camp in Philadelphia.

title: Catholic Spokesman Bars Plan For State Aid on Teachers' Pay
description: ALBANY, March 1  A spokesman for Roman Catholic schools in the state rejected today a proposal for state aid to pay the salaries of the schools' lay teachers. He called it a political gimmick and a trial balloon.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: March 1, 1971 THE PRESIDENT

title: More Cuban Fishing Boats Sent to Area Off Florida
description: MIAMI, March 1 (AP)  The Havana radio said today that two fleets of fishing boats left Saturday for an area off Flori da where four other Cuban ves sels were confiscated and charged with poaching in Unit ed States territorial waters.

title: PEACE HOPES RISE IN RAILS DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, March. 1 (AP)Hopes swelled today for early termination of a nation wide rallstrike threat as nego tiators for the union, who are legally free to walk out at any time, resumed talks on wages and work rules.

title: Women's Lob Drops In With a $15,000 Bounce
description: A $15,000 women's tennis tournament, which Mrs. Billie Jean King termed yesterday probably my supreme chal lenge, will be played here March 24 through 27 at the 34th Street Armory on Park Avenue.

title: New Airport Cab Service Starts With a Spurt, a Snarland a Snort
description: Mrs. Juliana Schoenfeld of Forest Hills, Queens, had trouble getting a cab at Ken nedy International Airport yesterday. The cab drivers were busy being interviewed on how taxi service at the airport was about to improve.

title: Saigon's Cambodia Drive in Confusion After Death of Its Colorful Commander
description: TAYNINH, South Vietnam, March 1  Bereft of leadership by the death of Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri in a helicopter crash last week, officers at his forward command post directing a 23,000man opera tion against North Vietnamese troops and supplies in cam bodia appear to be in a state of confusion and uncertainty.

title: Bride: Superior and Inferior Lines Of Play Can Net Same Result
description: Experts have to resign themselves to the fact that superior cardplay often goes unrewarded. In the long run they will show a profit, but in the short run their score may be no better than an other player who has selected an inferior line of play that happens to succeed.

title: Planes Fight Oil Slick
description: CAPETOWN, March 1 (AP) Three crop  spraying planes were called in today in an attempt to break up an oil slick, spreading from the strick en Liberian tanker Wafra, aground off Cape Agulhas.

title: Insurer Fails in Britain; 500,000 Drivers Affected
description: LONDON, March 1A lead ing British motor insurance company announced tonight that it was insolvent and warned 500,000 motorists to stay off the, roads until they could get new insurance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: AGENT IS QUERIED AT PANTHER TRIAL
description: Afeni Shakur, who warned her fellow Black Panther party members that one of their sup posed comrades was a police man, yesterday crossexamined the man she suspected.

title: Miss Brooks Gives Program of Songs, Her Recital Debut
description: Applause, bravos and an ex tended ovation greeted Patricia Brooks as she came on stage at Tully Hall Sunday night, and the popular soprano proceeded to earn them all with a glowing recital debut. Miss Brooks, a leading member of the New York City Opera company since 1960, was totally at home in the varied song literature she explored, her strong, free floating voice tempered by ex pressive restraint and buoyed by unfailing musical sensitivity.

title: MSGR. FRANCIS RYAN, RETIRED PASTOR, 81
description: ROSLYN, L I., March 1  Msgr. Francis R. Ryan, pastor emeritus of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here, died to day in St. Francis Hospital. His age was 81.

title: Variety Merchandise Show Stirs Buyers
description: They are writing! ex claimed Mrs. Beth Thalheim, who was radiant under a widebrimmed straw hat trimmed with purple flowers.

title: PRESIDENT WINS MIDWEST BACKER FOR TAX SHARING
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, March 1 President Nixon's plea for support et his revenuesharing program, punctuated by a pledge to add $100million to rural development funds, re ceived the backing of a Demo. cratic Governor here today, but his appearance touched off a demonstration by a coalition of farmers, antiwar protesters and construction workers.

title: EqualService Edict Irks Town
description: The Talk of Shaw

title: List of Recent Major Bombing Incidents
description: Following is a list of some of the recent major explosions and bombing incidents in the United States before the explo sion yesterday in the Capitol:

title: Court Will Rule on Birth Control Ban
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  The Supreme Court has agreed to rule on the constittuionality of anticontraceptive laws that make it a crime to distribute birth control materials to un married persons. Twentysix states have such laws.

title: Strike Halts Private Buses in Brooklyn
description: Drivers and mechanics for a private bus company serving the Mill Basin area of Brooklyn struck at 12:01 A.M. yesterday, forcing 4,500 commuters and 1, 500 school children to find oth er ways of getting to work or school.

title: AIR FORCE CURBS SLOT MACHINES
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)The Air Force is remov ing slot machines from its over seas bases and will have ban ished then entirely by July 1, 1972, Senators inquiring into military corruption announced today.

title: COLORADO BANK TIE APPROVED BY CAMP
description: William B. Camp, the Con troller of the Currency, has recommended that the First National Bancorporation, Inc., of Denver, the large bankhold ing company in Colorado, be allowed to acquire the National State Bank of Boulder, Colo., because it is an endangered bank.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: C.A.B. Rejects Fare Rises Sought by Merged Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board rejected today proposals of Northwest Airlines and North east Airlines to raise fares be tween certain Eastern cities.

title: Medina Says Army Will Not Allow Him To Reply to Calley
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Capt., Ernest L. Medina accused the Army today of trying to keep him from challenging the testimony of First Lieut. Wil liam. L. Calley Jr. that orders to kill civilians at Mylai had come from Captain Medina.

title: Price Rises of 11.9% Are Set On Paper for Grocery Bags
description: Twostep price increases amounting to almost 12 per cent for grocery bags and the paper used to make them were announced yesterday.

title: Trotskyist Trial Opens And Adjourns in Prague
description: PRAGUE, March 1 (Reuters) A trial of 19 persons ac cused of Trotskyist activity opened here today and was ad journed for one week when one of the defendants challenged the objectivity of the court.

title: GAINS ARE POSTED BY FLORIDA POWER
description: The Florida Power Corpor ation reported yesterday gains of 9.3 per cent in 1970 opera ting revenues and 5.8 per cent in net earnings. The annual report placed operating rev enues at $158,144,572, up from $144,739,865 a year earlier. Net income rose to $31,294, 306, or $3.08 a share, from $29,459,541, or $2.91 a share, in 1969.

title: Prehistoric Artifacts to Art Nouveau
description: Shop Talk

title: ILLINOIS BOY WINS TOP SCIENCE PRIZE
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) James H. Van Aken, 17 years old, of Western Springs, was named today top winner and recipient of a $10,000 scholarshipin the 30th an nual Westinghouse Science Tal ent Search among high school science students.

title: GIANTS GIVE MAYS TWOSEASON PACT
description: CASA GRANDE, Ariz., March 1(UPI)Willie Mays ended his first holdout today when he agreed to a twoyear contract with the San Francisco Giants for $155,000 to $160,000 a sea son, making him one of the highest paid players in baseball history.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The Army is going before Senator Ervin to try to explain its outrageous domestic sur veillance operations, which are sup posed to be a thing of the past. The Army has a lot to explain, all right, but its officials are not the only ones.

title: Common Market Sets British FarmPrice Transition
description: BRUSSELS, March 1  The Common Market's foreign min isters agreed today to give Britain a fourandahalfyear period of adjustment if she be comes a member. The period would be intended to bring her farm prices up to the higher levels in the sixnation trade bloc.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: TRENTON, March 1, (AP) The Trenton Education Associa tion, representing about 60 per cent of the city's teachers, reached an agreement with the Trenton Board of Education to day, ending a twoweek strike.

title: JERRY DADAP MUSIC PLAYED IN CONCERT
description: Jerry Didap, a young com poser from the Philippines, pre sided over a concert of his music Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. The major portion of the program consisted of Four 3 Short Pieces (1969 70) for various chamber com binations and Two 3 Short Pieces (1971) for solo piano and clarinet respectively.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: About Ducks
description: SISAL, Yucatan, Mexico Two mornings of excellent duck hunting and one morn ing of superb, if rigorous, quail hunting out of the Club de Patos on the nortliwest ern coast of the Yucatan were made even more memorable by our Mayan guides.

title: China Sea to the Caribbean
description: WASHINGTONThe United States is now withdrawing its ground forces from Vietnamall critics to the con trary notwithstanding. But this with drawal will not reduce the require ment for an American strategy offer ing some hope to the nations of Asia that the United States has an interest in their future.

title: STORE SALES HERE ROSE IN FEBRUARY
description: The change in the Washing ton Birthday holiday had no perceivable effect in retail buy ing last month, according to leading New York retailers. In the fourweek period ended last Saturday, department stores registered a gain of 4.9 per cent in their downtown stores and 5.5 per cent for their stores in the metropolitan area.

title: I.C.4A SCHEDULE ANNOYS COACHES
description: Picking a team winner in the I. C. 4A indoor track and field meet seemed easier yesterday for metropolitan area coaches than solving several administra tive disputes for this weekend's 50th annual championships.

title: MOSCOW REDUCES CONSUMER PRICES
description: MOSCOW, March  Soviet citizens awoke this morning to find that prices on washing machines, electric razors, ball point pens and other consumer goods had been reduced as part of cuts on prices of goods no longer in tight supply.

title: Talks on Passes Open
description: BERLIN, March 1The West Berlin City administration and the East German Government today opened talks aimed at reaching an agreement on bordercrossing passes for West Berliners during Easter.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 2, 1971

title: Pakistan Postpones Assembly in Conflict Of Major Parties
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 1 President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan announced today the indefinite postponement of the opening of the National As sembly two days before it was to begin drafting a constitution to return Pakistan to civilian rule.

title: $20,000 Raise for Howard
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 1 (AP)Frank Howard, the American League home run and runs batted in leader last year, signed with the Washing ton Senators today for $140,000 a year, a raise of $20,000.

title: 600 in Bronx Lose Power
description: Power was restored to the Riverdale section of the Bronx last night, 12 hours after a shortcircuit cut off electrical. service for 600 customers, a spokesman for Consolidated Ed ison said

title: Dr. Paul de Kruif, Popularizer Of Medical Exploits, Is Dead
description: Dr. Paul de Kruif, a bacteri ologist who won fame as a pop ular writer on medical and other scientific topics, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Holland, Mich.

title: Former Reuther Aide Joins Common Cause
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 Jack T. Conway, who for several years was executive assistant to the late Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, has been appointed president of Common Cause the national citizens lobby headed by John. W. Gardner.

title: New Director of Space Agency
description: Man in the News

title: Israelis Are Hopeful
description: JERUSALEM, March 1  Israel's policymakers, braced against criticism from the Unit ed States, are expressing con fidence that times is on their side in the diplomatic peace making effort and that the con tinuation of a firm stand on their basis positions will even tually pay off.

title: Buffalo Bill Rides Againin Fashion and in Memoryat Party
description: The wild, wild West came to the East Side last night. Dance hall girls and rodeo riders, chic Indians and just plain bluejeaned cowpokes rode through the night in taxis rather than broncos, al though one group went through the trouble of hiring a stagecoach.

title: CocaCola Profit at Record;
description: The CocaCola Company had record sales and earnings last year and record fourthquarter profits, according to the report issued yesterday by J. Paul Austin, president of the At lanta, Ga., based company.

title: Auction Fox Movie Memorabilia Brings $364,480
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1 Raymond Massey did not get the Raymond Massey portrait end Burt Bacharach did not get Butch Cassidy's bicycle. Still, the first auction to be held by SothebyParkeBernet in its new Los Angeles Hall generally seemed appropriate for Hollywood.

title: 5 Killed in Violence
description: NEW DELHI, March 1 (AP) Five persons were killed and scores injured today in violence that disrupted the opening of India's elections and forced a suspension of balloting in some areas.

title: George H. Stoner, Boeing Officer Who Helped Moon Rocket, Dies
description: SEATTLE, March 1 (AP) George H. Stoner, senior vice president of the Boeing Com pany, died yesterday in a Seat tle hospital where he was to undergo lung surgery. He was 53 years old.

title: Poland Cancels Price Rise
description: WARSAW, March 1 (AP) The Polish Government today rolled back the December rise in food prices that led to bloody street fighting and a shakeup in the leadership.

title: Crime on Capitol Hill
description: The bombing within the Capitol yesterday was another cowardly and senseless act rellecting a growing philoso phy of violence and a vicious approach to social change. The aim of the tiny minority of fanatics who are in the business of anarchy is to bring on a general repres sion in the hope that it will, breed more rebels, more anarchists and ultimately the dissolution of society.

title: DANIEL M'GUIRE, 82, HEADED G.M. UNITS
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., March 1 Daniel C. McGuire of 290 Oakwood Road, a Chevrolet dealer in North Bergen and former General Motors execu tive, was pronounced dead in Englewood Hospital yesterday after an accident in which the car he was driving ran off the road in Englewood Cliffs. He was 82 years old.

title: MRS. EDWARD R. BOSE
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1Mrs. Mildred Sophia Healey Bose of 860 Fifth Ave nue, wife of Edward R. Bose, retired executive vice president of the United Cork Company, died yesterday at their winter home here after a short illness.

title: Assembly Votes Extra Race Dates, Shift in Bet Pool
description: ALBANY, March 1  The State Assembly approved to day a proposal to extend the throughbred racing season by as many as 15 days and to enlarge the horse owners' and New York Racing Association's shares of the betting pool.

title: Phillips Carl Salman, 73, ExOfficer of Mobil Oil
description: Phillips Carl Salman, who retired as controller of the Mobil Oil Corporation in 1961, died Sunday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, He was 73 years old and lived in Enfield, N.H.

title: Vietcong Hit 4 Oil Tanks At Cambodian Refinery
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, March 2 (UPI) The Vietcong struck Cam bodia's only oil refinery at the port of Kompong Som for the first time in the war early today, burning four gasoline storage tanks, the high command reported.

title: Richard Zanuck Joining Warners As a Top Official
description: Richard D. Zanuck, who resigned under fire last De cember as president of 20th CenturyFox along with David Brown, his executive vice president of creative opera tions, have joined Warner Brothers as senior executive vice president and executive vice president in charge of creative operations, respec tively. John Calley will con tinue as the company's vice president in charge of world wide production.

title: 4 in U. S. Copter Killed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 2 (Reuters) A United States helicopter was shot down and destroyed over Komnong Chain Province in Cambodia yesterday, killing four American crewmen, the American command announoed here today. The crash brought to 59 the number of United States aircraft lost in the area since April 20, 1970, when American and South Vietnamese troops thrust into southeastern Cambodia to clear out North Vietnamese and Vietcong bor der sanctuaries.

title: Upstate G.I. Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)  The Defense Depart ment said today that Specialist 4 Harry Wolfenden of Phoenix, N. Y., had been killed in the war in Indochina.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 1 (UPI)  The Jordanian Govern ment and the Americanowned Trans Arabian Pipeline Com pany signed an agreement here today increasing annual transit royalties from $45million to $7.5million, the Amman radio reported.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD RULE BACKED BY LINDSAY
description: Mayor Lindsay told 50 urban experts yesterday that neigh borhood governments could work if the money was available.

title: Nixon Awards Medals
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) President Nixon awarded the Apollo 14 astronauts the space agency's highest award at dinner tonight and added a spe cial prize for Captain Shep herd's lunar golf game.

title: Knicks Seek 4th Straight Against Bullets Here Tonight
description: Only 10 more to go, said Willis Reed with a sigh on Sunday after the Knicks had exerted a rugged defensive ef fort in the final minutes to de feat the Bullets, 110104, at Baltimore.

title: 2D OKONITE OFFER IS SENT TO LTV
description: Merger News

title: Millions Vote in India as Election Starts
description: NEW DELHI, March 1Old men came whose eyes were not as strong as they had been in the four previous elections since independence, but their grandchildren, guiding them gently by the arm, helped them vote and helped them home again.

title: CITY SCORES STATE ON MOVERS' CODE
description: Consumer Affairs Commis sioner, Bess Myerson contended yesterday that a series of new rules governing moving com panies recently issued by the state Public Service Commis sion unfortunately avoid real regulation that would adequ ately protect consumers rights.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS PRICEFIXING APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to three corn panies and three individuals convicted of having conspired to fix prices on sinks, bathtubs and toilets from 1962 to 1966.

title: Syrians Nominate Assad
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 1 (UPI)Syria's political leader ship has nominated the Premier, Lieut. Gen. Hafez alAssad to be President for the next seven years, the Damascus radio an nounced today. General Assad, the country's strongman, will succeed Ahmed alKhatib, the interim President since Novem ber.

title: Governor Assails Steingut On Talk of BudgetCutting
description: ALBANY, March 1Gover nor Rockefeller told a group of state labor officials today that Assembly Minority Leader Stan ley Steingut's contention that up to $750million could be cut from his proposed $8.45billion budget was doubletalk.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: REP. GREEN RUNS IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Mar 1 Representative William J. Green rejected the advice of Mayor James H. J. Tate today and an mounced his candidacy for May or of Philadelphia.

title: SCIENTISTS DETECT A FERMIUM ISOTOPE
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 1 (AP)Scientists at the Law rence Radiation Laboratory of the Atomic Energy Commission reported today the first detec tion of a rare isotope of the element fermium.

title: British Rail Fares Raised
description: LONDON, March 1 (Reuters) Britain's nationalized rail roads tonight announced fare increases of up to 66 per cent.

title: Higher Taxi Fares Discourage Riders
description: Many taxiriding New York ers reacted swiftly and decis ively to the cab fare increase yesterday: They walked, took buses and rode the subway.

title: Galley Judge Expected to Permit Medina Testianony
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 4Capt. Ernest L. Medina, who leis accused the Army of trying to prevent his testifying at the trial here of First Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr., may be in vited to tettify after all.

title: Charles Engelhard, Industrialist and Turfman, Dies
description: BOCA GRANDE, Fla., March 2Charles W. Engelhard, the multimillionaire preciousmetais industrialist and race horse owner, died today at his winter estate here. He was 54 years old and lived in Far Hills, N.J. Death was attributed to a heart attack.

title: Norwegian Premier Resigns in Scandal Over Common Market
study Casts Doubt on Test for Sarcbid, an Inflammatory Disease
description: A test that has been used for 30 years to detect sarcold an inflammatory disease that affects hundreds of thousands of people throughout the world, has been stronglyr challenged by the findings of two tied can doctors.

title: Israeli Leaders Meet Envoys
description: TEL AVIV, March 2Israeli leaders today began a round of conferences in Jerusalem with ambassadors of countries rep resented in the Security Coun cil and explained their opposi tion to intervention by the Big Four or the Security Council in the peace mission of Dr. Jarring.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Feb. 22 news story about the discussions between Grace Church and the Church of the Ascension looking toward consolidation and possible merger was accurately and fully done. What was not emphasizedand this was due largely to our failure to put the matter in the perspective in which we see itwas the positive reason for these discussions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Dr. Robert Hall is taking a narrow view of the abortion problem. [OpEd Feb. 13.] He cites one abortion related death outside of a hospital as a primary reason for limiting abortions to hospitals and to legal residents of New York State. This solution is biased and devoid of humanitarianism.S. RAYMOND GAMBINO, M.D. New York, Feb. 17, 1971 The writer is Professor of Pathology at the College of Physicians and Sur geons of Columbia University.

title: GEORGE LA PIANA, 92, CATHOLIC HISTORIAN
description: NATICK, Mass., March 2 Dr. George La Plana, the John H. Morrison Professor of Church History at, Harvard Divinity School from 1926 until his re tirement in 1947, died in a nurs ing home here yesterday He was 92 years old.

title: Nathaniel Zalowitz, Wrote For Jewish Papers Here
description: Nathaniel Zalowitz, a staff writer for Jewish newspapers here for more than half a cen tury died yesterday at his home after a heart attack. He was 78 years old and lived at 6353 Haring Street, Rego Park, Queens.

title: Disintergration in Coal
description: Two decades ago the United Mine Workers, under the majestic leadership of John L. Lewis; decided that the coal industry and the jobs of union miners would both vanish unless industrial cooperation became the rule the strikeswept bituminous fields.

title: Britain's Reserves Soared $192Million in February
description: LONDON, March 2Britain's gold and foreign exchange re serves soared by $192million to more than $3.1billion, the Treasury reported today.

title: Engelhard, 54, Dies
description: Charles W. Engelhard, of Far Hills, N. J., the millionaire in dustrialist and horse owner, died yesterday in Florida. En gelhard was 54 years old De tails on Page 46.

title: SCIENTIST CALLS SST SKIN CANCER HAZARD
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 Dr. James E. McDonald, an at mospheric physicist from the University of Arizona, told a House committee today that a full fleet of supersonic trans ports would so reduce the pro tective layer of ozone in the atmosphere as to cause an ad ditional 10,000 cases of skin cancer in the United States each year.

title: St. John's Tops Holy Cross As Davis and Phillips Excel
description: WORCESTER, Mass., March 2Mel Davis and Bill Phillips led the way with their scoring and rebounding tonight as St. John's broke open a close game in the second half and pulled away to an 8974 victory over Holy Cross.

title: 8 ON TRIAL ON STOCK OF HERCULES GALION
description: The prosecution and the de fense delivered their opening statements yesterday as a trial of eight persons opened in Fed eral District Court here on charges of conspiracy, fraud and the manipulation of stock of Hercules Galion Products, Inc. The company is an Ohio manufacturer of truck bodies and hydraulic hoists.

title: Wife Speaks to Roge
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., March 3Mrs. John M. Fly, Dr. Fly's daughterinlaw, said that the family first learned about Dr. Fly's release when a Denver radio station called with the news she said that Dr. Fly's wife, Miriam, subsequently spoke by telephone with Secre tary of State William P. Rogers.

title: LAVER WINS FINAL BY 64, 60, 62
description: LONDON, March 2 (UPI) Rod Laver played with the pre cision of a machine to win the final of the $30,000 Rothmans indoor tennis tournament at the Royal Albert Hall tonight.

title: Put His Trust in Gold
description: By placing his trust in gold, along with platinum and dia monds, Charles William Engel hard in 20 years ran an in heritance of $20million into an industrial fortuneof more than $250million and became a power in the international fi nancial and business commu nity.

title: Hungarian Film, Love, May Set a Trend
description: BUDAPEST Love has captured this romancemind ed city. A film by that name Szerelem in Hungarian, has won enthusiastic critical praise and, to the surprise of its creator, so much public support that it may turn out to be a trendsetter.

title: CHARLES EDWARD DREW
description: TUCKAHOE, N. Y., March 2 Charles Edward Drew, author of books on electricity, died yes terday in Harlem Valley Hos pital in Wakefield. He was 81 years old and lived at 295 Main Street.

title: The Mood Changes When Senator Hughes Speaks
description: OXFORD, Miss., March 2 It happened again in Chicago the other night. The toastmas ter, confusing millionaire with politician, introduced the hon ored guest as Howarder, HaroldHughes.

title: Flexible Rates Described as Alternative
description: Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday he intended to seek a New York Stock Exchange seat for the State's $4.5billion pension fund if the Big Board did not alter its fixedcommis sion schedule to include nego tiated rates.

title: Savings and Loan Units Post Record Net Inflow
description: The nation's savings and loan associations had a rec ord net inflow of deposits of $2.6million during January, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced. The huge influx of funds was the prin cipal factor behind a record drop in interest rates on home mortgages during the month, which fell to 8.17 per cent from 8.38 per cent in De cember.

title: 30 Coast Students Arrested In Draft Board Protests
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., March 2  Thirty Stanford University students were arrested today after they attempted to block entrances to draft boards throughout the Bay Area.

title: Mielziner Design Show
description: Theater designs by Jo Miel ziner, encompassing nearly five decades, are in a retrospective exhibition opening today at the Wright/Hepburn/Webster Gal lery, Ltd., 205 East 60th Street. The show, to run through March 20, is Mr. Mielziner's first commercial exhibition; un like previous showings of the stage designer's work, the ex hibits are for sale.'Included are selections from designs for 284 major productions.

title: MOSCOW WILL LET 30 JEWS EMIGRATE
description: MOSCOW, March 2Some 30 Soviet. Jews, most of whom had taken part in two sitins in re cent days in government offices, were told today that they would be given permission to emigrate.

title: $500Million U.5. Outlay A shed. To Help states Combat Crime
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  President Nixon spelled out the details today of a proposal to give states about $500million in largely unrestricted funds to combat crime.Despite the similarit between Mr. Nixon's proposal and the system of grants to the states that now exists, those three changes may cause some con troversy on Capital Hill. A number of influential, members of the House Judiciary Com mittee, for example, believe that the Federal Government has not been sufficiently atten tive to what the states have done With Federal funds in the past, and are likely to argue that the President's proposal opens the door for even more abuses.

title: Bellow Wins 3d National Book Award
description: The 1970 National Book wards, beset by contro versies throughout the earlier nominating stages, had more of the same yesterday when this year's winners were an rnounced in ceremonies at the Biltmore Hotel.

title: 4thCentury Church Found in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, March 2  Greek archeologists have un earthed the remains of the basilica that the Roman Em peror Constantine built here in the fourth century at the site venerated as the one where Jesus was crucified and bushed.

title: Architect of the Capitol George Malcolm White
description: The Architect of the Capi tol is an architect. That seem ingly selfevident statement is perhaps the most signifi cant one that can be made about the new holder of the $38,000ayear position who is the superintendent of the nation's most important build ing. For more than a century, the post had been held by men who, what ever their other qualifications, were not practicing architects. Most recently, the Architect of the Capitol was J. George Stewart, an en gineer, who died last May at the age of 79 after serv ing 16 years.

title: BUILDERS, UNIONS TO REVAMP RULES
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 Construction unions and indus trial contractors agreed today to a nationwide reform of work rules as part of an effort to curb rising costs in their in dustry.

title: DACCA DISORDERS BRING A CUREFEW
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 2 Martiallaw authorities, who have taken over civilian rule in Pakistan's provinces, imposed curfew in the East Pakistani capital of Dacca tonight in the wake of widespread looting, arson and other lawlessness during a general strike.

title: 15 State Democrats in House Urge U.S. Welfare TakeOver
description: WASHINGTON, March 2A group of Democratic House members from New York began a counter attack on Governor Rockefeller today by signing their names to a bill calling for a Federal takeover of welfare costs.

title: Out of the Ashes of His Duplex, A New Home With New Mood
description: Credit it to the fire that ravaged Michael Greer's pre vious home on East 49th Street in Turtle Bay. Or the difference two years can make in any decorator's thinking.

title: CONGRESS RAILS APOLLO 14 CREW
description: WASHINGTON, March 2The Apollo 14 astronauts gladhanded their way through Congress to day in support support of the space program.

title: Refinery 80% destroyed
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 2 (UPI)Enemy mortar attacks early today on the nation's only oil refinery, at Kompong Som, 115 miles to the southwest, were reported to have destroyed 80 per cent of the installation.

title: DIXIE HOWELL, 58 I FOOTBALL GREAT
description: HOLLYWOOD, March 2 (AP) Millard (Dixie) Howell, who gained lasting fame as the passing and running star in Alabama's spectacular victory over Stanford in the 1935 Rose Bowl football game, died here today in Hollywood Presby terian Hospital, after a two year fight against cancer. He was 58 years old, and had Un dergone major surgery for the second time in two years.

title: BOYLE IS INDICTED IN MINE FUND USE
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  W. A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers, was in dicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of embezzle ment, conspiracy to embezzle, and violation of laws govern ing political campaign contri butions.

title: AMERICAN EAGLE OUTRACES FLEET
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, March 2 Like a big bird heading for her nest, American Eagle swooped past Running Tide and Windward Passage today and crossed the finish line first in the 176mile, Miamito Nassau yacht race. The time for Eagle, the winner last year, was 27 hours 1 minute 6 seconds.

title: Vegetable Oil Allowed hi Three Catholic Rites
description: ROME, March 2 (Reuters) Roman Catholic sacramen tal anointings may in future be performed with any veg table oil, according to a new Vatican ruling that lifts the church's ageold insistence on the use of olive oil.

title: Bread and Puppet Theater's Reality
description: Peter Schumann's vision in his Bread and Puppet The ter is of a heightened reality that both mirrors and dis torts life. He uses monstrous headheavy puppets with people inside, people whose faces are caked with make up so that they look mechan ical, and tiny handpuppets. With these strange crea tures, the Bread and Puppet Theater startles one's, eye and upsets one's equilibrium.

title: Fanny May Results for the, Week
description: WASHINGTON, March 2The average yield on six month commitments to purchase mortgages was 7.376 per cent, the Federal National Mortgage Association re ported today following the first auction since the rate on Governmentbacked mortgages was reduced to 7 per cent.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CAMBRIDGE, MassEuropean Com munists are seriously worried that a reStalinization drive will be touched off by the Soviet Communist party when it convenes this month at its twentyfourth Congress. This point has been stressed by Josef Szall, senior ambassador in the Hungarian: diplo matic service, who has defected. After stay in Italy, he is now in the United States.

title: Lockheed's Leader Talks With Britons About Rolls Engine
description: LONDON, March 2  Daniel Haughton, chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, opened negotiations with Brit ish Government representa tives today over the future of the RB211 jet engine for Lock heed's Tristar airbus.

title: DR. ABRAM WEISS
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 2Dr. Abram Weiss, a retired surgeon of 509 Warwick Avenue, West Englewood, N. J., died yesterday in Brower Gen eral Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Nixon Wants Lindsay To Stay a Republican
description: Herbert Klein, White House director of communications, said here yesterday that the Nixon Administration would like Mayor Lindsay to re main a member of the Re publican party.

title: 4. Teachers Get 6Month Terms For Continuing Newark Strike
description: NEWARK, March 2 For Newark teachers were sen tenced to six months in jail and fined $500 apiece today, for violating an antistriko in junction as the teachers' strike here continued into its fifth week.

title: Grounded Tanker Fouls South African Beaches
description: CAPETOWN, March 2 (AP) A major oil spill fouled the Leaches of the southern tip of Africa today as salvagework ers struggled to free the ground ed tanker Wafra.

title: Cooke's Recipe: Mix $4.S= Million, Then Add $750,000
description: Life used to be much simpler for Jack Kent Cooke. Since the; Canadian's arrival, in the United States in 1960, he has bought a hockey team, a basketball team, a piece of a football team, an arena and 15,000 acres of southern Cali fornia land that he describes as my ranch.

title: Court Orders Review of a Plan For Road to Cut Through Park
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 The Supreme Court ordered Federal District Court in Ten nessee today to review the de cision by two Secretaries of Transportation to approve Fed eral funds for a road cutting through Overton Park in Mem phis.

title: ...Riots in Pakistan
description: The general strike and other disturbances in East Pakistan are an ominous warning of the fate that awaits the entire subcontinent if the governmental proc ess breaks down in India as it threatens to do in the neighboring Moslem state.

title: Es.st Germany Asks Talks
description: BERLIN, March 2 (Reuters) East Germany today pro posed a meeting with the West Berlin city government on Thursday to start negotiations on opening its borders to West Berliners. A spokesman for the city said it would reply to morrow.

title: PenskeRebuilt Ferrari Ready to Roll
description: When the PenskeWhite Ferrari 512M is rolled off its trailer for testing this week end at Sebring, Fla., it will represent a triumph of the car preparation for which Roger Penske is deservedly famous (not to Mention his gall in painting a Ferrari blue). The car was nearly demolished in the TwentyFour Hours of Daytona and yet it fin ished third, held together by 3,000 yards of mechanic's silver tape, two broom handles and intensive care. Sections have been rebuilt in different parts of the country and the whole works have been reassembled in the Penske shops at New town Square, Pa.

title: Senate Panel Extends Nixon Price Curb Role
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)  The Senate Banking Committee voted today to extend for two months, to June 1, 1971, authority, for President Nixon to impose wage, price and rent con trols.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yester day in steppedup trading.

title: CONTINENTAL PHONE LISTS GAINS FOR '70
description: The Continental Telephone Corporation reported yesterday a 21 per cent gain in 1970 net income on an increase of 20 per cent in revenues and sales.

title: Engelhard Earnings in Fourth Quarter Drop 6.4%
description: Despite lowerfourthquarter results, record sales and earn ings were achieved by the Engelhard Minerals and Chemi cals Corporation last year, it was reported yesterday by the worldwide mineral  trading company, fabricator of precious metals and producer of koolin and other nonmetallic minerals.

title: CONNOR LAWRENCE
description: Connor Lawrance, a retired mortgage broker, died yester day in his home at 315 East 72d Street. He was 84 years old.

title: Students Face Drug Charges
description: HADLEY, Mass., March 2 (AP)  Nine University of Massachusetts students were arrested on narcotics charges last night by the state and city police, who said seven of the nine lived in an offcam pus house. Marijuana, LSD and a variety of pills were confis cated.

title: They Don't Like Girls
description: CHICAGO, March 2 (UPI) About 1,500 youths marched out of the allmale. Lane Tech nical High School today and protested at the Chicago Board of Education building because they do not want girls in the school next year.

title: 4 CHILDREN DEAD IN BROOKLYN FIRE
description: Four brothers and sisters, the oldest a 4yearold girl, died yesterday afternoon in a fire in the Williamsburg sec tion of Brooklyn.

title: Pincay's 84th Winner Sets Santa Anita Mark
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 2 (UPI)Laffit Pincay Jr. rode three winners at Santa Anita today and broke the track's jockey record set by. Alvaro Pineda in 1969.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I think the answer to Admiral. Hy man G. Rickover's question [OpEd Feb. 1and 2] is that schools are for the education of human beings rather, than places to turn out better intel lects than the Russians.MAGDALENE CONSTAN Montclair, N. J., Feb. 23, 1971

title: Court Rejects Suit to Ban Cigarette Ads on L.I.R.
description: The State Supreme Court denied yesterday a petition by a Garden City, L. I., psychiatrist to, bar cigarette advertising on Long Island Railroad trains.

title: A RELIGIOUS ISSUE RAISED ON U.S. AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 The Supreme Court was asked today to stop the Federal Gov ernment from financing the con struction of academic buildings and dormitories on the cam puses of sectarian colleges and universities.

title: Money ManagerBroker Divorce Urged
description: E. F. Hutton & Co., a major securities house, charged yes terday that a conflict of in terest exists at all brokerage firms that manage money on a discretionary basis and sug gested that money manage ment and brokerage be sepa rated;

title: 4 Lost Photographers Presumed Dead
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam March 2An American official here said today that the four photographers on a Vietnamese. helicopter that crashed in Laos Feb. 10 mus now be pre sumed dead.

title: RANGERS OBTAIN ROLFE OF WINGS
description: The Midwest distributor for the Rangers, the Detroit Red Wings, yesterday completed the fourth deal of the season between the teams when it shipped an agile defenseman, Dale Rolfe, to the New York ers in exchange for Jim Kru licki and cash.

title: Advertising:
description: Do you get the, feeling you're seeing the same TV commercials more often than you used to? You may, well be.

title: Senate Reopens Casey Hearing; Information on '65 Suit Received
description: WASHINGTON, March 2The Senate Banking Committee de cided today to hold additional public hearings on the nomina tion of William J. Casey to be chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Downtown Scene:Shaped Paintings of a Film Critic
description: The artistic environment which is by nature three dimensional in its physical expression, often tends to be twodimensional, or less, in its conceptual essence. It is also true that some two dimensional works can create a greater sense of environ ment through their virtual, simulated space than real en vironments can through ac tual, existing space.

title: Franulovic Gains at U.S. Net
description: HAMPTON, Va., March 2 (AP) Thirdseeded Zelkjo Franulovic of Yugoslavia, fresh from winning the Macon Inter national Sunday, defeated Ray Keldie of Australia, 64, 62, to day in firstround action of the United States indoor tennis tournament.

title: 8 Die as Election stirs HinduMoslem Rioting
description: NEW DELHI, March 2  At least eight persons were killed in HinduMoslem riots today in Aligarh, a predomi nantly Moslem city about 80 miles southeast of here.

title: STUART H. FRANK
description: Stuart H. Frank, a retired corporation executive, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 785 Park Avenue.

title: BRUINS SET MARK WITH 304TH GOAL
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 2 (UPI)  Wayne Carleton scored two goals, the first giv ing Boston a National Hockey League record of 304 team goals in a season, to lead the Bruins to a 6.0 victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

title: Theater: Mime Troupe Goes Astray
description: One simplistic working definition of theater would be that it is one specific course, for the dispersal of ideas through imitation and dialec tic. It follows, then; that the theater should be a particu larly important platform for the expression of political conceppts.

title: Another Battalion Of British Troops Will Go to Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland March 2An extra British infantry battalion of 750 men is to be sent to Northern Ire land shortly as part of a new campaign against Irish Repub lican Army terrorists, it was announced here today.

title: Pistons Sink Blazers
description: DETROIT, March 2 (UPI) Bob Lanier scored a career high of 38 points and Dave Bing added 34 tonight to off set a 41point spree by Geoff Petrie in leading the Detroit Pistons to a 128122 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Uruguayan Leftists Free U.S. Adviser Seized in '70
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Wednesday, March 3Dr. Claude L. Fly., a United States agroriomist who was kid napped nearly seven months ago by leftist urban Guerrillas, was Set free last Suf fering from a heart attack, he Was left in a stretcher at the gates of a hospital.

title: JAPAN TEXTILE MEN SHAPING RESTRAINTS
description: TOKYO, March 2 (Reuters) The Japanese textile industry is working out a plan of volun tary restraint on exports to the United States, international trade ministry officials said to day.

title: HIS MAJESTY 75 TO WIN FLAMINGO
description: MIAMI, March 2A gross purse of $155,000, with a first prize of $100,750, will be the attraction for 11 thoroughbreds in the Flamingo Stakes tomor row.

title: Maurice Eigen, Directed Hebrew University Drive
description: Maurice Eigen, who directed the welfare fund campaigns of the American Friends of Hebrew University, and the American Technion Society, died Monday at his home, 849 East 17th Street, Brooklyn. He was 59 years old.

title: Taxi Fares and Taxi Service
description: New York is at last to have a Taxicab Commission that will presumably ride herd on an industry that has long been largely indifferent to courtesy, comfort and, above all, service. The new body, which Mayor Lindsay rightly insisted on setting up as part of an agreement to raise taxi fares 50 per cent, should have more than enough to keep it busy.

title: Morals Charge Against Teacher Brings Brooklyn School Boycott
description: Parents kept their children out of Public School 15 in Brooklyn yesterday to protest the failure of the principal to discipline a teacher who al legedly had molested boys.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It should be pointed out to, William B. Elmer [letter Feb. 25] that the maintenance of welfare ghettos in the cities does not seem incredible, absurd or insane to the liberal politicians whose policies have lured these vic tims to the city to provide a voting bloc forthem. J. D. BocaKent, Conn., Feb. 25, 1971

title: Copters Return From Laos With the Dead
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 27The dead began to come into the emergency field hospital here today after 1 P.M.

title: The Road to Civic Bankruptcy
description: The recommendation by three city mediators for settlement of the police parity suit represents the least damaging way out of a financial disaster of the city's own making. That does not mean it is a good way out, much less that it guarantees any letup in the metoo leapfrog of municipal wages. It is simply the best the few poor options still open to the city in a ruinous, lawsuit born of a long history of municipal ineptitude in collective bargaining.

title: Some French Restaurants Skewered
description: PARIS, March 2  The Guide Kleber, perhaps trying harder because it is No. 2 to the legendary. Guide Michelin, staged a St. Bartholomew's massacre of restaurant ratings tonight.

title: MRS. ALLSTON DANA
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 2 Mrs. Dorothy Goodale Dana, widow of Allston Dana, a de sign engineer who worked on the George Washington, Tri boro and other major New York bridges, died Sunday in Prince ton Hospital after a short ill ness. She was 84 years old and lived at 52 Markham Road.

title: Advertising:
description: Charles Standen is the new chairman of the executive committee and chief executive officer of TathamLaird & Kudner of Chicago and New York.

title: Executive Changes
description: Bache & Co., Inc., an nounced yesterday that Robert W. Farrell will join the worldwide in vestment firm as director of research. Mr. Farrell has been elected a senior vice president and member of the board of directors. Mr. Farrell was formely director of research for E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc. In making the annotuice ment, the company said this represents an im portant step in our con tinuing development of the firm's research de partment, particularly in the institutional area. He has also been associ ated with the New Yorklife Insurance Company and the Affiliated Fund. Bache & Co., with headquarters at 100 Gold Street, has 125 offices throughout the United States, Can ada and overseas.

title: Quebec Puts Pressure on McGill to Change
description: MONTREAL  With snow banked around him and a win ter's wind snapping the pen nants, one recent morning Dr. Robert E. Bell ran up the flag proclaiming McGill University's 150th anniversary.

title: HARINGS OPENED IN CAPITOL BLAST
description: WASHINGTON, March 2An Army bomb expert told sena tors today that the explosives that shattered a portion of the Capitol early yesterday might have been smuggled into the building in an ordinary brief case.

title: Wagering Marks Are Set at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, March 2 With 20,438 fans wagering $2,692,854 tonight on the 50th and final session of the season's first meeting at Yonkers Raceway, world records were broken for overall and nightly average mutuel handle at a winter har ness racing stand.

title: Brother and Sister, 16 and 18, Find Early Success in Science
description: With the aplomb of the scien tists they hope to become, Mar tin W. Lo and his sister, Cecilia, calmly accepted congratulations yesterday for having placed sixth and third respectively in the 30th annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search.

title: Merger News
description: The original terms of the plan to merge LanvinCharles of the Ritz, Inc., into Squibb Beech Nut, Inc., were revised down ward yesterday by directors of both companies because the earnings results of Larivin Charles for 1970 were not as favorable as originally antici pated. On Oct. 16, the two companics said they had agreed in prin ciple to merge through an ex change of stock valued at $197,500,000.

title: Motorists Besiege A British Insurer After Its Collapse
description: LONDON, March 2 (Reuters) The police were called today to pacify angry motorists besieg ing the offices of the Vehicle and General Insurance Corn parry here after its financial collapse.

title: Paper Has No Comment
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  John Sharkey, night foreign editor of The Washington Post, said today that the newspaper would have no comment on the Trud statements. He said Mr. Astrachan's assignment in Mos cow was due to en'd this sum mer.

title: Recent Graduates Of Harvard Found Taking Manual Jobs
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 2  A study of last June's grad nating class at Harvard has Found that students are increas ingly uncertain about what to do after college and that many are accepting, even welcoming, manual jobs that make few in tellectual demands on them.

title: Nixon Gives Medal of Honor To 7 in a White Hoare Fete
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)  President Nixon today presented the Medal of Honor, the nation's highest decoration for valor, to seven United States servicemen at a private White House ceremony.

title: Promotor Seeks to Stop Fight Bulletins on Radio
description: Although there will be no live radio broadcast of the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier heavyweight title bout next Monday night, the Mutual Broadcasting System said yesterday it would issue bul letins on the progress of the fight in a special program over WOR beginning at 10:05 P.M.

title: Ambush by Foe Kills 11
description: SAIGON, March 2 (AP) The South Vietnamese com riand, reporting on its sweep against enemy bases in eastern Cambodia, said today that 11 of its soldiers had been killed and 16 wounded, in an ambush near the town of Suong.

title: Rockefeller Rebuffs City On Plea for School Funds
description: ALBANY, March 2Governor Rockefeller said today that there was no chance that the state would come up with the $40million needed to meet the budget crisis in the New York City school system.

title: Adm. John Fee Dead at 57; Converter of the Queen Mary
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 2 (Reuters)Rear Adm. John Fee, retired, director of the project to convert the British liner Queen Mary into a tourist attraction here, was found dead from carbon monoxide fumes in his car here today, the police said. His death was listed as an apparent suicide. He was 57 years old.

title: J. P. Stevens Records Deficit And a Drop in. Quarterly Sales
description: Unfavorable operating results during 1970 have continued into the new fiscal year, James D. Finley, chairman of J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., told the annual meeting yesterday at company headquarters here.

title: U.S. Acts to Block Mississippi Curbs On Poverty Project
description: JACKSON, Miss. March (UPI)The Justice Department filed suit in Federal District Court today to block Gov. John Bell Williams and two other state officials from unreason able interference with a fed erally aided program of health services to the poor.

title: DR. DONALD KERN, EXPERT ON ENERGY
description: CLEVELAND, March 2 Donald Quentin Kern, an au thority on the harnessing of he:tt transfers as a source of energy, died today after a brief illness at his home in Shaker Heights. He was 56 years old.

title: British National Gallery Obtains van der Weyden
description: LONDON, March 2  A longlost 15th, century mas terpiece, found by a London art expert in a private home, has been sold to the National Gallery for less than 500, 000, or $1.2millon.

title: Murphy Helps Beat 76ers
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 2 (UPDCalvin Murphy Scored 18 of his 27 points in the final Rockets to spark the San Diego Rockets to a 111103 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Associa tion game tonight.

title: Pennsy Chief Sees Gains but Depicts Problems as Vast
description: Six months after taking over as president and chief execu tive officer of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company William H. Moore says he sees substantial prog ress.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: School Board Orders End To Hiring of Substitutes
description: The Board of Education took emergency steps yesterday to meet its $40million budget def icit, including ordering an im mediate halt in the hiring of 10,000 to 11,000 substitute teachers who are employed daily to fill in for absent teach ers.

title: PRICES INCREASE ON CORN FUTURES
description: In a relatively quiet day for commodity futures trading corn contracts managed to gain 2 cents and more a bushel.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, March 2Henry Kissinger is in the center of a bitter controversy here for three reasons: (1) despite White House denials, he is undoubtedly the principal adviser to President Nixon on foreign policy; (2) that policy, particularly in Indochina, is opposed by influential members of the House and particularly the Senate, who feel they have a constitutional duty to examine the logic of the Presi dent's decisions; but (3) they cannot question Mr. Kissinger about Laos, the Middle East or anything else.

title: Ballots in India...
description: Balloting in national elections in India during the next few days poses a severe test, for the survival of freedom and unity in the world's largest democracy, a country embracing oneseventh of mankind.
