title: Anchorage Turns Urban as It Waits for Big Oil Boom to Start
description: ANCHORAGE, March 2 I used to be able to walk down Fourth Street and know most of the people, a, newspaper editor said the other day, but now there are so many new faces.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: William V. Spanos in his recent letter seems to be under the impression that Washington's decision, to resume arms shipments to Greece is a major factor in keeping the military government of that country in power.

title: Japanese Decide Not to Use Warning on Cigarette Pack
description: TOKYO, March 2 (UPI) A Japanese Government coun cil said today that the relation ship between cigarettes and cancer still is open to ques tion and said health hazard warnings need not be printed on cigarette packages.

title: 100 CZECH NEWSMEN FACE BAN BY UNION
description: PRAGUE, March 2 (Reuters) The Czech Journalists Union will fl blacklist all but 70 of the union's 170 freelance journal ists, according to a letter from the union secretary, Josef Prochazka, to newspaper and magazine editors.

title: SENATE REJECTS CLUSURE 3D TIME
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 The Senate refused for the third time today to cut off Southern filibuster against move to make it easier to limit filibusters, thus probably dooming once again the bien nial attempt to reform the Senate's rules.

title: Canadian Reserves Climb
description: OTTAWA, March 2 (Canadian Press)  Canada's foreign ex change rose $51.2million last month to $4,850,300,000, the Finance Department reported today. Most of the increase was in United States dollars, which rose to $3,076,600,000 from $3,025,700,000 at the end of January.

title: Kranepool Puts Into Practice A Plan to Become a Met Hero
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2The New York Mets Played their, first practice game of the spring today and the scene stealer was not one of the bright young rookies in camp but Ed Kranepool, the forgotten man.

title: Soviet Jew Seeks to Return
description: GENEVA, March 2 A Jew who left the Soviet Union in 1967 complained today about discrimination in Israel and said he wanted to return to his native Minsk.

title: 1,000 Nurses Go to Albany To Ask Changes in Law
description: ALBANY, March 2  than a thousand nurses verged on the Capitol tod?? bus caravans to press for a re definition of their profession under state law.

title: Symington Protests Kissinger's Power
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 Senator Stuart Symington pro tested today that Henry A. Kis singer, the President's adviser on national security, had be come Secretary of State in ev erything but title and that as a result Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers had become a laughingstock in Washington.

title: Chicago Broadcasters Agree To Add Community Services
description: Three Chicago community action groups yesterday with drew petitions they had filed with the Federal Communica tions Commission to deny re newal of broadcast licenses to WBBMTV and WBBM radio, of the Columbia, Broadcasting System. The withdrawals fol lowed an agreementbetween the community, groups and the stations for I upgraded munity broadcast services.

title: Governor Explains Privateschool Aid Position
description: ALBANY, March 2 Gover nor Rockefeller said today that he did not think most of the additional state aid being con sidered for parochial schools would go to impoverished in nercity areas.

title: TART OF CHAPS STARS AS NETS BOW, 130127
description: DALLAS, March 12Levern Tart sank four straight baskets in the closing minutes tonight to help the Texas Chaparrals gain a 130127 victory over his former teammates, the :New York Nets, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Newspaper Wins Renewal
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) A Federal Communications Commission examiner has rec ommended renewal of the Chronicle. Broadcasting Com pany's licenses for station's KRONTV and KRONFM, San Francisco.

title: City Betting Agency Sets March 29 Goal
description: The head of the city's Off track Betting Corporation said yesterday that if present negotiations with the race track unions were successful his agency would start taking bets March 29.

title: Women in Connecticut Sue To Void Ali Abortion Laws
description: NEW HAVEN, March 2 More than 1,000 Connecticut women filed suit in Federal Court here today to invalidate the stare's abortion laws, which now prohibit all abortions ex cept to preserve the life of the mother.

title: MARKET FINISHES ON AN EVEN KEEL
description: The market marked time yes terday and wound up without any perceptible movement one way or the other.

title: Fordham, Marquette Fives Accept Berths in N.C.A.A.
description: Fordham University became yesterday the first of 10 at large basketball teams to ac cept bids to the National Col legiate Athletic Association championship. The Rams drew the Southern Conference cham pionnot yet decidedas their opponent in the first round on March 13 at St. John's Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Music: A Rare Handel
description: One of Handel's best, yet leastperformed oratorios, Solomon, was the Handel Society of New York's second. offering this season. It was presented in Carnegie Hall. on Monday night, under the direction of Stephen Simon.

title: CAIRO SAY ISRAEL IS DEFIANT OF U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2The United Arab Re public declared today that Is rael has registered in the United Nations, for the first time in the history of the world organization, its deter mination to expand, annex and acquire Arab territory, ands overtly declare its refusal to withdraw from the Egyptian territories.

title: 13 Police Officers on East Side Win Stay on Giving Testimony
description: A group of 13 police ser geants, captains and deputy in spectors yesterday won a tern porary stay that in effect blocks the Knapp Commission from questioning hostile policemen for at least the next six weeks.

title: DR. AMSHEL GUEFT OF N.Y.U,, 85 DIES
description: Dr. Amshel Gueft, former Clinical Professor of Prostbetics at the New York University College, of Dentistry, died of leukemia at Mount Sinai Hos pital on, Monday. He was 85 years old and lived at 276 Riv erside drive.

title: Mutual Chairman Resigns
description: John P. Fraim resigned yes terday as chairman of the Mutual Broadcasting Corpora tion. He said he resgned be cause of personal commit ments brought about by his appointment by President Nixon as chairman of the People to People program. No successor to the Mutual post was an nounced.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: March 1, 1971

title: $1BILLION IS HIT IN BOND OFFERS
description: A big slug of new bond is sues  more than $1billion of corporate and taxexempt se curitieshit the credit mar kets yesterday in the most ac tive financing day since last spring.

title: Nyquist Is Lukewarm Private Aid to Pupils
description: ALBANY, March 2  Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Commis sioner of Education, said today that New York school districts should be allowed to pay pri vate concerns, under contract to improve students' school perforniance.

title: Gangs Roam Dacca Streets
description: DACCA, Pakistan, March 2 This capital of East Pakistan was in the grip of roving gangs of demonstrators today on the first day of the general strike. Youths carrying steel rods, poles and staves roamed through the city shouting in dependence slogans and seeing that this community of a mil lion and a half residents ob served a complete shutdown of business and transportation.

title: Market Place Banks Serving Fund Investors
description: Softlylike cats stalking a spring robinthe savings banks and the commercial banks are moving in on the $50billion market for mu tual fund shares.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Absence may Make the heart grow fonder, but it does absolutely nothing to awaken irresistible longing for any thing as fundamentally unromantic as a prizefight promo tion. That's why there was always a historical insistence on the total availability, of the two protagonists in every pugilistic drama so that the role of the ballyhoo drums could be heard with deafening and unmistakable clarity.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HARRY VITELES, 77, IN CP MOVEMENT
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 2  Harry Viteles who aided the development of the cooperative movement in Is rael, died yesterday in New Rodhelle Hospital after a short illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 130 Mongomery Circle.

title: RECITAL FOR PIANO BY URSULA OPPENS
description: The phenomenon that George Bernard Shaw in his day called the religion of the pianoforte lit still with us, though the ranks of the faithful have thinned. The dication that the instrument demands on high professional Level is probably not equaled dive outside certain cloistered orders and the classical corps' de ballet. And in this sisterhood of the keys, Ursula Oppens, who gave a recital on Monday night at the logers Auditorium of the Metro politan Museum of Art, must Unquestionably be ranked with the more accomplished younger entrants.

title: Slum Residents to Join Boards Of Protestant Welfare Agencies
description: The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies Began an ex periment last night to train people who aren't white, and don't have money contacts or social status to become mem bers of the governing boards of some, of the 250 charitable organizations that it represents here.

title: Car Stopped and Searched
description: BOSTON, March 2The F.B.I. today stopped and searched car it had been looking for as a result of the Washington bombing but permitted the ve hide to go on its way after no explosives were found inside.

title: Whitney Museum to Run New 10Week Film Series
description: The Whitney Museum, Which concluded its first 10 week New American Film maker series last Wednesday, twill start another 10week gram of movies created Independent filmmakers on March 11. According to,. David Blenstock, the mu seum's film curator, the grat ifying results of the first series spurred the presenta tion of the new series.

title: Bridge: Expert Can Disregard Caution Against Doubling of a Slam
description: It is wellknown that play ers who double slams merely because they think the de clarer is due to go down ofte'n have cause to regret it.

title: Michigan Capitol Evacuated
description: LANSING, Mich., March 2 (AP)Gov. William G. Milli ken, members of the Michigan Senate and other state workers evacuated the Capitol today after a bomb threat was tele phoned to one of the building's offices. The state police found no bomb.

title: WEST IS INJURED IN LAKER VIC TORY
description: BUFFALO, March 2 (AP)The Los Angeles Lakers moved with init victory of clinching at least a tie for the National Basketball Association Pacific Division crown tonight with a 131118 triumph over the Buffalo Braves, but they may have loot their star guard; Jerry West.

title: Iraqi Mission FireBombed, Light Damage Is Reported
description: A firebomb charred the out side of the Iraqi Mission to the United Nations art 11 P.M. last night, the police said. There were no injuries and damage was described as light.

title: NIXON IS CRITICIZED BY A FORMER AIDE
description: Dr James E. Allen Jr., who was dismissed by the Nixon Administration last June as United States Commissioner of Education,, criticized the Presi dent yesterday for allegedly failing to provide leadership in school desegregation and edu cational reform.

title: New V.M.I. Superintendent
description: LEXINGTON, Va., March 2 (AP)  Maj. Gen. Richard L. Irby, one of the Army's top armor experts, has been named superintendent of Virginia Mili tary Institute. General Irby, commanding general of the United States Army Armor Center at Fort Knox, Ky., will assume his new post July I, it was said yesterday. He will suceeed Lieut. Gen. George R. E. Shell, who is retiring.

title: CITY BETTING UNIT. WAS LENT $800,000 IN WELFARE FUNDS
description: An unpubicized $2.8million loan authorization from the city welfare agency to the floundering Offtrack Betting Corporation was disclosed yes terday touching off an uproar at a City Hall hearing.

title: STOCKS ARE OFF ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London Stock Exchange, reflecting Britain's major strikes and the perplexing fi nancial difficulties of concerns that had seemed serenely se cure, continued to decline yes terday.

title: A Soldier's Own Obituary
description: I am writing my own obituary for several reasons, and I hope none of them are too trite. First, I would like to spare my friends, who, may happen to read this, the usual clichs about being a good soldier. They were all kind enough to, tile, and I not enough to thein. Second, I would not want to be a party to perpetuation of an image that is harmful and inaccurate: glory is theinost meaningless of con cepts, and I feel that in some cases it is doubly damaging. And thirdly, I am quite simply the last authority on my own death.

title: Bay State Tax Bill Killed
description: BOSTON, March 2 (AP)  The Massachusetts House killed to day Gov. Francis W. Sargent's $311Million tax bill, after more than six hours of debate. The proposed tax program was re jected on a 126to108 rollcall, but a motion for reconsidera tion was filed and it will come up again tomorrow.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Tile Producers Object TO British Trade Practices
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)United States, industry representatives charged today that British ceramic walltile makers were using a cartel ar rangement to penetrate the American market with less than fair value sales at the expense of the United States industry.

title: NIXON AIDES DEFEND HUNGER DRIVE ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, March 2A panel of Federal officials, ac knowledging that much more remains to be done, testified today that the Nixon Admini stration had built a record of dramatic achievement against hunger.

title: Laos Protests to Thant
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2The charge, d'affaires of the Laotian Embassy in Washington, Lane Pathamma vong, called on Secretary Gen eral Thant today to protest the presence of foreign troops in his country. Similar protests were made recently to the So voiet Union and Britain, co chairmen of the 1962 Geneva conference that guaranteed the neutrality of Laos.

title: Pope's Mass Outdrew Sports at Stadium
description: Yankee Stadium is popularly known as the House That Ruth Built, but throughout its 48 year history a number of ten ants have used the Bronx arena.

title: Mordche S. Friedman, 80, Dies; Led Union of Hassidic Rabbis
description: Rabbi Mordche Shlomo Friedman, Hassidic leader of the Rizhiner dynasty and pres ident of the Union of Hassidic Rabbis, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: BASEBALL BEGINS ATTACK ON DRUGS
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 2  Baseball's cam paign for mass drugabuse edu cation got under way here today in a threehour seminar attended by 70 representatives of nine major league teams and baseball's administration.

title: SOVIET ASSAILS A U.S. REPORTER
description: Moscow, March 2  A Soviet newspaper called today for the expulsion of Anthony Astrachan, the Moscow corres pondent of The Washington Post, for articles about the problems of Soviet Jews that were described as slanderous concoctions.

title: BANKERS CAUTIONED ON FOREIGN LENDING
description: ST. LOUIS, March 2 (UPI) American banks have been making foreign loans without sufficient investigation as they did in the ninteentwenties and the chickens are now coming home to roost, a Philadelphia banker said today.

title: City Pollution Aide Assaili Federal Official on SST
description: The city's Air Resources Cdnunissioner, Robert N. Rick les, charged yesterday that the top Federal environmental of ficial had destroyed his credi bility by backing the controver sial supersonic transport plane.

title: Herbert Mitgang Is Elected President of Authors Guild
description: Herbert Mitgang author and a member of the editorial board of the New York Times, has been elected to a first term as president of the Authors Guild, Inc.

title: ERA. REPORTS CITY WILL DROP APPEAL OVER WAGE PARITY
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced yester day that the city had agreed to drop its appeal in the P.B.A.'s parity suit and to pay each patrolman $3,300 in retro active salary adjustments.

title: From Social Whirl to Aiding Addicts
description: Sometimes, said Judy Peabody the other day, Sam feels we live like her mits.

title: Taiwan Is Expelling U.S. Missionary and Wife
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 2 The Nationalist Chinese Gov ernment today placed an American missionary, the Rev. M. L. Thornberry, and his wife under house arrest and or dered them to leave Taiwan within 48 hours.

title: U.S., SOVIET ASSAILED ON NUCLEAR POSITION
description: GENEVA, March 2 Japan and Sweden urged the United States and the Soviet Union to day to reduce the destructive ness, and not merely the nurn bers, of their strategic nuclear missiles.

title: Knicks, Led by Reed, Top Bullets, 10995
description: Willis Reed, still hobbled by tendonitis in his left knee, played 38 minutes and scored 21, points to lead the Knicker bockers to a 10995 victory over the Baltimore Bullets in Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Prettybelle Closing After Boston Tryout
description: The Gower Champion pro duction of Prettybelle, the musical starring Angela 1ans bury, will close at the end of its Boston engagement on Saturday.

title: WOOD PULP PRICE TO RISE $10 A TON
description: The International Pulp Sales Company, a subsidiary of the International Paper Company, announced yesterday that it would raise prices by $10 a ton on all grades of dissolving wood pulp, effective April 1. The cur rent average price is $200 a ton, the company said.

title: RCA Is Seeking New Canaan Site For 1,018 Officers
description: The, RCA Corporation Sought permission yesterday from the town of New Canaan, Conn, to build an office building there for 1,018 excutive employes now working in New York City and New Jersey.

title: Aiding Global Economy
description: Vietnamand now Cambodia and Laoshave so dominated thought about the United States's international role that the nation's earlier reputation as rebuilder of the world economy has almost been blotted out. The most constructive aspect of President Nixon's State of the World Mes sage is his effort to look beyond the war in Southeast Asia and to set the United States back on its course as contribu tor to international economic development; this part of the message has received less at tention than it deserves.

title: SAIGON BOLSTERS ITS FORCE IN LAOS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 3More South Vietnamese troops crossed into Laos yesterday to counter a continued buildup of enemy troops and armored forces in the battle area.

title: THOMAS FORISTALL, FINANCIAL WRITER
description: Thomas M. Foristall, former ly of The Wall Street Journal, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 167 Center Ave nue New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: Prudential Hits Big Board on Membership
description: Donald S. MacNaughton, chairman and chief executive of the largest insurer in the world, the Prudential Insurance Company, chided the New York Stock Exchange yester day for moving too slowly to provide negotiated rates and to widen its memberships to in stitutions like the Prudential.

title: Dr. William B. Sherman Dies; Leader in Allergy Research, 63
description: Dr. William Bowen Sherman, an internationally known aller gist honored for his research in the Immune, mechanism of many allergic diseases, died yesterday at his home after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 1021 Park Ave nue.

title: House Panel Clears Voteat18 Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)  With little argument and practically no opposition the House Judiciary, Commitee approved today proposed con stitutional amendirient that would lower', the voting age to, 18 for all elections, including state and Ideal ones.

title: Israel Termed Flexible
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  Israel was reported here today to be willing to ease her stand on troop withdrawals from all of the Sinai Peninsula occupied during the 1967 war in return for concessions from the United Arab Republic.

title: F.C.C. EASES CURB ON BROADCASTERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)The Federal Communi cations Commission, in a ruling yesterday, eased its onetoa market ownership limit to allow one person to own both an AM and an FM radio station in one city.

title: Senate Panel Backs Bill To Save Appalachian Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)  President Nixon's revenue sharing plan suffered its first major legislative setback today when a Senate committee ap proved a bill to save the $1bil lion Appalachian antipoverty program.

title: Construction Outlays Up $2Billion in Month
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 Construction expenditures rose by more than $2billion in January to an annual rate of $96.7billion, the Com merce Department reported today.

title: City to Buy Yankee Stadium In Move to Keep 2 Teams
description: In a move to keep the New York Yankees baseball team and the Football Giants here, Mayor Lindsay an nounced yesterday that the city planned to buy and modernize the 48yearold Yankee Stadium, then lease it to the baseball club.

title: Ali to Log 3,276 Air Miles Before Mon day Night Fight
description: In a tremendous amount of travel activity prior to a heavyweight championship bout, Muhammad All intends to take three flights between Miami and New York before Monday night's title show down with Joe Frazier at Madison Square Garden.

title: SWEDEN POSTPONES MILITARY LOCKOUT
description: STOCKHOLM, March 2 (Reuters)The Swedish Gov ernment tonight postponed un til March 10 a lockout of 3,00G military officers that was scheduled to begin at midnight tomorrow.

title: CONNETICUT COURT REJECTS SEALE BID
description: HARTF'ORD, March 2The Connecticut Supreme Court re fuled today to intervene in the trial of Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins and let stand decision that the two must be tried by a 12member jury in the death of a fellow member of the Blatit Panther party.

title: 3 Ecological Groups Sue T.V.A. on StripMine Coal
description: Three national conservation groups filed a potentially far reaching Federal lawsuit here Yeaterday, accusing the Ten nessee Valley Authority of ig nding new Government en vironmental protection stand ards, in contracting for supplies of stripmined coal in the Ap palachian Mountains and has tening the desolation of the re gion.

title: Mrs. Btaiberg Wed to Israeli
description: TEL AVIV, March 2 (AP) Mrs. Eileen Blaiberg, whose late husband; Dr. Philip Blaiberg, was Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard's second heart transplant patient, was married last week to Her bert Blum, a retired Israeli Government official, it was re ported here today. Dr. Blaiberg died Aug. 17, 1969, at the age of 50. He lived 563 days after the transplant operation.

title: Connecticut Towns Debate Power Line's Scenic Cost
description: NEWTOWN, Conn., March 2The dilemma facing the overflow crowd in the Town Hall of this rustic communi ty today was one that is be coming increasingly com mon: How to gape with vault ing demands for electricity. and, at the same time, pre serve the environment.

title: Prospects for Averting a Steel Strike. Are Held Slim
description: The chief negotiator for man agement in this year's steel labor talks said yesterday that a strike next summer was far from inevitable, but he indi cated that it would take an unusual effort to avert a walkout after nearly a dozen years of peace between the in dustry and the union.

title: JapaneseChinese Trade Accord: An Annual Ritual
description: TOKYO, March 2 Once a year, an important segment of the governing Liberal Demo cratic party takes a trip to the People's Republic of China and figuratively stands with bowed heads in the snow awaiting ab solution from China's leaders the rulers of onefourth of man kind. The delegation, headed this year by a businessman rath er than a pond dim, negotiates a memorandum trade agreement. In re cent years, the M.T. agreement, as it is called, has regulated no more than 10 per cent of Chi neseJapanese trade. But it is important, nevertheless, for it is the only semiofficial pipeline between Peking and Tokyo.

title: Books of The Time
description: THE SENSUOUS WOMAN. The First' HowTo Book for the Female Who Yearns To Be All Women. By J. 192 pages. Dell. Paper. $1.25.

title: Growing Up in an Ian Village
description: Going back as far as I can remem ber as a child in an Indian community, I had no sense of knowing about the other people around me except that we were all somehow equal; the class structure in the community was hori zontal. There was duly one class. No body was interested in getting grit top of anybody else.

title: COURT BIDS STATES HELP THE POOR PAY COSTS OF DIVORCE
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 The Supreme Court ruled 8 to 1, today that persons who wanted, divorces but were too poor to pay filing fees and court costs must have those costs borne by the state.

title: Nixon Greets Poster Child
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)  President Nixon wel comed today sixyearold Peter John Heltemes of Rockville, Md., the national Easter Seal Child, and promised, We're all going to buy seals. The National Easter Seal Society for Crippled Children and Adults has started its 1971 fund raising drive that runs until Easter Sunday.

title: An Election Issue in India: Vicious Circle of Growing Unemployment and Lagging Output
description: BHARATPUR, IndiaWork Is Worship, says the big sign at the entrance to the plant making railway freight cars in this teeming North Indian town. If the sign bears truth, then about 1,300 men who used to work in the sprawling, metalroofed shed are not do ing much worshiping these days.

title: SEAMAN SENTENCED FOR HIJACKING SHIP
description: LOS ANGELES, March 2 (UPS) A merchant seaman pleaded guilty today to hijacking a mu nitions ship to Cambodia and was sentenced to 10 years in prison for mutiny and assault on the high seas.

title: Equal Time Urged for Strong 3d Party
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Com mission, proposed today a re vision of the campaign televi sion laws that would guaran tee equal exposure to a sig nificant thirdparty candidate like George C. Wallace.

title: Exhibit on Puerto Ricans Opens
description: The American Museum of Natural History, which is world renowned for its ex hibits of nature's phenomena, opened an exhibit on Puerto Rican contemporary life yes yesterday.

title: Pride and Worry on Hungary's Economy
description: BUDAPEST In the wake of Poland's violent economic trou bles, Hungarian officials are viewing their own happier situ ation with a mixture of satisfac tion and anxiety,

title: Ellis Knocks Out Doyle
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 2 (UPI)  Jimmy Ellis, former World Boxing Association heavyweight titleholder, scored a knockout tonight over Irish Tony Doyle at 2 minutes 42 seconds of the final round of a scheduled 10rounder. Ellis, weighed 198 pounds and Doyle 207.

title: Rush Goes to Redskins
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Clive Rush, who resigned in midseason as the Boston Pa triots' head football coach last year, was hired today as an assistant to the Washington Redskins' coach, George Allen. The Redskins said Rush would be a general assistant to Allen and would mainly handle the offense.

title: Foster Retains His Title By Halting Carroll in 4th
description: SCRANTON, Pa., March 2 Bob Foster proved again to night that he is one of the fast est hitters in boxing history. In the Catholic Youth Center, Fos ter defended his share of the world lightheavyweight cham pionship by knocking out Har old (TNT) Carroll of Syracuse.

title: Levi Strauss & Co. Plans Public Stock Offer Today
description: Levi Strauss & Co., the manu facturer of jeans and slacks that traces its origins to the days of the California gold rush, is to offer its shares to the public for the first time this morning.

title: M'GOYERN URGES ISRAELI PULLOUT
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 Senator George S. McGovern joined tonight the Nixon Ad ministration in suggesting that Israel withdraw from all but insubstantial portions of cap tured Arab territories provided her future borders are ade quately guaranteed in a Middle East settlement.

title: Mrs. Ricki Brody Revson Is Revved
description: Mrs. Ricki Brody Revson was married last Friday to Manuel De Miranda in a civil ceremony performed at his mountaintop home just out side of San Salvador.

title: Upward Changes
description: For a handicapped child or adult, change can mean dis carding a crutch and walking with, a brace, discarding a wheelchair and walking with crutches, or leaving a world of silence and speaking. All these changes have happened in the last year to thousands who benefited from the East er Seal Society's rehabilita tion programas. Gifts may be sent to Easter Seals, care of your Postmaster.

title: Senators Told Johnson Officials Began Army Check on Civilians
description: WASHINGTON, March 2A senior Pentagon official as serted today that the highest officials of the Johnson Ad ministration Initiated Arm surveillance of legitimate civil ian political activity in 1967 and 1968 and were aware of many details of that operation as it expanded.

title: Power Fails Again in Bronx
description: For the second consecutive day, 600 consumers in the Riv erdale section of the Bronx were without electric power for part of the day yesterday. The Conolidated Edison Com pany said the blackout lasted from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and af fected Palisade Avenue between 232d and Kappock Streets.

title: Nike and Fighter Cutbacks Ordered
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  The Army announced today that it would shut down a large number of its Nike Hercules antiaircraft missile installations and realign the duties of the re maining ones by June 30 to cut costs.

title: Pure Chance Makes Stander A Leading Bloodhound Owner
description: A leading bloodhound ken nel in the East is Matthew Stander's upstate establish ment in Cragsmoor. But it was by pure chance that Stander became a blood hound owner. I wanted a coonhound and went to Annie Rogers, who had the famous Ch. Mignon's Musical Rattler II, he said.She couldn't find one for me, but suggested I get a bloodhound. So I bought a 2montihold pup to have as a pet.

title: First Recorded Teller Vote Is Taken in the House
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  Mr. Chairman, I demand tellers with clerks.

title: Disruption in the Schools
description: To the Editor: I feel that your Feb. 20 editorial, Illegal School Suspensions, places unwarranted confidence in the relia bility of studies by the New York Civil Liberties Union, and also demonstrates some confusion in your thinking.

title: Network Called to Court On Fight Bulletin Plan
description: Justice Andrew R. Tyler will hold a hearing in the State Supreme Court in Man hattan today on the Mutual Broadcasting Systein's plan to broadcast bulletins on the progress of the AliFrazier heavyweight title bout Mon day night.

title: Two Toll Roads in Jersey Named Safest in Country
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 3The New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway took first and second spots, respectively, as the safest United States toll roads logging one billion or more vehicle miles last year, accord ing to a report by the Interna tional Bridge, Tunnel and Turn pike Association.

title: Executioner Scores By Head in Flamingo
description: MIAMI, March 3The $155, 000 Flamingo at Hialeah today turned out to be a two horse race but it did not involve the two horses most favored by the crowd of 27,582 on a torrid afternoon.

title: CONCORDE'S COST NOW AT $2BILLION
description: PARIS, March 3 Costs of the Concorde program have gone from under $400million to $2 billion since the British and French Governments decided to build the supersonic airliner in 1962.

title: Sparkman Assails Nixon For Refusing To Spend $8Billion
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 Senator John J.. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, at tacked the Nixon Administra tion today for impounding more than $8billion in appro priated fUnds for various pro grams; primarily domestic. He said that this constituted a serious breach of faith with Congress.

title: Orioles Sign Boog Powell For a Year at $90,000
description: MIAMI, March 3 (UPI)Boog Powell, the American League's most valuable player in 1970, became the last Baltimore Ori ole to sign a 1971 contract when he came to terms today for $90,000.

title: Royals Edge Bullets
description: BALTIMORE, March 3 (UPI) Norm Van Lier's free throw with two seconds left in over time gave the Cincinnati Roy als a 133.132 victory over the Baltimore Bullets tonight. The defeat spoiled the Bullets chances of clinching the Cen tral Division championship in the N.B.A.

title: Hawks Topple Blues, 51
description: ST. LOUIS, March 3 (UPI) Bobby Hull scored his 40th goal of the season and Stan Mikita, Danny O'Shea, Dennis Hull and dim Pappin added goals for Chicago tonight to give the Black Hawks A 51 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: Kings Tie Sabres, 33
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 3 (UPI)Ralph Backstrum's 15 foot rebound shot with just 12 seconds remaining tonight gave the Los Angeles Kings a 33 tie with the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Philadelphia, Miss., Erasing Memories of Violence
description: PHILADELPHIA, Miss.  Those who used to come here with fear in their hearts would not recognize the place today.

title: Lincoln Center Drive Nets $300,000
description: Last November the constit uents of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts took the calculated risk that when it came to obtaining gifts from corporations they could do a lot better if they tided jointly rather than separately.

title: Hawks Subdue Warriors

title: The Screen: 'Power Over Women':Tale of Love Explores Life of 'Right Guy' Rod Taylor Plays Role of Rock Singer
description: John Krish's "The Man Who Had Power Over Women" is a silly movie that wastes the talents of a generally good cast headed by the estimable Rod Taylor and including several very pleasant women. The title suggests all kinds of secret titillation, but the title is something of an ironic joke. "The Man Who Had Power Over Women" is really about true love, healthy sex and what a crummy racket public relations is for a basically right guy.Taylor plays the right guy, and he publicly represents a rock singer (Clive Francis), who, I guess, is the man with the power. To console him for his miserable life, for having to act like a rat even though a private quiver of distaste always lets us know he really isn't one, and for the frigidity of his nevertheless beautiful wife (Penelope Horner)  he has only his income, his Jaguar, his principles, the occasional favors of at least three terrific girls, and the perfect mate for the mind and body in Carol White, who happens to be married to his best friend.Although it sounds pretty much like every third movie you've ever seen, "The Man Who Had Power Over Women" enjoys a small distinction in the wonderful ease with which it resolves each of its insurmountable problems.Thus, no sooner does the frigid wife ask Rod Taylor for a divorce (because he's so sexy, I think) than Carol White falls into bed with him. And no sooner does she fall than her husband and his buddy (James Booth  who, thank goodness, didn't love her anyway) is conveniently killed under a truckload of toilet bowls. Rod Taylor feels very sad, and he cries for his pal before running off with the widow  having meanwhile plugged the vile rock star in the jaw, to signify independence.No actor could survive this material, but Rod Taylor, whose face really looks like a fund of worldly trust, does pretty well. He is at his best in sexual comedy, with Alexandra Stewart and Magali Noel, and at his worst in sexual sentimentality with Miss White. But in this he follows the fortunes of the movie, which discovers a certain moral bankruptcy each time it pauses to take stock of itself."The Man Who Had Power Over Women" opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters. I saw it at the R.K.O. 23d Street where, for the first show the houselights were left on so brightly as to wash out some of the color from the screen.

title: Dossier Dictatorship
description: Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. of North Carolina, that invalu able watchdog of the Constitution, has been conducting hearings on the threat of computerized information sys tems to political liberty. Data on the private lives of Americans are now piling up in government and private agencies to the extent that if a man does not have a file with the Federal Bureau of Investigation or one of the military intelligence offices, he has a good chance of making up for it by inclusion in the computerized information bank of the Central Intelligence Agency, one of the Congressional security committees, the Passport Office, the Justice Department's Division of Internal Security or any one of a dozen other agenciesFederal, state and local.

Today's crisis is, unfortunately, gen uine; to assume otherwise would be a serious error. Mayor Lindsay moreover misstates the case by charging that the board has overspent its budget.

description: CAIRO, March 3  The ceasefire that quieted the gunsalong the Suez Canal nearly seven months ago has revived foreign tourist trav el in Egypt, spreading mon ey and smiles among hotel managers, airline officials, camel drivers and shopkeep ers;

title: Suns Crush Bulls, 11590
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 3 (AP)The Phoenix Suns scored the first nine points of the sec ond half tonight and went on to crush the Chicago Bulls, 11590, in a National Basket ball Association game.

title: Nixon Wants Draft Authority Left With Congress
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  The Nixon Administration, which hopes to end the military draft by the middle of 1973, does not want to retain the au thority to reinstitute conscrip tion if the voluntary program, once adopted, fails to meet the nation's needs. It wants that authority to come from Con gress.

title: Vesco's Position Defended
description: Mr. Slater, who, is I.O.S.'s chief executive officer said in New York that be could see no difference in Mr. Vegas posi tion with I.O.S. before and after the latest board meeting.

title: New Chief for NASA
description: President Nixon has nominated James C. Fletcher, president of the University of Utah, to be the new administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. No one can accuse Mr. Nixon of exces sive haste in this matter since almost a half year has passed since Mr. Fletcher's predecessor, Dr. Thomas O. Paine, resigned. The delay reflects, no doubt, both the relatively low priority NASA now enjoys among the President's concerns and the difficulty of finding a suita ble candidate willing to take over leadership of an agency in as visible a state of decline as NASA is.

title: Know Harvard Men? Listless They're Not
description: Advertising:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The High School Principals Associa tion once again warns that if the Board of Education and Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner continue to under cut the authority of school principals, within five years there will not ari academic high school worthy of the name left in the city.

title: 40Hour Truce Observance
description: SAIGON, Thursday, March 4 (Reuters) United States and South Vietnamese forces will observe a 40hour truce today and tomorrow in western Kon tum Province of the Central Highlands to allow the promised release of 39 wounded South Vietnamese prisoners by the Vietcong, informed sources said today.

title: ACTION BY AURELIO SCORED BY RONAN
Brazil Studying Charges That Two Were Tortured
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 3 (UPI)The Government opened an inquiry yesterday into charges by a Roman Catholic priest and a socialwelfare worker that they had been tortured and submitted to in dignities in prison.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)The Nixon Administra tion announced today a $1.2 million program to train unemployed engineers and sci entists in the shrinking aero space industry for jobs in other fields. The announcement was made by Dr. Edward David, the President's science adviser, and Assistant Labor Secretary Mal color Lovell.

title: Investors Put Money Into Levi's
description: Levi Strauss & Co., which has been producing blue denim jeans since the days of the California gold rush, proved a big hit with investors yes terday as it offered its shares publicly for the first time.

title: Opulence Marks Moroccan Envoy's Fete
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  At tonight's party at the Moroccan Embassy, olive skinned Ambassador Adessa deq elGlaoui was marvelous to behold in his native desert white djellaba, but the most opulent sight at the party had to be the Ambassador's wife.

title: PRINCIPAL WEIGHS EFFECT OF LAYOFF
description: Substitute teachers are the safety pin in the diaper. It's the diaper that does the main job, but it can't do that with out the pin.

title: Reagon Urges Huge Cut In California Relief Rolls
description: LOS ANGELES, March 3 Governor Ronald Reagan pro posed today that California's welfare costs be cut by forcing hundreds of thousands of re cipients off the rolls and by cutting back sharply on the medical care provided for those who remain.

title: Israeli Stand Worries Eastern Europe
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 3  Rumania, the only Eastern European nation that maintains diplomatic relations with Israel, accused the Israeli Government today of blocking the path to a negotiated set tlement in the Middle East.

title: Wichita State Drops Coach
description: WICHITA, Kan., March 3 (AP)Gary Thompson is not being retained as head basket ball coach at Wichita State University. Thompson's three year contract expired at the end of the season, in which Wichita State finished last in the Mis souri Valley Conference.

title: Poll Finds Nixon Rating Lowest After Saigon's Invasion of Laos
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  President Nixon's popularity fell to the lowest level of his Presidency shortly after the South Vietnamese invasion of Laos, despite his recent appeal for support of domestic re forms, the Gallup Poll reported today.

title: NIXON SETS MESSAGE ON MANPOWER TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 President Nixon will ask Con gress tornorrow for a $2billion manpower retraining program, Administration officials said to night, and will follow this up with a $2billion request for community and urban develop ment on Friday.

title: U.S. AND URUGUAY SCORED ON DR. FEY
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., March 3The wife and son of the American agricultural adviser who was held for seven months as a hostage in Uruguay ac cused the State Department and the Uruguayan Government to day of lack of action and re fusals to negotiate with the Tupamaro guerrillas.

title: ExRep. Martin in Race
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., March (UPI)  Former Representative James D. Martin said yesterday he hopes a strong controver sial race would develop be tween himself and Postmaster General Winton M. Blount next year for the Republican nom ination for the Senate seat of John J. Sparkman, a Democrat.

title: Experts Assure House SST Would Not Be Harmful
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 Consulting scientists on the Government's supersonic trans port program told the House Appropriations Committee to day that though their research must continue they could al ready estimate confidently that SST's would not be environ mentally harmful.

title: Vatican Urged to End Ban on Suicides Burial
description: ROME, March 3A Vati can commission recommend ed today that the Roman Catholic Church lift its an cient ban on religious burial for suicides, heretics and Freemasons.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 4, 1971

title: At Aldo Parisot's Cello Recital, 2 World Premieres
MISS PORTNEY GIVES DEBUT PIANO RECITAL
description: If the competition were to be held tomorrow to choose the pianist who, can play fastest and loudest, Arlene Portney might be a strong contender for, the title. This young virtuoso, who made an execellent im pression a few weeks ago as soloist with the Youth Sym phony of New York, was pre sented in her recital debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tues day night by Carnegie Hall Jeunesses Musicales, Inc.

title: Judge in Jersey Clears a Suit on Sex Education
description: TRENTON, March 3  A New Jersey Superior Court judge has refused to dismiss a legal challenge to a state law that requires attendance at sex education classes in communi ties that have voluntarily made them part of the curriculum.

title: Appalachian Regional Unit Supported by White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)The White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said today the Administration had no objection to a Senate committee's recommendation to extend the Appalachian Re gional Commission for four years instead of one as pro. posed by President Nixon.

title: Chess: Kevitz Defense Can Lead To Classic or Modern Play
description: The Kevitz Defense1 PK4, NQB3is a singular deploy ment that grants the second player much latitude in plan ning his campaign of resist ance to White's firstmove initiative. The pattern may transpose, for example, to a sound and solid classical one of, say, the Ruy Lopez, or something akin to a hyper modern one in an Alekhine's Defense, where Black is will ing to sacrifice time and space to provoke White into over extending himself.

title: Defense Lawyer, Assailing Lisbon Court, Resigns
description: LISBON, March 3 One of the lawyers defending a Ro man Catholic priest and nine others charged with having links to Angolan nationalists withdrew today on the ground that the defense of his clients has been rendered impossible.

title: Theater: Inept Macbeth From Yale
description: NEW HAVEN  When a production of Macbeth is dedicated to the science fic tion writer Arthur C. Clarke, and even a program note has to be dedicated in somewhat selfseeking and gratuitous honor of Peter Brook, the expectations are raised high. But they are very soon cast down by the Yale Repertory Theater's inept and oldfash ioned staging of Shake speare's play.

title: H. J. Heinz Raises Profit to Records
description: The H. J. Heinz. Company, processors of an extensive line of food products including catchup, baby foods and cat food, posted record sales and earnings in the three and nine months ended Jan. 27, the Pitts burghbased company reported yesterday.

title: Education Official Defends School Layoffs at City Council Hearing
description: Members of the City Coun cil's Finance Committee charged at a stormy hearing yesterday that the Board of Education's announced layoff of teachers and other personnel was a charade to obtain more school funds to cover up the board's poor fiscal planning and man agement.

title: THOMAS NASON, 82, ENGRAVER, IS DEAD Artist Won Awards Here Also Honored Abroad
description: OLD LYME, Conn., March 3 Thomas W. Nason, engraver and artist, died yesterday at Lawrence Memorial Hospital in New London. He was 82 years old and lived here.

title: Hamilton Six Wins, 60
description: CLINTON, N. Y., March 3 (AP)Hamilton College scored five goals in the first period and defeated William College, 60, in hockey today Mike Thomas scored twice. The shut out was the first of the season for Greg Root, who had 26 saves.

title: LawyerLegislators
description: To the Editor: The unbelievable abuse to which, motorists are subjected by auto in surance companies is matched by the disgraceful failure of New York State to protect the driving public.

title: President Of Adelphi Resigning
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 3  The president and two vice presidents of Adeiphi University submitted their resignations to the board of trustees late today.

title: Big Board Moving Ahead With Negotiated Rates
description: The New York Stock Ex change is moving forward with plans to implement negotiated brokerage commissions, on the portion of all stock transactions above $500,000 and apparently will not try to bargain with the Securities and Exchange Com mission for a higher cutoff level.

title: ROUTE IS BLAMED IN WICHITA CRASH
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) A Federal board said today that the Wichita State Univer sity disaster in which 31 per sons died, could have been avoided if the copilot of the chartered plane had realized a minute sooner that he was flying into a deadend canyon.

title: Summer Begins Early With Network Repeats
description: In television the summer season now comes before the Ides of March. For the first time in the home screen's his tory this. coming Sunday's hour between 10. and 11 o'clock wiltconsist, of repeats of earlier Presentations, an economy move that a decade ago did not occur before the flowers began to bloom.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Your Future in the Sea 1971, the fourth annual symposium of the American Littoral Society, will be held at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, on Saturday from noon to 11 P.M.

title: PIPELINE AN OLD ONE, PENTAGON CONCEDES
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 Defense Department officials conceded today that a three foot length of gasoline pipe line, displayed to reporters last week by Lieut. Gen. John W. Vogt as having been cut from the Ho Chi Minh Trail complex during the current incursion into Laos had in fact been ob tained earlier.

title: Car Sales Up for Month But Lag in Last 10 Days
description: Spurred by strong performances of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, new car sales rose in February, reports from Detroit indicated yesterday. Sales of the nation's Big Four car makers registered a de cline in the final 10day pe riod of the month but there were seven selling days last year and only six this year. On the basis of a daily selling rate, industry sales were up for the period.

title: Negro Migration to North Found Steady Since 40's
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 The Census Bureau reported to day that Southern blacks streamed north during the six ties at a rate nearly the same as the high level of the two previous decades.

title: How They Taught Me I Was a Jew
description: You ask me how I came to the idea of leaving the Soviet Union and going to Israel. I think that though I heard about Israel only four years ago my whole life was the way to it. You can see it yourself.

title: Boyle and 2 Aides Plead Not Guilty
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 W. A. Boyle and two oth er officials of the United Mine Workers of America, accused yesterday of making illegal political contributions with union funds, pleaded not guilty today and were re leased without bail.

title: Fly's Condition Delicate
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 3 (AP)Dr. Fly was re ported in delicate condition and resting today at British Hospital.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: To the Editor: The Civil Liberties Union is justified in expressing fears over the abridg ment of the rights of pupils, but I fear it is sighting through the wrong end of its binoculars.

title: Javits Finds Hope For Trade Peace
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Senator Jacob K. Javits said in a Senate speech today that if the Japanese textile in dustry agrees to voluntary re straints on exports to the Unit ed States, it will contribute to the prospects of trade peace rather than trade war in the nineteenseventies.

title: UMass Official to Retire
description: AMHERST, Mass., March 3 (AP)Warren McGuirk, dean of the School of Physical Edu cation and director of athletics at the University of Massachu setts, announced today he planned to retire on Jan. 1, 1972. The 65yearold former Boston College football star, joined the university's staff in 1948.

title: RELIGIOUS VIOLENCE KILLS ONE IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, March. 3 (Reu ters)Snipers firing from roofs killed one man and injured an other today in the northern city of Aligarh, where five persons were killed in fighting between Hindus and Moslems yesterday.

title: Doctors Study in Zoos to Aid People
description: New York Medical College announced yesterday that it was, expanding a program to encourage some students and, doctors to leave its hospital arid to study in the city's zoos.

title: Bridge: Perkins, Dean of Columnists, Was Also a Player of Note
description: The dean of American bridge columnists died last month in Boston. Frank Per kins was 79 years old, and his column in The Boston Herald had appeared contin uously since 1931. He shared with Johannes Brun of Nor way the distinction of being the world's oldest writer on the game.

title: Israel and the Canal
description: To the Editor: On the somewhat safe assumption that, once the Suez Canal is reopened, the waters from the Red Sea to the Persian Gulf will be dotted with Soviet trawlers and warships, I wish to pose three hypothetical questions:

title: Seale Clashes in Court
description: NEW HAVEN, March 3 Bobby G. Seale, the Black Pan ther national chairman, clashed physically with guards and verbally with the judge today as a 12th juror was selected for his trial in the death of a fellow Panther, Alex Rackley.

title: Recommendation That Japanese Government Monopoly Need Not Print Cigarette Warning Is Assailed
description: TOKYO, March 3A Gov ernmentappointed commission's recommendation against print ing healthhazard warnings on cigarette packages was attacked by health experts and news papers today as a case of put ting the national treasury be fore the national health.

title: In the 40's, He Created Today's Look
description: HOLLYWOODThe glam our capital is gloomy these days. Two major studios are on the verge of giving up, and lines at the box office are dwindling while lines in the unemployment offices that service the film com munity are growing.

title: To Cook Japanese Style, It Helps If You Have Obliging Butcher
Trial Told of Panthers' Chagrin After Police Foiled Sniper Plan
description: Defendants in the trial here of 13 Black Panthers were up Set, and one of them limped, following a shootout on the Harlem River Drive that alleg edly marked the failure of a plan to snipe at policemen, an undercover agent testified yes terday.

title: 2 BANKS HERE CUT MORTGAGE RATES
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank and the Chemical Bank  fol lowing a move kicked off in this area last month by the Franklin National Bank  an nounced yesterday reductions in their minimum interest, rates on new conventional home mortgage loans to 7 per cent from 7 per cent.

title: TEACHERS LEADERS BOW TO JERSEY WRIT
description: NEWARK, March 3  Three officials of the Newark Teach ers Union said today that to avoid going to jail they would obey a court order and tell members of their union to end their fiveweekold strike.

title: Roosevelt Room Dedicated
description: WASHINGTON, March 3, (UPI)  Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. dedicated the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Dining Room at Blair House today at a gath ering of family and friends from the Roosevelt era. The late President's son donated the cost of the refurbishing project in historic Blair House.

title: Apollo 16 Crew Named
description: HOUSTON, March 3 (UPI) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named Capt. John W. Young and Lieut. Comdr. Thomas K. Mattingly 2d of the Navy and Lieut. Col. Charles M. Duke Jr. of the Air Force to fly the Apollo 16 lunar landing mis sion in March, 1972.

title: Teamster Talks Deadlocked
description: PHILADELPHIA, March (AP)Negotiations in the two dayold strike by the Teamsters Union against 12 private trash haulers remain deadlocked. Nearly 3,000 tons of refuse has piled up each day in commer cial, industrial and institutional buildings here. A union spokes man said the men earn $3.25 an hour and are seeking a $1an hour increase in a threeyear contract. He refused to say what the haulers were offering.

title: The New Red Cross
description: In seeking ways to meet the specific needs of our changing times, the Red Cross is acquir ing a new look. The Red Cross, as is widely known, is with the armed forces all over the world, and local chapters pro vide emergency communica tions, counseling and other assistance to servicemen's families. The part Red Cross plays in the collection and distribution of blood and blood products is also well known.

title: Distribution of U.S. Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The following tables, based on census data show the increasing distribution of the black population throughout the major regions of the country.

title: President Accountable
description: To the Editor: This is in reply to the comments by Allan Gordon and Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath [letters Feb. 22] on Vice President Spiro T. Agnew's Feb. 9 letter.

title: Democrats Urge Ban on Gifts in Major Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  The top officials of the Demo cratic National Committee pro posed today that private citi zens and organizations be pro hibited from making contribu tions to candidates for Presi dent, Vice President, the Senate and the House.

title: House BiII Calls for Team To Oversee Vietnam Vote
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)A Houge resolution to send a 15member team of United States observers to over see South Vietnam's Presiden tial election in October was introduced today by a group of 43 Representatives.

title: 10,000 Honor Daley At a Dinner by Labor
description: CHICAGO, March 3 (UPI) Mayor Richard J. Daley was honored by labor tonight in what was .described as the largest dinner ever served under one roof.

title: GRAEBNER DEFEATS MULLIGAN, 64, 62
description: HAMPTON, Va., March 3 (AP)Clark Graebner of New York and Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia won secondround matches tonight in the, United States indoor tennis tourna ment.

title: NASSAU RACE WON BY RUNNING TIDE
General Is Accused Of Ousting a Major For PX Exposures
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)An Army major testi fied today that he had been ousted from his job amid ru mors there was a price on my head because he had tried to disclose corruption in the oper ation of service clubs in Viet nam.

title: LINDSAY WILL ASK FOR PAYROLL TAX; ENDS PARITY FIGHT
description: Mayor Lindsay has decided to ask for a city payroll tax that would supersede the cur rent city income tax and pro duce far more revenue.

title: FREE SPEECH CURBED IN MALAYSIAN CRISIS
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 3 (Reuters)The Malay sian Parliament today ap proved a controversial constitu tional amendment bill that will curtail free speech even among members of Parliament on sen sitive issues likely to inflame racial hatred.

title: 9 P.M. News Conference Is Planned by President
description: WASHINGTON, March 3) (AP)President Nixon will hold a 30minute news con ference devoted entirely to questions on foreign policy at 9 P.M. tomorrow, the White House announced today. The presidential press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said it ap peared appropriate to limit the session since it followed the State of World Message.

title: METS ENCOURAGED BY SEAVER DEBUT
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3Tom Seaver pitched two innings in a practice game today in his first appearance of the spring, and reported no twinges from the tired arm that gave the New York Mets their worst fears of 1970.

title: Dr. Howard D. H. Brown, Ophthalmologist Here, 72
description: YONKERS, March 3  Dr. Howard D. H. Brown, an oph thalmologist, died at his home here Monday, apparently of heart attack. He was 72 years old.

title: Wilson Says Labor Would Bar Arms for South Africa
description: LONDON, March 3Harold Wilson, leader of the Opposi tion, said today that if his Labor party recaptured the Government it would stop any arms sales to South Africa be gun by the Conservatives.

title: Rangers Overcome Seals at Garden, 81
description: Showing little sympathy against an overwhelming col lection of Golden Seals, the Rangers last night piled goal upon goal and trounced the Californians, 81.

title: Round Top's Director, 22, Now on Trails in Vietnam
North Carolina Wins Title
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., March 3 (UPI) North Carolina recov ered from a shaky start tonight to clinch the regularseason At lantic Coast Conference title in convincing fashion by downing North Carolina State, 9781.

title: New Lighting in the Pantheon
description: Benjamin Franklin was so clearly visible in his own lifetime and in the years since that Mr. Fleming's claim to offer a new look at this conspicuous Founding Father appears a little puzzling. One would imagine that the niche and the figure in are fixed. A little more light might add an emphasis here, alter a facet there, cor rect a shadow. But the monument would remain substantially the same. What have changed over the years are our views and judgment of the man. To some he is the epitome of the resourceful, pragmatic, shrewd, acquisitive American, skipping no opportunity for selfadvancement. To oth ers he is a smug, selfsatisfied, material istic fanatic of practicality. He has been criticized by those who like to see aristo cratic graces leaven our culture and by others who miss in the man a spiritual breadth. D. H. Lawrence thought he was a little too wise in his own conceit. The pop ular notion, of course, is that of an im mensely versatile man, who made his mark in trade, in science, in politics, in letters. Having also made his fortune by middle age, he set a pattern by retiring to work for the public weal. In all things he was calm, balanced, controlleda born negotia tor. These judgments all evoke the same differ.

title: HUNGARIAN QUARTET IN 3 BARTOK WORKS
description: The Hungarian Quartet per forming the string quartets of Bartk would seem an ideal pairing, if only for sentimental reasons, and the veteran en semble and the music came to gether on Tuesday night at Hunter College Playhouse. All six masterpieces in the form by the Hungarian composer are being offered in two programs, the second being scheduled to morrow night, in commemora tion of the 25th anniversary of his death here on Sept. 26, 1945.

title: Space Lights Traced to Cosmic Rays
description: Scientists believe they have traced the mysterious flashes of light reported by Apollo as tronauts, in periods of other wise total darkness, to high speed cosmic rays passing through the retinas of the astro nauts eyes.

title: Geiger's Approach at Brown: Total Commitment to Athletics
description: Andy Geiger, the newly ap pointed director of athletics at Brown, has a refreshing and idealistic approach to in tercollegiate athletics. He said yesterday: Any non competitive league or con ference loses it validity.

title: Volkswagen Sales Down
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N. J., March 3 (UPI)Volkswagen of America, Inc., reported a drop in United States car sales last month to 40,187 units from 41, 322 in February 1970.

title: Statement by Cornfield
description: Mr. Cornfeld said through his attorney, Abraham G. Levin of Rubin, Wachtel, Baum & Levin, that at no time has he admitted the S.E.C. allega tions and he continues to as sert that he has never violated any of the securities laws.

title: Nyquist Nullifies 2 Actions of Board In Mount Vernon
description: ALBANY, March. 3  State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist ruled today that the Mount, Vernon Board of Education had acted illegally and violated the rights of a Negro. board member by failing to provide adequate notice of two meetings of the board in 1969 and 1970.

title: And in the Gold Robe ... Joe Frazier
description: Which heavyweight cham pion of the world threw, a fashion tantrum yesterday?

title: POSTAL UNION CHIEFS SIGN MERGER ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) The leaders of five postal unions signed today agreements to form a single, 320,000mem ber organization.

title: MARILYN COCHRAN VICTOR IN SKIING
description: LA PLAGNE, France, March 3 (Reuters)  Marilyn. Coch ran, the 21yearold star from Richmond, Vt., Won the giant slalom, the first event in the French national skiing cham pionships, today. Her time was 1 minute 26.24 seconds.

title: St. Patrick's Concert Set
description: Zubin Mehta will. conduct Verdi's Te Deum and Saint Saens's Symphony No. 3 for Orchestra and Organ in a con cert given at St. Patrick's Ca thedral on March 21 at 8:30 P.M. to benefit the 1971 Catho lic Charities and Education Ap lead. Tickets are available at the Cathedral Rectory, 460 Madison Avenue, and will be obtainable at the cathedral on the evening of the performance.

title: EXANTITRUST CHIEF ASSAILS U.S. POLICY
description: CHICAGO, March 3 (AP)A former Assistant United States Attorney General said today that the Justice Department's antitrust policy was a threat to subordinate all business to arbitrary Government control.

title: Opera: An Exciting Trovatore at Met
description: If lustiness were all, the performance of Il Trovatore at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night would have been a great one. On its own terms, these being the size and quality of the voices, it was fine and exciting, an obvious source of pleasure to the audience.

title: Mandela's Wife Sentenced
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, March 3 (Reuters)Mrs, Winnie Mandela, wife of the imprisoned black nationalist leader, Nelson Mandela, was sentenced today to a year's im prisonment for having violated an order restricting her move ments. Her counsel gave notice of appeal, and she was released on bail of $420.

title: Track Revenue Increase Gets Legislature's Final Approval
West Out for Season With Injury
description: LOS ANGELES, March 3 (AP)  Jerry West, injured last night in a game at Buffalo, will be out of action for the rest of the National Basketball Association sea son, the Los Angeles Lakers said today.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson Routs St. Francis Five, 8249
description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., March 3Fairleigh Dickinson scored its fifth straight victory tonight and lowered its defensive aver age, the best in college basket ball, to 53.9 points a game with an 8249 romp over St. Francis College of New York,

title: Designer Snowdon
description: The jolly good scrub in the tub may be on the way out in Englando. The team of Lord Snowdon and Terrance Conran, an industrial de signer, created this futuristic steel shower unit for the British Steel Corporation. It was demonstrated by a model during London's Ideal Home Exhibition Monday. Water sprays from jets on the floor, sides and ceiling; a de vice releases soap bubbles, and hot air does the drying, instead of a towel.

title: BREAKDOWN FEARED IN RAIL RULES TALKS
Planning Commission Calls Hearing on Buying Theater
description: The City Planning Commis sion yesterday set next Wednes day as the date for a special public hearing on whether the city should pay $2.6million in capital funds for the Public Theater, home of the New York Shakespeare Festival.

title: GEORGE SEARLE, 73, STATE POLICE AIDE
description: ALBANY, March 3 (UPI)  George M. Searle, retired depu ty state police superintendent, died Sunday at Albany Medical Center. He was 73 years old.

title: Stewart Cuts Record
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, March 3 (UPI)  Jackie Stewart of Scotland shaved more than half a second from the Kyalami track record, today when practice started for Satur day's South African Grand Prixfirst event on the 1971 Formula One world champion. ship season. Driving a. Tyrell Ford, he negotiated the 2.55 mile circuit in 1 minute 19.7 seconds, sixtenths of a second faster than the .lap record of 1:20.3, set by Dave Charlton, local driver.

title: JURY IS STUDYING ITALIAN PICKETING
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn is investigating the actions of members of the ItalianAmerican, Civil Rights League who have picketed out side The Staten Island Advance to protest the use of the terms Mafia in newspaper articles.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Wednesday's Fight

title: Scientists Review the Objectives Of Jupiter Voyage Starting in 72
description: REDONDO BEACH, Calif., March 4 One year from now American scientists will launch a small spacecraft into a totally unexplored area, the vast, si lent space beyond the earth's nearby neighbor Mars.

title: Cambodian Refinery Attacked
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 4 (AP)The Cambodian high command reported that North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops attacked Cambodia's oil, refinery in Xompong Som to day and cut off Government troops sent to bolster the de fenders.

title: TRACKS REBUFFED IN MONOPOLY CASE
description: A Federal judge here refused yesterday to dismiss a com plaint by a group of horse owners and trainers charging the New York Racing Associa tion, The Jockey Club and their directors with conspiring to monopolize the racing industry in New York to the injury of the horsemen.

title: Panel Is Told Medical Schools Face Money Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  Officials of Johns Hopkins Med ical Institutions told Congress today that a majority of the nation's medical schools were in critical financial condition and that theirs was broke.

title: Knicks Play 76ers, Opening Long Weekend
description: A weekend of hard work against their main rivals in the National Basketball Associa tion's Atlantic Division could earn the Knicks at least their starters  two weeks of com parative leisure.

title: Nixon Declines to Move
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 President Nixon declined today to recommend a course of ac tion to the Turkish Government in connection with the kid napped American airmen.

title: Screen: Tales of Horror:Graves and Monsters Share Double Bill
description: Don't be fooled by those lurid titles, the promotional ads and the hi-fi sidewalk growling piped from those posters fronting the Penthouse Theater. "Horror of the Blood Monsters" is nothing but a dull, excruciating and unfrightening little science-fiction flapjack that looks and smells like a piece of green cheese. In a couple of scenes, some apelike extras, inhabitants of some planet or other that looks like Arkansas, nibble smearily at each other's shoulders.The other half of the double bill, "Five Bloody Graves," is a plain, cotton-picking and perfectly awful little Western without a single gory grave. Its sole virtue is that everybody in itsome saddlesore derelicts, stagecoach survivors and sourfaced Indiansgets knocked off, with one inexcusable exception, the guy who wrote it. This is Robert Dix, son of the late Richard Dix, who plays a sheriff.What both pictures, directed by Al Adamson, amount to is a three-hour John Carradine film festival, since the veteran actor totters around in both, with that rumbling voice and his eyebrows still arching to his hairline. In the first mess, he sits at a control board yelping directions to the space travelers, played by some of the worst actors on this or any other planet. Never mind who they are.In the second one, he plays a lecherous preacher, wearing a close facsimile of his old "Stagecoach" garb. And, believe it or not, some of the scenic magnificence of the background, Monument Valley, Utah, suggests the old classic movie. This time, though, they've even done in Mother Nature.

title: Retail Sales in Week Up 3%
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales for the latest week ended Feb. 27 was an estimated $605million.

title: Uniroyal Hails Happy Days and Network TV Results
description: Uniroyal which until 1967 was called U.S. Rubber, is happy about network televi sion, which is nice since it spent about $7million in it last year and plans to do so again this year.

title: The House Rings to Laughter and Harmonica Music as Old Grads Hold Nostalgic Reunion
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 The old grads came back to Congress today and, for a few brief hours, it seemed as if they had never left.

title: Connecticut Directive
description: HARTFORD, March 4 (UPI) The heads of all Connecticut state departments and agen cies were directed by Gov. Thomas S. Meskill today to eliminate the use of the words Mafia or Cosa Nostra from any news releases, speeches, public documents or other public statements.

title: KY SEEKS STEPUP IN U.S. AIR SUPPORT
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 4  Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that unless South Vietnamese forces in Laos received increased American air support, they would be in a difficult situa tion.

title: Gen. Sergei Varentsov Dead; Hero Demoted in Spying Case
description: MOSCOW, March 4, (Reuters) Former Soviet Marshal Ser gei S. Varentsov, who was de moted to the rank of major general after a spy scandal in 1963, has died at the age of 70, it was announced here to day.

title: SNOWSTORMS LASH NORTHEAST REGION
description: Punishing winds and driving snow lashed the Northeast yes terday, producing heavy snow accumulations inland and peril ous conditions along the coast.

title: Defending Army Engineers
description: To the Editor: Your recent editorial Death of a Boondoggle does an injustice to the Civil Works branch of the Army Corps of Engineers in that it would make them vicar for the sins of others, notably our porkbarrel Con gressmen.

title: DOLE BACKS CURB ON CAMPAIGN FUND
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  The Republican National Chair man, Senator Robert Dole, split with several other party lead ers today by supporting some realistic limit on the amount of money a candidate could spend on his campaign.

title: James Felt, Former Chairman Of City Planning Agency, Dies
description: James Felt, a wealthy real es tate developer who dedicated many years to public and phil anthropic service and was former chairman of the City Planning Commission, died yes terday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: Western Newsmen Pushed After Visiting Moscow Home
description: MOSCOW, March 4 (Reuters) Two Western correspondents were pushed by Soviet men in plain clothes today as they left the apartment of a Jewish engi neer.

title: Senate Panel Approves Vote for 18YearOlds
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI)  The Senate Judi ciary Committee unanimously approved a constitutional amendment today that would give 18yearolds the right to vote in all elections.

title: Mayor Seeks $9.2Million for Methadone
description: The city has requested $9.2million in state funds to quadruple its methadone maintenance treatment pro gram to reach 9,000 addicts in the next 12 months, May or Lindsay announced yester day.

title: Saigon Battalion Is Flown 7 Miles Farther Into Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, March 5South Vietname ese forces in Laos have be gun a new move westward in their drive to cut the North Vietnamese supplytrail net work.

title: ALEX TAYLOR SINGS GASLIGHT PROGRAM
description: Alex Taylor of the family whose bestknown member is the folksinger James Taylor, is attempting to begin a perform ing career with a first New York appearance through Mon day at the Gaslight, 116 Mac dougal Street.

title: Chotiner Resigns Post at White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  Murray M. Chotiner, President Nixon's longtime political ad. viser, resigned from the White House staff today to enter pri vate law practice here.

title: Hollywood, Inside and Out
description: Two bulletins from the Dream Factory: the autobiography of one of its discontin ued products, and a fiction about the pack aging of a model that never reaches the market. Sandra Berkley has a good idea for a novel in Coming Attractions. Chap ter titles mark the stages in a Hollywood moppet's growing upChild Star,, The Awkward Age, Ingenue, Starlet, Leading Lady. The twist is that Cassie Keen lives through all these phases on the fringes of the industry, without ever arriving in front of the cameras. She has a mother whose name changes from Diligence to Hedy to Myrna as whim and new hair colors strike her; and a stepfather who's an assistant director so feckless that an exasperated star once tried to kill him with a nail file. Cassie attends Hollywood High where the fantasy of fame floats over the campus like a giant balloon, then a seedy dramatic academy where she learns more about sex than about acting. The peak of her career is her wedding on a radio show, to a juice bar proprietor, followed by a fadeout into domesticity.

title: FORDHAM QUINTET TRIUMPHS, 81 TO 68
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  Fordham improved its basket ball wonlost record to 222 tonight by downing George town, 8168, before 4,000 fans at McDonough Gymnasium.

title: A Free Man in Uruguay
description: I'm happy and excited about finding myself among free men again, said Claude L. Fly on his release after being held hostage for seven months by Uruguay's Tupamaro terrorists. Americans and Uruguayans will share that happiness with Dr. Fly and his family, along with the hope for his rapid recovery from the heart attack that obviously led to his release.

title: 3 Girls, 5 Youths Seized as Muggers In Times Sq. Area
description: A ring of youthful muggers who the police said used young girls as lures and operated in the Times Square area were arrested yesterday. The gang, the police reported, was al legedly responsible for 75 to 100 muggings since the first of the year.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: LOOKING for a Black Board Director? See Business & Society ad page 57.Advt.

title: QUEENS MOTHER OF 3 CHARGEDWITH ARSON
description: A Queens mother of three children was arrested yesterday on an arson charge after she reportedly started a fire in her topfloor apartment in a seven story 51family brick building at 7536 Bell Boulevard in Bay side.

title: Catholics Raise $8.4Million in Drive for U.S. Poor
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 The United States Catholic Conference announced today that more than $8.4million had been raised to help the poor in the most successful national collection ever conducted by American Roman Catholic churches.

title: Furman and W. and M. Win
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 4 (UPI)  Furman beat The Cit adel, 9582; and William and Mary downed Virginia Military Institute, 6965, tonight in the first round of the Southern Conference basketball tourna ment.

title: BEN PEARSON, 72, ARCHERY FIGURE
description: PINE BLUFF, Ark., March 4 Ben Pearson, who popular ized archery as a modern sport by devising a machine to make bows and arrows, died Tues day evening of a heart attack. He was 72 years old.

title: Tarkeshwari Sinha
description: NEW DELHI, March 4  Tarkeshwari Sinha, a promi nent member of the Old Con gress party, has soft features and a mellifluous voice, both belying a tough spirit and a fiery tongue, which she has used successfully during the three decades of her political career. Now 44 years old, she has represented her dis trict in Bihar State in Parliament since 1952, winning each of the last four elections by large majorities. She is ex pected to win again this time. Her reputation as a blister ing orator has won her many followers, especially among the young. She has led stu dent movements in Patna and is still a popular leader of students there. For them she is a firebrand but in Parlia ment she is known as glamour girl.

title: Tax Stimulus to Economy This Year Is Urged by 2 ExGovernment Officials
