While I do not foresee a quick turnaround in the company's operation, I am certain that the picture will change for the better in the second half of the year.

title: 35,000 Are Delayed on Three Rail Lines
description: An estimated total of 35,000 Penn Central riders were delayed for up to 80 minutes by series of mechanical problems during the morning rush hour yesterday.

title: Australian Yacht Triumphs In 1Ton Cup Sailing Race
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand March 5 (UPI)  The Australian yacht, Stormy Petrel, skippered by Syd Fischer, captured the OneTon Cup sailing championship today.

title: Red Sox Top Astros
description: COCOA, Fla., March 5 (UPI)  Mike Nagy, Cal Koonce and Gary Wagner limited the Houston Astros to eight hits today as the Boston Red Sox gained a 43 victory in the opening preseason game for both teams.

title: RIOTER IN ULSTER KILLED BY TROOPS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, March 6 (AP)British troops poured into a riottorn Rorrian Catholic district of Belfast early today and opened fire on bombthrowing demonstrators. One civilian was killed and two were wounded, the army said.

title: Ali Shadow Boxes, Slips. Trying to Leap Backward
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 5 With the fight only three days away, Muhammad Ali refrained from sparring at the Fifth Street gym today. Instead he went through what his trainer, Angelo Dundee, called a shakeout, defined by Dundee as keeping loose and doing his own thing.

title: Pope's Attacker Has Hearing
description: MANILA, March 5 (UPI)A psychiatrist testified today that Benjamin, Mendoza y Amor Flores had at first planned only a symbolic act against Pope Paul VI but then changed his mind and decided to kill the Pope. Dr. Manuel Pardo, who practiced in the United States for several years, testified at a hearing to determine whether the Bolivian painter is mentally and emotionally fit to stand trial on a charge of attempted murder in the attack here last Nov. 27 during the Pope's Asian tour.

title: Nixon to Address Ensigns
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)President Nixon will address a graduating class of Navy ensigns, including his soninlaw, David Eisenhower, next Friday at Newport, R. I., the White House said today. Mr. Eisenhower has been attending the Naval Officer Candidate School at Newport.

title: The Talk of London, Ont.
description: LONDON, OntarioMany Londoners are shocked to find that Canada's economic slump, accompanied by generally heavy unemployment, has touched this normally busy, typical industrial city in the heart of Ontario's golden triangle.

title: American Indians to Meet
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) The National Congress of American Indians will sponsor a conference starting Monday in Kansas City, Mo., to discuss forthcoming Federal legislative proposals on Indian affairs.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: PARISIt is going better than seems, but we shall have to have our crisis.

title: U.S. Group Is Briefed In Paris by Hanoi Aides
description: PARIS, March 5 (AP)An American citizens group trying to learn more about the issues of the Vietnam war met with North Vietnamese officials today. A conflict was shaping up over a meeting with United States officials.

title: Draft Call Put at 17,000 For Fourth Straight Month
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)The Pentagon said today that it would draft 17,000 young men in April, all of them for the Army.

title: Rolling Stones Quit Britain
description: LONDON, March 5 (AP)The Rolling Stones are moving from England to the French Riviera, Mick Jagger announced today, but he denied that they were breaking up or retiring. We felt we needed a change of scene, temperature and climate; the 27yearold star told newsmen after a concert in Newcastle launching a national Farewell to Britain tour.

title: Allan Nevins, Historian
description: A newspaperman once himselfon The Post, The Sun and The WorldAllan Nevins brought to the writing of American history and biography a journalist's curiosity, dedication to balanced judgment and lively readability. These qualities, along with a scholarly mind, made his Ordeal of the Union, an account of the Civil War period, the sort of history one reads for knowledge as well as pleasure. These attributes infuse his prizewinning biographies of Grover Cleveland and Hamilton Fish.

title: 3 YOUTHS ARE SEIZED IN SUBWAY DISORDER
description: Three Manhattan youngsters were charged with malicious mischief and tampering with subway property after they allegedly vandalized an IRT subway car in the Bronx yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editors
description: To the Editor: Your entertaining [Feb. 19] news article Business and Labor Help Edit Politics Out of a Tax Form highlights the inequity of the present tax law: It's O.K. for the Internal Revenue Service to ask churches and schools about their politics. But when it comes to the Chamber of Commerce or the National Association of Manufacturers it's a nono. [Editorial Feb. 25.]

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Mayor Lindsay announced this week that the city was going to buy Yankee Stadium, make it pretty and comfortable, then lease it to the Yankees on attractive terms, he became the first of three public officials whose recent exploits deserve enshrinement in some special sports Hall of Fame. The busts flanking Lindsay would be of Howard J. Samuels, president of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, and Dr. A. Harry Kleiman, a senior physician with the State Athletic Commission.

title: ThriftShop Eclectic: One Way to Decorate
description: It is quite possible to decorate an apartment successfully with very little money, if you provide another essential ingredient: imagination.

title: Japanese Farmers Losing the Battle of Narita Airport
description: NARITA, Japan, March 5Ever so gently, a leafless tree, three young; farmers in helmets still clinging to its trunk, was lowered to the ground. A power saw had severed the tree from its roots, but a cable and hook suspended from a crane kept the tree from falling while policemen below prepared nets to receive the men.

title: CONGRESS ASSURED ON 8 U.S. HOSPITALS
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) Witnesses for the Nixon Administration assured Congress today that eight Public Health Service hospitals threatened with closing would be kept in operation this year although no funds had been budgeted for them.

title: WIESNER NAMED TO TOP M.I.T. POST
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 5  The Massachusetts Institute of Technology reorganized its top administration today as it named Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, a 55yearold electrical engineer and former presidential science adviser, as its 13th president.

title: Music: Atlantans Visit
description: Some of the grandiose plans that came in a few years ago with the new cultural center in Atlanta have disappeared, but not the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra under Robert Shaw. That thrives, as much as any symphony orchestra in this country can thrive today. On Thursday night the group and its conductor paid New York a visit, giving a Carnegie Hall program as part of the International Festival of Visiting Orchestras.

title: Move for Calm in Decca
description: DACCA, Pakistan, March 5 (Reuters)Sheik Mujibur Rahman sent peace patrols to bring order to the cities of East Pakistan today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Auto Output Is Steady
description: DETROIT, March 5 (AP)United States auto production remained unchanged this week from last week's level as continued heavy overtime by the General Motors Corporation was offset by cutbacks by the Ameritan Motors Corporation.

title: 76ers Subdue Knicks, 121116
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 5 The Knicks lost twice tonight, and it was hard to figure out which setback hurt more.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: Blues Beat Leafs, 31
description: ST. LOUIS, March 5 (UPI)Jim Roberts and Christian Bordeleau scored goals against Jacques Plante within a oneminute span of the third period tonight to give the St. Louis Blues a 31 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: WINNIE LIGHTNER, 71, OF STAGE AND FILMS
description: SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., March 5 (AP)Winnie Lightner, a stage and film actress of the twenties and early thirties, died at her home of a heart attack today. She was 71 years old.

title: AMEX STOCKS RISE IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock pxchange made a strong advance yesterday in the heaviest trading in almost three weeks.

title: Rangers Will Seek 7th Victory in Row At Detroit Tonight
description: The New York Rangers will carry a sixgame winning streak into the Olympia tonight when they face the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game that will be tele vised in New York over WOR (Channel 9) beginning at 8 o'clock.

title: DICKINSON LEADS DORA BY STROKE
description: MIAMI, March 5Bruce Fleisher, a 22yearold golfer who lacks credentials to play on the pro circuit, moved into a tie for second place today after two rounds of the $150,000 Doral Eastern open tourney. He scored a fiveunder par 67 for a total of 139.

title: Dance Workshop Gives New Ballets, Touches All Bases
description: Choreographer Art Bauman habitually transforms the commonplace gesture into art, Kathryn Posin blithely explores, firstimpression emotionalism, and Jack Moore delves into the ritualistic and shadowy areas of experience.

title: Nixon Asks Consolidation Of Housing and Urban Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 5President Nixon asked Congress today to consolidate several major housing and urban development programs into a $2billion urban assistance program for rebuilding the cities.

title: Aftereffects of Storm Prove a Help and a Hazard
description: Aftereffects of the midweek snowstorm created opportunities for clam diggers in Asbury Park yesterday but hazards for motorists in convertibles on the George Washington Bridge.

title: New Issues Gain Is Paced by Debut Of Levi Strauss
description: Paced by the spectacular debut of Levi Strauss & Co. the newissue market resumed its upward course this week in heavy trading.

title: Lindsay Delays Publicly Detailing New Tax Plan
description: Mayor Lindsay deferred the public unveiling of his package of new taxes yesterday after his top officials briefed Governor Rockefeller's advisers.

title: Trucleau Congratulated on Marriage
description: OTTAWA, March 5  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, no longer Canada's most eligible bachelor, was warmly congratulated by political friends and foes today on his surprise marriage last night to Miss Margaret Sinclair. The bridegroom is 51 years old and the bride 22.

title: St. Joan Ticket Prices Cut
description: The Survival of St. Joan, the medieval rock opera playing at the Anderson Theater, has cut its ticket prices to $2, $3 and $4. Haila Stoddard and Neal DuBrock, producers, said they have adopted the temporary policy to permit audiences to make up their own minds about the work. The show received only one favorable notice.

title: Rockefeller Signs Bill Extending Race Year
description: ALBANY, March 5Governor Rockefeller put his signature today on a bill that lengthens the thoroughbred racing season by nine days and increases the parimutuel betting takeout by 1 per cent.

title: Allan Nevins, Historian, Dies; Winner of Two Pulitzer Prizes
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., March 5Allan Nevins, the historian and biographer who won two Pulitzer Prizes and pioneered in the establishment of the oral history movement, died today in a nursing home after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Pakistan's Leader Says the Assembly Will Meet March 25
description: NEW DELHI, March 6 (Reuters)President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan of Pakistan announced today in a speech monitored here that the first session of the new National Assembly would be held on March 25.

title: $120aWeek Clerk Is Seized as Embezzler of $380,000
description: A $120aweek clerk who had the responsibility of seeing that those to whom the GAF Corporation owed money were paid was arrested here yesterday, accused of embezzling $380,000 over the last two years.

title: Father and Son Among 4 Indicted in Bronx Murder
description: Four men, including a father and son, were, indicted by a Bronx grand jury yesterday on charges of murder and attempted murder.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: Prof. Charles Machines, British Historian, 79, Dies
description: LONDON, March 5  Prof. Charles Malcolm Macinnes, a former professor of imperial history at Bristol University, died today in a Bristol hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: JIMMY BRESLIN SUED IN PLAGIARISM CASE
description: A $350,000 damage suit alleging plagiarism and literary piracy against Jimmy Breslin was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court in New York on behalf of Fred Ferretti, a member of the staff of The New York Times, and a frequent contributor to New York magazine.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: PIRATES WIN, 21, FROM WHITE SOX
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March (UPI)  Three errors by the Chicago White Sox plus a brief wild spell by Hal McClain, rookie lefthander, staked Pittsburgh to two unearned runs and a 21 victory today in the opening spring preseason game for both clubs.

title: Dr. Elmer E. Schattschneider, Political Scientist, Dies at 78
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., March 5 (AP)  Dr. Elmer E. Schattschneider, a former president of the American Political Science Association, collapsed and died last evening as he prepared to discuss Congressional politics at a Civic Club meeting. He was 78 years old.

title: Bucks 19th in Row Sets Mark;
description: DETROIT, March 5 (UPI)Lew Alcindor and Oscar Robertson, who have sparked Milwaukee all season, dominated the game with the Detroit Pistons tonight in leading their team to a 10895 victory that gave the Bucks 19 straight triumphs  a National Basketball Association record.

title: Merger News
description: The board of LingTemcoVought, Inc., approved yesterday a definitive agreement for the sale of its 100 per cent stock ownership in the Okonite Company to OmegaAlpha, Inc., for $40.5million.

title: Lockheed Cool to Package
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation all but rejected yesterII:lay Britain's package proposal for saving the RollsRoyce jet engine developed for the Lockheed L1011 air bus. But the company left the way wide open for more negotiating.

title: Yale Downs Dartmouth
description: NEW HAVEN, March 5Jim Morgan and Scott Michel combined for 52 points tonight in leading Yale to a 93.80 victory over Dartmouth.

title: TV: The Magic of Peter Brook Studies Director
description: There it was, right on battered Broadway, the soothing spectacle of two backtoback hits. If the success of No, No, Nanette was something of a surprise, the standingroomonly response to A Midsummer Night's Dream has been little short of stunning. Shakespeare boffo on Broadway? Without bigname stars? in a production impertinently ignoring tradition?

title: Agency Aides Shown. Evidence Of Pollution in Flushing River
description: An oil  soaked plastic cup scudded across the gray, Flushing River yesterday and came to rest in the spokes of an old tricycle wheel half imbedded in the riverbank.

title: Apollo 14 Astronauts Welcomed in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, March 5 (AP)Thousands of Chicagoans gave a warm welcome today to the three Apollo 14 astronauts, their families and members of their recovery team.

title: MRS. WILLIAM CHARLES
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 5  Mrs. Kathryn Davies Charles, widow of William A. Charles, former president of Charles & Co., one of New York's oldest grocery concerns, died Wednesday at her home, 949 Palmer Road. Her age was 91.

title: White Plains Melee Ended Quiet Year
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 5The rampage by black high school students Wednesday that has kept this city's schools closed for two days did much more than property damage.

title: Her Goal: Better Office Decor
description: WASHINGTON  Mrs. James B. Allen, wife of the junior Senator from Alabama and a: petite mother of four, is going into business next month as an interior deccirator. One of her goals: to Improve the surroundings that people work in.

title: Egypt to Hold Fire
description: CAIRO, March 5The Egyptian leadership has decided to continue withholding fire along the Suez Canal after the expiration of the ceasefire this weekend to give a last chance to diplomatic efforts for a peaceful settlement with Israel, reliable sources here reported today.

title: Money Would Be for Engine
description: LONDON, March 5  The British Government has offered to invest an additional $144million in development of the RollsRoyce RB211 engine.

title: Letters to the Editors
description: To the Editor: I take exception to a letter in your Feb. 23 issue from Franz Willenbucher opposing.the Episcopal Church's stand on General Motors and the Republic of South Africa. Both the stand and its rebuttal do not deserve space.

title: MRS. J. R. BARTHOLOMEW
description: Mrs. Lelia Belle Sparrow Bartholomew, widow of James R. Bartholomew, a former banker here, died Wednesday in North Falmouth, Mass. She was 83 years old and lived in Wellfleet, Mass.

title: PRISON GUARDS SEE HARASSING BY CITY
description: The president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association accused the city's Board of Correction yesterday of harassing prison guards.

title: Rogers Asks Vote for GermWar Ban
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 Secretary of State William P. Rogers urged the Senate today to approve the 1925 Geneva protocol banning chemical and biological warfare but with the understanding that the United States Would remain free to use tear gases and herbicides.

title: New Capital Bomb Scare
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)  The Commerce Department Building, a block from the White House, was evacuated for 90 minutes today after man telephoned its switchboard and said, There's a bomb on the third floor. No bomb was found. Nearly 5,000 persons who work in the sevenstory building milled about outside until the bomb search was ended.

title: 42 Held in Drug Raids In Massachusetts Towns
description: QUINCY, Mass., March 5 (AP)Quincy and state police arrested 42 persons tonight in drug raids in a number of South Shore communities. The police said warrants for 13 other persons had been issued.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator Kennedy's article on the Inequities of the Draft should be carried one step further. Since a volunteer army would be manned primarily with the economically disadvantaged, military would be in the hands of society'smost frustrated classthe poor. It is not difficult to imagine such an army dictating policy during times of se'ere depression or anarchy. Wasn't control of the Russian Army one of, the deciding factors in the Bolshevik victory?

title: Shop Talk
description: When Ohrbach's invited a few people in to preview its spring and summer shoe collection the other day, a lot of misgivings turned to sighs of relief. Since Ohrbach's fashion experts are usually faithful disciples of the European couture, the audience was prepared for the clunky 1940 shoes the French and Italian designers showed with their clothes this season. Happily, the store didn't take the couture's sermons verbatim, as it had last fall when many of the shoes looked like Dr. Schollrevisited. The new collection is airy, colorful and decidedly pretty.

title: THANT BIDS ISRAEL AGREE TO GIVE UP ALL EGYPTIAN SOIL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5 Secretary General Thant appealed publicly to Israel today to reconsider and respond favorably to a request by Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary, for a commitment to withdraw her forces from all Egyptian territory.

title: Maoist Strategy Likened To Complex Game of Go
description: CAMBRIDGE. Mass., March 5To Scott A. Boorman, a 21yearold Harvard student who was born in Peking on the day the Red Army entered the city, Maoist revolutionary strategy in China is very much like giant game of go. In an attempt to help the Western mind grasp the enigma of China, he has built a simulation model in which Chinese military and political moves are likened to the complex methods by which a player of the oriental board game goknown as weich'i by the Chineseattempts to isolate, encircle and capture enemy pieces.

title: JOHNSON, HUMPHREY AT ENGELHARD RITES
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., March 5 (AP)Some of the nation's most, prominent Democrats, including former President Lyndon B. Johnson, paid final respects today to Charles Engelhard, multimillionaire industrialist and one of the party's largest financial backers.

title: PRICE OF GLYCERIN IS RAISED BY P. & G
description: The Procter & Gamble Company raised Prices yesterday effective Aprill on all gylcerin grades by 1. cent a pound, making P.&G.'s average price 21 cents a pound Glycerin is used making soap.

title: Diagnosis on Mete Agee: Minor Infection of Kidney
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 (AP)  Tommie Agec, outfielder for the New York Mets, is suffering from a minor kidney infection, docotrs said today after viewing Xrays.

title: STANLEY LEVEY, 56, LABOR REPORTER
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 Stanley Levey, labor editor of the ScrippsHoward Newspaper Alliance, died yesterday at George Washington University Hospital. He was 56 years old.

title: Man hi the News
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 5As a youngster growing up in Dearborn, Mich., Jerry Wiesner would often run downtown after school to watch the pitched battles between the automobile union men and the Ford goon squads. At about the same time, the enterprising youth, the son of a Jewish drygoods merchant, was confounding the power linemen with a private telephone system he had strung up along their poles to keep in touch with his classmates. Witnessing the union conflict imbued the promising young engineerscientist very early with a keen social awareness. Today Jerome Bert Wiesner's career has culminated in his election as the president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, one of the world's leading centers of research in the natural and social sciences.

title: Milwaukee Theater Aide
description: Nagle Jackson, former resident director of the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco, has been named artistic director of the Milwaukee Repertory Theater. He succeeds Tune Yalman, who withdraws from the post at the end of this season.

title: Giants Rout Cubs, 94
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 5 (UPI)Bobby Bonds and Ken Henderson hit home runs and Dick Dietz added three hits today to lead an 18hit San Francisco attack enabling the Giants to outlast the Chicago Cubs, 9.4, in the first preseason game for both clubs.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW PRICE RISE
description: A Government report showing that stocks of soybean oil had decreased last month sent prices of soybean futures up nearly 21/2 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. However, heavy selling near the close of trading almost earased the price rise in the nearby options.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)  The State Department again blamed the Soviet authorities today for the continued harassment of Americans in Moscow.

title: Pilot Wants Frazier to Retire, Win or Lose
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 5Joe Frazier sparred, today for the last time before Monday night's heavyweight championship bout with Muhammad All and perhaps for the last time in his career.

title: The Screen: Minus Sugar
description: Parents Interested in exposing the children to something really nice, bright and festive on the screen and aimed specifically at the youngsters, are urged to take them to The Phantom Tollbooth. This perfectly dandy animated feature is playing matinees today and tomorrow at neighborhood theaters in the metropolitan area and repeating next weekend as this season's final offering of MetroGoldwynMayer's excellent series of movies for the small fry.

title: PHANOR EDER, 90, LAWYER, IS DEAD
description: Phanor J. Eder, an international lawyer, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital at the age of 90. He lived at 29 Washington Square West and Stormville, N. Y.

title: Absence High at Freeport
description: FREEPORT, L. I., March 5Almost 900 of Freeport High School's 2,300 students were absent today in the wake of yesterday's racial disturbances that resulted in 10 injuries and the closing of the school at noon.

title: George Upham Harris Is Dead; Headed Stock Exchange Firm
description: George Upham Harris, retired board chairman of Harris, Upham & Co., Inc., member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in New York.

title: Market Place  2d Lawsuitilits Glen Alden Plan
description: The Glen Alden. Corporation's plan to merge Schenley Industries, Inc., into the parent company met another potential roadblobk yesterday with the Jfiling of the second lawsuit in two days to thwart the, plan.

title: Chadian Reports on Pullout
description: FORTLAMY, Chad, March 5 (Agence FrancePresse)President Francois Tombalbaye said today on his return from talks in Paris that French troops assigned to help Chadian forces fight Moslem rebels in the northern part of the country would be withdrawn on schedule. He did not amplify his statement.

title: Nixons Fly to Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md., March (UPI)President and Mrs. Nixon flew today to Camp David, their mountain retreat now blanketed in four inches of snow, for a weekend visit., The Nixons were expected to return to Washington in time for a worship service late Sunday morning in the White House.

title: To Hell or to Connaught
description: I have shared many rewarding experiences with fellow liberals, but find it difficult to understand their acceptance of Oliver Cromwell as champion of freedom. Today, they are undoubtedly filling the neighborhood theaters, where this 17thcentury butcher is being portrayed as a courageous Liberator.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Why resist the temptation to be relevant? The question nags historians as it does other scholars. The world is turning; needs knowledge; and possession of learning carries the obligation to attempt to shape events. Every crisis lends weight to the plea: transform the library from an ivory tower into a fortress armed to make peace (or war), to end (or extend) social inequality, to alter (or preserve) the existing economic system. The thought boosts the ego. Perhaps power really does lie in command of the contents of books!

title: Nyquist Orders an Inquiry On School Board Spending
description: ALBANY, March 5  State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist ordered an investigation today into the $40million budget deficit in the New York City school system to determine whether the Board of Education had overspent its current budget in violation of the State Education Law.

title: JAPAN TV MAKERS WILL FIGHT RULING
description: TOKYO, March 5Japanese television manufacturers said today that they would fight to the finish against the United States Tariff Commission's ruling that they had dumped television sets on the American market.

title: In an Indian City, the Real Issue in an Election Riot That Killed 13 Is Religion
description: ALIGARH, India, March 5The shoemaker's shop of S. M. Yusuf All and Sons was open at the usual hour. But neither the shopkeeper nor any customer was in signt.

title: PENN WINS 25TH ROUTING CORNELL
description: ITHACA, N.Y., March 5Pennsylvania raced to a 238 lead in the opening 10 minutes and then coasted to a 10864 victory over Cornell tonight in an Ivy League game.

title: Executive Changes
description: Frontier Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of A. L. Feldman as president and chief operating officer. Until now he has been president of the Aerojet Nuclear Systems Company, a division of the AerojetGeneral Corporation. Jack H. Vollbrecht, who is president of Aerojet General, will assume additional duties as chairman of Frontier. His leadership of Aerojet remains unchanged. E. Paul Burke, president of the airlinesince January, 1969, moves up to vice chairman. The actions were taken at a special board meeting in the New York headquarters of RKO General, Inc., which owns the controlling interest in Frontier. RKO and AerojetGenoral are both, subsidiaries of the General Tire & Rubber Company.

title: SCRIBNER IS FIRM ON SCHOOL ORDER
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner said yesterday that he will not honor payrolls that are in violation of Board of Education policies requiring cutback in school personnel starting Monday.

title: Murder Suspect Arraigned
description: Ross Jones, 29 years old, who was arrested Thursday and accused of the murder nearly four years ago of Lawrence Feldman, a theatrical producer and lawyer, in his Murray Hill penthouse apartment, wal arraigned yesterday before Criminal Court Judge Irving Lang. He was held without bail for a hearing March 23.

title: Furman Upsets Davidson
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 5 (UPI)Jerry Martin scored 36 points to lead Furman to an 8379 upset of topseeded Davidson tonight in a semifinal game of the Southern Conference tournament.

title: Harvard Tops Brown, 6560
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., March (AP)  Harvard opened a big early lead and posted a 6560 victory over Brown tonight.

title: Long Island Man Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) The Defense. Department announced today that Pfc. Douglas J. Crawford of Bay Shore; L. I., had been killed in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Dispatchers Back Pilots On Plan to Help T.W.A.
description: Trans World Airlines flight dispatchers have moved support fully the airline's pilots in their program to hold down the company's ordinary operating costs and to promote new traffic. Howard Swift, chairman of the T.W.A. Flight Dispatchers Group, Transport Workers Union of America, said in an interview yesterday that the group's local chairmen had met with W. A. Murphey Jr., chairman of T.W.A.'s Master Executive Council of the Air Line Pilots Association, and both groups now hoped to get the endorsement of other unions, including the machinists and the hostesses.

title: MRS. F. REID ISAAC
description: IRVINGTON, N.Y., March 5Mrs. Sharon Spalding Isaac, wife of the Rev. F. Reid Isaac, rector of St. Barnabas Episcopal Church here, died today of a heart ailment in Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown. Her age was 38.

title: Offer by Israel
description: NABLUS, Israelioccupied Jordan, March 5 (AP)Israel's Deputy Premier, Yigal Allon, said here today that his country was prepared to negotiate Middle East settlement with Egypt without any preconditions on borders provided that Egypt would do the same.

title: Council Gets Bills to Bar Withholding of Apartments
description: Two bills to force landlords to rent the thousands of usable apartments being with held from the residential market was introduced yesterday in the City Council by Councilman Carter Burden.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: Needed Federal Tax Lifeline
description: The enormous new city and state taxes confronting New Yorkers drive home the necessity for a massive program of Federal revenue sharing. Whatever the argument over the size and thrust of President Nixon's taxsharing plan, one point is undebatable: the Federal Government alone can raise funds in a manner that will enable New York and other metropolitan centers to meet their huge needs without drying up industry and driving away their most productive citizens.

title: Mrs. LeeMrs. Hesseltine Triumph in Platform Tennis
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 5  Mrs. S. Warren Lee of Short Hills, N.J., and Mrs. C. E. Hesseltine of Rumson, N. J., took the first woman's national senior platform tennis doubles championship today at the Stanwich Club.

title: COLOMBO IS JAILED IN JEWELRY THEFT
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 5Joseph Colombo Sr. was arrested with five other persons today in connection with the theft of $750,000 in jewels in Nassaui County three years ago.

title: CHURCH IN POLAND HINTS STATE AMITY
description: WARSAW, March 5 (Reuters) The Roman Catholic. Church cautiously hinted today at prospects for improved relations with the state following talks between Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski and Premier Piotr Jaroszewicz.

title: Puppets as an Art Form
description: Papier mache painstakingly molded into shape, washes of paint, scraps of fabric, and voila into being come an enchanting group of hand puppets, reminiscent of the imaginative creations of the 19th century.

title: Broadcasters Ask Repeal Of Equal Time Provision
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) The National 'Association of Broadcasters urged today the repeal of the socalled equal time law so as to permit major party candidates for President and Vice President to debate on television next year.

title: BARNARD GROUP OFFERS NOVELTIES
description: Art is long and life is short, and no one knew it better than the 18thcentury opera impresario, whose custom it was to break up long, serious works with oneact diversions known as intermezzi.

title: 2 DIE IN ANKARA IN HUNT FOR G.I.'S
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Saturday, March 6Two persons were killed and more than a dozen wounded yesterday when students exchanged shots with troops trying to enter a university dormitory in search of four kidnapped American airmen. One of those killed was a student and the other a Turkish soldier.

title: Ford Hits Britain On Labor Situation
description: LONDON, March 5 (Reuters)  The Ford Motor Company will no longer export spare parts made in Britain to the Far. East, Henry Ford 2d said today.

title: Letters to the Editors
description: To the Editor: In my, Jan. 19 letter I presented certain facts which were overlooked under the initial shattering impact of the cyclone disaster by many East Pakistanis and foreigners alike. That, for doing so; I have been subjected to abuse by Kazi S. Ahmed [Feb. 19 letter] and that The Times should have printed is perhaps the most tolerable of the Misfortunes resulting from that catastrophe.

title: Yankees Subdue Senators In Exhibition Opener, 61
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March. 5It's not often that an, experienced general maneger of a major league club can find himself surprised, in the second inning of the first exhibition game of the season, but Lee MacPhail found himself in that situation today.

title: BRUCE B. PAYNE
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., March 5Bruce B. Payne, founder and retired president of the Payne Coal Company, died Wednesday at the age of 81.

title: COURT IN PHILIPPINES BACKS BACHE ON RAID
description: MANILA, March 5 (AP)The Philippine Supreme Court has ordered the Tax Bureau to withdraw a $380,000 assessment against Bache & Co. (Philippines) and to return the concern's files, which were seized in a raid a year ago.

title: I.C.C. Sets Pennsy Hearing
description: The Interstate Commerce Cornmerce Commission yesterday fixed April 26 for a hearing for crossexamination of respondents in its investiption of thecitciamstances, behind the financial collapse last year of the Penn Central Transportatton Company.

title: Spitz, Hall Set Marks In Big Ten Swimming
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 5 (UPI)Indiana continued its assault on the, record books in the second night of competition in the Big Ten, swimming and diving championships tonight.

title: James Farmer Sees Peril in Tax Sharing
description: James Farmer, the civil rights leader Who resigned three months ago as Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, warned yesterday that cities might use Federal revenuesharing funds to disperse blacks who had begun to gain political power.

title: Soviet Jew Seized on Walk With a Reporter in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, March 5 (AP)Two Soviet policemen arrested a young Jew today as he walked, on a crowded Moscow street with an American correspondent. The incident occurred outside the Lenin Library shortly after an Associated Press correspondent, Roger Leddington, met Mikhail Spivak.

title: Teamster Vice President, Five Others Indicted in Counterfeiting
description: NEWARK, March 5Salvatore Provenzano, a vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was arrested today and  charged with conspiring with five others to operate a counterfeit ring dealing in United States currency, postage and food stamps.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: 3Alarm Blaze Fought At Church in Village
description: A threealarm fire raged through a 125yearold Episcopal church in Greenwich Village early this morning.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: Tobin and Kheel in Clash On Port Unit Transit Role
description: Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, told a joint New YorkNew Jersey legislative committee yesterday that the twostate agency would never take on any mass transportation projects that might endanger its highly respected financial position.

title: C. W. Post Students Vote To Retain Varsity Football
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., March 5  The movement to save intercollegiate football at C. W. Post College made an important gain today as anoverwhelming number of students voted in favor of the sport.

title: STAKEOUT UNIT KILLS 2 DURING BURGLARY
description: Two men allegedly robbing a Queens motel were shot and killed by a police stakeout team early yesterday morning.

title: Holy Cross Names Ed Doherty To Be Its Head Football Coach
description: Edward A. Doherty, a former Boston College quarterback who was called The Brain by teammates for his innovative style, yesterday was named head football coach of B.C.'s sturdiest rival, Holy Cross College. Doherty, 52 years old, replaces Bill Whitton, who resigned recently for personal reasons.

title: At the FrenchWest German Border, Lots of Amity and a Little Friction
description: KEHL, West Germany  In this bustling German border town on the east bank of the Rhine opposite Strasbourg, French buses mingle casually with the local traffic, French soldiers sip period with German girls at corner bars, and on Europe Bridge, Kehl's only road link to France, the French tricolor and the black, red and gold ensign of West Germany flutter side by side in the breeze.

title: Washs ington Notes
description: WASHINGTON, March 5President Nixon overruled three Cabinet members, the chairman of his Council of Economic Advisers and his postal chief when he made his decision last week to curb inflation in the construction industry by suspending certain provisions of the DavisBacon Act. A few of his key advisers and almost all of the bureaucracy  including George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development; John A. Volpe, Secretary of Transportation, James D. Hodgson, Secretary of Labor, and Winton M. Blount, Postmaster Generalurged the President to impose a wageprice freeze. Indeed, Mr. Hodgson had gone some lengths during a visit to Miami to prepare labor leaders for such a solution.

title: Manta Draws High Weight For $100,000 Coast Race
description: Everything Lovely, owned by Colin Campbell, and 10 other fillies and mares, 4 years old $1:2 up, were entered yesterday for today's $100,000 11/8mile S'anta Margarita Invitation Handicap at Santa Anita.

title: LA SALLE DEFEATS LAFAYETTE, 7471
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (UPIJohn Maull, a sophomore, came off the bench to score 12 points in the last 10 minutes and led La Salle to 7471 victory over Lafayette tonight in the Middle Atlantic Conference University Division playoffs at the Palestra.

title: Theater: Bentley Revue
description: The Red White and Black is Eric Bentley's patriotic demonstration of his disaffection with America. As Bentley sees it, the red white (and blue) is mostly black.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES FUEL FUND FOR SST
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)  President Nixon's ftlil $290million request to keep supersonic transport development on schedule cleared a House subcommittee today in the face of heavy opposition in Congress to any further SST funding at all.

title: BATTLE EXPECTED NEAR LAOS TOWN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 6  More South Vietnamese troops moved westward across the enemy's supplytrail network in Laos yesterday, and helicopterborne advance units were reported preparing a ring of troop landing zones near the key junction town of Tchepone.

title: GAF Head Fights Dissident
description: Jesse Werner, chairman and president of the GAF Corporation, urged stockholders in letter mailed out yesterday to reject a bid for control, of GAF by a group of dissidents and to support the management slate fdr electien at the annual meeting April 16.

title: Linden Continues Inquiry Into Blast at Humble Oil
description: LINDEN, N. J., March 5 (AP) Mayor John T. Gregorio said today he was not completely satisfied with a company report attributing the Dec. 5 explosion at the Humble Oil and Refining Company plant to equipment failure, not sabotage.

title: Lindsay Panel to Study WNYC's Future
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday creation of a sevenman committee to study the future of the Municipal Broadcasting System. One area of study is the feasibility of creating a Public Broadcasting Center here.

title: Legislatures Across U.S. Seek Tough Laws Against Pollution
description: For the last two years, everyone has been talking about pollution. Now, in state capitals across the country, officials are becoming more concerned with doing something about it Just how successful they will be must await the outcome of legislative sessions and the fate of countless bills.

title: David Rockefeller Urges Rise in Trade With Reds
description: ROME, March 5The chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, David Rockefeller, called today for more United States trade with the Soviet and Chinese Communist blocs to replace the Iron Curtain with a plateglass curtain.

title: MARKET ADVANCES AS TRADING SOARS
description: The New York Stock Exchange ended the week with a bang as the DowJones industrial average took another big jump yesterday and volume was the third highest in history.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A letter by Drs. George Contis and Warren. H. Hem of the Office of Economic Opportunity (Feb. 20) raised a number of questions about Federal programs of family planning services and population Tesearch. The Family Planning Services and Population Research Act of, 1970 which I introduced in early 1969 was Signed into law by the President on Dec. 24 with a statement of Administration commitment to the full implementation of the legislation.

title: Message to Cairo
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The United States sent a private message to the Egyptian Government this week appealing for continuation of the ceasefire and indicating that Washington would work for future flexibility from Israel in the Middle East negotiations.

title: CENSORSHIP LIMIT IMPOSED BY COURT
description: Limits on school censorship of student publications were set by the United States Court of Appeals here yesterday in a decision that weighed student rights to free expression against school needs for orderly education.

title: Louisville Awaits Vice Inquiries Set Off by Open City TV Show
description: LOUISVILLE, March 6There Is a feeling of suspense here these days as citizens wait to see if a grand jury and Federal investigators discover a major vice scandal.

title: The City
description: Urban crisis has become one of the great clichs of our time and the words don't seem to have impact anymore. But what they mean to someone living in New York City is simply this: The average family here will pay something like $600 more in taxes next year for worse schools, dirtier streets, more crimeand more and more welfare.

title: Announcements
description: BERNSTEINFrances and Louis. Very best wishes for your golden wedding anniversary and many more. Miami papers please copy. Your loving family, LEONARD, SHIRLEY and STEVEN.

title: Marjorie Jane Most to Be a Bride
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 6 Miss Marjorie Jane Most of New York, whose ancestor, Thomas Dudley, served as Governor of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, and Was a founder and one the first overseers of Harvard University, will be married to Stewart Leigh Wilson Jr. of Washington April 17 in Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va.

title: Queens Considering 32Story Towers
description: Queens Community Planning Board 13 is studying plans of private developer to erect three highrise luxury apartment towers in the nearrural setting of the Glen Oaks Country Club.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Yankees Shut Out Orioles
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 6More nourishing fodder for Yankee optimism was produced by today's 20 victory over the Baltimore Orioles than by yesterday's opening triumph over Washington.

title: BALLOT INDICATES MAIL STRIKE END
description: LONDON, March 6Balloting by union members indicated today that Britain's prolonged postal strike will be over on Monday.

title: The World
description: The Punjabis of West Pakisten and the Bengalis of East Pakistan are divided by history and culture as well as by 1,000 miles of territory. The division lies behind the political ferment that has been growing in recent months and last week threatened a breakdown in Pakistan's governmental process.

title: Court Orders Minneapolis To Hire Nonwhite Firemen
description: MINEAPOLIS, March 6 The Minneapolis fire department, which has been allwhite since 1962, may have at least 20 black or Indian faces by midsummer as a result of a Federal court ruling this week.

title: We die sooner, pay more, and East Germany
description: For 40 years, American medicine successfully resisted the attentions of the welfare state. While every other major industrial nation in the world adopted some form of national health insurance, the United States evolved the purely private system for financing medical costs. Most people relied on insurance for hospitalization or catastrophic illness, and paid other bills themselves. The poor (which for medical purposes included most of the elderly) survived, or expired, on charity.

title: Letter to the Editor 23  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Both John Simon and Andrew Sarris have served film more than they have harmed it. In the face of their public battle in The Times, I think this should be remembered.

title: Danes
description: SOME of my best, friends are relations, but you do, just, occasionally, get tired of relationships am thinking, or if not thinking at least pondering, about a couple of New York resident companies, the City Center Jaffrey Ballet and the Nikolais Dance Theater. Joffrey has been at City Center and the Nikolais troupe has been taking part in the City Center's grand, gala and gorgeous marathon (what an odd word for them to choose marathon?) of American moderndance at the ANTA Theater.

title: Barbara Ann McGuire Betrothed
description: Miss Barbara Ann McGuire, and David S. Cook will be married May 29 in New York.

title: L.I.U. Defeats Iona, 73.71; Finishes With 1015 Mark
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 6Long Island University defeated Iona College, 7371, tonight and ended its season with a wonlost record of 1015. The loss ended Iona's season at 1012.

title: PITTSBURGH SITE CALCULATED RISK Weather Threat to Showing in Three Rivers Stadium
description: PITTSBURGH, March 6 (AP) Nothing short of a blizzard will stop the outdoor closed circuit telecast of the FrazierAli heavyweight fight here Monday night, according to the promoters, who in desperation picked the new Three Rivers Stadium as a fight theater.

title: Headliners
description: Many women have enjoyed his charm, his prestige, his swinging ways. But it took a quiet, 22yearold beauty from British Columbia to make Pierre Trudeau end his renowned bachelorhood. In a ceremony attended only by the families in North Vancouver last Thursday, Margaret Sinclair was married to the 51yearold Prime Minister and thus became the talk of Canada. She is a daughter of Privy Councillor James Sinclair, a member of the Liberal party which Mr. Trudeau heads. The couple had met three years ago on a holiday in Tahiti. The Prime Minister, who prizes privacy, arrived from Ottawa early Thursday for what was described as a skiing holiday and used a pseudonym preparing for the wedding. He may be old, the bride's moth said, but he's a young man at heart.

title: Yale Loses in Lacrosse
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 6Jimmy Martone scored four goals and Tom Postel made three today to lead the Long Island Lacrosse Club to a 167 victory over Yale in the season opener for both teams at Hofstra Stadium.

title: DEMOCRATS SCORED BY DOLE ON VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)Senator Robert 3. Dole of Kansas, the Republican national chairman, said today that most of the Democrats who are considered potential Presidential candidates in 1972 have joined the mob on the left in a concentrated attack on America's defense establishment.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: GRASSY KEY, Fla. Soft and glowing, lingering, a lovely aftersunset light touched the waters of Florida Bay. At our backs, the fronds of coconut palms, whipped by a stiff southeast wind, tossed black against the sky. Before us a girl knelt on a wooden walkway beside the water holding a dead fish and pleading with a dolphin that swam before her to eat.

title: MEETING MR. KRAMNICK
description: I am extremely angry about one particular aspect of Thomas Meehan's article, The Yale Faculty Makes the Scene (Feb. 7). On what evidence does Mr. Meehan characterize Isaac Kramnick as an avowed leftist, whose political views would probably reduce most oldtime Yale alumni to tears? The reader, at this point, I suspect, immediately assumes that Mr. Meehan knows Mr. Kramnick, that they have met and talked, on which occasion Mr. Kramnick made clear his political views, or that Mr. Meehan has read Mr. Kramnick's political writings, or gone to his lectures.

title: Letter to the Editor 24  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Andrew Sarris complains that Simon has baited him; if so, he has risen to the bait with considerable avidity, and indeed might be said to have swallowed the hook. Simon's piece is concerned with criticism; Sarris's response is nothing more than a poison pen letter.

title: Chess
description: AMONG the chess buffs, there is an elite band that plays primarily for blood and fun. The challenge of this tough crew is the adoption by Black of an offbeat debut to outweigh the moveinhand initiative bestowed upon White by the rules of the game.

title: Fans Like the Triple
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March 6  Barring the unforseen, such as the hankypanky that led to the outlawing of the twin double, the triple, introduced in this country at Roosevelt Raceway last Wednesday night, is here to stay.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: GUARD AUXILIARY SAVED 527 LIVES
description: The United States Coast Guard Auxiliary, the yolunteer arm of the United States Coast Guard, grew in size and range of activities during 1970, according to the auxiliary's year end report.

title: For Young Readers
description: Remember some of those games we played as kids? Steal the Bacon, Spin the Bottle, Skip the Rope? Then you shouldn't have any trouble recalling I Spy. That old standby has been turned into a book, ISPY (American Heritage, $3.95), for preschoolers, and in its new form it does much more than just kill an hour on a rainy afternoon. Illustrator Joe Kaufman has supplied 356 clear, colorful and labeled drawings arranged in related groups of fourdesk, ruler, wastebasket, paperclip; dress, hat, coat, gloves, etc. According to authors Lucille Ogle's and Tina Thoburn's brief preface and instructions the book will do everything except provide immunity against scurvy: sharpen powers of observation, develop vocabularies, recognize common objects and printed words, teach relationships. But I don't mean to make sport of the book; it does have usefulness for learning and entertainment. (There are several suggestions offered for playing variations of I Spy.) Parents could do much worse these days.

title: Manitoba Curling Victor
description: QUEBEC, March 6 (AP)Don Duguid of Winnipeg led his Manitoba rink to its second consecutive Canadian curling championship today with an 116 victory over Northern Ontario Bill Tetley from Thunder Bay.

title: The Nation
description: SAIGONWhen South Vietnamese troops thrust across the border into Laos four weeks ago to disrupt Communist supply lines, a key target loomed ahead down twisting Route 9. Less than 30miles away was the rubble of the town called Tchepone, a strategic junction point on the Ho Chi Minh Trail network and long a favorite target of American warplanes. The South Vietnamese appeared to bog down and the target seemed to fade as a major objective. But yesterday afternoon, South Vietnamese troops, some airlifted by American helicopters, landed in the debris and captured the town.

title: Kentucky Tops Tennessee
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March (AP)  Kentucky, the Southeastern Conference basketball champion, pulled away from firedup Tennessee in the final seven minutes today for an 8478 victory.

title: Ban on Whaling Stuns Coast Company
description: POINT SAN PABLO, Calif., March 6The last small remnant of America's whaling industry is reluctant to muzzle its harpoon guns on the killer boats and write finis to the 300year history of adventure on the seas.

title: Art Notes
description: SHOULD artists, like other creators, earn royalties on the sale of their work? Should they have control over how its shown? To these burning questions, of increasing importance in the art world, exhibition organizer Seth Siegelaub and lawyer Robert Projansky say yes.

title: GRADE CROSSINGS A TARGET ON L.I.
description: BABYLON, L. J. March 6The state intends to eliminate at least 44 of the estimated total of 500 railroad grade crossings on Long Island over the next several years in an effort to reduce accidents.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: The argument about Henry Kissinger's status and special powers is only a new version of an old tale. For more than fifty years American Presidents have made a habit of designating special diplomatic powers to persons in whom they reposed particular confidence and who were neither elected nor appointed to regular office in the established manner.

title: Andretti's Ferrari First In So. AfricaGrand Prix
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 6Mario Andretti, driving an Italian factory Ferrari, beat European aces at their own game today to score a rare American Formula One victory in the South African Grand Prix, the first of the 1971 World Championship series.

title: Letter to the Editor 28  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Never has the case against either Andrew Sarris or John Simon been made so eloquently as they each made it against themselves in the Sunday Times. How vituperative exchanges such as this one serve the cause of criticism is beyond me. This was one of those bits of news not fit to print.

title: Education's Revenue Share
description: The compelling argument for revenue sharing is that the states and localities are plainly unable to keep up with the most basic demands for essential services. Except for catastrophically spiraling welfare costs, the crisis of state and local financing is nowhere more apparent than in the schoolsnot only in New York, but certainly including New York. Caught in the squeeze between inflation and taxpayers revolt, education is retreat the very moment when it is neither morally nor politically feasible to shelve again the longdelayed promise of true equality of opportunity.

title: Journey From The North
description: This is the selfportrait of a woman who sees herself divided between the egoist who is also an artist, and the altruistic lover of humanity. It is greatly to Storm Jameson's credit that she paints a picture neither complacent nor selfflattering: in fact, the opposite of these. She really does *tow herself to be an egoist. At the same time a subterranean plea runs through her pages that egoism is necessary to the artist.

title: Russian Writers
description: A literature as powerful and electric as the Russian, as packed with belief and unbelief, has inevitably put something strenuous and pretentious into the debates of its foreign critics. Even in pedestrian Soviet writing the strange void of timelessness survives in pools here and there. We are so anxious to fill them with analyses of our own. Over the years I have turned therefore to the reviews and longer critical articles of Helen Muchnic, a RussianAmerican scholar, for knowledge and good sense. The air of the classroom goes. From Pushkin to Solzhenitsyn she has Russian prose and poetry in her bones. Professor emeritus of Smith College, she has read everything and is as responsive as an artist. Above all, she is selfeffacing and graceful, and she is a good writer before she is an academic.

title: Legislator Scores State Car Insurers On Uses of Profits
description: The assistant minority leader of the State Assembly charged yesterday that automobile insurance companies in New York State were using their profits in outofstate investments to the detriment of state residents.

title: ROCKAWAYS SEEN AS CIVIC TEST TUBE
description: Helped by both geography and practical politics, the Rockaway peninsula may become a laboratory for the city's forthcoming test of neighborhood government.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Henry Alexander Walker Jr. contends that, regardless of what else happens, his $400millionayear consumerserviceoriented conglomerate is going to do better in 1971 than it did in 1970 when it reported record gross revenues and earnings. If an interviewer checked into that confidence a little, he finds it breaking down into three parts;

title: GARBAGE B URGED IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L. L, March 6Concerned with the possibility that Nassau County could run out of landfill sites to dump trash on in 30 years, the County Health Department this week released a report recommending methods of solidwaste disposal for the future.

title: Reader's Report
description: This is the stuff of which librettos used to be madeRio Rita, Girl of the Golden West and other extravaganzas set to hoofbeats and music. The owners of adjoining Texas haciendas at war over an ancient Spanish land grant, mysterious disappearances, secret identities, deathbed confidences and the doublewedding finale in the land of the everlasting rainbow. John Culp, a writer of Class A horse opera, has a lot of fun with these trusty ingredients. Would you like to know what awaits young Colin O'Relley at the end of the long trail awinding from St. Louis to the Chisos Mountains? The true identity of the Spanish beauty he meets on the Mississippi Queen? What really happened to Colin's dad, believed murdered by the villainous Don Sostelo? The houselights dim, the overture commences, and as the curtain rises we see our hero board Mississippi sidewheeler headed for.

title: Hormone Found to Be Cause of Kidney Damage in Rare Hereditary Disease
description: From observations on a set of twin sisters, doctors have discovered that a hormone that circulates in all normal people causes kidney damage in victims of a rare hereditary disease.

title: Senator Edward Sisco, 47; Former Mayor in Jersey
description: WAYNE, N. J., March 6 (AP) State Senator Edward Sisco, a Republican from Passaic County, died today at Chilton Memorial Hospital in Pompton Plains. He was 47 years old.

title: Running Tide Wins S.O.R.C. Title
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, March 6 Jakob Isbrandtsen once asked Sparkman & Stephens to design him a yacht that could win ocean races against established giants of the sea. A year ago he got his boat, Running Tide, and today he got his wish, the championship of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference.

title: National Notes
description: New York City's cabbies knew that the 50 per cent increase in the cost of an average cab ride, effective last Wednesday, would cut into their businessand it did. Taxi rides were down about 19 per cent at week's end, according to an industry spokesman, and tips were off even more.

title: Art Mailbag,
description: To THE EDITOR: Gene Thornton's review of the W. Eugene Smith exhibition at the Jewish Museum fails to perceive the special combination of qualities that make Smith stand almost alone among photojournalists.

title: Columbia Swimmers Bow
description: Columbia's swimming team closed its season with a 012 wonlost record yesterday, bowing to New York University, 60.53, in University pool. After eight events the meet was tied, 35.35, but the Violets outscored Columbia, 2511, in the next four events to clinch the vie tory.

title: Foreign Notes
description: For the 3.8 million people of Norway, the question of whether or not their country should seek to join the European Common Marketat once their biggest market and their largest supplier is fraught with emotional and economic uncertainties. Thus, when a little more than a week ago, the Oslo newspaper Dagbladet printed a previously secret state document reporting a conversation between Norway's Ambassador in Brussels and a ranking Common Market official which cast doubt on the feasibility of Norway's entry, the big mystery was: Where did Dagbladet get the explosive document?

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE WHITE HOUSE reaffirmed support for William J. Casey, whom President Nixon has nominated as chairman of the S.E.C., in a letter to Sen. John J. Sparkman, the Alabama Democrat who heads the Senate Banking Committee. The committee will hold additional hearings on the nomination Tuesday.

title: U.S. Forest Ranger Is Accused of Burying a Mountaineer's Home in North Carolina Land Dispute
description: BALSAM GROVE, N. C., March 6A forest ranger faces a trial in Federal District Court on a charge that he had his men bulldoze a large hole and bury a man's mobile home and barn in it.

title: Sarris Vs. SimonWho Won?
description: To THE EDITOR: John Simon is right about the auteurs. Andrew Sarris is right about John Simon.

title: LETTERS
description: The article on Union Carbide's William S. Sneath (Feb. 14) featured the quotation:

title: Susan Dughi Is Betrothed
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., March 6Miss Susan M. Dughi, a senior at the University of Miami in Florida, and William Thomas Rieder, a graduate of the university, plan to be married this summer in the Dughi summer home in Mantoloking.

title: The Dollmaker
description: To the Editor: It was with great interest and excitement that I read of Harriette Arnow's 1954 novel, The Dollmaker.

title: Movies
description: ONE thing about Ryan O'Neal, he's no Eastern Establishment WASP. I mean, you would think that this kid, who played sweet Rodney Harrington in 519 of Peyton Place's 540 TV episodes and is now reducing an entire nation to tears as Oliver Barrett IV in Erich Segal's mortal Love Story, would at least come equipped with the right Ivy League credentials, You would be mistaken. Furthermore, not only isn't he from the East, he isn't even a kid. Ryan O'Neal has been married twice, has three children and will be 30 years old on April 20. And he has a prison record.

title: Dance Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Mart is to dance what Harold Robbins is to the novel, and what Cecil B. De Mille was to film.

title: Marist College Gives 6 Students Cars and Sends Them Out to Recruit Its Next Freshmen
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 6In a novel experiment in student recruitment, Marist College has sent out six of its undergraduatesgiving them a stipend, an expense account, the use of a new automobile, and academic creditto recruit students for the small liberalarts college.

title: VILLANOVA TAKES I.C.4A TRACK FIFTH STRAIGHT TIME
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 6 Villanova won another Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America indoor track and field title today, but the Wildcats had to share the spotlight with a former shortstop from Rutgers and a Pittsburgh distance runner who says marriage is the way to faster times.

title: To Carolinians, a Green Beret Means a Helping Hand
description: RAEFORD, N. C., March 5 Kenneth Locklear, a 6yearold Lumbee Indian boy, had never been to see a doctor. Doctors, even the two overworked ones in Hoke County, cost money.

title: AIR TICKET THEFTS REAP BIG PROFITS
description: Airlines and law enforcement agencies around the world are trying to combat growing traffic in stolen airline tickets that has reaped huge profits for racketeers on the East and West Coasts.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONTo the men of government, whose in boxes each day nearly always contain some words or figures about the nation's balance of international payments, the issue often seems with apologies in advance for the analogydike Wommen's Lib.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Mary Charlene Faas Fiancee Of Wilford Alexander Smith
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 6Capt. Charles E. Faas, U.S.N., and Mrs. Faas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Charlene Faas, to Wilford Alexander Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Joyce Smith of Southport, Conn.

title: OFFICE OF AIRLINE BOMBED IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sunday, March 7 (Reuters)Terrorists blew up the office of British European Airways here early today.

title: Phone Capacity Outpaced Growth in 70
description: The New York Telephone Company made additions to capacity during 1970 that exceeded growth requirements, according to a new report to Governor Rockefeller by the State Public Service Commission.

title: Fire at St. John's in Village Linked to BreakIn at Church
description: A landmark, preCivil War church on a residential street in Greenwich Village was heavily damaged early yesterday by a fire that raged out of control for two and a half hours. The Fire Department termed the blaze suspicious, noting a report of a breakin at the church shortly before the fire was discovered.

title: The New Music
description: Instead of spreading art among the public, Debussy wrote, I would suggest founding a Society for Musical Esotericism. In fact, to a large part of the public today, the New Music is evidence that this was precisely what happened. Which is the reason a reliable new book for general readers, insofar as the problem is concerned with books, is almost more valuable, and is certainly rarer, than a reliable new specialist book for specialist readers. The New Music is in the first category. And in the second it may conveniently be compared with the recent Princeton Perspectives on Stravinsky and Schoenberg, for these same antipodeans also occupy abdut twothirds of Joan Peyser's pages.

title: Melee Puzzles MusicArt School; Beaten Teacher Lauds Its Spirit
description: People at the High School of Music and Art appeared puztied but not nervous last week over an incident 10 days ago in which a social studies teacher was seriously beaten in a confrontation between black and Jewish groups.

title: Woolf Establishes the Sports Lawyer as Unsigned Stars Best Friend on the Dotted Line
description: A Derek Sanderson watch? Robert Woolf says, hunching forward in his seat. Oh. You mean a watch with Derek's picture. Yes. he says slowly, playing with pencil. That could be an idea.

title: The Press and the Cold War
description: It was a time of evil, Dalton Trumbo reminisced during a recent speech on the McCarthy era, and no one on either side who survived it came through untouched by evil  it will do no good to search for villains or heroes or saints or devils because there were none; there were only victims. That is why none of usright, left, or centeremerged from that long nightmare without sin. Trumbo, one of the Hollywood Ten, spoke on behalf of those like himself who were victimized by the movie industry's anti  Communist blacklist, but his remarks apply to all those Americans a generation ago who lost jobs, were summoned before Congressional committees, sent to jail or harassed publicly for their present or former radical associations.

title: The Brilliant Subculture of Tokyo's Underground Town
description: TOKYOKunio Inoue is a young broker with Tachibana Securities Co. On weekends, he and his wife Emmy like to spend their time shopping, eating or barhopping in the Shinjuku district of Tokyo, the city's largest and most effervescent amusement center.

title: Miss Denys Stetson Is Married
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 6Miss Denys G. Stetson and Duncan Crawford were married here at noon today. The Rev. Franklin K. Robinson performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: What's Opened In the Theater?
description: AND MISS REARDON DRINKS A LITTLE, a play by Paul Zindel, got two favorable reviews, eight mixed and one unfavorable, Clive Barnes: Paul Zindel's play is nearly better than it is. But not quite nearly enough, despite very sympathetic acting from an excellent cast led by Julio Harris and Estelle Parsons. Mr. Zindel places all on the characters of his three sisters, and It is not enough: Too many jokes fall flat, and throughout the whole play there is a pervading air of unreality: It Is difficult to believe in what these people say to one another. And at the end Mr. Zindel can hardly conclude his play and the curtain falls with an unhealthy air of apology. Far from all is lost. Mr. Zindel Is an accomplished writer. And although the situation is unresolved and undeveloped, the sisters theme selves are rewarding parts to play, and the rewarding manner in which these parts are played may, for admirers of acting, well make And Miss Reardon Drinks a Little worth visit. For Walter Kerr, see Page 1.

title: Eisenhower Science Aide Opposes SST
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Dr. George B. Kistiakowsky, science adviser to President Eisenhower, said today that he was definitely opposed to massive public financing of the supersonic transport project.

title: Queens Civic Councils Propose Wide Program to Aid Borough
description: Economy in government is currently the main effort being urged wherever possible by the Federation of Civic Councils of the Borough of Queens, instead of new taxes on beleaguered citizenry such as those proposed by Governor Rockefeller.

title: The World
description: ROME  For the second time in a fortnight, police armor rumbled into an Italian city last week to quell a revolt. The place was L'Aquila, high in the Abruzzi Mountains and a striking change of scenery from Reggio Calabria, the site of earlier riots.

title: Miss Abby Howell Engaged to Officer
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., March 6Miss Abby Howell and Lieut. James Philip Samuels, U.S.A.F., plan to be married in Christ Episcopal Church here March 21.

title: Track Workers and Thoroughbreds Are: Getting Ready as Post Time 1971 Draws Near at Big A Tomorrow
description: While others await a 10:40 P.M. posttime for the FrazierAli fight, New York horseplayers will be more concerned tomorrow with a 1:30 P.M. posttime. The colorsplashed posters in the subways tell the story:

title: Are New Minstrel Men Robbing the Blacks?
description: THROUGHOUT the Negro's painful existence in this country, white Americans have consistently gone to great lengths to prove to him how unnecessary he was in the creation of this huge industrial complex. So effective have these efforts been that many of our most original and gifted black artists, such as Don Byas, Richard Wright, Josephine Baker and scores of others, chose to leave these shores, never to return again.

title: Dundee a Firm Adviser in the Ring
description: At the moment of truth in Muhammad Ali's first championship bout, Angelo Dundee knew what to do.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: THE BATTLE FOR STOCK MARKET PROFITS. by Gerald M. Loeb. Simon and Schuster. 350 pages. $7.95

title: Laotian Center Attacked
description: BAN SON, Laos, March 6Communist troops attacked this principal refugee center of northern Laos early this morning, killing 11 persons, including 3 children, and wounding 17.

title: Adolf Spangenberg Weds Miss Tandy
description: RIVER VALE, N. J., March 6The marriage of Miss Meredith Lynne Tandy to Adolf Spangenberg of Lima, Peru, took place here today at the Edgewood Country Club. Municipal Court Judge Bernard Dorfman of Hillsdale performed the ceremony.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: It isn't too difficult to Imagine the barrage of indignant mail which John Canaday will receive due to his Intruder in the Hothouse tale in the Sunday Times.

title: Manta, $8.20, Scores by Two Lengths in $100,000 Santa Margarita on Coast
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 6 (UPI)Elmendorf Farm's Manta carried her top weight of 126 pounds to a twolength victory today in the $100,000 Santa Margarita Handicap for fillies and mares at Santa Anita.

title: WELFARE EXPERT WARNS CALIFORNIA
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 One of the nation's leading welfare authorities warns California legislators, against accepting Gov. Ronald Reagan's welfare reform proposals before knowing whether they violate Federal statutes.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Dance Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Initially, Clive Barnes stated that Bejart's success in Europe was due to a lack of a strong dance tradition and a poorly educated audience in France. After Mart's initial success here, Barnes reminds us that the New York audience persists in making up its own mind. It is difficult to believe that 50,000 people went to Brooklyn to make up their minds. Then Barnes drags up his inevitable conclusion that Mart's success is due to the efforts of the Belgian Government, Sabena Airlines, sexy lapel buttons, and huge advertisements, plus the lure of inexpensive seats.

title: The New Freedom Rapping
description: SELF DETERMINATION MUSIC John Carter/ Bobby Branford (Flying Dutchman FDS  128). Slicing through, making startling things work, are John Carter and Bobby Bradford, two West Coast Brothers come to lay  I say lay sotnethin really heavy on us with this album of the new music. Like many forms in the new Black consciousness, the new music has sought a design outside the framework previously established by jazz. And, in doing so, reminds us that fresh forms in artistic expression are seldom welcomed with open minds.

title: The New In'Group Is the Guarneri
description: SEVEN minutes before starting time all of the 220 seats were filled in Baird Hall on the Buffalo campus of the New York State University. Left, right and rear on stage 90 or so suppliants were in straight chairs on floor space about right for half that many. Maybe two dozen stood in the aisles and doorways. At stage center were four empty music stands and four empty chairssure portents of a rite to be enacted when the performing ritualists arrived. Until then those present, some 340 at most, could size up the others come to worship.

title: Zug and Terrell Reach Squash Racquets Semifinal
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 6The topranked team of James W. Zug of Philadelphia and Larry P. Terrell of Haverford, Pa., advanced into the semifinal round of the 40th annual Greenwich invitation squash racquets men's doubles tournament today at the Greenwich Country Club.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: Article 14  No Title

title: Criminals At Large
description: Two priests: a defrocked Anglican and an idealistic, liberal Roman Catholic. They can be found, respectively, in Victor Canning's The Great Affair and Jon Cleary's The Lberators (both William Morrow, $6.95). And both raise the question of when mystery fiction ceases to be mystery fiction.

title: A touch of worldliness
description: This duplex residence in a venerable Park Avenue building fills two seemingly opposing functions. The owner is active in philanthropic and world affairs, so many of the rooms are planned for entertaining on grand scale. More often, however, the apartment is a home, a retreat from the bustle of social activity. In designing the rooms for those dual roles, Albert Hadley of Parish Hadley, Inc., sought an atmosphere of composure and serenity. He retained many existing pieces of furniture, refreshed the chairs with bright covers and painted frames, sheathed the living room in sunny yellows, and filled in with comfortable seating arranged in small groups. The distinction of the scheme derives from the exotic accessories from all around the world.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Dropout's Howto
description: What is the Whole Earth Catalog? It is a survival kit of tools and techniques for communards who don't yet know howtodo it, a recipe book for city dwellers whose fantasy life could use some gourmet foods. It is a lexicon of arcane and practical wisdom telling how to order from the Walter T. Kelly Bee Supply Super Market, where to get The Cultivator's Handbook of Marijuana; how to build a log cabin, play the autoharp, construct a working digital computer for less than $5, and bury the dead. It is both the sorcerer and the apprentice, able to make the breathtaking leap from the inner space of organic foods to the spacedout forms of cities by Paolo Soleri and Moshe Safdie in one page.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: To Understand Greece, Go to Lia (Jan. 31), by Nicholas Gage, was an excellent article except for one major fault. Mr. Gage states that the people of the villages are strongly in support of the junta. I believe he was wrong to include all the people of the villages in this opinion.

title: Haley Returns to Steelers
description: PITTSBURGH, March 6 (UPI) Dick Haley, former Pittsburgh Steeler defensive back, was named director of player personnel for the Steelers today.

title: Summer Savory
description: SUMMER and winter savory (annual and perennial respectively), rank high in value among culinary herbs, but equal to thyme or sage. Instead of changing the flavor slightly  the way basil does  the savories point it up, making various meat and vegetable dishes, soups and stuffings taste bettermore savory.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe Vietnam debate went off on an unexpected tangent last week. Suddenly, instead of debating whether the Administration's Vietnamization plan would lead to an end of the war, Congressional critics were arguing over whether William P. Rogers was Secretary of State in fact or whether Henry A. Kissinger was a modernday Rasputin dictating policy on the war from the sanctuary of the White House.

title: The Place to Phone if You Want an Organic. Buffet
description: It was bound to happen, what with the craze for organic foods and all, And it has. Stanley and Jean Fine, a Manhattan husband and wife team, have gone into the catering business serving only organic foods.

title: Giant? Monster? Showman? Charlatan? Genius? Yes!
