description: He was an outsize figure in every way: a giant of a man, built like heavyweight boxer, and with a boxer's bruised good looks and endless reserves of energy. In the unquiet but outwardly sedate days before the revolution he was a great shocker of the bourgeoisie, shouting down speakers at polite meetings, flaunting an obnoxious yellow tunic in the teeth of buttonedup respectability, occasionally sporting a wooden spoon in his buttonhole instead of a rose, preaching death of the old forms, the elimination of punctuation, and a new poetry of macihines. The violence and horror of the revolution and the early days of Communism, which drove even Gorki to a breakdown, acted on him as a stimulus: Mayakovsky entered the revolution, wrote a contemporary, as he would his own home.

title: Photography
description: NOTES from a working photographer on printmaking:

title: Judith C. Anker Will Be a Bride
description: ALBANY, March 6Miss Judith Constance Anker, a graduate student at the Simmons School of Library Science in Boston, and Richard Douglas Plotz of New York and Chilmark, Mass., a senior at Harvard College, plan to be married on March 28 at Brandeis University, from which Miss Anker was graduated last year.

title: Army Clears G.I. in Death Of U.S Woman in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) The Army has conceded a case of mistaken identity and has dropped a charge of unpremeditated murder against a Maryland soldier in the fatal stabbing of a Red Cross woman near Saigon last August.

title: CHAPOT TRIUMPHS ABOARD 2 MOUNTS
description: READINGTON, N. J., March 6Frank Chapot, an international star for almost two decades, and Kim Young, a high school sophomore who never had won a championship, shared honors at the Four Seasons farm's indoor horse show today.

title: JAPAN SAYS CHINESE IMPROVED ECONOMY
description: TOKYO, March 6Communist China's economy grew by 10 per cent last year and its gross national product reached $75billion, according to an estimate recently prepared by the Japanese Foreign Ministry.

title: Sands of Sheepshead Bay Runs Best 440 in Nation This Year in Mayor's Meet
description: Mike Sands, a senior at Sheepshead Bay High School who wants to make the Bahamian Olympic team next year, started his campaign toward that objective yesterday when he won the 440yard run at the 15th annual Mayor's AllCity indoor track championships.

title: EDITORS WILL MEET WITH HARPER'S HEAD
description: John Cowles Jr., chairman of the Harper's Magazine Company, will meet with the magazine's contributing editors here on Tuesday to discuss the publication's future following the unexpected resignation last Thursday of Willie Morris as editor in chief.

title: ITALIAN RIGHTS UNIT WILL PICKET F.B.I.
description: The ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League, which has been picketing a Staten Island newspaper for the last 10 days, will shift its activities to the Manhattan headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation tomorrow to protest the arrest Friday of Joseph Colombo Sr.

title: Cincinnati Swimmers Win
description: CINCINNATI, March 6 (AP)Cincinnati, paced by the Pyle brothers, Steve and Ed, who won three events each, posted a twoday total of 533 points to win the first annual invitation swimming championships of independent schools today. Second was Western Illinois with 366 points and Eastern Illinois was third with 359.

title: OSLO PARTIES TRY TO FORM CABINET
description: OSLO, Norway, March 6The four political parties that made up Norway's former coalition government agreed today to try to form a new government under Kjell Bondevik, a Cabinet minister in the administration that resigned on Tuesday.

title: Reader's Report
description: The trouble with Capt. Paul Damion, U.S.N., is that he is not only a hero but a martyr. Since the Inchon landing (for which he won a Navy Cross), Damion has been accumulating promotions and doubts, until the Vietnam war finds him a Navy Hamlet command of a nuclearpowered destroyer. An impasse between tactics and conscience leads to dereliction of duty and the professional harakiri that the captain seems to court. A Navy buff, Mr. Dibner is an imaginative investigator of the alignment between command decisions and morality. Unfortunately, he finds it necessary to construct a network of melodramatic detours to the youth and drug scenes, which dissipate the importance of the central idea.

title: Art Mailbag,
description: To THE EDITOR: I take a very dim view of John Canaday's Introduder in the Hothouse. It is a studied personal insult of a man for whom I have the highest regard. It is witless, undignified and bilious. It is far below the standard of your newspaper.

title: Decision Termed Nixon's
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Nixon himself decided against allowing the Enterprise to visit Valparaiso, wellinformed sources here said today. His decision was strongly supported by Henry A. Kissinger, his national security adviser, the sources added.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THE exchange of views offered by John Simon and Andrew Sarris is a dismal example of potandkettle debate. Neither writer is interested in a dialogue centering on issues. Instead, both are childishly concerned with their own egos; both use language as a lash between enemies, not as a light between respectful disputants in a mutual search for sense.

title: Fly Wrote a Diary While Captive
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 6 (AP)Dr. Claude L. Fly, the United States agronomist released Tuesday after seven months captivity by Tupamaro guerrillas, has written an account of his ordeal, his son John disclosed today.

title: HiFi: A List Of Pet Peeves
description: THE manufacturers of high fidelity equipment are doing wonders for us, generally speaking, in the quality of their units. Amplifiers, tuners, pickups and such are far better than they were as little as five to seven years ago, and listeners are happier for it. Nevertheless the writer is going to unburden here a few longstanding peeves, call it ingratitude though you may. It is a bit like a family spat over small matters that have run on too long.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: the traveler's world
description: WASHINGTON  It is going to be difficult to write a lilting song about The Atchison, Topeka and the Railpax or The Chattanooga Railpax. They will simply have to come up with a more euphonious name, they being the National Railroad Passenger Corporation which on May 1 takes over the operation of what is left of the passenger railroad trains in this country, excluding commuter trains.

title: The King of Swing Is At It Again
description: BENNY GOODMAN, whose name is synonymous with the big band idiom, has just released an album, Benny Goodman Today (London SPB 21) that recaptures the mood of the Swing Era in a vivid and vibrant live stereo performance. The selections are culled from a 1970 concert at Stockholm's Opera House; the Swedish capital being one leg of a grueling European tour Goodman made last winter with the first big band he's led in eight years.

title: Et Al.
description: Subtitled A New Look at Benjamin Franklin, this straightforward, popular biography is no more than a modest restatement of established facts and interpretations. The emphasis, properly, is on Franklin's fruitful, mature years.

title: Jarring's Plan for Sinai Said to Safeguard Israel
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 Wellplaced diplomats reported today that a United Nations suggestion last month for Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula included safeguards of Israeli interests.

title: Temple Fencers Capture 7th Straight M.A.C. Title
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 6 (AP)Temple won its seventh straight Middle Atlantic Conference fencing title with 56 points today.

title: Patriots to Open New Park With Giants Game Aug. 15
description: BOSTON, March 6The Bay State Patriots announced today that they would play the New York Giants, the Los Angeles Rams and the Atlanta Falcons in their three home preseason exhibition gamesall at night and in the new 62,000seat stadium now under construction in Foxboro.

title: Eric Ridder Jr. Plans to Wed Miss Tory Henry, a Travel Aide
description: LEBANON, Pa., March 6Charles Vincent Henry Jr. has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Catherine Victoria Henry, to Eric Ridder Jr. of New. York and Hampton Bays, L.I. He is the son of Mr. Ridder of Locust Valley, L.I., yachtsman and publisher of The Journal of Commerce, and Mrs. Tucker Ridder of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and a grandson of the late Joseph E. Ridder, board chairman of Ridder Publications.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The moral bankruptcy of our Indochina policy is well documented in two recent news articles. One describes the new prison to be built for the Saigon Government by the United States, at a cost of at least $400,000 and probably much more with the usual cost overruns. The second notes the sentencing of two South Vietnamese priests who dared to publish antiwar material, and who may well be headed for two of those new $1,400 isolation cells. Our Government has already revealed its intention fully to support and indeed Insure the success of this despotic and selfserving regime in the forthcoming presidential elections.

title: U.S. Copter Pilots In Laos Invasion Question the Risks
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 6  Peter Hale, a 22yearold warrant officer, climbed into his helicopter with the terrors of the previous day's mission still clear in his mind. Twelve miles west of here, beyond the Laotian border, the war's heaviest concentration of enemy antiaircraft guns was waiting.

title: Republican Named to Fill Out Term of Manhattan Surrogate Who Resigned
description: ALBANY, N. Y., March 6Governor Rockefeller appointed former State Supreme Court Justice Morris Aarons, a Republican, as a New York County surrogate today.

title: A Choice of Fur
description: To the Editor: In the interests of historical accuracy, here's the correct version of the jingle that accompanied Anne Fremantle's remarks on Sir Anthony Glyn's book, The British:

title: Spain's Top Matador Arrives to Watch Fight
description: Manuel Benitez, known as El Cordobes, Spain's leading bullfighter, arrived here yesterday to see the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier heavyweight championship fight and to complete negotiations for a closedcircuit bullfight to be telecast from Spain to the United States in June.

title: DENVER CAPTURES 14TH SKIING TITLE
description: LEAD, S. D., March 6 (AP)The University of Denver won its 14th National Collegiate skiing championship in 18 years today at Terry Peak. The Pioneers captured the team jumpMg in the final event of the threeday meet.

title: The Man Who . . .
description: A history of F.D.R.'s nomination in 1932 by a Washington correspondent for Look. Well written but slight. One wishes Mr. Oulahan had covered the election as well.

title: Three Ways To Solve The Welfare Problem
description: WHEN the Nixon Administration's Family Assistance Plan was shelved by the last Congress at the end of 1970, 15 per cent of New York City's population, 25 per cent of Newark's population and 6 per cent of all Americans about 12.5 million people  were on welfare, and since then their number has continued to rise faster than expected. One would therefore think that national and local task forces would be searching for other solutions to the welfare problem. But the White House  though it is still planning to revive FAP, as welfare experts now call it  is preoccupied with revenue sharing. And Mayor Lindsay and Congressman Wilbur Mills, the Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, who are trying in different ways to have the Federal Government take over welfare, are worrying about who pays the bill. None of the programs, FAP included, can do much about the welfare problem itself. That problem is really in the heart of the American economy, which simply does not need all the unemployed looking for work at a living wage and which cannot provide for all the working poor who require higher wages to support their families. Ultimately, therefore, an end to the welfare problem requires either remaking the economy so that it produces full employment at a living wage, or altering public beliefs about welfare so that the Government will provide the unneeded and underpaid with a decent income.

title: Accident Toll 113,000
description: CHICAGO, March 6 (AP)About 113,000 persons died in accidents throughout the nation last year, according to the National Safety Council. The council put the financial cost of accidents through the year at $26billion and said that there were 10.8 million disabling injuries.

title: Seville, Angry at Arrests, Reacts and Gets Results
description: SEVILLE, Spain, March., 1Jose Luis was in his slippers; so he went and put on his shoes Then he finished his milk, at an apple and took his pills. One of the policemen asked him what sort of man he was, taking pills instead of drinking wine. He told them, I drink wine when there is an occasion for it.

title: Helio Rise Wins Lecomte
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 6 (AP)Helio Rise finished seven lengths ahead of the pack in the $15,000 added Lecomte Handicap at the New Orleans Fair Grounds today.

title: Letters
description: Mr. Whitman was a perceptive observer in Iceland but inevitably he was the victim of a few misconceptions which he would have corrected had his stay been longer. While there is manmade devastation in Iceland, much of what he saw is the work of nature. The interior is a mountainous desert, icecapped and volcanic, with immense wastes of glacier, lavaflow and cinderfield.

title: Lehigh Rallies and Hands N.Y.U. 18th Defeat, 7872
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 6Lehigh University scored the final 11 points of the game tonight to triumph over New York University, 7872, before 1,000 fans at Grace Hall.

title: DETROIT REPORTS RISE IN HOMICIDES
description: DETROIT, March 6The Motor City is rapidly earning a new title: the Murder City.

title: Damp Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: If a school teacher arouses a reading interest in nonroading student, the teacher is considered successful. If a Christian converts a nonChristian to Christianity, supposedly he will go to heaven. If Maurice }Mart has converted one who knows nothing about ballet (a direct quote from Clive Barnes's review concerning the people Bejart attracted), he deserves his rightful place in ballet history.

title: New School Will Offer Master's in Urban Affairs
description: The New School for Social Research announced yesterday the establishment of a new twoyear master's degree program in urban affairs and policy analysis to begin in the fall of 1971.

title: Miss Acocella Wed in Suburb
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 6  In the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament here this afternoon, Miss Madelyn Acocella was married to Louis V. Fugazy 3d. The Rev. James F. Cunningham performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: SAITO CAPTURES SKI JUMP EASILY
description: ISHPEMING, Mich., March 6 Kimio Saito of Japan turned in sparkling flights of 243 and 245 feet in blustery winds today to dominate the Paul Bietila Memorial jumping tournament on this busy iron ore community's Suicide Hill.

title: News of the Rialto
description: IT may be that revival time has come again for Eugene O'Neill. It wasn't too long ago that Michael Kahn, artistic director of the American Shakespeare Festival, disclosed that he would be staging Mourning Becomes Electra this summer at Stratford, Conn., after a 40year lapse. Now there is word that the playwright's tumultuous Long Day's Journey into Night is returning to life. Indeed, should expectations be fulfilled, the production will precede the resurrection of Electra, being scheduled for a late March opening at the Promenade.

title: Manhattan C.C. Wins Final
description: FARMINGDALE, L. L, March 6Manhattan Community College defeated Staten Island C. C., 10282, tonight and won the Region 15 basketball tournament of the National Junior College Athletic Association. The Panthers will represent the region in the natioinal tournament starting a week from Monday at Hutchinson, Kan.

title: Stamps
description: NEW YORK'S annual spring stamp show, Interpex, opens Friday morning at the Americana Hotel. Simultaneously, the United States will Issue a stamp supporting the blood donor program, and the United Nations will issue three stamps promoting International Support for Refugees. Joint firstday ceremonies will be staged at the. Americana. The stamps will be available at show post office branches to be provided by John R. Strachan, Postmaster of New York, and Ole S. Hamann, recently named Chief, United Nations Postal Administration. Mr. Straohan and Mr. Hamann are scheduled to participate in the firstday program.

title: ElisabethAnn Boyd Engaged to Marry
description: Mrs. Locke Boyd of Manhattan has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss ElisabethAnn Boyd to Robert A. Failey of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Failey of Oil City, Pa., and Winter Park, Fla.

title: Sarris Vs. SimonWho Won?
description: To THE EDITOR: Though John Simon's nastiness is often gratuitous and his wordplay occasionally witless, every serious student of film realizes that beyond the cruelty and verbal blinks lies some of the most brilliant, articulate, and detailed film criticism to be had in America. How unfortunate that Simon does not realize he would be a more effective and appreciated critic were he less abusive. How disheartening that a man of such exquisite esthetic taste should descend so often into tasteless inhumanity.

title: The War Against Russia
description: A wellwritten account of the Crimean War by one of the better British military historians. Mr. Barker has a keen understanding of strategies and personalities. His account of the illstarred charge of the Light Brigade is a model of clarity, and he gives us the reasons why in good measure.

title: NewtonCleaver Clash Puts Party's Future in Doubt
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 6  Despite obvious efforts to ease a bitter internal dispute, the future of the militant Black Panther party grew more uncertain today.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: One of the hard facts of business, no less than of life, is the fact of change. This is surely true of the vast and diversified textile business, which last year turned out some $21billion worth of products to the ultimate benefit of the American consumer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Since I am currently engaged research on the CommanderinChief power of the. President I wish to comment on Norman Boardman's letter (Feb. 23) concerning the warmaking power of the President.

title: Talk With Ouologuem
description: My novel is not traditional and, although it is based in fact and history, it is not autobiographical wrote the book with references to international examples. AfroAmerican writers have influenced its style and there are Greek and Latin references that are intended to heighten its meaning on a human level. It addresses the problems of all civilizations at specific periods of development; it is not just an African novel.

title: Small Saver Wins at Last
description: For years, the small saver the average guy with a few thousand dollars to tuck away in the bankhas been an unhappy member of one of the nation's largest underprivileged majorities. All through the long money squeeze during 1969 and much of 1970, Government regulations kept the allowable interest rates on his deposits well below the return his welltodo cousin with big chunks of cash to invest could earn in the money market.

title: Johnson Scores 62 Points as Condors Win
description: PITTSBURGH, March 6 (AP) Stew Johnson broke the American Basketball Association singlegame scoring record today with 62 points to lead the Pittsburgh Condors to 142129 victory over the Floridians.

title: Lawyer's Suit Asks $200,010 Damages On Phone Service
description: A New York lawyer has decided that the right number for a wrong number is $200,010.80.

title: Rocky Mountain Warden
description: The experiences of a dedicated conservationist from the tithe he takes over as game warden in Vernal, Utah, until redtape and bureaucratic apathy lead him to quit. The style has a, frontier edge (treat a testy horse with the same gentleness of a man treating his piles); but the endless descriptions of general stores, saddles made in Pueblo, Colo., authentic woodland types pall like the second feature on an allWestern bill.

title: Television
description: AT 56, Richard Widmark looks much the same as he did in 1947 when he made his movie debut as psychopathic killer in Kiss of Death. There was never a lot of the pale, fine hair; today there is a bit more gray than blond. His remarkable face, which on the screen can seem to shine with sick menace, seen close up has the tanned, healthy, highboned look of a Swede who takes care of himself. And he has probably added no more than 20 pounds to the 140 he carried as a speedy end on the Lake Forest University football team.

title: The Assignment
description: Yoo hoo, junkman!

title: FORMER TIGER ACE HURLS 4 INNINGS
description: WEST PALM BEACH, March 6 (UPI)Denny McLain's grapefruit League debut with the Washington Senators today was a moderately successful one.

title: West Virginia Senate Votes Ban On Strip Mining in 36 Counties
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 6A twomonth fight to end the massive strip mining in West Virginia, the largest coalproducing state, brought a surprising partial success today and an almost certain political gain to Secretary of State John D. Rockefeller 4th.

title: Martirano Explores AvantGarde Music With a What Is It
description: Whether following, leading or in the midst of avantgarde compositional styles, Salvatore Martirano has been one of music's more successful practitioners. His O, O, O, O, That Shakespeherean Rag, Ballad for Amplified Singer and Instrumental Ensemble, L's G. A. and other works made distinct impression when they appeared during the last decade.

title: GARDEN HIDEOUT SET UP FOR All He Will Stay Secreted After Weighln Until Fight
description: After his weighin tomorrow afternoon, Muhammad All will remain in an impromptu apartment at Madison Square Garden until the heavyweight title bout.

title: North Stars on Ttop
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 6 (UPI)Ted Hampson scored an unassisted goal with Minnesota a man short tonight to lead the North Stars to a 31 victory over the Vancouver Canuck.

title: Marsee Will Sing Rosina in Barber At the City Opera
description: Susanne Marsee will appear as Rosina in the New York City Opera production of Rossini's Il Barbiere di Siviglia for the first time in a performance to be given on March 27 in the sixth week of the company's current season at the New York State Theater. Casts and conductors for the week are as follows:

title: Pacers Beat Chaparrals
description: DALLAS, March 6 (AP)The Indiana Pacers broke free in the second quarter and held on all the way today to gain 124112 American Basketball Association victory over the Texas Chaparrals.

title: BURDEN ACCUSES ODYSSEY HOUSE
description: City Councilman Carter Burden yesterday assailed Odyssey House, the private narcotics rehabilitation organization, for what he called wrong and destructive policies, and said he had requested the removal of his name from the programs list of 105 local honorary advisers.

title: German Wins Biathlon
description: HAEMEENLINNA, Finland, March 6 (AP)Dieter Speer of East Germany won the world 20kilometer biathlon title today in 1 hour 18 minutes 20.2 seconds, with two penalty minutes. Dexter A. Morse of Aspen, Colo., finished far back in 1:27.41.8.

title: Honka Monka and Roseland, Dancing Their Troubles Away
description: At Corso's, a nightclub in Yorkville, the surging interest in dancing can be seen how packed the dance floor was recently (left) and in the attention paid to a dance demonstration (above). Roseland (right) remains popular with middleaged couples.

title: IN MARINE pARIC: This sculpture by Peter Gourfrain is being exhibited in Brooklyn by the Department of Parks
description: A new outdoor sculpture, formed by large timbers stacked in an open triangular f ashion, has been installed in the Plum Beach area of Marine Park in Brooklyn.

title: Bills Sign Top Prospect
description: BUFFALO, March 6 (UPI)The Buffalo Bills signed today a defensive end, Louis Ross, regarded as a prime prospect. The South Carolina State player was the Bills eighthround selection in the collegiate draft.

title: California Democrats Propose Rules for 72 Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 California Democratic leaders have undertaken an unusual and ambitious political project: trying to establish some local ground rules for the party's Presidential candidates during their forthcoming 18 months of competition.

title: John Ingle Jr. to Marry Miss Josephine C. Ford
description: GROSSE POINTE FARMS, Mich., March 6Miss Josephine Clay Ford, a greatgranddaughter of Henry Ford, the auto pioneer, is engaged to be married to John W. Ingle Jr., a classmate at the University of Denver. No date has yet been set for their wedding.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Planners Bid Westchester Avoid Haphazard Growth
description: The Regional Plan Association urged yesterday that Westchester County start planning for its development before spread city of housing subdivisions and office parks effectively erased all local boundaries.

title: Growth Games
description: Subtitled How to Tune In Yourself, Your Family, Your Friends, this is a doitathome guide to encounter therapy. Games and exercises that can be practiced without a group leader or professional therapist. Don't invite any nuts.

title: Art Mailbag,
description: To THE EDITOR: Is John Canaday's abysmal cleverness really admired by the editors of The New York Times? Can they possibly be amused by his latest low in Personalized Kritixism? In his fatuous fairy tale, the tiny poisoned darts can do no harm to Canaday's targets, who are too many lightyears ahead of him, and no good to his readers, whether ahead of him, behind, or just bewildered.

title: Letters
description: In his interesting article, Fort Ross, Calif.A Russian Outpost in 1812 (Travel section, Jan. 31), Andrew Hamilton writes: On April 8, 1806, the Juno commanded by Nikolai Petrovich Rezanov and in search of pelts and trading privileges, became the first Russian ship to sail into San Francisco Bay. Your readers may want to know that originally this was an American ship, bought by Rezanov from an uncle of Herman Melville  the Russianspeaking Connecticut Yankee John deWolf (also known as Nor'west John). For details, please see pages 26 and 27 of my book America Learns Russian (Syracuse University Press, 1967).

title: Wash your hands, damn it!
description: P ASTEUR, Koch and Lister are rediscovered and vindicated! Here, as the above clipping from The New York Times (Oct. 7, 1970) shows, are doctors needing to remind doctors that dirty hands spread disease Small wonder that there is general disregard among parents and children of the importance of personal cleanliness.

title: Coins
description: DR. LEVI FOX, director of the Shakespeare Birthplace Trust, Stratford  Upon  Avon, England, has announced plans for a series of medallions to commemorate the plays of William Shakespeare. The series will be designed by Paul Vincze, artistsculptor of London, whose works have won many international awards.

title: The SUPER STARS by LeROY NEIMAN
description: See today's Sports Section, Advt.

title: Robin K. Feuer Will Be a Bride Here on April 24
description: Miss Robin Kathryn Feuer, a 1969 graduate of Swarthmore College, and Christopher Miller, who was graduated from Swarthmore in 1968, plan to be married here on April 24.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Burger Court pulled a surprise last week by demonstrating that, under certain circumstances, it can match the Warren Court in finding things in the Constitution that were not known to have been there before.

title: Casa Means Home
description: To the Editor: In her Jan. 3 roundup review of books about Puerto Rican children, Gloria Levitas rejects my novel about a family from the island, Casa Means Home, as the work of a talented outsider who unwittingly extols assimilationist ideals. This raises some interesting questions about critical standards.

title: Law
description: Ever since the courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. began early in November at Fort Benning, Ga., an unseen presence has hovered, over the courtroom. Though Capt. Ernest L. Medina has been no closer than his present station at Fort McPherson in Atlanta, 100 miles away, there have been many moments during the past five months when his name has dominated the proceedings. And there have been other momentsnot the least two weeks ago when Lieutenant Calley took the witness standwhen it almost appeared that it was Captain Medina, the. 34yearold former commander of C Company, First Battalion, 20th Infantry, who was on trial for the murder of 102 unarmed Vietnamese civilians at Mylai 4.

title: ANTIQUES GUTTER AMONG FLOWERS
description: It's springtime in a large patch of the groundfloor exhibition space at the Coliseumfragrant and bright with bloomsand a mixed season for the antiques show that, separately, occupies most of the precincts.

title: Overland Wins Pro Slalom
description: BEAR VALLEY, Calif., March 6 (AP)Terje Overland, former Norwegian Olympic skiing star, outraced Andero Molterer of Mount Rose, Nev., and Kitzbuhel, Austria, today to take the slalom on the International Ski Racers Association pro circuit.

title: Summer of 1972 Would See 150,000 U.S. Troops Still in Vietnam, According to Pentagon Budget Estimate;
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Defense Department planning calls for the possible retention of more than 150,000 United States troops in Vietnam in the summer of 1972 and some 50,000 the summer after.

title: Coping With ShoppingCenter Crises
description: The suburban shopping centers  those outlying store hubs surrounded by acres of parking lots encompassed by winding highwayshave inherited many of the social problems of the downtown areas that they have replaced.

title: Consumer Protection Office in Nassau Is Keeping Close Eye on Products and Services
description: MINEVLA, L. I., March 6John Nanoli stalds much of this time cooking hamburgers he doesn't eat. And the result of his culinary effort may be used pas evidence In court.

title: Harvard Sinks Yale, 9387, And Finishes 2d in League
description: NEW HAVEN, March 6Floyd Lewis, James Brown and Dale Dover scored more than 20 points apiece tonight, leading Harvard to a 9387 basketball victory over Yale. The winners finished second in the Ivy League.

title: 31 Local Boards Defy Teacher Layoff Order
description: The city's 31 local school boards announced yesterday that they would defy the Board of Education's order to lay off teachers and curtail programs because of the budget crisis.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Two statistics that tell a tale of progress and poverty:

title: Black Community in Freeport Has Candidate for Village Post
description: FREEPORT, L. I., March 6Nathaniel H. Jackson, a 43Yearold education consultant, is seeking one of two available posts on this village'a allwhite Board of Trustees in the March 16 elections as the candidate of Freeport's black community.

title: PATROLMAN SLAYS MAN, 50, IN MELEE
description: An offduty patrolman, attacked with a machete and knives while attempting to break up a melee in Brooklyn last night, shot and killed one man and wounded three other members of the same family.

title: Photography
description: COMBINING the convenience of cassette film loading with a power zoom lens, the new Bauer C Royal Super 8mm movie camera is the first cassette model to also offer the added feature of a builtin professional type lap dissolve (this permits the amateur to film one scene fading out as another overlaps and fades in  a technique normally limited only to those with professional equipment).

title: Hedda  Frigid Woman or Life Bearer?
description: IN TERMS like these the case of Hedda Gabler went into the Contemp. Drama notebooks of the Fifties. Ibsen was a breeze ?? those days of findthephallicsymbolsandyouhave thekey. The American adjustment version of Freudian psychology dominated not only the personal lives of a large percentage of the middle class, but the study of literature as well. Each literary character worthy of analysis was laid out like a patient on the couch and gone over by grubby graduate students emitting Ahs and knowing grunts as said patient revealed himself through action and dialogue as having fallen short of healthy heterosexual development.

title: Sandhill Crane Watching From Afar
description: RADIOVILLE Ind.Before dawn their raucous bugle call sounds in the marshlands, in the JasperPulaski State Wildlife Refugeand everyone Within two Miles knowa, that the greater sandhill cranes have arrived. In early March (and again in midSeptember), the 7,522acre refuge becomes a way station Where these rare birds pause for about six weeks in their rush northward, from the Gulf Coastal States to their summer breeding grounds In Michigan and southern Canada.

title: The RedWings
description: Some time this month the redwing blackbirds will arrive from the South, and from that day on we can watch for migrant robins and look, in the boglands where the redwings congregate, for pussy willow catkins. Sometimes, depending on the season, the redwings arrive by the end of February. Seldom do they delay longer than the week of the vernal equinox.

title: 3 Months After the Riots, Much Has Changed in Gdansk
description: GDANSK, Poland, March 4 The snow fell today on a., nearly empty street outside the headquarters, of this port city's provincial government. Last December, angry shipyard workers surged through that street, but now it is quiet.

title: STATE CUT ASKED IN CIVIL DEFENSE
description: ALBANY, March 6The state's Civil Defense Commission and Division of Veteran Affairs would be abolished under budgetcutting proposals by rilembers of the Republican majaity in the Assembly.

title: Loraine Strait, T. K. Petersen Plan Marriage
description: WADDINGTON, N. Y., March 6  Mrs. Wendell Rippon Strait of Waddington has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Loraine Hall Strait, to Thomas K. Petersen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thonias S. Petersen of New York and Monroe, N. Y.

title: Kerr on Three Off Broadway Plays
description: IT IS difficult to believe that the same young playwright, Israel Horovitz, wrote both Acrobats and Line, the two new oneasters now hack'toback at the Theater de Lys. Acrobats, which opens the evening and wisely gets out of the way as quickly as possible, is nothing more than a stock revue sketch tossed off by someone who's never taken the trouble to learn how funny even stock revue sketches must be. I hate your guts, Edna, the strong man says as he lifts his vaudeville partner high in the air, making it plain he wants a divorce. Why? Too much dependency, he keeps muttering as he balances himself upsidedown on her shoulders. I think that last line should take care of the matter. As a visual pun, the exercise is simpleminded.

title: P.S.A.L COLLAPSE SEEN BY COACHES
description: The Public Schools Athletic League program will collapse, is the way a leading official of that office yesterday characterized the Board of Education's ruling last week to cease afterschool activity, effective March IS, because of a financial crisis.

title: Et Al.
description: An industrious and routine anthology of 21 expository/ analytical pieces on Bernard Malamudnot the big rethinking of Malamud we might expect at this time, when Jewish fiction recedes into memory or is about to be apotheosized, parodied, transcended, what you will, by Philip Roth.

title: The Tropic's Own Supermarket
description: I you were shipwrecked on a desItisland what one thing would DU want to have with you? This iestion evokes hilarious answers but mine is a pragmatic oneI choose palms! Next to grasses, palms are said co be the most important family, of plants in usefulness to man. With their byproducts, I could exist quite comfortably on my isle.

title: Sports of at into
description: The press brochure for tomorrow night's championship showdown between Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali has an elegantly colored frontispiece that also serves as title page of austere simplicity. In an admirable bit of understatement, an event of epic proportions is merely characterized as The Fight. It's a glorious description that says it all.

title: Reader's Report
description: I tremble to call it a trend, but there does seem to be more humor about than in recent seasons. And of this new wavelet, Son of the Great American Novel is a particularly joyful ripple. Meet Arden K. Hoffstetter, alias Jeremy Haberman (or vice versa), each shard of whose fragmented personality becomes the nucleus of a parody. By day, Arden reads unsolicited manuscripts for book publishers. By night he adds to the 2,500 pages of his unpublished novel, Flush, thematic treatment of sewage disposal. Around this effluent source, Mr. Fritzhand strews fantasies, trips, flashbacks, critiques, a fan  magazine story, a movie treatment, a biography.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Gaze deeply into my pupils as I spin this glittering antenna in my hand. Round and round it goes. It is one of Secretary Rusk's antennas that he used in the old days to detect signals from Hanoi. Secretary Rusk's antennas were very sensitive, remember. Very sensitive. The Secretary has very sensitive antennas, they used to say at the State Department. Do not fight me now. Lie back and breathe deeply.

title: Ohio Court Blocks Radio Network Ads On Bout Broadcast
description: CLEVELAND, March 6 (AP) Judge Frank J. Battisti of the United States District Court issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the Mutual Broadcasting Company and its affiliates from advertising that they would broadcast the Joe FrazierMuhammad Ali fight while it was in progress Monday night.

title: Penn State's Wrestlers End 3Year Navy Reign
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 6 Penn State won the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association tournament tonight, piling up points in the middleweight classes to squeeze past Navy,. 8985.

title: Sarris Vs. SimonWho Won?
description: To THE EDITOR: I definitely find for John Simon. Why? Because he reasons better. He's like another unpopular personality, William F. Buckley: if you grant his premises, what follows after that follows pretty logically, almost inevitably. By contrast with this, Simon quotes Sarris in quite a number of instances wherein he demonstrates fuzzy, woolenheaded thinking, and also makes out a convincing, case against the auteur movement's reckless and sterile theorizing.

title: Weber Defeats BrotherinLaw, 237235 in Final of Buckeye Open Bowling
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, March 6 (AP) Dick Weber of St. Louis scored the 22d victory of his pro bowling career by defeating his brotherinlaw; Norm Meyers, also of St. Louis, 237235, today in the final game of the $60,000 Buckeye open.

title: Dancee Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: I found Clive Barnes's insistence on looking at Maurice Bejart's Ballet of the 20th Century in a narrow manner, desperately seeking to find some illusion of critical rationale for his obviously subjective feelings, just another instance of the kind of popular criticism which makes a mockery of the real thing.

title: Indiana Triumphs, 10488
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 6 (AP)  Indiana broke open a close game with a 10point scoring spurt early in the second half today and.went on to record a 10488 Big 10 basketball victory over Iowa.

title: Art
description: BETWEEN the very small public likely to derive some measure of Intellectual illumination, esthetic pleasure or spiritual satisfaction from the 1971 Guggenheim International Exhibition, currently installed at the Guggenheim Museum, and the larger art jiublic for whom it Is certain to be only a source of irritation, bafflement or boredom, there can be, I suspect, little real communication. If you have been wondering exaptly where the basic division of the art world now lies, look no further. It is here, at a juncture where elements of Minimal art, Conceptual art, and socalled Earthworks combine to remove the artistic experience  if indeed this void may be called an artistic experience  to a realm where few disinterested observers will find it esthetically profitable (or even feasible) to follow.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Numerous functions are ascribed to a critic, but that of a Judge in the Futurity Sweepstakes is among the least likely.

title: Uniform Voting Age
description: The 26th Amendment to the United States Constitution is, we hope, fairly on its way. Within two days each other the House and Senate Judiciary Committees have approved the proposed constitutional change to lower the voting age to 18 for all elections, including state and local. So overwhelming was the vote (32 2 in the House panel, unanimous in the Senate's) that the indications are bright for quick passage.

title: Words in the Mourning Time
description: To the Editor: Julius Lester's recent review of Robert Hayden's Words in the Mourning Time, in my opinion, was a master appraisal of a master of poetry.

title: FORDHAM DOWNS FAIRFIELD, 7669
description: NEW HAVEN, March 6 Playing on a court whose planks looked as if they had been borrowed from the nearby wharf, Fordham's scrappy basketball team showed Fairfield how to employ a pressing defense and whipped the Stags, 7559, tonight at the antiquated New Haven Arena.

title: SAIGON'S FORCES ENTERTCHERIE, KEY GOAL IN LAOS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 6  South Vietnamese troops moved today into the Laotian town of Tchepone, a major objective of their fourweekold offensive against, enemy supply lines.

title: Miss Dahlman Is Bride on L.I.
description: MANHASSET, L. I., March 6Miss Nancy Louise Dahlman and John Wheelan Riggs were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Dahlman, by the Rev. Wyndham Anderson, a Congregational minister.

title: Andrew Sarris vs. John Simon Who Won?
description: To THE EDITOR: While reading the SimonSarris exchange, I felt I was in an 18thcentury coffee house. The tone, the language, the wit could not have been more Jonsonian; everything was elegantly expressed, but the subject was wrong. Simon and Sarris should have been discussing literature, painting, even philosophy; but they were discussing movies.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Montclair Girls Win Title
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 6 (AP) Montclair State's undefeated girl's basketball team won the New Jersey women intercollegiate basketball tournament today by downing Glassboro State, 62.40. The victory was No. 11 for the Squaws.

title: PARLEY IN BERLIN ON PASSES OPENS
description: BERLIN, March 6The complex negotiations on Berlin reached a new level today when formal talks opened between the West Berlin City Government and the East Germans on Easter passes for West Berliners who wish to visit East Berlin.

title: SPRING PACE WON BY JAMES DARREN
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March 6Australianbred James Darren registered a halflength victory as the spring pacing series for aged standardbreds who were nonwinners of $75,000 in 1970 got under way tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: The Good Word: Kael vs. Sarris vs. Simon
description: On and on they come in murderous waves (they must have a Cause, Captain Sanders): the little grim books about Erich Von Stroheim, the large playful ones about Miss West, Blondie & Dagwood retrospectives, theological studies of Preston Sturges  last year the film books may have outnumbered the films themselves, suggesting at least two pointi. One, that the trueblue buff really prefers still pictures to moving ones (the passion for moviestills being a paradox G. K. Chesterton might have considered farfetched); and two, that though Film is King it needs its Old Retainer Print to do more and more of the work. Fact is that fewer films are distributed each year of the reign, and more books published.

title: ALABAMA EDITOR PROUD CRUSADER
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 4  A crusading Montgomery newspaper editor has shaken up Alabama political circles with a series of exposs about corruption in state government and at the same time has revived an old Southern tradition  muckraking journalism.

title: Study Warns L.I.U. Is Facing Economic Disaster
description: Long Island University has been advised that although it can continue as a viable institution of learning in downtown Brooklyn it faces imminent ruin and disaster within the next five years, if it falls to overhaul its educational and managerial policies and operate on a strict austerity budget.

title: Charles Edward Leonard 3d Weds Miss Ilze Dace Erglis in Stockholm
description: Miss Ilze Dace Erglis of Stockholm was married yesterday to Charles Edward Leonard 3d of New York in Stockholm. The Rev. Clive Rauscha performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the, Seglora Church. The church, built in the 15th century in the southern part of Sweden, was moved to Stockholm in the beginning of the 19th century to be part of the Skansen Museum.

title: Rosanne Bodow Plans Marriage to Student
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 6Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Bodow of Scarsdale and East Moriches, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosanne B. Bodow to Gary L. Lieber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Lieber of Dickson City, Pa.

title: Death as a Way of Life
description: An analysis of man's penchant for killing, with special attention to the hunter. Hunting, Caras argues, is an atavistic impulse, which, like the little toe, will fade away. Altogether a superficial perusal of the subjectone in which the author is unwilling to make a strong moral judgment about today's hunter and his perfidious slaughter of animal life.

title: Dartmouth Six Wins, 43
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 6 Dave Hill and Mike Turner scored two goals each tonight to lead Dartmouth's hockey team to a 43 triumph over Princeton.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Why does Secretary Volpe insist that Railpax make a profit? The U.S. Post Office is not run on this basis. Is the fast, efficient delivery of letters more important than the fast, efficient, comfortable transportation of people?

title: Zoning Plan Upsets Parkway Village
description: The specter of the highrise building is haunting the residents of Parkway Village, at quiet residential community in Queens that was built in 1947 to house the first delegates to the United Nations when it convened on Long Island.

title: Bridge Of No Return
description: An account of his experiences in captivity by the Operations Officer of the Pueblo. He attempted suicide once and was more than once subject to torture. Skip Schumacher is critical of the Code of Conduct for Members of the Armed Forces, which, he feels, is not responsive to the special needs of men fighting the Cold War. A workmanlike job done with the help of the military correspondent of The Washington Post.

title: Keller Wins in Speed Americans Are 2d and 3d
description: HEEREVEEN, the Netherlands, March 6 (AP)  Neil Blatchford and Jim Keane of the United States finished second and third respectively, behind Erhard Keller of West Germany in a 500meter speedskating race today.

title: Headliners
description: Dr. Claude L. Fly, an American agricultural consultant was working in a laboratory outside Montevideo, Uruguay, last Aug. 7 when suddenly he was kidnapped by Tupamaro guerrillas. He was one of several hostages taken by the Tupamaros to support demands for the release of political prisoners. In a letter to his family last December, Dr. Fly said he was being held in a tiny cell, seeing no daylight, knowing no time of the day or week. Abruptly last week, the 65yearold agronomist was released, left at a hospital, suffering from a heart attack. Though quite ill, Dr. Fly said, I'm happy and excited about finding myself among tree men again.

title: Tokyo to New York via Paris
description: Kenso Tokado, 26 and Japanese, is Paris's current rage. Tap, the sixmonthold boutique that carries Kenso's fresh, readytowear designs, is considered the place to go. American store buyers agree. They have swept up his clothes, and young Americans who want the romantic, almost childlike fashions that French girls are clamoring for can find them here the end of this month.

title: Sarris Vs. SimonWho Won?
description: To THE EDITOR: The conflict between Simon and Sarris is most interesting. May I suggest you provide each with a dozen marshmallows and have them square off at a dozen paces?

title: Britain's McAlinden to Fight Rahaman Ali in Preliminary
description: LONDON, March 6 (UPI) The heavyweight fights at New York's Madison Square Garden on Monday pack high interest to boxing fans in Britain.

title: Muskie
description: A solid political biography of Senator Edmund Muskie. The authorsa former Washington correspondent and a Maine political reporterhave come up with a convincing portrait of a cautious, intellectual man, rather vague in his programs, who speaks out slowly but with apparent integrity. There are many anecdotes about Muskie's Maine boyhood, his early political endeavors as a Democrat in a Republican state, his improbable victory in the 1954 gubernatorial election, and his eventual election to the Senate. The limitations of his Maine background are explored, and one is reminded that his present prominence is due to the tragedy of Ohappaquiddick. There is nothing so ephemeral as a political biography, but this one is better than most, objective and workmanlike.

title: Record List of 220 Nominated For 97th Kentucky Derby Run
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 6 (UPI)A record total of 220 3yearolds, including four fillies, were nominated today for the 97th running of the $125,000 Added Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs May 1.

title: Arkansas Victor on Links
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., March 6 (AP)The University of Arkansas golf team defeated Iowa State, 384396, today. Mike Mosser and Jim Cisne of Arkansas shared medalist honors with 74's.

title: PREMIERE IS GIVEN BY DANCE THEATER
description: A premiere by Kathryn Posin and a highly successful older work by Art Bauman were the highlights Friday night of the second of two current programs sponsored by Dance Theater Workshop at the American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street.

title: Ho
description: It's not, clear why this short book got, written. Stylish as it is, there is nothing in it that cannot be found in other eloquent books on Vietnam and Ho by Jean Lacouture, Bernard Fall, Lucien Bodard, Graham Greene, Joseph Buttinger, Paul Mus and John McAlister, all of whom are referred to copiously. It does have the virtue of being clear, also straightforward in its point of view: Ho was on the side, of history and taught the world, or most of it, the futility of imperialism.

title: Bridge.
description: T HE English Book of Common Prayer refers, in a prayer for the High Court of Parliament, to safety, bonour and welfare. These three considerations are all important to bridge experts; who may provide for the third and acquire the second by attending to the first.

title: 2 to Head Subcommittees
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) Repesentatives Paul Rogers, Democrat of Florida, and John Jarman, Democrat of Oklahoma, have been named to chairmanships of new House Commerce subcommittees. Mr. Rogers will head the public health and welfare unit, Mr. Jarman the transportation subcommittee.

title: Son to Mrs. J. P. Brown
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Peter Brown on Feb. 14 at the New York Hospital. Mrs. Brown Is the former Miss Barbara Jean Bandes. Mr. Brown is with Altman, Vos & Reichberg, Inc., advertising.

title: Sarris Vs. SimonWho Won?
description: To THE EDITOR: Unfortunately, Andrew Sarris chose to denounce John Simon's personality defects rather than to expose the true threat that Simon poses. The films of Hawks, llossellini, Ulmer, Fuller et al., so gratuitously dismissed by Simon, are in fact highly personal statements, rich in a formal beauty and an emotional and visual power that cannot even be hinted at here. These films are often difficult to appreciate, for each director must be approached on his own terms, not ours, and it is admittedly sometimes difficult to see just what those terms are.

title: Apollo 14 Astronauts in the City For Tour, Prizefight and Parties
description: The three astronauts of Apollo 14 Arrived here yesterday afternoon for a threeday visit that will include a motorcade to City Hall, visits to the theater and to the AliFrazier championship prizefight and partygoing.

title: AnneGro Buer Is Wed
description: RYE, N. Y., March 6Miss AnneGro Buer and Arthur Hill Diedrick Jr. of New York were married this afternoon in the Rye Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop and the Rev. Ralph Edward Peterson officiated. The parents of the couple are Mrs. Aina Lillemor Buer and Leif Kaare Buer of Oslo, Norway, and Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Hill Diedrick of Rye. Mrs. Diedrick is with Mytravel in. New York. Her husband whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is president of Travel Communications, Inc., a Cowles Communications subsidiary, and publisher of Venture and ASTA magazines.

title: Katherine Lupton Wed To Lucien B. Crosland
description: LOOKOUT MOUNTAIN, Tenn, March 6Miss Katherine Rawlings Lupton and Lucien Burns Crosland were married here this afternoon by the Rev Harold E. Barrett in the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd. A reception for 800 guests was given at Read House in Chattanooga.

title: Damp Mailbag
description: To THE Enrrort: N OW that Belgium's Ballet Of the 20th Century, under the artistic direction of Maurice NOM has completed its extended and highly successful (in terms of audience) American debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, I can't help but wonder at Clive Barnes's venom toward Mart as a choreographer. Hit continued attacks throughout the visit of this excellent foreign company seem more than legitimate artistic criticism. Behind the smokescreen of Barnes's erudition, there lurks the suspicion of malicefor methinks the gentleman doth protest too much.

title: The Israelis
description: The humorist and homespun philosopher in Israel following a tediously familiar trail. There are some fresh and lighthearted moments, but not enough.

title: The Control of Foreign Policy
description: Presidential primacy over foreign policy and the nation's warmaking powers is a necessity of the nuclear era. But under cover of security needs and of the splitsecond decisions required for nuclear war profound erosion of Congressional responsibility has occurred, endangering the very fundaments of the American constitutional system.

title: Frances Guest Engaged To Ernest M. Johnson Jr.
description: Miss Frances Ann Guest, daughter of the Dowager Viscountess. Wimborne and the late Viscount Wimborne, plans to be married on May 1 to Ernest Martin Johnson Jr., who is with the institutional investment department of the First National City Bank here. The wedding will take place in Ashby St. Ledgers, the future bride's family home in Northamptonshire, England. Her mother, who has announced her engagement, lives in Guernsey, the Channel Islands.

title: Beyond Malthus
description: Outside the dire consequences of overpopulation now discussed in every Ecology I course, the subject has other correlatives, according to Professor Chamberlain of Colum bia's Graduate School of Business. It accounts, he suggests, for all major shifts of political power, for the styles and functions of government, in fact for all major social forms. He is in effect presenting a theory of historical change as a result of population change; The writing is godawful, but the thinking is novel and may prove important.

title: Queens Planning Board Envies Cohesive Nassau
description: Living in a neighborhood on the New York CityNassau County boundary, the 23 members of local Community Planning Board 11 in Queens have observed smalltown government at a distance and like what they see.

title: The German Dictatorship
description: Two decades after the Fhrer's death, much of mankind still feels the need for a confrontation with the National. Socialist experience. In his introduction to this book, Peter Gay asserts that for those under 40 the Nazi dictatorship is mere history. However, to this day younger generations seem to be haunted by the ghost of the German dictatorship even if they no longer know it from firsthand experience. The use of words like Nazi, Fascist and genocide connect their present with this not altogether remote past.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Will President Nixon stop the Corps of Engineers from creation of still another ecological disaster? Construction of the Tocks Island Dam, which will back up the Delaware River from the dam site about five miles north of the Delaware Water Gap upstream 37 miles to Port Jervis, N. Y., is slated for May 1971.

title: Feelings Mixed on Modernization of S.I. Line
description: They bump and rattle, and the iron grating on their windows suggest prison bars. But it is not without affection that commuters refer to the Staten Island Rapid Transit coaches as the Toonerville trolley.

title: But Papa, It's My Music, I Like It
description: TERROR. Perhaps you think you can define it is sitting in a jet fighter cockpit, plummeting to crash landing in a hostile country. It is losing footing on a mountain ledge in the midst of blizzard. It is walking down a deserted city street the dead of night, with the sudden, certain sound footsteps behind you.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: A political campaign is an orgy of worrying, culminating in a mass worrygasm on election eve, and if you're no good at worrying you will never be much admired around headquarters. But since it appears that the men who worry the least win the most, here is a rundown of eight basic worries and how to stop worrying about all eight, starting with soap.

title: About. Motor Sports
description: The United States Auto Club's new roadracing circuit has had more than its share of teething problems, but it now appears to have a program of sorts for 1971. The club has managed to schedule five races, and there is brave talk of adding three others. One show will play in the New York areathe Bridgehampton (L. I.) Race Circuit Sept. 12. The other dates are June 20, Wentzville, Mo.; July 11, Loudon, N. H.; July 25, Castle Rock, Colo., and Aug. 1, Kent, Wash.

title: Traveler's Guide Explains Port Authority's Facilities
description: A 26page Traveler's Guide to Port Authority Facilities in the Metropolitan area, containing information on services available and access routes, has been issued by the Port of New York Authority.

title: Pay Restored
description: A trend toward executive salary cuts during the last six months of 1970 apparently is being reversed now.

title: CANADIENS SCORE OVER KINGS, 8 TO 2
description: MONTREAL, March 6 (UPI)Jean Claude Tremblay set a team record today as he scored two goals and made one assist to lead the Montreal Canadiens to an 82 victory over the Los Angeles Kings in a National Hockey League game.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I was very much pleased to read Andrew Sarris's little diatribe on John Simon. It was about time that some one hit back at him for his continuous vicious and insulting comments on the theater, the movies and their audiences. His socalled criticism of No, No, Nanette is a perfect example. This is not criticism, which should have something constructive or instructive in its content, but a display of fancy words and malice, which Mr. Simon mistakenly thinks is cleverness and sophistication.

title: Ceylon Issues Tea Statistics
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 6 The United States was Ceylon's second best customer for tea last year, purchasing nearly 40 million pounds. Britain was Ceylon's best customer, purchasing approximately 156 million pounds.

title: CHARLES E.TOPPING SR.
description: Charles E. Topping Sr., retired superintendent of buildings, supplies and vehicles for the New York Telephone Company in Long Island, died Thursday in Franklin General Hospital, Valley Stream, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived at 1423 Mill Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Bound to Violence
description: Great novels are rare; great novels by Africans are even more rare, but they are on the way. One has only to look around at the African writers: Mongo Beti, Camara Laye, Amos Tutuola, Zeke Mphahele, Chinua Achebe, Cyprian Ekwensi, and on and on. Bound to Violence, a first novel, is a great one and would be even without the 1968 Prix Renaudot, which it won. It deserves many readings, since mistaken views are apt to come out of the first.

title: Penn Captures 26th, Tops Lions by 7048
description: The University of Pennsylvania completed its first undefeated regular basketball season since 192021 last night by defeating Columbia, 7058, at University Gymnasium. It was the 26th victory for the Quakers, the 43d in a row in regular season play and the 27th in the Ivy League.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title

title: Mr. Ling Rides Again
description: DALLASLongtime watchers of James J. Ling say he will be running publicly owned company with sales of at least $250million a year before 1971 closes.

title: Why Masai Warriors Spear Missionaries
description: N'AIROBI, Kenya Several Masai women, heads shaven and wearing the rustred dresses that are the virtual uniform of their tribe, sat on the ground by the dirt road intersection. Each wore thick aluminum coils wrapped from ankle to knee, like Puritan offenders. Their bodies seemed to sag with the weight of their other ornaments. Multistrand, multicolored beads covered their chests, layer on layer, to a thickness that almost reached their chins. Earlobes loaded with beaded decorations hung close to their shoulders.

title: F.C.C. Warns Broadcasters On Lyrics Backing Drug Use
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)The Federal Communications Commission has notified commercial broadcasters that they are responsible for keeping off the air any song lyrics tending to promote or glorify the use of illegal drugs.

title: Dogs Killing Deer As Deep Snowfalls Bog Down Herds
description: Deep snows and freely running dogs are causing suffering for deer herds this winter, according to Al Hall, director of the Division of Fish and Wildlife of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Announcements
description: Announcements

title: A Changing Brooklyn, but One Thomas Wolfe Would Recognize
description: Only the dead know Brooklyn, Thomas Wolfe remarked in a famous sentence. But no man was more alive to the place, to its sights and smells, to its unique ambiance, to its swarming and blazing humanity than the North Carolinaborn, novelist who lived in Brooklyn Heights and places adjacent from 1931 to 1935.

title: Californians Are Calling It Dissolution' but That's Still End of a Marriage
description: SAN DIEGOThere hasn't been divorce in California in more than a year, but that's only because the name has been changed to protect the innocent, and the guilty as well.

title: Reader's Report
description: What would you expect to find upon excavating a couple who have survived 900,000 years of suspended animation? Certainly not the continuation of a millionyearold crime passionel, which is what M. Barjavel uncovers in this very French bit of science fiction. Some of the obligatory scifiction requirements are here all right: a civilization higher than our own; a catalogue of gimmicks more wondrous than anything in the Hammacher Schlemmer catalogue; apocalyptic fantasies that make reel the mind. But once the International Polar expedition has chiseled deep beneath the South Polar ice to excavate an ingenious time capsule containing two deeply frozen human beings, the climate alters into a love story that can warm the heart as well as chill the blood. I can well understand why The Ice People was a numberone best seller in France. Who doesn't like to see love pitted apainst laboratory science? Who isn't happy for Masters and Johnson in their recent marriage?

title: NIXON NOW TARGET OF U.S. HARD HATS Former Allies on War Shift to Criticiim on Pay Curb
description: The natibn's hard hate:ttie construction workers who have given President Nixon stanch support for his Vietnam pollcies in sometimes boisterous demonstrations  seem more concerned now with what many call the President's antilabor stand.

title: Orderly Development Sought for Suffolk
description: While Suffolk County is one of the state's most rapidly developing regions, there is still time to channel the consequences of change.

title: Drug Arrests Up in Canada
description: OTTAWA, March 6 (AP)In 1970 the Royal Canadian Mounted Police made arrests at the rate of 1,000 a month in cases Involving marijuana and other soft drugs. This was double the arrest rate in 1969 and four times the rate in 1968, the force's deputy commissioner, J. R. R. Carriere, said this week. Harddrug arrests, mostly involving heroin, numbered 619.

title: VANDERBILT ELECTS BLACK STUDENT HEAD
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 6 Larry Wallace, a junior engineering student from Raleigh, N.C., has been elected as the first blacjc student president at Vanderbilt University, predominantly white private institution here.

title: More Nazi hows and whys than Nazi whats
description: During the Third Reich, one of the forms of resistance to the regime (admittedly not a very effective one) was the fabrication and circulation of jokes about Hitler and his associates. Hermann Goering, the muchbemedaled chief of the Air Force, and Josef Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, were favorite and often associated targets, as in the story concerning additions to the Table of Weights and Measurements, which were to include a GOr, which would signify the amount of metal a human being could carry on his chest, and a Goeb, the amount of energy needed to shut off 100,000 loudspeakers simultaneously.

title: MARGARET R. MAYNARD
description: LEWISTON, Me., March 6Miss Margaret R. Maynard, former Rockland County chairman of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, died here yesterday at the age of 86. She formerly lived in Nyack, N. Y.

title: DR. RALPH CHANEY, A REDWOOD EXPERT
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 6 (AP)Dr. Ralph W. Chaney, leading authority on redwood trees, died of a heart attack on Wednesday. He was 80 years old.

title: 35 Countries to View AliFrazier Title Battle
description: These 35 nations will see the FrazierAli fight by telesion via cable or satellite:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The draft law is up for renewal this June. What better way is there for all the dovish Senators, if they are indeed doves, to end the war in Vietnam than by not renewing the draft?

title: A Power Struggle Divides Rights Project
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., March 6 A power struggle rooted in ideological differences has jeopardized the future of the Delta Ministry, which was once regarded as one of the most energetic and innovative civil rights enterprises in the South.

title: Stamps
description: COMMUNITY stamp clubs have their exhibitions, too. Scheduled are shows in Westchester County and Rockland County, with the Westchester Stamp Show to be staged April 24 at Westchester County Center, White Plains, N. Y. Edward L. Ceccolini, P. 0. Box 2122, Eastchester, N. Y., 10709, is show director.

title: TALKS BROKEN OFF IN RAIL DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The nation's railroads and the United Transportation Union broke off contract negotiations today, raising the possibility of a strike by at least some of the union's 190,000 railroad firemen, brakemen, switchmen and other workers who ride and operate trains.

title: LETTERS
description: A high Federal Reserve official was reported to have said recently that the best economic recovery would be a gradual one, which might even involve unemployment rising for a while before falling slowly. At about the same time a former high official of the Nixon Administration was reported to have warned against a too rapid recovery planned by the Administration.

title: Letter to the Editor 29  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Isn't it time to put away the boxing gloves and pick up the pen again, this time with eyes clearly focused on films and not on the critic in the next seat?

title: POLICE ARE SUED OVER WARNINGS
description: A Greenwich Village man and a Brooklyn woman have asked Federal District Court here to order the Police Department to stop serving liability notices on the owners of buildings in which there has been a narcotics, gambling or prostitution arrest.

title: U.S. Six Halts Notre Dame
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 6 (AP)The United States national hockey team stretched its wonlosttied record to 249.3 tonight with a 75 victory over Notre Dame.

title: Sarris Vs. SimonWho Won?
description: To THE EDITOR: Now that Sarris and Simon have beaten each other on top of the head (who says two heads are better than one?), I think you should let Judith Crist and Rex Reed go at it in Round Two. I don't know if the results will be more interesting, but they could not be more childish.

title: Proctor Academy Appoints David Fowler Headmaster
description: Proctor Academy in. Andover, N.H., has announced the retirement of its headmaster, Dr. Lyle H. Farrel, and the appointment of David Fowler as his successor.

title: Airline Flights Altered for Fans Due From Italy
description: ROME, March 6 (Reuter)Some 1,500 Italian boxing fans will have to fly to the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier fight aboard scheduled flights, following an Air Ministry ban on six charter flights arranged with small United States air companies.

title: Photography
description: IN one of the most overrated movies of the 1960's, Francois Truffaut's Jules et Jim, part of the decor consisted of a series of reproductions of Picasso paintings. The unframed reproductions were done on stretched canvases, just like real paintings, but in smaller sizes than the originals. And, as the movie progressed, the pictures were changed, starting off with early works and progressing chronologically through the painter's various periods.

title: 3 Poor Prisoners Released
description: MANCHESTER, Ky., March 6 (UPI)Judge Clay M. Bishop released three Clay County jail prisoners today under a Supreme Court ruling last Wednesday that persons too poor to pay court fines cannot be jailed. The case was the first test of the high court decision in Kentucky.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson Tops Montclair State Five, 55.50
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 6Outshot from the floor by five field goals, Fairleigh Dickinson University converted 21 of 30 foul tries to down Montclair State, 5550, today.

title: Elizabeth Anne Ivey Is Married
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 6Miss Elizabeth Anne Ivey was married here this afternool to Robert Chadwick Roy Jr. in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Clifford Grise.

title: Former Nassau Police Aide Named to Help Drug Fight
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 6Former Nassau County Police Commissioner Francis B. Looney has been named by County Executive Ralph G. Caso as a special consultant on the problems of narcotics and drug abuse.

title: 20 Reported Killed
description: DACCA, East Pakistan, March 6 (AP)  Witnesses reported at least 20 persons were killed yesterday in clashes between security forces and demonstrators in the Tongi Industrial suburb of Dacca.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONIf President Nixon still is pursuing his policy of unrestricted air strikes in Indochina year from now, he will be opposed in the Republican Presidential primariesand that could turn out to be the biggest joke since Eugene McCarthy took on President Johnson in 1968.

title: FREE SPEECH BAN A BERKELEY ISSUE
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 6 Free speech and the right of political advocacy on campus have again become a prime concern of some students and faculty members at the University of California here.

title: City's Five Outdoor Rinks To End Season March 22
description: The city's five outdoor skating rinks are going to c'ose on March 22, a month earlier than usual, but two indoor rinks will stay open.

title: Dance Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I thought it appropriate that Faubion Bowers should use St. Francis Xavier to describe Clive Barnes, for it was surely out of Christian humility that Barnes let Bejart off so easily. I have never seen able dancers so badly used. The superficiality and the affectation of the choreography, coupled with its air of deep seriousness, could only be explained as commercial opportunism, at best, or as mediocre amateurism, at worst.

title: Letter
description: To the Editor: I was amused by A. L. Rowse's recent essay, London Letters Falling Down. After broadmindedly suggesting that writers might come from Yorkshire or Dorset as well as Bloomsbury, this version of the British literary scene decried the expansion in the numbers at the universities. Mr. Rowse, unfortunately, can't have it both ways.

title: Borough President Leviss Faces Challenge of Keeping Increasingly Industrial Queens Reside
description: Queens is still primarily a residential borough, and I'm going to do everything in my power to keep it that way, Sidney Leviss, Queens Borough President, said as he settled into his office chair and paused, either to think or to allow the noise of the airplane overhead, which all but drowned out his words, to fade away.

title: Holovak on Raider Staff
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 6 (UPI)The Oakland Raiders hired the former Boston Patriot coach, Mike Holovak, today as coach of pass receivers. The 51yearold Holovak was head coach of the Patriots for eight years.

title: Jet Engines Salvaged
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 6 (Reuters)An aircraft dealer, Vaughan Lamb of San Jose, Calif., has bought five engines from a Swissair DC8 and T.W.A. Boeing 707 blown up in the Jordanian desert by Palestinian guerrillas last year. He feels they are in good enough condition to be used again.

title: Welfare Recipients Hold Las Vegas Protest March
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March. 6 (UPI)  Nearly Z000 welfare recipients and sympathizers marched into Caesar's Palace gambling casino here today during a protest designed to interrupt business as, usual on the Las Vegas strip.

title: To Hades and Back (Hic) With Homer's Help
description: IOANNINA, GreeceI have just returned from a visit to Hades, and I had a devilishly good time. This ancient Greek dwelling place of the dead, some 300 miles northwest of Athens, is only a hop, skip and a jump from Ioannina, but I would never have made it without the aid of two modern Greek guides  drunk as they became curing our travels.

title: Joe Frazier: A Relentless Champion
description: Joe Frazier always has been a laboreron a farm in his boyhood, in a slaughterhouse and as a boxer.

title: DR. MAX GRUNEWALD, A CEMENT EXECUTIVE
description: Dr. Max Eugene Grunewald, an executive in the cement industry, died Friday at his home here. He was 66 years old.

title: C Particle'A Unified Theory of Cancer
description: FOR half a century a small, persistent and intrepid brand of scientists insisted, often at the top of their decibel range, that cancer is caused by man's tiniest and most mysterious natural enemy: the virus. Very few scientists ever listened; if they did, they generally objected. How can a virus cause cancer when doctors don't seem to get it from their patients, or from research animals, or from tissue cultures?, the skeptics asked. Why do the old folks come down with cancer more frequently than the young? Why are there so many different agents1,000 chemicals alone at last countcapable of bringing about animal cancers in the laboratory? And why do Japanese males and New York Jews suffer more than other ethnic and cultural groups from cancer of the stomach, while the Chinese on Taiwan die more often from cancer of the nasopharynx?

title: Gierek Cautions Poles On Subversive Forces
description: WARSAW, March 6Edward Gierek, Poland's Communist party chief, warned today against centers of hostile subversion that he said were trying to underruine the nation.

title: EISEINIOWEIVS POSITION
description: Some comments on two of the more obvious errors of fact in Richard H. Rovere's article, Eisenhower RevisitedA Political Genius? A Brilliant Man? (Feb. 7).

title: Letter to the Editor 26  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: The attack by John Simon on Andrew Sarris and by Sarris on Simon was essentially a minor annoyance made great only by the prominence given it by The Times. Between the two articles, the greater blame must go to Simon's, for Sarris's articles are generally pacific whereas Simon's are known for their badtempered acidity.

title: Music
description: A FIVEDAY international festival and conference celebrating the 450th anniversary of the death of Josquin des Prez will probably seem like an extremely esoteric venture to nonmusicians and to musicians whose interest extends no further back than Bach. If the observance were for Michelangelo, no one would be surprised. Yet, says Edward Lowinsky, director of the festivalconference, Josquin's place in cultural history is just as important as Michelangelo's. He has been described as the first musician to have genius as well as one of the greatest musical geniuses of any period. To give a simplified explanation, he brought to music an expressive power it had never known.

title: Dance Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Clive Barnes has rarely written as much about ballet as he has about Mart's Ballet of the 20th Century. He has rarely seemed so bent on destruction.

title: Mrs. Mary Pool Wed to Broker
description: Mrs. Mary Schwab Pool of East Hampton, L.I., and New York, widow of H. Lawrence Pool, was married here yesterday afternoon to Philip M. Brett Jr., who is with Stillman, Maynard & Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, The ceremony was performed in the Central Presbyteriat Church by the Rev, Robert Perry and attended by members of the immediate families.

title: Mounted Great Auk Brings $21,600 at London Auction
description: LONDON, March 6, (Reuters) The highest price ever paid for a natural history specimen $21,600was paid this week for a mounted great auk at Sotheby's auction house.

title: The Soviet Version
description: MOSCOW, March 6 (UPI)Stating that Muhammad, Ali was deprived of his title because he refused to serve in the United States Army and fight in Vietnam, the Russian news agency, Tass, told its readers today that Frazier was awarded the champion's title in 1968. This was done against the established order.

title: Peter King to Wed Barbara A. Howard
