description: CAIRO, March 9 (UPI)Following are the texts of a letter sent to the United Arab Republic on Feb. 8 by Dr. Gunnar. V. Jarring proposing moves for peace with Israel and of the Egyptian reply, dated Feb. 15, which became available here today:

title: Rogers Says Chou Tried to Soothe Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Secretary of State William P. Rogers tonight characterized the Hanoi visit of Premier Chou Enlai of Cominunist China as an effort to give some comfort to the North Vietnamese because they have been suffering setbacks.

title: Upstate Man Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, March (UPI) The Defense Department said today that Specialist 4 John W. Kupkowski of Blasdell, N. Y., of the Army, had been killed in the war in South east Asia.

title: Cornell 63 Victor
description: ITHACA, N. Y., March 9 Cornell scored five goals in the second period to erase a 10 Providence lead and go on to defeat the Friars, 63, in an E.C.A.C. playoff quarterfinal game at Lynah Rink tonight.

title: Toxic Paint Is Found On Hospitals'
description: The city's yearold Cam. Paign to eliminate lead poisoning among slum children has turned up another hazard highly toxic paint on the walls of hospital pediatric wards.

title: Proposal for Cuts For Conservation Held Aid to Polluter
description: ALBANY, March 9  Proposed budget cuts in state environmental programs would give aid and comfort to polluters and seriously cut back recreation programs, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation charged today.

title: ARE'S RULE CUT IN EAST PAKISTAN
description: DACCA Pakistan, March 9 East Pakistani Government officials refused to go to work today for the martiallaw authorities assigned by the central Government in West Pakistan to administer this eastern wing of the country.

title: Excerpts From the Interview Granted by President Nixon on Foreign Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  Following are excerpts from an interview with President Nixon conducted here yesterday by C. L. Sulzberger, foreignaffairs columnist of The New York Times. The transcript, which is unofficial, was prepared by Mr. Sulzberger from his notes.

title: Observance of Purim To Begin at Sundown
description: The Jewish festival of Purim will begin at sundown today and last through tomorrow, with ceremonies in synagogues and homes.

title: F.D.I.C. Chief Hits Brokered Deposits
description: WASHINGTON, March (AP)The head of the nation's bank deposit insurance system said today that Congress should outlaw brokered deposits, device by which banks become intermediaries for sometimes doubtful loans.

title: Building Unions Defend Hiring Policy
description: Four building union locals accused of refusing to comply with a city plan to get more minority workers into construction jobs defended their own integration records at a public hearing held here yesterday by the state advisory committee of the United, States Civil Rights Commission.

title: JOHN KING ACCUSED BY U.S. ON REPORTS
description: DENVER, March 9 (AP)John M. King, former chief executive of the financially troubled King Resources Company, was accused today by the Securities and Exchange Commission of having disseminated false reports on the condition of the company during a period when he and an associate, A. Rowland Boucher, were selling their own stock.

title: AUSTRALIAN PARTY REPLACES GORTON AS PRIME MINISTER
description: CANBERRA Australia Wednesday March 10John G. Gorton was deposed as Prime Minister of Australia today when he lost a vote of confidence by members of his Liberal party.

title: Books of The Times
description: Doris Lessing's new novel can be most accurately described as protean: no sooner does the reader get a grip on it than it becomes something else. Just when he thinks he has lined up the author's intent, changes. These volatile alterations in emphasis and direction don't seem to trouble the author. Somehow the book manages to be something more than its parts. In spite of its jigsaw structure, the book compels the reader's interest. The result is certainly proof of Mrs. Lessing's skill and vision. But as her previous works have revealed, she is not one whose novels necessarily fall into easy categories. Perhaps these changes in key and concern are only ways of permitting her to declare herself on a number of topics. Since, like most of us, she is not interesting at all times, some of her disquisitions, no matter how exotic in setting or fanciful in incident, are vacuously selfevident. Sometimes in fact she becomes so intent on the preachy side of her fiction that the novel limps to a halt. Yet even these sections are absorbed into her story.

title: Jockeys and Fans Playing It Cool at Aqueduct
Britain Will Chart Safe Lane To Skirt 3 Channel Wrecks
description: LONDON, March 9  Nine ships of the British Navy are gathering in the English Channel to seek a safe temporary lane for westbound traffic be cause of the recent wrecks in the normal lane.

title: MISS ZUKERMAN IN FLUTE RECITAL
description: Lots of flutists have a fatter, rounder tone than does Eugenia Zukerman, and more of a silvery sheen, a greater range of color and dynamics, and they can play faster and more accurately.

title: NURSERY SCHOOLS GROWING RAPIDLY
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The Census Bureau reported today an explosive growth between 1965 and 1970 in the number of children aged 3 and 4 enrolled in nursery schools and kindergartens.

title: Protest by Homosexuals
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (Reuters) Members of the Washington area gay liberation movement invaded the Pentagon today to protest discrimination against homosexuals by the armed services and the Department of Defense. They marched upstairs to the office of Army Secretary Stanley R. Resor but were unable to see him.

title: Louisiana Files Suit
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 9 (AP) Louisiana's Attorney General asked a United States. District Court here today to force the four maor auto makers to install antipollution devices on all cars manufactured, since 1953.

title: STATIONS CAUTIONED ABOUT DRUG LYRICS
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)  Acting on complaints about songs that promote the use of illegal drugs, the Federal Communications Commission has warned broadcasters that they have a responsibility to be aware of the lyrics of records they play over the air.

title: Postal Clerk Slain
description: PITTSBURG, Calif., March 9 (UPI)A woman postal clerk, Mrs. Etha Bauman, 56 years old, was shot to death today by a gunman apparently enraged because a letter he expected did not arrive. The police seized Donald Russell, 45, shortly after the shooting at the Pittsburg Post Office. He was booked for investigation.

title: TIMELIFE TO SELL CASSETTE PROGRAMS
description: TimeLife Video, the prerecorded television division of Time Inc., will, offer subscribers selections of outstanding programs for, new cartridge and cassette video players.

title: Ohio State Takes Title
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 9 (UPI)Jim Cleamons scored 30 points tonight to lead Ohio State to a 9175 victory over Indiana. The triumph gave the Buckeyes the Big Ten basketball title and a berth in the National Collegiate tournament.

title: PACIFISTS ATTACK U.S. STAIID IN PARIS
description: PARIS March 9A band of 171 American pacifists ended today a pilgrimage during which they prayed with David K. E. Bruce, the chief United States truce negotiator, sang with his associates and explored the Issues of the Indochinese war with all parties here.

title: Soviet Moon Tests Resume
description: MOSCOW, March 9 (UPI)1 Lunokhod I, the Soviet Union's moon vehicle, resumed scien1 tific experiments and perform. ance tests on the lunar surface; late last night, Tess, the Soviet press agency, said today. It had been idle for two weeks during the lunar night.

title: Private Rejection in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 9  Government officials here privately rejected today the Japanese call for voluntary restraints on textile exports to the United States.

title: Bridge: Touring Stars in First Loss, Bowing to Washington Tearm
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The AllStar Precision Club touring team met its first defeat here Sunday, losing a short exhibition match to an American Bridge Association group by a 10point margin, 45 to 35.

title: David Rockefeller in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, March 9 (Reuters) David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, arrived here this evening on fiveday visit by private plane from Cyprus after visits to Cairo, Amman and Beirut.

title: Drunkenness Bill Introduced
description: BOSTON, March 9 (AP)Legislation that would repeal the crime of public drunkenness by March, 1974, and establish more comprehensive treatment facilities in the interim was filed yesterday by Gov. Francis W. Sargent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ChairmanDesignate of Tariff Commission Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The White House announced today that President Nixon had accepted the resignation of Chester L. Mize, chairmandesignate of the United States Tariff Commission.

title: Herbert A. Hofmann, President Of Loews Hotels, Is Dead at 54
description: Herbert A. Hofmann, who was named president of. Loews Hotels a week ago, died yesterday morning while in San Juan, P. R., on a business trip. He was 54 years old and lived at 70 Greenhaven Drive, Rye, N. Y.

title: CIVIL WAR PICTURE HAS FESTIVAL LEAD
description: DALLAS, March 9 (AP)First official feature chosen for the U.S.A. Film Festival, which opened here yesterday, was Donald Siegel's The Beguiled, a psychological drama of the Civil War.

title: A Selective Ban On Chemical Arms Urged by Sweden
description: GENEVA, March 9Sweden recommended today that the 25nation disarmament conference prohibit chemical and bacteriological weapons on a sliding scale, depending upon haw deadly they are and whether their components have any peaceful use.

title: Laird Hints at Missile Threats But Asks Restrained Response
description: WASHINGTON March 9 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird spoke guardedly today of possible new Soviet and Chinese strategic missiles, but recommended a restrained response in United States weapons programs.

title: Jersey City Strike Continues
description: JERSEY CITY, March 9All 40 city schools remained closed for the second day today as a strike by 400 custodial and cafeteria workers continued. A spokesman for the school board said it would not seek a restraining order against the strikers as long as it appeared the strike could be settled at the bargaining table. But no negotiations were scheduled.

title: Resolving the Textile Dispute
description: The Japanese textile industry, acting in response to suggestion from Chairman Wilbur D. Mills of the. House Ways and Means Committee, has come through with plan for ending the dispute between Japan and the United States over import quotas.

title: HARRY E. GOULD; STRICKEN AT FIGHT
description: Harry E. Gould, former chairman of the Universal American Corporation, suffered a heart attack in his ringside seat in the fourth round of the FrazierAli fight in Madison Square Garden Monday night, and was pronounced dead at Polyclinic Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived on Taconic Road in Greenwich, Conn., and at the Pierre Hotel.

title: Lithuanian Barred by U.S. Is Now Reported jailed While Soviet Studies Treason Charge
description: MOSCOW, March 9Simas Kudirka, the Lithuanian sailor who was refused political sanctuary in the United States after jumping from his fishing ship to a Coast Guard cutter last November, is reported to be in a Vilna prison undergoing investigation of treason charges.

title: Dayan Says Israel Detains Families of 29 Guerrillas
description: JERUSALEM, Maroh 9 (AP) Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that the Is, raeli's were operating a detention camp in the Sinai Desert for families of wanted Arab guerrillas.

title: Average Family's Tax Under Lindsay's Plan
description: An average New York family of four, with an average number of tax deductions that has taxable income of $10,000 a year, pays $32 in city income taxes now and would pay $59.66 under Mayor Lindsay's new plan.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It was a ritual that Muhammad All unfailingly followed, at least up to that point before he was driven into enforced exile. After each fight the onetime Cassius Clay would step blithely through his dressingroom door and walk straight to a mirror. That handsome face would smile back at him, giving him all the reassurance he needed.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTONThe most interesting thing about President Nixon is that he regards himself as a genuine but practical pacifist who is slowly building a world which may never see another war. He attributes this urge to his maternal Quaker heritage, but he views his approach as necessarily pragmatic, cautious and based upon wide international experience.

title: ASPIRA IS ORDERED TO SHUT CENTERS
description: The Council Against Poverty has ordered Aspire, one of the city's leading Puerto Rican selfhelp agencies, to close its youth centers in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx and to add 26 representatives of the community corporations to its 19member board of directors.

title: Landscaping Plan Filed by Museum
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has filed a plan for the landscaping of the slope that rises beyond its western facade in Central Park. The work would be done near the site on which it intends to build a new wing, the Lehman Pavilion.

title: 3,000 VISIT ALBANY ON SCHOOLS'
description: ALBANY, March 9Three thousand New York City parents, teachers, administrators and students roamed the vast corridors of the State Capitol this afternoon and complained to every legislator they could find about the proposed spending cuts that they contend will destroy their already troubled schools. Most found it a frustrating and depressing experience.

title: Rudel Leads Jaunty Serenade By New Amsterdam Ensemble
description: Like other intensively trained professionals, musicians tend to stop developing shortly after leaving school unless they work at keeping up an interest in fields beyond their own. Just as a surgeon may spend his career doing one operation, the opera musician, especially, can step into the orchestra pit as a young person and never be seen again.

title: Democratic Coalition Is Joining Protest on City Housing Policy
description: The New Democratic Coalition, which threw pivotal support to Mayor Lindsay as he won reelection in 1969, is planning to play a leading role in picketing his residence Saturday for doing nothing to alleviate the worst housing shortage in the city's history.

title: Senate Finance Panel Votes Rise in National Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON, March (UPI)The Senate Finance Committee approved today, to 4, a bill that would raise the ceiling on the national debt by $35billion and permit the Treasury to sell longterm bonds at prevailing interest rates.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This letter is in response to your Feb. 24 editorial making specific reference to the Administration's position on the plight of Negro colleges.

title: MEDINA REJECTS CALLEY ACCOUNT Tells Trial He Told Soldiers Before Mylai, You Do Not Kill Women and Children
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 10With a hard, unblinking stare at his subordinate, Capt. (Ernest L. Medina testified today that he had never given First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. orders to kill women and children at Mylai.

title: Builder of Concorde Says Soviet Is Winning SST Race
description: PARIS, March 10 (Reuters) France's leading aircraft producer warned today that the Soviet supersonic transpqrt was coming up fast and that the West was losing the race for an SST.

title: ARMY KEEPS FAITH ROLE OF COPTER
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Serious helicopter, losses in the allied offensive in Laos have not shaken the United States Army's faith in the choppers as an indispensable and revolutionary element in conventional and guerrilla war.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: March 10, 1971

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS RURAL AID PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 10President Nixon, declaring that urban America has a vital stake in the wellbeing and progress of rural America, called on Congress today to provide $1.1billion to the states in the fiscal year beginning July 1 to make rural life more attractive.

title: Dumping Duty Authorized On TV Sets From Japan
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)  The Treasury Department formally declared today that Japanese television sets imported from Japan are subject to special dumping duties under a 1921 law.

title: Corrected Texts of Letter From Jarring and Reply by the Egyptians
description: Jarring's Letter

title: Their Vacation TrophiesMementos of Meals
description: When the Fred McMillins want to prepare a special dish, or even an entire meal, that they remembered from one of their frequent trips to Europe, there's no problem. They simply trot out their movies, color slides and tape recordings to refresh their memories.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The redesign of the Park Avenue malls is a poorly conceived project in all Its aspects.

title: Mrs. Thesieres, Partner Squash Racquets Victors
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 10 Mrs. Terry Thesieres and Mrs. Nathan Stauffer gained the semifinal round of the Unit ed States squash racquets doubles championship by defeating Mrs. David Maroney and Mrs. Alan Reed, 1815, 15.5, 15.8, today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club. Mrs. Thesieres is the United States singles champion and Mrs. Stauffer is former holder of that title.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We read with deep concern your [Feb. 20] editorial on cleanliness at the Port Authority Bus Terminal. Some two and a half to three tons of litter are removed from the bus terminal each day by a 79man cleaning staff employed directly by the Port Authority and supplemented by outside contractual forces.

title: Charge Moderated
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., March 10 (AP)The Army said today that the charges on which Captain Medina would be tried did not accuse him of personally killing 100 Mylai villagers during a sweep by his company.

title: DR. H. C. SCHARFE, 63, PITTSBURGH PASTOR
description: PITTSBURGH, March 10Dr. Howard C. Scharfe, pastor of the Shadyside Presbyterian Church for 26 years, died yesterday in West Penn Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: Services Planning To Reshuffle Units In Economy Move
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) The Army, Navy and Air Force announced today a reshuffling of units and personnel to save money, while the Strategic Air Command disclosed plans to realign its forces.

title: Who Knows What About Drugs?
description: Drug addiction persists as a major, stubbornly unyielding problem in New York City. Municipal efforts to combat it continue to flounder and, after the spending of millions of tax dollars and the deaths of thousands of addicts, the public is unhappily left with too many questions and too few answers.

title: I.R.A. Faction Accuses Rivals
description: BELFAST, March 10 (AP)The militant provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army accused the leftist official branch today of beatings and torture in the battle for control of Belfast's Catholic area.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Bicyclists in the city's parks ignore regulations with impunity. Dog owners seem not to have heard of leashes. Let's hope the Parks Department does something about the noxious influx of minimotor scooters before they too get out of hand.

title: International Paper, Board Sets Up an Executive Unit
description: The International Paper Company announced yesterday the formation of an executive committee of the board of directors.

title: Clash on Temple Mount
description: TEL AVIV, March 10Israeli policemen scuffled this afternoon with Jewish students trying to organize a demonstration on the Temple Mount, which is sacred to both Jews and Moslems. The demonstrators were protesting the Israeli Government's reported intention to recognize Jordan as the custodian of the Moslem holy places on Temple Mount.

title: Deciding to Stay and Fight Pollution
description: Ten young housewives, who looked more like fashion models in their shiny long hair and midicoats, marched into a D'Agostino's supermarket on the East Side yesterday and taped posters listing the phosphate count of detergents on the walls.

title: Fusion Power Is Still Facing Formidable Difficulties
description: Controlled fusion  the taming of the reartion in a hydrogen bomb  seems to be on the horizon. It is now clear, in the words of two scientists of the Atomic Energy Commission, that no laws of nature stand in the way.

title: MOORER IS GLOOMY ON ARMS OUTLOOK
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff told Congress today that the United States could, in the next several years, find itself in a position of strategic inferiority.

title: G.M. CHIEF SCORES BUSINESS CRITICS
description: James M. Roche, chairman lof the General Motors CorporaItion, delivered a broad counterattack last night against what he called the instant ecologists, the new consumerists and other professional critics lof private business.

title: Misconduct by Vietnam G. I.'s Charged
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Army is investigating charges by a colonel who served in Vietnam alleging a variety of misdeeds by American and South Vietnamese and a coverup by one of his superiors.

title: School Deficit Settled For Very Brief Period
description: For a fleeting moment yesterday, it appeared that the Board of Education had been blessed with an answer to its budget deficit in the form of a $45million check.

title: Brown, Ali Aide, Is Suspended For Throwing Water Over Ring
description: Drew (Bundini) Brown, who has been Muhammad Ali's assistant trainer since 1963, has been suspended indefinitely by the State Athletic Commission for acts detrimental to boxing during Monday night's world heavyweight championship bout at Madison Square Garden.

title: Browns Sign Blanchard
description: CLEVELAND, March 10 (AP) The Cleveland Browns signed today Felix (Tony) Blanchard, son of the former star Army player, Felix (Doc) Blanchard. The Browns picked Blanchard in the 12th round of the National Football League draft. Contract terms were not disclosed.

title: Nash Buckingham, Outdoorsman, Dies; Wrote Sport Books
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 10 Nash Buckingham, dean of Tennessee sportsmen and one of the founders of the Outdoor Writers Association of America, died here today at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Roy Witt. He was born in Memphis 90 years ago and began his career as a sports writer for The Memphis Commercial Appeal.

title: Damage Suit Is Rejected
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10 (AP)A $500,000 damage suit against Corinne Calvet, the actress, was rejected yesterday by a Superior Court jury. The decision went against Roslyn K. Scott, 37 years old, who charged that Miss Calvet, 45, and Mrs. Scott's former husband and codefendant in the suit, Donald P. Scott, 41, conspired to conceal his assets when she accepted a $45,000 divorce settlement in 1966.

title: 3 BRITISH SOLDIERS SLAIN IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, March 11Three British soldiers were found slain last night near a pub on a lonely road three miles north of Belfast.

title: China Pledges Sacrifice to Aid Hanoi
description: HONG KONG, March 10Communist China and North Vietnam issued a joint communique today that spoke of new plans for cooperation between the two countries and Chinese preparedness to make the greatest national sacrifices.

title: 71 Whooping Cranes
description: PORTLAND, Ore., March 10 (AP)The world's whooping crane populationdown to 14 in 1930stood at 71 today. Dr. Kenton C. Lint, president of the Whooping Crane Conservation Association, reported the latest count to a meeting of the group in Portland.

title: BRITISH ARTIST FOUND SLAIN IN STUDIO HERE
description: John Rudge, a British abstract painter, was found bludgeoned to death early Sunday morning at his studio, 269 Bowery. According to the police, there were no clues to the killer of Mr. Rudge, who was 46 years old.

title: RETAIL SALES UP A BIT IN FEBRUARY
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Retail sales continued to gain in February, though at, a moderate pace, the Census Bureau reported today on the basis of preliminary'figures.

title: Stocks on Amex Register Drop For First Time in 8 Sessions
Barbara Loden Speaks Of the World of Wanda
description: The film Wanda opened recently at the Cinema II under banners of international critical praise. It bears the signature of Barbara Loden she wrote it, directed it and played its central rolein other than obvious ways.

title: China Policy: Confrontation...
description: There is probably a large element of propaganda last weekend's highly publicized visit of Communist Chinese officials to North Vietnam, as Secretary of State Rogers has suggestedjust as there is no doubt a considerable measure of bluff in recent South Vietnamese threats to invade North Vietnam.

title: JOSEPH FRANK
description: Joseph Frank, former assistant chief engineer in the office of the Manhattan Borough President, died yesterday in St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Washington Heights. He was 90 years old and lived at 900 West 190th Street.

title: Mayors Lay President's Rebuff To Reluctance to Help Lindsay
description: BALTIMORE, March 10The President of the United States Conference of Mayors said today that President Nixon had rebuffed the group's repeated requests for a White House meeting because the. President regarded such a meeting as a national buildup of Mayor Lindsay's political career.

title: STONY BROOK ACTS IN CAMPUS STRIKE
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., March 10The administration of the State University Center here agreed tonight to step into threedayold strike of food service workers after a sevenhour sitin by 200 students and cafeteria workers in the president's suite of offices.

title: Study Urges Greater Use Of TransHudson Tunnel
description: A New YorkNew Jersey study group, noting that the transHudson rail tunnel was being utilized to only half its capacity, urged yesterday that use of the facility be Increased providing access to it by two New Jersey commuter lines.

title: Libya Spurns New Offer on Oil But Extends Deadline 3 Days
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, March 10The Libyan Government today rejected the latest offer by Western oil companies for increased payments but gave the companies three more days to reach agreement.

title: Papp Is Named Winner Of Margo Jones Award
description: Joseph Papp,, founder and director of the New York Shakespeare Festival, has been named winner of the 10th annual Margo Jones award for having made the, most significant contribution to the dramatic art with hitherto unproduced plays.

title: MEDICAL COSTS UP 10.1% HERE IN 1970
description: The cost of medical care. in New York State and northeast. ern New Jersey is experiencing its sharpest rise in 20 years, Federal authorities reported yesterday.

title: The Nixon Outlook: Internationalism and Commitment
description: WASHINGTON, March 10President Nixon's highly personal definition of his foreign policy, given to The New York Times this week, amounted above all to a confident reassertion of the faith of the World War II generation of American internationalists against the challenge and disillusionment spread by the war in Vietnam. More directly than before, Mr. Nixon argued that he had kept the faith of the nineteenforties and nineteenfifties while the nation's once farsighted Establishment was running out on its principles toward isolation and weakness.

title: Frazier Boxer of Month
description: MANILA, March 10 (UPI)The World Boxing Council named today the world heavyweight champion, Joe Frazier, as its boxer of the month for his decision over Muhammad Ali.

title: Queens G.I. Is Killed
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)The Defense Department today announced the names of 12 American servicemen killed in action in the war in Southeast Asia. Among them was Pfc. Joseph B. Hart, an Army man of Richmond Hill, Queens.

title: S.E.C. HALTS TRADING IN ROLLS FOR 10 DAYS
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced a 10day suspension of trading in American securities of RollsRoyce Ltd., the bankrupt British aircraft engine maker.

title: LADY AGAR
description: Lady Agar, widow of Sir Arthur K. Agar, Chief Justice of British Honduras, died on Tuesday at her home on Grand Cayman Island, in the West Indies.

title: Perez Signs Reds'
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 10 (UPI) Tony Perez, the slugging third baseman, signed with the Cincinnati Reds tonight for an estimated $75,000, leaving twotime batting champion Pete Rose as the National League Champions only holdout.

title: East Pakistanis Think. Regime Treats Them as Colony of Old
description: DACCA, Pakistan, March 10 The domination of the eastern region of Pakistan by the western one is almost exactly parallel to the domination of the land that is now Pakistan by British colonial rulers 50 years ago.

title: Nixon Bill Offers Bonuses to Schools to Speed Doctor Training
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Nixon Administration disclosed today that it would attempt to use the bait of Federal funds to have medical schools reduce their, training periods as well as to increase class sizes to turn out many, more critically needed doctors.

title: Professor Offers to Resign N. Y.U. Residence Hall Post
description: Dr. Joseph Gennaro Jr. has offered to resign as resident master at Rubin Hall, a dormitory at New York University, following a meeting Tuesday with students and university officials.

title: I.T.T. 1970 Net Up 21%;
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation achieved new highs in sales and earnings for 1970. The company announced yesterday that its operations last year marked the 11th consecutive year of record performance.

title: MISS PROELL WINS WORLD CUP TITLE
description: ABETONE, Italy, March 10 (AP)  Annemarie Proell, 17yearold skiing daredevil from Austria, clinched the World Cup today by winning the giant slalom in the Coppa Foemina international races.

title: Vermont 21 Hockey Victor
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., March 10 (AP)Goals by Bill Dunnington and Ned Grant, plus outstanding goaltending by Dave Reece, gave Vermont a 21 hockey victory over Massachusetts tonight in an Eastern College Athletic Conference Division II firstround game.

title: DR. DOMINICK A. CONTINO
description: FLORAL PARK, L. I., March 10Dr. Dominick A. Contino, who had practiced medicine here for 36 years, died apparently of a. heart attack today, at his home, 26 Floral Parkway. He was 63 years old.

title: New Aqueduct Jockey Room Gets Woman's Touch
description: A jockey room with nylon stockings on the couch, a fulllength mirror on the wall and a handbag on the he'd made its debut yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Symington Suggests Jackson Disclosed Classified Material on Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, March Senator Stuart Symington suggested today that Senator Henry M. Jackson had used classified information in stating on a nationwide television program that the Soviet Union was deploying an advanced intercontinental ballistic missile.

title: F.C.C. Renews Quest for Cable Policy
description: WASHINGTON, March 10On the verge of a fresh plunge into the murky issues of cable television, the Federal Communications Commission is determined to come up with a policy but openly confused as to what it is looking for.

title: ELGAR WORK FINDS ORMANDY AT BEST
description: Eugene Ormandy, in his element, is an unbeatable conductor, and since his element includes Elgar's Enigma Variations, the Philadelphia Orchestra concert at Philharmonic Hall Tuesday night ended gloriously.

title: Eddie Miller, for 50 Years A Stage and Radio Singer
description: Eddie Miller, veteran Broadway baritone, died Tuesday in South Oaks Hospital, Amityville, L.I., at the age of 80.

title: Advertising:
description: Pan American World Airways is adopting its own version of the packagegoods industry's productmanager system. Why not? It sells soap.

title: LAOTIANS DRIVEN FROM VITAL BASE
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 10  The Laotian military command announced today the loss of a base that is vital for harassment and surveillance of the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in the southern panhandle.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Has Big Lead With Half of Votes Counted
description: NEW DELHI, Thursday, March 11Prime Minister Indira Gandhi took a surprisingly big lead today with half the returns in from India's fifth national election, which was largely a referendum on her personal standing. Her supporters were leading victory processions through New Delhi streets.

title: Town in Kansas Is Willing To Live With Atom Dump
description: The Talk of Lyons, Kan.

title: Bridge: Doubling on Principles. Has an Element of Risk
description: GREENVILLE S.C., March 10 The allstar Precision Club Owing team scored a comfortable victory in its penultimate march here last night.

title: Bishop Loughlin Dethroned By La Salle's Track Team
description: La Salle Academy won the Christian Brothers Schools indoor track title yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory, ending Bishop Loughlin's fouryear reign.

title: Newark's School Strike
description: The strike that has disrupted Newark's public schools for more than five weeks underscores the need in all states for impartial machinery to resolve civil service labor disputes on a basis fair to citizens and public employes alike.

title: Nyquist Aide Starts City School Study
description: The state's investigation into the projected budget deficit of the Board of Education here began yesterday.

title: View of India Amid Election Stress: Democracy Endures but the Problems Are Manifold
description: NEW DELHI, March 10A sympathetic Western world once regarded India as a crucial test of whether a country with overwhelming problems of poverty and social backwardness and a crippling legacy of colonialism could survive as democracyor even as a tion. The world's attention is no longer on India, but the country has survived after a fashion. She may not have done so brilliantly  some say she has just barely done so, and not for longbut she has in fact endured and is still practicing democracy.

title: Selectivity Is Key to a Champion Dog
description: Mrs. Harry Quick of Chicago Heights, Ill., should serve as an inspiration to the fancier who goes to shows, wins a few ribbons, but never has a champion. I bought a black standard poodle in 1950, when I was living in Boston, said Mrs. Quick. She picked up a few points, enough to encourage me to continue, so that I added some toys and miniatures. I enjoyed showing and bred several litters, but never had any real success.

title: Von Braun Reports New Skylab. Plans For Space Rescue
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) The space agency disclosed plans today to develop a space rescue capability late next year.

title: Russell to Coach Quintet
description: MEMPHIS, March 10 (UPI)Officials of MidSouth sports Action, Inc., announced today that the fornier Boston Celtics star, Bill Russell, would coach the East team in the EastWest senior allAmerican basketball game April 1. Mike Lynn, president of MidSouth Sports, earlier had announced that Bob Pettit, former star of the St. Louis Hawks, would serve as coach for the West squad.

title: Buckley Offers Tax Plan as Alternative to Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Senator James L. Buckley suggested an alternative today to President Nixon's revenuesharing plan under which the state legislatures would ask the Federal Government to collect specified portion of federal income taxes to be turned back to each state.

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES ON BOMB'S VALUE
description: A 22yearold witness testified yesterday that he and a friend hail been questioned at gunpoint in February, 1969, by Black Panthers dissatisfied with the quality of some dynamite.

title: PARTY IS OF NO HELP IN PANTHER SLAYING
description: New York policemen investigating the daylight slaying of a Black Panther party official on Monday reported yesterday that they had received no cooperation so far from party members in Manhattan.

title: U.S. CHOICE HARD ON TEXTILE OFFER
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 President Nixon is expected to announce within the next few days his reaction to Japan's unilateral decision to restrict textile exports, according to authoritative sources today.

title: West Pakistani Offers To Meet Eastern Rival
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 10  Zulfikar All Bhutto, leader of West Pakistan's dominant People's party, offered today to meet immediately with Sheik Mujibur Rahman, leader of the Awami League of East Pakistan, to devise a common solution to end the crisis between the two parts of the country.

title: Criminal Penalties Urged For Air Charter Violations
description: WASHINGTON, March.10 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board recommended today the establishment of criminal penalties for charter airlines that II violate Government regulations.

title: Cambodia Reports Losses
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 10 (AP)  The Cambodian high command said today that 51,505 North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops have been killed and 21,133 wounded in nearly a year of fighting, while Government losses were 4,496 men killed and 8,624 wounded.

title: Lon Nol on Mend
description: HONOLULU, March 10, (UPI) Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia has checked out of Tripler General Hospital and is convalescing at a United States Government guest house at Hickham Air Force Base here, it was announced here today.

title: LABORITE TO FORM CABINET IN NORWAY
description: OSLO, Norway; March 10Trygve Bratteli, leader of the Labor party, was asked by King Olav V today to form a minority government.

title: ASTROS CONTINUE MASTERY OF METS
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10  The Hbuston Astros, who joined the National League with the New York Mets in 1962, played their annual exhibition game against they Mets today and continued their strange hex over them.

title: Dali Painting Auctioned for $100,000, a Record
description: Seventythree impressionist and modern paintings and drawings were auctioned last night at the ParkeBernet Gallery at 980 Madison Avenue, setting records for several artists, including Salvador Dali, whose works are seldom auctioned.

title: Ivy Group Lets Freshmen Join Some Varsity Teams
description: Faced with increasing costs, the eight Ivy League presidents voted unanimously yesterday to permit freshmen to compete on varsity teams in track, wrestling, swimming and some other sports starting next fall. However, the ban on freshmen remained in football, basketball, baseball, hockey, soccer, lacrosse and crew.

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED IN A HOTEL SLAYING
description: The 32yearold resident of an Upper West Side hotel was charged last night with the murder of a woman who lived two floors above.

title: Hanoi Reports Men in Asbestos Drive Trail's Tunnels of Fire
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 10 (Agence FrancePresse)  Truck drivers don asbestos clothing to drive through tunnels of fire created by American bombers along certain sections of the Ho Chi Minh Trail network, a North Vietnamese correspondent reported in the Hanoi press today.

title: Coming Soon: HiltonUponStratford
description: StratfordUponAvon where Shakespeare was born anddied liked Plays and players Well enongh when its greatest son was no more than the shiftless wenching heir to a failed glove business. We have the records and we know that Many of the big London companies put on shows at the Guildhall heing Paid their shillings and pence at one time by Shakespeare's own father who in his brief years of affluence was a borough official.

title: Humphrey Desmond, 68, Dies; Officer of Printing Ink Maker
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., March 10  Humphrey H. Desmond, retired financial vice president of the Sinclair & Valentine Company, a division of Martin Marietta Corporation, died today in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived here at 916 Grant Avenue.

title: The Dance: Valentine
description: Valentine, Gerald Ar. pino's new pas de deux or trots (there is some doubt) for the City Center Joffrey Ballet, is set to a score by Jacob Druckman and is a onejoke ballet. It is a sluecessful onejoke ballet, and the audience at last night's premiere at the City Center loved it.

title: CITY CENSUS FINDS A RISE IN HOUSING
William Bundy Appointed Editor of Foreign Affairs
description: The appointment of William P. Bundy to succeed Hamilton Fish Armstrong as editor of Foreign Affairs, quarterly review of the Council on. Foreign Relations, was announced yesterday by Grayson Kirk, the council's president.

title: Lagos Expels U.S. Newsman
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 10 (Reuters)Andrew Jaffe, a correspondent of Newsweek magazine, was expelled from Nigeria today and arrived here tonight. Immigration officialg who took him to the airport in Lagos gave no reason for their action.

title: Policeman in Jersey City Slays Another Patrolman
description: JERSEY CITY, March 10 (AP) Patrolman Augustine Lopez shot and killed a fellow policeman early today when he discovered the man in the apartment of a girlfriend, the police said.

title: A.H.L. Player Fined $300
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 10 (AP)  Roger Cote of the Cleveland Barons has been fined $300 and suspended for six games for attacking a referee, Ken Bodendistel, the American Hockey League announced today. The incident occurred last Saturday in. Springfield. Cote, who was playing for the Springfield Kings at the time of the incident, later was traded to Cleveland.

title: Inquiry on Surveillance Hears State Aide
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 A high police official from New York State told Congress today that computerized personal information systems could be effective without infringing on the privacy of the individual citizen.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW PRICE RISE
description: A late surge of buying sent soybean futures prices up and tended to influence higher prices for grain futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Bill James, Helped Work Baseball's 1914 Miracle
description: OROVILLE, Calif., March 10 (AP)Bill James, who pitched two winning games in the 1914 World Series and led the miracle Boston Braves to a series sweep, died today after a long illness. He was 78 years old, and entered a nursing home with his wife a month ago.

title: State Senate Approves Bill to Permit the Instituting of Junior Military Officer Training in High School
description: ALBANY, March 10  The State Senate approved a bill today that would permit local school boards to institute junior military officer training in high schools despite warnings that the schools could be turned into armed camps.

title: Vietnam Veterans Here Finding Job Hunt Tougher Than in 1970
description: Thousands of young veterans of the war in Vietnam are returning here to discover, often bitterly, that prospects for employment are acutely worse than a year ago.

title: Cuite Wants to Study Budget Before Council Acts on Taxes
description: In asking for new taxes before disclosing the budget the taxes are supposed to support, Mayor Lindsay is putting the cart before the horse, according to the majority leader of the City Council.

title: Curb on Labor Envisioned
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board told Senators today that it might be necessary to tighten some of the nation's labor laws to reduce the power of unions to force wages up.

title: BIG BOARD PUNISHES ADVEST AND OTHERS
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday a series of disciplinary actions against allied members and registered representatives of member firms for February.

title: LEADER SWORN IN BY AUSTRALIANS
description: CANBERRA, Australia, March 10William McMahon, winner of his country's highest office on his third attempt, was sworn in as Prime Minister of Australia today shortly after the dominant Liberal party had deposed John G. Gorton in an explosion of longsImmering political animosities.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: John A. Hamilton's observations on the growing welfare caseload [OpEd Feb. 22] reflects the frustration felt by all of us who deal with the problem day after day. But in charging that Mayor Lindsay, among others, has been most derelict in doing anything meaningful about it, Mr. Hamilton is wrong.

title: 100 JEWS STAGE A MOSCOW SITIN
description: MOSCOW, March 10More than 100 Soviet Jews demanding permission to emigrate to Israel were forced tonight to leave an office building of the Supreme Soviet that they had been occupying for several hours.

title: Final Basketball Poll COLLEGE DIVISION WRITERS RATINGS
State Housing Permits at 12Year Low
description: Authorizatiens for new housing construction throughout the state dipped in 1970 to the lowest level in at least 12 years, despite a 16 per cent increase in New York City, a report indicated yesterday.

title: DOUGLAS LEVICK Jr.
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 10  Douglas G. G. Levick Jr., who retired in 1961 as worldwide marketing coordinator for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) because of ill health, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital after a long illness. He was 61 years old and lived at 30 Mallard Drive.

title: Proposal for Tax on Containers Scored by Industry at Hearing
description: Spokesmen for the packaging and softdrink industries raised strong objections yesterday to proposals for taxes, or bounties, on containers that the city says have become a major part of the solid waste problem here.

title: Abyss Performed By Dermot Burke And Donna Cowen
description: While Miss Cowen's portrayal of the lighthearted maiden had a modest and fitting charm, she appeared excessively wooden as the victim; the product of lobotomy more than a lascivious assault. In the ballet small divide separates the plausible from the improbable, and the credibility of the work depends on the girl's retaining some connection with her former self. She, should be vulnerable but not totally helpless.

title: Screen: 'Double Suicide'
description: The Japanese playwright Monzaemon Chikamatsu died in 1724, but with the opening of Masahiro Shinoda's "Double Suicide" at the Bijou yesterday and Kenji Mizoguchi's great "The Crucified Lovers" at the New Yorker today, both closely based on his work, he becomes, like Shakespeare, like Neil Simon, one of the better represented dramatists in the city. But unlike Shakespeare, Chikamatsu, at least in these two plays, deals with problems of bourgeois domesticity. And unlike Neil Simon, his mode is tragedy.Shinoda's film concerns a paper-shop owner of Osaka (Kichiemon Nakamura) who neglects his business and ruins his young family in order to court and to buy the redemption of a woman of pleasure (Shima Iwashita) with whom he is in love. Ultimately the pressure of patient wife (also Shima Iwashita) and impatient in-laws, relatives and rivals, grow too great, and he runs away with his courtesan to consummate his love and commit the suicide to which the two of them are fated.Fate figures pretty heavily in "Double Suicide," a bit more heavily, I suspect, than in Chikamatsu's original, which is a puppet play. Shinoda begins with puppets (a direct connection with the bodies of his dead lovers, which he also introduces very earlyso you may know the end at the beginning), and all the way through his movie he retains the puppeteers  black-cloaked, black-masked figures in the background or the foreground, who help change sets, assist the characters and see the action to its conclusion.It follows that "Double Suicide" understands that its story is theater, and that its space is theatrical. It is a very modernist reading of classical material, turning walls into stage flats, noticing that substance is insubstantial, and, in its multiple approaches to truth, feeling a good deal like Pirandello.All this may sound very interesting, but I am afraid that it sounds more interesting than in the issue it actually is. For one thing, Shinoda (whose other work I have not seen) seems a tirelessly arty directorwith his camera, his props, his lights and his shadowscontinually discovering effective composition where others might find a revelation or two.But more importantly, all his attempts to distance his material really do distance it (although he allows his actors a good deal of emotion) and suggest an intellectual's mistrust of mere event. Where Mizoguchi in "The Crucified Lovers" uses the multilevel spaces of his middle-class houses to build a complex dramatic environment, Shinoda uses potentially similar spaces to indicate a complicated stage set. It is as if he felt the idea of a theater were enough to replace a theater or if he thought that the elaborate mechanics of a metaphor were in themselves a meaning.

title: Newspapers and Magazines Hit By a Job Squeeze as Ads Decline
Former General Says PX Charges Are Slanderous
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 A demoted Army general, accused of helping profiteers to operate in the lucrative post exchange market, told the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations today that the charges against him were unprecedented, unproved, untrue and slanderous.

title: Morton to Present Plan to Reorganize Interior Department
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Administration will announce tomorrow a plan for reorganization of the Department of the Interior to make it more responsive to Administration policies and to curb conflicts and independent actions among multiple agencies.

title: U.S. Monetary Reserves Used for Debts
description: The United States has borrowed almost $1.7billion from foreign central banks in the last 18 months that it has been unable to repay through the normal workings of the foreign exchange markets, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Supreme Court has again indicated, after five years of unusual judicial rationality, that our inalienable rights are in fact alienable by hostile and parochial state officials.

title: PyramidLike Ski Slope Rises Out of Michigan Wheat Fields
description: FREELAND, Mich., March 10John Bintz, the operator of busy Apple Mountain in this tricity area encompassing Saginaw, Bay City and Midland, has started to add 40 feet of vertical drop to his 1,000foot ski slope and nobody is surprised. Ordinarily, such a project would cause a bit of eyebrowlifting. But Bintz, an enterprising 40yearold graduate of Michigan State, had already provided a precedent. He was the ski enthusiast who built the present 160foothigh Apple Mountain on top of a flat wheat field.

title: SOME PUPILS AIDED BY AMPHETAMINES
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Amphetamines can be used to treat school children who have trouble concentrating, but they are no substitute for parental concern and proper medical supervision, according to a Government study made public today.

title: Humphrey Surge is Found in a Poll on 1972 Democratic Contenders
Layer Is Upset by Cox In Aussie Open Tennis
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 10 (AP)The elimination of topseeded Rod Laver and thirdseeded John Newcombe gave an upset flavor to the $56,000 Australian open tennis championships today. Secondseeded Tony Roche also was on the verge of defeat in the tournament, the first of the grand slam quartet.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In victory, Muhammad All had unfailingly displayed cool and subtle arrogance. Poor Sonny, he said the mornning after he beat Liston for the second time, he got built up so big, now he got so far to fall. And the morning after he beat Floyd. Patterson; he turned to the former champion and said: You should get honors and medals, the spot you was on, a good clean American boy fighting for America. It would be a disgrace on the Government if you had to end up scuffling somewhere.

title: 8 Hell's Angels Charged in Attack on Girl, 17
description: Eight members of a group who described themselves as the Hell's Angels motorcycle gang were seized here last night and charged with the gang rape of a 17yearold girl in an East Village leather goods shop.

title: A $3Million Increase In Parses Is Planned
description: The New York Racing Association announced yesterday it planned to increase purses by $3million as result of legislation passed recently in Albany.

title: GEN. STOPFORD, 78, OF BURMA CAMPAIGN
description: LONDON, March 10  Sir Montague Stopford, a British general who commanded a key corps in the Allied fight to retake Burma from the Japanese in World War II, died yesterday. He was 78 years old and lived in Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire.

title: 6 Harper Editors Resign After Talk With Cowles
description: The managing, editor, four contributing editors and the poetry editor of Harper's Magazine resigned yesterday morning after meeting with John Cowles Jr., chairman of the board of the magazine.

title: Head of HarrisIntertype Adds White Motor Post
description: The directors of the White Motor Corporation yesterday elected George S. Dively as chairman and announced the formation of two new committees with responsibilities for finance and management development.

title: SENATE APPROVES 18YEAROLD VOTE IN ALL ELECTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Senate approved today, 94 to 0, and sent to the House a proposed constitutional amendment that would lower the voting age to 18 years in all elections, possibly by 1972.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As long as we insist that the Government's executive branch be permitted to classify certain kinds of people as unworthy of the respect of law and morality, we must expect that practices like those disclosed to Senator Ervin's Constitutional Rights Subcommittee will continue.

title: Rogers Plans No Latin Tour
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)The State Department said today that Secretary of State William P. Rogers planned to attend the Hemisphere Foreign Ministers Confernce in Costa Rica, opening April 14, but does not expect to visit other LatinAmerican countries.

title: Protest in London
description: LONDON, Thursday, March 11Fifty young Jews were evicted by the police just before midnight from the building that houses the London office of Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: For Men OnlySewing Lessons
description: It was a sight to brighten the eyes of anybody who's really committed to women's lib: men, family men, business executives learning to handle sewing machines and fighting their way through the tissue paper jungle known as a dress pattern in order to make shifts for their wives.

title: SWEDEN FILES BILL ON LABOR TURMOIL
description: STOCKHOLM, March 10The Government introduced emergency legislation today that would bar strikes and lockouts in Sweden until April 25.

title: Equalization Tax Extended
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (Reuters)  The House of Representatives approved today and sent to the Senate legislation extending for two yearsthrough March 31, 1973the interest equalization tax, on American purchases of foreign securities.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: KEY WEST, Fla. Long and brown, lying just below the surface, the school of cobia contained a few fish of nearly 50 pounds.

title: Books of The Times
description: After 10 years of listening to America from a distance, as Deputy Director of the Peace Corps, special assistant to President Lyndon B. Johnson and publisher of Newsday, Bill Moyers decided to travel forth from the crescent of the East Coast and see what the country is about and who the people are. So in the summer of 1970, carrying a tape recorder and a notebook, [he] boarded a bus in New York to begin a journey of thirteen thousand miles through America. Good, good, I thought upon reading this in the preface to Listening to America and lapsing into a form of New York City sentimentality that assumes that things out there are not like things in here. The day before my departure, Mr. Moyers goes on, I received from a friend... a letter urging me not to go out earnestly in search of America's problems but rather in search of its humor, its ironies, its humanness we need to be reminded that we are no worse than the rest of the human race.  Yes, yes, I thought, recalling an idyllic summer in NeW Hampshire: New York City is a paranoid fantasy. Remind us of the salt of American earth, Mr. Moyersthe country doctors who still make house calls and the people who still pace their lives to the rise and fall of the sun.

title: Picketing at the U.N.
description: A group of about 20 young men and women who said they planned a hunger strike in sympathy with Soviet Jews barred from emigration picketed across the street from the United Nations entrance yesterday. The pickets said they represented the Jewish Defense League.

title: Nixon Address Set Today
description: WASHINGTON, March 10. (AP)The White House announced today that President Nixon would ,make an address tomorrow before the National Conference on the Judiciary at Williamsburg, Va. The White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said the President would depart the White House shortly after noon for the 2 P.M. engagement and return immediately afterward.

title: City and State Officials Are Wary on the Governor's Reported Ideas on Curbing Welfare
description: Both the effectiveness and the legality of Governor Rockefeller's newest idea for tightening welfare rolls and spending were question yeaterday by city. officials and state legislators.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK FAST PENSION RISE
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 Democratic Congressional leaders have decided to press for speedy passage of a bill increasing Social Security benefits by 10 per cent, a bill that bogged down in the last Congress.

title: Safety Expert Says Cars Pick Consumer's Pocket
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 The Federal Government's former automobile safety chief, disclosing results of lowspeed crash tests of 1971 models, accused manufacturers today of picking the pockets of consumers by producing needlessly fragile cars.

title: Economic Issues of SST Disputed at Senate Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 The economic issues that could decide the fate of the supersonic transport airplane in Congress this month were joined today for the first time before the Senate Appropriations Committee.

title: House Again Votes WagePrice Power
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 The House approved today a twoyear extension of a law giving President Nixon standby authority to impose wage, price and rent controls.

title: U.S. PLANS TO POOL RAIL FREIGHT CARS
description: Senator Warren G. Magnuson, chairman of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, proposes to introduce legislation early next week calling for the formation of a new Governmental corporation to purchase and make available to shippers and the railroads a fleet of general purpose freight cars.

title: More Chinese Aid Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Communist China is expected to step up deliveries of small arms and munitions and possibly start supplying trucks and light armor to North Vietnam to make up for the losses suffered in Laos, United States officials said today.

title: 2 Western Businessmen Win Retrials in East Germany
description: BERLIN, March 10The East German. Supreme Court today nullified severe prison sentences against two West GerMan businessmen and ordered their retrial.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 Very few of us probably ever think of the mendacity discount rate. It is the percentage which we all instinctively knowbit which we instinctively mark down the true value of this ad's claims for a given toothpaste, that politician's claim to have the new miracle answer, this newspaper columnist's claims to wisdom, arid so forth.

title: Bond Market Continuing Its Swing to Lower Yields
...Cooperation?
description: The orbiting of Peking's second earth satellite less than a year provides impressive evidence of the advance of Communist China in warrelated technology. It hardly needs underlining that a rocket capable orbiting a sputnik could also deliver a hydrogen bomb to a distant target on earth.

title: State Senate Votes Inquiry Into the City School Crisis
description: ALBANY, March 10  A bipartisan call for an immediate State Senate investigation into the disastrous educational crisis in New York City was approved unanimously today as lawmakers angrily denounced the city school board.

title: CITY BOARD SCRAPS ALL SCHOOL CUTS; 72 FUNDS TAPPED
description: The Board of Education rescinded all planned cuts in school staffs and services yesterday after Controller Abraham D. Beame said he would shift $25million of this year's school costs into next year's budget to ease the system's current fiscal deficit.

title: Nixon Acts in Tariff Cases
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)  President Nixon has exercised his tiebreaking authority in two tariff cases announced today by the White House.

title: ...Negotiation...
description: Among the more hopeful signs of an evolving new China policy in Washington is President Nixon's recent hint that the Administration is preparing to drop its opposition to Peking's membership in the United. Nations. This newspaper has long argued that it isessential for the development of peace to engage a Government that represents onequarter of mankind in the deliberations of the world organization.

title: Inspections of Mine Questioned At House Committee's Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 Representative Carl D. Perkins told a Bureau of Mines inspector today that a more thorough investigation might have resulted in lives being saved at the Finley Coal Company mine in Kentucky.

title: City Unit Backs Aid for Theater
description: A choppeddown aid plan under which the city would acquire the deficitplagued Shakespeare Festival Public Theater for $2.6million was approved by the City Planning Commission in a 50 vote yesterday.

title: David Eisenhower 17th In Navy Officer School
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)David Eisenhower will graduate from Naval Officers Training School in Newport, R. I., Friday as 17th in his class of 225 students..

title: SOUTHPAWS EXCEL IN BOWLING HERE
description: Bowling is one sport in Which lefthanders have a slight edge, and Johnny Petraglia of. Brooklyn is taking full ,advantage of it this year.

title: RALPH R. FREYER
description: Ralph R. Freyer, principal of Henry Hudson Junior High School in the East Bronx, died in his sleep on Tuesday apparently of a heart attack at his home, 2 Roy Place Eastchester, N. Y. He was 61 years old.

title: MRS.R.E. HENDERSON, LED VASSAR ALUMNAE
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., March 10Mrs. Clifford Sellers Henderson, the wife of Ralph E. Henderson, a founding editor of the Reader's Digest Book Club, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, after a long illness. She was 72 years old and lived on Greenmeadow Road here and in Kent, N.Y.

title: DEMOCRATS URGE STATE DEFER AID
description: ALBANY, March 10Democratic members of the Assembly urged Governor Rockefeller today to reduce the need for new taxes by postponing payment of $250million in state assistance to local governments for welfare.

title: Northwest Airlines Drops Plan for a Northeast Link
description: The board of directors of Northwest Airlines, Inc., terminated yesterday their merger agreement with Northeast Airlines, Inc., because of certain conditions imposed by the Civil Aeronautics Board in approving the consolidation. The merger agreement, filed with the C.A.B. 15 months ago, provided that the merger would not become effective if the Gov ernment agency imposed condition's that could adversely and materially affect the surviving corporation, Northwest Airlines, Inc.

description: WASHINGTON, March 10Federal District Judge John H. Pratt enjoined the United Transportation Union today from conducting a selective strike against two railroads.

title: Advertising:

description: The American Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report on changes in ownership by leading shareholders, directors, and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue an insiders report yesterday.

title: Gypsy Rose Lee Sale Is Part Fashion Show
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10  Gypsy, said a friend, went all around the world saying, I like that. I have to have it

Barker chairman and chief executive officer of the company and its subsidiary MooreMcCormack Lines, Inc., at the April 14 directors meeting. Mr. Barker will succeed William T. Moore, chairman of Moore & McCormack since 1965 and Mooz6b. McCormack Lines since 1962, who will beconm. chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Barker is executive vice president of Temple, Barker & Sloane, Inc., transportation consultants.

description: WASHINGTON, March 10Israel, through her embassy here, declared today) that she would not withdraw from Sharm el Sheik and accept the kind of international security arrangements there envisioned by the United States and suggested by Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary.

title: Advertising:
description: Martin Landey, Arlow Advertising, which as you well know already had Muguet des bois, now has been given L'Aimant and Imprevu.

title: JAMES COX, EXHEAD OF MET OPERA CLUB
description: James W. Cox, a former resident of New York who had been a president of the Metropolitan Opera Club, died yesterday in Atlanta, where he made his home. He was 84 years old.

title: Yankees'
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 10Any baseball fan who takes his rooting interest seriously needs something to worry about as well as to hope for, and New York Yankee fans, who have been fed an unbalanced diet of enriched optimism since last year, deserve their share of apprehension. And they have plenty to choose from.

title: WERTHER CAST LED BY FRANCO CORELLI
description: For all its physical and vocal merits, there is not much even nominally French about the Metropolitan Opera's new Werther. That peculiarity was accentuated in the season's fourth performance Tuesday night, when Martin Rich stepped in to replace the indisposed conductor, Alain Lombard, the one Frenchman visible in earlier performances.

title: Heavy Fog Cuts Copter Flights in Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 11 Heavy fog closed down air operations at the huge allied forward supply base at Khesanh yesterday and brought a near halt to American helicopter support of South Vietnamese troops in Laos.

title: Heart Association Backs Drive By Government to End Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 The American Heart Association gave its support today to a Congressional proposal for Government sponsored campaign to conquer cancer. The association said the same thing ought to be done for heart disease, the number one killer of Americans.

title: Tupamaro Rebels In Uruguay Kidnap Attorney General
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 10 (AP)The Tupamaro guerrillas kidnapped Uruguay's attorney general today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 11, 1971

title: State Bill Would Return Historic Wampum to Iroquois
description: ALBANY, March 10  A series of bills to strengthen the oftenviolated treaty rights of the state's 10,400 reservation Indians was introduced today, in the Assembly.

title: Two Unions Reject Offers by Con Ed
description: The two unions threatening a strike against the Consolidated Edison Company rejected new contract offers yesterday, but negotiations were continuing.

title: PHILCOFORD RECALL OF 1,000 IS PLANNED
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 10 (AP)The PhilcoFord Corporation, reporting increased sales in television sets, stereos and auto radios, announced today it would recall 1,000 workers in two plants to handle increased production.
