description: We talked to a friend about a man he knows who gives him stock market winners, and we were intrigued when the friend explained how he pays for the advice.

title: Pipe Dreams in New York
description: John Lindsay, it says here in the New York papers, is thinking of turning Democrat and running for President of the United States, and it could be true. There is nothing a man won't consider these days to get out of being Mayor of New York.

title: 2 YEAR SENTENCE GIVEN TO COLOMBO
description: Joseph Colombo Sr., a reputed leader of organized crime, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court on perjury charges to serve one to two and a half years in prison.

title: Dressmaking for Those Who Are All Thumbs
description: Grow your own food, roll your own cigarettes, make your own clothes. A wave of doityourself is sweeping the country, stirred up both by the economy and the ecology. Home sewing has boomed to a $3billion industry and handcrafts are not far behind.

title: YALE AND VIRGINIA REACH POLO FINAL
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I would like to express my thanks for your publication of the selfwritten obituary of John Alexander Hottell. One only hopes that this will perhaps temper the wrath of those who see William Calley in every army uniform or a Charles Manson as the exemplification of my generation.

title: VIETNAM COVERUP LAID TO 2 OFFICERS
description: ATLANTA, March 11Military charges against a general and a colonel were drafted here today by a fellow United States Army officer who has accused them of covering up war crimes in South Vietnam.

title: Stage: Miller Version of An Enemy of the People Issues Take Ascendancy Over Characters
POST OFFICE PLANS 56 NEW FACILITIES
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Post Office Department announced plans today for a massive modernization program involving more than $1.5billion for the construction of 56 new postal facilities and the purchase of new machinery in the next four years.

title: ABRAHAM S. RICE
description: Abraham S. Rice, a director of trade shows, died Wednesday at his home in Jamaica Estates, Queens, after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

title: Love Turns 'New Leaf' at Music Hall
description: When Henry Graham (Walter Matthau) learns that his fortune has finally run out, he is overwhelmed with quite reasonable self-pity. "All I amor wasis rich. It's all I wanted to be." Henry's butler agrees: "You'll be poor in the only real sensein that you'll have no money." The desperate problem demands a desperate solution: Henry decides to many an heiress and then get rid of her with all possible dispatch."A New Leaf," which was written and directed by Elaine May, who also costars in the film, is the story of Henry's reluctant character reformation through the love of a rich woman. It's also a beautifully and gently cockeyed movie that recalls at least two different traditions of American film comedy to which I've always been partial.Not since the two-reelers of the 1930's in which Edgar Kennedy, the genius of the slow "burn, made his accommodation with the idiocies of Florence Lake, his bird-brained wife, have there been displays of anger, frustration and greed as marvelous as those of Matthau in "A New Leaf." Then, too, "A New Leaf" shares with the great screwball comedies of the Depression an almost childlike appreciation of money: it may not buy happiness, but having a lot of it helps.Essentially, however, "A New Leaf" is a love story, since Henry Graham and Henrietta Lowell (Miss May) are eccentrics who could have been made for nobody but each other. He is a misanthropic, suspicious, hand-tailored, high-living playboy, whose preference is for Chateau Lafitte '61, while she is a sweet, trusting, sloppy, near-sighted botanist, who drinks Mogen David Extra Heavy Malaga ("every year is good"), and who also happens to be loaded with money.Although Miss May's approach to the writing and directing of film comedy is pretty consistently at the blackout-sketch level, reminiscent of her collaborations with Mike Nichols, the quality of the sketches in "A New Leaf" is so consistently high, and its cartoon characters are so human, that criticism of its form becomes academic. The entire project is touched by a fine and knowing madness.I've always been aware of the fact that Matthau is an excellent actor, who is at his best in comedy, but until now I've only been able to suspect this of Miss May. Her Henrietta Lowell is a kind of spin-off of the gauche ladies who used to confront Nichols on television, but she's also as honestly appealing as she is funny. This has the effect of giving a surprising dimension to the kind of slapstick routine in which a lady manages to put on a Grecian-style nightgown by sticking her head and her left arm through the gown's only arm hole.However, it doesn't do to describe too many details in such a comedythey should be discovered. Everyone in the supporting cast is appropriately lunatic, especially James Coco, as Matthau's stingy uncle, who plans to leave his fortune to Radio Free Europe, but possibly excepting George Rose, as Matthau's philosophical butler, a role once played (more swishily but no better) by Eric Blore. Mostly, however, I admire Miss May's accurate appraisal of the weird world in which we live, in which peppermills are transistorized and sports cars are built to run faster than is possible on any highway."A New Leaf" opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall under something of a cloud. Miss May sought, unsuccessfully, to enjoin the film's opening and to have her name removed from it on the grounds that Paramount, which financed the film, was releasing a version of which she disapproved.Not having seen Miss May's version, I can only say that the film I saw should be a credit to almost any director, though, theoretically at least, Miss May is right. The only thing that gives me pause is the knowledge that its success will probably be used in the future as an argument to ignore the intentions of other directorsbut with far less happy results.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your Feb. 21 editorial Last Chance for Strip Mining you presented a needlessly colored and hysterical point of view.

title: Lincoln Races Snowed Out
description: LINCOLN, R. I., larch 11 (AP)Lincoln Downs canceled its race program today because of a snowstorm.

title: YOUTHS LEAVING YUGOSLAV FARE
description: NOW SAD, Yugoslavia Young people are disappearing from Yugoslavia's granary, the Serbian autonomous province of Vojvodina, moving into this attractive provincial capital on the banks of the Danube, and leaving behind a social and economic problem that officials believe is critical.

title: Staten Island G.I. Dies
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)The Defense Department announced today that Sgt. George H. Spence of Staten Island, of the Army, had been killed in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Dance: Don Redlich in ANTA Series
description: The City Center's American Dance Marathon, which has brought modern dance to everyone's doorstepor at least to the convenient location of the ANTA Theater in the last eight weeks, presented the Don Redlich Dance Company last night as the final group in the series.

title: A Glamorous New First Lady
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 11  The most glamorous Prime Minister's wife that Australia has ever had, a leading Sydney newspaper, The Morning Herald, said in a front page story this morning about Mrs. William McMahon on the day following her husband's selection as the new head of the National Government.

title: Fordham Eleven to Play Columbia in '72
description: Fordham, which returned to varsity football competition in 1970 after a 16year absence, will play Columbia in the 1972 opening game for both teams. The contest is scheduled for Sept. 30 at Baker Field, Columbia's home arena.

title: Court Gives Dog Right To Stay in Apartment
description: Dogs and their masters cannot be evicted from their apartments even though lease says no animals allowed so long as the prohibition is not a substantial obligation of the lease, Civil Court judge held yesterday.

title: High Honor for Small Man
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 11Joe Summa, 5foot10inch Wesleyan cocaptain, was named today by New England college coaches to receive the Bob Cousy award for the top basketball player under 6 feet in New England.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Wins Parliament Majority
description: NEW DELHI, March 11 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today won the parliamentary majority for which she had gambled in calling elections year ahead of schedule.

title: S.E.C. Sets April 5 Date for End Of Fixed Fees on Large Trades
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Securities and Exchange Commission told the New York Stock Exchange today that it must terminate pricefixing of commissions on large stock transactions no later than April 5, even though it is not technically possible to amend the exchange's constitution by that date. The constitution, which prescribes fixed commissions, sets up a rigid timetable for amendments.

title: PROGRESS IS SEEN IN CON ED TALKS
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, reported some progress last night in critical contract negotiations between Consolidated Edison Company and two unions threatening to strike Sunday.

title: Port Authority Will Build Ship Terminal on Hudson
description: The Port of New York Authority will build a longdiscussed passenger ship terminal on the Hudson River in midManhattan and a raillike interterminal transportation system at Newark Airport.

title: Nixon Envisages Abolition Of VISTA in Merger Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The White House has circulated a confidential plan that would dismantle VISTA, the embattled domestic volunteer service agency. The plan, copy of which was obtained today, outlines how President Nixon's proposed merger of volunteer agencies would operate. While the Peace Corps would continue as an entity within the new agency, VISTA Volunteers in Service to Americawould disappear.

title: BOND BIDS HELD UP ON ALBANY MALL
description: ALBANY, March 11State officials of the huge South Mall office building project were at a loss today to explain why Albany County officials suddenly canceled a bidding session on $70million in construction bonds.

title: SOME PRAISE WON BY HEWS ANGELS
description: There were five Hell's Angels on the grimy stoop outside their clubhouse at 77 East Third Street yesterday afternoon, keeping an eye on the gleaming choppers lined up at the curb.

title: Jersey City Schools Reopen
description: JERSEY CITY, March 11 (UPI)Classes reopened at the city's 36 schools today after custodians and cafeteria workers signed a memo of agreement with the Board of Education for twostep wage increases totaling $600.

title: Executive Changes
description: Dow Chemical of Canada, Ltd., has announced the appointment of Clyde H. Boyd as president and a director of the company. Leroy D. Smithers, formerly president, has been made chairman. Mr. Boyd joined the Dow Chemical Company in 1941 and in 1966 he was named director of manufacturing for Dow's European operations and in 1967 was appointed a vice president of Dow Chemical Europe S.A., the position he has held until the present time.

title: GERMAN IS SUED BY PENN CENTRAL
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company have brought suit in Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., to sequester the United States assets of a German financier, Fidel Gotz.

title: Ashe Tops Drysdale In 4 Sets to Gain Sydney Semifinal
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 11 (UPI)  Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., defeated Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 76, 76, 2.6, 62, to move into the semifinals of the Dunlop Australian open at White City today.

title: Drive Seeks End to Chinese Restaurant Raids
description: A Columbia University law student was having dinner in a Chinese restaurant on Broadway one night several years ago when he noticed a flurry of activity near the door. A waiter told him that immigration officers were raiding. the restaurant to look for employes who might be in the country illegally.

title: Their Shirts Aren't Brown
description: RALEIGH, N. C.In America we National Guard men have a twofold mission. First we provide immediate backup support for the regular Army and Air Force; our secondary but more highly publicized, mission is that of providing military support for civilian authorities.

title: Tributes Are Paid to Young
description: PRESIDENT NIXON  With Whitney Young's death today in Nigeria, I have lost friend, black America has lost a gifted and commanding champion of its just cause, and this nation has lost one of the most compassionate and principled leaders it haS had in all the long centuries since whites from Europe and blacks from Africa began building together toward the American dream.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Is A Soldier's Own Obituary really an epitaph for our future? Can it be read with anything less than the deepest feelings of abhorrence and uneasiness? The subtle glorification of violent ways in the obituary is appalling; it, and the series of institutions within whose framework it was derived, should be questioned.

title: Irate Newswomen Protest as 8 Others Interview President
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (Reuters)About two dozen women reporters staged a protest inside the White House tonight after being excluded from an interview President Nixon gave in his office to eight of their female rivals.

title: Defendant in Hijacking Case Shot Outside Brooklyn Home
description: A truck driver under Federal indictment in a truck hijacking case was seriously wounded yesterday when he was shot outside his home at 2783 Brighton Eighth Street, in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn.

title: U.S. Hijacker May Go Free
description: ROME, March 11 (AP)faele Minichiello, the 21yearold Marine lance corporal who hijacked a Trans World Airlines plane from California to Rome in November, 1969, will be freed May 1 if, as it appears likely, legal proceedings against him are not completed by then, his lawyer, Edmondo Zappacosta, said today. He said an appeals court had accepted a request that Corporal Minichiello be freed under a 1970 law setting an 18month limit on imprisonment prior to conviction.

title: Predictable 2Length Aqueduct Victor
description: Predictable proved to be aptly named in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4yearold, owned by Ogden Mills Phipps, was the strong favorite in the mile test for older fillies and mares, and she came through as expected. Her win price was $4.40 for $2.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As an Annapolis graduate I am moved to respond to A Soldier's Own Obituary. It is touching and tragic and pathetic: touching in the man's devotion to his personal consummation by Army life and tragic in his purposeless and pointless death.

title: Lucas's 'THX1138':Love Is a Punishable Crime in Future
description: "THX 1138" is derived from a prize-winning short that George Lucas made a few years ago while a graduate student at the University of Southern California. Under the auspices of the young San Francisco film company American Zoetrope, Mr. Lucas, now 25 years old, expanded his project into the feature length science-fiction movie that opened yesterday at the Loew's Cine and Loew's State 2. I have a good many reservations about the film's ideas, but they are greatly outweighed by my admiration for a technical virtuosity that by fair means and foul achieves exceptional emotional intensity at the same time.Set in a sanitized, computerized, monasticized underground society of the future, "THX 1138" concerns a technician (Robert Duvall) whose roommate (Maggie McOmie) decreases his daily required sedation dosage to the point where he feels desire and they make love. Apprehended for this (a capital offense), he is placed in some kind of wall-less prison that, like everything else in this society, works better in theory than in practice. Together with two companions (Donald Pleasence and Don Pedro Colley, who plays a mistakenly materialized TV image he begins an escape that for sheer suspenseful invention would do credit to the best of adventure films."THX 1138" is considerably more than an adventure film, but it is also considerably less than major prophetic fiction. Despite a sustained solemnity in approach and a musical background as ominously ponderous as that of "Last Year at Marienbad," "THX 1138" works with much potentially comic material (I think that Mr. Lucas is aware of this) and in the design of itsconsistently beautifulphotography, observing white-garbed figures against an often undifferentiated white background, it sometimes resembles the kind of minimal-information cartoon that was indicative of good taste in animation a few years back."A few years back" might almost be a motto for "THX 1138," because whatever horror lies ahead, I don't think that anybody now seriously imagines that it will take the form of a de-emotionalized asexual society enslaved by its own models of technical efficiency. In this respect Mr. Lucas's film looks like a slightly old-fashioned anxiety dreambut if you can accept that (and you should), it becomes very potent material indeed."THX 1138" is aided by lovely performances  not only Donald Pleasence, who with typical appeal plays a pathetically enterprising wheeler-dealer in a world that makes no deals; but also Robert Duvall and Maggie McOmie, who must achieve a kind of human identification without highly individualizing characteristics. Miss McOmie's story is pure pathos, and as it materializes in her so vulnerable flesh and then passes into electronic data it becomes one adequate image of the sadness that attends us all.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTONConsistency is by no means always a virtue, above all when dealing with foreign policy's changing kaleidoscope. The admirable thing about George Ball is not that he has been consistent in his attitude on Vietnam but that he fought for his views when they were unpopular and, now that they have become popular, refuses to let his emotions on this irrationally passionate subject distort his friendships or other opinions.

title: Elliot S. Foreman Is Dead at 87; Once Advance Man for Shows
description: Elliot S. Foreman, one of the last of the oldtime theatrical advance men, died on Wednesday at Polyclinic Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at the Mayflower Hotel, 15 Central Park West.

title: Ulster Fears New Strife; Slayers of Soldiers Hunted
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 11  Protestants and Roman Catholics, stunnerat the slaying, of 4hree. British soldiers fears today that tle'w violence would erupt in tense Northern Ireland.

title: AMEX PRICES DROP AS TRADING GAINS
Saigon Is Said to Abandon Big Refugee Resettlement
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11The Saigon Government's plan to move refugees from the northern part of South Vietnam to the southern part has been quietly set aside in favor of resettling them within their native provinces, American officials said today.

title: LIBYA IS PESSIMISTIC ON OIL NEGOTIATIONS
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, March 11 (Reuters)The current secret talks between Libya and Western companies on oil payments are deteriorating, the official Libyan news agency reported today.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President met with top aides to discuss Japanese textile imports. Later in the morning he conferred with Ambassador Gerard C. Smith before Mr. Smith's departure for Vienna and the next round of talks with the Soviet Union on strategic arms limitations.

title: Lynch Condemns Slayings
description: DUBLIN, March 11Prime Minister John Lynch of the Republic of Ireland issued a statement today deploring the slaying of ,the three British soldiers in Ulster.

title: Grant Backs Tobacco Study
description: ST. LOUIS, March 11 (UPI)  Seven tobacco companies and a tobacco growers association awarded a $2million grant today to Washington University here for a basic research program on the immunologic properties of cancer. The grant is the largest research grant ever made by the tobacco industry to a single institution the university chancellor Thomas H. Eliot, said.

title: M.I.T. Plans Student Posts
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11 (AP)  The Massachusetts Institute of Technology said today that it would add five recent graduates to its governing corporation this year to place greater emphasis on the perspective of recent student experience. The announcement said that seniors or alumni who had been out of school for no more than two years would be eligible for nomination to the 80member corporation. They will be elected by members of their own classes.

title: Commodity Price Index Dips 0.3 From YearAgo Level
Legislators Weighing Cuts for City U.
description: ALBANY, March 11  Possible cuts in state aid to the City University of New York are Included in a $400million array of pruning suggestions in local aid now being considered by the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.

title: U.S. Denies Pressure
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The State Department, reportedly smarting over what officials interpreted as an indirect criticism from Israel yesterday, emphasized today that the United States was not exerting pressure on Israel.

title: MODEL CITIES LOAN FOR FILMS BACKED
description: The Model Cities agency in Harlem would buy a onethird interest in a new moviemaking company controlled by blacks and Puerto Ricans under a plan approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

title: Senator Scores Panel That Kept File on Him
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 11 (UPI)After finding himself listed in its files, State Senate leader James R. Mills said today that he would work to have the Senate Subcommittee on UnAmerican Activities abolished.

title: PRESIDENT URGES GENUINE REFORM OF COURT SYSTEM
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., March 11 The accelerating campaign to reform the nation's creeping system of justice picked up momentum today as President Nixon told a national conference on the judiciary that imagination and daring were needed, along with genuine reform, to improve the courts.

title: 10 Hurt in Elevator Fall
description: Ten persons were injured, none seriously, when an elevator fell three floors yesterday in a fourstory office building at 320 West 31st Street. The injured were treated at French Hospital and released.

title: Business Inventories Fell for January
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Total business inventories fell sharply in January, resulting in the largest decline in nearly 10 years. The drop came about mainly because of a drop in manufacturers inventories, which Commerce Department economists were at a loss to explain.

title: Chamber Scores Nixon Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)A panel of the Council of State Chambers of Commerce called today for Congress to reject President Nixon's welfare reform, generalrevenue sharing, and allvolunteer Army proposals.

title: Excerpts From President Nixon's Address to National Conference on Judiciary
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., March 11 [UPI]Following are excerpts from the text of President Nixon's address today to the National Conference on the Judiciary:

title: Throws His Strong Support Behind QuotasTokyo's Move Held Inadequate
description: WASHINGTON, March 11President Nixon rejected as inadequate today the plan announced earlier this week by Japan to restrict textile exports to the Linked States, and again threw his strong support behind legislation to restrict textile imports by mandatory quotas.

title: C.I.A. ROLE IN LAOS: ADVISING AN ARMY
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 11 A month after the enemy attack on the American compound at the northern Laotian military headquarters at Long Tieng, the station chief, case officers and other officials of the American Central Intelligence Agency continue to perform their functions there and at other regional headquarters in Laos.

title: Experiment in FundRaising: A Greek Love Fest Raises $5,000
description: The moment it became fashionable to assume that the nation was up to its ears in Romance again somebody was bound to cash in with the help of a prestigious charity.

title: Books of The Times
description: It is an odd fact, to a music lover that is, that Joan Peyser's book should be called, The New Music, and. that it serves so well as a foreword to the two volumes in the TwentiethCentury Composers series. For her book, with slight divergencies, deals with the work of Arnold Schoenberg, Igor Stravinsky and Edgard Varese. Since the dates of their most radical and influential compositions go back more than half a century, it would appear that the break with the past was so great that has taken all this time for the musical public to measure its extent, or that the musical public has been so sluggish that it hasn't caught up with it yet.

title: SAM Site Laos Reported Hit
description: SAIGON Friday, March 12 (UPI)United States military sources said today that American fighterbombers last week destroyed the only North Vietnamese surface,toair missile site ever discovered in Laos. They said that the nearly functional launching pad was spotted on a reconnaissance picture taken by a United States jet near the LaosNorth Vietnam border and that Air Force and Navy jets destroyed it.

title: Advertising:
description: In February, before last week's network TV bull market, prices had dropped so that, although the amount of time sold was 1.6 per cent more than in February, 1970, revenues had fallen 9 per cent.

title: U.S. Attorney Balks Indictments Of Sheriff and 3 Others in Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 10  Three documents labeled indictment, which have been on file with the United States District Court. clerk here for two weeks, accuse the sheriff, of Salt Lake County of cheating jail prisoners out of their proper food, in order to enrich himself.

title: San Quentin Prisoner Slain
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., March 11 (UPI)An inmate, William P. Hanson, 28 years old, was stabbed to death today in San Quentin Prison, where most convicts have been kept locked up during a shakedown for weapons. It was the sixth stabbing since Sunday.

title: Karl Knaths, Painter, Dies at 80; Works in Many Major Museums
description: Karl Knaths, one of the best known abstract painters of the older generation, died Tuesday in Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass., after a brief illness. He was 80 years old,

description: WASHINGTON, March 11Business, industry and Government spokesmen joined in urging Congress today to remove outmoded restraints on the funding and operations of the ExportImport Bank. They said such restraints were stifling the Government's own export expansion campaign.

title: Seale Jury Seated After 4 Months of Questioning 1,035
description: NEW HAVEN, March 11The fourmonth effort to form a jury in the murder trial of Bobby G. Seale ended today with the selection of a black woman and a white man as the two alternate jurors.

description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 11The final witness in the courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. said today that troops involved in the Mylai killings were so unready for combat that the brigade commander protested and asked for 60 additional days of training in Hawaii before the men were shipped to Vietnam in December, 1967.

description: TOKYO, Friday, March 12Japanese Government and textile industry sources here were surprised by the stiff tone of President Nixon's rejection of unilateral selfrestraints on textile exports to the United States as announced earlier this week by the Japan Textile Federation.

title: DR. ARTURO CASILLI
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., March 11 Dr. Arturo R. Casilli of 618 Newark Avenue, a pathologist at three Elizabeth hospitals, died yesterday at his home of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 78 years old.

title: Advertising:
description: If America misses Burt Bacharach on C.B.S. televi sion Sunday night it's its own fault. Lord knows it's been told. And told.

title: 3 Theaters Raided In Times Sq. Area For Obscene Films
description: The police yesterday raided three movie theaters said to he showing pornographic films in the Times Square area as patrons streamed out hiding their faces behind hats, newspapers and, in one case large opened umbrella. Managers and projectionists were arrested at each theater.

title: Britain's Trade Gap Grows Wider
description: LONDON, March 11The Government announced today that Britain suffered a trade deficit of $151.2million in February.

title: Pakistanis Crisis Virtually Halts Rehabilitation Work in Cyclone Region
description: DACCA; Pakistan, March 11 The crisis in relations between East and West Pakistan has virtually halted rehabilitation and reconstruction work for the two million people affected by last November's cyclone disaster in coastal areas of East Pakistan.

title: Government by Laws
description: American democracy rests on faith in government by laws, and not by men. From time to time, arrogant frightened men have deviated from that principle, in the mistaken belief that only their wisdom could keep the nation protected from its enemies.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 12, 1971

title: Red Ink Cuts Grandstands On 5th Ave.

title: Hospital Staff Warned of Risk In Testifying Before Committee
description: The chief administrator of the United States Public Health Service Hospital on Staten Island warned his professional staff yesterday that there would be an element of risk for any member who expressed views contrary to the policy of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare at a Congressional hearing at the hospital today.

title: 2 JAPANESE BANKS PLANNING TO MERGE
description: TOKYO, March 11 (Reuters) The Daiichi Bank and the Nippon Kangyo Bank said today that they had agreed to merge into what would be the largest domestic bank in Japan in deposit volume.

title: Airline Talks on Flight Cuts Approved
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board agreed yesterday to permit the nation's airlines to hold limited preliminary discussions that could lead to agreements under which the airlines could reciprocally reduce flights on some overly competitive routes.

title: ASHKENAZY JOINS PERLMAN IN RECITAL
description: An extraordinary amount of natural skill was on hand at Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday night, and the wielders of it were Vladimir Ashkenazy, pianist, and Itzhak Perlman, violinist, in a sonata recital.

title: Miss Proell First Again In Giant Slalom Skiing
description: ABETONE, Italy, March 11 (AP)Annemarie Proell of Austria continued her domination of women's Alpine skiing today by winning the final giant slalom of the Foemina Cup competition.

title: PROXY BID PLANNED FOR CONTAINER CORP.
description: A group of stockholders of the Universal Container Corporation who said they own 21 per cent of the voting stack of the company, announced yesterday they plan to seek control of the company at the annual meeting next month.

title: THREE ME IN RIOT AT PUERTO RICO U.
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., March 11Two policemen and a student were shot dead today when a riot erupted here on the green and pleasant campus of the University of Puerto Rico.

title: Banking Conflict in Legislature Charged
description: ALBANY, March 11 Should legislators who are also bankers be barred from serving on the. State Senate and Assembly Banks Committees?

title: BOOKKEEPER IS HELD IN THEFT OF $717,000
description: The head bookeeper and office manager of an investment concern was arrested yesterday, charged with stealing $717,000 of the company's assets by juggling the books.

title: DeCavalcante Wins a New Trial After Getting 15Year Sentence
description: NEWARK, March 11  The extortion conspiracy conviction of Simone Rizzo DeCavalcante, a reputed leader of organized crime in New Jersey, has been reversed by a Federal appeals court.

title: State Department Opposes Further Curbs on Latin Nations That Seize Boats
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The State Depa'rtment voiced opposition today to Congressional proposals for further legislative sanctions against LatinAmerican countries  notably Ecuadorthat seize American fishing boats operating off their coasts and fine the captains.

title: Fiscal Practices Tightened, Scribner Says
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner said yesterday that a reorganization of the school system's business and fiscal practices was under way to assure tighter control over spending.

title: Long Texas Dry Spell Defies Rainmaker
description: ASPERMONT, Tex., March 11  The sun was shining on this parched West Texas town today. Still shining, despite the ,last best efforts of Homer F. Berry, the Arkansas rainmaker.

title: RCA SUBMITS PLAN FOR SATELLITE NET
description: WASHINGtON, March 11(AP)  The RCA Corporation proposed today to build and operate a $198million domestic satellite system for all 50 states and Puerto Rico.

title: Red Sox and Petroceili Sued By Stewardess for $1 Million
description: Rico Petrocelli and the Boston Red Sox were named in State Supreme Court yesterday as defendants in a $1million damage suit charging the Boston ball club's shortstop wi?? assault and battery against an airline stewardess.

title: BRUCE SETS RECORD: A 4SENTENCE TALK
description: PARIS, March 11David K. E. Bruce today delivered the shortest, speech on record at the Vietnam peace talks as he denounced what he described as the propaganda maneuvers of the Communist delegations.

title: After the School Crisis
description: The most urgent need in the city school system's fund crisis was clearly to prevent any action that would disrupt or otherwise damage the education of over one million pupils. Too many irresponsible, selfish or militant past actions by adults have already done unconscionable harm to the children's schooling to permit another blow.

title: Books of The Times
description: Thomas McGuane made an odd, ferocious debut two years ago with The Sporting Club, in which a demonic practical joker set off a chain reaction that destroyed a venerable rich men's hunting and fishing retreat in the woods of northern Michigan. Before the novel ended, a lake over seventy years old that had become part of the general memory of the county's wildlife was a suppurating mudbowl, and we had been shown some unnerving aspects of male rivalry and affluent boredom. Toward the end, The Sporting Club went dizzily out of control and left even its most sympathetic readers buffaloed, struggling for footing and gasping promising. But it's a resonant, daring piece of work, with a fine play of conflicting feelings: the novelist both hates the rich members of the sporting club and is appalled by the destruction of their Eden, which attracts him. McGuane writes lyrically of the outdoors and brutally about the human figures who people the landscape.

title: 113806 Wins Jersey Lottery
description: WAYNE, N. J., March 11 (AP) The winning number in this week's state lottery drawing was 113806. The holders of tickets with all six numbers in order will win $50,000; with the last five, $4,000; the last four, $400, and the last three, $40. Those with only the last two are eligible for a milliondollar drawing later.

title: Knicks'
description: A limited number of tickets for the Knicks first four home games in the National Basketball Association playoffs at Madison Square Garden will go on sale Wednesday at the Felt Forum box office, Eighth Avenue between 31st and 33d Streets. The sale is scheduled to begin at 10 A.M., but if the crowd is large, it may begin earlier.

title: DOUGLAS K. SMITH
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 11 Douglas K. Smith, a management consultant with Case & Co., New York, for the last 27 years, died yesterday at Hunterdon Medical Center, Flemington. He was 64 years old and lived on Montgomery Road in Skillman, near here.

title: Morton Says He Plans Steps To Ease Micronesia Problem
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton told Congress today that the United States had dragged its feet in relations with Micronesia and that he intended to take new initiatives to resolve differences with the sprawling Pacific Territory.

title: A Role for Youth
description: Through the Red Cross Youth Program, young people are learning about narcotics so they can help prevent the spread of addiction. They are also participating in storefront projects provid ing activity for young people in arts and crafts, sports, photography and remedial tutoring. And they are still involved in traditional programsbeing volunteers in hospitals, the blood program, vacation day camps and afterschool centers. Through the Red Cross, young people are learning community responsibility and leadership. Contributions may be sent to Red Cross, New York, N. Y. 10023.

title: MINE OWNER ABSENT FROM HOUSE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Charles Finley did not appear today at a House bearing concerning the explosion that killed 38 men at the Kentucky mine he operated.

title: Some Bond Prices Surge To Year's Highest Levels
BOSTON AIDE SEES NO RELIEF ANSWER
description: BOSTON, March 11  The state Welfare Commissioner, Stephen A. Minter, argued today that there were no single answers to the explosive growth that has made Boston the first among the large cities for the number of people on welfare.

title: Miss Penny Luter Is Wed Here To Steven Michael Asherman
description: Miss Penny Luter, daughter of John Luter of New York and the late Mrs. Mary Jane Hickey Luter, was married here last night to Steven Michael Asherman son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Asherman of Geneva Canon William Van Meter, an Episcopal clergyman and executive director of the Department of Christian Social Relations of the New York City Council of Churches, performed the ceremony at the Overseas Press Club.

description: More than half a century ago, when Henry Jack Gaisman attracted widespread attention because his inventions were fetching high prices, he fled to an isolated house in the woods of northern Michigan to escape reporters.

title: Famed Moroccan Restaurant Opens Branch Here
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Panel Told SST Is Economic Folly
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Paul A. Samuelson, the economist, told the Senate Appropriations Committee today that the supersonic transport airplane was a colossal economic folly that would bring severe losses to the Government and the private companies involved.

title: Welfare's Bankruptcy
description: It Is not the figurative bankruptcy of the cities and states in terms of dollars that must be of such concern now. It is, instead, an emerging bankruptcy of spirit and thought on the part of political leaders trapped in impossible budgetary binds.

title: Nixon Comment on Missiles In Times Interview Clarified
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The White House said today that President Nixon referred to megatonnage when he told an interviewer this week that the Soviet Union was far superior to the United States in missile strength.

title: Black Panther Fugitive in Algiers Charges That Huey P. Newton Is Seeking to Split Party
description: Michael (Cet) Tabor, one of two Black Panther party members who jumped bail during the current bombconspiracy trial of the Panther 21, charged, in a videotape shown here yesterday, that a bewildered and baffled Huey P. Newton was bringing about an ideological split that threatened to disintegrate the party.

title: EGYPT IS SEEKING TO WIN U.S. FAVOR
description: CAIRO, March 11The United Arab Republic, convinced that allout support by the United States offers the only hope for a recovery of Its Israelioccupied lands without the risks and ordeals of war, has begun to direct suggestive glances at Washington after years of scolding and condemnation.

title: CITY PLANS TO ASK $75MILLION OF 11.S. FOR SCHOOL CRISIS
description: The Lindsay administration is planning to ask the Federal Government for $75million under the Social Security Act to end the budget crisis in the city's school system.

description: Huntington Hartford, whose grandfather founded the A. & P. food chain, charged yesterday that the present management had misused its power with policies that had led to unfair treatment of blacks.

description: KEY WEST, Fla.,  Somewhere out of the shifting channels that cut through the vast sandy shallows west of Boca Grande Key, the pair of gleaming permit came nosing the bottom in the kneedeep water to search for crabs and other crustacea.

description: HOUSTON, March 11 (AP)Mrs. Delores Pollard Johnson of DeQuincy, La., underwent surgery yesterday for removal of a brain tumor that has caused her to grow more than eight feet tall.

British Shun Reprisals
description: LONDON, March 11  The British. Oovernment made clear today that it would not take harsher measures. in Northern Ireland despite profound ,shock here at the latest killings. ,

title: Councilmen May Represent Some Suspects in Court

title: JACK ENTRATTER OF LAS VEGAS, 57
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 11 Jack Entratter, former president of the Sands Hotel and entertainment entrepreneur, died This morning at a Las Vegas hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: ISRAEL AND EGYPT HINT AT DEADLOCK
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 11  The envoys of Israel and the United Arab Republic today called separately on Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary, and then issued sharply worded statements indicating that the Indirect peace talks between their countries had reached a deadlock. Each insisted that the next move was up to the other.

title: Michigan Chancellor Named
description: FLINT Mich., March 11 (AP) Dr. William Moran, assistant executive vice president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, has been named chancellor of Flint College of the University of Michigan. Dr. Moran's appointment, effective July 1, was announced in Ann Arbor by Robben W. Fleming, president of the university.

title: Welcome to Cuba Yanqui
description: HAVANAThere were only a few of us in the auditorium of the Habana Libre (formerly the Havana Hilton) hotel waiting for the afternoon session to begin. It was an international affairthe 7th Congress of the International Organization of Journalistsbut it was running on Cuban timelate time. We are getting better, they all say. The revolution requires us to be more precise in our schedules. But old habits are hard to break. So....

title: Man Convicted in Slaying Of Neighbor and Her Son, 2
description: A Criminal Court jury in Queens last night found Kevin Goode guilty of murdering his nextdoor neighbor and her 2yearold son and then setting their apartment on fire.

title: War Protester Walking to Washington Prays Here
description: Louise Bruyn, a dance teacher and housewife from Newton, Mass., crossed the Third Avenue Bridge into Manhattan yesterday morning, beginning the 23d day of a walk to Washington to protest the war in Indochina.

title: VARLEY OF PENN SETS SWIM MARK
BUSINESSES FIND DRUGS A PROBLEM
description: Drugs are becoming a major business problem and there are growing fears that it will worsen. This was the major conclusion drawn by the Conference Board on the basis of a survey of 222 companies.

title: END IS SEEN NEAR IN NEWARK STRIKE
description: NEWARK, March 11  The sixweekold Newark teachers' strike appeared close to a settlement today, although some pay issues remained to be resolved.

title: Bruins Win as Esposito Sets Mark of 60 Goals
Duplan and Colt Plan Deal
description: The Duplan Corporation said yesterday it had agreed in principle with Colt International, Inc., to form a joint venture to own and operate retail fabric and notion stores.

title: Liquori to Run Two N.C.A.A. Distance Races
description: DETROIT, March 11  Figuring that two secondplace finishes may be better than one first place, especially with his school scrambling for a team title, Marty Liquori will try the difficult onemile and twomile double tomorrow and Saturday in the National Collegiate indoor track and field championships.

title: High Black Cleric Seized for Defying South African Law
description: CAPETOWN, March 11 South Africa's senior black clergyman, the Anglican Bishop of Zululand, was arrested at A.M. today for failing to show a pass that all blacks must carry.

title: New Policeman Arrested
description: Probationary Patrolman Steven J. Catalanotte, 21 years old, was arrested yesterday at his home at 2535 Bath Avenue, Brooklyn, on a charge of possessing and selling narcotics.

title: African Christians Are Developing Their Own Distinctive Theologies
description: LAGOS, NigeriaAfrican Christian theologians, most of whom have been raised and educated in the religious traditions of Europe, are beginning to develop indigenous African theologies.

title: JohnsManville Sees Gains
description: The JohnsManville Corporation, building products manufacturer, anticipates increased sales and earnings in 1971, W. R. Goodwin, president and chief executive, told stockhold, ers at the annual meeting yesterday in San Francisco.

title: A Clarification
description: The New York Times reported Monday that the brokerage firm of L. H. Rothchild & Co. had been in trouble With the Securities and Exchange Commission and has recently been reorganized under the name of Stevens, Rothchild & Co. The firm was simply renamed in 1969, not reorganized. In 1962 the firm was fined $1,200 by the National Association of Securities Dealers for violation of one of its rules regarding offerings of stock, and the S.E.C. dismissed the firm's request for an appeal. The firm has not been the subject of any direct disciplinary order by the S.E.C. There was no connection between the change of name and the N.A.S.D proceeding.

title: U.S. Jury Unable to Agree In Tax Agent Bribery Case
description: Nicholas A. Rattenni of Yonkers, the owner of two garbageremoval companies in Westchester County and a reputed underworld leader, went free yesterday when a jury in Federal District Court here failed to agree on charges that he tried to brige a tax agent.

title: 4 Coaches Gain Football Hall of Fame
description: Four college coaches who were successful in the early years of this century were named yesterday to the National Football Foundation's Hall of Fame.

title: C.B.S. Is Shifting Its Weekly News Hour in Fall
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System, in a somethingforeverybody compromise, announced yesterday that althgugh it was dropping its weekly prime time documentary hour in the Fall, the programs would be replaced with a monthly twohour documentary and a Sunday evening newsdocumentary series.

title: Returning Green Berets Face Uncertain Future
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C., March 5  The Green Berets have come home from Vietnam with their colors and decorations, checkered reputation and an uncertain future.

title: FIREMEN AND CITY REJECT PROPOSAL
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association and the city yesterday rejected a mediator's recommendations in the firemen's contract, dispute with the city.

title: YALE NOMINATES WOMAN FOR BOARD
description: NEW HAVEN, March 11For the first time in Yale's 270 years, a woman has been nominated to the Yale Corporationthe university's 16member board of trustees.

title: Needlepoint PillowsWith Diamond Prices
description: For those who lack the patience or the skill to do their own needlepoint, there is a new collection of designs by Jou, a New York concern, offering handstitched pillows and rugs. Organized by June Beveridge, Jerome Hanauer and Joseph Minicucci, who have their designs made by a studio in Avon, Conn., Jou introduced the pillows shown here (the fish, a 16inchsquare, is $172, and the numbers, an 18inchsquare, is $233), as well as a host of other pillows (from $90 to $525) and rugs (from $1,000 to $3,362, the latter for a rug just over 6,feet square). The collection of Mondrianlike designs and zebra, crab, floral and geometric patterns is available through decorators and architects at Lord & Adams, Inc., 155 East 56th Street.

title: ROSENSTIEL LINK TO CRIME DENIED
description: Louis Nichols, a former as. asistant to the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said yesterday that Lewis S. Rosenstiel, former chairman of Schenley Industries, shunned any connection with the underworld like the plague.

title: MARKET TOPS 900, THEN EASES A BIT
Sports of The Times
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11There is just no escape from the continuing shock waves generated by The Fight. Even in this baseballoriented territory the sports pages are still brightened by aftermath stories of the FrazierAli superspectacular and ballplayers pounce on newly arrived eyewitnesses for still further details. Strangely enough, though, there is far less curiosity about Joe Frazier, the winner, than about the loser, the man most players called Cassius Clay.

title: ROLLS RB211 OUTPUT GIVEN 2 MORE WEEKS
description: LONDON, March 11  The Government announced tonight that work on the RB211 engine intended for the Lockheed Tristar air bus would continue for two weeks longer than planned at RollsRoyce, which is in bankruptcy.

title: Overturn in Australia
description: The ouster by his own Liberal party of John Grey Gorton as Australia's Prime Minister is no great surprise. The dispute with his former Defense Minister involving the Australian Army's civil affairs role in Vietnam was merely the catalyst that fused enough opposition Liberal ranks to force Mr. Gorton's resignation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Major Hottell's own obituary is very moving. I cannot, help but wonder how he might have written the obituaries of those other souls, both friend and foe, who did not volunteer war as their career and did not wish thus to die.

title: Papp Walks Out on City Talks About Buying Festival Theater
description: In a theatrical climax to a dull discussion about city plans to buy his building, Joseph Papp, head of the Public Theater, spun on his heel and stalked away from a Board of Estimate meeting yesterday.

title: Bridge: Play in the Spring Nationals Will Start Today in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, March 11The advance guard of several thousand players gathering here for the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here tomorrow has been able to watch an interesting series of preliminary exhibtion matches. Three teams have played a preliminary roundrobin, with a playoff to follow tonight between the two teams with the best records.

title: Bullins's Miss Marie Comes to New Lafayette
Force for Understanding
description: Whitney M. Young Jr. made himself a healing force the tormented relations between blacks and whites. As executive director of the National Urban League, he applied his impressive resources of intelligence, energy and charm to leveling the walls of the slums through expanded opportunity for education and good jobs.

title: BENJAMIN STERN, 57, ACTIVE IN INSURANCE
description: ORANGE, N. J., March 11Benjamin L. Stern, a New York insurance executive, died this evening in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 350 Montrose Avenue.

title: An Articulate Leader
description: The only criterion by which I want to be measured is whether or not I have helped to improve the economic, political, health and social future for black peoplenot on the basis of how many white people curse out.

title: Pavarotti at Met: A GoldenAge Voice
description: Luciano Pavarotti has previously sung at the Metropolitan Opera, but he cut short his appearances the last time around because of illness. On Wednesday evening the Italian tenor made his first appearance this season, as Rodolfo in Puccini's La Boheme. It was really something.

title: SAIGON'S FORCES LEAVE TCHEPONE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 12 (AP)South Vietnamese troops who occupied the Laotian town of Tchepone last Saturday have withdrawn to positions in the surrounding hills, military sources reported yesterday.

title: STRIKERS IN SWEDEN ARE ORDERED BACK
description: STOCKHOLM, March, 11 (AP)  Parliament approved a bill today calling for a temporary halt to the strikes in Sweden.

title: FRANK CLUNE, 77, NOVELIST, IS DEAD
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, March 12  Frank Clime, one of the most prolific authors in Australia, died in a Sydney hospital yesterday. He was 77 years old and was at work on his 68th book when he became ill last Saturday.

title: AUBURN'S GUARDS TERMED ABUSIVE
description: AUBURN, N.Y., March 11One of the six convicts seeking removal from the state prison here on the ground that their constitutional rights are being violated at the institution said today that guards had refused to let him telephone a lawyer and had ripped his legal papers.

title: ADVERTISED PRICES UP 0.61% IN MONTH
description: Prices of merchandise advertised by department, specialty, and general merchandise stores rose slightly in January compared with the corresponding month of 1970, according to the Bureau of Advertising, a division of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

title: A Bach Cantata Superbly Sung
description: That thriceannual gathering of the faithful, the Bach Aria Group and its audience, took place for the last time this season at Tully Hall on Wednesday night. The loyalty on the part of all concerned is understandable. However varied in quality the programs of cantatas and cantata arias that the group puts on many be, there are always some wonderful items.

title: Villard Houses, City Landmark, Are Purchased by Archdiocese
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has taken full possession of Villard Houses, a Renaissance revival landmark on Madison Avenue, and plans to use the buildings for executive offices.

title: Chile Reported Unable to Fill Contracts for Export of Copper
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 11  Copper production at Chile's major mines, which face the pr;ospect of nationalization, has fallen short of goals and is insufficient to meet exportsales contracts, industry sources repcirt.

title: Store Sales Up in Week
description: WASHINGTON, March, 11The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales for the latest week ended March 6 was an estimated $609,000,000, an increase of 1 per cent above the $602,000,000 sales for the corresponding week last year. Total retailstore sales for the latest week was an estimated $6,694,000,000, an increase of 5 per cent above the $6,394,000,000 sales for the same period last year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It was with considerable emotion that I read the March 3 OpEd article A Soldier's Own Obituary by Maj. John A. Hottell. I thank you very much for printing it.

title: Navy Charges 30 Sailors
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 11 (UPI)Thirty crewmen of the James E. Keyes, a Navy destroyer, have been detained at the naval station here for disciplinary action and possible courtsmartial resulting from use of marijuana aboard ship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Previewed on your March 3 front page was an advertisement of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, proposing that we start a new morning routine: coffee, doughnut and the daily double.

title: U.S. War Deaths Drop; Toll of Wounded Rises
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11 (AP)The United States command announced today that 44 Americans were killed in combat in Indochina last week, 25 fewer than the week before.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE OFF FROM 70 WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Freight traffic On United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended March 6 were both below the volume in the corresponding 1970 week..

title: Catholic Students Picket Here for State Assistance
description: Up to 1,000 students and faculty members of the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Brooklyn staged a two hourdemonstration yesterday outside Governor Rockefeller's office on West 55th Street to support state aid for students in nonpublic schools.

title: Academy of Sciences Names Chief
description: The New York Academy of Sciences has appointed Dr. Fred G. Armstrong as its executive director, the 154yearold institution announced here yesterday.

title: VATICAN CLARIFIES BAN ON EXPRIESTS
description: ROME, March 11  The Vatican disclosed today that it had instructed bishops and superiors of religious orders throughout the world to bar men who left the priesthood from all church work.

title: Market Place: InDepth Studies Of I.B.M., Xerox
description: Indepth studies of hightechnology companies are rather out of fashion these daysespecially in an era in which today's technological advance is tomorrow's obsolescent junk.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The real mystery of Internal Revenue Form No. 990 (editorial Feb. 25) is why the censorship function of the I.R.S. has existed for 37 years without effective challenge.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It was cruel of The Times to reprint A Soldier's Own Obituary.

title: ECONOMISTS BACK A PACKAGING TAX
description: Two leading economists lent their support yesterday to the city's proposals for a tax or bounty on virtually all packagings, from glass bottles to plastic wrap, to control the growing solidwaste problem here.

title: PINCAY REGISTERS 5 WINNERS IN ROW
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 11 (UPI)Laffit Pincay Jr., the leading rider at the meeting, recorded five straight winners today but Bill Shoemaker captured the $54,150 Santa Susana Stakes with Turkish Trousers at Santa Anita.

title: Screen: Diary of Couple
description: "Brandy in the Wilderness," which opened yesterday at the Film Forum, a nonprofit movie club open to the public and specializing in independent, non-theatrical fare, is, according to its operators, a largely autobiographical feature shot as a documentary "with some re-enactments."As such, this 16-mm. black-and-white visual log of its young creators' love-hate and filming experiences over a long, unspecified period (the film was completed in 1969), is a stark, purposely repetitious record of a search for fulfillment. Since the film is its own mark of achievement, it must also be noted that, despite its commendable sincerity, it is often as callow as its principals' dedicated but fumbling efforts to make it as people and movie makers.Its title notwithstanding, this amalgam of documentary, cinema vrit and reenactment is the diary of Brandy (Michaux French) and Stanton Kaye. Through off-screen narration and onscreen dialogue, we follow Mr. Kaye (herein called Simon Weiss) through his early youth, in his drive to make movies in his native Los Angeles, his arrival here to join with his "patron," Brandy, to make a movie; their personal relationship on a cross-country auto trip to her native Chicago and L.A. and back again in a strained affair that ends in apparent contentment complete with a baby daughter, cats and a dog.As noted, there are reprises of the action from Brandy's view as she falls in love with Simon but is flatly rejected by him long before the happy ending. And we are also introduced to their parents and friends in vignettes that, like the entire account in this movie about them and their movie, are often static and rarely emotionally equal to the muted anguish and trials projected by the dialogue.Miss French, a petite but unspectacular brunette, and Mr. Kaye, a largely placid type despite the problems, who reportedly are in their twenties, are obviously devoted to their film. If it occasionally leaves the impression of a home-made movie, their unusual inspection of themselves leaves no doubt of their honesty and, perhaps, potential."Brandy in the Wilderness" will be shown through Sunday and repeated next Thursday through Sunday.

title: SISTER OF BUCKLEYS SLAPS AT FEMINIST
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)  A sister of the conservative, Roman Catholic Buckley brothers said today that she had assaulted the radical feminist TiGrace Atkinson for an illiterate harangue against the mystical body of Christ in a speech at Catholic University.

title: Lawmakers With Banking Links
description: Members of the Banks Committees of both houses of the State Legislature are required to list any bank stocks they may own or offices and directorships they may hold in banks doing business in the state.

title: Wheelock Names Head
description: BOSTON, March 12 (AP)The appointment of Donald R. Cruickshank as the sixth president of Wheelock College was announced today by the board of trustees.

title: Giants Increase Prices On 1971 Football Tickets
description: Season ticket renewals are in the mails today for fans of the New York Giants and it is going to cost more to see the team play this season at Yankee Stadium.

title: Duke Ellington Named To Swedish Academy
description: The Royal Swedish Academy of Music has conferred membership on Duke Ellington, marking the first time a musician of popular music has been included in the rostership of the 200yearold institution.

title: GOVERNMENT BLOCKS DUMPING OF ARSENIC
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)A Pennsylvania chemical company canceled today its planned dumping of waste arsenic compounds into the ocean at the request of the Federal Government.

title: Johnson of F.C.C. Scores Notice on Drug Lyrics
description: Federal Communications Commissioner Nicholas Johnson, in a radio broadcast here yesterday, attacked with sarcasm, scorn and song lyrics the public notice issued last week by the F.C.C. urging broadcasters to make themselves aware of music tending to promote or glorify the use of illegal drugs.

title: Mulligan Indictment Dismissed; Action to Delay Police Inquiry
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed a contempt indictment against Hugh Mulligan, who has been described by the police as a major bookmaker and loan shark with 50 employes and a key corrupter of policemen.

title: Texas Senator Says Nixon Has Not Leveled on Laos
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, whom President Nixon once counted among his ideological majority, said today that the President had not leveled with the American people or Congress about the full extent of risk involved in the current operation in Laos.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS ADVANCED FOR WEEK
description: DETROIT, March 12 (UPD)United States passengercar production jumped significantly this week with 13 General Motors assembly plants turning out cars on overtime, Ward's Automotice Reports said today.

title: CITY ADDS SCHOOLS IN BUDGET SHIFTS
description: Three new elementary schools, 24 small size elementary schools and a variety of other school buildings and plans $47.5million worth in all are being added to the city's capital construction plans.

title: Personality Heads Field In Aqueduct Dash Today
description: Personality, the Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs colt who was acclaimed champion of his class in 1970, will make his local debut as 4yearold today when he competes in the Paumonok Handlap at Aqueduct.

title: Study Finds Early Malnutrition Damaging to Brain Cells in Rats
Puerto Rican Campus Is Quiet But Root of Riot Is Untouched
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., March 12The gates are closed and the students are gone and a weekend calm has settled over the lush, green Rio Piedras campus of the University of Puerto Rico.

title: Glen Alden Reports Peak Net and Sales
Books of The Times
description: The publication of The Gift Relationship should make it clear in this country, as it has long been clear in Britain, that Richard M. Titmuss is a major figure in contemporary sociology. For many years the Labor party's chief adviser on social welfare policy and a professor of social administration at the London School of Economies and. the University of London, Professor. Titmuss has written a book that has the force and elegance of a novel and the immediacy of an emergency ,news bulletin. Just as Max Weber used the rise of Protestant capitalism to refute Mark's economic determinism and reaffirni the place of ideology in human activity, Professor Titmuss analyzes various systems of blood donation to draw a line between economic and social good and reaffirm the social value of an individual's moral choice to give freely, not to sell. He has combined the depth and humane insight of a social philosopher with the muckraking energy of an investigative reporter.

title: Lineman Electrocuted
description: ROBBINSVILLE, N. J., March 12 (AP)William Spence, a 40yearold lineman for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, was electrocuted today while working on power lines in this Mercer County community.

title: Jersey Man Is Arrested In MachineGun Shooting
description: NEWARK, March 12 (AP)An Irvington man said to be an associate of Anthony Caponigro, a reputed member of organized crime, has been charged with the machinegun shooting of a Brooklyn, N. Y., Man.

title: Newark Airport Links
description: NEWARK, March 12  The Port of New York Authority has agreed in principle to acquire the Penn Central Railroad Station in Newark, to build a rail link to Newark Airport and to build short takeoff and landing (STOL) airports In New Jersey, the authority chairman said yesterday.

title: Clarkson and Harvard Triumph And Gain East Hockey Final
LUCIA WITH SILLS STILL A DRAW HERE
description: Tickets for runofthemill opera performances may not be selling now the way they were this time last year, but the New York State Theater was filled Thursday night for the New York City Opera's presentation of Donizetti's Lucia di Lammermoor with Beverly Sills in the title role. It was the company's first performance of the opera in its current spring season.

title: Men's Fashions: No Sign of Retrenching
description: Francine Farkas, Alexander's fashion director, wore her black velvet hot pants outfit to in traduce the store's spring fashions for men the other day. Everybody agreed she looked cute. But when a male model emerged in similar pants over black pantyhose and with a ruffled white shirt, the audience howled and let out a wolf whistle or two.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Feb. 13 editorial criticizing my recent order to the Housing and Development Administration is so permeated with error that the record must be set straight.

title: SAIGON'S FORCES IN LAOS PULL BACK
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 13 (AP)  South Vietnamese forces in Laos pulled back yesterday from positions near Tchepone, former transshipment point on the enemy's supply trail complex.

title: Billy Taylor's Bind Stands Among Best Of Big Jazz Groups
description: The place to develop a big jazz band nowadays, it would appear, is on a television talk show. Billy Taylor, whose 11piece band works the David Frost Show, yesterday brought it out from behind the conversation and commercials that normally obscure it to present it livevividly aliveat Downbeat, 42d Street and Lexington Avenue, as part of the weekly noontime Jazz Adventures series.

title: ... the Fire Alarm Rings Again
description: Once again the people of New York City are the shutouts in news that critically affects their battered pocketbooksand perhaps the viability of the city as well.

title: PAN AM FILES SUIT ON 747 INSURANCE
description: Pan American World Airways filed a $24million suit yesterday against ti the United States Government, Lloyd's of London and 14 leading American and British insurance companies on its claim involving damages caused when Arab guerrilla hijackers ,blew up on of its 747 jets in Cairo last September.

title: Out of Ireland's. Bogs, a Handwork Cooperative Has Arisen
description: CLOONFAD, IrelandIn Gaelic, Cloonfad means Long Meadow, but this area is so poor and wet that there is a local saying that a snipe would drown here.

title: Philo T. Farnsworth, a Pioneer In Design of Television, Is Dead
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 12 Philo T. Farnsworth, a pioneer in television, died yesterday in LatterDay Saints Hospital here. He was 64 years old.

title: Bank Robbers Kidnap Girl
description: BELLEVUE, Wash., March 12 (UPI)  Two very courteous and very pleasont men kidnapped a bank manager's 6yearold daughter today, robbed the Seattle Firk National Bank and fled with the child and an undetermined amount of money. Allen G. Larson, manager of the bank, and his wife Corrine were re united with their daughter Amy at a parking lot several miles north of the bank where she was found tied and gagged under a blanket in the rear of a stolen thuck but unharmed.

title: Auburn Guards Deny Striking 6 Inmates Seeking Transfers
description: AUBURN, N. Y., March 12Two guards at the, state prison here said today that they did not know of any assaults by guards on the six inmates who are seeking removal from the institution.

description: New Jersey's largest utility company is considering the construction of a twomillionkilowatt nuclear generator at Bayonne, in the heart of the New YorkNew Jersey metropolitan area, to meet an expected doubling of the power demand by the end of the decade.

title: Ecuador Warship Fires Warning at U.S. Vessel
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)State Department officials said today that an unarmed United States Navy freighter was halted briefly yesterday by warning shots from an Ecuadorian warship, then allowed to proceed.

title: New Drives Swell Number Of Vietnam War Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 The number of war refugees in South Vietnam has risen dramaticallyperhaps by as many as 150,000  since new allied operations in Indochina were begun late last year, Congressional informants said today.

title: Army Officers Accuser Anthony Bernard Herbert
description: ATLANTA, March 12In 1943, when he was a strapping, 13yearold kid in the Pennsylvania coal fields, Anthony Bernard Herbert ran away from home and, enlisted in the Marines. I guess I should be glad Mom came and took me back, he laughs now. I always was an Army man, anyway. That, despite his levity, is precisely what he is a robust lieutenant colonel who was once a private, a steelnerved hero with a chest full of medals, an Army man from the gleam on his spitshined shoes to the closecropped hair on his head.

title: Federal TakeOver Of Welfare's Costs Predicted by Boggs
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Representative Hale Boggs, the new House majority leader, predicted today that the current Congress would approve a broad program of fiscal relief for states and cities, including a full federalization of welfare.

title: 2 UNIONS IN PACT WITH CON EDISON
description: The Consolidated Edison Company and two unions, that had threatened to strike tomorrow reached tentative agreements laSt night.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)The Pentagon announced today that the following servicemen from the New York area had been killed in action in Southeast Asia:

title: Rangers, 72, and Extend Unbeaten Streak to 10
description: A remarkable team effort by the Rangers resulted in a 72 rout of the Philadelphia Flyers last night at Madison Square Garden. With each body check they threw, the Rangers seemed to be making up for years of frustration against the Philadelphians.

title: Buckley's 9,343 Gains Top Spot For $85,000 Cougar Pin Finals
Chile Assailed for Bar on AntiRed Film
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 12 A score of prominent people gathered almost furtively in the private screening room of a motionpicture distributor this week to see the antiStallnist film The Confession directed by CostaGavras, the creator of Z.

title: 89 Demonstrators Are Held In Indiana School SitIn
description: RICHMOND, Ind., March 12 (AP)The police arrested 89 demonstrators today when they refused to abandon a sitin outside the Richmond High School principal's office.

title: EPEE, FOIL TITLES TAKEN BY N.Y. U.
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., March 12New York University won the team championships in epee and foil today and opened a large lead in its bid for third Intercollegiate Fencing Association threeweapon crown in the last four. years.

title: Seville a FastGrowing City, but No One Is Doing Anything About It
description: SEVILLE, Spain  What kind of city would shut down its river? a local editor demanded as he sat at a cafe beside the Guadalquivir.

title: U.A.W. Office Is Struck

Members of Local 42 of the Office and Professional Employes International demanded a $10.80aweek increasea 6.6 per cent raiseand a $100 vacation bonus. The U.A.W.'s last offer included a raise of $8 and two more vacation days.

It will surprise only those who have taken seriously the fatuous statements of Defense and State Department officials about the early restoration of a constitutional order and parliamentary democracy in Greece.

title: Utilities Included In Easing of Rules On Depreciation
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Treasury announced today that the benefits of the new, liberalized procedures for figuring depreciation of equipment for tax purposes should be extended to regulated public utilities.

title: Sinai Views Called New
description: WASHINGTON March 12 Much of Premier Golda Meir's outline of an ArabIsraeli settlement has been put forward publicly by Israeli officials before but some of her comments about the terms for the Sinai Peninsula are new at this juncture in the negotiations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I differ with Prof.. Henry S. Commager as to the wisdom of tuition charges. [OpEd Feb. 25.] His opposition rests on two claims:

title: U. S. Team Flies to Vienna for a Fourth Round of Arms Talks
description: WASHINGTON, March 12American negotiators flew to Vienna today for the fourth round of the talks on the limitation of strategic arms with little hope of an early break in the deadlock with the Soviet Union on major issues.

title: Suit Seeks to Oust Hoffa As Teamsters'
description: NASHVILLE, March 12 (AP) James it Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and his lieutenant, Frank Fitzsimmons, have been ordered to explain April 1 why they should keep their union offices.

title: New Attacks on British Troops Feared in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 12Northern Ireland officials have warned the British Government that the conflict here has taken a new turn with an underground terrorist group increasing its violence against British troops. The ter rorists are suspected of the murder of three offduty soldiers on Wednesday.

title: Lloyd Home to Be Museum
description: LOS ANGELES, March 12 (Reuters)  Harold Lloyd, the film comedian who died of cancer on Monday at the age of 77, asked that his luxurious Beverly Hills home be a motion picture museum, it was disclosed when his will was filed in Superior Court here today. The house, one of the last great mansions of the Golden Age of Hollywood, includes a ninehole golf course. The rest of the estate valued at $5.5million was left to his three children and a grandchild.

title: Canada Is Negotiating to Buy Home Oil
description: OTTAWA, March 12  The Government of Canada is negotiating to buy Home Oil, Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta, if necessary to prevent it from falling under the control of a United States bidder.

title: Today's South Is Not Much Like Faulkner's
description: GREENSBORO, N. C. We want you to tell us about the South, said the man from. The Times, and I thought of Shreve McCannon feverishly questioning Quentin Compson in their Cambridge flat: Tell about the South. What's it like there. What do they do there. Why do they live there. Why do they live at all....

Mr. Mitchell, his associate artistic director, Karel Shook, and their 24 dancers have had a great deal of sentiment on their side. Yet, happily, they never needed it.

title: The Downtown Scene: Sculpture for Outdoors
description: Most outdoor public sculpture fails., It fails because it, rarely. comes to grips with the multiple and complex relationships it must effect with the surrounding environment. More often than not, the numerous sculptures that haVe 13en increasingly dotting the city plazas and shopping centers throughout the country are more of an eyesore, more of a visual and physical deterrent than they are an esthetically pleasing, organic part of the landscape.
