title: Mrs. ClassenMrs. Vosters Win Squash Racquets Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 12Mrs. Charles Classen of Haverford, Pa., and Mrs. Francis Vosters Jr. of Wilmington, Del., regained the United States squash racquets doubles championship today by defeating the defending litleholders, Mrs. Terry Thesieres and Mrs. Nathan Stauffer of Cynwyd, Pa., 157, 15.12, 1615, at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. President Nixon left for Newport, R.I., this morning to speak at the Naval Training School commencement. He then flew to Key Biscayne, Fla., for the weekend.

title: Thursday Night Fight
description: Los AngelesRudy Robles, 1601 pounds, Carson, Calif., outpointed Al Stankie, 159, Downey, Calif 10 rounds.

title: City BridgeToll Plans
description: A plan to help avoid another transit fare increase next Jan. by imposing new bridge and tunnel tolls is being seriously considered by the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Eyes on Yankee Giant
description: BUENOS AIRESIs the Nixon Administration willing financially assist the development of socialism or at least economic nationalism in Latin America? If so, with how much money? And if not, how much more of United States investments in the region is Washington prepared to lose? These perplexing questions surfaced at the special meeting of the InterAmerican DevelopmentBank, which convened here recently to install Antonio Ortiz Mena of Mexico as its new president. Among those who are awaiting the answers are the owners of some $13billion of United States investments in the area, which compare with almost $12billion in the European Common Market.

title: PEKING REPORTS ECONOMIC GAINS
description: Official figures disclosed by Premier Chou Enlai indicate that Communist China has made significant, though limited, economic progress in the last decade.

title: Opening of Hair in Capital Tops Hectic Week
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  A gala affair, graced with assorted Senators, ambassadors and social superstars, welcomed the Age of Aquarius to the nation's capital tonight at the official opening here of Hair.

title: Harkness Ballet Ends Tour
description: The Harkness Ballet has returned to New York after a sixmonth tour. The company, which arrived here Wednesday, performed in Spain, Portugal, France, Germany, Switzerland and Italy.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A young black photographer angrily said, What's going on? The promoters are going to make millions off two guys who never even went into the Army and the poor doggies out in the mud who keep this system going might not even have gotten to hear it. Go find out how many American soldiers died in Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam Monday night while the fight was on. Dig this. Some 19yearold kid, he's going out on patrol and going to get killed, maybe his last few minutes might have been brightened by listening to the fight, take his mind off where he was, connect him up with something big and glamorous going on out in the world.

title: Tekoah Again Sees Jarring
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12Yosef Tekoah, the Israeli delegate, met for the second consecutive day today with Dr. Jarring. Both meetings were at Mr. Tekoah's request.

title: SUSPECT CHARGED IN JERSEY DEATHS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 12  A 21yearold exconvict was arraigned here early this morning in the murders of two, teenagers last month.

title: The Militant Bluecoats
description: LOS ANGELESIt would have been very nice had cops not forgotten that historically it. has been their destiny to forbearthat,. like Bernard Malamud's Jewish protagonists, one can become ennobled and liberated by his ability to silently abide.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, March 12  I suppose you Americans have twice our income per capita, but that is just a way of lying with statistics. This is a better country to live in, we all know that: more comfortable, less worried, a satisfactory life. The fact that we show up poorer in the figures does not really matter.

title: DR. EUGENE OPIE, RESEARCHER, DIES
description: Dr. Eugene Lindsay Opie, a Pathologist, bacteriologist, medical school administrator and pioneer researcher on the cause of diabetes, tuberculosis and other diseases, died yesterday in the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 97 years old.

title: Hearing Studies Fate of S.I. Hospital
description: Politicians and union leaders, welfare mothers and doctors, crowded a Congressional hearing on Staten Island yesterday to try to help determine the uncertain future of the United States Public Health Service Hospital there.

title: Screen: Sudsy, Sentiment:Robert Miller Directs 'Buttercup Chain'
description: Like the four young people whose interlocking loves it charts, with more attention to scenic than psychological detail, "The Buttercup Chain" is rather attractive to look at and none too bright in the head, especially when it finally makes its futile little stabs at self-understanding."You can't love everyone," says the exhausted Manny (Leigh Taylor-Young), a pretty American girl who has had a baby and lost it, left her husband and slept with almost every man in the film. "It just means that nobody gets enough."It's the measure of the film's characters, and of the film itself, which has no real overview, that they talk about love as if it were sex that could be poured from magnums, like champagne. Soap operas, and the audiences that watch them, are most fond of this sort of verbal conceit, which has the ring of wisdom and the effect of relieving characters of responsibility for their actions. Because love runs out on them, instead of the other way around, people are free to indulge themselves in the most unrewarding kind of self-pity.Like most soap operas, "The Buttercup Chain" has within it some legitimately interesting but largely unexplored human relationships. France (Hywel Bennett) and Margaret (Jane Asher) are first cousins, born of twin sisters on the same day and raised as brother and sister. They never consummate what is, actually a non-incestuous love, but their guilt is such that it makes them both incapable of loving anyone else. When Margaret comes to live with her cousin in London, he immediately expands his household to include a young Swedish architectual student (Sven-Bertil Taube), whom he picks to be Margaret's lover, and Manny, the American girl, who becomes his mistress.On idyllic holidays in southern Spain, in the English countryside and, finally, in Sweden, the mnage  quatre explores the various heterosexual possibilities of mating to the apparent satisfaction of no one, except possibly Robert Ellis Miller, the director ("The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter").Miller and his screen writer, Peter Draper, avoided any revealing psychological confrontations in favor of making one of those depressingly modish movies in which the sensations created by things like slick photography, beautiful nudes and intrusive soundtrack music become the substance of the film, instead of its context.In addition to the four leads, who have the physical graces of youth and something of its stridency, the cast includes Clive Revill, a fine if middle-aged (41) actor, as the millionaire who, like Father Christmas, pops in and out of the lives of the young quartet, bringing presents of picnic hampers and champagne, as well as a decent reticence otherwise lacking in the movie."The Buttercup Chain," which was the British entry at last year's Cannes film festival, opened yesterday at the Baronet Theater.

title: HOIST THE FLAG ROMPS AT BOWIE
The Campus Left and Israel
description: That some academics, students and intellectuals have dropped their support for Israel is hardly news. In part it seems a quite normal development. A power struggle rages in the Middle East; both sides make passionate claims; the arguments grow complicated. Serious people, it follows, may find the Israeli case not entirely persuasive. Agree or disagree, such judgment is entirely proper in a democratic society.

title: CANADIAN SURPLUS OF EXPORTS AT PEAK
description: OTTAWA, March 12 (Canadian Press)Canadian export sales last month exceeded imports by almost $240million, record surplus on merchandise trade for February.

title: Honeywell Plans Layoffs In Computer consolidation
description: WALTHAM, Mass., March 12 (AP)Honeywell, Inc., announced today plans to consolidate some of its Massachusetts computer operations stemming from its merger last October with the General Electric Company's computer equipment business.

description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 12 (AP)Trouble with a rocket pressurization system forced postponement today of an attempted to launch the Explorer 43 satelite to probe scientific secrets in space. The launch was rescheduled for 11:15 A.M. tomorrow.

description: FARGO, N. D., March 12 (AP)  Several upsets marked the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association College Division. wrestling tournament today.

title: AN AUSTRIA NIGHT AT PHILHARMONIC
description: Mozart and Bruckner make an ideal concert pairing, as Karl Bohm showed in his guest appearance with the New York Philharmonic Thursday night. Starting with Mozart's Symphony No. 33 in B flat (K.319), a deceptively light and dry wine that can suddenly turn heady; the conductor capped off the feast with one of the heaviest ports in the symphonic repertory, Bruckner's Eighth Symphony.

title: Japan's Stainless Steel Studied
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Treasury is making a preliminary investigation of a complaint that Japan is dumping stainless steel sheet in the United States market, officials said today.

description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., March 12Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said today that some types of issues that are now handled in court may have to be shifted to administrative agencies ,to give overburdened judges time to deal with cases and controversies,

description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Senate's passage today of Social Security legislation has all but assured an additional Government stimulus for the economy this year of at least $4billion.

description: DACCA, Pakistan, March 12  East Pakistan's selfrule was broadened today in an effort to cope with mounting economic problems stemming from West Pakistan's control of much of the economic structure in the East.

description: WASHINGTON, March 12New evidence suggesting that viruses are a. factor in causing humanbreast cancer has been reported by an international team, of scientists.

description: NEW DELHI March 12 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has won a stunning personal triumph.

He died a half hour later at Jerferson Hospital, apparently of natural causes, according to the city Medical Examiner's office. He was 69 years old.

description: The New York Telephone Company his applied to the State Public Service Commission for permision to install picture telephones after May 1.

If the composer had not let the pieces run on in Oriental fashion, they would have seemed even more listenable.

description: A year ago, in one of the more despicable acts violence committed by white segregationists, a mob Lamar, S. C., stormed three school buses carrying Negro children to a newly integrated school. Police, also under heavy attack, used tear gas to disperse the rioters but said that their primary concern for the youngsters safety prevented them from making arrests on the scene.

title: City as Buckminster Fuller Views It
description: As he walked jauntily out onto Fifth Avenue he seemed all eyes and ears Serious and alert, he looked about him.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The periodic discussions of how we select Presidential candidates usually assume two polar positions. One suggests the abolition of the national convention as unsightly, undemocratic and bossridden, and the substitution of national primary. The other argues that a national primary would restrict the nomination to wealthy athletes, i.e., those who have the stamina and money to survive a first primary, a possible runoff primary and the election campaign itself.

title: MRS. MEIR CITES BORDER CHANGES SOUGHT BY ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, March 12 Premier Golda Meir said today that there must not be another war in the Middle East and indicated the frontiers for Israel that she said could prevent it. It would be a painful solution for President Anwar elSadat she said, but people had to pay for their deeds.

title: TV: Peculiar Genre of The Special
description: Tomorrow at 9 P.M. the Burt Bacharach Special will be shown on the Columbia Broadcasting System. All right. Now consider for a moment the peculiar genre of the Television Special.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON POST AN ADVANCE
KnitFabric Companies Gain From Going Vertical
description: Going vertical has always been identified in business with bigness. Visions of many plants of a single company devoted to a full spectrum of activities, from the manufacture of primary materials all the way to production of the finished consumer product, have loomed large in the minds of most people contemplating the concept of going vertical.

description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)  The Senate Majority Leader, Mike Mansfield, said today he hoped the Nixon Administration would reconsider the rejection of the Japanese textile industry's offer.

description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 7The new man in town, the Rev. Carl McIntire, has become this spacecenter village's most controversial figure in his first few weeks on the scene.

description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 12 (Reuters)President Yahya arrived here from Rawapindi today, presumably on his way to Dacca for talks with Sheik Mujib.

title: Artists at Work Subject of Finch Show
description: Artists, and the rambling roundabout ways in which they go about their business, are the subject of a quite entertaining new show at the Finch College Museum of Art (Contemporary Wing), 52 East 78th Street. Called Projected Art:sArtists at Work, it makes its presentations via movies, slides and videotapes, everything elicketyclacking away in various rooms, so you can drift in and out as you please.

description: CAIRO, March 12 (Reuters)Walter B. Emery, British Egyptologist, died in a hospital here today. He was 67 years old.

title: NEW CRISIS LOOMS FOR GERMAN COAL
description: BONN, March 12Two years after tenuous consolidation through merger, West Germany's coalmining industry is facing a new crisis, but this time it is poor management and not dwindling demand for coal that is causing the, problems.

description: Fordham's basketball team, attempting to emulate the New York success stories of the 1968 Jets and the 1969 Mets, will meet Furman in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tonight.

title: F.T.C. ACTS TO BAR RAZOR BLADE ADS

title: Supplies Picture or DataAid for Color TV Devised
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  When someone presents a credit card in charging purchase, a skeptical clerk can insert it in a sensor on his desk and have the rightful holder's picture displayed. The system, protected by Patent 3,569,619,granted this week, is the latest of the many inventions of Luther G. Sitnjian, president of General Research, Inc., Greenwich, Conn. The photographs can be kept in a microfilm file at a central office for transmission tb a receiver when the code or account number is sent in by an interested office or store. Mr. Simjian favors the use of closedcircuit television or Pioturephone.

title: Lockheed Aircraft Order
description: BURBANK, Calif., March 12 (UPI)The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has been advised that Belgium plans to buy 12 C130H Hercules Aircraft for an estimated total of $55million, the aerospace concern reported today. The Hercules, a cargotroop transport, has now been selected by 23 nations, Lockheed added.

title: Nixon Warns of Peril to U.S. in Domestic Demands of New Isolationists
description: NEWPORT, R. I., March 12 President Nixon today denounced new isolationists who favor cuts in the defense budget in order to spend more on domestic programs.

title: Sokolow Captures Final
description: Mel Sokolow of the Lone Star Boat Club defeated Roger Wales of the Downtown Athletic Club yesterday in the final, of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association limitedA division at the Yale Club. The scores were 1816, 1514, 15.8.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 (AP)The San Francisco Warriors moved to within one victory of clinching a playoff berth by defeating the Seattle Supersonics, 11195, tonight.

title: GORDON TO LEAVE JOHNS HOPKINS U.
description: BALTIMORE, March 12Dr. Lincoln Gordon, president of Johns Hopkins University since 1967, resigned today.

title: JAZZ CONCERT GETS A LIFT FROM BLUES

But despite the efforts of a quintet, a quartet and a 17piece band, that was how long it took Thursday night for a concert at Town Hall for the benefit of Phoenix House to lift itself from a sense of placidity that settled early and hung doggedly on.

title: European Skiers Are Leaders In World Student Alpine Trials
Returns to Florida
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 12 (AP)President Nixon arrived here this afternoon for the weekend. Mrs. Nixon, David Eisenhower, and his wife, Julid, were with the President.

title: 2 Girls Shot in Class

title: HEAD OF HEROIN RING DIES IN U.S. JAIL HERE
description: Luis Stepenberg, described by Federal autorities as one of the world's biggest heroin smugglers, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, government officials said yesterday.

title: Miners'Fears Recalled In Testimony of Widows
description: HAZARD Ky., March 12 Several widows testified today that their husbands had been afraid to go to work at the Finley Coal Company at Hurricane Creek near Hyden, Ky., in the days before the explosion that killed 38 miners on Dec. 30

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Rev. Andrew M. Greeley may be the director of the Center. for the Study of American Pluralism, but judging by his sweeping condemnation of the Berrigans, Catholic liberals and radicals, pluralism is unknown or unacceptable to him. [OpEd Feb. 19.]

title: Erpf, an Investment Banker, Left an Estate of $8Million
description: Armand Grover Erpf, a senior partner of Loeb, Rhoades & Co., an investment banking firm, and a supporter of publishing enterprises including New York magazine, left an estate valued at about $8million, according to a will filed in Surrogate Court here yesterday.

title: Harvard Threatens Eviction

Dean Archibald Cox, in an 11page letter to the women who took over the architectural technology workshop Saturday, urged them to obey a court order to leave. Between 40 to 80 women remain boarded in the building, scheduled to be torn down this summer.

title: RECEIVER NAMED FOR THE BEATLES;McCartney Victor in First Episode in Legal Contest
description: LONDON, March 12  Paul McCartney today won the first round in his battle to dissolve the Beatles partnership when a High Court judge appointed a public receiver to manage the group's assets.

title: The Mayor's Tax Package...
description: Mayor Lindsay callsthis tax prograrn a survival package, but the question, whether this plan to boost taxes by $880 million will Om the city or hasten its, decline.

title: Prime Rate Firm at 5%; Some Cut Savings Rates
description: A prime lending rate of 5 per cent was firmly established at major banks across the country yesterday. With the exception of three major institutions, those leading banks that had not already acted on Thursday fell into line yesterday by establishing minimum interest charges on business loans of 5 per cent, down from 5 per cent previously.

title: Executive Changes
description: Thomas J. Burns has been elected president and chief executive of the Dura Corporation, a division of Walter Kidde & Co., Inc.

title: In Marseilles Vote, Aim Is to Keep Communists Out
description: MARSEILLES France, March 11When you have a good mayor, you keep him, proclaims a poster in the streets of France's second largest city. Comiti will do better, another says.

title: CAN MAKERS AGREE ON TERMS IN STRIKE
description: PITTSBURGH, March 12 (UPI)The United Steelworkers of America announced today that a wage contract proposal had been negotiated with three major can manufacturers to settle a 26,day strike.

title: PENTAGON LISTS ECONOMIES FOR '71.
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Pentagon said today, that it would save $270million this year by closing four minor based, trimming others and eliminating 24,000 military and 2,500 civilian jobs.

title: Mitchell Is Studying Idea of Establishing A Limit on Appeals
description: MILLBURN, N. J., March 12 Attorney General John N. Mitchell said tonight that the Justice Department hoped to recommend ways to establish predictable time after which a convicted person's opportunities for appeal would have been exhausted.

title: British Eating Guide Stiffens Attitude
description: LONDON, March 12The Good Food Guide, a publication of Britain's Consumers Association, published a new edition today that dropped about 500 British restaurants from last rear's recommended list of 1,600.

title: Thomson &
description: TORONTO, March 12 (Canadian Press)  The New York brokerage firm of Thomson Sc McKinnon Auchincloss is to close its offices here and in Ottawa next month, it was announced today, because of restrictions on expanded foreign ownership of Canadian investment houses.

title: No Big Shift Expected in the Urban League
description: The philosophical thrust of the National Urban League toward an economically strong black community integrated into the general societywill not be radically changed by the death on Thursday of Whitney M. Young Jr., the organization's bestknown exectitive director.

title: Ribicoff Says Rep. Rivers Tried to Block Inquiry on Army PX's.
description: WASHINGTON, March 12Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff said today that the late Representative L. Mendel Rivers, who was chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, had tried to stop a Senate inquiry into alleged corruption in Army post exchanges.

title: Personnel Policies Of Subways Scored
description: A panel of experts has sharply criticized methods used by the Transit Authority to select promote train and discipline motormen and other subway personnel.

title: Pentagon Skeptical
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)  Pentagon officials said today it would have been impossible for the North Vietnamese to know about plans for the Laos invasion last October because planning did not begin until December.

title: Miss Carol Lees Is Affianced To Robert Royce Williams 3d
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 13Miss Carol Lees and Robert, Royce Williams 3d, both of New York, plan to be married here in May. Mr. and Mrs. H. Thomas Lees have announced the engagement of their daughter to the sdn of Mr. and. Mrs. Donald A. Williams of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich.

title: TONSILLECTOMIES
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Land cultivation of course, predates by many years industrial development throughout the United States. Industrial development, in turn, has given rise to mining and mineral extraction endeavors, which remain, along with land cultivation, major businesses in various regions of the country.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Constant readers of the stock tables will notice a change this week when the newspaper listings of price ranges for the year switch bom the highs and lows for 197071 to those for 1971 alone.

title: Man of Multiple Skills
description: At various (and frequently simultaneous) periods of his long life the protean Rockwell Kent was an architect, painter, illustrator, lithographer, xylographcr, cartoonist, advertising artist, carpenter, dairy farmer, explorer, trade union leader and political controversialist. He is so multiple a person as to be multifarious, Louis Untermeyer, the poet, once observed.

title: Lodge in Rome to See Pope
description: ROME, March 14Henry Cabot Lodge, President Nixon's special envoy to Pope Paul VI, arrived tonight for a threeweek stay. Mr. Lodge told newsmen he hoped to see the pontiff in his fourth audience since President Nixon appointed him as his representative last June. Mr. Lodge had his last audience with the Pope on Dec. 12.

title: Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn to Help New Immigrants Adjust to City
description: A diocesan migration office was established last week by the Most Rev. Francis J. Mugavero or Brooklyn to serve the growing numbers of new Roman Catholic immigrants settling in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: News of Dogs
description: The Saw Mill River Kennel Club, staging its 31st allbreed event at the Westchester County Center in White Plains today holds an unusual Place in the dog show world. It is said to be the only major fixture in the country in which there is neither group nor bestinshow judging. Several clubs in the past tried to conduct shows without benefit of a top award but when their entries declined they quickly reverted to the regular format.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.Despite official termination of the IsraeliEgyptian ceasefire and despite continuing nerve warfare and political argumentation, the United States seems persuaded that chances for Middle East peace are now better than at any time since 1967. Some officials think there can be actual peace; more believe a form of settlement can be arranged that lies between armistice and normal relationships.

title: Hanoi Gives Peking Aide Pot Made From U.S. Plane
description: TOKYO, March 13 (AP)The North Vietnamese gave a flower pot made from fragments of a downed United States plane to a Chinese Communist official who visited Hanoi with Premier Chou Enlai last weekend, Hanoi's official press agency reports.

title: Thant Names Argentine To High Political Post
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12Secretary General Thant announced today the appointment of an Argentine, Dr. Roberto E. Guyer, as Under Secretary General for Special Political Affairs, one of the highest positions in the United Nations Secretariat. He replaces Jose RolzBennet of Guatemala.

title: Fee Is Raised for Pass To City Tennis Courts
description: The price of season permits for most of the city's tennis courts has been raised from $10 to $15, the Parks Department announced last week.

title: Antigua's Tropical Stonehenge
description: ST. JOHN'S, Antigua, B. W. I. Having seen Nelson's Dockyard and the view from Shirley Heights, having heard the steel bands and indulged myself In snorkeling, sailing and dutyfree shopping, I sat over a beer in Darcy's Kensington House casting my eyes over a map of Antigua.

title: Fire in Clinic Near Paris Kills Two Newborn Babies
description: PONTOISE, France, March 13 (AP)Two newborn babies died tonight night in a fire that swept through the incubator room of a private clinic in the Paris suburb of Sarcelles.

title: Linowitz Asks Businessmen To Stress Social Problems
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The chairman of the National Urban Coalition, Sol M. Linowitz, has asked businessmen to become more deeply involved in urban and environmental problems.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Penn Takes East Swim Title, Ending EightYear Yale Reign
description: PHILADELPHIA, Pa., March 13The University of Pennsylvania captured the Eastern Seaboard Intercollegiate swinuning, championship for the first time in the 31 year history of the competition tonight.

title: Miss Howard Bride on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, March 13  Miss Deanne Lynn Howard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael James Howard Jr., was married here this morning to Herbert Simon Winokur Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Winokur of Philadelphia. The Rev. Ralph Carpenter performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church.

title: Ginseng, Seoul's Oldest Export
description: Americans and Europeans don't believe in Chinese medicine, which is based on herbs and other natural remedies, but actually Chinese medicine cures.

title: Computer to Save Millions In Film Editing Due Soon
description: A major technological advance in Hollywood's methods of producing films and tape,s for television and motion pictures is only weeks away with the commercial introduction of an electronic computerized system for editing visual material.

title: Kentucky St. Wins, 102.82, For 2d NA.I.A. Title in Row
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 13 (UPI)Travis Grant scored 43 points25 in the first halfas Kentucky State captured its second straight National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball championship tonight, defeating Eastern Michigan, 10282.

title: Broker's Tip II Triumphs in $ 52, 175 Canadian Turf Handicap at Gulfstream
MUSKIE MAILINGS STRESS WAR ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Senator Edmund S. Muskie, in a bid to strengthen his support among students and the liberal antiwar faction of the Democratic party, has undertaken a letter campaign to emphasize that he favors a fixed timetable for withdrawal of all United States troops from Vietnam.

title: Illinois Triumphs, 10387
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 13 (AP)  George McGinnis broke the Big 10 sophomore scoring record and became Indiana's alltime single season high scorer, but Illinois defeated the HooSiers, 10387.

title: ColdWeather Angling Out of Brooklyn Drops as Pollution Grows
description: As the Ranger IV gently bobbed at its pier at 3 o'clock on a cold morning, 40 sleepy men and a womanpart of the legion of New York's winter fishing buffsslowly climbed aboard, bright yellow and green oil cloth slickers under their arms, fishing goar in their hands.

title: The Story of a TeenAge Nader cider
description: BOTH of my grandfathers died before I was born.

title: cartwheeling into summer
description: Down to earththat's what children's clothes are this season. And they are all American in spirit with a strong Western and American Indian influence. There are overalls right off the farm, breezy cowboy shirts, shorts and knickers, and tough, knockabout denims for active kids on the go like Laura, left, who cartwheels into a happy summer in her denim overalls and striped cotton Tshirt. It's by Cinderella. Sizes 7 to 14 are $18 at Bonwit Teller. All photographs were taken in Albuquerque, New Mexico, and in Isleta pueblo, a nearby Indian village. Cover information Page 34

title: Cuba to Bid for Games
description: MEXICO CITY, March 13 (UPI)Cuba will make a bid to host the VIII Pan American Games to be celebrated in 1979, Manuel Gonzalez Guerra, the president of the Cuban Olympic Committee, said today.

title: HARVARD SIX TOPS CLARKSON IN FINAL
Coins
description: MOST Americans engage In their daily financial transactions without showing any particular interest in the designs on the paper money they are handling. After all, it's the denomination printed on this folding moneyand the desire to have enough of it to go aroundthat is important.

title: South Africa Drops Case Against Bishop of Zululand
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 13 (AP)Authorities have decided not to prosecute the Anglican bishop of Zululand on charges of breaking the racial segregation law.

title: GUARD IS WIDENING ITS DEFENSE ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The National Guard, which is receiving the latest weapons and aircraft, is assuming a greater role in national defense.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: SCULPTURE PRICES FALL AT AUCTION
description: Sculpture at auction, which, along with fine prints and Americana, had best withstood the effects of the recession on the fine arts, succumbed to the general economic malaise Thursday evening in a sale at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

title: FEDERAL BUILDING GIVEN TO COLLEGE
description: A 12story building on West 44th Street that once housed the Yale Club has been deemed surplus property by the United States Government and donated to Touro College, a new nonsectarian liberal arts college that will stress the Jewish heritage, western humanities and the sciences in its curriculum.

title: PARTY WYN FIRST IN OPEN JUMPING
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y., March 13 Jenny Donald's Party Wyn captured all three classes today to win the open jumper championship at the Bennett College Horse Show.

title: A Colossus Catastrophe, But...
description: EXTRAORDINARY, that's the word for the Fiesta of St. Joseph in Valencia, Spain, being held this week, and for the fallas, wood and papiermch figures or tableaux that decorate the city's streets. Last year there were 210 falias, made by local artists and carpenters. This is the story of one of themthe most extraordinary: a 100foothigh Colossus, for the main square.

title: Movies
description: G ET CARTER is the kind of movie you hate to love and hate to hate. Its violence is so ghastly and unremitting and its view of the human condition is so perfectly vile that one would almost rather wash one's mouth out with soap than recommend it. Yet it is so finely acted and craftedand is so spectacularly better than the run of its genrethat as a lover of movies one feels practically diitybound to sing its praises.

title: MEAT IMPORTS IN '71 SET NEAR '70 TOTAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin said today that 1971 meat imports would be limited to 1.16 billion pounds, about the same level as 1970 imports.

title: FourLegged Joe Frazier Defeated by 12to1 Shot
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 13 (AP)Rio Bravo won the $75,000 New Orleans Handicap today running the mile and an eighth in 1:48 4/5 to equal the Fair Grounds track record.

title: Dance: A Ballet in the Fun. Category
description: There are funny ballets and fun ballets, and the two are not necessarily the same. George Balanchine's Square Dance, which the City Center Joffrey Ballet restaged at the City Center on Friday night, falls into the fun category. It is as light and fluffy as a masteromelette, as blithe as a spring dawn.

title: U.S. Refuses to Comment On Mrs. Meir's Position
description: WASHINGTON, March 13United States officials declined to comment officially today on Israel's latest negotiating pbsition as outlined in an interview, published in The New York Times today, with the Premier, Golda Meir.

title: Residents of Hamptons Petition For Fewer X and R Films
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., March 13More than onethird of the residents of this village and its environs have petitioned the area's leading theater chain to show more family motion pictures and fewer films rated X and R.

title: PAS DE NOM WINS SPRINT AT BOWIE
U.S. Aide in Berlin to Retire
description: BERLIN, March 13 (AP) Brewster H. Morris, the American Minister in West Berlin since 1967, is retiring in April, United States Headquarters has announced. He will be succeeded by his assistant, David Klein of New York.

title: COURT REFORM SET IN TWO BOROUGHS
description: The Criminal Courts in Queens and the Bronx will soon begin night and weekend sessions and institute a system of centralized booking of suspects to end the timeconsuming transfers of prisoners between boroughs and precincts.

title: Neurologist Wins Prize
description: BALTIMORE, March 13Dr. Stephen W. Kuffler, a Harvard Medical School neurologist, has been awarded the $7,500 Passano Foundation prize. Dr. Kuffler was recognized for his research on a better understanding of how information is transmitted from one cell to another, how it is analyzed in the nervous system, and how miracle movement is controlled and executed.

title: ALBANY MAY TAP RAINY DAY FUND
description: ALBANY, March 13For the first time in 20 years, the state may have to use money in the tax stabilization reserve fund, its rainy day account, to avoid a deficit during the fiscal year ending March 31.

title: Charles Lewis Scott 2d Plans To Marry Miss Judith A. Stultz
description: Miss Judith Anne Stultz and Charles Lewis Scott 2d, Seniors at Lake Forest College, will be married June 13 in Christ Episcopal Church in Winnetka,

title: Education
description: In the tradition of The Perils of Pauline, New York City's school system was about to be chased into the cold night, with thousands of teachers laid off as the money changers foreclosed on a $40million deficit. Last week, in the nick of time, the heroin this case Controller Abraham D. Eeamerushed to the rescue, telling the budget men that he had been able to borrow enough of the money to bail out the system.

title: The World
description: NEW DELHIA new wordIndirajaal, a takeoff on indrajaal, the Hindu word for magicwas coined yesterday by the stunned leaders of the conservative fourparty front that opposed, and was crushed by, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and her victorious New Congress party.

title: RICHARD KAPUSCINSKI GIVES CELLO RECITAL
description: Richard Kapuscinski, a professor of cello at Oberlin, covered a sizable amount of stylistic ground Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Whether the composer was Bach or Davidovsky, the cellist proved to be a reliable technician and, as an interpreter, something of an intellectualist.

title: Vote on Splitting Suffolk County. Gets Backing of Duryea Despite Possible Effect on His Power
description: ALBANY, March 13  Two constitutional amendments of vital importance to Suffolk County and to its leading Republican, Assembly Speaker Patty Buryea of Montauk, are scheduled for votes.at the overeat session of the Legislature.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Contemplation in a World of Action
description: The sixties were a time when American youth engaged this society in a moral confrontation and challenged it to make the rhetoric of peace and democracy a reality in each of its citizens, America responded to the challenge with flags on its police cars. While some youth reacted to this by trying to make a moral virtue out of violent revolution, others withdrew from the picket lines and mass demonstrations to establish communes, where they could concentrate on creating the new society within the context of their own lives.

title: Capitol Guards Tighten Security to Prevent Another Bombing
description: Washington, March 13 Richard Helms, the Director of Central Intelligence, was stopped and searched Thursday morning as he arrived at the Capitol for a closed briefing with key Congressmen.

title: Stamps
description: ERNEST RUTHERFORD Baron Rutherford of Nelson, New Zealandphysicist, teacher (at McGill in Canada, Manchester and Cambridge in England) and recipient of the Nobel Prize in 1908, will be the subject of a commemorative stamp from Canada on March 24.

title: National Health Insurance Is Expected in 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The legislative rush toward National Health Insurance is on and even leaders of the Amer. ican Medical Association, for decades arch foes of federally directed medical coverage, overwhelmingly believe that some form will be enacted within three years.

title: Copper Pacemaker
description: About the middle of last year, a long stretch of almost unclouded prosperity ended for the primarycopper industry. After nearly a decade of piling record upon record in prices for the metal and profits for the producers when the major problem seemed to be excessive demand  the companies have recently been jolted by a series of setbacks.

title: U. of Nebraska President Resigns for Investment Job
description: LINCOLN, Neb., March 13Dr. Joseph Soshnik, president of the University of Nebraska's Lincoln campuses and outstate activities, announced today that he was resigning his $35,000ayear post.

title: Their Blood, Our Sweat And Tears
description: THE audience has got to have more rehearsal time. It is being asked to do so many things these days, and under such breathtaking circumstances, that in all fairness it must be given some opportunity to limber up, memorize its moves, get in fighting trim. It may also have a little money coming, if it can only unionize.

title: Tarville to Be Captain Of U.S. Cup Team Again
description: Edward A. Turville of St. Petersburg, Fla. has been reappointed captain of the United States Davis Cup team for this year, it was announced yesterday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Puerto Rico Is Concerned About Image
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., March 13 In the wake of student rioting this week, the Government of Puerto Rico finds itself today very much concerned with its image abroad, particularly in the United States.

title: What Is a Garden?
description: A GARDEN is a place, outdoors, where man can come to realize that he is, after all, human, that he is capable of dignified and intelligent action and that he is something more than a biological creature. It is time, in America, that we ought to recognize human values when we talk of environment and not just the physical and the biological ones.

title: LEHMAN EXPANDS AN EXPERIMENT
description: An experimental curriculum that began at Lehman College in the Bronx with 100 selected freshmen in September,, 1969 has proven so successful that it has been expanded to a total of 255 students. The curriculum, under which the student is not subject to any course requirements, is designed to encourage independent research and the initiation of courses by the studrnts themselves.

title: Phillip Kelley Marries Alison Laird in Virginia
description: WARRENTON, Va., March 13Miss Alison Laird, only daughter of Melvin R. Laird, Secretary of Defense, and Mrs. Laird of Washington was married at a private estate in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains this afternoon to Phillip Gregory Kelley, a law student at the University of Tennessee. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Kelley of Kingsport, Tenn.

title: A Better Pipeline?
description: For the first time since oil was struck at Prudhoe Bay, it begins to be doubtful that it will ever be sent to refineries by way of an environmentally dangerous pipeline across the state of Alaska. In the past few weeks both Secretary of the Interior Morton and Russell Train, chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality, have issued strongly worded reservations. Then came a severe criticism, surprisingly, from the Department of Defense; it reflected the grave doubts of the Army Corps of Engineers and offered not the slightest support to the Interior Department's claim that the pipeline was urgently needed for security reasons.

title: The Nation
description: After The Fight of the Century was over, former heavyweight champion Muhammud All tried to duck out from under the unanimous verdict against him. News don't last too long, the puffjawed All assured his auditors the morning. after. Plane crash, 90 people die. Presidents get assassinated, civil rights leaders assassinated.... World go on, you got children to feed and bills to pay, got other things to worry about. You all be writing something else soon.

title: Quake in the Pacific
description: PALMER. Alaska, March 13 (AP)  A strong earthquake measuring 6.0 on the Richter scale ocurred Friday in the Pacific Ocean 100 miles west of Vancouver Island, B. C., the National Oceans Observatory here reported.

title: Mailbox :
description: To the EDITOR:

title: A U.S. SATELLITE FIRED INTO ORBIT
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 13 (AP)Explorer 43, a scientific satellite, was rocketed into orbit today to help man fern more about the solar system.

title: Brooklyn College Course on Black English Designed to Help Students Learn Standard English
description: In a Brooklyn College freshroan English grammar course the following sentences are considered correct.

title: Reader's Report
description: Gus Gilpin and his banjo (submachine gun) are to bootleggers what Paul Bunyan and his big blue ox are to lumberjacks. Heroic. Superhuman. Pure in heart. Unique as a three dollar bill. Out of the reality of rural poverty that spawned the gangsters of the Prohibition eraDillinger, Karpis, Barrow, Floyd, etc.Mr. Curtis has hatched a fabulous folk tale.

title: Religion
description: Several months ago, a group of Roman Catholics wearing red berets was arrested on charges of breaking into a hospital clinic in Washington, D. C., to protest the performing of abortions. Contrary to what might be assumed from their style, the demonstrators were not from the militant Catholic left, but quite the opposite. Backed by an organization known as the Sons of Thunder, they spoke for new, if still relatively small, force in American Catholicismthe militant right.

title: Putting Brakes on Buying Abroad
description: THE last thing my husband said as we disembarked from the plane in Italy was, No buying and schlepping stuff all over on this trip. Remember what a nuisance it was In Portugal last year. And it took two men to help carry our purchases onto the plane for home. We'll limit ourselves just a few soft, packable things, right?

title: Bay State Transit Agency Hit by Revolt
description: BOSTON, March 13Nearly every night this winter some 780 buses owned by the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority have been sitting empty outside car barns, their engines idling and consuming more than $200,000 worth of fuel.

title: Gilligan Seeks Drug Funds
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 13 (UPI)  Gov. John J. Gilligan says he will ask the General Assembly to nearly triple the amount the state is spending to fight drug abuse. The Governor, a Democrat, said this week that his budget calls for $36.5million to be devoted to drug programs during the next biennium, compared to $13.9million for fiscal 197071.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Brookhaven Is Hoping to Make Airport Center of Development
description: BROOKHAVEN, L. I., March 13The Town of Brookhaven hopes to improve and expand the township's airport and develop its vicinity into what the Town Industrial Commissioner described as a center of industrial and residential Long Island.

title: Eisenhower Trustee Named
description: SENECA FALLS, N. Y., March 13Mrs. Arnold Schwartz, the former Marie Smith, an author and reporter covering the White House for many years for The Washir.gton Post, has been named a trustee of Eisenhower College, it was announced today. The college is a private, coeducational, independent liberal arts institution that was established in 1969.

title: New York Presbytery Picks Ombudsman
description: The Presbytery of New York City, governing body for 115 Presbyterian churches in the five boroughs, this week named David Gilman, a 32yearold lawyer, its advocate attorney or ombudsman.

title: Nuclear Power and the Public
description: By the year 1980, 150,000,000 kilowatts of electricity will be generated by nuclear reactors in the United States. This astonishing triumph of nuclear energy comes just as we have become sensitive to the environmental side effects of technology. As a consequence, nuclear power is caught in noisy controversy: the proponents of nuclear energy claim it is clean, safe, and necessary; its opponents claim it is unclean, unsafe and unnecessary. The immediate results of the controversy are long delays in the commissioning of nuclear power plants and frustrating shortages of power.

title: SYRIAN VOTERS BACK ASSAD AS PRESIDENT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 13 Lieut. Gen. Hafez alAssad was today proclaimed the President of Syria after having received overwhelming approval from voters in yesterday's referendum.

title: U.S. Sextet Beaten
description: PRAGUE, March 13 (AP)Czechoslovakia scored four goals in the second period today and went on to a 60 victory over the United States National ice hockey team. Both teams are preparing for the world championship competition, which starts Friday.

title: 5 ProLindsay Lawmakers Join A Protest of His Housing Policy
description: Five Democratic and Liberal legislators who supported Mayor Lindsay for reelection in 1969 joined 100 demonstrators outside Gracie Mansion yesterday afternoon to protest the Mayor's housing policies.

title: Segregationist Bid to Oust Rusk From Faculty Fails
description: ATLANTA, March 13 (UPI)A segregation spokesman fell short Wednesday in an attempt to remove former Secretary of State Dean Rusk from the University of Georgia faculty.

title: Cyclist to Fight Cancer
description: GREENFIELD, Mass., March 13 (AP)Judson Hindes of South Weymouth, an 18yearold prep school senior, bicycled off through a light snow flurry today on the first leg of a 5,400mile trip to the Grand Canyon to raise funds for the American Cancer Society. He carried with him pledge card's and American Cancer Society leaflets with which he hopes to raise $1p,000 for the organization.

title: Cockerill Regains Dyer Dhow Title in Dinghy Regatta
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., March 13Robert V. Cockerill of the host Mamaroneck Frostbite Association Fleet, the 1969 winner, regained the Dyer dhow championship of Long Island Sound today in the fourth annual event.

title: Architecture
description: THIS week, in our continuing discussion zoning, we are dealing with castles in the air. That sounds a lot more romantic than air rights construction. But it is literally true: we build on air in our cities today, because the zoning laws that control construction say that we can a certain volume of building on a certain site, and if less is built, what is left over are unused air rights.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Television
description: Vox popull in radio No idea could be more attractive. The people own the airwaves, and listeners of all persuasions want a chance to sound off beyond the walls of their own homes. What more suitable instrument than access by telephone to the broadcasting facilities of a radio outlet?

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: V.F.W. Contest Winner
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)The Voice of Democracy speech contest sponsored andually by the Veterans of Foreign Wars was won this year by Marcus B. Robertson of Gadsden, Ala. The runnerup was David H. Ahrendts of Kearney, Neb, The winner receives a $10,000 college scholarship and a $5,000 scholarship goes with the second prize. The competition was completed Tuesday.

title: Taiwan Defector in Peking
description: HONG KONG, March 14 (Reuters)A Chinese Nationalist diplomat who disappearedi from a Geneva hotel early this month arrived in Peking yesterday. Hsinhua, the Chinese; news agency, said that Sun, Chichou, third secretary of Taiwan's Embassy in Senegal,; arrived by air after crossing; over to the motherland on March 5 in Geneva on his way from Dakar to Saigon. His wife, son and daughter were reported with him.

title: Movies
description: IN HER very first movie Marcia Rodd gets robbed, pounced on by punks in the park, menaced by a heavybreathing pervert on the telephone, and married to a nearcatatonic in a ceremony presided over by a hippie minister who joyously proclaims her father a fraud and her brother a fag. To top it all Off, she is shot, dead by a sniper.

title: City Water Found Occaiionally Tainted by Chemical Used in Recirculating Systems of AirConditioners
description: Officials are becoming concerned about chemicals used in recirculating systems for airconditioners occasionally contaminating parts of the city's water supply.

title: Farm Real Estate Taxes In U.S Rose 11% In 1969
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)The tightening money pinch, felt by local and state governments has produced, a sharp new drain on farm come through rising real estate taxes, an Agriculture Department report indicates.

title: Swiss 31 Hockey Victor
description: BERN, Switzerland, March 13 (AP)Switzerland defeated favored East Germany, 31, tonight to virtually assure itself the world ice hockey B championship.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Takes Over the Guggenheim Castle
description: Special to The New York Times SANDS POINT, L. I., March 12Nassau County has taken over from the Federal Government a 128acre portion of the estate of the late Daniel Guggenheim, father of Harry F. Guggenheim, the late publisher.

title: HE HITS JACKPOT AND MISSES TAX
description: ROME, March 13Italy where the sly art of tax evasion is becoming increasingly disreputable and perilous, has a new champion of tax dodging.

title: ITALIAN ON A VISIT IS MURDERED HERE
description: One of three women who accosted an Italian businessman in midtown Manhattan early yesterday morning stabbed him fatally during an argument.

title: SAIGON'S FORCES SAID TO ESTABLISH NEW BATTLE BASES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, March 14South Vietnamese troops have moved into five or six new combat bases on a mountain ridge southeast of Tchepone, the junction area 25 miles inside Laos from which they withdrew Friday, high American officials said yesterday.

title: H.E.W. SECRETARY ENDS TOUR OF CITY
description: Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, completed a twoday Presidential listening trip to New York City, yesterday and concluded that everywhere he went there was a juxtaposition of human tragedy and human hope.

title: U.S. Bars ItalianMade Drug Whose Patent Is Held by Lilly
description: MIAMI, March 13A Federal judge here has issued a preliminary injunction prohibiting sales in the United States of an Italianmade drug already manufactured by an American company under a provisional United States patent.

title: Pharmacist Is Sentenced For Drugging of Women
description: Carroll James Lombardi, a former Manhattan pharmacist convicted of using barbiturates to drug young women so he could make sexual advances, was sentenced last week by Supreme Court Justice Harold Baer to five to 12 years in prison.

title: Hope for Stroke Victims
description: A new aura of hope for stroke victims was evidenced earlier this month at the second annual stroke conference held in Jacksonville under the sponsorship of the Florida Regional Medicine Program.

title: Mideast Tensions Find an Echo at American University in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Of all our graduates who went Into politics, I'd say about half are now in governments around the Arab world and the other half are In jail  and both groups are dreading or anticipating the days when they will change places.

title: Option on Social Security Is Proposed by Thurmond
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)  Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, has introduced a bill to allow people who continue working after they are 65 years old the option of paying no further Social Security taxes.

title: Kidnapped Boy, 2, Returned to Father
description: SAN DIEGO, March 13A 2yearold boy with dark, solemn eyes was returned to a father he no longer remembered following the arrest by F.B.I. agents this week of a couple accused of kidnapping him in Mexico seven months ago.

title: About Pro Football
description: Northwestern, which needs the money, is appealing the Big Ten's deoision forbidding the university to take in the Chicago Bears as paying guests next season. Athletic directors and faculty advisers voted 128 to ban the Westem Conference members from leasing their stadiums to pro teams on a seasonal basis. Northwestern, the only private university in the Big Ten, stood to gain $2.2million in rent over five years from the Bears, who planned to move from Wrigley Field to Dyche Stadium in Evanston. Northwestern will ask the conference to reconsider its vote.

title: Value of Homes Increased By 43% Over Last Decade
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)The Census Bureau says that the median value of owneroccupied homes increased by 43 per cent over the last decade while median monthly rents rose 55 per cent.

title: Basketball Star Killed
description: GRAMBLING, La., March 13 (UPI)Charles Anderson, the captainelect of next year's Grambling College basketball team, was killed in a hitandrun accident last night. Mr. Anderson, 20 years old, of New Orleans, was a junior. He was 6 feet 6 inches tall and led the Southewestern Athletic Conference in rebounding last season with an average of 17.8 a gams He was Grambling's second leading scorer with an average 18.3 points a game.

title: ANTISEMITISM AND ANTIZIONISM
description: To THE EDITOR:

description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Dean of Admissions At Penn Quits Job In a Policy Dispute
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 13Dr. George A. Schlekat, Dean of Admissions and Financial Aid at the University of Pennsylvania, has resigned here in a dispute over policy involving his office.

title: INTEREST FADING IN MANSON TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, March 13Once they stood in line for seats, but all that has changed now and in the late afternoon the noisy old courtroom on the eighth floor of the Hall of Justice is nearly empty.

title: Miss Betsy Kimmelman to Be Married on April 3
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton A. Kimmelman of New York and Quogue, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsy Kimmelman, to George T. Frampton Jr., son of Professor Frampton, vice chancellor of the University of Illinois, where he is also a professor of law, and Mrs. Frampton, of Urbana, Ill.

title: Judge Rules for Inmates
description: BOSTON, March 13 (AP)Federal District Judge Andrew A. Caffrey has issued an injunction directing Massachusetts prison officials not to interfere with mail from inmates to lawyers, courts or public officials. Ruling on a complaint by Benjamin Tyree, a Concord Reformatory inmate, he directed prison officials not to delete or excise material from, withhold or refuse to mail, letters from inmates to courts, attorneys or public officials.

title: Power for the PeopleWhere It's At
description: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md.To the untrained eye, the setting seems peaceful enough. At the edge of a wide stretch of the Susquehanna River near here sits a square, factorylike building topped by what resembles a large water tower. A single chimney rises over the complex. No sound or sign of activity provides the slightest hint as to what takes place inside.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation
description: An article in this section March 7, signed by Philip M. Stern, discussed the issue of corporate responsibility including the role of critics of corporation policies on such subjects as air and water pollution. Among the critics mentioned was an organization called Campaign G.M. General Motors has criticized The Week in Review's failure to identify Mr. Stern as a trustee of a family foundation that provided financial support for Campaign G.M. Mr. Stern, author of books on tax loopholes and the J. Robert Oppenheimer case, is currently under contract to research and write a book on the subject of corporate responsibility. Mr. Stern said, In my opinion the article itself is evidence that my association with the foundation does not prevent me from being a fair observer of the corporate responsibility issue.

title: Books:
description: PERIL ON THE JOB. By Ray Davidson. Public Affairs Press. 198 pages. $6.

title: John E. Basinski Weds Miss Biddle
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 13 Miss Alexandra Biddle, daughter of Mrs. Constance Biddle of Newtown Square and Sydney Francis Biddle of Hoboken, N. J., was married here this afternoon to John Edward Basinski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Basinski of Tonawanda, N. Y.

title: Jury Will Consider Indictments for 57 In Fight Fatal to S
description: CLEVELAND, March 13The Cuyahoga County grand jury will meet Monday to hear evidence and consider indictments against 57 persons charged with the murders of five persons in a battle between two motorcycle gangs here last Saturday night.

title: FISCAL METHODS OF SCHOOL BOARD FOOD CHAOTIC
description: A State Senate committee investigating the Board of Education's $36.2million deficit asserted yesterday that the city school system's accounting procedures were antiquated, chaotic, based on guesstimates and drastically in need of revision.

title: Each grotesque is rendered with loving accuracy
description: Thomas McGuane has now written two novels, each uncommonly arresting if flawed. Similar in theme, they are most dissimilar in setting and mood. They share, however, one overriding characteristic: they are the work of a writer of the first magnitude.

title: Polaris Sleds Dominate
description: OSWEGO, N. Y., March 13 (AP)Winning 11 races, Polaris sleds dominated today's qualifying heats for the $21,000 Schaefer Oswego Snowmobile championships set for tomorrow. Arctic Cat sleds triumphed in six other heats, while Rupp and Skidoo snowmobiles took one heat apiece.

title: MILITARY DECREE ASSAILED IN DACCA
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Sunday, Pakistan, Sunday, March 14Sheik Mujibur Rahman, head of the Awami League that is leading East Pakistan's movement for selfrule, today protested a new order issued last night by, the martiallaw authorities here threatening prison terms for civilian employes of defense installations who do not report for work tomorrow.

title: The Nation
description: FORT BENNING, Ga.  There was a hush, almost a sense of disbelief in the small courtroom here at 10:55 last Thursday morning. After 45 days of testimony spread over nearly four months, after 104 witnesses and countless depositions and exhibits in one of the longest trials in American military annals, the last witness had left the stand.

title: Books:
description: THE CHALLENGE TO U.S. DOMINANCE OF THE INTERNATIONAL CORPORATION. By Rainer Hellmann. Dunellen Publishing Company. 348 pages. $17.50.

title: CAROLINA HAILED ON RIOT JAILINGS
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., March 13 Gov. John C. West has hailed the sentencing of three white men for the assault on school buses carrying black children at Lamar last year.

title: McCarthy Says 3d Party Could Be Important in 1972
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 13 (UPI)Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota, believes a thirdparty candidate could perIform a service to the American people and play an important role in the 1972 Presidential election.

title: Et A1.
description: Memoir by a Polish girl of her flight and exile from Russian and German persecutors. The portion about life in a Siberian labor camp is graphic; but, on the whole, the Reader's Digest prose is numbing.

title: City Pension Systems Earn Highest Percentages Ever
description: The yield from investments of the city's pension systems rose last year to 4.6 per cent, the highest return in history, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: Kenyan Seeks Help for Bush Airline
description: Shadrack Ole Sainopu summed up the opinions of the two tribal branches of his family. The Somalis think they have got a great son. The Masai think they have a genius son.

title: Lee Chamberlain to Be Bride Of William Cleveland Kuhn 2d
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 13The engagemCnt of Miss Lee Chamberlain to William Cleveland Kuhn 2d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Chamberlain, parents of the prospective bride, Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Kuhn of Costa Mesa, Calif. formerly of Denver.

title: Marcia Tracey Engaged
description: DALLAS, March 13 Mr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Tracey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marcia Beth Tracey, to Steven Irwin Frank, son of Josept Frank of Houston and the late Mrs. Frank. Miss Tracey and her fiance, graduates of the University of Texas, plan to be married on Aug. 22. The bridetobe is studying for a master's degree at the university. Mr. Frank is a graduate student at Columbia University.

title: Rutgers Will Institute Strict Economy Measures
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 13The Rutgers University Board of Governors voted yesterday to institute a job freeze, a ban on outofstate travel expenses for staff, a ban on all building renovations, and a holdback of all new programs, program improvements and promotions.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The United States Government is trying to avoid aw open break with Israel over peace terms in the Middle East, but a break is surely coming unless the Israeli Government modifies, its territorial demands and its diplomatic tactics.

title: Soviet Lifter Sets Mark
description: MOSCOW, March 13 (Reuters)  David Richert, a 24yearold Soviet weight lifter, set a world record for the total lift in the middle heavyweight class with 542.5 kilos (1,196 pounds) at a competition in RostovonDon today. He pressed 182.5 kilos (402 pounds), snatched 160 kilos (352 pounds) and jerked 200 kilos (441 pounds).

title: A Castle in France For the Price of A Beach Cottage
description: OUR summer house was a model of Provencal elegance. Situated in the tiny town of Venasque, some 20 miles northeast of Avignon, it was originally part of a 15thcentury monastery and had been impeccably restored in the early nineteensixties. Done entirely in stone, great dark beams, ruddy tiles and vaulted ceilings, it perched on the edge of a 1,000foot limestone cliff that offered us a commanding view of the Vaucluse Valley with its neat rows of cherry trees and sunsoaked apricot orchards, its scrambling vineyards, sharp cliffs and sweep of purple mountains. At sunset, we would sip aperitifs and watch the sun leave the valley. And, if the mosquitoes were at bay; we would stay on to watch lightning dance on Mount Ventoux, at 6,000 feet the tallest mountain entirely in France.

title: Chicano March is Quiet In a Tense Texas Town
description: SAN JUAN, Texas, March 9 Last Sunday was an almost perfect spring day along the Rio Grande, the meandering river that marks the border between Texas and the Republic of Mexico. The north wind still had a tinge of winter in it but in the sunshine it was almost hot.

title: S.CAROLINA EDGES TAR HEELS, 5251
description: GREENSBORO, N. C. March 13 (UPI)Tom Owens scored a layup in the final two seconds as South Carolina defeated North Carolina, 5251, to win the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball championship tonight.

title: R. M. Smith Fiance Of Suzanne Harris
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 Miss Suzanne Harris, an assistant news editor of the Style section of The Washington Post, and Robert M. Smith, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, plan to be married in Alexandria, Va., in May.

title: Horse Show News
description: Dr. Jordan Woodcock, a veterinarian from Katonah, N. Y., whose family equine interests go back to the gaslight era in England, has been appointed administrator of the American Horse Shows Association's new drugprevention program. Dr. Woodcock has been a lifelong horseman. His father, who came to the United States in 1913, his grandfather and his greatgrandfather were active in horse circles in England. His greatgrandfather was one of the country's leading trainers.

title: Medicine
description: The rate of illegitimate births in the United States has nearly doubled during the last decade, but the causes of this phenomenon remain elusive.

title: 35 WOMEN PICKET GRIDIRON DINNER
description: WASHINGTON, March 13About 35 members of the Journalists for Professional Equality picketed the main entrance to the Statler Hilton Hotel here tonight as members of the Gridiron Club and their guests arrived for the club's 86th annual dinner.

title: Education
description: Five years ago the coeducation movement in college began attracting attention with hints of a marriage between Yale and Vassar. The engagement was subseqtrently broken, but both colleges have since gone coeducational on their own. Within that period, women's colleges have declined from about 250 (out of more than 2,000 colleges and universities) to 150, the majority of them Roman Catholic. Some men's colleges followed suit.

title: Miss Morse To Be Bride
description: WILMETTE, Ill., March 13 Miss Margaret Levis Morse of Cambridge, Mass., who teaches the second grade at the Chestnut Hill (Mass.) School, plans to be married May 15 in Winnetka to Lawrence Howe Delafield, who works for the Boston architectural firm of Anderson, Beckwith & Haible.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Is Closer To TwoThirds Margin
description: NEW DELHI, March 13 (UPI)  Prime Minister Indira Gandhi gained today in her drive toward a twothird majority in the new Indian Parliament.

description: LONDON.

title: Miss Cornbrooks to filed in Fall
description: BALTIMORE, March 13The engagement of Miss Elaine Adel Cornbrooks to C. Henry Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith Jr has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Ivon Cornbrooks Jr.

title: BoatRace Dinner March 26
description: The OxfordCambridge annual boatrace dinner will be held on March 26 at the Harvard Club. The dinner chairman is Alan L. Bain, Suite 1001, 445 Park Avenue, New York, N. Y. 10022, telephone 4861333.

title: National Notes
description: People who say they don't have a problem are usually the ones who haven't looked, said the personnel director of an automobile company. His response was typical of many received in a nationwide inquiry into the degree of drug use in American industry. The overall conclusion: drugs, hard and soft, are soon expected to surpass alcoholism as a problem.
