description: WASHINGTON, March 16 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that reports of large oil deposits off the shore of South Vietnam have absolutely no effect on United States policy.

title: Hippie Girl's Father Wins Support Case
description: By a fourtoone decision, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court reversed yesterday a Family Court order that a father had to support his daughter's hippie way of life, which he frowned on, and pay for her college tuition.

title: Training Council Post Filled
description: ALBANY, March 16 (AP)  Edward A. Bjork, a New York City labor leader, was appoint ed by Governor Rockefeller to the State Apprenticeship and Training Council today. The council advises, the State In dustrial Commissioner on job training programs. Members are paid $71 a day for attend ing meetings. Mr. Bjork is pres ident of the State Council of Carpenter, A.F.L.C.I.O. He was designated for a council term ending Dec. 2, 1972.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Merger News
description: The Beatrice Foods Company announced yesterday an agree ment to acquire Peter Eckrich & Sons, Inc., in an exchange of stock valued at about $63mil lion.

title: Fox Film Deficit Widens;
description: The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, which is threatened with an impending proxy battle for control, last year lost $77,355,000, or triple the $25,249,000 deficit incurred in 1969, according to the com pany's report issued yesterday.

title: FREDERIC BROWN, RETIRED GENERAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 Lieut. Gen. Frederic J. Brown, artillery commander of the Third Armored Division in its World War II drive from Nor mandy to the Elbe River, died Saturday in Walter Reed Army Hospital. He Was 65 years old and had lived since his retire ment in 1967 in McLean, Va.

title: Kennedy Proposes U.S. Loans To Aid Scientists Seeking Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 Provision of longterm guaran teed loans for unemployed engi neers, scientists and technicians was proposed today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy to help ease their conversion from aero space and defense work to civilian projects.

title: Hawks Down Canucks, 74
description: VANCOUVER, March 16 (UPI) Bobby Hull scored once and Set up four other goals tonight to power the Chicago Black Hawks to a 74 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Chile Buys Bank Shares
description: SANTIAGO, March 16 (Reu ters)The Chilean Government said today that it had bought 16 per cent of the shares of the Banco de Chile, the country's largest private bank.

title: Navy Suit Accuses Standard Oil
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 After more than three years of unpublicized legal effort, the United States and Standard Oil of California are scheduled to meet in court next Monday in what Congressional oil experts say is a Government effort to protect the vast Navy oil re serve at Elk Hills, Calif.

title: Bronx FishStore Operator Is Found Shot Dead in Car
description: A 42yearold operator of a Bronx fish store was found shot dead in his car early yesterday near the Fulton Fish Market, the police reported.

title: Sweden Submits Plan
description: GENEVA, March 16 (Reuters) Sweden today presented to the Geneva disarmament con ference a working paper under which agents for chemical and biological weapons would be graded according to their dead liness.

title: U. S. and Soviet Restate Views In Vienna on Arms Limitation
description: VIENNA, March 16  The United States and the Soviet Union restated their positions on the limitation of strategic nuclear arms today as they held the first working session of the newly begun fourth round of their talks.

title: Body Flown to Kentucky
description: LOUISVILLE, March 16The plane carrying Mr. Young's body and the funeral party ar rived here this afternoon.

title: NIXON SHIFT SEEN ON CAMPAIGN BILL
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 The Republican national chair man said today that President Nixon would approve the cam paign spending legislation that Congress sends him this year.

title: Alcindor Gets 48 Points
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 16 Lew Alcindor poured in a Coli seum record of 48 points to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 119111 victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight.

title: Botany Also Reports Loss
description: Botany Industries, Inc., a major manufacturer and re tailer of men's apparel, re ported a deficit yesterday for the first half of the fiscal year ending July 31 and predicted that the full year would also show a loss.

title: Private Health Insurance Plans Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 Leaders of the health insur ance business told Congress to day that the best means of fi nancing national medical care was through private industry. However, New York City unions complained that their members Were being short changed and urged Federal coverage.

title: SOVIET SAID TO LET MORE JEWS LEAVE
description: MOSCOW, March 16  Reli able Western sources today re ported a significant increase in the number of Soviet Jews who have received exit permits and left the country for Israel in the last two weeks. They said that according to authoritative sta tistics, close to 15 Jews on the average were emigrating daily.

title: RECITAL OF SONGS BY ELLY AMELING
description: There's many a voice that floats through the air more ex travagantly than Elly Amel ing's, heard in recital Monday night at Tully Hall.

title: Couple in the News
description: She has been called the mystery princess of the White House, a reallive but waxen Debbie Reynolds doll, all wrapped up in white lace with pastel ribbon sashes.

title: Man Who Was Cited in PX Inquiry Assails Accuser
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 A businessman, accused of ex tensive abuses in his dealings with American military forces in Southeast Asia, has gone on television to deny a number of, charges against him and to lodge several of his own.

title: Mrs. Crimmins Shouts Her Innocence in Court
description: Mrs. Alice Crimmins, ac cused of killing her two children, stood up in a Queens courtroom yesterday during the questioning of prospective jurors and shouted, I am, too, innocent, you know I'm innocent.

title: High Court Is Asked to Bar Welfare Aid for Strikers
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)A Massachusetts manu facturer appealed to the Su preme Court today to upset the ruling that striking workers may receive welfare benefits.

title: Shamrock Shipment Seized
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, March 16 (Reuters)  A parcel of thousands of sprigs of shamrock from Ireland, destined for the lapels of Irish men here for St. Patrick's Day, has been seized at the Inter national Airport here on orders from plant pest control author ities.

title: Cooling Tower Slated for Nuclear Plant
description: CHICAGO, March 16Con servation groups trying to pre vent the dumping into Lake Michigan of hot water from nuclear power plants won an other round today when the Consumers Power Company agreed to build a cooling tower at its generating station near South Haven, Mich.

title: Saul to Leave Amex to Join First Boston
description: Ralph S. Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange and a Wall Street leader, re signed yesterday to become vice chairman of the First Bos ton Corporation, one of the na tion's leading investment bank ing houses.

title: Candidates Chosen for 19 Tony Awards
description: Home, Sleuth, Story Theater and The Philan thropist have been nomi nated in the best play cate gory for the 1971 Antoinette Perry Awards, and Com pany, The Me Nobody Knows and The Roth schilds have won nomina tions in the best musical play classification.

title: A Chance to Hear
description: Today, through new test ing devices, a serious hear ing defect in even a very young child can be de tected. Thus therapy so im portant to overcoming such a dis ability, can be gin, sometimes even before the child learns to walk. The Easter Seal So ciety of New York pioneered in this field and established one of the first speech and hearing clinics in the state.

title: Gilmore Is Signed To Colonels' Pact Worth $1.5Million
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 16 (AP)Artis Gilmore, Jackson ville's allAmerica performer, today signed a contract, con sidered to be worth $1.5mil lion, with the Kentucky Colonels of the American Bas ketball Association.

title: Port Unit Is Urged to Revoke Stevedore's Permit
description: A hearing officer recom mended, yesterday that the Waterfront Commission revoke the temporary stevedore license of the Erb Strapping Company and deny it a permanent one because of the company's asso ciations with members of or ganized crime.

title: VIETNAM G.I. FORCE OF 50,000 SEEN BY '73
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird indicated today that few er than 50,000 American sol diers would remain in Vietnam by the end of 1972.

title: Quintuplets Born on Coast; Boy Dies, 4 Girls Survive
description: LOS ANGELES, March 16 (AP)A year after she started taking fertility pills, Mrs. Paul Kaplan gave birth to quintup lets today. One, a boy, was still born and doctors said another showed signs of respiratory trouble.

title: Stars Rout Kings, 72
description: LOS ANGELES, March 16 (UPI)Bill Goldsworthy scored three goals tonight as the Min nesota North Stars snapped a drought by collecting a club record six goals in the first period en route to a 72 rout of the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Bribe Report Denied
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)Martin J. Bromley, iden tified in Senate testimony as head of an international slot machine syndicate that made up to $100million profit in the last 10 years, told the subcom mittee today that he never of fered a $50,000 bribe to silence an Army general.

title: A 2Year Extension Of Draft Is Voted By Panel in House
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)The House Armed Serv ices Committee voted today to extend the draft until June 30, 1973, and to give President Nixon authority to abolish de ferments for undergraduate col lege students.

title: Design for Churchill Statue Shown
description: LONDON, March 16The winning design in a compe tition for a statue of Sir Winston Churchill to stand in Parliament Square was unveiled today. The sculptor, Ivor RobertsJones, shows the war leader bareheaded, wearing a militarystyle greatcoat and grasping a stick.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Protocol Ends &
description: Not every problem at the United Nations concerns international affairs.

title: Teacher, Drop That Plan
description: A series of reports by Joseph Lelyveld in this news paper on the progress of a fourth grade class in Public School 198 in Manhattan have provided valuable insights into the skills with which able teachers introduce city children to the mysteries of learning and living together. Almost in passing, however, these accounts have also underscored some of the follies of educational routine which the system and the profession impose by habit.

title: Ton of Marijuana Seized
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)The Customs Bureau an nounced today that a ton of marijuana was discovered in a trunk in Philadelphia last night and three persons were ar rested.

title: City Drops Bid to Seek '72 Democratic Parley
description: New York City has with drawn its request to play host to the 1972 Democratic nom inating convention.

title: FRANK HASTINGS, IN U.S. RESEARCH
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Dr. Frank W. Hastings, head of the Federal Government's artificial heart research pro gram since 1964, died last night, a week after suffering a stroke. He was 52 years old.

title: Pros Down Rockets, 127118
description: DENVER March 16 (AP) Combining for 94 points, Steve Jones, Jimmy Jones and Wen dell Ladner led the Memphis Pros to a 127118 victory over the Denver Rockets tonight.

title: Amex Finishes Slightly Higher in Active Trading
description: The American Stock Ex change managed to finish slightly higher yesterday after some late selling had erased many of the earlier gains in active trading.

title: Thomas E. Dewey
description: The legacy of Thomas E. Dewey was an enduring advance in the efficiency and integrity of government in this state and city. From his emergence as a youthful smasher of labor rackets, through his capture of the District Attorneyship from Tammany Hall, to his three highly successful terms as Governor, Mr. Dewey elevated both the standards and the quality of public service.

title: Criticism Heads Agenda In BankAmerica Meeting
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 Executives of the BankAmer ica Corporation, the parent holding company of the Bank of America, came to their annual meeting of stockholders here today prepared for criticism. They got plenty, although it came from a small minority of the some 500 stockholders gathered in the Masonic Me morial Temple auditorium.

title: Canadian Films Are Rivaling Imports
description: MONTREAL  Canadian actors, directors, cameramen and businessmen are shoot ing and financing feature films, in French and in English, on a scale never be fore known in this country.

title: MEMBER OF RESERVE BACKS BANK CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 A member of the Federal Re serve Board said today that he favored a vigorous and ex pansionary use of the new onebank holding company legislation to increase bank ing's association with finan cially related business.

title: HERMAN S. PRESCOTT OF SALVATION ARMY
description: Herman S. Prescott. a Salva tion Army official, died Monday in Denver, where he was at tending the American Prot estant Hospital Association conference. He was 43 years old and lived at 400 Cozine Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: DEFENSE AND STATE REST IN TATE TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, March 16 (AP)  Both sides rested their cases today in the penalty phase of the TateLaBianca murder trial, and the judge an nounced that final arguments would begin this Thursday.

title: Envoy's Home Burglarized
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)A thief broke into the home of the West German Am bassador, Rolf Pauls, last night and stole about $2,600 in Ameri can and German currency from the butler's room, according to the Washington police.

title: Fought Divisive Ideas
description: A mediumsized man with a leonine head, Hans Kohn spoke with a Czechaccented lion's roar about the need for genuine world peace, the inalienable rights of man, and the neces sity for justice and the rule of law. His manner was kindly and intellectual, but his strong words sought to mobilize public opinion against totalitarianism of the Right and the Left, be tween which he drew no dis tinction.

title: Theater: Father's Day
description: The brittle bitterness of di vorce, at least for women, is the subject of Oliver Hailey's dark comedy of New York mores, Father's Day, which opened last night at the John Golden Theater. It takes a very harsh view of the woman's lot in divorce, and supports it with a few modestly amusing wise cracks and enormous gushes of hardbitten feminine self pity.

title: Curbs on German TV
description: BONN, March 16West Ger man's Health Ministry and the West German cigarette indus try have agreed on stringent new curbs on cigarette ad vertising, including a stepby step discontinuance of tele vision advertising, it was con firmed here today.

title: Nixon Announces Patricia's Engagement
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 Patricia Nixon's engagement to Edward Ridley Finch Cox was finally confirmed tonight.

title: Bilingual Schools Flourishing Here
description: When kindergarten chil dren at P.S. 25 in the Bronx play musical chairs, their teacher, Maria Acevedo, holds a card on which is printed the word Martes. Then, to the accompaniment of piano music Mrs. Acevedo recites the days of the week in Spanish. When she reaches Martes (Tuesday), the chil dren scramble for their chairs.

title: Italian Court Due to End Ban On BirthControl Data Today
description: ROME, March 16Judicial sources said today that Italy's highest court was about to re move a legal ban on any form of public information on birth control.

title: Knicks Trounce Lakers In Garden Dimout, 11582
description: The new Madison Square Garden, just past its third birthday, suffered its first dim out last night during a basket ball game in which the New York Knickerbockers beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 11582. But the most serious inconvenience to a capacity crowd of 19,500 resulted from the huge struc ture's loss of voice.

title: Midwest Board Backs Chief
description: CHICAGO, March 16 (UPI)  The board of governors of the Midwest Stock EXchange to day unanimously approved a vote of confidence in Michael E. Tobin, president of the ex change. The board also voted unanimously to approve the negotiation of a new contract for Mr. Tobin, replacing his previous threeyear contract.

title: Irish Are in Luck: Mild Day Forecast For Parade Today
description: The man at the National Weather Service office here, usually a taciturn type, said yesterday with a smile that to day's weather would be sunny, breezy and mild, with tempera tures in the 50's.

title: TV: Your ChoiceGiggle or Snicker
description: Doris and Carol. Or, if you prefer, Carol and Doris. Either way, it spells television stars  and several other things about some of the curious matters flickering across the screen these days.

title: NEWARK TEACHERS RETURN TO TALKS
description: NEWARK, March 16The Board of Education resumed negotiations with the teachers' union and the A.F.L.C.I.O. called off a threatened city wide work stoppage today in support of the seven week old ool strike.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: The U.S. Army is in trouble in Indochina, not so much because of difficulties in mastering the new kind of war it has been summoned to fight but because of psychological reper cussions arising from doubts as to the validity or value of its mission. These doubts are more inspired by news from home than by enemy propaganda.

title: Ulster Leader in London Seeking Additional Troops
description: LONDON, March 16The Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, Maj. James D. Chi chesterClark, unexpectedly flew into London today to plead for more British troops to save his government.

title: Theater: Manhattan Arrangement
description: The Manhattan Arrange ment, the new revue Up stairs at the Downstairs, gets its name and supposedly its impetus from an imagined se cession of the city from the state. This is an interesting, if not novel, conceptre member Mayor Norman Mail er?but it provides only the slightest thread for the eve ning's entertainment.

title: School Budget Procedures Called Totally Inadequate
description: ALBANY, March 16  The New York City Board of Education was seven months into its fiscal year before it discovered it was overspending its substituteteacher appropriation by 50 per cent, a special State Senate inquiry disclosed today.

title: ETHIOPIANS SEEKING NEW ARMS FROM U.S.
description: ASMARA, Ethiopia, March 16 (AP)The United States is be ing asked to improve the fire power of Ethiopian troops fighting guerrillas of the Eritrean Liberation Front.

title: Nassau Relief Clients May Get Bank Deposits Instead of Checks
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 16 Nassau County announced to day that it would study a new method of payment for welfare clients in which funds would be deposited every two weeks in a bank of their choice, in stead of their receiving checks.

title: Militant Students Close Coast Community College
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 16 The 7,000  student Merritt College campus, which was closed today after nearly 100 black, chicano and radical whites took over administration offices, was to remain closed tomorrowless than a week before final examinations.

title: Rise in Lumber Supply Is Urged
description: Secretary of Agriculture Clif ford M. Hardin said yesterday that the future growth in hous ing and other uses seems cer tain to mean higher prices for wood products.

title: Blues Down Canadiens
description: ST. LOUIS, March 16 (UPI) The St. Louis Blues over whelmed Montreal's goalie, Phil Myre, with 44 shots to night and gained a 62 victory, their first triumph over the Canadiens at the St. Louis Arena.

title: Nixon, Paying Tribute, Hails Dewey as Great Patriot
description: The following tributes were paid yesterday to former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey:

title: TALKS ARE FLUID ON SECURITY BANK
description: Negotiations for control of the Security National Bank, a $1billion institution based in Huntington, L. I., are fluid at the moment, Patrick ford, chairman of the bank, said yesterday evening. Last week, Mr. Clifford and Frank A. Weil, president of the Abacus Fund, Inc., announced a tentative agreement for Abacus to sell its 25 per cent holding in Secu rity to a group of investors be ing formed by Mr. Clifford.

title: Sports of The Times
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 16Denny McLain, a spectac ular and arrogant winner of 55 games for the Detroit Tigers over a twoyear span, no longer is a part of the local scenery, and the Tigers already are calculating this sub traction to be a definite plus. It would seem to demonstrate that McLain can foul up everything, including the immuta ble principles of mathematics.

title: The Banning of the Ban
description: DUBLINThey're banning the ban and Ireland can hardly be the same again. There'll be nudes at the Abbey next.

title: E. I. du Pont Plans a Halt To Production of Corfam
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., which spent be tween $80million and $100 million on the development of Corfam, announced yesterday it would stop making the poro meric shoe material.

title: SchoolAid Foes Clash at Albany Rally
description: ALBANY, March 16Oppon ents and supporters of state aid to parochial schools con fronted each other briefly on the steps of the Capitol shortly after noon today, then went to meet with legislators to lobby for their respective positions.

title: Kissinger Meets McCarthy For Talks at White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)One of President Nixon's key advisers, Henry A. Kissin ger, who seems to be opening up communications with doves who usually are his strongest critics, has met privately with former Senator Eugene J. Mc Carthy.

title: New Outbreak of Malaria in California Traced to Heroin Users
description: California and Federal health officials have discovered 38 new cases of malaria, the larg est outbreak of the disease in this country in nearly 20 years.

title: CITY GETS JUDGMENT AGAINST SCOFFLAWS
description: The city has obtained judg ments totaling $122,000 against 375 scofflaws who have re ceived three or more parking tickets since July 1, Transpor tation Administrator Constan tine SidamonEristoff reported yesterday.

title: The China Travel Office in Hong Kong Remains Pessimistic
description: HONG KONG, March 16 The prim, young woman be hind the counter at the China Travel Service was polite but pessimistic.

title: 4.8% Demand Rise Forecast by Oilmen
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 16 Leaders of the American oil industry told the Texas Rail road Commission today that they expected a growth of 4.8 per cent to 5.6 per cent in demand for oil and its products in the United States this year.

title: The Sourdoughs Have Vanished, but Sour Doughs Live On
description: TALKEETNA, Alaska  Occasionally a food is so distinctive that it gives its name to an entire subculture. In London there are the Beefeaters and in Southern California the lotus eaters. In Alaska there were the sourdoughs, the itinerant prospectors who roamed this vast and hostile territory looking for gold. There are not many true sourdoughs left, but the food they made famous has survived.

title: SOYBEANS DECLINE AS CORN ADVANCES
description: Prices of futures were in fluenced yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade by the strong possibility that farmers would grow more soybeans and less corn this year.

title: F.T.C. Says Continental Baking Makes False Claims for Bread
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)The Federal Trade Com mission accused the nation's largest independent baker to day of making false nutritional claims for Wonder Bread and Hostess Snack Cakes and false weight loss claims for Profile Bread.

title: Blankets With 35% Rayon Found Flammable in Tests
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)An independent product testing organization reported today that blankets containing 35 per cent rayon catch fire in one second when exposed to a flame.

title: G.O.P. AIDE URGES TAX LAW CHANGE
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Representative John W. Byrnes of Wisconsin, the ranking Re publican on the House Ways and Means Committee, pro posed today two changes in the Federal tax laws that would have the effect of giving the states more revenue of their own to spend.

title: Surge by Colonels Beats Nets,122104; Issel Collects 39
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 16 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels capitalized on a thirdquarter rally to down the New York Nets 122104, tonight in the second game of an American Basketball Association double header.

title: POWER PRIORITIES FOR CITIES BACKED
description: Two top officials of the New York Power Pool, which co ordinates operations of the state's seven major private electric utilities, said yesterday that core areas of large cities, such as Manhattan, should get preference to keep their power when shortages forced inten tional blackouts of various areas.

title: Briton's Bet Wins $801,6001
description: LONDON, March 16 (Reuters) Mrs. Joan Wilkes, a house wife, today won $801,600 with a 54cent bet on a soccer pool, using a system that includes the number 13 with street num bers of the homes of friends and family members. The sum is believed to be the second largest ever won by an indi vidual. In December, a woman identified only as Mrs. X won $813,600.

title: MORGAN TRUST CUTS PRIME RATE
description: The 5 per cent prime rate on business loanswhich was established at most large banks only last weekcontinued to erode yesterday.

title: Rights Leader Is Mourned With Awe
description: Among the thousands who came without printed invita tions to pay final tribute to Whitney M. Young Jr., the respect was close to awe.

title: CONCERT SERIES TO BENEFIT UNIONS
description: The New York Philharmonic will inaugurate a series of nine concerts for members of vari ous unions and their families that will take the orchestra into unionmeeting halls for the first time in history.

title: STOCKS RISE AGAIN AS TRADING SOARS
description: The bull market thundered ahead yesterday as volume rose to 22.27 million shares, making it the fourth busiest session on record at the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Economists are generally re garded as compulsive promoters of economic growth for its own sake, But more and more econo mists are coming to feel that the most important, unsolved problem facing their profession is how to reduce or prevent the undesirable consequences of growth  such as choked highways, overcrowded airports, noise, foul air, polluted water, despoiled nature, urban sprawl, decaying central cities. Radicals contend that these effects are endemic in the capitalist system.

title: Young Funeral on TV
description: All three major television net works said last night that they would broadcast coverage of the funeral of Whitney M. Young Jr., today in Lexington, Ky. The American Broadcasting Company, the Columbia Broad casting System and the Nation al Broadcasting Company said that live coverage would begin at 11:30 A.M.

title: Taipei Regrets U.S. Action
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 16 (AP)Nationalist China said to day that it deeply regrets the lifting of the ban on travel by American citizens to Commu nist China.

title: JERSEY SEEKS CUT IN TOBIN'S POWERS
description: TRENTON, March 16  Gov. William T. Cahill announced to day that the six New Jersey commissioners of the Port of New York Authority had agreed to seek a restoration of their policymaking power that the Governor contends has been largely taken over by the authority's Executive Director, Austin J. Tobin.

title: Thomas E. Dewey Is Dead at 68
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., March 16  Thomas E. Dewey, Gover nor of New York for three terms and twice the Republican nomi nee for President, died about 3:30 P.M. today while alone in his room at the Seavlew Hotel in this resort town north of Miami Beach. He was 68 years old.

title: ONEMAN PATROLS SOUGHT FOR CITY
description: In an effort to increase the number of available patrol cars and to reduce police response time, the city has asked the Patrolmen's Benevolent Asso ciation to Permit the use of oneman car patrols in some areas.

title: CATHOLIC PRIESTS URGE 6 REFORMS
description: BALTIMORE, March 16  Representatives of the coun try's priests urged the Roman Catholic hierarchy today to adopt six major reforms in the priesthood.

title: S.P. Chief Cites Traffic
description: Benjamin F. Biaggini, presi dent of the Southern Pacific Company, said in an interview here yesterday that he was get ting a bit dizzy watching the fluctuations weektoweek this year in railroad traffic.

title: Congress Votes on SST
description: As a vote in both the House of Representatives and the Senate Appropriations Committee on the supersonic transport plane nears, the Administration and its busi ness and labor union allies in the aircraft industry have joined in a major propaganda drive to squash the public's doubts.

title: Political Kidnapping Plot Tied to White Panthers
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)The White Panther party considered kidnapping political leaders of the prominence of Vice President Agnew to gain release of jailed radicals, ac cording to a policeman's testi mony released today by a Senate subcommittee.

title: Nashville Influence Strongly Evident In Irish Program
description: The news from Carnegie Hall on St. Patrick's Eve was that Ireland, after fending off the English for all these years, had succumbed without even raising a pennywhistle toof all for eign realms!Nashville. Anyone who has checked out the juke box in a New York Irish bar recently might have guessed, from the preponderance of country and Western records, what was blowing in the musi cal wind. But Larry Cunning ham made it official Monday night when he began a two night stand at Carnegie Hall.

title: George Schaefer to Retire As Public Library Manager
description: George L. Schaefer will re tire as business manager of the New York Public Library at the end of this month after a career of 22 years in the nation's largest public library system.

title: SHEIK MUJIB SEES PRESIDENT YAHYA
description: DACCA, Pakistan, March 16  President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan opened discussions here today with Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the political leader of rebellious East Pakistan.

title: French Seize 2 in Bank Theft
description: NIMES, France, March 16 (Reuters)The police today ar rested two men and retrieved most of the $75,000 taken yes terday in one of the most spec tacular bank holdups in French history. The robbery was at Toulouse, 185 miles west of here.

title: Baby Left in Bus Goes With Driver And Wife to Jersey
description: A new brn baby girl found abandoned on a school bus in Brooklyn two weeks ago went home yesterday with her foster parents, the bus driver and his wife who already had five chil dren.

title: Twins, 3, Drown Upstate
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 16 (AP)Twin 3yearold boys drowned today in a pool of water less than a foot deep near their home in the nearby Town of Glenville, the Schenec tady County sheriff's office said. Mrs. Lloyd Hagen told the police that her sons, Glen and Erik, had been playing near the house when they disappeared. She said she followed their tracks through snow to the pool, where she found their bodies.

title: VELASQUEZ RIDES 4 WINNERS HERE
description: If at first you succeed, don't stop trying.

title: Rout Reported in Hanoi
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 16 (Agence France Presse)The Communist com mand in Laos issued an order to its troops today to com pletely annihilate and prevent the withdrawal of South Viet namese troops, who it said were fleeing in disorder.

title: 6,000 HERE ATTEND FUNERAL OF YOUNG
description: More than 6,000 of the na tion's mighty and lowly attend ed the funeral yesterday of Whitney M. Young Jr. in the Riverside Church, where they heard the internationally known civil rights leader eulogized as another pioneer of the new age.

title: Crafts Council Starts a Drive For Funds to Expand Its Scope
description: The American Crafts Council, which operates the Museum of Contemporary Crafts here and, more broadly, is involved in aid ing craftsmen throughout the country opened this week a fund drive for $7million to en large its mission.

title: TOP GRAMMIES WON BY SIMONGARFUNKEL
description: Simon and Garfunkel, the poprock duo, walked away with the three most prestigious Grammy Awards for 1970, given annually by the 3,500 members of the National Academy of Recording Arts And Sciences. The members are musicians, conductors, singers, arrangers, producers and other members of the recording industry.

title: GALLEY CASE GOES TO MILITARY JURY
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 16The case of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who is charged with the murder of at least 102 unresisting South Vietnamese civilians, went to the jury this evening.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Slum Priest Shakes Pope's Diocese
description: ROME, March 16A Bel gian priest who sees himself as the champion of shack dwellers on this city's mangy outskirts has become a sym bol of Roman Catholic social protest in the Pope's backyard.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE GRANDEES. America's Sephardic Elite. By Stephen Birmingham. 368 pages. Harper & Row. $10.

title: Advertising:
description: His voice was soft and warm like a summer breeze on Galway Bay and there was a bit of a tear in his eye as he spoke of the new ad campaign for Irish Interna tional Airlines.

title: Phone Company Asks Rate Rise; Calls Earnings Perilously Low
description: ALBANY, March 16The New York Telephone Company declared today that its earnings were so dangerously low that it would not be able to meet its responsibilities to its customers, employes and investors if it did not get a substantial rate in crease.

title: Lawyers for Angela Davis Ask Dismissal of Charges on Coast
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., March 16Attorneys for Angela Davis argued today that murder, kid nap and criminal conspiracy charges lodged against her should be dismissed.

title: Portents From West Berlin
description: Many West Berliners deserted Chancellor Brandt's So cial Democrats in their city election because they feared the effects on their own security of his effort to improve relations with the Soviet bloc. The opposition Christian Democrats had played heavily on this concern, and Mr. Brandt had accepted their bid to make the election a referendum on his Ostpolitik.

title: Knesset Backs Mrs. Meir After Opposition Walkout
description: JERUSALEM, March 16  Premier Golda Meir used up some of her dwindling political capital in parliament today by forcing a strict partyline vote to defeat an opposition motion of no confidence, challeng ing the terms she had laid down for an eventual peace settle ment with the Arabs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OPPOSITION SEEN TO GASWAR PACT
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 The first significant signs of opposition began to appear to day in the Senate Foreign Re lations Coimnittee to the Ad ministration's request that the Senate approve the 1925 Ge neva protocol banning gas and germ warfare.

title: Fear Among U.N. Diplomats
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 16A mood of anxiety prevails these days among members of the diplomatic community, who are fearful that their families are unsafe on the streets and that their embassies might become tar gets of bombs or threats.

title: Passengers Get Roses
description: PARIS, March 16 (Reuters) Airline hostesses handed out newlyplucked roses to each of the 30 passengers aboard a Nicebound jet today. It was the first French plane to take off after the strike.

title: Dobrynin Balks at U.S. Bid
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 The Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, declined today to call on John N. Irwin 2d, Under Secretary of State, to receive a United States pro test over violation of the Amer ican Embassy's diplomatic im munity in Moscow.

title: The Seeds of Future Wars
description: Secretary of State Rogers's warning that failure to achieve a Middle East settlement now could plant the seeds of future wars sums up United StatesIsraeli dif ferences over current approaches to peace.

title: U.S. Rules PigIron Imports Are Sold Below Fair Value
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)  The Treasury Depart ment ruled today that pig iron imported from Canada, Finland and West Germany was being sold in the United States at less than fair value.

title: Red Chinese Report Satellite Launching That U.S. Detected
description: HONG KONG, March 16 Communist China announced today that it had orbited its second earth satellite on March 3. The Chinese announcement came nearly two weeks after the launching was detected by the North America Air De fense command and reported by the Pentagon.

title: Capital Will Get Theater for Blacks
description: Robert Hooks, the stage film and television actor, has gone back to his home town, Washington, where he was born 34 years ago, to start a theater for and by blacks.

title: Air France Ends Dispute; Flights to Resume Today
description: PARIS, March 16France's commercial air fleet of 158 planes will resume service to morrow after a 26day interrup tion caused by a labor dispute.

title: Health Warning to Appear On Cigarettes in Britain
description: LONDON, March 16  Brit ain's tobacco manufacturers have agreed voluntarily to print health warnings on cigar ette packages. The message in red, Warning by H.M. Gov ernment: Smoking can damage your health, is expected to appear on packages sold in stores by this summer.

title: State Backs Con Ed In Indian Point Plan For a Heat Barrier
description: ALBANY, March 16The Public Service Commission to day approved a plan of the Consolidated Edison Company to construct a facility using as much as $1.8million in state funds to protect the waters of the lower Hudson River from thermal discharges from the utility's controversial nuclear generating plant at Indian Point.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The most serious problem in Washington today because it affects most other prob lemsis the decline in honest argu ment. There has always, of course, been an element of propaganda in most political discussion, but now the techniques of advertising seem to be overwhelming the normal procedures of Congressional debate, and the lan guage in the capital is more inflated than the currency.

title: 2 Arrested in Kidnapping
description: ANKARA, Wednesday, March 17Two leaders of a gang of leftwing extremists suspected of the kidnapping of four Unit ed States airmen March 4 were captured by police early today in a town in eastern Turkey.

title: Veterans Plan a War Protest in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 Vietnam Veterans Against the War announced today that the organization, which claims to have 8,000 members and chap ters in every state, would hold a fiveday encampment here next month to protest the war and the lack of adequate serv ices for returned veterans.

title: W2 Form Rule Suspended
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service said today it was tem porarily suspending a require ment that employers provide former workers with W2 with holdingtax forms 30 days after they leave their jobs. The serv ice said it had taken the step because it had delayed printing 1971 W2 forms since new So cial Security legislation was probable.

title: State's Outlay to Jobless Rises; Jump Traced Mainly to Layoffs
description: ALBANY, March 16The state paid $58million more in unemployment insurance bene fits in January and February than it did in the same period last year, Controller Arthur Levitt reported today. Sources in the Controller's office said this reflected a sharp surge in layoffs.

title: Bugner, 21, Wins Title; Cooper Retires
description: WEMBLEY, England, March 16 (UPI)Joe Bugner, a natu ralized Briton, ended. Henry Cooper's long reign as king of British boxing tonight, taking the old warrior's European, Brit ish and Commonwealth heavy weight titles by the closest possible margin after 15 rounds.

title: British Delegation Due in U. S. Today With New Rolls Bid
description: A highlevel team of British officials will fly to the United States today to sweeten the re jected British proposal aimed at keeping the RollsRoyce jet engine program alive.

title: Mopac Orders Freight Cars
description: ST, LOUIS, March 17 (AP) The Missouri Pacific Railroad announced today it had ordered 1,500 new freight cars at a cost of more than $24million to continue modernization and ex pansion of its fleet.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Plebiscite Decision Reserved
description: THE HAGUE, Netherlands, March 17 (Reuters)The World Court announced today that it has reserved a decision until a later date on a South African offer to hold a plebiscite in SouthWest Africa to allow the people there to express an opinion on the territory's polit ical future.

title: SAIGON'S FORCES QUIT FOURTH BASE IN LAOS FIGHTING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday March 18  South Vietnamese troops evacuated another base in Laos today.

title: TV: No Oscars or Emmys for Grammy
description: And now it's the Grammy Awards special, presented Tuesday night over the American Broadcasting Com pany, live from the Holly wood Palladium and for the the first time, hold your breath, winners were not an nounced before the beginning of the program.

title: Italy, Fearing a Rightist Plot, Seizes Explosives
description: ROME, March 17  The Italian police seized explosives and documents today in a broad drive against suspected ultra rightist plotters, the Govern ment announced.

title: Cuba Makes Work Obligatory
description: MIAMI, March 17The Gov ernment of Premier Fidel Cas tro enacted today a law making work obligatory for the major ity of Cubans and providing punishments for vagrants and parasites. The law makes work a social duty that must be unavoidably fulfilled by all ablebodied men between the ages of 17 and 60 and women between 17 and 55.

title: Incorporation Is Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, March 17  The Securities and Exchange Commission has informed the New York Stock Exchange that it has some question concerning the desirability of the ex change's incorporating itself.

title: Menuhin Plays Especially Well With His Festival Orchestra
description: Yehudi Menuhin must have known that he was in es pecially good form Tuesday night at Philharmonic Hall. He and the Menuhin Festival Orchestra had prepared a generous program for their appearance on Lincoln Cen ter's Great Performers series, but they extended it with two encores. For one, the violinist played Beethoven's Romance in F with the ensemble; for the other, he conducted the Entrance of the Queen of Sheba from Handel's Solomon.

title: WHITE SOX DOWN YANKEES, 4 TO 2
description: MARACAIBO, Venezuela, March 17 (UPI)Errors by Frank Baker at shortstop and Gene Michael at second base contributed to the New York Yankees' 42 defeat tonight by the Chicago White Sox in the second and final exhibition game in Venezuela. The loss was the Yanks' ninth in a row.

title: 12 Artists Join in an Uncommon Show
description: Twelve artists who live and work in Westbeth, the artists' housing development in the West Village, have mounted a large exhibition of their recent work in four siz able galleries adjoining the building's courtyard at 155 Bank Street, between Wash ington and West Streets.

title: Reds and Socialists in France Aiding Each Other in Runoffs

title: Executive Changes
description: The First Boston Cor poration announced yes terday the election of Andrew N. Overby to the post of chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Overby, who will continue as vice chairman of the board, fills the vacancy created by the death of Charles C. Glavin on Jan. 30. Mr. Overby, who joined First Boston in 1957, was elected a mem ber of the executive com mittee in 1963 and was made vice chairman in 1964. Prior to joining First Boston, he served from 1952 to 1957 as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, United. States Executive Director of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank), and as a member of the National Security Council Planning Board.

About 40 students who had occupied the building through the night fled through the front door as the police moved in from the rear at 6:21 A.M. No arrests were made.

title: Tricia Kept Secret WellEven Nixons Didn't Know

title: A Satirical Visit to a Greedy Small Town
description: Like Paul Mazursky and Larry Tucker, who hit the Hollywood bigtime with "Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice," Bud Yorkin (the director) and Norman Lear (the writer) are social satirists bred in television, where satire not only is aimed at rather obvious mass attitudes, but also is severely limited by the optimistic attitudes of the same masses. The Yorkin-Lear "Divorce American Style" thus became a kind of TV situation comedy about one of America's favorite pastimes. The contents were often surprisingly accurate and cynical, but the packaging was cheerful, pure Saran really."Cold Turkey," which opened yesterday at the Victoria on Broadway and other theaters around town, is Mr. Lear's first solo venture as writer-director-producer, with Mr. Yorkin as executive producer. And it is, within its limitations, a very engaging, very funny movie. The Saran is still there, but it is wrapped around a lot of typical, nasty humor and old-fashioned, clean-cut vulgarity.It's the sort of movie in which the President of the United States is shown running around the country trying to horn in on somebody else's national publicity stunt (and mostly failing); in which a fine, upstanding Protestant minister sleeps with curlers in his hair, and in which the vocabulary of a nice, fanatically anti-Communist, little old lady is pretty much restricted to Jennifer Cavilleri's favorite eight-letter word, which she uses incorrectly."Cold Turkey" is, basically, a gimmick movie, but Mr. Lear is so skilled a formula practitioner that most of the variations he works on his gimmick amused me, instead of setting my teeth on edge.Hiram C. Grayson (Edward Everett Horton), the ancient, senile head of a huge tobacco company, is persuaded he'll win an immortality equal to Alfred B. Nobel's by presenting $25-million to any town that can give up smoking for 30 days. The only town that succeeds in signing all its citizens to the no-smoking pledge is Eagle Rock, Iowa (pop. 4,006), an economically depressed area whose social life centers around parties for burghers fleeing to Des Moines and Davenport.How Eagle Rock meets its terrifying challenge is dramatized by Lear in a series of frantic, more or less hit-and run sketches that involve Bob and Ray, impersonating just about every television newsman who has ever become bigger than the events he reports (Walter Chronic, David Chetly, Hugh Upson, among others), as well as (in news clips) Mrs. Patricia Nixon, Shirley Temple and Vice President Agnew.The Eagle Rock citizens, who come apart in their various, spectacular ways in the course of the test, include Dick Van Dyke, as the town's leading minister, who is not above comparing himself to Albert Schweltzer and Popes Plus, John and Paul, and whose only concern for his wife is that she not slouch; Pippa Scott, as his wife, a sad, dreamy, secret smoker; Tom Poston, the town's positively lyrical drunk; Vincent Gardenia, the mayor; and Judith Lowry, the foul-mouthed old fighter against Communism and Big Government. There also are a number of other eccentricly realized, comic stereotypes played with exuberant, hammy joy by people like Sudie Bond, Jean Stapleton, Barnard Hughes and Barbara Cason.Lear shot his film entirely on locations in Iowa, which explains not only its decent, generally unsentimentalized rural beauty, but also, perhaps, its decent, generally unsentimental attitude toard its characters. There are moments when the movie makes a few, half-hearted attempts to say something about the evils of greed and avarice, but its concerns are both more immediate (to get laughs out of things like false teeth and flatulence) and its intentions more specific (to question the economic system that must punish as it rewards)."Cold Turkey" is not terribly significant satire. It was madeafter allto amuse the very people it is satirizing, but it does this with such hustling, commercial vitality that I found most of it irresistible, even, I might add, when the jokes about catarrh had begun to produce not laughs but wheezes.

title: Beauty Talk
description: Hairdressers have been hav ing a dull time of it these last few years. As long as clothes were reasonably con temporary, they weren't much inspiration to the men be hind the curlers. But given a revival of a periodany pe riod  hair stylists have a great time reproducing the good old days. This season, fash ion's good old days are the bad old days of the wartime forties. And naturally, the hair men have pounced on the over done coiffures of the period. The trend began gingerly last month with the gypsy hairdos of Rita Hayworth, but now hairdressers are bringing back the pompadours and the frizz that made even nice girls of the period look like tramps.

title: ' When Dinosaurs Ruled the Earth' in Neighborhood Houses
description: A tale of cavemen and the cavewomen who love them, Val Guest's "When Dinosaurs Ruled the Earth" opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters. Just as she is to be sacrificed to the misbehaving sun, blond Sanna (Victoria Vetri) falls off a nearby cliff into the tumultuous seas below. Miraculously escaping the wild surf, she swims into a cyclone. She almost drowns, but by lucky chance the crew of a passing raft rescues her. On the raft is Tara (Robin Hawdon), who turns out to be the man of Sanna's dreams.How Sanna and Tara, against all odds, against her people and his people, natural disaster and human wickedness, brachiosauruses and pterodactyls, win their right to true loveand how of the sun the moon is born, creating the tides that in the nick of time drown all their enemiesthis requires comment, consideration, praise, perhaps a poem. But not, I think, movie criticism as we commonly practice it.And yet there is no doubt that "When Dinosaurs Ruled the Earth" answers several thorny questions, such as when and how the moon was formed: After the coming of man, before the extinction of the dinosaurs, and to the accompaniment of a choir of heavenly voices. At the same time, the film fosters a healthy historical humility, for the sight of Miss Vetri, or Magda Konopka, or Imogen Hassall, or many others in their mastadon-skin bikinis, is enough to demolish distance and shatter the perspective achieved through several hundred thousand years of civilization's march.Toward dinosaurs the film is scrupulously fair, recognizing that there were friendly dinosaurs as well as unfriendly dinosaurs, but that most were merely indifferent. In the course of her travails, Miss Vetri grows close to one dinosaur (a stegosaurus, I believe) and to its appealingly playful offspring. But my favoritethe source of my favorite moment in the movieis a fierce triceratops, which, madly pursuing a bothersome caveman to the edge of a precipice, simply doesn't stop running and so falls off the precipice and into a bottomless abyss. You can see how an animal like that, lacking all wisdom and self control, would have low survival value."When Dinosaurs Ruled the Earth" presents a special language problem because it is in Caveman, and without subtitles. However, Caveman isn't a very extensive language (27 words and no grammar), and you quickly learn by watching that "zak," for example, means "gone away."Since almost the entire movie consists of Sanna going awayfrom the people, plants and animals who want to do her inthe phrase "Sanna zak!" serves for perhaps 85 per cent of the dialogue and gives a tremendous boost toward understanding the action.

title: U.S. Labor Aide Selected
description: Frank G. Zarb, formerly ex ecutive vice president of CBWL Hayden, Stone, Inc. here, has been appointed Assistant Sec retary of Labor for Administra tion by eSoretary of Labor J. D. Hodgson, the Labor Department announced here yesterday.

title: White Motor Registers Losses
description: The depressed business cli vate, particularly in its truck and farm equipment, resulted in a loss at the White Motor Corporation last year of $19, 340,000 contrasted to a net prof it of $12,435,000, or $1.83 a share, in 1969, the Cleveland based company reported yes terday.

title: Bullets Edge Cavaliers
description: BALTIMORE, March 17 (UPI) Kevin Loughery stole the ball from Dave Sorensen with three seconds left and scored a bas ket at the buzzer to give the Baltimore Bullets a 113109 vic tory over the Cleveland Caval iers tonight.

title: A New; Busy Life For Mrs. Morrow
description: Mrs. Edward R. Murrow, widow of the famed radio and television commentator and executive, is in the city these days as part of an ar rangement that many another widow might envy.

title: Armco Steel Chairman Will Retire Next Month
description: Logan T. Johnston, the 70 yearold board chairman of the Armco Steel Corporation, will retire next month, the company has disclosed. A native of Pitts burgh, he has been with Armco for 45 years. He became pres ident in 1960 and chairman in 1965.

title: Gentry Hurls 5 Shutout Innings as Mets Down Royals, 61
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17Gary Gentry pitched five more shutout innings and Cleon Jones hit his first home run of the spring today as the New York Mets over powered the Kansas City Royals, 61.

title: ExBay State Parking Aide Paroled on Garage Sentence
description: NORFOLK, Mass., March 17 (AP)George L. Brady, who pleaded guilty last year to charges of larceny involving $450,000 in the construction of the Boston Common parking garage, was paroled today from the Norfolk Prison Colony.

title: Schoolboys Are Scalping Knicks' Tickets for $75
description: At 3:10 yesterday morning tickets for the first four Knick home playoff games went on sale. At 7:30 the sale was com pleted. Minutes later some youngsters, who had waited up to 18 hours in line, started scalping their $5 and $7.50 tick ets for $50 and $75 a pair.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, March 17  There was a notice in the mail. It came from the automobile insurance com pany. It said that the cost of auto mobile insurance had gone up again. This time the increase was 80 per cent. It, would cost $715 to insure the car for one year.

title: New Zealand to Pull Out Unit
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 17, (AP)Prime Minister Kieth Holyoake said today that New Zealand would withdraw its 131man artillery battery from South Vietnam at the be ginning of May.

title: Senate Rejects Rules Change In Selecting Panel Chairmen
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)  The Senate voted 4828 yesterday to kill a proposed change in rules to modify the seniority system of selecting the chairmen and ranking mi nority members of committees.

title: $1  Million Winner
description: TRENTON, March 17Ed ward Henry, a telephone tech nician who earns $11,000 a year and is part Irish, today won New Jersey's first mil liondollar lottery in a draw ing that had been scheduled by Gov. William T. Cahill to coincide with St. Patrick's Day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Export Sanitation Is Topic for O.A.S.
description: PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, March 17The United States mentioned a previously un mentionable topic at a special meeting here today of the Or ganization of American States the health and sanitary level of LatinAmerican exports.

title: Benvenuti Knocked Down Twice In Losing TuneUp to Argentine
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, March 17 (AP)Jose Roberto Chirino, a 26yearold Argentine, knocked down Nino Benvenuti twice and went on to outpoint the former middleweight champion in a 10round fight tonight.

title: Juliana Flies to Montreal
description: MONTREAL, March 17 (Ca nadian Press)  Queen Juliana of the Netherlands arrived here last night for what a Dutch Consulate spokesman said was a private visit. She was accom panied by her daughter, Prin cess Christina. The Queen ar rived on a regularly scheduled KLM flight.

title: Copper Interests Attacked
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 17 Chilean officials today began new attacks on American cop per interests and attributed declining dollar reserves to what was termed the failure of the copper companies to pay dividends.

title: RANKIN TO GIVE UP HIS LAW PRACTICE
description: A special threeman commit tee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York recommended yesterday that Corporation Counsel J. Lee Rankin give up his limited pri vate practice of law.

title: SCANLAN'S MAGAZINE IN BANKRUPTCY MOVE
description: Scanlan's, a monthly, mag azine of investigative reporting has suffered severe losses and must file for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, according to Sidney E. Zion, one of its coeditors.

title: Bula Wins English Race
description: CHELTENHAM, England, March 17 (AP)  Capt. E. EdwardsHeathcote's favored Bula won the Champion Hurdle Cup today by four lengths, with Persian War, winner of the race the last three years, in second place. Bula, ridden by Pat Kelle way, earned first money of $18,918.

title: Board Votes to Ease Qualifying For High School Principal Test
description: The Board of Education last night adopted new rules de signed to enable more appli cants, particularly younger ones, to take the qualifying examination for high school principal.

title: An Open Presidency
description: Every Chief Executive organizes the office of the Presidency in his own way. No outsider can tell President how he can best manage his awesome responsibilities.

title: Tax Cut by U.S. Forecast If Business Lag Continues
description: Chances are now two to one that a dull and dis appointing business perform ance in the first quarter will lead the Administration to pro pose an immediate tax cut, Alan Greenspan said yesterday.

title: Twins and Oliva Agree On a 2Year Contract
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 17 (AP)  Tony Oliva, twotime American League batting champion, signed a twoyear contract with the Minnesota Twins today for a reported $90,000 to $95,000 the first year.

title: Honored in Legislature
description: ALBANY, March 17 (AP) The state Legislature postponed action on bills today and made its only order of business the paying of tribute to Mr. Dewey, who had been Governor of New York for 12 years.

title: Jan B. Washington Bride in Germany
description: Miss Jan Blackburn Wash ington, daughter of Lieut. Col. Richard B. Washington, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Washington of New Milford, Conn., was married yesterday in a civil ceremony in Darmstadt, Ger many, to Karsten, Gnther Stodte. He is the son of Mrs. Gnther O. Stodte of Lbeck, Germany, and, the late Dr. Stodte.

title: Books of The Times
description: Ted Hughes has written a strange, eerie, powerful set of poems that stand un matched in their singular quality. They resemble a stack of steel beams: slate gray, hard, menacing in their weight, gravity and destructive possibilities. The effect of the book is chilling: there is not a single warm emotion in it. The language is violent, colors are stark, the imagery reduces humans to their animal status. The overriding impres sion the poems leave is of man trapped by God, by nature and by woman. The re sponse to his poems is visceral. In reviewing the poet's earlier Hawk in the Rain, the late Edwin Muir spoke of the author's admirable vio lence. It's not an adjective one would apply to the current volume. One can admire the workmanship, the force and precision of language. But there is little that is attractive in the bleak, wasteland vistas this Yorkshireborn English poet conjures up or in the dehu manized cruel nature that rules them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mankilling Is the King's Game
description: REYKJAVIK, IcelandWhen as a youngster I went to a Jesuit school (Osterley, London, 192324) I learned this: Mankilling is the King's game.

title: Arts in Peril
description: Important segments of the cultural life of this state those libraries, museums, dance and drama companies, orchestras and children's activities that have been finan cially helped up to now by the New York State Council on the Artsare threatened by a Legislature apparently bent on indiscriminate budgetcutting.

title: White Panthers Call Charge Of Kidnap Plot Fabrication
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 17 (AP)  Leaders of the White Panther party denied today charges that the group consid ered kidnapping Vice President Agnew and others to gain re lease of jailed radicals, terming them a total fabrication.

title: Pan Am Will Seek New Stock Class
description: Pan American World Airways will ask stockholders at their annual meeting on May 4 to authorize a new class of 20 million shares of $1 par value preferred stock as well as to increase the authorized com mon stock to 80 million shares from the present 60 million shares.

title: Thoeni Upset by German In Italian Giant Slalom
description: VIPITENO, Italy, March 17 (UPI)  West Germany's Sepp Heckelmiller defeated the new world champion, Gustavo Tho eni of Italy, today in the giant slalom event of the interna tional military ski champion ship.

title: 2 Industrial Teams Back Cape Kennedy as the Assembly Point and Launching Base for Space Shuttle
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 17 Two aerospace industrial teams have recommended to the space agency that Cape Kennedy, Fla., be the final assembly point and the launching base for the space shuttle, the multibillion dollar postApollo project planned for the late 1970's.

title: EFFECTS OF CUTS IN VOLTAGE CITED
description: A 5 per cent voltage reduc tion  such as was imposed during recent electric power squeezes  dims the ordinary tungstenfilament lamp about 15 per cent, the State Public Service Commission was told yesterday, but operating at such a rate could lengthen its life to about twice as long.

title: ANTHONY COLOMBO FILES LIBEL SUIT
description: Anthony Colombo, 25year old son of Joseph Colombo Sr., sued Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., and WCBSChan nel 2 for $1million yesterday, charging that he had been libeled and defamed in a tele cast that described him as a reputed Mafia leader.

title: Greece to Shut 2 Prison Camps; Revises Plan to Free All Exiles
description: ATHENS, March 17  The Greek Government announced plans today to shut two politi cal prison camps on Leros is land next month. But it left unfulfilled its expressed hope to free all of its exiled opponents.

title: ComposerPerformers Present Concert at Whitney Museum
description: There is not much point in approaching The Open Window, a group that of fered a concert on Tuesday night at the Whitney Muse um in search of seriousness. Its musical aims seemed on this occasion so unpreten tious as to be disarming. The Open Window was out to entertain, a noble enough reason for putting on a con cert; unfortunately one's in terest could not quite remain fastened to the results.

title: Bricklayer Falls to Death From East Side Building
description: A bricklayer fell 35 stories to his death yesterday when a scaffold rope snapped, but a second worker managed to hold on and swing onto a terrace to safety.

title: Perth Amboy Tanker Afire
description: Fire broke out early this morning on the Liberian tank er Trade Daring, tied up at the Hess Oil Company docks in Perth Amboy, N.J. The ship was towed into the Kill Van Kull as a precautionary mea sure.

title: Louisiana Dealer Will Sell Russian Supersonic Plane
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 17 A Berwick, La., aircraft dealer said today that he had reached an exclusive agreement with the Soviet Union to sell the Russian TU144 supersonic transport in the Western Hemi sphere.

title: 2 From State on Port Unit Wary Over Mass Transit
description: At least two of New York's six commissioners on the Port of New York Authority split with the six New Jersey com missioners who joined with Gov. William T. Cahill on Tues day in a call for a greater au thority role in mass transporta tion.

title: Gets 5 Years in Child's Death
description: A 21yearold Bronx man was sentenced in Bronx Su preme Court yesterday to five years in prison for the fatal beating pf his 1yearold daughter in July. The man, Anthony McCray of 1057 Simp son Street, faced a maximum sentence of 15 years on the second  degree manslaughter charge to which he pleaded guilty.

title: Bus Falls Off Peak
description: BRISBANE, Australia, March 17 (AP) Two children were killed and 23 others and the driver were injured today when a school bus fell 300 feet down a mountainside near Woodford, 50 miles north of here.

title: Dull Double Bill
description: There is a great deal of dull, speculative yammering about sex in a pair of dogs titled "Kama Sutra" and "Bora Bora," which opened yesterday on a circuit double-bill.If you can stay awake through "Bora Bora," which speaks for itself, you'll see a moldy, dinky little marital story pasted against the mouth-watering background of Tahiti, so awesome and exotic, even in runny color, as to make the story, direction and acting seem even drearier than they are. As a bickering American couple, visiting the islands, Haydee Politoff and Corrado Pani are stultifying. The dialogue of this French-Italian project was dubbedor drubbedin English.The other picture, at the finale, is at least pepped up, if not elevated, by the wallowing, half-simulated orgy of a braying, simpering group of American couples. The rest of the film, moving like molasses and tinted in purplish green, has an English narrator droning away about the wisdom of Kama Sutra, that ancient book of sex mastery from India.Illustrating it are two self-conscious newlywed natives shown in panting facial close-up and an older, giggly pair who need a bath even more than they need good old Kama Sutra, which hits the floor for that all-out, American-style scramble at the end.

title: According to Plan, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)  The Defense Depart ment said today that the South Vietnamese forces in Laos were engaged in mobile maneuver ing and were proceeding ac cording to plan.

title: The Talk of South Boston
description: BOSTON, March 17An unexpectedly warm March sun streamed through the window into a dusty corner of the Boston Public Library yesterday and picked out Clement Agustine Norton huddled over a wild collec tion of books, magazines, newspapers and neatly typed and indexed notes. His hands flicked down from a pair of plasticrimmed glasses to hover over a pile of notes like a witching wand sensing the wellspring.

title: O. T. B. PROPOSES AID TO HORSEMEN
description: In an apparent effort to head off possible disputes with horsemen, the City's Offtrack Betting Corporation is seeking State permission to earmark some of its revenue for higher purses and backstretchem ployee benefits.

title: RABBI STEINBERG
description: Rabbi Ephraim Steinberg, an instructor of Talmud at the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theologi cal Seminary for 46 years, died Tuesday night in Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 74 years old and lived at 2514 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Forces Move Back
description: SAIGON, Thursday, March 18  Some South Vietnamese forces in Laos continued to move southeast back toward the border yesterday, trying to consolidate their positions after running into intense Commu nist attacks.

title: MOSCOW INCIDENT PROTESTED BY U.S.; Dobrvnin Is Given Note on ?? Entry' at Embassy
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 The United States accused the Soviet Union today of violating both international law and a twoyearold consular conven tion. The charges, in a strongly worded note, referred to yes terday's forcible entry by So viet policemen into the prem ises of the United States Ern bassy in Moscow.

title: Seagren Wins in Japan
description: HITACHI, Japan, March 17 (AP)Bob Seagren of the United States cleared 17 feet today to win the pole vault in a track meet.

title: The Opera: A Rarely Heard Olimpiade
description: So New York has now heard an opera by Johann Adolf Hasse. Clarion Con certs, in Tully Hall Tuesday evening, presented a concert performance of Olimpiade, and believes that it is the first performance since the composer's day. Considering that Hasse's dates are 1698 1782, and that Olimpiade was composed in 1756, that is indeed a long stretch.

title: CITY COLLEGE SETS A NEW DRUG POLICY
description: Dr. Robert E. Marshak, the president of City College, offi cially endorsed yesterday a studentfaculty report that called for the use of the police to rid the campus of drug pushers.

title: In Pakistan, Some Flee to the East as Others Seek Haven in West
description: DACCA, Pakistan, March 17 Carrying all their belongings of value, their children bal anced on their hips and cradled in their arms, nervous Bengalis are fleeing West Pakistan. Equally nervous Punjabis and other West Pakistanis are flee ing East Pakistan in reverse.

title: Art Gallery Owner Seized as Receiver Of Stolen Paintings
description: The police and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday arrested the owner of a Madison Avenue art gallery and charged him with receiving nearly $70,000 worth of paint ings stolen last November from the warehouse of the Parke Bernet galleries.

title: Finland's Government Quits In Split Over Price Controls
description: HELSINKI, Finland, March 17 (Reuters)The fiveparty coali tion Government of Premier Ahti K. Karjalainen resigned today because of an internal split over price controls. Dr. Karjalainen presented the resignation of his Cabinet to President Urho Kekkonen after members of Parliament from the Communist party, one of the coalition partners, had voted against a bill to free 15 items from price controls. The principal items were coffee, cigarettes and sugar. The bill was approved, but Dr. Karjalainen had said before the balloting that it would be impossible for the Government to continue with a split in Its ranks.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The private healthinsurance indus try has testified to a Senate subcom mittee that a national system of med ical care should be administered through private healthinsurance com paniesnaturally.

title: The Screen: Japanese Barber in War
description: Shinobu Hashimoto's I Want to Be a Shellfish, which opened at the Bijou yesterday on a double bill with Kurosawa's Hidden Fortress, is a film so marked by its negative virtues that I am persuaded to admire it despite its inability to rise more than a foot or so above the pathos that is its primary subject.

title: Iran Executes 13 in Gang
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 17 (AP)  Thirteen members of an underground gang, charged with killing, armed robbery, il legal possession of arms and forging Government documents, were executed today by a firing squad after a secret military trial, the Government an nounced.

title: SCION OF BIDDLES, A DRIFTER, KILLED
description: HADDONFIELD, N. J. March 17 (AP) Winthrop L. Biddle, scion of a prominent Philadel phia family who became a drifter in southern New Jersey, was struck and killed today by a hitrun driver.

title: Bipartisan Group in Congress Urges a Legal Services Corporation for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, March 17A bipartisan group of 98 Sena tors and Representatives pro posed today that the often embattled program of Federal legal services for the poor be permanently insulated from po litical pressures.

title: Personal Finance: Credit and Ratings
description: An indication that the re cession is hitting home comes in the latest figures that show families are paying their bills more slowly. The New York State Bankers As sociation has disclosed that, as of the start of February, the delinquency throughout the state is at record levels.

title: Staff at 2 Papers In Chicago Protest Support for Daley
description: CHICAGO, March 17 Most of the city reporters and edi tors at The Chicago Daily News and SunTimes have signed petitions criticizing the Field newspapers' endorsement of Mayor Richard J. Daley for a fifth term and asking for an opposing staffwritten editorial.

title: I.C.C. DEFENDS ROLE IN PENNSY'S MERGER
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 The Interstate Commerce Com mission defended today its role in approving the merger of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads into the now bankrupt Penn Central Railroad and said obviously the merger was not enough.

title: Robert K. Hamilton, Banker And Businessman in Jersey
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N. J., March 17Robert K. Hamilton, of 125 Maple Place, a leader in banking and business here for many years, died yesterday in Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield. He was 72 years old.

title: China Says Soviet Is Tool In Workers' Suppression
description: HONG KONG, March 17Communist China charged today that the Soviet Union had become a tool with which the restored bourgeoisie suppressed the working class. The statement, transmitted by Hsinhua, the Chinese Commu nist press agency, was the first major ideological attack on the Russians in almost a year.

title: President of Engelhard Named Chief Executive
description: The Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation an nounced yesterday in Newark that Milton F. Rosenthal, 57 years old, president of the con cern since 1964, had been elected chief executive officer.

title: Authorize Wins by Neck In $33,600 Florida Stake
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 17Fred W. Hooper, the own erbreeder, is an astute horse man, but he appears to have made a $5,000 mistake when he nominated Pitching Wedge for the $100,000 added Florida Derby to be run at Gulfstream Park a week from Saturday and neglected to nominate Au thorize.

title: Infant Mortality Rate in City Drops to a Record Low
description: New York City's infant mor tality rate dropped to a record low in 1970, the Health De partment reported yesterday.

title: GRAINPRICE PACT WITH BRITISH SET
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) The Nixon Administra tion announced today a new graintrade agreement with Britain that will result in some increases in minimum import prices for United States grain entering that country.

title: Bill Would List Doctors
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)Senator Clinton P. An derson, Democrat of New Mex ico, introduced a bill today requiring that the names of physicians being paid more than $10,000 a year from Medi care and Medicaid programs be made public.

title: Uneasy Riders
description: Disclosure by the Transit Authority of its growing deficits has the familiar ring of that softening process intended to prepare subway and bus riders for the next round of fare increases. A serious factor in the alarming rise in operating losses appears to be a steady decline 6 per cent in five yearsin the number of passengers who use the public transportation system.

title: Personal Income Up a Bit in February
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 Two more economic indicators supported today the picture of a relatively sluggish economy in February.

title: Illness of Juror in Calley Trial Threatens to Halt Deliberations
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Thurs day, March 18The sudden ill ness of a juror late last night threatened a probable suspen sion of jury deliberations on the fate of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., charged with the pre meditated murder of 102 South Vietnam civilians at Mylai three years ago.

title: U.S. AIDE CRITICIZES JAPAN ON TEXTILES
description: The textile dispute with Japan exemplifies the strik ing inconsistency in Japanese trade policy, a high Commerce Department official said yester day.

title: Funds Said to Be Key to G. I. Pullout Rate
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 17The United States command in Saigon has told Washington that a lack of money for the Vietnam war has been more crucial in determin ing the rate of troop withdraw als than has the progress of Vietnamization or what the enemy does on the battefield.

title: NEW RIOTS FEARED IN ARGENTINE CITY
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 17 (UPI)  Union leaders in riot torn Crdoba, working from un derground headquarters to avoid arrest, announced a new antiGovernment strike for to morrow, raising the threat of more violence.

title: More Laughable Than Shocking:Gloria Grahame Cast in 'Blood and Lace'
description: There's a good deal of blood and a minimum of logic, or lace for that matter, in "Blood and Lace," which was exposed in local theaters yesterday, to illustrate, we assume, that horror can be both vague and silly. Exposed also are Gloria Grahame and a clutch of decidedly lesser-known performers in a low-grade exercise in shadows, screams, traumas and slayings that are largely more laughable than shocking.There is, for openers, the hammer murder of a prostitute whose daughter, Melody Patterson, a blond chick beside herself with neuroses, hate for her mother and a yen to find her father, is sent to the local orphanage run by Miss Grahame.Miss Grahame is not a standard type. She needs the money she gets for operating her sylvan concentration camp and when youngsters try to break out, she has them caught with the aid of her wacky handy man, Len Lesser, who dispatches them with a cleaver and hangs them up in the orphanage's basement freezer.In the convoluted and mindless plot, Miss Grahame indicates through dialogue that is neither scientific, clear nor reasonable that she has a thing for preserving bodies.Everyone, it might be noted, gets his just deserts, including a social worker (Milton Selzer) with eyes for Miss Grahame; and a middle-aged detective (Vic Taybeck) who, it turns out in the ironic, climatic twist, has more than a casually amorous relationship with our young heroine.The haggard Miss Grahame, who simply walks through her assignment and at one point says, somewhat wistfully, "Oh, yes, I was young once," also ends up in her own deadly freezer. That frigid ending, at least, seems proper, even if "Blood and Lace" is hardly a recommendation for freezers or flimsy films in the genre.

title: Ellender Honored in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)The Senate Agriculture Committee today honored Sen ator Allen J. Ellender, Dem ocrat of Louisiana, who headed the committee longer than any previous Senator. Senator El lender was chairman of the committee for 18 years prior to last January, when he relin quished the post to become head of the Senate Appropria tions Committee. He remains a member of the Agriculture Committee, however.

title: Precinct Heads Are Given Initiative to Combat Graft
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has begun requiring that precinct commanders  rather than headquarters in vestigating units  assume re sponsibility for bringing charges of corruption and other serious misconduct against any of their men suspected of wrongdoing.

title: Disordered Economic Policy
