description: A group of 43 politicial leaders yesterday denounced as irre sponsible an effort to repeal the part of last year's rent control amendments that au thorizes a second round of rent increases next January.

title: Indicted Newark Man Is Named Investigator
description: NEWARK, March 19Frank Addonizio, a former City Councilman here who is awaiting prosecution under a 66count Federal indictment charging extortion and con spiracy, is scheduled to take up his duties on Monday as one of three newly appointed investigators of fraud for the Essex County Welfare Board.

title: PPG PLANS BIG PLANT MAKING FLOAT GLASS
description: CARLISLE, Pa, March 19 PPG Industries today announced plans to build what is believed to be the world's largest float glass plant at a cost of more that $50million.

title: Isaksson Sets Indoor Vault Mark of 179
description: CLEVELAND, March 19 (UPI) Kjell Isaksson of Sweden set a world indoor pole vault rec ord of 17 feet 9 inches tonight in the Knights of Columbus track meet.

title: Hoist the Flag Heads Field of 11 in $34,900 Bay Shore at Aqueduct Today
description: Hoist the Flag, Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s colt who was the champion of his division 1970, will encounter more op position than was expected in the sevenfurlong Bay Shore Aqueduct today.

title: Pirates Sink Mets, 52, With 4 homers, 2 Off Koosman
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 19 The New York Mets got their last look at the Pittsburgh Pi rates today before the pennant race opens and they saw more signs that the summer of 1971 might be as troublous as the summer of 1970.

title: Operating Loss at Benrus Is Put at Over $2Million
description: The Benrus Corporation esti mated its operating loss for the year ended Jan. 31 at over $2 million. Victor K. Kiam 2d, president, said that in addition it was estimated that nonre curring losses in connection with restructuring of watch manufacturing facilities, a pre viously announced change in marketing policies, writeoffs of physical assets and revaluation of inventories would also be in excess of $2million.

title: Bach Group to Audition
description: The Institute for Bach Studies of the International Bach Socie ty will hold auditions on April 7 and 8 for fellowships for the 1971 Bach Society Congress. Professional musicians and ad vanced students in the fields of singing and instrumental play ing are eligible to enter the auditions. Application forms may be obtained by writing to the Institute for Bach Studies at 140 West 57th Street, New York, 10019.

title: FORMER GOVERNOR NOW TV NEWSMAN
description: SANTE FE, N. M., March 17 The television ratings aren't in yet so no one is sure whether former Gov. David F. Cargo will succeed as a tele vision newsman.

title: CITY COLLEGE TO END ITS R.O.T.C. PROGRAM
description: City College will discontinue its Reserve Officers Training Corps next year, after 52 years on campus.

title: MRS. NATHAN GARTEN
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 19 Mrs. Ethel Hyman Garten, widow of Nathan Garten, a New York real estate man, died to day in White Plains Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived at 116 Lake Shore Drive, East chester.

title: Seize College Offices
description: NEWTON, Mass., March 19 (AP)About 30 students, most of them women, seized the of fices of Boston College's dean of students and vice president for student affairs today. The protesters, calling themselves the Women's Action Commit tee, said that a list of demands given to the administration earlier this week had not been satisfactorily answered.

title: TV System To Connect Local Units
description: A microwave television network will link the offices of 16 local governments in the metropolitan area start ing this autumn, officials of the Metropolitan Regional Council announced yester day.

title: RAP BROWN CASE TO BE REVIEWED
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., March 19  A lawyer for H. Rap Brown, the fugitive black mili tant, won permission today to stage a full court hearing here next month on the validity of the Maryland charges from which Mr. Brown fled a year ago.

title: Mohawk and Its Pilots Agree on a Plan for Arbitration
description: Mohawk Airlines and its pilots, who have been on strike since Nov. 12, agreed yester day to submit their contract dispute to binding arbitration unless they can resolve the principal issues by next Thurs day.

title: Amy Amizich Is Shot Ahead In Orange Blossom With 70
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 (UPI)Amy Amizich of Honolulu shot a twounder par 70 today to take a one stroke lead in the $20,000 Orange Blossom Classic at the Pasadena Golf and Country Club.

title: YANKS CAN'T KICK THE LOSING HABIT
description: MIAMI, March 19The Yan kees not only lost their 11th straight game tonighta 64 decision to the Baltimore Oriolesbut they also lost player and a coach along the way.

title: Break in Pakistani Deadlock Indicated at Talks
description: DACCA, Pakistan, March 19  The first apparent break in the tense deadlock between the two feuding sections of Pakis tan came today with a clear indication of movement in :the talks between the leader of East Pakistan, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, and the President of Pakistan, Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, over. East Pakis tan's demand's for selfrule.

title: ARMY'S RIOT ROLE LAUDED BY GIEREK
description: WARSAW, March 19Ed ward Gierek, Poland's Commu nist party leader, indicated to day that only firm action by the Polish Army in putting down last December's anti Government riots kept Soviet troops from intervening.

title: Three for Off Broadway
description: Three Off Broadway plays were announced yesterday for presentation this season. Donald Goldman will produce Eric Bentley's The Red White and Black at the Players Theater, 115 Macdougal Street, March 30. Jack Marshall's The Olathe Response will be put on April 5 by Rene Enriquez and Mr. Marshall at the Actors Play house, 100 Seventh Avenue. Any Resemblance to Persons Living or Dead, a comedy by Elliot A. Caplan, is announced for production in May by Lou Na Poseidon, Ltd., in associa tion with Robert L. Steele.

title: The Navajo vs the Bulldozer
description: SANTA FE, N. M.  On the hogans of the old sheep herders of the Navajo people, in northern Arizona, the snow is heavy. It buries not only the sheep pastures but also the stripmining machinery. The bulldozers that lave been gutting the sacred Black Moun tain, the Female Mountain of the Navajo's religious belief, are momen tarily silenced.

title: Russians Plan Wide Expansion In APower Generating Stations
description: MOSCOW, March 19While the future of nuclear power in the United States continues to be obscured by controversy, the Soviet Union has decided after long hesitation to embark on an ambitious program of ex pansion of atomic generating plants.

title: EDWARD FOWLES OF ART GALLERY
description: Edward Fowles, former own er of the Duveen Brothers art gallery, died yesterday at his winter home in Holetown, Bar bados, West Indies. He was 85 years old and lived also in Mount Kisco, N. Y., and New York.

title: Moderate Chosen to Form New Turkish Government
description: ANKARA, March 19  Presi dent Cevdet Sunay ended week of constitutional crisis today by designating a re spected middleoftheroad poli tician to form a new govern ment. The President also called on all parliamentary groups to give the new leader, Nihat Erim, their unconditional sup port.

title: Cotton knit dress over shorts is by Eric Lund for Narcissa. About $35.
description: Shop Talk

title: NEW ISSUES SHOW GAINS FOR WEEK
description: The newissue market, where shares of companies that have never previously had public owners are traded, registered its third consecutive advance this week in fairly heavy trading.

title: Brimmer Favors Tax Cut If Economy Needs Stimulus
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 A member of the Federal Re serve Board said today the economy might well need more stimulus this year but that it should come through fiscal measures such as tax reduction rather than still easier monetary policy.

title: 16 Young Radicals Convicted in Prague In Subversion Trial
description: PRAGUE, March 19 (Reuters) Sixteen young radical left ists, who said they were op posed to Communist bureauc cracy but not to Communism, were convicted of subversion today and sentenced to prison terms of one to four years.

title: Merger News
description: Stockholders of American Airlines, the nation's second largest domestic air carrier, and Western Air Lines, the sixth largest, approved yester day a merger initially proposed in a different form last Oc tober.

title: Indians Denied Free Ride
description: ALBANY, March 19 (UPI) The head of the State Thruway Authority said today that de spite ancient treaties, Indians must pay tolls just as any one else does to use the Gov, Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. Some Indians had demanded tollfree us of the highway, say ing that early treaties gave them free access to all turn pikes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Stewart Does Fastest Lap In TuneUp at Brands Hatch
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, March 19 (AP)Jackie Stewart of Scotland, in his latest Tyr rellFord, set the pace in rain drenched practice drives today, for Sunday's Race of Cham pions. The former world cham pion did the twisting 2.65mile circuitin 1 minute 41.1 seconds an average speed of 94.36 miles an hour.

title: State MentalHygiene Employes Are Told Not to Lobby on the Job
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., March 19 The State Department of Mental Hygiene has directed its employes and patients not to use state resources or their own working time to lobby against proposed legislative budget cuts.

title: Plan to Dispense Free Heroin Elicits Caution From 2 Doctors
description: The suggestion that free her oin be dispensed to addicts in the United States was described yesterday as, at best, something to be approached with great caution and, at worst, a pub lic health catastrophe.

title: SST Gains in the Senate; Key Vote Set Wednesday
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 informal polling of Senators Showed gains for supporters of the supersonic transport today as the Senate scheduled a new and possibly final vote on the controversial airliner for next Wednesday.

title: White House Plans For Youth Parley Criticized by Bloc
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 The Nixon Administration was accused today of seeking to curtail public awareness of and citizen participation in next month's White House Confer ence on Youth in an effort to eliminate controversy.

title: Reciprocal Security Urged For Film Industry in U.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, March 19 (AP)Mayor Sam Yorty has advised an aide to President Nixon that without reciprocal protections the American Film industry will cease to exist.

title: INFLATION RATE IN NATION EASES FOR A 29 MONTH
Orders Drop 1.7% On Durable Goods
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 A decline in new orders for durable goods rounded out today a picture of rela tively sluggish economic in dicators for February.

title: Jewish Veterans Bar Protest
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)The Jewish War Veter ans of the U.S.A. will not sup port a Sunday White House demonstration for freeing So viet Jews, a spokesman said today, calling such protests disruptive and unprofitable.

title: U.S. Agency Says Snow Raises Threat of Floods in Northeast
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 The United States Geological Survey reported today that snow depth and snow water content in the Northeast were far above normal.

title: Ballet: A Canadian Visit
description: NEWARK  Although the Royal Winnipeg Ballet, as the name would suggest, is a Canadian ballet company, it has an international reputa tionit has even been to the Soviet Unionspends a great deg of its time touring, visit ing the United States every year, and not one of its cur rent six principal dancers [happens to be Canadianborn. It is a small North American touring company, based in Winnipeg where it has a school, and comprised of about 25 dancers.

title: Talks to Be Exploratory
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 19 (Agence FrancePresse)It was understood here today that direct talks between British and Rhodesian officials would be held in Capetown and would be exploratory.

title: Show Is Suspended as Artists Dissent
description: Dissent by a number of artists has caused the in definite postponement of a show organized by the Art Gallery of the Center for InterAmerican Relations, 680 Park Avenue.

title: MARKET DECLINES AS TRADING SLIPS
description: Stock prices drifted down ward in relatively slow trading yesterday, but the market had its share of individual movers.

title: U.S. Navy Faces New Setback in Culebra
description: CULEBRA, Puerto Rico, March 11  A campaign of demonstrations motivated by concern for ecology, hopes for Puerto Rican independence, and, perhaps, for future real estate values has won one victory over the United States Navy on this island and could win another.

title: Religious Hypocrisy
description: No normal person validly denies the existence of a world that shows order ly intelligence in its origin and its creation by some power. If we agree that this power was a conscious and intelligent force that is still function ing, then we fulfill the literal defini tion of believers in God. We can then modify this belief by the assumption that after they were created, the world and man were left to their own de vices and their creator figuratively washed his hands of his own elab orate creation.

title: END OF LAOS DRIVE HINTED IN SAIGON; 2,000 WITHDRAWN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, March 20The South Vietnamese command an nounced yesterday that it had withdrawn 2,000 to 3,000 of its troops from action in Laos in 48 hours.

title: JIM HALL IS HEARD IN A JAZZ PROGRAM
description: Jim Hall brought his deft and subtle guitar to the Jazz Ad ventures series yesterday after noon at Downbeat, Lexington Avenue at 42d Street, and both he and the audience made a happy discovery.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION DROPS SLIGHTLY
description: DETROIT, March 19 (AP) Domestic automobile production continued steady this week with the industry planning to as semble its twomillionth car of calendar 1971 two and a half weeks earlier than last year.

title: Study Shows Heart Tablets Lose Potency in Plastic Vial
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 Nitroglycerine tablets, used by millions of heartdisease suffer ers whenever they experience the chest pains of angina pec tors, lose their potency if dis pensed in plastic vials or stored in plastic containers or strip, packaging, a graduate student] at the University of Maryland has found.

title: Ingrid Bergman, Serene at 55
description: LONDON  Twenty years ago Ingrid Bergman shocked her fans, outraged the Daugh ters of the American Revolu tion and saw her films boy cotted in the United States.

title: Utility Nominates Woman
description: The president of the League of Women Voters of the United States, Lucy Wilson Benson, has been nominated to be a trustee of Northeast Utilities. She would fill the board va cancy to be left by the retire ment of Stanley M. Cooper, re tired chairman of the Fafnir Bearing division of Textron, Inc. Northeast Utilities has op erating subsidiaries in Massa chusetts and Connecticut.

title: Mrs. Rosenstiel Pleads
description: Susan L. Rosenstiel, the di vorced wife of Lewis Rosen stiel, pleaded not guilty yes terday to misderneanor perjury charges stemming from a $9, 900 lawsuit she filed against her bank, the Bankers Trust Company. A grand jury had charged her with three counts of perjury in her testimony at a pretrial hearing on her suit, in which she alleged that the amount was changed on check she had written. Judge Irving Lang of Criminal Court set May 13 for a jury trial.

title: Godfather Film Won't Mention Mafia
description: At the request of the Italian American Civil Rights League, the producer of the film The Godfather has eliminated all references to the Mafia and Cosa Nostra from the screen play, which is based on the bestselling novel about Mafia family.

title: MARTIN KYNE, 72, A UNION LEADER
description: Martin C. Kyne, an interna tional vice president of the Re tail, Wholesale and Department Store Union and president of its Local 923, died Thursday at his home, 99 Metropolitan Oval, the Bronx. His age was 72.

title: Businessmen Elect Chief
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)  John D. Harper, chair man of the board and chief executive officer of Aluminum Company of America, has been elected chairman of the Na tional Alliance of Businessmen, the White House announced today.

title: Donald C. Malcom Rites Will Be Held Next Friday
description: A funeral service for Donald Canmore Malcom, retired man ufacturer and a veteran of World War I, will be held next Friday at Trinity Church, New port, R. I. He died at the Amer can Hospital, Neuilly, France, on March 5 after a brief illness at the age of 78.

title: N.Y.U. Is Leading N.C.A.A. Fencing With Round to Go
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, March 19New York University led by George Sztinyogh, its unde feated pe star, took a 2point lead over the University of Detroit after today's second round of the National Colle giate fencing championships at the Air Force Academy.

title: INCUMBENT IS RULED U.M.W. VOTE WINNER
description: PITTSBURGH, March 19 (AP) Michael Budzanoski, incum bent president of United Mine Workers District 5, was de clared the winner of a contro versial election today.

title: Crime Panel Reportedly Urged Mackell to Drop Aide
description: A former member of the State Commission of Investi gation said yesterday that the commission had asked Queens District Attorney Thomas A. Mackell four years ago to dis charge a key assistant because of his record in the Police Department.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A WARNING REPEATED ON MEAT TENDERIZER
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)Following the death of a Maryland man, the Food and Drug Administration repeated today an urgent warning about a poison mistakenly sold as meat tenderizer in seven states.

title: Gallup Fondly Recalls Friendship With Dewey
description: On Nov. 3, 1948, as the elec tion tallies disclosed the major upset of modern American pol itics, the second biggest loser in the country was probably Dr. George H. Gallup, whose Polls had promised the Presi dency to Thomas E. Dewey by a decisive margin.

title: Vermont Boy, 15, Triumphs In Combined Nordic Skiing
description: BOREAL RIDGE, Calif., March 19 (UPI)Ron Yeager of Durando, Colo., won the boys' 10kilometer crosscoun try race in 31 minutes 58 sec onds today, but the combined title in the national junior Nordic ski championships went to 15yearold Bill Koch of Putney, Vt.

title: COLUMBIA SENATE ASSAILS VIOLENCE
description: The Columbia University Senate, by a 53to6 vote, yes terday approved a resolution condemning classroom disrup tion and other violent, coer cive or destructive actions that interfere with academic freedom at the university.

title: President Selects A JobSafety Chief And Review Board
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)  The White House an nounced today the selection of George C. Guenther to direct the Federal Government's re cently enacted job health and safety program covering more than 50 million persons.

title: Controversy on Vietnam Policy Has Abated on Capitol Hill for the Moment
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 For the time being, at least, the controversy over the Viet nam issue has abated on Cap itol Hill.

title: Books of The Times
description: KEATS AND HIS POETRY. A Study of His Development. By Morris Dickstein. 270 pages. University of Chicago. $9.50.

title: 4Day, 40Hour Work Week Gains in Small Companies
description: MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., March 17  James nicker sank back in the couch and began the pleasant task, as he has done on every Thurs day evening for the last year, of speculating about how he Would spend his threeday weekend.

title: Music of Mike Seeger Draws A Crowd to Folklore Center
description: Listeners eager to catch Mike Seeger, just back from a tour of Australia, New Zealand and Japan and en route to Saratoga Springs to appear tonight and tomorrow at the Cafe Lena, packed the Folklore Center, 321 Avenue of the Americas, on Thursday. They overflowed out the door and were squeezed into a storage room in the back.

title: PHONE COMPANY DRAWS PROTEST
description: Blue, white and gold posters papered along the lower East Sides Madison Street proclaim that Public Enemy Number 1 is the New York Telephone Company.

title: Black Artist Shows in Whitney Lobby
description: In the latest of its shows devoted to minority artists, the Whitney Museum has in stalled in its lobby gallery an exhibition of paintings and drawings by Malcolm Bailey, a 23yearold black painter whose auspicious debut oc curred in 1969 at the Cinque Gallery, a very offMadison Avenue showcase for young ethnic talent.

title: SHOEEXPORT PLAN OFFERED BY MILES
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (Reuters)Representative Wil bur D. Mills, the Arkansas Democrat who helped to per suade the Japanese textile industry to impose voluntary restrictions on exports to the United States, said today that a similar formula should be ap plied to shoe imports.

title: U.S. Officers in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 19 (UPI)  A sixman United States Air Force delegation headed by Maj. Gen. Kenneth 0. Sanborn, commanding the Air Force, Southern Command, in the Panama Canal Zone, ar rived in Chile today to partici pate in the 40th anniversary celebrations of the Chilean Air Force,

title: DAYTON HUDSON GAINS IN QUARTER
description: Net income of the Dayton Hudson Corporation rose in the final quarter but fell in the fiscal year ended Jan. 30, 1971, the retail chain reported yes terday.

title: 6 U.S. Medical Students in Mexico Sue for Hospital Internships Here
description: Six students from New York who are attending medical school in Mexico filed a law suit yesterday to obtain in ternships in hospitals in the city.

title: CHARLES F. LEWIS, LED CONSERVANCY
description: PITTSBURGH, March 19 Dr. Charles Fletcher Lewis, whose successful career as a newspaperman was followed by activity in conservation and other civic endeavors, died to day at his home. He was 81 years old.

title: 34th N.I.T. Begins Today at Garden With Five Games
description: The 34th annual National In vitation Tournament opens to day at Madison Square Garden with eight hours of basketball, some of the nation's top col lege scorers and rebounders, and a wide open race for team honors.

title: Yankee Hostage Survives Taxing Day in Venezuela
description: MIAMI, March 19  Dip lomats in the United States and Venezuela can relax. L'Affaire. Fislel has ended, eradicating the threat of a cessation in friendly relations between the countries.

title: Eban Meets With Rogers, Bars Pullback to '67 Line
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel emphatically reaffirmed today that his country would never withdraw to the bound aries before the 1967 war as the price for a peace treaty with the United Arab Republic.

title: SOVIET DENIES PLAN TO EASE JEWS' VISAS
description: MOSCOW, March 19 (UPI) Authoritative Soviet sources to day denied reports that the Soviet Union intended to issue 300,000 visas over the next few years to Jews who want to leave the Soviet Union.

title: 76ers Oust Royals, 147127
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 19 (UPI)Archie Clark scored 24 points and Hal Greer and Con nie Dierking added 20 apiece as the Philadelphia 76ers trounced the Cincinnati Royals, 147127, tonight. The loss eliminated the Royals from the N.B.A. playoff berth.

title: ROCKETS DESCRIBE HAYWOOD'S PACTS
description: LOS ANGELES, March 19 (AP)  Details of, two con tracts signed in 1969 by Spen cer Haywood were unfolded be fore a jury in Federal court to day in the Denver Rockets' breach of contract suit against the former rookie of the year in the American Basketball Asso ciation.

title: SUGAR FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Interest in world sugar fu tures dissolved hero yesterday as a result of a sharp break in such futures at London, The decline was attfibuted to a weakening of sugar prices gen erally.

title: Consumer Complaint Office Dedicated in Forest Hills
description: What was described as the first government  financed neighborhood consumer com plaint office in the country was formally opened yester day amid considerable con fusion in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: OIL CONCERNS OFFER 4 COUNTRIES A DEAL
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, March 19 (Reuters)Western oil compa nies have offered a package deal to four Mediterranean oil exporting countries aimed at breaking deadlocked talks here on oil prices, informed sources said tonight.

title: Swallows at Capistrano
description: SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif., March 19 (UPI) The mission bells pealed as the sun broke through the fog and the swallows returned to Capi strano today again this year as they have for nearly 200 years.

title: Airport Copter in Emergency
description: A New York Airways heli copter that shuttles passengers between Newark, La Guardia and Kennedy airports made an emergency landing at 4:30 yes terday afternoon on a baseball diamond in Flushing Meadow Park with 22 passengers aboard. A spokesman for the company said that the pilot heard something foreign to him and made a normal precaution ary landing. He said there were no injuries.

title: Sadat Visits Libyan Chief
description: CAIRO, March 19President Anwar elSadat flew to Libya yesterday for talks with Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Lib yan Premier, the Egyptian Mid dle East News Agency reported [tonight.

title: Rhodesian Talks Said to Be Near; London Denies It
description: LONDON, March 19  In formed sources in Rhodesia were quoted today as saying that peace talks between that breakaway colony and the Brit ish Government Would begin in a few days. But the reports, from Agence FrancePresse, were, denied by the Govern ment in London.

title: XRAY SOURCE FOUND BEYOND MILKY WAY
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)  The discovery of a new and extremely powerful source of Xrays in deep space trillions of miles beyond the Milky Way was announced to day by the Navy, which termed it a major scientific discov ery.

title: Unbeaten Penn Faces Villanova in Eastern N.C.A.A. Basketball Final To
description: RALEIGH, N. C., March 19  Pennsylvania, the only un defeated baseketball team in the nation and Villanova will meet tomorrow afternoon in the first battle of neighborhood riv als ever staged in the quarter finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship.

title: 3 LI. Lawyers Convicted Of Extortion Conspiracy
description: A former assistant state at torney general and two other Long Island lawyers were found guilty here yesterday of con spiracy to extort and attempted extortion.

title: Army Pushes Reform on OffBase Housing Bias
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI)Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor announced to day major policy changes de signed to end offbase housing discrimination wherever Amer ican soldiers are stationed and to help make sure Negroes get fairer treatment generally.

title: The Powerful Mills Tells Presidents No
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 When the news broke last May that Speaker John W. McCormack was retiring, Rep resentative Wilbur D. Mills was presiding over a meet ing of his House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Indictment in Bomb Plot
description: AKRON, Ohio, March 19 (UPI) A grand jury today indicted Charles Lawrence, Akron or ganizer of the. National Social ist White People's party, on charges of placing a bomb on the front porch of the home of Ben Maidenburg, executive edi tor and publisher of The Akron Beacon Journal.

title: Israeli Jet Intrusion Is Charged by Egypt
description: CAIRO, March 19The Unit ed Arab Republic reported to day that two Israeli Phantom jet fighterbombers intruded into Egyptian air space this morning near the northern end of the Suez Canal and were challenged by antiaircraft de fenses.

title: 5% PRIME RATE ADOPTED BY BANKS
description: Interest rates on business loans and savings accounts de clined yesterday.

title: Merger News
description: The Walter E. Heller Inter national Corporation, a Chicago based, worldwide commercial finance company with $990 million in assets, emerged yes terday as the leading contender to take over the Security Na tional Bank, a $1billion institu tion based in Huntington, L.I.

title: Minnesota Upsets Harvard, 65, In Overtime, Gains Hockey Final
description: SYRACUSE, March 19Min nesota, a fifthplace finisher in its own Western Association and a definite underdog in this tournament, ended Harvard's dream of a national hockey title tonight by defeating the Crimson, 65, in a 10minute suddendeath overtime period.

title: Soviet Terms Expulsion Of 5 by Mexico Unjustified
description: MEXICO CITY, March 19 The Soviet Embassy responded today to the expulsion of five of its diplomats here with a statement that it had always observed the principle of non intervention in the affairs of other countries.

title: Frazier Weighs Taking A Year Off From Boxing
description: Reacting to reports of his retirement, Joe Frazier im plied yesterday that he would resume his boxing career, but not until next year.

title: T.V.A. Aides Warn StripMined Coal Bars Power Failure
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 19 (AP)  If stripmined coal were no longer available to the Tennessee Valley Authority, the agency said today, the region it serves would immed iately experience an emergency shortage of disastrous propor tions.

title: A Board for Abolishing
description: The State Senate's vote to increase membership on the New York City Board of Elections, from the present four members to a proposed ten, perpetuates a political anach ronism. The board is a patronage pot, largely controlled by the Democratic and Republican leaders of Manhattan and Brooklyn. In general, its members have been aged politicians rewarded for partisan service.

title: After Blood in Albany
description: Like hounds on a scent, conservative members of the State Legislature in Albany are baying for blood. Their political prey is State Commissioner of Social Services George K. Wyman. As welfare rolls rise and welfare costs contribute to the need for new tax revenues, there are reports that Governor Rockefeller has also become less than happy with Mr. Wyman's performance.

title: Vatican Hall Seating 8,000 for papal Audiences Nears Completion
description: ROME, March 19Work on a vast new hall for Papal audiences in the south corner of the.Vatican is approaching completion. The struoture, of reinforced concrete, is to be inaugurated by Pope Paul VI late this summer.

title: Crimmins Favors Trying of ExWife
description: The former husband of Mrs. Alice Crimmins testified yester day that he had wanted to help his wife during her first trial for murder of their daughter, but said he felt differently now that she was being tried a second time.

title: Curb Asked on Smokers
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI)  Senator Edward J. Gurney, Florida Republican who is a former smoker, proposed legislation today that would require establishment of special sections on planes, trains and buses for those passengers who do not smoke. The same legis lation was introduced in the House earlier by Representative C. W. Young, Republican.

title: Avalanche Said to Kill 400 at Peruvian Mining Camp
description: LIMA, Peru, March 19 (AP) An avalanche rained tons of water, mud and rocks on an isolated mining camp high in the Andes Mountains and killed 400 to 600 people, the federal police said today.

title: Celtics Triumph, 125117
description: BOSTON, March 19 (AP) John Havlicek scored 28 points and led a fourthperiod rally that carried the Boston Celtics to a 125117 victory over the Baltimore Bullets tonight.

title: AMEX LIST DOW AS TRADING LAGS
description: The American Stock Ex change ended the week in bearish manner yesterday as the list declined in less active trading.

title: Watch Checks Radioactivity
description: A Swiss inventor was granted a patent this week for a wristwatch that checks on radioactivity in the en vironment. The luminescence of material forming part of the watch face varies with the radiation to which it has been subjected.

title: Price Index Here Climbs At 4 Times National Pace
description: The Consumer price Index in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area rose at four times the national rate last month, mostly because of higher rents and automobile insurance rates, the Bureau of. Labor Statistics reported yes terday.

title: Market Place
description: Remember how General Host got involved in that big battle for Armour & Co. with Greyhound and lost? Well, lots of people in Wall Street are wishing they could lose the way General Host did.

title: MYLAI GENERAL SAYS HE'S A SCAPEGOAT
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)  Brig. Gen. George H. Young Jr., facing possible demotion for his role in the investigation of the Mylai slay ings, said today that he believed he was being made the Army's political scapegoat.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC SANS WORDS FOR FRENCH, VOILA
description: PARIS, March 19  The French national broadcasting system, possibly the most talkative in the world, has in response to popular demand decided on a cautious experi ment. For a week, there will be music without commentaries on its leastheard radio net work, FranceMusique.

title: AMAX UNIT PLANS RISE IN ZINC PRICE
description: Amax Lead and Zinc, Inc., a subsidiary of American Metal Climax, Inc., announced yester day that it would raise the basic price of zinc by half a cent a pound, to 15.5 cents, effec tive March 22.

title: A Tight Mayoral Contest in Grim Lille
description: LILLE, France, March 19 The worn cobblestone streets of this capital of French Flan ders have sproluted something new in the last year: parking meters. They add a little more austerity to what is already an austere region of textile mills, coal mines and steel plants.

title: Dutch Outbreak of Polio Linked to Sect's Stand
description: STAPHORST, the Nether lands, March 19 (Reuters)  A poliomyelitis epidemic at tributed in part to a religious sect's refusal to accept vac cination struck two more children here, raising the to tal to 32. Three children have died.

title: What Is Needed in Italy
description: Italy's Interior Minister insists there is no reason for the alarms that have been rife this week concerning a neoFascist plot against the Government. He will be right about that only if the democratic forces that par ticipate In Premier Colombo's coalition or support it Parliament can end their incessant bickering and close ranks quickly in the national interest.

title: Tarrytown Man Convicted In BoardingHouse Slaying
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 19 (AP)A Tarrytown man was convicted last night of first degree manslaughter in the fatal beating of Mrs. Janis Schindler, widow of a private investigator, Raymond Schind ler.

title: MIGRANT CLASSES CALLED STINTED
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  A private study charged today widespread mismanagement and irresponsibility in the Federal program of educating mig?? children.

title: Cloisters Shows Medieval Vestments
description: The Cloisters, the medieval branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tryon Park, has taken upon itself to resurrect works that have been relegated to the storage cemeteries and, in some cases never exhibited. It has, with in recent months, mounted exhibitions on such relative ly untapped matter as the art of the medieval blacksmith and medieval lusterware. It plans, before the end of this year, to exhibit some stained glass windows that the pub lic has never seen. Yester day it opened a display of ecclesiastical vestments of the Medieval Ages.

title: Resistance to a Connecticut Income Tax Is Strong
description: News Analysis

title: REV. S. R. BRINCKERHOFF
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., March 19  The Rev. Samuel Ray mond Brinckerhoff, rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Somers and St. James in North Salem from 1938 until his re tirement in 1956, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hos pital. He was 87 years old and lived in Yorktown Heights.

title: TAMPERING CITED IN RAIL DIVERSION
description: CHICAGO, March 19 (AP) A Government investigator said today that someone had manip ulated Penn Central Railroad computers to divert and hide $1million worth of the line's freight cars.

title: Art: Diebenkorns That Speak Softly
description: The exhibition of drawings by Richard Diebenkorn, cur rently on view at the Poin dexter Gallery, 24 East 84th Street, brings, us a large se lection of the work he has done in this medium since his last New York show in the fall of 1969: That show gave us our first view of Mr. Diebenkorn's Ocean Park picturesthe very subtle and poetic abstract paintings on landscape motifs which ini tiated a new development in his work.

title: Teacher Sexually Attacked In Classroom in the Bronx
description: A 28 yearold teacher in the Bronx was sexually assaulted in her thirdgrade classroom by an intruder yesterday shortly before class was to start.

title: SEALE JURY TOED OF MURDER NIGHT
description: NEW HAVEN, March 19 The State Superior Court jury hearing the case of Bobby G. Seale and Ericka Huggins was told today that there was no discussion at all among the five Black Panthers, including Mrs. Huggins, as they watched Alex Rackley being taken from Panther headquarters the night of Rackley's murder.

title: Dr. Mervin J. Kelly Dies at 77; ExHead of Bell Laboratories
description: Dr. Mervin J. Kelly, former president and board chairman of the Bell Laboratories and a leading figure in the fields of science and technology, died Thursday in Port Saint Lucie, Fla., where he had one of his two homes. He also lived at 2 Windemere Terrace, Short Hills, N.J. His age was 77.

title: Antiques: Colonial Caveat
description: Eightyyearold reproduc tions of important 18thcen tury work prove that Colonial American furniture has been admired for a long time, and that caution is always ad visable in collecting.

title: Pistons Down Braves, 111.105
description: DETROIT, March 19 (UPI) Bob Lanier scored 40 points, a record for a Pistons' center, and Detroit topped its team record for victories in a season tonight with a 111105 conquest of the Buffalo Braves.

title: Oil Chiefs to Visit Ottawa
description: The presidents of several ma jor oil companies will go to Ottawa next week at the in vitation of the Government of Canada to discuss a Canadian alternate route for the contro versial transAlaskan pipeline, Thornton F. Bradshaw, presi dent of the Atlantic Richfield Company, said yesterday.

title: AWARDS PRESENTED BY WRITERS GUILD
description: BEVERLEY HILLS, Calif., March 19  The 23d annual Writers Guild of America awards were presented last night at the Beverley Hilton Hotel.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)The Defense Department announced today that the fol lowing servicemen from the New York area had been killed in action in Southeast Asia:

title: Wisconsin Senate Passes A Bill Challenging the War
description: MADISON, Wis., March 19 The Wisconsin Senate has passed a bill challenging the Government's right to draft Wisconsin men to fight in un declared wars such as the In dochina conflict.

title: MORTON J. PRESCOTT
description: Morton J. Prescott, who re tired from the Police Depart ment as a lieutenant in 1969, died Thursday in Einstein Hos pital after a long illness. He was 60 years old and lived in Bay Harbor Island, Fla., and formerly in Parkchester, the Bronx.

title: News and Editorials
description: A number of readers havewritten The Times objecting to our editorial of March 10 denouncing the AliFrazier fight, in view of the large amount of space this news paper had devoted to the subject on its sports pages and in promotional advertising during the preceding few days.

title: Bridge: Dallas Aces Inch Through In Vanderbilt Team Contest
description: ATLANTA, March 19The world champion Dallas Aces came within a hairbreadth of defeat in a quarterfinal match in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Champion ship here last night. They won on the very last deal of a 72deal match in this pre mier event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bomb Goes Off in Altman's Here; Suspects Tied to 100 Other Plots
description: Two young men arrested Thursday for possession of bombs ere placed under $200, 000 bail yesterday after prosecutor said they were con nected to a series of more than 100 actual or attempted bomb ings in the city over the last two years.

title: STARS BEAT NETS ON RALLY, 115104
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 19 (AP)  Zelmo Beaty, Willie Wise and Glen Coombs combined for 73 points tonight to lead the Utah Stars to a 115 104 American Basketball Asso ciation victory over the New York Nets at the Island Garden.

title: Utility Plans Election
description: Stockholders of the Public Service Electric and Gas Cor poration will be asked at the annual meeting April 19 in Newark to elect Nathan H. Wentworth to the board of di rectors.

title: Heath Sends Aides to Ask Ulster Chief Not to Resign
description: LONDON, March 19  The British Government, in a dra matic move, announced tonight that two key defense officials would fly to Belfast tomorrow in an effort to prevent the res ignation of the Northern Ire land Prime Minister, Maj. James D. ChichesterClark.

title: U. S. Six Upsets Czechoslovakia, 51
description: BERN, Switzerland, March 19 (UPI)The United States na tional hockey team pulled a major upset today on the open ing day of the 1971 world ama teur championships by defeat ing Czechoslavakia, 51.

title: Barrault Rabelais In English Version Is Given in London
description: LONDON, March 19Jinxed by repeated lighting failures and by a topless group of People's Theater demonstrators who were finally carried screaming out of the auditorium, the Eng lishlanguage premiere of Jean Louis Barrault's Rabelais at the Roundhouse at least Won support from the British sport ing instinct.

title: Day of the Rail Merger Is Seen as Over
description: Jervis Langdon Jr., a trustee of the Penn Central Transpor tion Company, said here yes terday that the day of the rail road merger is probably over with for the moment at least, largely as a result of the Penn Central collapse.

title: SHORT INTEREST HIGHEST SINCE 68
description: Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange climbed 1,198,876 shares in the month ended March 15 and reached a total of 20,758,529 shares, the highest since Dec. 13, 1968, the month the bull market reached its apex.

title: Welfare Man on the Spot George Kerker Wyman
description: Man in the News

title: Making War in Asiain 1900
description: Seventy years ago, the United States fought a protracted and bloody war of counterinsurgency in the Philippines. Circumstantial evidence suggests the possibility that Americans initiated the fighting in 1899, only two days before the Senate was to ratify the treaty with Spain, in order to stampede recalcitrant legislators who were balking over the controversial provision to annex the Philippines.

title: ARGENTINE LEADER OUSTS A GENERAL
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 19 President Robetto Marcelo Lev ingston said today that he had dismissed the chairman of the Argentine joint chiefs of staff for a disciplinary infraction of grave character.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MON IS ADAMANT ON BORDER ISSUE
description: JERUSALEM, March 19  Deputy Premier Yigal Allon emphasized today Israel's con viction that no political ar rangements or guarantees could substitute for defensible fron tiers, guarded by Israel's own forces.

title: Alarm Devised for Watering Systems
description: Patents of the Week

title: MRS. GIORGIO CAVAGLIERI
description: Mrs. Norma Sanford Cava glieri, a mental hygiene con sultant and the wife of Giorgio Cavaglieri, president of the New York Chapter, American Institute of Architects, died Thursday of a heart attack at her home, 75 Central Park West. She was 58 years old.

title: U.S. 'Invasion' Perils Another South Pacific Paradise
description: The Talk of the New Hebrides

title: BERNARD KRANOWITZ
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., March 19Bernard G. Kranowitz, for mer executive director of the New Britain Chamber of Com erce and former executive vice president of the New Britain Association, died today at the Miami Heart Institute in Miami Beach. He was 69 years old.

title: Distortion in Moscow
description: Professional students of the Soviet Union were not surprised the other day to learn of the cynical distortion with which a Soviet scholarly magazine presented Supreme Court Justice Douglas's book to its readers. The technique of tearing material out of context by carefully eliminating all unsuitable passages is one long prac ticed by Soviet propagandists. Mr. Douglas is not likely to be the last victim. His criticisms of this country were welcome in Moscow, but not his balancing recogni tion of American freedom and American prosperity.

title: Donohue's Ferrari Gains Pole for 12Hour Sebring Race Today
description: SEBRING, Fla., March 19  Despite the pain of a sprained right ankle, Mark Donohue broke the qualifyinglap record today to win the pole position for tomorrow's running of the Twelve Hours of Sebring. The race, which begins at 11 A.M., is the third of the 1971 series of 12 for the world manufactur ers' championship.

title: Parents Ease Road for Medical Students
description: It's been three years since her son was graduated from medical school, but Mrs. Al bert Waldman was at Alumni Hall on First Avenue Wednes day night for the meeting of the Parents Association of the New York University. School of Medicine. Some habits die hard.

title: I Labor. Ahead in British Poll
description: LONDON, March 19 (AP) A Gallup poll today showed the Labor party 12 percentage point ahead of the Conserva tive Government in popularity. This was an increase of 4.5 points In the last month. The unsettled economic outlook and rising unemployment were be lieved responsibile.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Laver Trounces Okker For Sweep, 75, 62, 61
description: To the surprise of no one, including Tom Okker, Rod Laver won the final match in the Tennis Champions Classic last night and a check for $35,000 for a second consecu tive year.

title: Lindsay Urges Key Role for City In Devising U.S. Plan for Aged
description: Mayor Lindsay suggested yes terday that the city take the lead in formulating an action plan for the aging to present to the Nixon Administration, but without associating it with his office because politically it cannot help.

title: GILLETTE NAMES TWO TO SHARE PRESIDENCY
description: ANDOVER, Mass., March 19 (AP)The Gillette Company, which has been without a pres ident since Stuart K. Hensley resigned three years ago, has filled the void by promoting two executive vice presidents to share the responsibilities.

title: ROLE IN WERTHERP SUNG BY MISS ELIAS
description: It takes two acts for Char lotte to discover that she re turns Werther's love in the Massenet opera. Perhaps it was right that Rosalind Elias, singing the role of Charlotte for the first time in the Metro politan Opera's new production of Werther, on Thursday night, should have seemed rather bland for the first half of the performance. With her slim figure and pretty face, she was lovely to look at, but she did not project any of the inner intensity she has at other times.

title: Western Financial Says Loans May Cut Earnings
description: The Western Financial Con poration said in Phoenix, Ariz., yesterday that two mobilehome park loans totaling about $2.3 million might be affected by bankruptcy proceedings filed by some creditors of Holiday Mo bile Home Resorts, Inc., owner of the properties.

title: They Shall Build in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEMI am grateful that Philip Johnson's open letter to me on this page placed the controversy over Jerusalem's development in its proper perspective. Too many miscon ceptions have been created In the minds of Jerusalem's friends abroad.

title: Victory Demonstrations On
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)Demonstrations for mili tary victory in Vietnam by July 4 will be held tomorrow in state capitals and the national capital, the United States March for Victory organization of the Rev. Dr. Carl McIntife an nounced today.

title: Who Runs the Port Authority?
description: In the halfcentury since its creation the Port of New York Authority has tended increasingly to become a law unto itself, initiating its own policies and having them dutifully rubberstamped by the elected officials of New York and New Jersey.

title: Israel Withholds Comment
description: TEL AVIV, March 19 (Reut ers)Israeli military sources would neither confirm nor deny the Cairo report that Egyptian antiaircraft batteries had drivel off two Israeli jets over Egypt tian air space.

title: GEORGE HOLLISTER
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., March 19, George Hollister, for mer superintendent of the Hart ford Park System, died yester day in his home at the age of 88.

title: Soviet Aides Due in U.S. To Study Patent Methods
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  Three Soviet officials will ar rive, here on Sunday to spend, two and a half weeks studying American use of computers in patent management and Amer ican licensing procedures.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Sy S. tapped out on the 1965 Kentucky Derby, betting his last $75 on a 301 shot named Dapper Dan who finished second. That was the biggest bet I ever won, he likes to recall, because 1 lost it. A few nights later, Sy attended his first Gamblers Anonymous meeting, and the following day he walked to the telephone five times place a bet, and five times held himself back. At 2 P.M., when he knew the bookie had left to make his collections, Sy called his wife and said, That's one.

title: Calley Jury Ends Its Third Day After Testimony Is Read Again
description: FORT BENNING. Ga., March 19The jury of six combat of ficers charged with determining the fate of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. ended its third day of deliberation today with out reaching a verdict.

title: Nixons Attend Simple Funeral Service for Dewey
description: A simple Episcopal funeral was held here yesterday for Thomas E. Dewey, Governor of New York for 12 years and twice an unsuccessful Republican candidate for the Presidency. It was attended by President, and Mrs. Nixon, some Cabinet members and scores of politicians who had played various public and behind  the  scenes roles in Mr. Dewey's political career. For an hour before the start Of the funeral at 4 P.M., they emerged from limousines and hurried up the steps of St. James' Church at 7.1st Street and Madison Avenue in cold, driving rain. Across the street several hundred peo ple huddled under umbrellas and behind barricades and watched. There were no for mal invitations to the funeral, which was open to the pub lic, but the presence of so many noted people and of dozens of police and security men seemed to discourage ordinary citizens from enter ing the imposing brownstone church. Almost everyone who attended was welldressed and appeared at least middle aged. One elderly woman in a flowing black cape and a hennaed wig askew marched up the steps undaunted. After a moment's hesitation, secu rity men searched her volu minous shopping bag and al lowed her to enter. The church, which seats 1,130, persons, was almost filled. On the right side of the aisle next to the mahogany coffin, which was covered with carna tions, were Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey Jr. and the other son, John.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: There is a pickup in sales and manufacturing on Sev enth Avenuealmost imper ceptible in nature and too soon for the figures to show itbut the industry reces sion is hardly over. Women are still generally afraid to buy, preferring to save their money. But manufacturers are so anxious to please the customer that they are try ing every sort of styling in their lines. One result is ter rific diversification, short production runs and slightly dower workweeks.

title: FLORIDA TO GET NEW RESCUE BASE
description: A new era in boating safety on the Gulf Coast of Florida was launched yesterday with the ar rival in Sarasota of the 82foot patrol boat, Point Thatcher, and ceremonies marking the start of construction on the United States Coast Guard SeaRescue Station.

title: Dodgers Rout Phils, 127
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 20 (AP)  The Philadelphia Phillies took a threerun lead in the first inning today but then succumbed to a 15hit Los Angeles Dodger attack and lost, 127.

title: Mail: Park Encroachment
description: To the EDITOR:

title: Roast Politico Served Up by Reporters
description: President Nixon was por trayed as a ventriloquist, with a tarttalking Vice President Agnew as his dummy. Gover nor Rockefeller was a spend thrift builder more ambitious than the Pharaohs. Mayor Lind say was a glamorous bungler, hooted by the New Yorkers he governed and hailed by tourists dazzled by his political image.

title: Margaret Ann Fletcher Married
description: TENAFLY, N. J., March 20 Miss Margaret Ann Fletch er and Richard Lloyd Mc Intosh were married this afternoon in the Tenafly Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Harry E. Chase and the Rev. Michael Jousan offici cated.

title: Yale Polo Players Pay the Price...It's $750
description: NEW HAVEN, March 20 When he was a youngster in Closter, N.J., Dan Wallace used to read of the difficulties of college basketball and football coaches  not enough scholar ships, not enough money from the athletic departments, not enough assistants.

title: Fast Hilarious, $52.60, Sets Track Record in $128,400 Gulfstream Handicap
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 20Track records have been falling like rain at Gulfstream Park this season, and it was not great surprise when the mile andaquarter mark of 1:59 4/5 also went down this afternoon in the $128,400 Gulfstream Handicap. What was surprising was the horse who broke it Fast Hilarious, the longest shot on the board at 25 to 1.

title: Wimp Joins Jets' As Assistant to Weeb
description: The New York Jets now have a Wimp to go with their Weeb.

title: Group Here Helps Students Get Summer Jobs Abroad
description: College students seeking sum mer jobs abroad will again be aided by the Council on Inter national Educational Exchange, which has a cooperative pro gram with Britain, Ireland, Au stralia and New Zealand.

title: SPYING ON SENATORS FEARED BY MONTOYA
description: DENVER, March 20 (AP) Senator Joseph M. Montoya says that he and other Senators believe the Justice Department has tapped private telephone lines of Senators and Repre sentatives.

title: Nancy J. Zwigard Married in Jersey
description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J., March 20  Miss Nancy Jordan Zwigard and Robert White Benjamin were married here this morning by the Rev. George Connelly in the Im maculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: Congressional Probe in Vietnam
description: At a critical moment of the Korean War, after Presi dent Truman had fired General Macarthur, Congressional hearings probed deeply and publicly into all aspects that controversial Asian conflict. The highest civilian and military officers of the executive branch, with the important exception only of the President, appeared before joint sessions of the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees in MayJune, 1951. They submitted to 43 days of questioning, during which more than 3,000 pages of testimony were taken to enable the Congress and the country to come to a judgment on major undeclared war into which the country had been taken, without consultation, by Presidential decision.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Hundreds of mystery novels are published every year, and a certain regular percentage is by lady writers in lady prose. Lady prose: How to describe it? Lady prose generally is written in short sentences and short paragraphs. Lady prose is full of hadIbutknown. Lady prose almost always has a dol lop of romance in the best Harold Bell Wright tradition. Lady prose can be so arch it would curdle a shark's blood. (Some men write lady prose, too.) Lady prose is sensitive and full of suffering. Lady prose is icky prose. Lady prose is genteel, with a G rating. Lady prose is next to impossi ble to read.

title: Et Al.
description: Assembled from the papers and lectures, mostly written and delivered in the sixties, of Sir S., the eminent adviser on science to the British Govern ment. His discussions of the manner in which fashions af fect research and of public science, that is, applied science subsidized by Government, are interesting and intelligent. The issues he addresses himself to are, of course, British; but the same issues apply here.

title: 70,000 Drivers Notified by Albany Of Invalid Licenses
description: ALBANY, March 20 (UPI) More than 70,000 drivers in the state have had their licenses suspended for failure to answer New York City traffic sum monses.

title: Police Seize 10 and Charge ViceRing Kidnapping
description: The police last night freed three of four young women who department spokesmen said had been kidnapped, beat en, raped and forced to become prostitutes.

title: Jackson State a Year After
description: JACKSON, MISS.

title: Shopping Tips for the BabyPacking Tourist
description: TRAVELING with your children in Europe can be as much funor tribulationas living with them at home. If you are bothered by your children's antics, or what others think of them, forget the whole thing. On the other hand, if you have what I call parental confidence, traveling will be a groove.

title: SWEDEN RALLIES, TOPS U.S. SIX, 42
description: BERN, Switzerland, March 20 (UPI)Sweden came from be hind to beat the United States, 42, tonight in the toughest and most exciting game so far in the world ice hockey champion ship.

title: A lady for whom much went right and something went wrong
description: Niel Herbert, the young narrator of Willa Cather's A Lost Lady, is haunted by the reckless, flawed love liness of the heroine of that novel, her passionate power for life, the promise, when her eyes for a mo ment laughed into his, of a wild delight such as he might never know.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: CLEVELAND  Hays T. Watkins Jr. acknowledges that there is a lot he doesn't know about being president of a railroadthe job he will assume at the Chesa peake & Ohio Railway and the Baltimore & Ohio Rail road on April 1.

title: Felonious Victor in Trial
description: NEW ORLEANS, La., March 20 (AP)Felonious took the $10,000added Louisiana Derby trial despite drifting wide in thte stretch today, running the mile and 40 yards before 15,744 at the New Orleans Fair Grounds in 1:39 2/5.

title: STOLPORT CALLED DEAD ISSUE HERE
description: Representative Edward Koch said yesterday that Trans portation Secretary John A. Volpe had Informed him that opposition by residents had stopped further consideration of a plan to build a landing field for short takeoff and landing planes in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.

title: If Out on a Limb,When Pruning . . .
description: A SINGLE dead limb on shade tree usually is of itself nothing to worry about. Trees are equipped with, adventi tious buds which sprout in time of need to compensate with new foliage, Simply saw off the dead limb flush with the trunk and seal the wound with tree paint.

title: Miss Milliken Becomes Bride
description: WINNETKA, Ill., March 20 In the Winnetka Congrega tional Church this afternoon, Miss Amelia Porter Milliken, a student at Lake Forest Col lege, was married to Marsh Mason Rowell Jr., a commer cial photographer, by the Rev. Dr. Lawrence E. Schwarz.

title: Chileans Capture Doubles For 21 Lead in Davis Cup
description: BOGOTA, Columbia, March 20 (UPI) Patricio Cornejo and Jaime Fillol beat Jairo Velasco and Ivan Molina in doubles to day, 75, 75, 46, 63, to give Chile a 21 lead over Columbia in the South American Zone Davis Cup tennis series.

title: 2 Killed at Valencia Festival
description: VALENCIA, Spain, March 20 (UPI)  Two persons were killed and 176 injured early to day at Valencia's spring festival when rockets from a fireworks display misfired because of rain and fell into a crowd of about 200,000 merrymakers. People were trampled and pushed through plateglass windows in the panic that followed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Marathon Here Today To Start at 11 O'Clock
description: A marathon sponsored by the Road Runners Club of New York will be held begin ning at 11 A.M. from the, Central Park Mall in conjune tion with the Earth Day celebration today in Central. Park.

title: Soviet Computer Center
description: MOSCOW, March 20 (AP) A computer center has been built in the Siberian city of Khabarovsk to coordinate light industry In the Soviet far east, the official Soviet press agency Tass reports.

title: CHARGES DROPPED IN TAXFIXING CASE
description: ST. LOUIS, March 20 (AP) Indictments oharging a former lawyer, Harry I. Schwimmer, with conspiracy in a 1952 tax fixing case involving Truman Administration figures were dismissed yesterday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY PLAYOFFS CONFUSING FANS
description: Although the National Hockey League's East Division playoff berths probably will be decided by tonight; most fans are, un aware of just who plays whom, and when.

title: Fordham Lists 13 Events In Track on Outdoor Slate
description: Fordham has 13 dual, tri angular, relay carnival and championship meets listed for its varsity and freshman out door track and field teams. The season will mark For dham's 87th year of intercol legiate track and field.

title: Central Java: Where Indonesia's Ancient Arts and Crafts Survive...
description: JOGJAKARTA, IndonesiaWe ap proached the crumbling but still majestic ninthcentury Buddhist temple in the blaze of midafter noon, when Indonesians usually retreat to their beds, and so we were surprised io hear the rich sonorities of the Java nese gamelan floating over the green fields surrounding the shrine.

title: Astros Rout Twins, 124
description: COCOA, Fla., March 20 (UPI) Doug Rader and Dennis Men ke batted in four runs each to day as the Houston Astros beat the Minnesota Twins, 124.

title: Bent and Miss Rathbone Take Franconia Giant Slalom Races
description: FRANCONIA, N. H., March 20  Chuck Bent, 22yearold Dartmouth senior from Etna, N. H., won a United States Eastern Amateur Ski Associa tion special giant slalom race on Cannon Mountain today in a field of 72. The event re placed a U.S.E.A.S.A. senior Alpine championship originally scheduled.

title: WISCONSIN'S CHIEF BREAKS A PATTERN
description: MADISON, Wis., March 17 For northern Democratic poli ticians it has been traditional to support Federal as against state programs. The Federal Government had a more liberal outlook, they felt, and the nec essary national authority.

title: The vices and virtues of Simon and Pechter
description: How definitive is any critical work? In most of the arts there are critical standards accessible to the intelligent reader. But in film criticism there is no general agreement on stand ards. Every new film book, what ever its immediate aim, of necessity therefore is also a definition of true film criticism.

title: Cabbies Seem More Willing Now To Co to Brooklyn and Queens
description: The fierce reluctance of many Manhattan cab drivers to carry riders to Brooklyn and Queens appears to have melted away since the recent taxi fare in crease. But this is small con solation to many residents who have decided that rides between Manhattan and those bor oughs are now beyond their means.

title: Goodrich Will Pay a Fine For Tires Called Unsafe
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)The B. F. Goodrich Tire Company has agreed to pay a $35,000 fine for producing tires that failed to meet Government, safety standards.

title: Art
description: PICASSO'S Guitar, now bearing the slightly revised date of 1911 12, is currently on exhibition in a small show of new acquisitions at the Museum of Modern Art. This is the work a construction of sheet metal and wire, 301/2 inches in height, now believed to have initiated the entire tradition of modern constructed sculp turewhich Picasso unexpectedly pre sented to the museum as a gift last month. It was exhibited in this country for the first time in the museum's large survey of Picasso sculpture in 1967. It is the first example of the artist's con structed sculpture to enter a museum collection anywhere in the world, for Picasso has alwaysuntil nowjeal ously held on to these historic sculptures for his own private delectation.

title: This Book Is About Schools
description: This book is a representative anthology of pieces that have appeared in the quarterly, This Magazine Is About Schools, published on a shoestring in Toronto since April, 1966. This Magazine has served as a scrapbook record of a happen ingthe freeschool explosion, which has engaged the full time services of more Ameri cans than any other part of the Liberation Movement or the New Left. Its contributors include parents who promise that we won't do to our kids what our parents did to us, young educators inspired by the nonauthoritarian ideas of Tolstoy and A. S. Neil as well as Marshall McLuhan and Thomas Szasz.

title: Science Prize Awarded
description: Kenneth F. Weaver, assistant editor of the National Geo graphic, was named winner yesterday of the 1971 science writing award in physics and astronomy, presented by the American Institute of Physics and the United States Steel Foundation. Mr. Weaver will receive the $1,500 prize on April 27 for the article Voyage to the Planets, which appeared in the August, 1970, issue of the National Geographic.

title: Wood, Field and Stream New Edition of Galton's Art of Travel Is for Those Who. Yearn for the Past
description: Those who yearn for the rugged simplicity of years gone by will gain pleasure from the reprint edition of Francis Galton's Art of Travel (Stackpole Books, 366 pages, illustrated, $6.95).

title: Prisons Step Up Training for Guards
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 More and more of the nation's correctional officials are invol ved in training programs that emphasize a more sophisticated and sensitive handling of in mates and probationers.

title: Son to the Victor Greenes
description: A son was born on Mon day to Mr. and Mrs. Victor Greene of New York in the University Hospital at the New York University Medical Center. The child has been named Samuel Mitchell. His mother is the former Miss Nancy C. Konheim. His father is with CBWLHayden, Stone, Inc., investment bankers.

title: To Marsh and Dune for a Glimpse of the Early Birds
description: EAST QUOGUE, L. I.Wild birds transmit a highly contagious dis ease to human beings: bird watching fever. This mania grips certain segment of the population twice a year at the very minimum, and its string phase is about to begin.

title: SAIGON ABANDONS TWO MORE BASES BATTERED BY FOE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 20South Vietnamese troops retreated from two more bases in Laos today after the heaviest series of enemy attacks since the start of the allied thrust six weeks ago.

title: Canadians Beat Sabres, 5.2
description: MONTREAL, March 20 (UPI) Jacques LeMaire scored with a 70foot drive in the second period and added an assist to night as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 572: in the first National Hockey League game to feature broth ers in opposing nets.

title: GEORGE L. M'CLINTOCK
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., March 20George L. McClintock, retired printing broker, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospi tal. He was 83 years old and lived at 31 Tanglewyld Avenue.

title: A mind beset by images, haunted by itself
description: Nothing is harder than to write on Keats. He commented so well on himself that critics, though addicted to Keats, feel obscurely unworthy in writing about him. And yet the three recent biographies are matched by continuing critical efforts, the latest Morris Dickstein's book. It is clearly a first book, and a second generation booka result of the dis tinguished revaluation of English Romanticism now going on in the United States, and especially at Yale.

title: Curtis Captures First Place In Amateur Gelande Event
description: WAITSFIELD, Vt., March 20 (AP)Chris Curtis of Stowe won the amateur division at the fourth annual North Ameri can gelande championships to day at the Glen Ellen ski area.

title: West Side Survey Shows Conditions Have Worsened
description: Conditions on the West Side of midtown Manhattan are for the most part, getting worse or staying the same, in the esti mation of businessmen respond ing to a survey undertaken by the West Side Association of Commerce.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: If Jenny Were Alive Today How Would Love Story Go?
description: Evening. New York. Oliver comes home to Jenny after a hard day at the office.

title: Japanese.Troupes to Appear In Community College Fete
description: Two Japanese troupes, tour ing for the first time in this country, will perform next Sun day at the annual Festival of the Arts series of New York City Community College in Brooklyn.

title: Art
description: FOR some viewers, suppose, Van Gogh's art has reached the hohum stage. The Dutch painter has become a legendary figure, a popular artist, yet his work seems to have little relevance to con temporary esthetic issues. Reproductions of his paint ings are as ubiquitous as the calendars and postcards they adorn. His tragic life story his remarkably short 10 year career as an artist dur ing which he nevertheless managed to execute 800 paintings and a greater num ber of drawings, the periods spent in hospitals and lunatic asylums, his suicide in 1890 at the age of 37has been thoroughly digested and pre digested. He has, quite simply, become too familiar.

title: Don't Say Yes Until I Finish Talking
description: Mel Gussow has written an intelligent, informed, compre hensive, sympathetic (though not sycophantic) biography of Darryl F. Zanuck, perhaps the last of the authentic movie mo guls. With a subject as gossip laden as Zanuck, the author is to be commended for touching all the bases without sliding into the muck of rumor, scan dal, hearsay, anecdotage, smug piety and cultural condescen sion. Gussow never fails to see his subject in the full perspec tive of a career responsible for the production of close to 200 films over half a century.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  For the moment, at least, the Securi ties and Exchange Commis sion's institutional investor saidy seems to have disap peared without a trace. Ap plause and denunciation have been equally absent in the 10 days since its publication.

title: Oustecky Signed to Coach C. W. Post Varsity Soccer
description: Henry Oustecky of Berner High School in Massapequa, L.I., has been named varsity soccer coach at C. W. Post College.

title: Lieut. R. P. McAleer Weds Brenda Oates
description: WALTHAM, Mass., March 20Miss Brenda M. Oates and Lieut. Robert Paul Mc Aleer, U.S.M.C., were married here this morning in Our Lady Comforter of the Afflict ed Roman Catholic Church.

title: DR. JAMES DUNSEITH
description: Dr. James G. Dunseith, a physician in the Times Square area for 62 years before mov ing to Mount Vernon, N. Y., six years ago, died there Friday at his home, 171 Archer Avenue. His age was 91.

title: The Nation
description: SAIGON  The longrange weather forecast issued infre quently by 'the United States Command usually; passes un noticed in the flood of official verbiage. But the one issued last week contained an item of par ticular interest: The rainy season over the Ho Chi Minh. Trail net work is not likely, to, begin until well into May.

title: COURT SUES CITY OF PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 20 The cost of administering jus tice has gone up along with everything else, and Philadel phia's Court of Common Picas has found that one way to get more taxpayer money to fi nance its operations is to go to court.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BOGOTA, ColombiaAs far as know the only integral independent country on the map with which the United States has never had diplomatic relations is the Mongolian People's Republic, a proSoviet state lying be tween the eastern reaches of the U.S.S.R. and Communist China. This spring the republic celebrates its fifti eth birthday.

title: The World
description: BELFASTLike a tragedy un folding toward its pitiless finale, the plight of Northern Ireland took one more inevitable plot turn last week.

title: Miss Cerisoles to Wed in London
description: Miss Genevive Nanette Cerisoles, United States vice consul in Casablanca, Morocco, and Richard John Smale Edis, third secretary at the British High Commission in Nairobi, Kenya, will be married April 3 in London.

title: Smoking Banned for Day
description: SALEM, Ore., March 20 (UPI) The Oregon House of Repre sentatives kicked the smoking habit for 24 hours but was soon back to its old ways. The House voted 34 to 24 last Monday to ban smoking in its chamber and committee rooms. But after a day of withdrawal, the legislators changed their minds and struck down the new rule, 32 to 25.

title: Tourist Tower Opposed
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 20 (AP) Pennsyvania's battle against a proposed tourist observation tower at Gettys burg National Park has won another powerful recruit former United States Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall. Mr. Udall said the tower would dominate the historic battlefield.

title: Et Al.
description: Will Rogers and the Ameri can Dream is the subtitle of this study about what the man meant to his mass following, what made him almost univer sally loved. The author deals with Rogers through such mythic ideals as the American Adam, the American Prome theus, the SelfMade Man, the democratall adding up to his embodiment of the American dream. Rogers's own common folk might find the going difficult.

title: Addiction and Mental Health Called Harlem's Top Problems
description: Drug addiction, mental health and retardation, and alcoholism were cited this week as Har lem's three mostpressing health problems.

title: 4 Killed in Plane Crash At Atlantic City Airport
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 20 Four persons were killed when their singleengine Piper Commanche crashed on take off into the bay at the end of the runway at Bader Field here shortly before 10 P.M. tonight.

title: Miss Lehmann Becomes Bride Of P. D. Radley
description: HAMILTON, Ohio, March 20Miss Melanie Lehmann, a doctoral candidate at Teachers College, Columbia University,, was married here this evening to Philippe Dan iel Radley, assistant profes sor of Russian language and literature at the State Uni versity of New'York at Stony Brook, L.I. Rabbi Albert Gold man performed the ceremony at Temple Bene Israel.

title: Toward Court Reform
description: A British lord Chancellor once referred to the Ameri can courts as a living museum of 18thcentury British law. If a farreaching improvement is to be achieved the performance of the courts, It will require all of the imagination and daring which President Nixon recently commended to a National Conference on the Judiciary. To achieve genuinely speedy justice may require drastic changes in court procedures.

title: Education
description: These are hard times for the urban school principal. lie Is caught in a crossfire of demands by students, parents and unions for new answers to old problems. Yet he is confined by an inflexible sys tom.

title: NEW POWER PLANT PLANNED BY STATE
description: A specific plan and site for onemillionkilowatt pumped storage plant to provide elec tricity for New York City and the southeastern part of the state in times of peak demand has been proposed by the State Power Authority.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Nisivoccia, 123Pounder, Wins 2d Jersey Mat Title,
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 20 Gerry Nisivoccia of J. P. Ste vens High School, Edison, N. J., outpointed Gary Nottingen of Pascack Hills, 186, tonight to take his second straight New Jersey State Interscholastic Ath letic Association wrestling championship in the 123pound class.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Bulls Top Hawks
description: CHICAGO, March 20 (AP) Paul Ruffner, a rookie who had played only 22 minutes all sea son, scored 13 points in the fourth quarter tonight to lead the Chicago Bulls past the At lanta Hawks, 138121.

title: Rome Police Arr'est Another In Alleged NeoFascist Plot
description: ROME, March 20 (Reuters) Policemen hunting the leaders of what is called an abortive neoFascist coup arrested today a fourth leader of the extreme rightwing National Front move ment headed by Prince Junio Valerio Borghese.

title: Indians Top Giants, 32
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 20 (AP)  John Lowenstein, al rookie, and Ken Suarez sparked an eighthinning rally that led the Cleveland Indians to a 32 victory over the San Francisco Giants today.

title: Art Notes
description: E.A.T. (Experiments in Art and Technology) lives. The fiscal fiasco that attended its crea tion of the PepsiCola Pa villon at Osaka's Expo 70 last year has by no means dampened the restless spirit of the artIndustryengineer ting collab. (The pavilion, you'll remember, exploded Pepsi's budget; E.A.T. and Pepsi are no longer seeing each other.)

title: DROUGHT IN KENYA CUTS FOOD STOCKS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 20 (AP)Drought in areas of Kenya has placed more than 140,000 persons on famine re lief and abetted the spread of cholera. Twenty persons died of the disease in one recent week.

title: Foe Reports B52 Downed
description: HANOI, North Vietnam,March 20 (Agence FrancePresse)An American B52 bomber was shot down in North Vietnam on Thursday, the Hanoi radio re ported today. It said the air craft was hit over Vinhhlinh near the 17th Parallel. Foreign military experts said that the North Vietnamese were using new antiaircraft rocket that cannot be detected by the elec tronic detection devices in these planes.

title: Mail: Park Encroachment
description: To the EDITOR:

title: Foreign Notes
description: The delicate relationship between the Roman Catholic church and the Italian State has undergone some heavy shocks in recent months in the field of marriage and sex. On Dec. 1, after a fiveyear battle, Parliament made di vorce legal. This month the Italian Supreme Court ruled that the 1929 concordats, which govern VaticanItalian relations, were not above scrutiny by Parliament or the courts. That had the effect of nullifying church efforts to have the divorce reform declared unconstitutional. And last Wednesday, the Su preme Court strucx down as unconstitutional & law writ ten during the Fascist regime banning dissemination of birth control information. Hitherto, birth control de vices had been sold only on

title: Stamps
description: RAVIDAS is considered one of the great bhagats, or saints, of the Vaishnava revival in India. Also known as Rohidas and Raidas, he was a chamar, a leatherworker disciple of Ramananda, a 15thcentury brahmin theo logian. Ravidas was to be come revered, especially in Northern India. A 20paisa, redbrown diamondshaped stamp was issued last month by India in his honor.
