He was the country boy who made good in the city less through inspiration than per spiration, and the skyscrapers from which he so often dangled expressed not only the upward mobility of his aspirations but also his morbid fear of falling back into the herd below.

title: Keith E.Simpson Weds Miss Pamela M. Tenney
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, March 20Miss Pamela M. Tenney was married in St. John's Episcopal Church here at noon today to Keith E. Simpson. The Rev. Peter C. Moore performed the cer emony, assisted by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee.

title: Masks of Love And Death
description: Another valuable book about Yeats as dramatist for readers of Harold Bloom's recent Yeats and Helen Vendler's Yeats' Vision and the Later Plays. The author elaborates on Yeats's doctrine of the masks (the core of his dramatic technique) and dwells on the idealistic intent of works like Deirdre and Four Plays for Dancers (which have proved uneasy on the stage). Al though the subjects of the plays are sex, violence, aliena tion and madness, their deeper concern is supernatural reality and heroes of high purpose. In this, Yeats remains an aristo crat of the theater and not truly modern, as the author maintains.

title: Marie Kizzer Affianced
description: ELMONT, L. I., March 20 The engagement of Miss Marie Kizzer to Louis Schet tini, son of Mrs. Anne Schet tini of Flushing, Queens, has been announced by her par ents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Kizzer.

title: Photography
description: MIKE MITCHELL, as a young Washington, D. C. professional making his New York debut at The Under ground Gallery, is one of a growing number of young photographers Who use dark room techniques that their elders disapprove of. So far the youngsters are keeping their focuses sharp and avoiding the handmade look of the gum print, but other wise anything goes.

title: PROVIDENCE WINS FROM. LOUISVILLE
description: Duke, Providence and North Carolina advanced yesterday to the quarterfinal round of the National Invitation Tourn ament at Madison Square Gar den. Varied defenses played key roles in all three victories.

title: Bernard Kranowitz, Active In Connecticut Development
description: MIAMI, March 20 (UPI) Bernard G. Kranowitz, a mem ber of the Connecticut Devel opment Commission, died yes terday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 69 years old.

title: the traveler's world
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The solemn strains of that modern Ameri can folkhymn, Mic key MOUSE, penetrate the mind through the overpowering sweetness of the young orange blossoms as one drives through the cool evening breezes of Central Florida. It is all somewhat hallu cinatory to a refugee from a northern snowstorm  the 2hour jetleap from cold to warm, the roadside unreality of orangecolored oranges and brightyel low grapefruit actually hanging on row after row of trees instead of lying in heaps, smelling of chemical preserva tives, in supermarket display racks; and just around the bend, 15 miles south west of Oriando, a new Disney World springing forth so fast, so vast and so complete as to appear to be another Hollywoodborn showbusiness miracle.

title: Deferred Tuition Sought For Ohio Public Colleges
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 20 Gov. John J. Gilligan will in troduce legislation Monday to create a new form of deferred tuition requiring virtually all 182,000 students in the state's fouryear public colleges to re pay eventually the cost of their education.

title: GhanaSoviet Trade Plans
description: ACCRA, Ghana, March 20 (Agence FrancePresse)Ghana and the Soviet Union have agreed on draft proposals for the export to the Soviet Union of Ghanaian cocoa, butter and wood, and imports of Soviet sugar, fish, fish preparations crude oil, machinery and machinery parts.

title: Negro Facing 4th Trial in '57 Slaying
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 20Caliph Washington entered jail at the age of 16 when he was arrested on a charge of murdering a police officer in a suburb of Birmingham in 1957.

title: Wild Oil Well Killed in Gulf
description: NEW ORLEANS, La., March 20 (AP)The eighth of 11 wild wells that originally fed an off shore oil platform fire in the Gulf of Mexico was reported killed today, Shell Oil Com pany spokemen said. The plat form, control point for more than 20 wells, exploded Dec. 1, killing four men. Drilling con tinued today in efforts to kill the other three wells.

title: Medicine
description: Should the pediatrician be the key figure in a vigorous national effort to curb the plague of heart disease which kills almost a million Ameri cans annually?

title: DROPPING OF MAFIA ASSAILED BY MARCHI
description: State Senator John J. Marchi declared yesterday that the de cision of Paramount Pictures to excise the words Mafia and Cosa Nostra from the script of The Godfather was a monstrous insult to millions upon millionsof loyal Ameri cans of Italian extraction.

title: Bedsheet Law Updated
description: DES MOINES, March 20 (UPI)A municipal court jury has ruled that Iowa's 60year old law requiring hotels and motels to iron their bed sheets does not necessarily apply if permanent press sheets are used. The jury deliberated for one hour last Tuesday before finding the Ramada Inn Motel innocent of violating the code as charged by the Iowa Depart ment of Agriculture.

title: Truck Driver Is Killed
description: An oiltruck driver was killed yesterday and a taxi driver and his passenger were injured when their vehicles collided near the Queens Midtown Tun nel at 36th Street and Second Avenue. The police said Wil liam Hanvey, 45 years old, of Hicksville, Li., was killed when his truck overturned. Ben Na dleman, 24, the cabby, of 50 East 191st Street, the Bronx, and his passenger, Robert Tyn an, 32, of 57 Huntington Road, Gorden City, LI., were taken to Bellevue Hospital for treat ment.

title: Brooklyn College Opens Playwright Competition
description: A special selection commit tee at Brooklyn College is searching for undiscovered playwriting talent. The pur pose is to find plays that can be produced in the New American Playwrights Series competition, which will enter its fourth season at the col lege in July.

title: Oil Company, Twice Rejected, Now Seeks Searsport, Me., Site
description: SEARSPORT, Me., March 20 An oil company that has been rebuffed by Long Island, N.Y., and South Portland, Me., in its attempt to construct a $150 million refinery is trying for success a third time. It wants to locate here.

title: Perils of Extremism Linger in Quebec
description: MONTREAL, March 16Al though Paul Rose, the first of the Quebec separatist revolu tionaries to be tried, has been convicted and sentenced to life Imprisonment, the civil ordeal of Canada's largest city follow ing the terrorist kidnappings and murder five months ago is far from over.

title: Miss Wootton Will Be Wed
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 20 Mr. and Mrs. Philip Henry Wootton Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Bar ron Wootton, to Maurice Pierre Fisher Tonissi.

title: POLISH WRITERS PUBLISHING AGAIN
description: WARSAW, March 20Polish writers whose work had been banned here since the 1968 student protests and subse quent antiZionist campaign are beginning to reappear in print under the new Polish leadership.

title: Queen Anne
description: Oueen Anne's death (not her life) lies at the very heart of England's history: the accession of the Hanoverian family, which still rules, and the final end of the Stuarts. And what is more, her death ruined the Tory party for a hundred years and gave the Whigs generations of power. But throughout her reign, her death was the most important fact about her life a crisis constantly envisaged, constantly debated, the source and hope of endless intrigue, the mainspring of the treason that tainted almost all of her servants.

title: National Notes
description: Shopper's Guide There are two brandname detergents on the supermarket shelf, both large economy size. Brand X, is priced at $1.59. Brand Y is only $1.29. The shop per's choice is obviousor is it? Brand X actually contains 5 pounds of detergentBrand Y, only 4 pounds.

description: Queens environmental ac tivists are expanding their horizons for spring, proposing an extensive natural area in the northeastern part of the borough that would bring together their disparate dreams.

title: A Code Covering Faculty's Conduct Blocked on Coast
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 20 Faculty members at the Uni versity of California campus here have blocked an effort to gain immediate approval for code of conduct that would have set disciplinary standards for professors on all nine cam puses of the university.

title: 21st in Row for Kansas
description: WICHITA, Kan., March 20 (AP)  Kansas forged from be hind in the last five minutes for a 7371 victory over Drake in the N.C.A.A. Midwest re gional final today.

title: Referee Dies on Court
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., March 20 (UPI)Dale E. Mc Kenzie, 44 years old, collapsed and died last night while re fereeing a high school basket ball tournament game. West Virginia Medical Center offi cials said McKenzie, who was from Marietta, Ohio, appar ently had a heart attack.

title: Mets Down Reds, on Walk in 10th
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 20A 10thinning walk to Ron Swo boda with the bases loaded gave the New York Mets a 65 victory today over the Cincin nati Reds, the team that re placed them last year as cham pions of the National League.

title: Photography
description: CLAIMED by the manu facturer to be the wmild's smallest 3:1 zoom camera (and certainly the most compact version this writer has seen) a new Super 8 movie camera recently introduced by Honeywell Photograhic Prod ucts, 5501 South Broadway, Littleton, Colo. 80120, also has a builtin device that permits the user to superim pose titles or scenes on top of the main scene (simul taneous filming) without ad ditional attachments. Called the Honeywell Elmo Super 103T, the camera has a mir ror that snaps out on one side to direct the light through a window to an internal beamsplitter prism. A title, scenic color slide or other small object held directly in front of this is then automatically superim posed over the scene being taken by the main lens. Both viewsthe main scene and the superimposed subject are visible simultaneously in the viewfinder. In addition, if the main lens is capped the mirror becomes the equivalent of an ultra closeup taking lens whose point of focus is only as far out as the front of the main lens.

title: U.S., Soviet Girls Head World Title Basketball
description: RIO DE. JANEIRO, March 20 (UPDThirteen countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, will participate in the sixth world women's basketball cham pionships in Brazil May, 15 through 29.

title: Knifton Walks to Victory
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP, N. J., March 20 (AP)John Knifton of the New York Athletic Club missed the American record in the 20mile walk by less than nine minutes today in winning the annual race at Rider Col lege. Knifton was clocked in 2 hours 42:17,8 seconds, com pared with the record of 2:33.42 set last year by Goetz Klopfer.

title: HERBERT S. RAUH
description: Herbert S. Rauh, who retired 20 years ago as head of S. Rauh & Co., spats and chil dren's leggings manufacturer, died Friday in his apartment at the Carlyle Hotel. His age was 95.

title: HERBERT E. JENSEN
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., March 20Herbert E. Jensen, who re tired as treasury manager of Westinghouse Electric Corpora tion in 1961, died yesterday in Westwood Hall, a nursing home. He was 74 years old and lived at 98A Eaton Crest Drive, Eatontown.

title: A. S. Okun Fiance Of Joan A. Dankner
description: Miss Joan Aileen Dankner, an elementaryschool teacher in the New York City public school system, and Arthur S. Okun, a New York State as sistant attorney general in the Bureau of Securities and Public Financing, plan to be married here in August.

title: Senator Hughes Gets Aide
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, March 20 (UPI)  An insurance ex ecutive, Watson Powell Jr., was named today to head a national Hughes for. President committee to support Senator Harold E. Hughes of Iowa for the Demo cratic Presidential nomination.

title: Voting Bill in Carolina
description: RALEIGH, N. C., March 20 (AP)A bill seeking to lower the voting age in North Carolina to 18 years has cleared the House, 109 to 0, and has been sent to the Senate. The bill calls for a referendum next Nov. 4 on lowering the age for voting in state and local elec tions from 21 to 18.

title: Blazers Win in Overtime
description: BUFFALO, March 20 (AP)  Shaler Hatimon, who sat out the first half, scored 16 points in the fourth quarter and 6 more in overtime tonight as the Portland Trail Blazers shaded the Buffalo Braves, 132.129, in the National Basketball Asso ciation.

title: 10.6Mile Nassau Expressway May Be Completed in 10 Years
description: BABYLON, L.I., March 20 Plans for the 10.6mile Nassau Expressway were announced 10 years ago and the cost was estimated at $51.8million. But since then, only two miles of an eastbound portion have been built at a cost of $18million, and state officials now believe that the superhighway will cost more than $100million and will take at least another 10 years before completion.

title: For Young Readers: Has Caldecott's Name Been Taken in Vain?
description: Randolph Caldecott (184686) is the English illustrator who animated children's picture books, winging the eye from page to page and running away with the story line. (In Hey Diddle Diddle the manly Dish and the flirty Spoon run off only to have a quick fallhe shatters, she is re proved by her parents the knife and the fork.) The American Library As sociation's Caldecott Medal (1938) is the preeminent American picture book prize, the only such accolade for a single book from each (pre vious) year's publication.

C., March 20Miss Virginia Dee Anne Newell who is in her first year at the Case West tern Reserve School of Medi cine in Cleveland, plans to be married here Sept. 4 to Paul Dwaine Payne 2d, a law stu dent at the University of Akron. She is a graduate of Western College and he of Miami University, both in Ox ford, Ohio.

description: THE films of three new American writerdirec tors are so successful, so intelligent, so Sur prisingly competent in their highly dissimilar ways, that I'm tempted to believe  against my better judgment that talent will out in spite of philistine indifference and corporate interference and, sometimes, in spite of itself.

title: Bible Used in Church Fire
description: ROAIIOKE, Va., March 20 Firemen said pages torn from a pulpit Bible were used to set one or several small fires that did an estimated $25,000 damage yesterday at the Maple Street Baptist Church. The police blamed burglars.

title: Mrs. Meir Repeats Refusal to Withdraw To Pre1967 Lines
description: JERUSALEM, March 20 Premier Golds Meir showed no signs of weakening today in Is rael's demand for new, defensi ble frontiers with the Arab states after Foreign Minister Abba Eban's discussions with Nixon Administration officials over differences between the two countries.

title: Further communications about communications
description: The available literature about the future of communications is severely limited. Most of it is either the product of, or heavily influenced by, those with economic interests in the outcome. As Ben H. Bagdikian observes, In guessing the di rection of technology it is wise to ask who is in the best posi tion to profit most. There are some sciencefiction writers, journalists, philosophers and pundits who try to make the most of a bewildering array of hope and despairdepending upon their moodand econo mists, systems analysts and merchandisers who try to tell us what's likely by when and what it will all cost (without giving too much notice to what it's going to do to all of us).

title: U. S. Denies Loss
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)A United States Defense Department spokesman said no United States B52's had been lost in Indochina as the result of hostile action. He said three had crashed in the area over the years, but that none had been struck by enemy fire.

description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 20 (AP)The Phoenix Suns closed out their home schedule on a victorious note as they coasted to an easy 114107 victory over the Seattle Sonics tonight.

description: MOSCOW, March 20 (UPI) The Soviet Union launched yesterday the 400th in its all purpose Casinos program of weather, weaponry, research and surveillance satellites.

description: Spring clothes are simpleshirts and skirts, a fluid dress here, a collarless coat there. Their calm, collected kind of quiet is as fresh as the first daffo dil after all the feverish fashions of seasons past.

title: Mujib. Sees Gains in Dacca Talks
description: DACCA, Pakistan, March. 20 The leader of East Pakistan, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, report ed some progress today after emerging from his fourth bar gaining, session, with Pakistan's President, Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan; over East Paki stani demands for selfrule.

title: There Are Roughly Two Kinds of Bullfighters
description: MADRIDYes, I am an aficio nado. In almost the same breath, however, I have to add that the socalled typical bull fight to which the average American tourist is exposed is an event imbued with about as much art as one is likely to encounter on a visit to a country circus or perhaps a slaughterhouse. And so, what I would like to tell the million or so Americans who will be flocking to the plazas de taros across Spain this yearmany of them to be disgusted by the spectacleis that the secret of ap preciating bullfights is simply to do as the aficionados do: go to fights featuring members of the grupo especial, the best matadors in Spain. These dozen or so men are the most frequent performers during the eightmonth season, which from March into October. They fight the biggest bulls; they are paid the highest fees, and most often they show what la fiesta brava should bea spec tacle of great beauty and emotional transference.

title: BIG 4 FAR APART ON MIDEAST ISSUES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20The United States, the. Soviet Union, Britain and France are still far from agree ment on the issues of interna tional guarantees and peace keeping forces in the Middle East, according to informed sources.

title: Farmers Facing Two Worries: A Recurrence of Blight or an Oversupply of Corn
description: CHICAGO, March 20  As Midwestern farmers began tun ing up their machinery this week for early corn planting next month, they were facing two worrisome possibilitiesa recurrence of corn blight or an oversupply of corn and soybeans.

title: The Perennial Avant Garde
description: Don't let the title of Gerald Sykes's new book fool you. The avantgarde, as he sees it, is by no means perennial, since it was born in 19thcentury France and is now all but dead. Once geared to exploration and discovery, it has deserted its lonely faroutposts for an easy trip down the gullets of the Es tablishment. And where the arts that it led once created soulsustaining myths, they have today become trivialized by the headoverheart values of our technourban society.

title: Ozolins to Give Piano Recital
description: Arthur Ozolins will give a piano recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday. A former stu dent of Nadia Boulanger, Nadia Reisenberg and Vlado Perle muter, Mr. Ozolins will play works by Bach, Bartk, Chopin and Prokofiev.

title: Music
description: THE house deals the cards at random  John Cage is right about thatbut each of us arranges his hand in sequences and patterns to suit his own notion of what game is being played. For Virgil Thomson, the com poser and critic who will be 75 in November, the game is about clarity, grace, formal order and carepassionate care. A painstaking crafts man, he finishes things, and expects others to finish things; neatness, as in the old contests, counts. Charles Ives, for one, was not neat. But more of that.

title: Brazil Devalues Cruzeiro
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 20 (Reuters)  Brazil's Central Bank devalued the cruzeiro for the second time this year and announced that, from Monday, one United States dollar would he sold for 5.11 cruzeiros. The buying rate will he 5.08 cru zeiros. The previous rates for the dollar, set on Feb. 9 this year, were 5 cruzeiros and 5.03.

title: Leroy N. Takes Spring Pacing Final as Favored James Darren Finishes 7th

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The nation's trilliondollar gross national product sug gests an economy composed of giants  financial if not physical. There are, of course, some genuine giants of financial proportions, but the trilliondollar G.N.P. also in includes some modest entries.

title: Bridge in Oradell Is Reopened, But Shutdown's Effects Linger
description: ORADELL, N. J., March 20 The Oradell Avenue bridge has been reopened, two and half months behind schedule, but the sevenandahalfmonth shutdown of the town's prin cipal eastwest artery has had an impact that will be long remembered.

title: Orantes and Koch Reach Final in Venezuela Tennis
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 20 (UPI)  Manuel Orantes of Spain and Tom Koch of Brazil won semifinal matches today in thte Altamira international ten nis tournament.

title: Cambodian Ferry Sunk
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sun day, March 21 (Reuters)Viet cong gunners sank a vital ferry on the Tonle Sap River 19 miles north of Pnompenh today, breaking the supply lines to important military installations in central and eastern Cam bodia.

title: LATVIANS CHIDED FOR NATIONALISM; Party Chief Asserts Some Seek to Bar Russians
description: MOSCOW, March 20  The nead of Latvia's Communist party organization today as tied those Latvians who are nationalig that they Want to prevent the migration of Rus elan and other nonLatvian peo nies to that Baltic republic.

title: MONITORS URGED FOR ARMY REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 The Army policy changes an nounced yesterday that are aimed at ending discrimination in offbase housing and mili tary justice will require strict monitoring and the imposition of sanctions if they are to work, an Army judge said today.

title: The Travels of an Illegal Bug With No C.I.A. Connections
description: WE were in the firstclass cabin of Pan American World Air ways Flight 100, on a giant 747 sitting on a J.F.K. runway wait ing the goahead signal for its flight to London. The captain had announced an hour's delay. The stewardess popped the champagne, even though it was 10 A.M. My wife reached into her purse and drew out a small perforated cardboard box, tied with green ribbon. Across the top was written, Not to be opened until airborne.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE has found a way to resolve its impasse with the Securities and Exchange Commission over negotiated rates. The exchange itself won't comply with the S.E.C.'s April 5 directive, but it plans to inform members they may negotiate rates with impunity.

title: WAGONER SHOWS ECLECTIC'S TASTE
description: Dan Wagoner likes to be precise and accurate about performing movement and he has an eclectic's taste in join ing various styles together. The combination gives a charming variety to his work and also enables him to create dances that have his own personal surface finish to them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sadat Talks With Commanders
description: CAIRO, March 20 (Reuters) President Anwar elSadat conferred with his military commanders and ministers to day amid signs that Egypt is losing patience with the slow pace of the Middle East peace talks.

title: Et Al.
description: A collection of the C.B.S. newscaster's speeches on issues of the day. Sensible, general ized, nothing that men of good will could find fault with.

title: U.N. Assembly Tallied 424 Hours' Lost Time
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 (Reuters)  The General Assembly lost more than 424 hours' working time at the recent session because of the lateness of dele gates and the early adjourn ing of meetings, according to a report by Secretary Gen eral Thant.

title: The Theater: Long Day's Journey Into Night
description: HARTFORDin all of his early plays Eugene O'Neill was facing life and transmit ting experience. In the final plays he was facing himself. Long Day's Journey into Night, which is now being given a distinguished produc tion by the Hartford Stage Company, is probably the greatest of American plays.

title: StockCar Official Resigns
description: SPEEDWAY, Ind., March 20 (UPI) Bill Taylor, United Stat (UPI)  Bill Taylor, United States Auto Club stockcar su pervisor for three years, sub mitted his resignation today.

title: MRS. KING SCORES IN A 3SET MATCH
description: ROCHZSTER; Mich., March 20 (AP)Topseeded. Mrs. Bil lie Jean King Played a strong net game to wear down Brit ain's Mrs. Ann Jones and the No. 2 seeded, player, Rosemary Casals, defeated Mrs. Mary Ann Curtis of St. Louis in the semifinals of the KMart in vitation tennis tournament to day.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Instead of old and new Nixons, there are now said to be two Nixons, the public and the private  and maybe even a third Nixon. It is the private President, we are told, who has been finally coaxed and encouraged to show himself so elaborately in public.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Opera: Dead or Alive
description: Detailed examination of opera styles, productions, personnel, business problems, etc. There is a curious lack of a personal point of view, which the gen eral reader may find discourag ing, but the book has authority.

title: June Nuptials. Being Planned By Sheila Long
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 20Mr. and Mrs., John C. Long have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Sheila Long, to Andrew Munster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Munster of Park Ridge, Ill. The wed ding is planned for June.

title: Nassau Is Warned That Water Supply Is in Growing Peril
description: MINEOLA, L. L, March 20 An official of the state Environ mental Conservation Depart ment warned the Nassau Coun ty Planning Commission last week that steps should be tak en to combat water pollution and a decrease in Nassau's wa ter supply.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: TOKYO, March 20 (UPI) Su Robert Thompson, the Brit ish guerrilla expert who is an adviser to President Nixon, be lieves the invasions of Cam bodia and Laos have removed the military threat to South Vietnam.

title: Music
description: TWO pleasant and useful books have crossed this desk,Per cussion Instruments and Their History, by James Blades (pub lished by Praeger), and The Piano Duet by Ernest Lubin (Grossman). The Blades book is bigger, and it is an epochal work of its kind. Blades is a British percussiornst who lives, breathes, eats and sleeps percussion, loves percussion and, the guess is, talks about nothing but percussion. He lives in a world of stretched skins, drum sticks and cross rhythms, and is the dear kind of man who can write in his preface about such household names as Gerassimos Avgerinos, Jan Labor dus, Tele Lesbines and Karel Cernicky. But admittedly Blades's household different from most others. (I suppose we all have our own household names. Mine include Paul Morphy, Moritz Moszkowski, James Branch Cabell and Natalie Janotha.)

title: For G.I.'s, Freedom Bird Means Home
description: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, March 20 (AP)For the soldier, DEROS by any other name would smell as sweet. It is military jargon for Date of Es timated Return From Overseas. It means going home.

title: New Marines to Find Life EasierFor a While, at Least
description: SAN DIEGO, March 20  Tommy Taylor, an 18yearold high school dropout from Indianapolis, stumbled sleepy eyed from a bus at the Marine Corps recruit depot one night this week and stood in trem bling fear before a leathery faced drill sergeant.

title: David Breeden Plans to Wed Miss Evelyn Pennell in July
description: WASHINGTON, Conn., March 20 Miss Evelyn Pennell and David William Breeden, both Peace Corps volunteers from 1967 to 1969 in Kenya, East Africa, plan to be mar ried here July 3.

title: Boston U. Wins N.C. A. A. Hockey Title by Beating Minnesota in Final, 42
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 20 Boston University, sparked by Capt. Steve Stirling's two goals, shed its bridesmaid role tonight by beating Minnesota, 42, to win the National Collegi ate hockey championship.

title: Mary Shotter Bartholomew Bride
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 Miss Mary Shotter Barthol omew was married here this afternoon to Prof. Daniel Walter Bernd of Homewood, Ill., in the Universalist Na tional Memorial Church by the Rev. Seth R. Brooks.

title: Crisis for Golfers
description: The future of the private golf club is being threatened by rising costs, a study has found. The club golfer is trapped in the middle of the squeeze, forced to pay higher fees to re tain his membership and to keep the club in business.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: With determined resigna tion, quiet frustration and oc casional bursts of outright anger, Wall Street is girding itself for what could prove to be the most unsettling event for the securities in dustry since the crash of 1929.

title: UNDERWOOD TIES MILLER WITH 210
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. March 20  John Miller of San Francisco carded a threeunder par 69 in a howling wind today and tied Hal. Underwood for the lead after three rounds in the $125,000 Greater Jacksonville open tournament. Their totals were 210.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: A flurry of selfexamina tion among corporate per sonnel directors and publish ers of tests has emerged in the wake of a Supreme Court decision two weeks ago bar ring discriminatory job test ing.

title: BOOKMOBILES AID NEW BORROWERS
description: A bookmobile project spon sored by the Model Cities pro gram is overcoming bureau cratic problems to bring the pleasure of reading to hundreds of residents of central Brook lyn who normally have little op portunity to obtain new books etc who are intimidated by pub ??c libraries.

title: Home Improvement
description: COMBINING the ap pearance and weath erresistant durability of masonry with the laborsaving easy installa tion that is characteristic of plywood, the unusual exte rior panel material illustrat ed at right is actually a pre finished form of siding that needs no painting or other maintenance. It consists of colored chips of stone per manently bonded with a special epoxy coating to the face of exterior plywood panels, and it can be used for remodeling older homes, as well as for finishing new houses and additions. It is also suitable for use over ex posed foundations, for build ing fences and for installa tion on interior walls where a colorful, textured masonry effect, or an outdoor look.

title: Saigon and Pnompenh Assail Pillaging
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 20A joint report by high South Vietnamese and Cambodian officials calls for radical measures to halt vi olence and theft by South Viet namese troops against Cambo dian civilians.

title: In North Bergen, Boxing Is Something to Do When Bingo Takes a Night Off
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J.Outside, red neon lights blink Embassy on the white marquee above the Bergenline Avenue storefronts. Once it was a movie theater, but now it advertises seven bingo dates each week. And about once a month there's a boxing show.

title: Canada Beats Scotland For World Curling Title
description: MEGEVE, France, March 20 (UPI)Canada swept to another world curling title with a 95 victory over Scot land today. The triumph gave Canada the Silver Broom Trophy for the 11th time in 13 years.

title: Et Al.
description: A solid history of the peasant revolts that enlivened the 17th century. Although the author limits his discussion to the three countries of the title, the phenomenon was worldwide. The French section bogs down in its inquiry into the class and tax situation, but otherwise is fresh and interestingparticu larly in its contrast to the usual lives of kings and their great and good friends.

title: Palm Beach is the big stadium and if you don't make it you go back to the bushes
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.

title: ROCKEFELLER ASKS $25BILLION BONDS TO AID TRANSPORT
description: ALBANY, March 20Gover Inor Rockefeller proposed today a $2.5 billion transportation bond issue that he said was needed to avoid a halt in all state highway construction and masstransportation projects next year.

title: JERSEY LEADERS FAVOR VOTE AT 18
description: TRENTON, March 20  The Republican majority leaders of the State Legislature announced this week that they would try to make New Jersey the first state in the nation to ratify an amendment to the United States Constitution that would allow 18yearolds to vote in state and local elections.

title: One Billion Americans?
description: If American families average two children and immi gration remains the same, the population of the United States will grow from the present 206 million to 266 mil lion by the year 2000. By 2071, the total would be 340 million. If families average three children, the population will soar to 321 million by 2000 and to nearly a billion hundred years from now.

title: Former Albany, Ga., Police Chief Builds a New Reputation in a New Town
description: HIGH POINT, N. C., March 13For Laurie. Pritchett, Al bany, Ga., is 500 miles, a bitter 10 years and an embarrassing era away from this quiet Pied mont plateau town.

title: Protection From Police Action Asked for Soviet Coin Collectors
description: MOSCOW, March 20Some prominent Soviet archeologists have called for legal measures to protect coin collectors from police harassment and criminal prosecution.

title: Kerr on Enemy of the People, Pinkville and Dream on Monke Mountain
description: WHEN Fredric March and Morris Carnov sky played Arthur Miller's somewhat free adaptation of Ibsen's An Enemy of the People here in 1950, no attempt was made to tame it into what Mr. Miller calls realism. It was offered, exuberantly, as high melodramatic rhetoric, with the principal opponents squaring off to make the best possible cases for themselves at the tops of their lively, and very persuasive, lungs. As un abashed argument, done at aria pitch, it was wonder fully exciting.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  Sena tor Sam J. Ervin Jr.'s tour weeks of hearings into the Government's collection of information on American cit izens seem to have persuad ed almost everyone but the Justice Department that a certain amount of Govern mental ignorance is bliss.

title: How to Fly to Morocco
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Ulster Leader Quits. Under Protestant Pressure
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 20The Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, Maj. James D. ChichesterClark resigned to night after resisting growing Protestant pressure for militant moves against Roman Catholics.

title: A vision of ourselves as a society of vampires
description: Richard Titmuss is a careful schol ar, a gentle person, and a socialist of Fabian instincts. A man of sense and sensibility, he resists the de mons of his nightmare; but he brings us to within a razor's edge of vision of ourselves as a society of mechanized vampires, living off the blood of others, using our institutions to redistribute the available sup plies of blood from the deprived to the affluent classes, from the impov erished to the powerful nations. All this, he says, has not yet fully come to pass but it is the drift of things.

title: Mural Depicting Birth of a Library Returned Home
description: Last month it hung in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and before that it had been displayed in Detroit, and Tallahassee and Fort Lauder dale, Fla. Now the 40foot mural is back in its home hanging in the Langston Hughes Community Library and Cultural Center in Queens.

title: L.I. Offers Bounty of Culinary Riches
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., March 20  It is no surprise whatever that three poets as dissimilar as Walt Whitman, John Howard Payne and John Hall Wheelock should exult in their works about home and the land. They have one overweening thing in common. They were born and reared on Long Island.

title: GIAP SAYS AMERICANS CANNOT AVOID LOSING
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 20 (Agence France. Presse)Deputy Premier Vo Nguyen Giap said yesterday that the United States, its wild illusions shattered, was un able to avoid total defeat in Indochina.

title: City Adopts Rule Allowing Interviews With Prisoners
description: The city's Department of Correction has adopted a new regulation permitting reporters to interview prisoners await ing trial.

title: SchoolTax Relief Is Sought in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 20 Nassau County Democrats pro posed this week that counties throughout the state be given the option of levying up to a 20 per cent surtax on state in come and business taxes for the purpose of lowering local educational costs.

title: Agent Provocateur Of Films
description: PARIS.

title: CANADIANS SURPRISE IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: WILMINGTON, Del., March 20Bill Bewley and Vinnie Taylor of Toronto upset the thirdseeded team of Maurice Heckscher and Kit Spahr, the Pennsylvania titleholders, 15 10, 1215, 1015, 1512, 1816, to gain the quarterfinal round today in the United States squash racquets doubles cham pionship at the Wilmington Country Club.

title: Hoist the Flag, Colt With Charisma, Entered in Gotham
description: Jean Cruguet's lean face broke into a wide grin recently at Aqueduct when the name of Hoist the Flag came up.

title: Stamps
description: GEORGE ECKMAN re ports from Tokyo that the Phoenix, a bird out of mythology, will dominate the design of a 150 yen definitive stamp from Japan on March 29. Observ ing that Japan's stamp de sign committee exercises a sense of shibuigood taste in the restrained and cultured manner of old tradition, Col. Eckman writes that the Phoenix (Ho, Howo or Hoho bird) is one of the best known supernatural creatures of Eastern mythology and equally well known in West ern myths. The Phoenix of ancient Egypt was sacred to the sun god Ra because of its ability to rise out of the ashes in rebirth to become a symbol of immortality.

title: Dance
description: EVEN marathons come to an end, and the American modern dance season at the ANTA Theater, described as an American Dance Mara thon, crossed the finish line last weekend. It had given New York eight weeks of uninterrupted moderndance, with a little classic ballet creeping in at the end.

title: Hoist the Flag,15, Wins by 7 Lengths
description: Hoist the Flag, the long range favorite for the Ken tucky Derby, strengthened his position by winning the $34, 400 Bay Shore at Aqueduct yesterday. The fact that Mrs. Stephen Clark's representative won the sevenfurlong event was not in itself sufficient to further his potential. It was the manner in which he did it.

title: Oh, to Be Out In England
description: Coming out in Englanddelicious, fascinating, ponderable: Will it hap pen this way again? Not likely. What gave it the special edge?

title: RALPH BUTLER, 88, OF GENERAL FOODS
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 20 Ralph Starr Butler, who re tired as a vice president of General Foods Corporation in 1948 and who had been an educator and a leader in adver tising and merchandising asso ciations, died today at his home, 52 Midland Avenue. His age was 88.

title: Big Ten to Consider Bears As Evanston Tenants Today
description: CHICAGO, March 20 (UPI) Big Ten Conference officials will meet tomorrow to recon sider their refusal to allow the Chicago Bears to play in North western University's Dyche Stadium in suburban Evanston, Ill.

title: Abigail Coffin Dammin Engaged
description: WESTON, Mass., March 20 Miss Abigail Coffin Dam min, a student at Moore Col lege of Art in Philadelphia, and Livingston Vance Watrous, a graduate student in classical archeology at the University of Pennsylvania, plan to be married in June.

title: Cavaliers Wing 114103
description: CLEVELAND, March 20 (AP)  Walt Wesley scored 33 points, Dave Sorenson 27 and Bobby Smith 23 tonight to lead the Cleveland Cavaliers to 114103 victory over the De troit Pistons.

title: An Early Start for Begonias
description: BRILLIANT color, un usual blooms and dra matic foliage are abundant when tend er bulbs, tubers and rhizomes perform well in northern gardens. Some prefer shade; others full sun.

title: The World
description: MOSCOW  At Shere myetevo, Moscow's interna tional airport, about 70 So viet citizens boarded an Aeroflot flight to Vienna last week. It was, for the Soviet Union, a highly political event. The passengers  of all age groupswere leav ing for good. And the per mission for them to do so reflected an apparent policy decision in the Kremlin to let Jews emigrate to Israel in increasing numbers.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: WITH the return of spring, hopes are bulding up as they do perennially at this point in the yearfor a decisive breakout in consumer spending and general business activity. But not many blossoms can be sighted as yet on the economic bush.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Yonkers Air Force Captain Dies in Accident in England
description: SAXMUNDHAM, England, March 20 (UPI)  A United States Air Force captain from Yonkers who won the Distin guished Flying Cross in Viet nam died in a threecar crash near here today.

title: M'GOVERN ASSERTS HE'D END THE WAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 Senator George S. McGovern, the only declared candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, has asserted he would negotiate a settlement of the Indochina war within weeks of being inaugurated President in 1973.

title: Kings Point Leads Regatta
description: Kings Point, with three first place finishes in seven races, took the firstday lead yester day in the Admiral Moore Trophy regatta at the New York State Maritime Academy at Fort Schuyler.

title: Walter and Jean Kerr Are Awarded Laetare Medal
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 20 Walter F. Kerr, New York Times Sunday drama critic, and his wife and fel low author, Jean, have been named the 1971 recipients of the Laetare Medal, the Uni versity of Notre Dame's high est honor.

title: Grant Given for Conversion Of Garbage Into Crude Oil
description: WORCESTER, Mass., March 20 (AP)Dr. Alvin H. Weiss and a team of researchers at Worcester Polytechnic Insti tute have won a $129,000 grant to spend two years seeking ways to convert trash and gar bage to crude oil.

title: Tenant, 82, Killed in Fire; Religious Candle Blamed
description: A fire that started in an East Harlem tenement yesterday when religious candles tipped over took one life and left seven families homeless, the po lice reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Horseman Recalls Brooklyn
description: Horse Show News

title: City Still Lags in Housing
description: The city's plan to start 14, 000 mostly new units of low rent public housing in 1971 has already fallen behind schedule. And less than two months after the plan was first announced as the biggest public housing building program in the history of New York City, there are mounting doubts among hous ing experts that the city can meet its goal by year's end.

title: CANBY SINGERS USE AN 1808 PIANOFORTE
description: The debut of an 1808 Broadwood fortepiano, recently restored by Charles Wilson, stole the limelight at the Canby Singers' concert in Carnegie Re cital Hall Saturday night. Both Haydn and Beethoven owned similar models of this historic Englishmade instrument, and presumably they wrote many works with its particular sound in mind.

title: Mayor Follows Up His Inner Circle ActLike an Actor
description: Sardi's is where the cast goes after opening night, and the Mayor of New York, not one to break tradition  at least, not yetended up there in the early hours of yester day morning after his starring role in the Inner Circle pro duction of Help!

title: Yankees Snap Losing Streak at 12 Games
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 21After losing 12 con secutive games and looking like inept amateurs much of the time while doing it, the Yankees were flooded by a cas cade of success today.

title: Books of The Times
description: Aaron Latham's engagingly titled ac count of Scott Fitzgerald's involvement with Hollywood covers not only his final years there but also a couple of briefer stops earlier (including his screen test as a leading man In the twenties and his famous disgrace at Sunday tea with the Irving Thalbergs in the early thirties). How much you enjoy it will depend on your appetite for Hollywood anec dotage and for de talla of Fitz gerald's by now rather familiar personal history: This isn't a book that changes the picture in any major way, as Nancy Milford's remarkable Zelda did. Mr; Latham modestly follows Arthur Mizener's and par ticularly Andrew Turnbull's biog raphies; he retells stories from Sheilah Graham's memoirs, Dwight Taylor's, Lil lian Hellman's, and from Bosley Crowther's The Lion's Share. But he fills in some gaps, he names some names, he's inter viewed several people we haven't heard from before. The most valuable (and most tantalizing and frustrating) aspect of his book is that he's had a, look at Scott Fitzgerald's movie scripts, which almost nobody else has seen or written about.

title: Nixon Back in White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)  President Nixon re turned to the White House tonight after a weekend alt Camp David in Maryland.

title: LIBERTY PERILED, ITALIANS WARNED
description: NAPLES, Italy, March 21  Premier Emilio Colombo warned today that Italy's democratic freedoms were menaced.

title: Harold Miller. Weds Lynne E. Goldsmith
description: In the Stephen. Wise Free Synagogue yesterday after, noon, Miss Lynne Ellen Gold smith was married to Harold Michael Miller by Rabbi James Ferman. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Gene Goldsmith of New York and the late Mr. Goldsmith, who was with N. W. Ayer & Son, Inc., the advertising agency. Mr. Miller is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Miller of Yonkers.

title: Officer Weds, Abby Howell
description: OYSTER BAY, L. 1, March 21Miss Abby Howell and First Lieut. James Philip Sam uels, U.S.A.F., a pilot sta tioned at McGuire Mr Force Base in New Jersey, were married here today in Christ Episcopal Church. The Rev. Robert T. Hollett, the rector, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Gary F. Maier. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Douglass Howell. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Patrie Winston Samuels and Seymour Sam uels of New York:

title: Heath and Wilson Meet
description: LONDON, March 21Harold Wilson, leader of the Labor Op position, conferred with Prime Minister Heath today in an at mosphere of urgency over the Northern Ireland political cri sis.

title: HERMAN GOTTESMAN OF CREDIT CONCERN
description: Herman Gottesman, retired vice president and treasurer of the Credit Utility Banking Cor poration, died yesterday in Mount Siani Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 262 Central Park West.

title: State CleanWater Aides Cheered by U. S. Promises
description: When Governor Rockefeller won a billiondollar bond issue in 1965 to build sewage treat ment plants, it was on his broad commitment that the sixyear plan would result in the elim ination of water pollution in New York's lakes, streams and rivers.

title: McGuire of South Carolina Denies Move to New York
description: COLUMBUS, S. C., March 21 (UPI)  Frank McGuire, South Carolina basketball coach, has denied reports that he plans to have the Gamecocks for a sim ilar post at New York Univer sity.

title: GIRL, 14, EXCELS IN RIDING EVENTS
description: RYE,. N.Y., March 21Blair Pinsley, a 14yearold from Red Bank, N.J., dominated the Ban bury Cross horseshow today by riding the winners of the large pony and regular working hunter championships.

title: Butchering a Budget
description: Governor Rockefeller has switched. Will he fight?

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 There is no real dispute here anymore that the quantum jump in President Nixon's public ex posure, including tomorrow night's scheduled interview with Howard K. Smith, is de signed in large part to smooth the edges of the Nixon image, to present to the public the appealing Presi dential personality that his staff says it sees in private, to provide a vari ety of settings in which to explain his policies, and to lift his ratings in the public opinion polls.

title: ONE MILLION JOIN INVESTOR BRIGADE
description: The nation's shareholder pop ulation grew by about one mil lion during 1970, despite the stockmarket decline, and reached an estimated 31.9 mil lion at the beginning of this year, according to a report is sued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Personal Finance
description: It's not the most pleasant thing to contemplate, but if your spouse died today either unexpectedly or after a long illnesswould you know where to find all the papers, legal documents, in surance policies, valuables and other things that most people accumulate over the years?

title: Minor Gains Made by Gaullists In French Municipal Elections
description: PARIS, March 21The ruling Gaullists and their allies made only :slight gains today in their efforts to win power in France'S 37,713 municipalities.

title: Beaunit Corp Changing Management Structure
description: Beaunit Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the El Paso Natural Gas Company, has reorganized its manage ment structure, dissolving its separate fiber and textile divi sions to provide broader staff support to all areas of the con cern's business.

title: PIANO RECITAL GIVEN BY WILLIS STEVENS
description: Willis Stevens, pianist in residence at St. Mary's Col lege in Indiana; gave a Town Hall recital Saturday afternoon, his third since his local debut in 1964. His program gave evi dence of careful planning, and there were times when sensi tive musicality shone, through his careful playing. For the, most part, however, the per forrnances were lackuster and the inner dimensions of the music remained untapped.

title: SOCCER GROUP LEAD LOST BY ELIZABETH
description: The German  Hungarians dropped Elizabeth, the United States soccer champion, from first place in the South Group of the GermanAmerican Soc cer League yesterday, with a 42 defeat, while New York Hota, the leader in the North Group, downed Hungaria, 53.

title: Spending by City Is Criticized by Citizens' Group
description: A leading civic watchdog group declared yesterday that New York Citys problems must be solved and can be solved, but complained of con tinuing inefficiency in city government.

title: N.Y. Board of Trade Elects New President
description: The New York Board of Trade has announced the elec tion of Robert S. Marker as its president. The board is a private organization whose members are major New Yorkbased corporations.

title: Chi Cheng Fete Today
description: An article in yesterday's New York Times incorrectly re ported that Chi Cheng, the world champion Taiwan sprint er, would receive the Tanqueray Sports Achievement Award at a luncheon at Gallagher's Res taurant tomorrow. The lunch eon has been scheduled for today.

title: Arts Abroad
description: BASEL, SwitzerlandPeter Handke first came to public notice six years ago when, in his narly twenties, he shook up a Princeton meeting of the German Writers Associa tion Gruppe 47 with a widely publicized blast against what he charged was a lit erary parade. At the time, Handke had pub lished one un successful, rather dull novel, Die Hornissen (The Hornets). His youth, his Beatle hairdo were then more noticeable than his achievements. By creating a deliberate scandal, young Handlke seemed likely to be come a literary Showman rather than a powerful new writer. Yet quite the oppo site has happened. Within six years, the workingclass boy from the Austrian pro vincial capital of Graz, who was raised by the Jesuits and studied law, has become a highly considered best selling novelist and an effec tive playwright as well, such as with his latest Ritt Uber den Bodensee (The Ride Over Lake Constance).

title: Chile Defeats Colombia,32, In So. American Davis Cup
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 21 (UPI)Chile defeated Co lombia, 32, in their South American Zone Davis Cup ten nis series today when Patricio Cornejo beat Ivan Molina in the final singles, 6.3, 64, 62.

title: MRS. THOMAS TOWELL
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 21Mrs. Loretta M. Tanker Towel], wife of Thomas W. Towell, former president of General Motors Acceptance Corporation, died yesterday at the New Rochelle Medical Center. She was 64 years old and lived at 14 South Ridge Road.

title: GERMAN VOTE WON BY CONSERVATIVES
description: BONN, March 21The con servative Christian Democratic Union won an, election today in the West German State of Rhineland Palatinate with 50 per cent of the vote and thus will continue to govern the state.

title: . . . And a Decision for Peking
description: Another unhappy consequence of the cold war has been the unfortunate habit the State Department got into of declaring various countries off limits to Americans who did not have specific State Department clearance for a visit. China, of course, was the prime case in point until the Nixon Administration eased the regulations during the President's first year in office. As a result it has been a long time since any American scholar or journalist has faced any serious problem in obtaining State Department approval for a proposed visit to China. Nevertheless it was wise for the department totally lift its ban on American travel to China so that the question of obtaining even formal Washington per mission no longer arises.

title: Manager of U.S. Tourist Office Seized in New Greek Roundup
description: ATHENS, March 21  The general manager of the Greek branch of the American Express was arrested here Friday in the latest security roundup ordered by the Government.

title: Maine Sugar and Creditors Reach a Tentative Accord
description: PORTLAND, Me., March 21 (AP)  A tentative agreement between Maine Sugar Indus tries, Inc., and its creditors, the Finger Lakes Sugar Beet Growers Association, was reached this weekend after a fourhour session in United States District Court.

title: Cronkite to Do Saturday TV Shows for Children
description: Walter Cronkite is going to get equal time with Bugs Bun ny next fall in the Columbia Broadcasting Syttem's Saturday lineup of televised children's programs.

title: Bars Tap New Law By Opening Earlier, Confusing the Police
description: Taking advantage of a new state law, hundreds of bars throughout the city opened their doors and began serving drinks at noon instead of at 1 P.M. yesterday. The change was as smooth as a sip of good Scotch, except for some con fusion on the part of the Police Department.

title: Royals' Baseball Academy Dedicated by Kuhn, Others

title: Sports of The Times
description: The most common physical complaint of dedicated horseshoe pitchers is chronic leftheel bursitis. The only thought held in common by all athletes is that the fans are for the birds. Inactivity can lead to loafer's heart. Box lacrosse is the national game of Canada. Athletes from countries with high infant mortality rates do poorly in the Olympics. Experienced handball players use up fewer calo ries than inexperienced handball players. And psychoana lysts who understand golf may derive a greater communica tion with their golfing patients since golfers are usually more than happy to report the details of their play.

title: Carol Ann Gluck Is a Bride Here
description: Miss Carol Ann Gluck was married here last eve ning to Frederick St. Vrain Rickard. Both are doctoral candidates at New York Uni versity, where her field is educational psychology And his is counseling psychology.

description: WASHINGTON, March 21 The United States is cautious ly exploring the possibility of resumption of the indirect EgyptianIsraeli peace talks at the United Nations, qualified diplomats said today.

White, pledg ing to put the city's high schools back on a sane opera tive basis, said today that he had ordered plainclothes police men, firemen and truant offi cers to patrol certain schools as a last resort. Several high schools have been hit by stu dent boycotts and disruptions that have included fires, mass walkouts, false alarms and as saults.

title: Na Barriers Against Ideas . . .
description: The Federal court ruling that Dr. Ernest E. Mandel, noted Belgian Marxist scholar, could not be barred from delivering lectures or attending conferences in the United States upsets a repressive edict by Attorney Gen eral John N. Mitchell. In denying an entry visa to Dr. Mandel, the Justice Department embarrassed the United States rather than the applicanta fact evidently under stood by Secretary of State William P. Rogers, who had urged Mr. Mitchell to admit the scholar.

title: Screen: Wise's 'Andromeda Strain'
description: Of all the solutions that science-fiction movies have proposed for the problems facing mankind, my favorite is the saline solution. I mean that handy diffusion of salt in water, as available as your local ocean, that, when the Army and the Navy and the Atomic Energy Commission have failed, proves to be the only thing that will shrivel a Triffid or shrink a Monolith Monster down to size.Somebody has introduced a bit of ultimate ocean (the Pacific) at the end of "The Andromeda Strain"one of several additions, plus a few subtractions, that have been made in Robert Wise's screen version without in any way improving upon (in my opinion) Michael Crichton's dreadful novel. In general the drift of the filmmakers has been to heat things up: laser beams rather than curare guns to complicate the crises; a littlewell, I shouldn't call it romance, but the kind of girl (Paula Kelly) with whom there might be romance once this awful mess is overand a momentary crunch of conscience for the Wildfire scientists when they discover, quite gratuitously, that their benevolent top-secret project is really a cover for research in germ warfare.Wildfire, from deep in its fifth sub-basement super-antiseptic laboratories in Nevada, has been engaged in tracking the extraterrestrial reason that almost the entire population of a little Arizona town died one night when they opened up the nose cone of a retrieved satellite. The assembling of the scientists (Arthur Hill, David Wayne, James Olson and Kate Reidno one of whom gets a chance at a real performance) and their biological research against time is all the action of "The Andromeda Strain."Crichton put his novel together as if from a collection of note cardsa story outline beefed up with a lot of semi-scientific data. Wise preserves the impoverished positivism of Crichton's method (even to dividing his screen in a dull bid for informational range) but necessarily assigns most of it to his actors. The result is that, except for an odd 30 seconds here and there for individualization (not characterization), everybody delivers exposition right up to and through the last lines of the film.Despite all the drama of the situation (United States threatened with biological destruction from outer space, etc.) nothing very exciting goes on in "The Andromeda Strain." Since nobody greatly feels or acts, we are left with the drama of people tensely sitting around in chairs, twisting dials and watching TV monitors. From time to time, somebody gets up and paces the room.Occasionally "The Andromeda Strain" returns to the sacred texts, not of science but of science-fiction, and admits its five vulgar resources  as in the sea water, or when in the massive microscope the alien green matter suddenly shimmers and expands, and in agonized horror the Nobel Prize-winning bacteriologist turns to the distinguished microbiologist with, "My God, it's growing!"

title: The Screen: Making It,' the Story of an Adolescent
description: "Making It," which opened yesterday at the Coronet Theater, is about Phil Fuller, a 17-year-old Albuquerque high school student who has read Joyce and Hemingway and Miller, who says that Willa Cather is "girl's stuff" and that Salinger sentimentalizes adolescence. The movie presents Phil's literary credentials, which we have to take more or less on faith (although we do see him carrying a copy of "Tropic of Cancer"), as if to certify his sensibilities, but it has the secondary effect of reminding us of other, more complex fictional world, beside which Phil's is as simplistic as it is bleak.In its own, rather backhanded way, "Making It" sentimentalizes Phil's adolescence by placing him in a world circumscribed by well-meaning failures and idiots, all of whom are over 30 and thus, according to the gospel that Phil has had preached at him in movies like this, either envy him or mistrust him.His widowed, mini-skirted mother, who insists on acting like a sister to her son, wakes up at night crying over her lost youth. Yvonne, the wife of the football coach, seduces Phil, who then junks her at about the time she reaches her 30th birthday. Mr. Mallory, Phil's English teacher who is defeated by things like a haggard wife and crying babies, urges Phil to become committed to something, to grow up. He finally does, or so we are led to believe, when he accidentally finds himself assisting at his mother's abortion."Making It," which was written by Peter Bart and directed by John Erman (his first theatrical feature), quite happily avoids a lot of the more hysterical clichs of most under-20 movies. There are no riots, no psychedelic sequences. The soundtrack music is kept to a minimum. But Phil is such a mild, non-particular sort of fellow that it is impossible, at least for me, to become terribly involved.It is perhaps significant that the only moving moments in the film involve the feelings of other characters, such as those of his mother, nicely played by Joyce Van Patten as a sort of pretty, but passive, perennial stenographer, or they involve a certain amount of cruelty, as when Phil turns-on the mother of his girl by giving her a mashed up Marlboro, which she thinks is pot.At the heart of the film is Kristoffer Tabori's performance as Phil. He is a handsome, intelligent young actor, yet what he does kept reminding me of the sort of formances Margaret O'Brien used to give by using adult gestures imposed on her by a drama coach. I should add that at the time I saw the film I did not remember that Mr. Tabori, the son of Viveca Lindfors and Don Siegel, the director (but who uses the surname of his stepfather, George Tabori, the playwright), had actually been a successful child actor on the New York stage some years ago.Phil, of course, spends a good deal of his time in "Making It" playing roles, as man-of-the-world (with a fake mustache), as guidance counselor to his adolescent mother, but when Phil drops his disguises, Mr. Tabori seems to find only a rather well-varnished, professional teenager. Like the movie itself, the performance is composed of details, all of which are accurate enough but which are never fitted together to make an especially meaningful experience.

Everyone smiles. There is a cordiality. An in formal atmosphere. It's some thing like a party you're glad you came to.
