description: Major elements of television are bracing for a tilt with Congress and the Nixon Administration on the exercise of reportorial independence by a journalistic medium that operates under a Federal Government license. The issue, one of the oldest in the evolution of broadcasting, is coming to a climax over the coverage of fighting in Laos. In a step believed to be without parallel in radio or television, Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, former journalist himself, is sending a personal letter to every member of the Senate and the House, objecting to a recent Congressional review of film footage from Laos.

title: Nixon Submits Plan to Merge 9 Volunteer Programs
description: WASHINGTON, March 24After weeks of internal infighting, President Nixon unveiled today a general plan for merging the Peace Corps, VISTA and seven other voluntary service programs.

title: Drug Abuse Office Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of the Bronx, and a bipartisan group of 49 other House members introduced today legislation to create an office of drug abuse control within the Executive Office of the President. Under the measure, the director of the drug office would have his own budget and appropriations and would have the authority to coordinate the activities of all Federal agencies to combat drug abuse.

title: Governor to Seek Aid
description: SEATTLE, March 24 (AP)Gov. Daniel J. Evans said to day that the state would immediately ask for Federal economic aid to replace the rejected SST funding.

title: Prices in Band Market Falter As Rates Display Upward Move
description: The credit markets trend toward higher prices and lower interest rates that got under way on March 9 faltered yesterday.

title: SENATE BARS FUNDS FOR SST, 5146; NIXON CALLS VOTE SEVERE BLOW
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 The Senate voted, 51 to 46, today to end further funding of the supersonic transport aircraft.

title: Johnson, Ex Champion, Is Back in Business at 42
description: Out on Broadway, next to the gaudy Fascination amusement center and across from the Circus Cinema, a vertical sign advertised a Flame Steak for $1.59 with baked potato, garlic bread and salad. Inside, behind a partition that created a back room for the occasion, Harold Johnson was on display. Ordinarily, a boxing promoter uses such restaurants as Toots Shor's or Les Champs or Jack Dempsey's for a news luncheon, but somehow the Flame Steak back room, with its bare walls and tile floor, was the perfect setting to announce the 42yearold grandfather's comeback.

title: Fire Delays IRT Trains
description: Trains on the IRT Seventh Avenue line in Brooklyn were delayed 25 minutes at the height of the rush hour last night when a train developed an electrical fire at the Borough Hall station. There were no injuries.

title: CANADIAN HOPES DIM FOR AN OIL PIPELINE
description: OTTAWA, March 24Canadian hopes that a route through Canada might be used to bring Alaskan oil to United States markets dimmed today after a meeting between Government ministers and the senior executives of five international oil companies.

title: Mexico City Gets Tough New Law Against Pollution
description: MEXICO CITY, March 24 A new antipollution law, said to be the toughest in Latin America, went into effect here today in an effort to combat Mexico's growing environmental problem.

title: About Pro Basketball
description: A legal tightrope walking act of breathtaking; or at least bewildering, proportions may bring about a mer. ger of the National Basketball, Association and the American Basketball Association very quicklyor It may end, in a slip that will lead to a bigger court fight than the one now in progress about Spencer Haywood. There were strong reports yesterday that essential agreement on merger terms had been reached Tuesday night by enough N. B. A. owners to carry the proposition through their league. A. B. A. owners have been in favor of a merger all along.

title: PREVIN CONDUCTS THE PHILADELPHIA
description: Perhaps because of his backgrand In moviemusic scoring, for which he his won four Oscars, Andr Previn seems drawn to symphonic works that in the wrong hands can sound like the music that flourished back when Hollywood was really Hollywood. The three pieces that the Philadelphia Orchestra played under Mr. Previn at Philharmonic Hall on Tuesday night could never be confused with filmtrack music, since Mr. Previn is a better conductor than he was a few seasons ago. And Berlioz, Vaughan Williams and Shostakovich do rate serious artists.

title: $2,400 Family Guarantee Approved by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  The House Ways and Means Committee has reached tentative agreement on a comprehensive revision of the welfare system that would guarantee a $2,400 annual income for a poor family of four from Federal funds.

title: Thieu Said to Have Curbed Offensive to Reduce Loss
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Wellplaced Pentagon sources say that President Nguyen Van Thieu decided to curtail South Vietnam's offensive in Laos despite suggestions from some senior American militarymen that he send in replacements and try to stay on for a few more weeks.

title: MRS. FRANK DE COURCY
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 24Mrs. Bertha E. de Courcy, one of the first women members of the Darien Republican Town Committee, died yesterday in Stamford Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived at 72 Sedgwick Avenue here.

title: 4 SEIZED IN MIDTOWN IN THRUWAY HOLDUP
description: Four men accused of robbing a woman collector at riflepoint at the Yonkers toll booth of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway were captured an hour after the holdup yesterday by a patrolman on traffic duty at 49th Street and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: U.S. Shrugs Off Move
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (Reuters)  The State Departmerit spokesman, Charles W. Bray 3d, as about the Communist move, said today, If I could shrug my, shoulders audibly, I would do so.

title: WILLIAM LEWITTES, MANUFACTURER, 93
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., March 24 William J. Lewittes, a retired furniture manufacturer died yesterday in the Jackson Hotel where he had lived since the death of his wife, the former Bertha Arm, two years ago. He was 93 years old.

title: KNICKS OPEN SERIES WITH HAWKS TODAY
description: Before another capacity crowd of 19,500, even though it will be a weekday afternoon, the New York Knickerbockers will begin defense of their National Basketball Association title today at 2:30 P.M. at Madison Square Garden, facing the Atlanta Hawks in the opener of a fourofseven playoff series.

title: Report Firids OverAll School Integration in South
description: Despite the proliferation of allwhite private schools and the probable creation of allblack public school systems in some parts of the South, desegregation for the first time is the rule rather than the exception in the region at large, according to a report made public yesterday by the Southern Regional Council in Atlanta.

title: U.A.R. SAID TO GET NEW SOVIET ARMS
description: CAIRO, March 24A new wave of weapons and military equipment deliveries from the Soviet Union has reached the United Arab Republic in the last few weeks, according to reliable Western sources, coinciding with steppedup, widely publicized measures by the Egyptian leadership to prepare the country for war.

title: Lindsay Supports State Bill Tightening Consultant Process
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday described as wholly fair and reasonable a state bill to require all cities to advertise and hold public hearings on consultant contracts of more than $20,000.

title: RCA to Form Joint Concern With Chunghiva Electronics
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Chunghwa Electronics Development Company, Ltd., of Taiwan for the formation of a joint company to manufacture and sell blackandwhite television picture tubes. The new company will be known as Chunghwa Picture Tubes, Ltd.

title: LOOSER I.C.C. REIN WEIGHED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Nixon Administration is making a thorough review of the Interstate Commerce Act to determine how it could initiate a plan for gradually dropping the regulation of the nation's surfacetransportation industry in its 1971 report to Congress.

title: Cowles Holders Approve
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, March 24In a brisk 25minute special meeting at the Look Building here this morning, stockholders of Cowles Communications, Inc., approved a proposal, to exchange 10 publishing and broadcasting properties for 2.6 million shares of Class A common stock of The New

title: One of Silent Generation Finds Way to Get Involved
description: As pleasant and accom modating a young man as ever .made it to the top of his family's business, Oakleigh B. Thorne has never felt drawn to that supercharged world of achievement with its socially responsible whirl of charity balls, board meetings and fundraising cocktail parties.

title: 2 Teachers Seized as Police Report Finding Heroin in Car
description: Two teachers at Intermediate School 201 In Harlem were arrested yesterday afternoon when the police said they had found quantities of heroin and marijuana in a tar the two said they were using to transport five children to basketball in East Harlem.

title: BANKS PLAN CONCERN TO HELP MINORITIES
description: Nine commercial banks said yesterday they were setting up a $1million corporation to invest in minority enterprises in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Burning Oil Well Killed
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 24 (AP)The Shell Oil Company killed the ninth burning well today on its offshore drilling platform in the Gulf of Mexico, leaving two still burning. A spokesman said the company hoped to kill the two others before the end of the month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Current hearings in the Congress concerning medical care in this country have again raised the issue of the doctor shortage. Several observations are offered to substantiate shortage of physicians:

title: Hospital to Get $10,000 Raised in 130Mile Trek
description: MEMPHIS, March 24 (AP) Twentysix tired and footsore young men straggled into St. Jude's Children's Hospital yesterday, pushing a wheelbarrow filled with $10,299.95.

title: Dance Groups Turn to Labanotation
description: On Saturday evening, a New Jersey dance company will perform in a Hackensack auditorium a work created in 1947 and last danced 12 years ago. It was never seen by the man who is directing it.

title: JURORS DEFENDED BY GALLEY JUDGE
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 24  Cries of whitewash would inevitably follow an acquittal of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and angry criticism of another kind would just as surely greet a conviction, the military judge said today while defending the Calley jurors against defense charges of wining and dining and dilatory conduct.

title: Auto Sales Climb 6.4%
description: The first days of spring brought good news for the nation's automobile industry as reports from Detroit yesterday indicated improving newcar sales.

title: States' Racing Officials Urge Taking Over Offtrack Bets
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 24  State racing commissioners from the United States and Canada proposed today that offtrack betting be placed under their supervision and operated by the tracks.

title: F.B.I. Files Tell of Surveillance Of Students, Blacks, War Foes
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Copies of Federal Bureau of Investigation documents that have been mailed anonymously to several newspapers and individuals indicate that the agency is engaged in active surveillance of student, Negro and peace groups.

title: St. Regis Moves Officers; Royal Dutch Unit in shift
description: Major executive changes were announced yesterday by companies in the oil and paper industries.

title: Churches Assailed Here as Foes of Homosexuals
description: The pastor of the United Church of Christ in Newark, charged yesterday that the church historically and hysterically has been the greatest antihomosexual force, but that one does not have to be a heterosexual before he can be a Christian.

title: Judge Questions the Legality Of Grand Jury Interrogations
description: The practice of_allowing more than one, prosecutor to interrogate a potential defendant be fore a grand jury has been questioned by a State Supreme Court Justice.

title: U.S.MEXICAN ACCORD ON ART LOOT SIGNED
description: WASHINGTON, March. 24 (AP)The United States and Mexico today exchanged ratifications of a treaty providing for cooperation in recovering and returning what has become a flood of stolen art treasures from Mexico.

title: Market Place: Trading Active In RollsRoyce
description: Frenzfed trading in RollsRoyce in the everthecounter market by naive traders in recent weeks has carried the shares as high as 80 cents, despite the weight of informed opinion that they are virtually worthless.

title: Crossfire Kills Customer In Store as Holdup Fails
description: A customer of a Bronx food store was shot and killed, and another customer and the owner critically wounded last night when three armed men attempted a holdup at the Commock Superette, at 1362 Clinton Avenue, at 10:50 P. M.

title: Tolls on Harlem River Bridges Studied
description: The Lindsay administration is considering charging tolls on the nine Harlem River bridges as well as on the four East River bridges, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: NIGEL COXE, PIANIST, MAKES DEBUT HERE
description: Nigel Coxe, a Jamaicanborn pianist who received his musical education in England and now lives there permanently, made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. Mr. Coxe is teaching at Smith College this semester.

title: EARLY GAINS HELD BY CORN FUTURES
description: Corn futures and soybean prices held onto early gains, but some of the rises achieved early in the day by wheat fuores were trimmed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Georgia Tech, Bonnnies Gain Semifinais of N.I.T.
description: Georgia Tech and St. Bonaventure emphasized last night the prediction that the National Invitation Tournament would be a wideopen battle for team honors.

title: School Unit and Public Aides Form Bloc
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The National Education Association and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes announced today the formation of coalition to promote the interests of public service workers throughout the country.

title: Politics and the Pentagon
description: The bill of irrelevancies invoked by Vice President Agnew and Defense Secretary Laird against the Columbia Broadcasting System's documentary, The Selling of the Pentagon, missed the central issue. It is not the Defense Department's flamboyant tactics in advertising its skills with arms and men. It is not the question of profligate spending of taxpayers' money on publicity sideshows and expensive lobbying for the favors of American business leaders. It is not even the repulsive display of dirty fighting brutality before audiences including children.

title: Insides' Stockholdings
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stockholdings by major stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The lists include the following:

title: Film: Grimm's Fairy Tales
description: The late Brothers Grimm, who, for the record if not posterity, are no strangers to moviegoers, should be whirling like dervishes wherever they are as a result of Grimm's Fairy Tales, the Germanmade, Englishdubbed color version of some of their classic tall tales for kids, which turned up at the Penthouse yesterday. Since the import has been specifically subtitled, For Adults, it is not misrepresented. It's as adult as almost any skin flick or striptease we've been getting in full measure these days.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscalculations by White House and Labor Helped Defeat Supersonic Transport
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 The White House miscalculated that it could sway the vote of a woman Senator from Maine. And organized labor misjudged the political allegiance of a former Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: Sexes Found Divided on 4Day, 40Hour Week
description: The fourday, 40hour work week has widespread appeal with America's male population, particularly younger men, but the idea is strongly opposed by women, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: AGNEW CRITICISM OF U.S. RENEWED.
description: ST. LOUIS, March 24 (UPI)Vice President Agnew aimed more criticism at Columbia Broadcasting System television today, accusing the network of deliberately publishing un. truths. He also attacked a Newsweek magazine report that a new image was being created for the Vice President.

title: Vigilance Is.Heightened at 2 Schools
description: Public School 63 in the Morrisania section of the Bronx and Public School. 23 in Manhattan's Chinatown have much in common: They both serve poor neighborhoods, they both occupy old buildings and they both have reputations as orderly, wellrun schools.

title: STATE BILL VOTED TO LET GOVERNOR FILL WELFARE JOB
description: ALBANY, March 24  Acting with unusual speed, the Senate and the Assembly passed a bill today to strip the State Board of Social Welfare of its power to appoint the Commissioner of Social Services.

title: PROTEST CLOSES SCHOOL IN BRONX
description: A protest over the arrest of three students earlier this week forced the closing of the Bronx High School of Science yesterday morning.

title: VOLUME OF CHECKS CREATES PROBLEMS
description: George W. Mitchell, a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, declared yesterday that the volume of checks now being written was becoming increasingly difficult to handle, and would become economically unmanageable in the next 10 years under the present system.

title: Memorial for the Carses
description: A memorial service for Robert Carse, a merchant mariner and writer, and Mrs. Janet Wood Carse, a story editor for films and television, will be held at St. George's Episcopal Church in Stuyvesant Square on Saturday, April 3, at 11 A.M. The day was given incorrectly in yesterday's New York Times. Mr. Carse died on Jan. 14 and Mrs. Carse died Monday. A daughter, Mrs. Jean Wachtel, and a granddaughter, survive.

title: Britain Accuses ExSargeant
description: DONCASTER, England, March 24 (Reuters)A court was told today that a British Air Force sergeant gave away secret information in 1961 about Britain's radar defenses. Agents of the Czechoslovak intelligence service, were said to have received material. The accused man is Nicholas Prager, who was said to have been born of Czech parents in Vienna. He is no longer in the Air Force.

title: LTV LOSS PARED IN LAST QUARTER
description: LingTemcoVought, Inc., had a smaller loss in the fourth quarter of last the than a year earlier, but the deficit for all 1970 grew to $69,619,000 from $38,294,000 the year before, Paul Thayer, chairman and president of the Dallasbased conglomerate reported yesterday.

title: Most Objectives Held Attained
description: SAIGON, March 24 (AP)Lieut. Col. Tran Van Am, chief spokesman for the South Viet. namese command, said today that Government forces had accomplished SO to 90 per cent of their objectives in the Laos operation.

title: Slumping Jacklin Hopes Boom Start Today in Miami
description: MIAMI, March 24Tony Jacklin, the United States Open champion, is a frustrated golfer these days. But he hopes his bad batch of golf will end here during the $200,000 National Airlines open that starts tomorrowor next week or the week thereafter at the Masters in Augusta, Ga.

title: Lodge, Nixon's Voice at Vatican, Gets Enviable Papal Audiences
description: ROME, March 24  Whenever President Nixon's special envoy to the Vatican, Henry Cabot Lodge, is about to see Pope Paul VI he dons a dark blue suit and blue necktie and does some lastminute reading on Indochina in the confidential files from Saigon, Washington and Paris.

title: They Know Exactly How Tricia Feels
description: Soon after Tricia Nixon announced her engagement to Edward Cox last week, she received a telephone call from two young women who not so long ago had been in the same situationor predicament, as they might call it.

title: TaxAnticipation Bill Tenders Accepted at a Rate of 3.678%
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Treasury announced late this afternoon the acceptance of tenders for $2,000,395,000 of 23day tax anticipation bills.

title: Laurence Olivier Becomes a Peer
description: LONDON, March 24Sir Laurence Olivier, the first actor to be made a peer, took his seat in the House of Lords today as Lord Olivier, the second to bear that title. The new life peer took the oath in the presence of many of his relatives and friends.

title: SOVIET UNION SIX HELD TO 33 TIE;Sweden Also in a Deadlock Leaders Stay Unbeaten
description: BERNE, March 24 (AP) Unbeaten Sweden and the Soviet Union both played tie games today, leaving the Soviet Union in first place in the world ice hockey championship.

title: Model Bitten by Lion Here Awarded $500,000 by Jury
description: A model bitten by a lion during a photographic sequence at a preview of the International Automobile Show in the New York Coliseum five years ago was awarded $500,000 damages by, a State Supreme Court trial jury yesterday.

title: Mrs. Henry Rowland Is Dead; Restored Maryland Mansion
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Va., March 24Mrs. Matilda Spence Rowland, widow of Henry Rowland, a retired steel executive with whom she restored Kennersley, a mansion on the Maryland Eastern Shore, died Saturday at her home here after a short illness. She was 79 years old.

title: GOODMAN ASSAILS RENTAL HOSPITAL
description: ALBANY, March 24 State Senator Roy M. Goodman charged yesterday that conditions at Manhattan State Mental Hospital on Wards Island were an outrageous disgrace, with inadequate staffing, a serious shortage of medical equipment and generally filthy conditions.

title: Death Rate for Infants in U.S. Fell to Lowest Point in 1970
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)America's infant death rate, long a cause of debate over health care for the poor, dropped to a record low in 1970, the Health. Education and Welfare Department said today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Long after the grimfaced leaders had hurried past, leggy blonde girl slid down off the hood of her father's MercedesBenz.

title: Mrs. Jones Wins 2Hour Tennis Battle
description: Mrs. Nancy Richey Gunter wore out the new gut in her racquet, Pip Jones said it was the finest exhibition of ground strokes he'd ever seen and his wife, Ann, said that if the match had been played at Wimbledon, it would have brought the place down.

title: COURT ORDERS UNION TO STOP RACE BIAS
description: A Federal judge ruled here yesterday that Local 638 of the Steamfitters Union had practiced racial discrimination here for years in maintaining a predominantly white membership.

title: YACHT RACE TAKEN BY IMPROBABLE
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 24  Improbable, a 43foot sloop designed by Gary Mull of California and built in New Zealand, captured the 811mile, MiamitoMontego. Bay yacht race today.

title: Martin Bodmer, Rare Book Collector, Dies at 79
description: GENEVA, March 24Martin Bodmer, a wealthy Swiss scholar and collector of rare books and manuscripts, died at his residence in the Geneva suburb of Cologny on Monday. He was 79 years old.

title: House Is Accused of Bias as Hearings on Women's Rights Open
description: WASHINGTON, March 24, Hearings on the proposed equal rights amendments to the Constitution opened in the House of Representatives today with a demand that the House, in addition to passing it, end what was said to be its own discrimination against women.

title: Irish in South Split On Ulster's Troubles
description: DUBLIN, March 24  The Irish here, historically corn raided to reuniting. Northern Ireland with the Irish Republic in the south, are split in their reaction to the troubles in the north.

title: RollCall Vote in Senate On Funds for the SST
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)  Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate rejected today an amendment to provide $134million to continue Federal funding for the supersonic transport plane project:

title: PLAN ON PENSIONS SCORED BY UNIONS
description: Leaders of public employe unions warned yesterday that any legislative move to have members' pensions regulated by a bipartisan commission would jeopardize collective bargaining under present state law.

title: A Japanese Trading Company Talks of Acquiring SST Assets
description: A leading Japanese trading company has been sounding out United States officials for the last week on buying the enormous assets of the supersonic transport program, if funds for le were cut off, as they were yesterday.

title: Executive Changes
description: Marine Midland BankNew York announced yesterday the election of Stanley W. Hubbel to the newly created position of senior vice president. He was also elected a member of the bank's senior policy group. The following officers have been elected executive Vice presidents: Robert B. Decker, financial control; Jerry V. Jarrett, national banking; John P. Maney, loan administration and Eugene T. Mann, branch administration. All were formerly senior vice presidents. Announced simultaneously was the election of the following vice presidents as senior vice presidents: Matthew R. Ciancimino and Henry Reuter, international banking; Clyde R. Claus, human resources; Thomas Donovan, branch administrationNassau Region; John J. Raphael, branch administrationRegion and James F. Schneider, mortgages. presidents as senior vice presidents: Matthew R. Ciancimino and Henry Reuter, international banking; Clyde R. Claus, human resources; Thomas Donovan, branch administrationNassau Region; John J. Raphael, branch administrationRegion and James F. Schneider, mortgages.

title: SWISS HALT OFFERS OF 2 FUNDS BY I.O.S.
description: GENEVA, March 24The Swiss Federal Bank Commission banned today the public offering of the two mutual funds still being sold in Switzerland by Investors Overseas Services.

title: Penguins Beat Wings
description: PITTSBURGH, March 24 (UPI) A threegoal first period, engineered almost singlehandedly by Jean Pronovost, was enough as the Pittsburgh Penguins handed the Detroit Red Wings an 82 setback in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: West Coast Chain To Buy Bergdorf's
description: Bergdorf Goodman, the Fifth Avenue specialty store, has signed an agreement in principle to be acquired by BroadwayHale Stores, Inc., the largest department store organization in the West and one of the 50 largest retailers in the United States.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)Five servicemen, killed in Indochina were identified today by the Defense Department. They included:

title: Dance of Death Premiere
description: Strindberg's Dance of Death, costarring Rip Torn and Viveca Lindfors, will open April 28 at the Ritz Theater on West 48th Street.

title: Friends' at the Paris
description: The last 10 minutes of "Friends" is a deeply touching finale, after a pair of runaway mid-teenagers deliver their own first-born in a remote cottage in Provence where they have lived for a year. The sequence is tastefully handled by the director, Lewis Gilbert, and played with affecting simplicity by the youngsters, Sean Bury and Anicee Alvina. And the beautiful color photography of the marshy Camargue area frames the conclusion idyllically.Finally, and at long last, this rather exasperating drama has scored its point about pure love and two neglected young people isolated from the contemporary scene. Until then, the point takes forever, tediously hovering over the unhappy protagonists in Paris, then setting them up, inch by inch, in their rustic retreat.They are nice children but not especially interesting, until the extremely belated consummation of their tender love. And some of their dialogue has a curiously naive, singsong quality, rendered accordingly.The adults are generally relegated to the sidelines, and the dignified behavior of the two young people is at odds with the thumping pop rock musical themes on the sound track, with two grating tunes yodeled by Elton John, a current favorite. Yes, love can certainly come to two smitten children. But here they symbolize just that and nothing more.

title: AUGUSTUS E. LEWIS
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., March 24Augustus E. Lewis, a retired bond specialist died yesterday of a heart attack. He had been driving alone in the car when he was stricken. He was 83 years old and lived in this community.

title: MinorityGroup Program Offers Mechanic Training
description: A joint committee formed by about 100 New Yorkarea car dealers and Local 259 of the United Automobile Workers announced yesterday the start of a program to help train minoritygroup members as auto mechanics.

title: BIG A FANS ENJOY A RISE IN PRICES
description: Successive defeats by two oddson favorites confounded the students of form at Aqueduct yesterday. The more startling failure occurred in the $32,350 Correction Handicap, the sixfurlong test for fillies and mares.

title: Networks Asked to Hire Minority News Employes
description: The Joint Equality Committee of four East Coast craft unions representing employes in television, radio and film called on the major radio and television networks yesterday to substantially increase the number of members of ethnic minority groups employed hi their newsrooms.

title: Lansky Indicted for Contempt in Inquiry on Las Vegas Casino
description: MIAMI, March 24 (AP)Meyer Lansky, reputed financial wizard of the underworld, was indicted by a Federal grand jury for contempt today for refusing to testify about the opcrations of a Las Vagas casino. Bond on the onecount indictment, which was announced in Washington by Attorney General John N. Mitchell, was set at $200,000, the Justice Department said.

title: Yanks Beat Red Sox, 95, as Munson, Murcer Connect
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 24  The New York Yankees, who broke out champagne for finishing second last year, didn't break out anything today  but might have been tempted after they defeated the Boston Red Sox, 95.

title: STOCKS DECLINE FOR SECOND DAY
description: The stock market's tumble from its recent 21month peak gathered momentum yesterday. Wall Street analysts ascribed the slide not only to the usual profittaking forces but also to the growing sense of unease over the military situation in Laos.

title: U.S. AIDES CLARIFY VIEWS ON MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Senior Administration officials said today that security arrangements in the Sinai Peninsula, including the status of Sharm el Sheik, the strongpoint at the southern end of the peninsula, should be negotiated by Israel and the United Arab Republic in arriving at a peace agreement.

title: Sports Council Cites Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)  President Nixon was awarded today the Grand Medal of Honor by the International Military Sports Council; an organization whose objective is to encourage military sports and friendly international relations. The medal was presented by the council president, Aldo Massarini of Italy.

title: Stage: The Proposition
description: Anyone can see that theater can be improvised, but why should it be? This is a question that a Boston companyyouthful, talented and engaging  calling itself The Proposition sought to answer at, the Gramercy Arts Theater last night. It wasand I feel sad about thisa somewhat dusty answer.

title: Minute of Silence Urged
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he would ask the city to observe one minute of silence on Good Friday, April 9, and that he would proclaimApril 28 as Prisoner of War Day.

title: NIXON SEES PEACE BY 72 ELECTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, March 24President Nixon told Republican diners who contributed $1.5million to the party at a dinner here tonight that the cans would go into the 1972 elections with the achievement of minimum goalspeace and prosperity without war.

title: Bellevue Completes Project To Improve Its Services
description: Bernard M. Weinstein, executive director of Bellevue Hospital Center, announced yesterday the completion of a $2.3million construction program to improve patient care and health services at the center.

title: Koppers in Pollution Stuit
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)The Government filed suit today against a West Virginia Chemical concern that it said was polluting the Ohio River upstream from two cities that use river water for drinking purposes. Attorney General John N. Mitchell said the civil suit, which seeks an injunction against further discharges into the river was filed in United States District Court in Wheeling, W. Va., against the Koppers Chemical Company, of Follansbee.

title: AMEX LIST DOWN FOR 4TH SESSION
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday for the fourth consecutive session as the trading pace slackened. Brokers attributed most of the weakness to continued profit taking. Prices opened stronger and then gradually weakened throughout most of the session.

title: News Analysis
description: BONN, March 24 Just one year after they began, the fourpower talks aimed at easing the situation of West Berlin have reached a standstill, according to ranking officials here.

title: Mara Cities Conditions
description: PALM BEACH, March 24 When Wellington Mara, the owner of the New York Giants, received word yesterday that New Jersey was proceeding with its plans for a football stadium, he and the rest of the National Football League owners were deeply immersed in their deliberations over a Super Bowl Site.

title: Governor Submits 5 Court Measures To Ease Congestion
description: ALBANY, March 24  Governor Rockefeller today submitted five bills to the Legislature that he said were designed to ease congestion in the criminal courts.

title: ALEXANDER T. DOUGLAS
description: Alexander T. Douglas, a specialist in corporate and administrative law, died Tuesday in Naples, Fla., where he was on vacation. He was 76 years old Street.

title: U.S. Citizenship Is Won by Homosexual
description: An order to grant United States citizenship to a 24yearold homosexual from Cuba was issued in Federal District Court here yesterday over the opposition of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 The mandate of Congress to the Railpax corporation was to establish and operate a basic railroad messenger service for the nation. The route system announced this week does little, to answer the question whether Railpax can even come close to doing so whether, in fact, it is simply another step toward a foreordained death of rail passenger service, in America.

title: CONVICTION UPHELD ON FLAG DISRESPECT
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)  By a tie vote, the Supreme Court today upheld conviction of a New York City art dealerfor displaying the United States flag in a disrespectful way.

title: Board Chief Quits Penn Central Post
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP)Gaylord P. Harnwell resigned today as board chairman, president and chief executive of the Penn Central Company, parent concern of the financially troubled railroad. Four other directors also resigned.

title: Democratic Council Backs Funds Cutoff For the War by '72
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 The Democratic party's Policy, Council voted unanimously today to support a Congressional, cutoff of all funds for American military operations in Indochina after Dec. 31.

title: Lindsay Tours a Methadone Clinic
description: Mayor Lindsay visited the. city's 14th methadone center yesterday  in the heart of the financial district  and was told by a patient being treated for heroin addiction that the program was lifesaver.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (Reuters)  Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe said today the Senate vote ends our program for the development of two experimental supersonic transport planes.

title: T.V.A. Emphasizes Its Need for Coal From Strip Mining
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March, 24 (UPI)  The Tennessee Valley Authority said today that there was no way to avoid some environmental damage from surface mining and no way that strip mining could be eliminated as a prime source of needed coal for power production.

title: Italian NeoFaseists Protest State Visit by Tito
description: ROME, March 24The neoFascist party declared today that President Tito of Yugoslavia, Who is scheduled to arrive tomorrow for a state visit, is unwelcome, in Italy.

title: Lott O'Halloran Dies at 61; Roosevelt Raceway Official special to The New mark
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., March 24 Lott J. O'Halloran, assistant racing secretary at Roosevelt Raceway, died today in Nassau County Medical Center, East Meadow. He had been recuperating at his home here from an operation. He was 61 years old.

title: A Defeat for the Bulldozer
description: A recent decision of the United States Supreme Court will make it harder than it has been for the highwaybuilders to cover urban parkland with concrete in the blind service of the automobile. The opinion directs Federal District Court in Tennessee to review its earlier decision that two successive Secretaries of Transportation had acted within the law in authorizing Federal funds for a sixlane, highspeed expressway through the heart of Overton Park in Memphis.

title: Uganda Bans All Politics
description: 24 (UPI)Uganda's new Military Government, which seized power in January under Maj. Gen Idi Amin, has banned all political activity for two years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Turk Seized in Kidnapping
description: KAYSERI, Turkey, March 24 (Reuters)A third member of a gang alleged to have kidnapped four American servicemen in Ankara earlier this month was captured in a village near here yesterday. The suspect was identified today as Huseyin Ivan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Chain to List Calories
description: BOSTON, March 24 (UPI)Stop & Shop, Inc., one of the East's largest food store chains, said yesterday that it would count calories on its privatelabel canned goods. Mrs. Millicent Snow, the chain's director of consumer affairs, said labels on canned fruits, vegetables and drinks would list calories per 4ounce serving.

title: The Government Needs an Overhaul
description: The President has recommended major Overhaul of executive departments. Many think Such reorganization is long overdue. The pros and cons of the particular changes proposed are proper subjects for public debate. One statement sometimes heard in that debate is that departments such as the ono recommended will be unmanageable because they will be too large.

title: A Turncoat on 7th Avenue?
description: Fashion is finished, says Giorgio di Sant'Angelo. A startling statement for a fashion designer, even an avantgardist. But less startling when he explains that what he means is sterile, followtheleader fashion, with its emphasis on fancy names and fancy prices.

title: News of. Skiing
description: Recent snowstorms in the North Country have encouraged ski resort operators to put on added attractions.

title: Stern Angel Returns Home to Hackley, Ala.
description: Sidney Poitier's recent "They Call Me Mister Tibbs" contains a revealing moment in which a desperate friend asks Mr. Tibbs (Poitier) for advice and receives, instead, the answer that the friend should make up his own mind, that Tibbs-Poitier is tired of playing God. It's a revealing moment becauseuntil that pointwe have no reason to believe Mr. Tibbs is anything more than an honest cop who does his job as well as he can.Mr. Poitier is an actor-producer of unique economic clout at the boxoffice and thus, I think, it can be safely assumed that that line did not get into the script by accident. It was somebody's inspiration and it was put there to make a point. Because it didn't really fit into the story, it could only be saying something about a real-life career. Here was Sidney Poitier, wearily acknowledging the apotheosis by which a good actor was being transformed into an exalted public figure, a man more or less forced into second-order movies ("They Call Me Mister Tibbs," "The Lost Man") that demand, not performances, but visitations.With "Brother John," which opened yesterday at the Astor and Loew's Theaters, the apotheosis of Sidney Poitier is now complete, celebrated in a stern, finger-pointing fantasy that has the apocalyptic aspirations of "Samson and Delilah" and the vision of "Search for Tomorrow." At last Mr. Poitier has taken on a fictional role that matches his lofty public image, an image reinforced by performances of which disengagement has, more and more frequently, been the key.In "Brother John," Mr. Poitier couldn't be more disengagedhe plays nothing less than God's messenger, an impeccably tailored, world-traveled, multi-lingual angel who, born some years before in Hackley, Ala., as John Kane, has returned to his home town to make one final audit before Judgment Day. Since this is familiar, "In the Heat of the Night" country, it's no surprise that Hackley is very much on edge.The black workers at the Hill-Donaldson plant are on strike and are becoming impatient. The red-neck sheriff is nervous. He's been warned that a union organizer is coming down from the North. The district attorney, an opportunistic rat, is looking for any disturbance that will help him become Governor (and thus, apparently, unseat George C. Wallace). An out-of-county reporter arrives. Says the sheriff ominously: "When The New York Times takes an interest in a town like this, we're going to have trouble."However, what trouble there is in Hackley all takes place off-screen. "Brother John" is interested in neither people nor issues, nor even, I suspect, in making much of a case against bigotry, prejudice, cruelty and environmental pollution, all of which get passing notice at one point or another.It is, rather, completely concerned with the proper presentation of its handsome epiphany, James Goldstone, the director (Winning"), is constantly discovering Brother John against aurorean backgrounds of sunlight or blazing white walls. He also favors close-ups that are so tight you get the sensation that you're looking at Mr. Poitier through some Olympian mail slot. Ernest Kinoy's script is no less self-conscious, but then it must be inhibiting to write dialogue for an angel who's not supposed to be funny, who was born in the midst of a thunderstorm and who will return, we are told, "on the day of the big wind."There are some good people in the castWill Geer, Bradford Dillman, Beverly Toddbut they all look pretty foolish under the circumstances. If "Brother John" is a disasterand it isthe responsibility is Mr. Poitier's, whose company produced the movie and hired everyone connected with it. Time has run out. It's too late to believe that he's still a passive participant in his own, premature deification.

title: U.S. CONCERNS ADD TO STAKES ABROAD
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Investment abroad by United States corporations soared 22 per cent last year to a record of $13.2billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Contractor Asks WagePrice Freeze

title: Bill Reclassifies Marijuana
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 24 (UPI)The California Assembly approved yesterday a bill, removing marijuana from the category of a narcotic and listing it as a restricted dangerous drug. The measure would not change the penalties for possession, sale or use of marijuana. The bill was sent to the Senate.

title: BOEING SAYS IT WILL END PROJECT
description: SEATTLE, March 24  The Mockup of the supersonic transport plane, 298 feet long and 53 feet high, dominated the big shop.

title: Kan. State Women's Five Vanquishes Queens, 4935
description: CULLOWHEE, N.C., March 24Queens College's first venture in national competition ended in failure today when Kansas State defeated the Knights, 4935, in the first round of the women's collegiate national invitation basketball tournament at Western Carolina.

title: Youth Auditions April 12
description: Auditions to select instrumentalists and singers for presentation in the 197172 Young Concert Artists Series will be held for two weeks beginning April 12 by Young Concert Artists, Inc., a nonprofit management organization directed by Susan Wadsworth. Audition applicants must be between the ages of 18 and 28 and may obtain application blanks from the Young Concert Artists office at 75 East 55th Street. Further information may be obtained by calling PL 92541.

title: Hot TamalesShe Built a Legend Around Them
description: Whenever Mable Grimes returns to Denver, they still talk about her hot tamales of 40 years ago, for in their day they became a local legend. She still makes them in New York for special occasions, using a handsome old copper washboiler that used to belong to her grandmother. Mrs. Grimes made her hot tamales according to her mother's recipe, and where it originated she doesn't know.

title: Miss Rosenthal Becomes Bride
description: Miss Judith Susan Rosenthal was married here last evening to Steven Howard Wayne Winter, whom she met at the start of her freshman year at the University of Vermont. The bridegroom was graduated from Vermont in 1969. His wife expects to receive her degree next year.

title: A Lot of Speed and Loads of Hair
description: It must have seemed a sure-fire idea. So many dumb movies have been saved by an exciting automobile chase in the last few minuteswhy not make a dumb movie that is nothing but an automobile chase? And perhaps it is a sure-fire idea. At least that is a way of explaining my pleasure in Richard Sarafian's "Vanishing Point," a movie about which I can think of almost nothing good to say.The chase begins in Colorado and ends against a pair of massive bulldozers in California, and it is wholly the idea of one Kowalski (Barry Newman) who is supposed to deliver a car from Denver to San Francisco but in so doing gets involved in a personal race with time, and then with the cops, and then, I guess, with his own fate. A kind of supercharged, overaged, four-wheeled easy rider, Kowalski doesn't show much mindbut he shows lots of hair, lots of heart, lots of soul, and a terrific memory.About the hair, more in a moment. The heart we know, because everytime somebody chasing him goes careening off the road, Kowalski, despite his break-neck pace, always stops to make sure the fellow gets up and walks away from the wreckageand the fellow always does. The soul we know because we are continually reminded of it by a character named Super Soul (Cleavon Little), a blind, black disk jockey unaccountably working out at some dust bin crossroads, who follows the chase on police radio, broadcasts encouragement to Kowalski and thereby makes him an instant culture hero with young people throughout the Far West.Thus Kowalski's public image, though essentially unclear, is very well advertised. He is, according to Super Soul, "The last American to whom speed means freedom of the soul." And speed, to this pill-popping last American, means everything you might imagine. But his private images are much more fun, for Kowalski is one of the best flash-backers in the businessalways recalling moments of physical crisis just at the most photogenic danger point or moments of sexual satisfaction when the flesh is warm, the hair is tawny and the focus is mellow.As for the present, the chase is managed with a fairly conventional taste for excitementmuch soft-shoulder work, too much dust, and far too much evocation of grind of the open road.I suspect that Barry Newman really can act, though in "Vanishing Point" all he needs is a driver's license. In his first movie, "The Lawyer," he played a fictionalized F. Lee Bailey. And now, aspiring to heavy youth identification, he looks quite accurately like F. Lee Bailey in a fright wig.The nicest thing about the movie is the womennot only Victoria Medlin and Gilda Texter, both beautiful in supporting roles, but also the extras, glorious kids who cheer Kowalski on or line up to oversee his doom. I fear that the gift of "Vanishing Point" is not freedom of the soul, but rather a certain pang at being stuck in New York and missing all those great girls in Colorado, Utah, Nevada and eastern California."Vanishing Point" opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.

title: WITNESS DENIES PRESSURE TO LIE
description: A police undercover agent] who joined the Black Pan ther party here denied yesterday that his superiors had pressured him to make up conversations he allegedly overheard among the Panthers.

title: GEN. G. G. O'CONNOR, HEAD OF 4TH ARMY
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 24 (AP)Lieut. Gen. George G. O'Connor, who assumed command of the 4th Army here March 1, died today of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: Submarine Ready for Sea
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., March 24 (AP) deepdiving submarine Alvin, which gained international attention in 1966 when she located a missing hydrogen bomb off the coast of Spain, is ready to return to service. The Alvin sank 2 years ago in 5,000 feet of water off Nantucket. She was recovered 11 months later and brought to the Oceanographic Institute here for refitting and repair.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: March 24, 1971

title: Personal Finance
description: With the official start of spring most people have begun to think in terms of summer vacations at the seashore or in the mountains. Where to go? How much will it cost? Shall it be a hotel or a rental cottage?

title: Chess: Soltis Shows an Ability To Take Command Quickly
description: Andrew Soltis, a member of the United States students world championship team and a threetime champion of the Marshall Chess Club, led the Marshall Club championship, a 12man round robin, after. the fourth round with a score of 3.

title: Advertising:
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies' long  awaited stock offering was made yesterday with 825,000 shares of common stock sold. There was very little excitement, however, as it came out at 171,4 over the counter and closed about the same.

title: Mao Makes It in London, Joins BestDressed List
description: LONDON, March 24 (Reuters)  Chairman Mao Tsetang has been named as one of the 100 best dressed men in the world in a list compiled for the magazine Tailor and Cutter.

title: STATE INVESTIGATES RENT BROKER FEES
description: Demands by some realestate brokers for exorbitant commissions and gratuities for apart1 ment rentals have led New York Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo to start what he called a crackdown on guilty brokers.

description: NEW HAVEN, March 24Warren Kinibro, the man who has admitted firing the first shot at Alex Reckley the night he was murdered, described graphically today how Rackley was beaten and tortured by fellow Black Panthers three days before his death.

title: Advertising:
description: In the Rattle of the Marketplace, combat intelligence has a vital role. You've got to know how well you're doing and how well the en. emy is doing. The oldest and biggest operator and really a double triple, quadruple agent since anyone can buy its findings is A. C. Nielsen, whose plainclothes forces audit retail outlets to compile the top secret retail food and drug indexes.

title: PANEL VOTES PAST ON U.S. SCHOOL AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 24After a year of disagreement, the Nixon Administration and liberal Democrats in the Senate have agreed on compromise legislation for Federal aid to school districts that are trying to desegregate.

description: PARIS, March 24 (UPI)Gen. Alain de Boissieu, soninlaw of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, was appointed Army Chief of Staff today and promoted to general of the army.

description: PARIS, March 24  President Anwar elSadat of the United Arab Republic hinted an ininterview published today that a major oil field had been discovered in his country.

title: TRADING IS QUIET ON LONDON BOARD
description: Speculative Australian issues dropped sharply yesterday on the London Stock Exchange following the suspension in Sydney of Leopold Minerals, but early protective marking: down prevented any largescale selling. This development, described as the latest bout of uncertainty in Australians (issues) induced caution in equities and activity was very quiet.

title: Argentine Strongman Alejandro Augustin Lanusse
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 24 I like looking at that door, said Lieut. Gem Alejandro Agustin. Lanusse. It means a lot to me.

description: The city's public hospitals are sure to run out of cash before the fiscal year ends June 30 and Will be forced to borrow to keep going.

title: Threat to Capital Eased
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 24 (AP)  Military sources said today that the enemy threat to Luang Prabang, the Laotian royal capital, had been eased by three battalions of Govern ment reinforcement. These troops reportedly pushed Communist forces back from the edge of the city.

title: SAIGON DRIVE IN LAOS ENDS AS 1,500 LEAVE LAST BASE; ENEMY KEEPS UP PRESSURE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Thursday, March 25  The South Vietnamese drive against enemy supply lines in Laos ended yesterday, 44 days after it began.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his recent letter Vice President Agnew has again properly focused attention on the contradiction in media attitude concerning their role and rights in our American social and economic structure.

title: THE 3 KREUGERS: NO FAMILY AFFAIR
description: WESTBURY, L. I, March 24 Harness racing has been turned into a family affair by the Mons, the Dancers, the Myerses, the Gilmours, the Abbatiellos, the Inskos, the Harners, the Pattersons and the Simpsons. Fathers and sons, brothers, cousins and nephews often drive against one another.

title: MORTGAGE RATES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)Average interest rates on conventional homeloan, mortgages registered the sharpest decline on record in February, falling below 8 per cent for the first time in 18 months, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: Plan for Skills Center Honors Whitney Young
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)The White House announced today the establishment of a skills training center in Kentucky in honor of the late Whitney M. Young Jr., exbcutive, director of the National Urban League.

title: The Wisdom of the Orient
description: In September, 1895, in Chinn, one blue and white day the scholar led me to a lighthouse of black wood on the sands of the shore. We emerged from the last thickets, and walked halfasleep, drowsy from the sloth of the ground  a spongy powder that soaked up our efforts and yielded under our feet. At last we quit the sand.

title: YOUNG DEMOCRATS STAGE HOUSE COUP
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 Younger liberal Democratic members of the House of Representatives from New York staged a small revolution today by replacing two senior New York Representatives, on party advisory and patronage posts.

description: ALBANY, March 24Governor Rockefeller proposed $695.2million package of highway improvements for New York City today, including improved access to airports and the deletion of several controversial road projects.

description: Betty Grable's legs. Rita Hayworth's curves. Veronica Lake's hair. Rosalind Rus sell's clothes. All famous cinema landmarks of the nineteenforties.

He was 54 years old And had been a resident of Smoke Rise, N.J., from 1965 until his transfer to Houston .last year.

description: PRINCETON, N..J., March 25 Robert Francis Goheen, the 51yearold president of Prince ton University, today an nounced his resignation, effec tive not later than June, 1972.

description: Bond prices declined for the second clay in a row yesterday, chiefly because some traders thought the advance in prices that began March 9 had car ried about as far as it was go ing to go.

description: The New York Stock Exchange is presently studying the application for membership of the Dreyfus Corpora tion, manager of one of the largest mutual funds in the world. The aver age man on the street might say: Who cares?

description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)  The Hearst Corpora tion joined Cowles Communica tions, Inc., today in denying Federal Trade Commission alle gations of deceptive tactics in doortodoor magazine subscrip tion sales.

description: The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday At had bought 792,500 shares of its own Class A stock from the Ford. Foundation for about $45.4million. The company said the shares were acquired to off set the issuance of its common stock, deliverable upon con version of debentures offered outside the United States on Feb. 25 by the Ford Internation al Capital Corporation.

title: PAPERWORK JAM GROWS ON WALL ST.
description: Wall Street has encountered increased difficulty in process ing its paperwork in recent weeks, but its troubles still have not reached a critical level, according to a report issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BLACKS IN HOUSE GET NIXON PLEDGE
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 President Nixon appointed a committee of five White House staff members today to work on a list of recommendations from black members of the House of Representatives, with whom he met earlier in the day.

title: Senate Passes Sugar Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)  The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill to authorize establishment of feed grain bases or wheat al lotments for sugar beet pro ducers who cannot market beets because processing plants have been closed. The legisla tion would enable the pro ducers to qualify for Federal payments and loans on wheat and feed grain acreages.

description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)  A State Department spokesman declared today that the question of recognition of the junta in Argentina does not arise.

description: A group of women lawyers and law students took over an open meeting of the Bar of the City of ew York last night in what one demonstrator called a lawyerlike way to denounce the association for male chauvinist attitudes.

description: PARIS, March 25The French Government decided today to build the world's first commer cial aircushion railroad, as one of a series of measures to re lieve the auto traffic crisis by improving public transporta tion.

description: After six months of its open admissions program, the City University is gradually adjust ing to the largest and most di verse freshman class in its his tory and preparing for an even greater influx of newcomers next fall.

description: NEW DELHI, Friday, March 26 The Pakistani Govern ment reasserted control over East Pakistan this morning and banned all political activity, the Pakistan Radio announced in a broadcast monitored here.

description: WASHINGTON, March 25  A highlevel British team flew home today carrying a new counteroffer made by the Lock heed Aircraft  Corporation to keep the RollsRoyce RB211 jet engine in production for Lockheed's Tristar airbus.

description: The head of the Community Education Center in the Inter mediate School 201 complex in Harlem said yesterday that two employes who were arrested on charges of possessing nar cotics would be dismissed if they were found guilty.

title: Foe Lists Raid Casualties
description: HANOI March 25 (Agence PrancePresse)United States bombing raids over the south ern provinces of North Vietnam have caused some 100 casual ties since the beginning of the month, according to a corn muniqu published here today.

title: Man Shot in '65 Is Slain
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 25 (UPI)An elderly real estate dealer who was wounded by holdup man in 1965 was fatally shot by a robber today. Morris P. Wise, 70 years old, was shot once in the chest and once in the head by a man who de manded money at the Circle Home Realty Company. Mr. Wise had been shot once in the chest in the 1965 holdup.

title: AMERICANS BEGIN TROOP PULLBACK NEARlAOSBORDER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, March 26United States units began pulling away from the Laotian border today as concern continued that North Vietnamese troops would try to intensify their attacks against American installations.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Aide Is Guilty
description: BATON ROUGE, La., March 25 (UPI)  The head of the Louisiana branch of the Na tional Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People, Emmitt Douglas, was found guilty today of inciting to riot at a protest rally in Baton Rouge two years ago. The 12 member jury reduced the charge from a felony to a misde meanor. He had been indicted on the charge for speeches at the rally, made in protest against the fatal shootings of two black burglary suspects by white policemen.

title: Circuit Court Approves LineUp Of Policemen in Brutality Case
description: The public's need for trustworthy police force was stressed by the United States Court of Appeals here yester day in an opinion that weighed the rights and responsibilities of policemen.

title: Barring of Official in Ocean Hill
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice temporarily upheld a court order yesterday that prohibited Mrs. Nellie R. Duncan, the suspended superintendent of School District 23 in Brooklyn, from assuming her office.

title: TIMES MAN GETS A SCIENCE AWARD
description: WASHINGTON, March 25  Lawrence K. Altman of the news staff of The New York Times was one of three $1,000 winners of the annaual Claude Bernard science journalism awards for 1970, announced here today by the National So ciety for Medical Research.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Although President Nixon de, nied this week that he had just passed through his winter of discontent, there is little doubt around the White House that this is his stormiest season yet.

description: MEMPHIS, March 25 (AP) The 13yearold son of an art academy director was kid napped and threatened tonight by a person Who demanded that pictures of nudes be removed from an academy show.

title: Rites for Dr. Steinman
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., March 25,  A funeral service was held here yesterday in the Free Synagogue of Westchester for Dr. Charles Steinman, chief of surgery of Cross County Hos pital, Yonkers. Surviving are his widow, the former Shirley Ada Rubin; a son, David, and three daughters, Suanne, Judy and Ruth.

title: USM Earnings Down Sharply;
description: The USM Corporation, the nation's largest domestic man ufacturer of shoe machinery which has expanded into other, fields, suffered a sharp drop in earnings in the fiscal quarter and year ended Feb. 28. William S. Brewster, chairman, in reportinc, the results yester day, noted that annual gross revenues set records due largely to recent acquisitions. But he added, Volume in im, portant domestic product lines decreased and rising costs, in cluding interest and strikes last fall and summer, put further pressure on our margins.

title: MARKET LOSSES SHAVED BY RALLY
description: Stock prices sagged yester day, under the weight of several market factors, but an after noon recovery pared losses con siderably. Some popular stock averages even displayed token gains.

title: Sports of The Times
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25The palm trees swayed in the gentle breeze beyond the centerfield fence and the sunshine danced on the waters of Tampa Bay across the street from the leftfield wall. It was a lovely day. It seemed an especially elegant day for baseball, be cause those erstwhile subway riders from New York, the Mets and the Yanks, were having another confrontation at Al Lang Field today in what once was known as the Subway Series.

title: Clash at Tokyo Airport Site
description: NARITA, Japan March 25 (AP)Riot police and airport workers battled with students and farmers again today and drove them from the site of Tokyo's new international air port. The farmers, supported by leftist students, contend that the Government has no right to evict them from the land. Most of the owners of the land have sold their property to the Government, but a small group is holding out.

Tickets with the last two numbers be come eligible for the million dollar drawing.

title: Film: Unusual Journey:' Silence Has No Wings,' From Japan, Bows
description: "Silence Has No Wings" is the first feature directed by Kazuo Kuroki, a Japanese filmmaker about whom I have no information other than that he made this film in 1966 after having directed a number of documentaries.In this day of over-communication by press release, by underground rumor and even by Sight and Sound, it's as refreshing as it is rare to come upon a filmmaker so completely anonymous that his work really can stand on its own. However, in the case of new Japanese filmmakers I'm never quite sure whether an ambiguity is intentional, or simply the work of the occasionally fanciful translators. "Butterfly," says one subtitle, "is eagle and flies between swans.""Silence Has No Wings" is a collection of life's turning points, or crises, mostly having to do with love, faced by a succession of unhappy people to whom a tropical Nagasaki caterpillar  itself facing a turning pointbecomes, quite literally, attached on its chance migration from southern to northern Japan.The journey, by train, jet and shank's mare, begins in Nagasaki, moves on to Hiroshima and Osaka, takes an inscrutable leap to Hong Kong, returns to Yokohama, then makes the big leap to Hokaido. It is herein the film's nicest, least self-conscious sequence  that the-caterpillar, newly evolved into a butterfly never before seen in Hokaido, is caught by a small boy. The child is immediately accused by his elders of attempting to promote a scientific hoax only slightly less iniquitous than that of the Piltdown Man.Mr. Kuroki approaches his fiction obliquely, which I like, never overwhelming his characters with exposition, but then, as if he didn't trust himself, he overwhelms them with symbols, heavily meaningful juxtapositions of character against background (cemeteries, junk yards, slums and the like), and, finally, with straight-out allegory.Somewhere towards the end of the film, when the director is (I think) having his say about the crimes of capitalism (or maybe the capitalism of criminals), the passive worm becomes the object of a small gang war. Says one banker (or perhaps industrialist) to another: "We'll lose a lot if it becomes a butterfly." Lines like that can turn critics gray overnight.I have no way of knowing for sure, but I have the impression from "Silence Has No Wings" that Mr. Kuroki was a young man in the 1950's or early 1960's. It's not his fondness for stop-action, for reverse-negative printing, nor for alternating sweeping long shots with slow pans across a section of human skin, so closely seen that you can't tell whether you're looking at an elbow or a drumstick. Rather it's that replay of the A-bomb explosion, which, with the Coca-Cola bottle, was the trademark for an entire school of Japanese avant-garde filmmakers between 10 and 15 years ago.

title: MICHIGAN STATE TAKES MAT LEAD
description: AUBURN, Ala., March 25 (AP)Michigan State, the Big 10 champion, piling up points on a pair of pins by Greg John son in the 118pound class, took the lead today in the National Collegiate wresting champion ships.

title: HEARD'S 66 LEADS BY SHOT AT MIAMI
description: MIAMI, March 25  Jerry Michael Heard, who wears his golf hat like a sailoron the back of his head with the brim upturned  led the $200,000 National Airlines open golf tournament today with a 66.

title: Bids Sought For Subway Tunnels in Ceratral Park
description: The New York City Transit Authority asked for bids yester day for the construction of the portion of the new Queens Manhattan subway under Cen tral Park.

title: TAX PLAN CALLED A THREAT TO CITY
description: The Citizens Budget Commis sion, a businessoriented organ ization that has been reporting periodically on city finances for 39 years, asserted yester day that Mayor Lindsay's new tax proposals pose grave dan ger to the city's economy and to its very survival.

title: Chrysler Recalls Valiants
description: DETROIT, March 25 (AP) The Chrysler Corporation an nounced today the recall of 51 Plymouth Valiant 1971 model passenger cars for inspection of control arm cam bolts. The bolts will be tightened if neces sary, the company said. The potential flaw was found through an assembly line qual ity audit.

title: Bill Rates each Record Low At Treasury's Monthly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Average interest on ninemonth Treasury bills dropped to a rec ord level at today's auction of 275 and 366day bills.

title: Legislature Approves Expansion 0f Board of Elections in the City
description: ATBANY, March 25  The Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a measure expanding the membership of the New York City Board of Elections from 4 to 10 and giving representation to the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE MAKING OF ITALY, 18151870. By Edgar Holt. Introduction by Luigi Barzini. 320 pages. Atheneum. $7.95.

title: Monsanto Sees Lag in Quarter
description: Shareholders of the Mon santo Company attending the annual meeting in St. Louis yesterday were told that the company expected lower first quarter earnings but a mod est profit improvement for the year.

title: Consultations Started
description: A group headed by a major subcontractor on the supersonic transport began intensive consultations with the finan cial community yesterday in hopes of resurrecting the SST program without further Gov ernment aid.

title: President Tito, front left, being welcomed by Mayor Clelio Darida of Rome, back camera. President Giuseppe Saragat is at center. Behind them is Arch of Constantine.
description: ROME, March 25  Presi dent Tito of Yugoslavia be gan a fiveday visit to Italy today surrounded by the heaviest security seen here in years.

title: Galley Jury Deliberates 9th Day; Submits No Requests to Judge
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 25For the first time since they received the case nine days ago, the military jurors in the trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. deliberated today without asking the judge questions or requesting any rereading of testimony.

title: WILLIAM LAMB GETS STERLING CATV POST
description: William J. Lamb has been elected president of Sterling Manhattan Cable Television, Inc., according to an announce ment yesterday by Charles F. Dolan, Sterling board chairman.

title: PANEL'S MEMBERS CLASH ON WITNESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)Representative Richard H. Ichord, chairman of the House Internal Security Com mittee and Representative Rob ert F. Drinan, a Roman. Catholic priest, clashed at a meeting to day over Father Drinan's dis closure that a witness worked for the Voice of America.

title: SCOUTS' LETTER IN F.B.I. DOSSIERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Files stolen from the Federal Bureau of Investigation disclose that copies of letters mailed to the Soviet Embassy here by persons who wish to visit the Soviet Union can find their way into F.B.I. dossiers.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Nothing Is harder to conduct than coalition warfare with divided counsel and com mand. This cost the allies hundreds of thousands of lives in, the two World Wars when the separate nations could not agree on who had the decisive voice on the battlefield, and it is clear from the recent operation's in Laos that the United States and South Viet nam are now running into that dan gerous pproblem in the final phase of the war.

title: The Old and Young Hear Complaints of Consumers
description: Fortyfive or so elderly volunteers and a dozen part time law students are help ing to negotiate settlements on the complaints that pour into the City's Consumer Af fairs Department.

title: Sheik Majib Calls Strike
description: DACCA, Pakistan; March, 25  The leader of cast Pakistan, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, tonight called a general strike through out the province for Saturday in protest against reports of heavy firing upon the population and of atrocities be ing committed on them.

title: 3 Lake Michigan states Agree to Thermal Pollution Standards
description: CHICAGO, March 25Three of the four states bordering Lake Michigan agreed today to join the new Federal Environ mental Protection Agency in setting strict thermal pollution standards that will prevent power companies from dump ing any heated water into the lake.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President met informally with student body presidents of five col leges. He held a meeting of the National Security Council. Mr. and Mrs. Nixon were hosts of a reception for pub lishers of small newspapers and, in the late afternoon, the President met with 13 Negro Democratic members of the House of Representatives. He sent to Congress his plan for a major reorganization of the Executive branch, reducing seven departments to four.

title: Georgia Tech and N. Carolina Win
description: Georgia Tech walked off the Madison Square Garden court last night as a finalist in the National Invitation Tournament, but for Paul Hoffman of de feated St. Bonaventure, it was an especially sad exit.

title: STATE RELIEF CUTS TO SPARE 3 GROUPS
description: ALBANY, March 25Legisla tive sources emphasized today that disabled, aged and blind relief recipients would be spared in the expected cut backs in the state's welfare budget.

title: Women Smokers March
description: LONGVIEW, Wash., March 25 (UPI) More than 250 women marched three miles to Oregon today to buy cigarettes in defi ance of a Washington State drive against outofstate ciga rettes taxed at rates lower than Washington's 11 cents a pack. The women bought about 250 cartons of cigarettes at a store in Rainier, Ore., where the tax is just 4 cents a pack. Wash ington recently began enforcing a long  standing law requiring payment of state taxes on goods bought outside the state.

title: Bishop Installed in Hartford
description: Hartford, March 25 (AP) The Right Rev. J. Warren Hutchens was installed today as the 10th Episcopal bishop of Connecticut. The ceremony was conducted in Christ Church Cathedral.

title: Judge Peter M. Nucci, 47, Of Suffolk, Dies in Crash
description: MOUNT SINAI, L. I., March 25Judge Peter M. Nucci of the Suffolk County District Court was killed early today when the car he was driving went off route 25A near here and struck a tree. He was 47 years old and lived at 5 Gaines Avenue, Greenlawn.

title: Concorde Push Is Urged
description: PARIS, March 25The head of the French company making the FrancoBritish Concorde called today for accelerated development of the supersonic plane following the refusal yes terday by the United States Senate to continue funding the American SST program.

title: Weatherford Award Given
description: BEREA, Ky., March 25  Berea College presented the first W. D. Weatherford Award today to Ben A Franklin, regional reporter of The Times. Mr. Franklin is based in Wash ington.

title: The Screen:
description: The Whitney Museum pro gram notes for Quick Billy, a 75minute experi mental film by Bruce Bailie, refer to the essential ex perience of transformation, between Life and Death, death and birth, or rebirth. One viewer, who would cheerfully have settled for Bugs Bunny, found the first half fascinating, often beauti ful. After that, hang on to your sideburns.

title: City Defers Action On Yankee Stadium As Giants Hold Out
description: The city's plan to keep the Yankees and the football Giants in New York by buying and modernizing Yankee Stadium was imperiled yesterday when City Councilmenrebuffed in their attempt to get the Giants to agree to staydeferred ac tion on the purchase.PROMISES TO KEEP TEAM IN CITY: Michael Burke, Yankees' president, testifying before the City Council.

title: Miss Casals, on Late Rally,
description: Once upon a time, Jane (Peaches) Bartkowicz was the princess of women's tennis: the agegroup champion at every level, the holder of records for batting balls against a back board and the toast of Ham tramck,Mich., with her little sister Plums.

title: Lanusse to Take Argentine Presidency
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 25 The ruling military junta here announced today that Lieut. Gen. Alejandro Agustin La nusse would be sworn in as President of Argentina tomor row evening.

title: Market Place: S.E.C. Criticized On Javelin Move
description: Ralgh Proodian teaches spate improvement at Brook lyn College and moonlights at another college. With a 7yearold daughter in a pri mate school, he finds it diffi cult to make ends meet.

title: JACOB L. DRUCK
description: Jacob L. Druck of Scranton, Pa., and Miami Beach, a news paperman more than 50 years, died of a heart attack here Wednesday. He was 79 years old.

Funa Benkei (Benkei in the Boat), a Noh wardance or demonplay, and the featured piece in the opening program of the NohKyogen National Theaters of Japan series that began Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, is marked by austerity and sim plicity.
