description: WASHINGTON, March 25  The Commerce Depart ment said today that, while auto production has rebounded as expected in the current quar ter, neither output nor sales to consumers are exceptionally high.

title: 2 Universities in Capital Charged With Pollution of Potomac River
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Georgetown and American Uni versities were charged by the United States Attorney's office here today with pollution of the Potomac River and its tri butaries as, a result of oil spills last year.

title: Democrats in House Criticize Nixon for Holding Back Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 25  House Democratic leaders ac cused President Nixon today of pushing for Federal revenue sharing at the same time that he is withholding up to $20, billion already available for vital state and city programs.

title: MRS. ELBERT C. DANIEL
description: ZEBULON, N. C., March 25 Mrs. Elvah Jones Daniel, mother of Clifton Daniel, an associate editor of The New York Times, died today in a nursing home in Raleigh, after an illness of several weeks. Mrs. Daniel, who was 80 years old, was the widow of Elbert Clifton Daniel, a former presi dent of the North Carolina Pharmaceutical Association, who died in 1968.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: New York State is one of only seven states which lack an auto title law. That's a sad thing in itself. But what really is sad is that our auto theft ratio is the highest in the country, and the rate of recovery of stolen cars is the lowest. The Legislature should adopt an auto title law. Car owners will profit through the years to come.

title: PAN AM TO BEGIN WARSAW FLIGHTS
description: WARSAW, March 25A five year effort by Pan American World Airways to open service to Poland has ended success fully with agreement on a New YorkWarsaw route.

title: DANIEL O'CONNELL OF CITY COLLEGE
description: Dr. Daniel T. O'Connell, member of the City College faculty from 1922 until his re tirement last year, died of heart attack Tuesday in Spring field (Vt.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in South Londonderry, Vt.

title: Yankees Pound Koosman in Beating Mets, 42
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25The Yankees and Mets held their springtime re union 1,000 miles from New York today, and the Yankees prevailed with a 42 victory that ended the Mets' four game winning streak.

title: EDWARD C. NEZBEDA, GRUMMAN OFFICER
description: BETHPAGE, N.Y., March 25 Edward C. Nezbeda, vice presi dent of the Grumman Aero space Corporation, died yester day at Brunswick Hospital, Amityville, of cancer. He was 54 years old and lived at 328 Ocean Avenue in Amityville.

title: TARIFF BODY TO STAY INDEPENDENT AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 The Tariff Commission would remain an independent, quasi judicial agency under the mas sive Government reorganiza tion plan submitted to Con gress today by President Nixon.

title: Charles Mandel, Vice President
description: Charles T. Kandel, a vice Piesident of the Sands Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., died of a heart attack there Wednesday. He was 72 years old.

title: Woodhouse Rallies Punchs Penny to a Length Victory at Aqueduct
description: Punchs Penny and Bobby Woodhouse formed the winning partnership in the main event at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing in the sixfurlong sprint for older fillies and mares, Wood house guided Edwin Holton's Kentuckybred filly to a one length triumph over the Hobeau Farm's Lullah Lullah.

title: G. M.'s Chief Scores Critics of Business
description: DETROIT, March 25  The chairman of the General Mo tors Corporation today, at tacked the social critics of business as the adversary cul ture and charged them with misleading the young, the courts and the Government.

title: Pan Am Air Reports Loss
description: Pan American World. Airways announced yesterday a $16, 393,000 net loss for the first two months this year, compared with a yearearlier net loss of $16,843;000. This year's results included $1.1million of retro active payments from the Mili tary Airlift Command for in creased rates, and $975,000 of other nonrecurring credits.

title: Books of The Times
description: This Is the saddest story I have ever heard is the opening sentence of one of the best novels ever written. Ford Madox Ford's publisher didn't like his title for it, and it was changed to The Good Soldier when the book came out in 1915. Arthur Mizener has now affixed the original title to his account of Ford's life where it fits a bit loosely. A dis appointed life, yes. A sad story rather than a tragic one. Ford was that physical impossi bility for heroic tragedy, a fat ro mantic with a wal rus mustache. He wrote 81 books, of which only 5 are now easily available. He was, for two brief, fi nancially disas trous periods, the best literary edi tor of this cen tury. And he was, as he got older, such a grandiloquent fibber that he often obscured his very real achievements with ridiculous curlicues: a critic who admired him lamented that it is difficult to take seriously a man who so recklessly exposes himself to the charge of asininity. His embroideries hurt his own reputation, but did they harm anyone else? Mr. Mizener's 600 pages record a life of elephantine ab surdities, not one act of malice or mean ness. Ford was a vain, preposterously lov able man, as the devotion of a succession of remarkable women attests, and the reader of this biography falls for him, too. He's a buoyant, quite wonderful character, and Arthur Mizener's given the detailed account we've needed.

title: Papp Doth Win Battle of Public Theater
description: Like Henry V rallying his troops before the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, Joseph Papp, head of the shaky Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, exhorted his forces on the City Hall steps yes terday just before they cap tured the Board of Estimate.

title: FREDERICK STOKES, CORPORATE LAWYER
description: Frederick H. Stokes, a law yer, who was active in religi ous and community causes died Wednesday at his home, 18 Sumer Street, Forest Hills, Queens, after a long illness, his age was 78.

description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) The Justice Department filed suit today to halt alleged dis crimination against Negroes in (several construction trades in the Newark area.

title: PENNY UNIT SET TO PAY DIVIDENDS
description: The Pittsburgh & Lake Erie, Railroad, a 92.6 per cent owned affiliate of the Penn Central Transportation Company, yes day resumed dividends on its stock, after having deferred action last December.

title: U.S. Officials Relieved
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Although the formal United States reaction to the Common Market farm price increases is likely to be one of disapproval, some officials expressed relief tonight that the Increases were not greater.

title: Birgit Nilsson Excels as a Recitalist
description: In some vocal recitals the interest can lie in seeing how much a singer can communi cate with a small voice. In Roland Hayes's later years, when the tenor's vocal re sources were a shadow of what they had been, he could turn a recital into a remark able artistic experience through an uncanny knowl edge of how to use what he had.

title: POLLUTION STAND MODIFIED BY G.M.
description: DETROIT, March 25  The General Motors Corporation has said for the first time that it might be able to pass tough antipollution tests for 1975 leers, but only if the Govern ment changes the tests.

title: Her Hymn to Nature Is a Guidebook for the Simplest of Lives
description: OCCIDENTAL, Calif., March 25Alicia Bau Laurel is 21 years old, lives alone in a hut that seems to be grow ing from a grove of pines, has had a love affair with nature as long as she can remember and doesn't care about money.

title: PROPOSAL IS MADE FOR NEWARK STRIKE
description: NEWARK, March 25The Newark Teachers Union ac cepted a proposal by the state appointed mediator today to settle its eightweekold strike, but the Board of Education announced that it would make no response to the proposal.

title: Bonn Curtails F104 Flights After 8 Crashes in 4 Weeks
description: BONN, March 25  West German's Defense Ministry, or dered a cutback today in flights of the air force's American designed F104 Starfighters but it ruled out a grounding of the accidentprone aircraft.

title: Innocence Unprotected':Makavejev Directs Yugoslav Feature Orphan Loves Acrobat Despite Opposition
description: Dusan Makavejev's marvelous "Innocence Unprotected," which opened yesterday at the New Yorker, is different enough from any other movie you are likely to have seen to deserve some special explanation.The original "Innocence Unprotected" was the first Serbian talking picture, filmed in Belgrade in 1942, under the noses of the Nazis, and for the absolutely nonpolitical purpose of making money. After the war, the film suffered a certain eclipse, at least partly because it pushed the birth of the Yugoslav talkie back into a pre-history when nothing like that was supposed to have happened.Nada, the heroine of "Innocence Unprotected," is a beautiful orphan whose obnoxious stepmother wants her to marry a rich, old, evil and rather unhealthy seeming man. However, true to the concept of a sound mind in a sound body, Nada loves the acrobat Aleksic, and her love is well placed. For after a particularly hairy episode with the rotten old man (Aleksic is at that moment capping his career as he hangs by his teeth from an airplane flying over Belgrade), the acrobat arrives in the nick of time, pulverizes the competition and removes the lady, via tightrope, to a future of presumably everlasting athletic bliss."Innocence Unprotected" was written, directed and co-produced by one Dragoljub Aleksicwho also wrote the songs and of course starred himself in his own character. Rather a lot of the old movie is given over to Nada's reveries on the prowess of her hero, each reverie accompanied by appropriate footage showing Aleksic breaking chains, balancing on monuments or hauling hundreds of pounds in weights or people high above the city by means of his wonderful teeth.Aleksic survived, as did all but one of the cast, and I suspect that it was the personality of this charming egomaniac (and true enough national hero) that led Dusan Makavejev in 1968 to make his own tribute to "Innocence Unprotected" and those unsung pioneers of the Yugoslav commercial cinema.Makavejev's method is to take big sections of the old film, variously tint them (and hand-color some details), and intercut them with newsreels of the German occupation, Nazi propaganda films, and interviews with the crew, the cast and especially with Aleksic still triumphant. I have some reservations about the mixing of Aleksic's melodrama with the drama of the occupation, but not many about the original film itself and none at all about the sensibility the present director brings to his old folks and their old movie.He describes "Innocence Unprotected" as "the art of a metropolitan half-world . . . on the margins of an industrial culture and morality, somewhere between cafes and circus entertainment, cheap literature and melodramatic trash," and he sees this art as finding both intellectual and financial viability in the anarchy fostered by the Occupation.Obviously, Makavejev, (known here for "The Case of the Missing Switchboard Operator"1967) brings an exceptionally sophisticated understanding to his project. But it is also an exceptionally understanding sophisticationironic, loving, clear-sightedly appreciative of all illusions. For this, rarer than most things on film, I value Makavejev's extraordinary insights into ordinary affairs and his gentle juggling act with Acrobat Aleksic.

title: Bridge: Defender's Sure Triumph Look Gives Declarer a Vital Clue
description: A poker face is a desir able asset for bridge players, but also a rare one. Playing against a member of the great majoritythose who do not have impeccable facial controlit is often possible to judge whether an oppo nent is gloomy or contented.

title: SCHOLASTIC AWARDS GO TO 12 CITY BLACKS
description: Twelve New York City public high, school students who were among 340 winners of the Na tional Achievement Awards for outstanding Negro students were honored yesterday by the Board of Education at its head quarters at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 A few days before he de cided to accept the chairman ship of the Securities and. Exchange Commission, Wil liam Joseph Casey was talk ing to an acquaintance who knows the S.E.C. and its per sonnel much better than he does. How tough would it be, Mr. Casey asked, td head an agency that has four other commis sioners whose votes each count as much as his own. The acquaintance suggested that it wouldn't really be so different from running a law firm where the partners sit around and discuss things as equals.

title: WEST GERMAN SIX DOWNS U.S., 7 TO 2
description: BERNE, March 25 (UPI) West Germany beat the injury ridden United States national team, 72, tonight for the Amer icans' fourth straight defeat in five games in the 1971 world ice hockey championships.

title: Hawaii Ratifies Voting at 18
description: HONOLULU, March 25 (UPI) Hawaii has become the seventh state in the union to ratify the proposed constitu tional amendment to give 18 yearolds the vote. The state House of Representatives passed it, 51 to 0, yesterday and the Senate approved it, 21 to 1.

title: David Rockefeller Reports U.S. Economy on Way Up
description: SYDNEY, Australia March 25  David Rockefeller told a group of leading Australian businessmen today that the United States economy has hit, bottom and is on the way up.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market closed firm yesterday, and deal ers said that buying and institu tional inquiries in anticipation of a reflationary Government budget had met a shortage of issues.

title: SST CHIEF FAILS IN FINAL EFFORTS TO SAVE PROJECT
description: Late in the day, the Office of SST Development in the Department of Transportation was accepting the Congres sional verdict against funding the plane as final. We're out of business, a spokesman said.

title: 10 Officers Dropped By Alabama Guard In Hatch Act Case
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 25The commander of Ala bama's Air National Guard and nine other top career Guard officers were dismissed today on a charge of violating the Federal Hatch Act by forcing Guard officers to make political contributions.

title: Congress and the Middle East
description: The interests of the United States, of Israel and of world peace will be well served if Secretary of State Rogers's extraordinary meeting with the Senate yesterday prompts critics of State Department policy on the Middle East to reexamine their own premises.

title: Chinese Satellite Silent
description: BOCHUM, Germany, March 25 (AP)  Red China's second earth satellite, Mao2, stopped transmitting signals Tuesday night, the West German Space Institute reported today. The institute said it did not know whether the broadcasts stopped because of a failure.

title: Tremor Jolts Coast Area
description: LOS ANGELES, march 25 (UPI)An earth tremor joltedi the Los Angeles area today and knocked out electricity in some areas of the San Fer nando Valley. There were no other reports of damage.

title: BYRD SCORES TRIPS FOR SLUM CHILDREN
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr. of Virginia said today that dis closures that New York City slim children had been sent on ski trips and that welfare fam ilies had been put up at the WaldorfAstoria would cost welfare programs support in. Congress and with the public.

title: KEYBOARD FACILITY SHOWN BY OZOLINS
description: Arthur Ozolins, a pianist who made his debut here, in 1966 while studying at the Mannes College of Music, came to Tully Hall on Wednesday night for his second New York recital.

title: Deficit $19.38Billion
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)Government spending exceeded revenue by $19.38 billion during the first eight months of the current fiscal year, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: SoftCoal Output Grows
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)The National Coal Asso ciation today estimated last week's softcoal production in the United States at 12,515,000 tons, up from the yearearlier 12,040,000 tons. Production from Jan. 1 through March 20 was estimated at 130,710,000 tons.

title: CONFIDENCE RISING FOR U.S. CONSUMER
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 25 (UPI)American consumers, while still lacking extreme optimism about the nation's economy, have overcome the depressed sentiment that pre vailed lastyear, University of Michigan economists reported yesterday.

title: 2 U.S. NI FAIL IN N.C.A.A. SWIM
description: AMES, Iowa, March 25 (AP)  Gary Hall of Indiana and Stanford's 400yard medley re lay team set American records tonight in the 48th National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championships.

title: Seale Loses Bid to Fight Tapes' Use
description: NEW HAVEN, March 25 Bobby G. Seale lost his bid today even to argue against introduction at his trial of tape recordings made during the alleged torture of Alex Rack Icy.

title: Theater: Scenes From American Life at Forum
description: Pages from American his torypast, present and future are the sociological subject matter of A. R. Gurney Jr's Scenes From American Life, given last night by the Lin coln Center Repertory The ater at its splendid Forum Theater.

title: Allen Runs Into Palm Tree, Suffers a Mild Concussion
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., March 25 (AP)  Rich Allen of the Los Angeles Dodgers suffered se vere bruises and a mild con cussion today when he ran into a palm tree while chasing a fly ball in left field before an exhibition game with the Cin cinnati Reds.

title: EASIER DIVORCES
description: TRENTON, March 25  The State Senate voted today to lib eralize New Jersey's 64year old divorce law by eliminating in some cases the requirement for placing blame for a bad marriage.

title: First Boston's Membership Approved by the Big Board
description: The application of the First Boston Corporation, the nation's largest underwriter of corpo rate securities, to join the New York Stock Exchange was ap proved yesterday by the ex change's board of governors.

title: What is the President's Policy?
description: WASHINGTONThe politics of was in Southeast Asia is not, as some ob servers have been saying, simply a rerun of 1967 and 1968.

title: Eurppe's Farm Problem
description: PARIS, March 25  Europe has too many farmers, and few, of them want to leave the land: In Prance there is a special attachment to la terre: that is part of the national, charac ter.

title: Jack Warner to Make 1776 Into a Movie
description: 1776, the prizewinning Broadway musical now in its third year on Broadway, will be filmed by Jack L. Warner and Columbia Pictures. Mr. Warner, who acquired film rights to the play last Jan uary for a reported sum of $1,250,000 and a percentage, will produce the movie and cofinance it with Columbia on a budget of $5million to $6 million, it was reported yes terday at a news conference.

title: PRICES INCREASED FOR PAPER LINES
description: The International Paper Com pany announced yesterday that it would increase prices cover ing a broad line of its printing, publication and converting paper grades, effective with shipments July I.

title: Greece, Torn by Factions, Marks 150th Independence Anniversary
description: ATHENS, March 25The Creek people, commemorating the 150th anniversary today of their revolt against Turkish rule, remain torn by rival fac tions, each claiming to be the sole heirs and defenders of the principles of national independ ence and human fredom for Which the fight was waged.

title: Barge Spills 10,000 Gallons of Gasoline in East River
description: A barge carrying 65,000 gal lons of gasoline spilled about 10,000 gallons of it into the East River last night after collision with a Colombian freighter in midchannel be tween the Downtowwn Heliport in Lower Manhattan and Pier 3 at the foot of Pierrepont Street in Brooklyn.

title: Maritime Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)  Robert J. Blackwell, a native of Brooklyn, was named today Deputy Assistant Secre tary of Commerce for Maritime Affairs. Mr. Blackwell has been Deputy Maritime Administrator since May, 1969.

title: Emerson Tuition Rising
description: BOSTON, March 25 (AP) Emerson College, which spe cializes in communications training, today announced an increase in tuition of $175, to a total of $2,175, effcetive next September, because of increased costs.

title: Credit Growth Spurred;
description: The Federal Reserve appeared to have pursued its steady course of moderate credit ex pansion during the latest two week period, according to cen tral bank data published yes terday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee for Program and Coordination10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SOVIET EMIGRANTS HAILED IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, March 25One of the largest groups of Soviet Jews to arrive in Israel was greeted ecstatically today at Lydda Airport.

title: WHIPPED CREAM IS FOUND TAINTED
description: WASHINGTON March 25 (UPI)Acknowledging that it delayed the announcement two weeks, the Food rind Drug Ad ministration said today that salmonella contamination had been found in samples from nearly 100,000 cartons of a whipping cream distributed na tionally under 25 different brand names.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Breed of Big Trust in Japan
description: OSAKA, JapanTwentyfive years ago the great family owned financial trusts of Japan, Mitsui, Mitsubishi, Sumitomo and others, lay prostratetheir coffers nearly empty, their mines and factories devastated by bombing, their rew work able installations earmarked for reparations to the victori ous Allies.

title: Uruguay Guerrillas Release Letter Reportedly by Envoy
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 25 (AP)The Tupamara guerrillas released a statement attributed to the kidnapped British Ambassador, Geoffrey Jackson today in which he said his health is good and his morale is high.

title: Fumes Peril Georgia Town
description: MARIETTA, Ga., March 25 (AP)Fourteen cars of a Sea boardCoastline Railroad train derailed here today, and the police and Civil Defense au thorities began to evacuate nearby areas because of naptha fumes leaking from one of the cars. Georgia Highway 3, be tween Marietta and Atlanta, was closed because of the dan ger of fire or explosion.

title: Advertising:
description: The advertising industry's current search for an effec tive form of selfregulation received strong support yes terday from one of the na tion's leading advertisers.

title: Legal Aid Society Elects
description: Leon Silverman was elected yesterday as president of the Legal Aid Society here. Mr. Sil verman is a senior partner in the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver and Jacobson and is a resident of Great Neck, L. I. He succeeds Robert P. Pat terson Jr., president since 1967.

title: KENNEDY DECRIES LAOS OPERATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Senator Edward M. Kennedy today described the South Viet namese incursion into Laos as a nightmare that has ended in a humiliating retreat car ried out so obviously in panic.

title: Soviet Announces A Direct Converter For Atomic Power
description: MOSCOW, March 25The Soviet Union announced today a breakthrough in the develop ment and testing of an ad vanced engineering system ca pable of converting nuclear energy directly into electricity for of this type. It gave no details on the oper ating lifetime already achieved, on the efficiency of the convert er or on the rnateirals used in its design. Nor was its location identified. The Soviet Union has a number of nuclear re search and development cen ters, including a reactor ex perimentation complex at the town Of Melekess on the Volga River.

title: VIOLATIONS ALLEGED BY S.E.C. TO 2 FIRMS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission moved yesterday to enjoin what it said were secu rities violations by Capital Coun sellors, Inc., and Capital Ad visors, Inc., of 110 Wall Street.

title: Poles Cheer Lionel Hampton
description: WARSAW, March 25  Three thousand jazz enthu siasts gave a 20minute ova tion to Lionel Hampton and his 10piece jazz band and cheered the American musi cian with a rendition of sto lat, the Polish version of For He's a Jolly Good Fel low, after a threehour per formance here yesterday.

title: No Fault in Albany
description: While there Is much that conscientious members the State Legislature in Albany cannot do this year through no fault of their ownthe budget is tight and money is scarce  there is also much that they can do, much that carries no price tag in additional tax revenues and falls in the broad but shadowed area of overdue reform. Governor Rockefeller last year proposed funda mental changes in the state's automobile insurance laws. He has proposed these changes once more, and they ought to be enacted.

title: Interviews in State Prisons Sought in U.S. Court Suit
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that it had filed suit in Federal District Court for the Western District of New, York in behalf of 11 journalists and three inmates of state prisons.

title: HUMPHREY URGES LIMITS ON ARM'S
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Hubert H. Humphrey, in his first major speech since re turning to the Senate, urged the Nixon Administration today to seek an agreement limiting antiballistic missile systems as the first step toward a compre hensive strategic arms agree ment with the Soviet Union.

title: Rogers Reassures His Senate Critics On Mideast Policy
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Secretary of State William P. Rogers mollified his most vocal Senate critics on the Middle East issue today by assuring them that the Nixon Adminis tration was not requiring Israel to give up occupied Arab terri tories before a peace settlement is reached.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BOGOTA, Colombia  This nation's greatest shortrange problem would be solved if every American housewife brewed twice as many cups of coffee and its greatest longrange problem would be solved if every Colombian housewife took the pill. However, since neither event is likely to occur, a time of trouble looms.

title: A Cavorting, Amiable Doctor Miracle
description: Before Bizet got around to Carmen, he wrote 10 com plete, stageable operas, not to mention more than a dozen others that he aborted at various stages. His first effort was an operetta, La Maison du docteur, and so was his second, Le Docteur Miracle, a oneact slice of buffoonery that won him a prize that Offenbach had put up in hopes of raising operetta's artistic status.

title: A Restaurant Worth a Trip by Subway
description: The restaurats reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Businessmen Get Briefing And Dinner at White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 A group of 50 leading busi nessmen received a briefing to day on various aspects of Gov ernment policy that concluded with a dinner at the White House.

title: Kotouc Trial Is Set
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., March 25 (AP)Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc, accused of cutting off a suspected enemy's finger during an interrogation after the alleged massacre at Mylai 4, will be tried April 26, the Army announced today.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: NEW WEEKLY BI0GRAPHICAL SERVICE. The New York Times Biographical Service, Write: The New York Times Library Serv ices. Box FP480, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.Advt.

title: N.A. A.C.P. Sues Oyster Bay, Charging Zoning Bars Blacks
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed its first lawsuit yesterday challenging the con stitutionality of zoning ordi nances that bar apartment houses from suburban towns.

title: West Germany Trades Dollars For $500Million of U.S. Gold
description: PARIS, March 25The West German central bank, its cof fers bulging with surplus dol lars, has acquired $500million worth of gold from the United States.

title: Jarring Leaves for Moscow
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25Dr. Gunnar V. Jar ring, the United Nations special representative for the Middle East, left for an Easter hodiday with his family in Moscow today, a week earlier than orig inally planned.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's department store sales at $675 million, up 4 percent from the yearearlier $652million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,039,000,000, up 7 per cent from $6,594,000,000.

title: DEADLOCK AT FORD DEEPENS IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, March 25The deadlock in the 53day strike against the British subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company deepened today with the sus pension of union meetings for two weeks and an offer of cash assistance to the British strik ers from automobile unions around the world.

title: How Agencies Would Be Restructured Under Nixon's Proposed Cabinet Changes
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 The White House issued today the following list of Govern ment agencies as they would be restructured into four new departments under a reorgani zation program President Nixon sent to Congress:

title: Contessa de Flemotomos Wed To Daniel P. Skouras Here
description: Contessa Marietta de Flem otornos was married here yesterday afternoon to Daniel Plato Skouras, vice president in charge of foreign distribu tion for American Interna tional Pictures. Criminal Court Judge Nicholas Tsou calas performed the cere mony at the bride's apart ment.

title: Newburgh Split on Effects of Proposed Jetport
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y., March 25The opportunities and problems that have con fronted such widely scattered places as Narita, Japan; Stewkley, England, and Sol berg, N.J., sharply divided this old Hudson River city this week when it became known that Governor Rocke feller might put a major jet port here.

title: KIDNAPPED ROY, 11, HELPS TRAP SUSPECT
description: MACON, Ga., March 25 (AP) An 11yearold boy, held in handcuffs for 20 hours by kid nappers while his parents bor rowed $5,000 ransom, was re leased unharmed today and promptly led the police to the hideout, the authorities said.

title: Weekend Recipes
description: In the menus below dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: The Casey Appointment
description: President Nixon's nomination of William J. Casey the Securities and Exchange Commission has now been approved by the Senate, and the President has made clear that he intends to appoint Mr. Casey the S.E.C.'s chairman.

title: Frazier Steals Spotlight From TV Ring Series Here
description: In a surprise appearance, Joe Frazier arrived in New York last night from his Philadelphia hospital hideout and upstaged a news conference announcing the formation of a monthly TV boxing network.

title: Villanova, U.C.L.A. Gain Final
description: HOUSTON, March 25Villa nova became tonight the first team from the Eastern College Athletic Conference to reach the final of the National Col legiate basketball championship in 16 years when the Wildcats survived two overtimes and beat Western Kentucky, 9289, in the Astrodome.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP AS TRADING EASES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended lower yester day although increased buying in the afternoon erased some of the sharp earlier losses.

title: Two Japanese Banks Plan to. Merge on Oct: 1
description: TOKYO, March 25 (UPI) Japan's two major city banks signed a formal contract today to become the nation's largest bank and the seventh largest in the world. The DaiIchi bank and the Nippon Kangyo bank said in an announcement that a merger would take place Oct. 1 if shai.eholders ap proved.

title: U.S. WARNS HANOI ON DMZ BUILDUP
description: WASHINGTON, March 25  The Defense Department issued a veiled warning today that air strikes against North Viet namese artillery and rockets might have to be ordered if they fired from new posi tions within the demilitarized zone that straddles the border between the two Vietnams.

title: G.I. Mood at Battered Khesanh: We Don't Want to Be RelievedWe Want to Get Out
description: KHESANH, South Viet nam, March 25When Spe cialist 4 Gregory Geneviva heard at noon today that the American troops of the 101st Airborne Division would shortly be leaving the huge allied base here, with the Vietnamese drive into Laos at the feeble end of its final chapter, he shook his head and sighed:

title: U.S. Engineers Hail Feat
description: Sources in the Atomic Energy Commission called the Soviet development of a system to convert nuclear energy directly into electricity an important technical step.

title: Kosciuszko Awards Tonight
description: The Kosciuszko Foundation will, award medals of recogni tion for distinguished service to Polish and American culture to Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, music director of the Minne sota Orchestra; and Maria Kuncewicz, a writer; at a con cert and reception to be held tonight at the Foundation House, 15 East 65th Street. Mr. Skrowaczewski is appearing as guest conductor with the New York Philharmonic. Mrs. Kun cewicz has taught at the Uni versity of. Chicago and the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: Crowding on the Rail
description: Officials of New Jersey's thoroughbred race tracks re acted with dismay yesterday to the prospect of competing against a stateoperated super track in the Hacken sack River meadowlands.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Students of Latin America had be gun to believe that the political sophistication of the United States corporations doing business in the re gion had improved since the early decades of the century. Philip G. Walsh of W. R. Grace & Co., in his March 19 letter about contemporary Brazil, indicates that we were wrong.

title: Skimping on the Environment
description: With a wary eye on taxpayers' resentments, the Ways and Means Committee of the New York State Assembly is planning an extremely illadvised cut in the budget of the Department of Environmental Conservation. Other agencies are admittedly suffering the same sort of atten tion, but drastic cuts in a field where needed programs have barely been launched can be especially, even fatally, damaging.

title: SILVER FUTURES SHOW PRICE RISE
description: Silver futures prices rose yesterday in moderately heavy trading on the New York Com modity Exchange.

title: President Submits Plan For Reorganizing Cabinet
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 President Nixon, contending that form should follow func tion in Government, sent to Congress today his plan to con solidate seven Cabinet depart ments into four.

title: Meeting a New Need
description: Sixty years ago the Red Cross was raising money to combat tuberculosis through the sale of Christmas seals. Today in New York, it is as sisting in the detection of a new scourge, leadpaint poi soning.

title: U.S. Asks Action in Geneva To Halt Pollution of Oceans
description: GENEVA, March 25 (UPI) The United States called today for prompt international action to prevent further pollution of the oceans.

title: LANSKY IS INDICTED ON GAMBLING COUNT
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)Meyer Lansky, a reputed financial leader of the under world, was indicted today on Ilcharges of illegal gambling ac tivities in eonnection with a hotel in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Tate Murder Trial Costly
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25 (UPI)The cost of the Sharon Ttate murder trial, now in its 10th month, is: approaching the milliondollar mark. As the case neared its end, the cost stood at $915,172, Los Angeles County Supervisor Kenneth Hahn reported today. The trial was in recess today because one of the defense lawyers was ill with the flu. Final arguments in the penalty phase were ex pected to resume tomorrow.

title: U.S. SEEKS REVIEW OF CHICAGO 7 CASE
description: CHICAGO, March 25The United States Attorney's office filed a Motion here today re questing a new hearing on the contempt sentences of the sev en defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE, SHOWS SLIGHT GAIN
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended March 20 was slightly above the corresponding 1970 week. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period registered a de crease.

title: 150 Works by Marcks Exhibited Here
description: Gerhard Marcks, one of Germany's bestknown living sculptors, has been the oc casional subject of New York gallery exhibitions since 1948. His last, in 1967, was a comprehensive display of his most recent bronzes at the Leonard Hutton Galleries. The New York Cultural Cen ter yesterday opened a Marcks retrospective, his first exhibition in a New York museum, and it contains 150 sculptures, drawings and prints. Installed on three floors of the center, the show traces the development of Mr. Marcks's work from the early twenties to the present.

title: WAGEPRICE PLAN FOR CONSTRUCTION GOES TOPRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Labor and management in the nation's construction industry agreed today to accept wage and price stabilization machin ery if President Nixon restores Federal support for construc tion wages, industry and Gov ernment officials said.

title: Nixon Talks to Workers
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 AP President Nixon talked by telephone today to workers on the abandoned supersonic trans port plane in Seattle and Wichita, and said he was deter mined that America must and will continue pushing outward the horizons of the unknown. He added: We may have lost this one, but we're going to win the next one.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials edged higher to 109.7 Tuesday from 109.5 last week.

title: Executive Changes
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corpo ration has elected George D. Kennedy as executive vice president and member of the executive office. Mr. Kennedy who was president of the Brown Paper Company, will be responsible for new thinness de velopment and operations other than those in the company's agricultural area.

title: HEARINGS ARE SET ON CAMPAIGN CURB
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Responding reluctantly to Re publican pressure, the Senate Commerce Committee decided today to stop drafting a cam paign spending bill and resume public hearings on the contro versial issue.

title: VASILY DYACHENKO, SOVIET ECONOMIST
description: MOSCOW, March 25Vasily P. Dyachenko, a prominent Soviet financial economist, died, here Tuesday after a long ill ness. He was 68 years old.

title: Abrams Urges Link To Enable IRT Use Of Cool PATH Cars
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx proposed yesterday the building of a link to enable the use of aircondi tioned PATH (Port Authority TransHudson) cars on IRT tracks in nonrush hours.

title: Albert L. Reeves Is Dead at 97; U.S. Judge Sat in Coplon Case
description: DUNEDIN, Fla., March 25  Federal Judge Albert L. Reeves, who presided at the Judith Coplon trial in 1949, died here last night. He was 97 years old.

title: Einstein to Raise Output of Doctors In 3Year Course
description: The Albert Einstein College of Medicine is setting in mo tion a program to increase its output of physicians by 50 per cent.

title: Ulster's Prime Minister Aims at Unity in Naming New Cabinet
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 25 Northern Ireland's Prime Minister, Brian Faulkner, made gestures tonight to both the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority of this bitterly divided province when he named his Cabinet.

title: Ashe and Okker Advance In Chicago Tennis Tourney
description: CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) Arthur Ashe of the United States defeated Ray Ruffels of Australia 64, 6.4, today, ad vancing to the semifinals of the $50,000 Sportface international tennis tournament.

title: In Pakistan, United States Is Villain
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 25An American newly arrived in Pakistan might have been surprised by the speech of a rightwing Pakistani politician at a Karachi rally Monday claiming that the United States Central Intelligence Agency, Premier Golda Meir of Israel and Indian officials had teamed up to divide Pakistan under the patronage of the United States of America.

title: G.O.P. Leaders in Albany Agree on Budget Slashes
description: ALBANY, March 25Gover nor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders have tenta tively agreed on budget cuts totaling more than $600million, sources high in the party re ported tonight.

title: Vatican Restates Its View On Status of Jerusalem
description: ROME, March 25The Vati can today restated pronounce ments by Pope Paul VI calling for a special international sta tus for Jerusalem and other holy places in Palestine.

title: Curfew Imposed
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 25A 10hour curfew was im posed tonight on Lyallpur, an industrial city 700 miles north of here, after daylong clashes between rioters and police.

title: Court in California Says Welfare Cuts Violate State Law
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 (UPI)The California Supreme Court, in a decision that could affect 400,000 families and threatens the state budget, ruled today that recent welfare cuts by the administration of Gov. Ronald Reagan violated state law.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTONThe Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended March 23:

title: Merger News
description: The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire certain of the American Zinc Company's properties in three states for an estimated $27million in cash and notes. Under the agreement, Asarco is to buy all of American Zinc's mines, plant's, mineral properties and other real estate in Tennessee, all of the assets of American Zinc's American Limestone division and all the zinc oxide plants and real estate owned by American Zinc in Hillsboro, Ill., and Columbus, Ohio.

title: 19,959 See Phelps Stop Dixon In First Round in Gloves Final
description: A crowd of 19,959 fans of amateur boxing jammed. Madison Square Garden last night to watch the finals of the 45th annual Golden Gloves championships, sponsored by The New York News Charities, Inc.

title: Triple Pays $3,112.60 On 7,6,8 at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March 26Harness racing's latest betting lure, the triple, paid a resounding $3,112.60 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The winning combination comprised the numbers of 7, 6 and 8.

title: Deal for Mrs. Crimmins Is Revealed
description: A detective testified yesterday at the murder and manslaughter trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins that he offered to help the defendant arrange a deal with the District Attorney's office that might include full immunity if she agreed to tell the whole truth about what happened.

title: Josef Hermann Dufhues Dead; A Leader of Bonn Opposition
description: BONN, March 26Josef Hermann Dufhues, a leading member of West Germany's opposition Christian Democratic party who once aspired to succeed Dr. Konrad Adenauer as Chancellor, died in a hospital at Rheinhausen today. He was 63 years old.

title: Tapes of Torture Fought by Defense In Panther Trial
description: NEW HAVEN, March 26After calling 19 witnesses in less than five hours, Ericka Huggins's attorney today concluded her argument that tape recordings made during the torture of Alex Rackley should not be admitted into evidence against her client.

title: 360 ARE INFECTED BY FLUID FEEDING
description: Federal health officials reported yesterday that at least 350 patients had suffered blood infections from contaminated intravenous fluids and that a growing number of American hospitals had recognized that their patients were affected by the problem in recent weeks.

title: NADER SCORES F.D.A. ON LIQUID LYE PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, March 26(UPI)Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, accused the Food and Drug Administration today of endangering small children by failing to ban drain cleaners that contain liquid lye.

title: New Rochelle Schools Cut Jobs To Meet Deficit of $1.6Million
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 26The school system here, prohibited by the State Constitution from raising any more taxes, will eliminate 136 of 750 professional positions, freeze salaries and make sweeping cuts in nonacademic areas to offset a projected $1.6million budget deficit for the school year.

title: Children's Ballet Finale
description: The Children's Ballet Theater will give its last two performances of the season today and tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. at the Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West 27th Street. The company, which includes dancers from 7 to 17 years of age, will perform a new work by Christine Neubert, its choreographer and director, titled The Inventor and the Comedians. The ballet was inspired by a play presented in 1937 by the Moscow Theater for Children.

title: Youths Upset by a Youth Parley
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Nixon Administration is being accused by activist youths and some establishment adults of going to great lengthsto Colorado, in factto mute controversy at the White House Conference on Youth next month.

title: Pollution Ban Makes a Ghost Town
description: ROCKAWAY TOWNSHIP, N. J., March 26 Empty shells of unfinished houses stant,1 forlornly oil a vast tract of wooded land here that was to be Fleetwood Homes, an expensive suburban development.

title: Maker Calls Federal Report On Whipping Cream False
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)The Avoset Food Corporation, producer of 100,000 cartons of whipping cream that the Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday were contaminated, said today that the reports are false and misleading.

title: Cordero Caps Quadruple With Brabant II
description: Angel Cordero thrilled the crowd of 23,505 at Aqueduct yesterday by riding four winners, including Sigmund Sommer's Brabant II in the feature onemile race. In registering his quadruple, Cordaro scored in two races in which heavilybacked rivals competed.

title: Bishop Installed in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, March 26 (AP)The Right Rev. J. Warren Hutchens was installed yesterday as the 10th Episcopal bishop of Connecticut. The ceremony was conducted in Christ Church Cathedral.

title: OKLA. STATE SEALS TIE FOR MAT TITLE
description: AUBURN, Ala., March 26 (AP)Oklahoma State, sending five competitors into championship matches, virtually clinched its 27th National Collegiate wrestling championship tonight.

title: Montherlant Play About Homosexuals Staged in London
description: LONDON, March 26If one purpose of the World Theater Season is to emphasize the foreignness of foreign theater, it certainly succeeds by opening this year's program with the Theatre Michel production of Henry de Montherlant's La Mlle dont le prince Est un Enfant at the Aldwych.

title: Hazard for Cairo Taxi Women: Men
description: CAIRO, March 26A little black and white taxi, No. 2338, stopped at a red light in downtown Cairo. Another taxi pulled alongside and the driver shouted a warning, Your tire is going flat!

title: Soviet Union Blanks Sweden In World Hockey Tourney
description: BERN, Switzeland, March 27 (AP)  Anatoli Firsov, a 30yearold wing, scored tour goals tonight, leading the Soviet Union's national team to an 80 victory over Sweden in the world hockey championship.

title: Originala to Close Division
description: Originala, Inc., a women's apparel manufacture, announced yesterday that it will phase out its Ginini division, its smallest division, after the summer season.

title: Mrs. Winthrop Rockefeller Sues for Arkansas Divorce
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 26 (AP)Mrs. Winthrop Rockefeller Sued the former Arkansas Governor today for divorce. The couple announced Feb. 19 that they were going to be divorced after 14 years. It had been the second marriage for both.

title: JORDANIAN TROOPS BATTLE COMMANDOS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 26 (Reuters)  Jordanian troops and Palestine commandos clashed in the north Jordan city of Irbid at dawn today and one of the commando groups, Al Fatah, reported that heavy firing was still going as night fell.

title: Slum Sports Program Aide Arrested on Drug Charge
description: A man who the police said was affiliated with a sports program for slum youths was arrested last night while allegedly carrying heroin valued at $1.5million.

title: Protestants See Paris Envoys; Urge U.S. Withdrawal Pledge
description: PARIS, March 26A group of 46 American Protestant church leaders, clergymen and laymen urged the United States today to pledge unconditional withdrawal of its troops from Indochina in the immediate future to facilitate a political settlement at the Vietnam peace talks.

title: End of Tax Exemption Ordered For 23 Mississippi Academies
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Internal Revenue Service, operating under a Federal Court order, has revoked the tax exemptions of 23 private academies in Mississippi for failing to adopt nondiscriminatory admissions policies.

title: Mills Welfare Bill Will Disappoint Some
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The welfare reform plan developed by Representative Wilbur D. Mills in the House Ways and Means Committee seems certain to disappoint some Govrnors, despite the $2.1billion in fiscal relief it would provide the states.

title: Soviet Missile Site Pattern Called Hint of New System
description: WASHINGTON, March 26United States officials said today that the pattern of recent construction of intercontinental missile sites in the Soviet Union might presage the deployment of a new Soviet offensiveweapon system.

title: Bridge: Defender Ignores a Principle And Beats NoTrump Contract
description: A valuable principle of defensive play concerns the location of honor cards. A defender with an honor card ranking immediately above an honor card to his right should generally avoid leading the suit.

title: Democrats to Plan Strategy
description: ST. LOUIS, March 26 (UPI) Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic National Chairman, will met hem with Democratic Governors this weekend to discuss strategy for the 1972 election. At least 15 Governors and the aides of two others are expected to attend the closed sessions, Which will begin tomorrow afternoon.

title: FINAL PLEA HEARD IN MANSON TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26The fate of Charles M. Manson and the three young women who were convicted of the seven TateLaBianca murders along with him was placed in the hands of the jury today.

title: Plans for Pulp Mill Dropped
description: TORONTO, March 26 (AP)The Canadian International Paper Company, a subsidiary of the International Paper Company, has abandoned plans to build a $70million kraft pulp mill in Prince Edward County, the Ontario lands and forests ministry announced today. A low rate of return on investment and difficult business conoditions were cited.

title: Violence Reported Quelled In a City in West Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI, Saturday, March 27 (Reuters)  Violence in the riottorn West Pakistan city of Lyalipur was brought under control by the police today and a 24hour curfew was lifted, the Pakistani radio, monitored here, reported.

title: Letters to the Editor;Why Tax Vegetable Seeds?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rogers Hints Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States intended to continue negotiations for peace in Vietnam but held open the possibility that the United States and South Vietnam might boycott the next round in Paris.

title: U.S. Aides Rate West Pakistan's Forces as Stronger
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Warfare in East Pakistan would find the regular West Pakistani army with superior numbers of troops and modern weapons, according to United States analysts here.

title: Queens Detour Announced
description: The city's Traffic Department announced yesterday that Springfield Boulevard traffic in Queens would be detoured in both directions at the Grand Central Parkway, Mondays through Fridays, starting next week, between 9 A.M. and 3:30 P.M. for a month because of construction in the area.

title: Dacca: Sprawling, Dusty Metropolis
description: Dacca, scene of the reported sharp clashes between Pakistani Government troops and East Bengal separatists, is Paldstan's thirdlargest city, with an estimated population of 800,000.

title: Harpsichord Skill Is Shown at Recital By Gerald Ranch
description: Given the multitude of decisions harpsichordists must make about ornamentation, registration and so on when playing the instrument and its literature, it is scarcely surprising that there are many divergent notions as to how everything should be done.

title: Voiceprint Mistake Conceded In Tying Inspector to Gambler
description: A company that specializes in identifying people by their Voiceprints now says that its original identification of a highranking police official demoted during a corruption investigation was wrong.

title: French Elections: A Draw
description: The tworound French municipal elections have reconfirmed the political division in France between a Gaullist majority in the central government in Paris and opposition predominance in the provinces.

title: George Gross, 59, President Of Maintenance Firm, Dies
description: George Gross, president of Prudential Building Maintenance Corporation, 1430 Broadway, died Thursday at his home, 24 Spring Hill Drive, West Orange, N. J. His age was 59.

title: CHARLES J. HORAN, HOUSING OFFICIAL
description: Charles J. Horan, a prominent official of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development and its predecessor agencies, died Thursday evening in French Hospital after an illness of three months. He was 59 years old and lived at 321 East 43d Street.

title: Horse Serum Error Cited
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)An Agriculture Department official said today that the department had wrongly identified two companies yesterday as among four subject to a stopsale order on several serums used in treating horses. The two unaffected companies are Diamond Laboratories, Inc. of Des Moines, Iowa, and Phillips Roxane, Inc., of St. Joseph, Mo. The stopsale order was issued as a precautionary step after tests disclosed that some horses used by the companies as donors for serum material were carriers of equine infections anemia.

title: City Schools Are Adding 50 Guards to Force of 380
description: Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the City School Chancellor, announced yesterday that 50 security guards would be added to the 380man force that patrols the 900 city schools as soon as they could be recruited and trained..

title: 5,000 Beg for Food in Brazil
description: RECIFE, Brazil, March 26 (Reuters)More than 5,000 starving peasants begging for food entered the center of Cupira, in northeastern Brazil, tonight, the Globo Radio reported. Dozens fainted in the main square where Mayor Joaquim da Silva distributed food to almost all. But 500 went hungry when supplies ran out.

title: DR. JAMES BOYD, 51, CHAPLAIN AT DREW U.
description: MADISON, N.J., March 26The Rev. Dr, James M. Boyd, chaplain of Drew University, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 51 years old.

title: Where the Smart Set Dines in London
description: LONDONOne of the best places to get roast beef and Yorkshire pudding in this tratorla  riddled cosmopolitan city is Burke's, a private club that caters to the international smart set.

title: David Griffin Weds Mrs. Grace Darling
description: Mrs. Grace Darling, daughter of Mrs. Barnett Golding of New York and the late Mr. Golding, was married here yesterday afternoon to David Griffin, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Griffin of New York.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 26 Some undergraduates invited Harvard's presidentelect to tea the other day, and he went. That may not sound like news. At this university, after thirty years of presidential remoteness from students, it is.

title: If Venison's Not Your Dish, There's Always Hare
description: MONTAGUE, N. J.Charles Fries of Roslyn, L.I., wouldn't even taste the venison. Every time I'd go to eat it, he said, I'd see those big deer eyes staring at me as they do along the edges of the fairways in the summer.

title: BULLETS SUBDUE 76ERS BY 119.107
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26The Baltimore Bullets, faced for almost the first time in this National Basketball Association season with a game they could not afford to lose, completely outplayed the Philadelphia 76ers, 119107 tonight at the Spectrum.

title: Trade Balance of U.S. Improved in February
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The United States surplus of exports over imports improved in February over the low level of January but remained well below the monthly average for 1970, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Phelps Dodge Sets a Rise In Domestic Copper Price
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the second largest producer of American primary copper, announced yesterday that it would raise the basic price of the metal by about 4.7 per cent, effective Monday.

title: State Savings Under Welfare Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Following are the estimated amounts states would save in present costs next year if the welfare reform bill tentatively approved by the House Ways and Means Committee is enacted. The figures are based on the assumption that states will maintain their present benefit level in the family category rind not be required to spend more than 90 per cent of their 1971 costs in the adult category. The savings involve increased Federal assumption in almost all cases, of overall costs in both types of benefits and state administrative expenses.

title: Market Place: Pros and Cons Of Sales Data
description: How would you feel if you opened the annual report of a company whose shares you owned and found there were no sales or gross operating revenue figures?

title: Diana Ross Will Play Role Of Billie Holiday on Screen
description: Diana Ross will start as Billie Holiday in a film based on Lady Sings the Blues, the late singer's autobiography, it was announced yesterday by Jim White, vice president of Motown Productions, Inc.

title: Henderson Hearing Set
description: FORT MEADE, Md., March 26 (AP)The initial pretrial hearing for Col. Oran K. Henderson, charged with dereliction of duty in connection with the investigation of the alleged Mylai massacre, will be conducted here next Friday, the Army said today.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 A Minigenerator produces a continuous supply of radioisotopes, making it possible for students in high schools and colleges to perform safe and economical nuclear experiments. Wayne J. Gemmill, a scientist at the Union Carbide Corpora tion's research center in Sterling Forest, N. Y., was granted Design Patent 220,267 for the tiny instrument this week. A mechanical pattent covering the construction was issued to him a month ago.

title: 6 Tie for Lead With 136's Over Windy Miami Course
description: MIAMI, March 26Despite a 25mileanhour wind that swept the course, Hubert Green, a 24yearold rookie from Birmingham, Ala., scored a sevenunderpar 65 today and moved into a sixway tie for the lead in the $200,000 National Airlines open golf tourney.

title: CITY SCHOOL BOARD CLEARED BY STATE
description: A State Education Department inquiry cleared the Board of Education here yesterday of having violated a state law against overspending in connection with its current $29.2million budget deficit.

title: Budgetary Roll.Overs
description: The little that Governor Rockefeller has not been able to do with bondsstate bonds, authority bonds, housing bonds, dormitory bonds, transportation bonds, water bonds, development bondshe has tried to do with budgetary rollovers. To capitalize it has been one magical phrase used to wipe away fiscal problems in Albany. To roll it over has been another. Every conceivable expense that has not been capitalized and paid with bond funds has been rolled over, or deferred, from one fiscal year to the next.

title: Theater: Uncle Vanya
description: Everyone interested in the theater should see Chekhov's Uncle Vanya every year or so just to keep in training There are some classics we always have to return to, not to learn about them but to learn about ourselves. And this is the value of the Classic Stage Company, which pursues its ideals of a classic repertory theater at 89 West Third Street. The ideals, incidentally, get caught regularly on Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings, and Sunday afternoons.

title: LINDSAY OFFERS CITY FOR U.N. DRUG STUDY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26Mayor Lindsay invited Secretary General Thant today to use New York as a laboratory in seeking ways to combat drug addiction.

title: Army TV in Saigon Airs Selling of the Pentagon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 26The official Army television station here aired the Columbia Broadcasting System's Trie Selling of the Pentagon twicelast Saturday at 6 P.M. and yesterday at 5 P.M.

title: Nixon Expected to Order Building WagePrice Curb
description: WASHINGTON, March 26President Nixon is expected to issue early next week an executive order establishing machinery aimed at controlling wage and price increases in the construction industry.

title: GROUPS ASK VETO OF WELFARE SHIFT
description: ALBANY, March 26Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish organizations urged Governor Rockefeller today to veto a bill that would give him the power to appoint the State Commissioner of Social Services.

title: Hope for Vote on Calley Rises As Jury Asks Copy of Charges
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 26The military jury in the trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. approached its second weekend of deliberations today by asking for a more legible copy of the Army specifications of charges against the 27yearold officer.

title: Czechs Jail ExGeneral Critical of Warsaw Pact
description: PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 26 (Reuters)Vaclav Prchlik, a former general and the political commissar for the armed forces during the reformist Government of Alexander Dubcek, was sentenced to three years' imprisonment today for having criticized the Warsaw Pact nearly three years ago.

title: New Jazz Center to Be Site Of Expanded Noon Concerts
description: The noontime jazz concerts that have been presented on Fridays by Jazz Adventures at Downbeat, Lexington Avenue at 42d Street, for the past three months, will move next Friday to La Martinique, 57 West 57th Street, which will become a center of jazz activity.

title: G.A.O. REPORT POLICY DEFENDED BY STAATS
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)Controller General Elmer B. Staats defended today the General Accounting Office practice of submitting draft reports to agencies or contractors being studied by the G.A.O. before a final report was issued.

title: TV: Ustinov as Gideon
description: Paddy Chayefsky's Gideon opened on Broadway in 1961 for a modest run. Last night at 8:30, the Biblical conceit, as the playwright dubs it, made it to television, on the National Broadcasting Company's Hallmark Hall of Fame. And under the intelligent guidance of producerdirector George Schaefer, it provided one of the better hourandahalf segments on the television horizon these days.

title: HARLEM TEENAGERS IN HOUSING PROTEST
description: A group of about 30 Harlem teenagers barred workers from the offices of HarlemEast Harlem Model Cities and MillbankFrawley Circle Urban Renewal in the second day of a sitin protesting housing and relocation policies of the two agencies.

title: Tito on Piazza Venezia
description: For anyone who remembers how close to war the Trieste dispute led Yugoslavia and Italy twenty years ago, the spectacle was hard to credit. Here was President Tito of Yugoslavia receiving the keys of the city from the Mayor of Rome at the Colosseum then moving on Piazza Venezia to draw polite cheers from Italians as ho placed a wreath at the tomb of Italy's Unknown Soldier.

title: Nathan Cohen, Stage Critic For Toronto Star, 47, Dies
description: TORONTO, March 26 (Canadian Press)  Nathan Cohen, theater critic of The Toronto Star and a writer and broadcaster, died today of a heart attack. Mr. Cohen, who was 47 years old, recently had under gone heart surgery to correct a circulatory ailment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WILLIAM BEEKHUYSEN
description: CRANFORD, N. J., March 26  William J. Beekhuysen, a self  employed consulting engineer, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit: He was 51 years old and lived at 10 Tulip Street.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: March 26, 1971

title: Two With Stolen Miami Silver Seized After Chase in Jersey
description: NEWARK, March 26 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced the arrest tonight of two Miami men and the recovery of silver artifacts valued at several hundred thousand dollars that were stolen from the Villa Vizcaya Museum in Miami.

title: Auto Output Trimmed
description: DETROIT, March 26 (AP) The General Motors Corporation cut back somewhat in overtime production this week, causing a decline of 2,000 units in this week's auto production schedules, the trade paper Automotive News reported yesterday.

title: H.E.W. Issues Rules For States to Curb Fraud in Medicaid
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)  The Health, Education and Welfare Department announced today a series of regulations to prevent fraud by dispensers of medical services in the Medicaid program of health care for the needy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT HEARING SET ON PENNSY PETITIONS
description: The Federal District Court in Philadelphia will hold a hearing next Friday on two petitions of the trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company.

title: ECONOMIC GAUGE UP FOR FEBRUARY
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Government's composite index of leading Indicators of economic activity rose in February for the fourth consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: British Bar 112 Passengers From Charter Flight to City
description: A British chartered airliner landed at Kennedy Airport last night, minus 112 angry American and Canadian passengers who were denied permission to board the plane at London's Gatwick Airport when British officials said they were not bona fide members of the clubs that chartered the aircraft.

title: Puerto Ricans Strengthen Political Power
description: A strong drive by Puerto Ricans to increase their political power in the City has emerged from a bitter struggle to control the antipoverty programs in a Bronx slum area of 260,000 people.

title: DETROIT EDISON CO. LIFTED 1970 PROFIT
description: The Detroit Edison Company showed gains in operating revenues and net income in 1970, according to the company's report mailed yesterday to stockholders.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: NEWARK, March 26 (AP)Federal Judge Anthony T. Augelli today approved a $6million loan to keep the bankrupt Jersey Central Railroad running until the end of the year. Each time the Jersey Central waists to use part of the loan, backed by the Government, the railroad must ask court approval.

title: BLACKS GIVE NIXON MAY 17 DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Black members of the House of Representatives said today that if President Nixon has not begun to act by May 17 on a set of demands they presented him yesterday they would take the issue to the people.

title: The Easter Egg People
description: Easter is right around the corner, and right around the corner from 51st Street, at 900 First Avenue, is an amusing window display of Easter egg people. The characters include Napoleon, a circus lion seated on a drum, Friar Tuck, a strongman, a hobo with a flower in his hat, a laurelwreathed Roman with a placard announcing, I only have ides for you, and an Indian carrying sign that says, Martini... $1.35. Manhattan . . . $24. They are the seasonal offering of Nancy's Fancy, a 10yearold gift shop that specializes in whim seys. The more than 50 tiny figures in the window are made from eggs and bits of fabric and paper, with embroidery thread for hairor for a mane, as the case may be. Most of them cost $6, but a rotund Queen Victoria proclaiming, Damned shame we lost India is $10. Pego Paar, a bookkeeper whose avocation is decorating the window of Nancy Schuchman's shop, made the little people. Nancy's Fancy is open Tuesday through Friday, from 10 A.M. to 6:30 P.M., and on Monday and Saturday from 1 to 6:30 P.M.

title: LEGISLATOR ASSAILS LOGUE'S LUSH LAIR
description: A Brooklyn Assemblyman yesterday accused Edward J. Logue, president of the State Urban Development Corporation, of squandering millions of dollars to furnish the agency's midtown Manhattan office.

title: Turkey Gets New Cabinet; Emphasis Is on Specialists
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 26  Premier Nihat Erim announced his Cabinet today, choosing 15 of the 25 ministers in it from outside the Turkish Parliament. It includes many young technical experts with no political experience.

title: The Talk of Pontianak
description: PONTIANAK, Indonesia, March 16The first clue that this town is slightly off the beaten track comes at the airport. There are butterflies in the waiting room.

title: Soviet Said to Offer Hope of Berlin Easter Visits
description: BERLIN, March 26  The Soviet Union reportedly held out to the three. Western allies today the prospect of a temporary opening of the Berlin wall to let West Berliners visit the eastern half of the city during the Easter holiday.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS VOLUME GAINS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange scored their first advance in six sessions yesterday as most issues rose in moderate trading.

title: ISRAELIS PROTEST AWARD TO BORGES
description: JERUSALEM  No literary awardnot even in this Holy Citycan escape controversy these days.

title: Regents Allow Girls to Compete With Boys in Noncontact Sports
description: ALBANY, March 26  The State Board of Regents voted today to allow girls to compete with boys in selected noncontact sports.

title: SOLO DANCES GIVEN BY MISS BILDERBACK
description: Carolyn Bilderback presented a program of solo dances at Judson Church on Thursday evening that had a haikulike brevity to commend them, but little else. Her use of movement materials was economical if not downright parsimonious, but her restraint indicated impoverishment of invention rather than prudent artistic pruning.

title: JOHN F. DAILEY JR., A PROSECUTOR HERE
description: John F. Dailey Jr., a former Chief Assistant United States Attorney here, died Thursday in Wintdale, N. Y. He was 68 years old and lived at 14 Plymouth Road, in Chappa.qua, N. Y.

title: Sonics Retain Haywood In OutofCourt Compact
description: An outofcourt settlement of the Spencer Haywood case, leaving the basketball star the property of the Seattle SuperSanics as fares the National Basketball Association is concerned, was announced yester, day by Walter Kennedy, N... commissioner.

title: COLONELS TRIUMPH OVER NETS, 122115
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 26 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels clinched a tie for second place in the East Division of the American Basketball Association by beating the thirdplace New York Nets, 122115, tonight at Island Gardens.

title: In Brazil's Northeast, a Droughtand Quiet Despair
description: SAO JOSE DO EGITO, Brazil, March 19  The procession to honor St. Joseph moved in silence under a clear, lateafternoon sky with the smallest children In their Sunday best at its head and the older women, rosaries tangled in their fingers, in the rear behind a simple wooden cross.

title: Chinese Art Sale Benefit
description: An auction of old and new works by Chinese artists will be held May 21 at the Hartman Gallery, 978 Madison Avenue, for the benefit of the Actors Youth Fund and the FuJen Catholic University of Taiwan. Paul Cardinal YuPin of Taipei will attend the auction.

title: Mrs. King Wins Semifinal
description: For the seventh time this year, Mrs. Billie Jean King and Rosemary Casals will meet in the final round of the women's professional tennis tour.

title: RIGHTS CHIEF DIES IN ATLANTA CRASH
description: ATLANTA, March 26 (UPI)The Rev. T. Y. Rogers, a leader of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, was killed in an automobile accident today, forcing postponement of a planned march against repression.

title: 7.4% Rise in February
description: Major chain store companies scored a 7.4 per cent increase in sales in February and a 6.4 per cent gain in the first two months of this year, according to a New York Times survey.

title: BLACK COLLEGES GAIN PRIME TIME
description: The GramblingMorgan State football game, scheduled for Saturday night, Sept. 11, In Yankee Stadium, will be televised nationally by, the American Broadcasting Company as the opening game in its weekly college, football series.

title: U.S. Bank Sets French Unit
description: The Bank of America plans to establish additional overseas branches in Hamburg, Germany, and in Strasbourg, France, the Federal Reserve Board disclosed yesterday. The Merchants National Bank and Trust Company of Indianapolis plans a branch in Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: Anne W. Brigman's Photos Displayed
description: If you've never heard of the photographer Anne W. Brigman, you're in good company. One of the medium's many forgotten names, Mrs. Brigman (18691950) was a brilliant camera club amateur (amateur in the old sense) discovered by the photographer Alfred Stieglitz in his travels through the country scouting talent for exhibition at his new York gallery.

title: FIGHT THREATENED ON SCHOOL FUNDS
description: An organization founded in 1967 to combat repeal of a state constitutional amendment that bans state aid to parochial schools is prepared to initiate a court battle if the Legislature passes bills this year to aid parochial schools.

title: BIG BOARD PRICES MODESTLY HIGHER
description: Stock prices moved modestly higher yesterday as the market continued to weave a consolidation pattern. For the first time in six sessions, advancing issues outpaced the laggards on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Argentine President Sworn In, Keeps 6 of 8 Cabinet Ministers
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 26Lieut. Gen. Alejandro Agustin Lanusse, who on Tuesday ousted Brig. Gen. Roberto Marcelo Levingston from the presidency, was sworn in this evening as President of Argentina.

title: EARLY RISE PARED IN LONDON STOCKS
description: A firmer tendency began to falter toward the close of trading in the London stock market yesterday as buyers failed to follow early small institutional support end many prices finished below the day's highs.

title: Specter of a Civil War Has Long Haunted Pakistan
description: As Pakistan prepared for her first direct democratic national election last December, a visitor to Dacca commented on the number of khakishirted soldiers discreetly sequestered along back streets of the humid East Pakistani capital.

title: Moscow Criticizes Nixon On His Smiles for Peking
description: MOSCOW, March 26  The Soviet Unionexpressed concern today over President Nixon's latest efforts to improve United States relations with Communist China.

title: Joan Crawford to Aid Negro Troupe on Funds
description: Joan Crawford has accepted the honorary chairmanship of a new board of advisers established recently to raise funds for the Negro Ensemble Company, now facing financial difficulties despite the fact that it plays to almost capacity houses.

title: Nixon Asks Clergy to Give Faith To Youths as Drug Alternative
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)  President Nixon urged a visiting group of clergymen at the White House today to give youth some sense of faith as the best alternative to a life ruined by drugs.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, March 26A Justice Department spokesman, told about the threat, said, This is not unexpected. He said that names of informers were among the documents stolen and that the names had not yet been distributed by the thieves.

title: ERNEST E. RIDOUT, 81, MANAGED AN ESTATE
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., March 26 Ernest Edward Ridout, superIntendent, of the Westchester County estate of the family of Representative Ogden R. Reid, Republican of Westchester, for more than 30 years, died yesterday, in White Plains Hospital at the age of 81.

title: G.O.P. CHIEFS BACK $700MILLION CUT IN STATE BUDGET
description: ALBANY, March 26  Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. told Republican Assemblymen today that Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders had agreed to cuts of $700million in the administration's proposed $8.45billion budget.

title: BLEFARY'S HOMER TOPS ORIOLES, 32
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 26The last time Frank Robinson was at Fort Lauderdale Stadium, he was in a role that prompted Ralph Houk to say, I'd rather see him in the dugout than in the outfield.

title: The Coed's a Colonel, Too
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 26 (UPI)Susan Ann Orkins says she is not a women's liberation advocate, but merely wants to do my own thing. That just happens to be commanding the 600member Air Force Reserve Officers Training Corps traditionally an allmale forceat State University.

title: C. B. S. Team Wins Award for a Vietnam Project
description: A Columbia Broadcasting System tearn that produced The World of Charlie Company, a portrait of the life of United States soldiers in Vietnam, has won the 1971 Overseas Press Club's George Polk Memorial Award, it was announced yesterday.

title: Screen: Corman's 'Gas':Kips Bay Attraction Is Part of Retrospective
description: To the extent that Roger Croman's "Gas" is an end-of-the-world movie, you mightif you were taking leave of your right sensesdescribe it as both his "Weekend" and his "Shame," although it's far less funny than Godard and a good deal more pretentious than Bergman.According to the Corman vision, which has actually become less poetic since "Attack of the Crab Monsters" in 1957, a strange nerve gas turns everyone who is over 25 into an instant ancient, thus leaving the world to the young people, who lose no time in repeating the mistakes of their elders."The film opened yesterday at the Kips Bay Theater as the climax of a four-week retrospective devoted to approximately 30 of the almost 50 movies that Mr. Corman has directed since 1955. (He has produced an additional 40 or so.) As anyone who has followed the Corman career must know, he has special gifts for sensational melodrama ("The Wild Angels") and fruity horror romance ("Masque of the Red Death"), which he has been free to exercise largely because he works fast and makes films that always look as if they cost five times what they actually did."Gas," sadly, is Mr. Corman's latest attempt to be funny and hipCorman in a Robert Downey mask that doesn't fit. It also reminds me of the story about the four fishermen who, after spending several hours hoping that the pelican overhead would lead them to fish, realize that as they are following the pelican, the pelican is following them.Are movies like "Gas" and "Brewster McCloud," spontaneous responses to the lunacies of the age, or are they attempts to exploit them?
