Without knowing it, could they possibly be following attitudes that, in turn, are following them? I'm really not sure, though I am certain that "Gas" is tolerable only as a movie that wants desperately to please. To turn your back on such a defenseless film requires a resolute rudeness.George Armitage's screenplay sounds very much like the work of a writer who has lowered himself into his subject while trying to hang onto heaven. The film pretends to be a Pop Odyssey that leads from Dallas to a New Mexico commune of last resort, enacted by characters with names like Coel, Cilia, Demeter and Jason. There also are encounters with Edgar Allan Poe, riding a Harley, and Billy the Kid, atop a horse named Pretentious.Mr. Armitage's comic conceits seldom make up in surprise what they always lack in originality. His lovers, Coel (Robert Corff) and Cilla (Elaine Giftos)," display a steadfast optimism that is, indeed, funnier than the various disasters that befall them on their journey. Among other things, they are constantly being captured, once by a football team for whom the sacking of El Paso is the big game, and, later on, by a band of Hell's Angels, whose members spout the clichs of the old right-wing middle-class. There also are A.M.A. jokes (doctor to woman in labor: "take two aspirins and call me if It gets worse") and borrowing from other films, including the man-in-the-raincoat from "Putney Swope."Most apparent, however, is Mr. Corman's inability to reflect, in the images he chooses, what shouldI assumebe a comic mood. "Gas" sounds as if it wanted to be funny, but its style is as solemn as "The Wild Angels," despite its slapstick chases, its Op art effects used as bridges between scenes, and despite its soundtrack score by Country Joe and the Fish that's not bad at all.I must say that I liked all the young performers, and at least one gagthe one about a chemical that could induce movies on the insides of the eyelids. The experiments, however, never succeeded in producing anything except 1930's musicals, and these only in mice. For the most part, the fantasy of "Gas" is simply heavier and less absurd than the reality it means to demolish.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Down Twins, 53, on Jones's 3d Hit of Game, a 2Run Single in 7th
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26  With less than one week to go in Florida, the New York Mets defeated the Minnesota Twins today, 53, for their fifth victory in their last six games.

title: Senate Pollution Panel Faces Dilemma As Dumping Off Delaware Increases
description: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del., March 26Senator Edmund S. Muskie and his Subcommittee on Air and Water Pollution faced a dilemma here today over what to do about contamination of the ocean by the increasing amount of sewage sludge that is being dumped off the shore here.

title: B.O.A.C. Profitability Off in Last 6 Months
description: LONDON, March 26 (UPI)  Profitability of the stateowned British Overseas Airways Corporation, has dropped in the last six months to a point where it faces a potentially difficult cash problem in the coming financial year, it was reported today in the airline's publication, B.O.A.C. News.

title: Bank Apologizes to Rye for School Vote Statement
description: The First National City Bank, the second largest bank in the United States, apologized to the Town of Rye in Westchester County yesterday after town school officials charged that the bank was trying to scare some 2,000 voters into turning down two controversial issues in a school referendum.

title: Saigon Patrols Moved Up To Help Retreating Units
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 27Several hundred South Vietnamese marines were sent to patrol in small units along the Laotian border yesterday, and some were ordered back into Laos to reoccupy a hilltop position overlooking the Khesanh plateau of northwestern South Vietnam.

title: Princeton's Loss
description: Shortly after Robert Francis Goheen, then an assistant professor of classics, was named president of Princeton University in 1957 at the age of 37, he said: I look forward to spending my entire life here. Since then, the pace and conditions of academia have changed furiously, and fourteen years on campus now may well seem a lifetime. It is therefore hardly surprising that Dr. Goheen, in announcing that he will leave his post by June 1972, insisted that the tempo of change argues against a tenure of more than ten to fifteen years in the modern university presidency.

title: Three Students at Fordham Are Robbed in Dormitory
description: Three Fordham University students were robbed of a total of $160 in a dormitory yesterday by two armed youths. The students were not injured.

title: 4 indicted With Lansky Are Released on Bond
description: MIAMI, March 26 (AP) Four men indicted with Meyer Lansky, the reputed underworld financial expert, surrendered today on charges of skimming profits from a Las Vegas casinohotel. They were released on recognizance bonds of $100,000 each.

title: 100 SOVIET JEWS MAY LEAVE SOON
description: MOSCOW, March 26More than 100 Soviet Jews who staged a sitin at a Government office building here have been told they would soon be allowed to emigrate to Israel, reliable sources said today.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robintech, Inc., has elected Thomas Nast as chairman and chief executive officer, and Bradford G. Corbett was made president and chief operating Officer. This follows the merger of Universal Pipe & Plastic, Inc., where Mr. Corbett was president, into Robintech, where Mr. Nast was president.

title: U.S.C. SETS MARK IN N.C.A.A. SWIM
description: AMES, Iowa, March 26 (AP) Southern California's 800yard freestyle relay team broke the American record by more than eight seconds, but Indiana, behind Gary Hall, continued to build a huge team lead in the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming and diving championships tonight.

title: Newark Teachers Reject Mediators Chosen by Mayor
description: NEWARK, March 26  The Newark Teachers Union today rejected as unacceptable a threemember team of negotiators appointed by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson to settle the eightweekold teachers' strike.

title: KNICKS SEEKING 20 SERIES LEAD
description: Game No. 2 of the firstround National Basketball Association playoff series between the New York Knicks and the Atlanta Hawks will take place at Madison Square Garden at 8 o'clock tonight, after which the teams will fly in separate charters to Atlanta for the next games of the fourofseven competition.

title: GROUP TO PUBLICIZE F. B. I.'S INFORMERS
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (Reuters)The Citizens Commission to Investigate the F.B.I., which contends it stole documents from the agency's office in nearby Media, says it will soon make public lists of F.B.I. informers and provocateurs.

title: Coast Court Ruling Jars Reagan's Welfare Plan
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 26The California Supreme Court has dealt Gov. Ronald Reagan a severe blow in his efforts to slash welfare expenditures and avoid a projected state budget deficit now approaching $1billion.

title: Hart to Oppose Draft
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)Senator Philip A. Hart, an antiwar critic, said today he would vote against extending the draft beyond its June 30 expiration date. President Nixon has asked Congress to extend the draft for two more years

title: End of the Parity Gravy Train
description: The recommendations to be made Monday by three municipal factfinders covering wages and other contract terms for policemen, firemen and sanitation workers will have a crucial bearing on both the cost and quality of government in this most problemafflicted of cities. Every dollar in excess of a fair settlement that goes the uniformed forces means a diversion of funds from underfinanced services or an extra burden on overstrained civic taxpayers.

title: 2 Experts Back Ban on Tear Gas and Sprays in War
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Two scientific consultants to the executive branch differed with Administration policy today by arguing that it was in the interest of the United States to accept an international ban on the military use of tear gases and herbicides.

title: Closing of Spofford Will Be Requested In Court in Bronx
description: The director of the Institute for Juvenile Justice, a national childadvocacy organization, said yesterday that legal action would be taken to close the Spofford Juvenile Center in the Bronx once and for all.

title: British Holdup Men Get $1Million
description: LONDON, March 26An armed gang held up an armored security truck in suburb south of London today and escaped with $1.1million in cash.

title: WAR FOES BREAK UP TEACHINATHARVARD
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 26 (UPI)Several hundred antiwar demonstrators broke up a teachin on Indochina shortly after it started tonight at Harvard University.

title: Telegraph Avenue's Flower Children Have Gone Underground
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 26 The flower children are gone from Telegraph Avenue, and their disappearance underscores a fundamental change that is taking place in the lives of disaffected young people across the country.

title: MUSEUM HERE OPENS TALKS WITH STAFF
description: Management and staff representatives at the Museum of Modern Art have begun formal negotiations toward an employment agreement, in what are believed to be the first collective bargaining sessions carried on by an American museum with its professional and administrative staff.

title: Clashes Near Border
description: SAIGON, Saturday, March 27 (AP)  Scattered clashes were reported in northwestern South Vietnam yesterday as allied troops continued to withdraw eastward.

title: U. S. Opposes Plea to Disclose Data Overheard in Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)The Government admitted today that it had overheard telephone wiretap conversations by one of the radicals accused of conspiring to cause riots in Chicago in 1969.

title: ARMS SESSION HELD; 5TH ONE IS DELAYED
description: VIENNA, March 26United States and Soviet negotiators met for 90 minutes at the American Embassy today and put off until next Thursday their next formal discussion of ways to limit strategic nuclear arms.

title: Waters, Guitarist And Singer, Plays Blues at Gaslight
description: Muddy Waters, the Chicago blues guitarist and singer, is playing through Monday at the Gaslight Cafe, 116 McDougal Street.

title: Coach Allows Tar Heels to Come and Go as They Please
description: By letting his starters decide when they want to come out of the game and when they want to go back in, Dean Smith, North Carolina's dapper basketball coach, has introduced a touch of democracy to his team and compiled a 258 wonlost record this season.

title: Miss Reed Bride of F. L. Hayden
description: PITTSBURGH, March 26The marriage of Miss Virginia Louise Reed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Frederick Reed Jr., to Frederick Lester Hayden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Hayden of Manchester, N. H., took place here this afternoon in the Third Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Charles C. Bray performed the ceremony.

title: 12 on Philippine Bus Killed
description: MANILA, March 26 (UPI)Twelve passengers were killed and 38 injured Thursday when a bus plunged into a river near Davao, 550 miles southeast of Manila, the Philippine Constabulary reported today.

title: LEADER OF REBELS IN EAST PAKISTAN REPORTED SEIZED
description: NEW DELHI, Saturday, March 27The Pakistan radio announced today that Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the nationalist leader of East Pakistan, had been arrested only hours after he had proclaimed his region independent and after open rebellion was reported in several cities in the East.

title: AID FOR FARMERS PLEDGED BY THIEU
description: LONGXUYEN, South Vietnam, March 26 (UPI)  President Nguyen Van Thieu informally opened his reelection campaign today by announcing a fiveyear plan to bolster the rural economy by cutting Imports but increasing exports of such commodities as rice.

title: Manufacturers Warned On Rising Textile Waste
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 26William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, told textile men convening here today that the sharply increasing use of synthetic fibers and nonwoven fabrics in their industry would create a dramatic increase in the amount of textile wastes. This will result, he said at the meeting of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, in a greater burden on community solidwaste facilities.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE PASSIONS OF THE MIND: A novel of Sigmund Freud. By Irving Stone. 840 pages. Doubleday. $10.

title: New Fighting In Cambodia
description: PNOMPENIH, Cambodia, Saturday, March 27 (Reuters)Fierce fighting erupted again today at the Pich Nil Pass on the road from the capital southwestward to Cambodia's deep water port at Kompong Som.

title: Chile to Buy In First Major
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 26 An American  owned company, the Bethlehem Iron Mines Company, has signed contract with Chile's leftwing Government to sell its iron mines here, reliable sources said today.

title: Jaguar Introduces LongAwaited V12
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 26Jaguar, one of the British makes that did so much to make America conscious of sports cars after World War II, introduced its long awaited V12 here yesterday.

title: WNBC BARS LYRICS AS DRUGORIENTED
description: One Toke Over the Line, a current hit record composed by Mike Brewer and Tom Shipley, will no longer be played on WNBC Radio because of its drugoriented lyrics, the station's program manager said yesterday.

title: Golf Writers Honor Werden
description: QUINCY, Mass., Mares 26 (AP)The Golf Writers Association of America announced today that the William D. Richardson award has been voted to Lincoln Werden of the New York Times. The award is made for outstanding contributions to golf. Werden is a former president of the G.W.A.A. and is chairman of its board of directors.

title: PAUL M. SKOLNICK
description: Paul M. Skolnick, president of the HyGrade Sportswear Company, Inc., 105 Fifth Avenue, and of Promenade Fashions for Men, maker of men's apparel, died Monday here. He was 73 years old and lived at 185 East 85th Street.

title: HERBERT ROSENGREN, ARTIST AND DESIGNER
description: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N. J., March 26Herbert Carl Rosengren, artist and industrial designer, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at Old Pascack Road. His age was 61.

title: Phosphate Facility to Close
description: The American Cyanamid Company said yesterday that it would end its phosphate fertilizer chemicals operation in Bradley, Fla., on April 28. The shutdown will not affect phosphate rock operations at the plant but will eliminate 355 jobs.

title: Profit Taking Drops Futures In NewCrop Corn and Wheat
description: Profit taking and evening up for the weekend sent newcrop corn and wheat futures down yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Kenneth Irwin VanCott, 67; Upstate and Local Jeweler
description: Kenneth Irwin VanCott, retired Binghamton (N. Y.) and former New York jeweler, died Sunday in Johnson City, N. Y. His age was 67.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SST Stirs Japanese Interest But Not to Point of Purchase
description: TOKYO, March 26  Ataka & Co. is interested in the supersonic transport program voted down by the United States Senate two days ago, but not in terms of buying up the billiondollar project, a company official said here today.

title: Victor HugoVidal Jr. Marries Miss Holly Marrow in Suburb
description: IRVINGTON, N. Y., March 26  Miss Holly Marrow, daughter of Mrs. Bernard Marrow of Croton and the late Mr. Marrow, was married here this afternoon to Victor HugoVidal Jr., son of Mrs. HugoVidal of Palm Springs, Calif., and the late Mr. HugoVidal. Village Judge John H. Norris of Irvington performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Roland B. Stearns.

title: LAKER RALLY TOPS BULLS, 105 TO 95
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26 (AP)Gail Goodrich, the smallest man on the floor, scored 14 points in the final quarter tonight to rally the Los Angeles Lakers to a 10595 victory over the Chicago Bulls and a 20 lead in their National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: Antiques: From From China
description: The exhibition of the silk tapestries called K'OSsu currently at the China Institute should hearten collectors who complain there is nothing left to acquire.

title: ChavezTeamsters Pact Ends Lettuce Labor Rift
description: SALINAS, Calif., March 26Cesar Chavez, the farm union leader, announced an agreement today that could bring an end to a national boycott of lettuce grown in this valley and to labor strife in the fields.

title: Chou Sees Nixon Widening The War Before Election
description: PEKING, Saturday, March 27 Premier Chou Enlai predicted last night that President Nixon would expand the war in Indochina to coincide with Presidential campaigning in 1972 in the United States.

title: 7,000 Marchers Bid Governor Raise Aid To Church Schools
description: More than 7,000 students, parents and teachers marched past Governor Rockefeller's office at 22 West 55th Street yesterday, filling the air with shouts and chants for more state aid for parochial schools and sporadically jamming traffic in the immedaite area.

title: Armed Rebellion Reported
description: NEW DELHI, Saturday, March 27  Open rebellion broke out in East Pakistan yesterday, with fighting reported in several cities, and a radio station broadcast a proclamation of an independent people's republic.

title: NOHKYOGEN GROUP PRESENTS A 2D BILL
description: Somehow, the stage of Carnegie Hall seemed like an open Frigidaire on Thursday night, and it was chilly enough outside, as the Japanese visitors from the NohKyogen National Theaters gave their secondtolast performance.

title: ALBION FITZGERALD, PHYSICIAN HERE, 77
description: Dr. Albion J. Fitzgerald, a retired general practitioner, who had donated his services to Roman Catholic organizations, died Wednesday at his home, 43 West 95th Street. His age was 77.

title: Wille Calls for Overhaul Of U.S. BankLink Law
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The chaimman of the. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation called today for en overhaul of Federal law governing bank mergers in the interest of fairness, predictability and rationalitynone of which, he suggested, was being achieved at present.

title: CITY WILL SET UP CABLE TV AGENCY
description: As passed, the resolution represents a compromise between Mayor Lindsay's office and the Bureau of Franchises. It is understood that the Mayor favored the concept of an independent Office of Telecommunications but that the Bureau of Franchises, an arm of the Board of Estimate, was insistent upon its right under the city charter to grant and regulate franchises.

title: Laotians Yield 3 Positions
description: VIENTIANE, Laos March 26 (AP)Government troops have abandoned three hilltop positions overlooking the airfield at the royal capital of Luang Prabang, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today. He said two other positions two miles north and northeast of the airfield came under heavy mortar attack.

title: Music: Mennin Sinfonia
description: It is hard to think of the younglooking Peter Mennin as one of the veteran American composers, but he is. Almost 50 years old, he has been steadily getting performed for half of his years, has always been winning prizes and honors, and by now belongs to the older guard. His lean, somewhat William Schumanesque style has not changed much through the years, though naturally his writing continues to grow In expertise and assurance.

title: PANEL APPOINTED IN LEGAL AID CASE
description: WASHINGTON, March 26Three state Supreme Court judges were appointed today as a commission to investigate the validity of charges made by Gov. Ronald Reagan of California against a leading antipoverty law program in the state.

title: MESKILL DISCLOSES TOLL PLAZA THEFTS
description: HARTFORD, March 26Gov. Thomas J. Meskill disclosed today that up to $10,000 was being stolen monthly from the Greenwich toll plaza on the Connecticut Turnpike.

title: Arrives on Coast
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., March 26 (UPI)President Nixon's helicopter was unable to land at the Western White House tonight because of heavy fog. Instead, it had to be diverted to the nearby Camp Pendleton Marine Base, where it was guided down by radar. The First Family was then driven to the Western White House about two miles away.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIONER 21 IN FLORIDA DERBY
description: Executioner, who likes to run lat top spped from wire to wire, will be the headline horse today in the headline racethe $137,800 Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park.

title: Japan Bars Textile Exports To U.S. for 2Week Period
description: TOKYO, March 26 (UPI)The Japanese Government announced today a twoweek moratorium on export approval for polyesterfilament fabrics and knitmaterial cloth to the United States.

title: Shop Talk
description: The race is clearly between Chanel and Saint Laurent on Lord & Taylor's second floor these days, where relatively inexpensive Paris copies are or sale. Any number of women aren't bothering to take sides. Such as Mrs. Robert S. McNamara, whose husband is head of the World Bank. She came to look at the Chanels (I'm always interested in Chanel), soon decided on a beige suit, and then tried on a Saint Laurent blazer. She picked that one, too. The multiple purchase was feasible because hardly anything is priced over $100 and several of the copies were only $50.

title: EDWARD H. LARSON
description: Edward H. Larson, a Chicago advertising executive, died Tuesday in Venice, Fla., at the age of 61.

title: American Airlines Terms 71 Outlook Encouraging
description: American Airlines, Inc., which last year lost $26.4million, said in its annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday that prospects for 1971 are more encouraging.

title: New Stock Issues Up for Week in Heavy Trading
description: The newissue market continued to carve out new gains this week. Trading was heavy.

title: Helen Schwartz, ExAide To Lindsay, Dies of Injuries
description: SUFFERN, N.Y., March 26 (AP)Helen Schwartz, a former staff assistant to Mayor Lindsay of New York, died at a hospital here last evening of injuries suffered in a bus accident March 19.

title: Sports of The Times
description: At the age of 68, Fred Capossela looks as if he could go a fast five furlongs, but the sad fact is that the Voice of New York Racing has only two years left before he must retire to his stamp and coin collections. The race track will never be the same when Fred leaves, no matter who takes his place. But there is no reason why our town should be deprived of his clarion calls even after mandatory retirement from horse racing. There is still the stock market.

title: MillionDollar Star's Kin Still on Relief
description: DETROIT, March 26 (AP)Ralph Simpson cut short his college career to sign an estimated $1million hardship contract with the Denver Rockets of the American Basketball Association nine months ago. Today his mother said she and six brothers and sisters were still on welfare.

title: Utility'Plano More Stock
description: Stockholders of the Consumere Power Company will be asked, at the annual meeting On April 13 to approve an increase in authorized common stock from the present 25 million to 32.5 million shares and an increase in authorized preferred stock from 1.5 million to 12.5 million shares.

title: Japanese Investor Group Plans Visit to U.S.
description: A toplevel group of Japanese institutional investors  armed with authorization to apend up to $100million on foreign securities and possibly much more  will arrive here next month for a close lock at the United States stock market, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Formula One Cars Notch Fastest Times on Coast
description: ONTARIO, Calif., March 26The Formula One cars of the international Grand Prix circuit showed a decided superiority over homegrown American Formula A cars today at the end of the second day of qualifying for Sunday's running of the Questor Grand Prix. Of the 10 fastest cars, eight were Formula One machines.

title: Art: Dubuffet's Path Over the Years
description: The creative use of visual slang for the purpose of high art is now such an established and respectable convention that we tend to take its complex procedures for granted. Nothing now seems more natural or inevitable to us than the idea of basing a serious work of art on such popular or untutored idioms as graffiti, comic strips or children's art.

title: DEWEY LEFT ESTATE EXCEEDING A MILLION
description: Thomas E. Dewey, threetime Governor of New York and twice the Republican Presidential candidate, left an estate valued at more than $1million, according to a will filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court here.

title: Pacific Phone Weighs Sale
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company may have to raise $300million through the sale of additional stock toward the end of the year, J. W. Hull, president, said after yesterday's annual meeting at San Francisco. The concern is 89.7 per cent owned by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Chrysler Planning To Recall Workers At 2 of Its Plants
description: DETROIT, March 26  The Chrysler Corporation said today it will hire or recall 1,325 workers at two plants to increase its bigcar production May 10.

title: FEE OF 1C A SHARE IS SET BY BROKER
description: A rockbottom commission rate of a penny a share has been announced by a small member firm of the New York Stock Exchange in anticipation of an upcoming deadline to implement freely negotiated rates.

title: NEW ULSTER CHIEF WINS PARTY VOTE
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 26Northern Ireland's Prime Minister, Brian Faulkner, received a substantial vote of confidence from Unionist party members today, but controversy raged over the composition of the Cabinet he named last night.

title: Indians Seek Land
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) Representatives of two Indian tribes pleaded today for the return of lands taken from them during the Depression.

title: U.S. DENIES GERMANS REPURCHASED GOLD
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The Treasury denied today that West Germany had purchased $500million of gold from the United States or had indicated a request for such a purchase.

title: Chase Bank Establishes Economic Consulting Unit
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank has announced the establishment of an economic consulting service, including economic analyses and forecasts, annual projections up to a decade ahead and quarterly oneday seminars with the bank's specialists.

title: Alitalia Ad With Tears Causes Anguish Here
description: An Alitalia Airlines advertisement showing the Statue of Liberty weeping has brought anguished cries from the city's Convention and Visitors Bureau.

title: DR. HELEN D. LOCKWOOD
description: Dr. Helen D. Lockwood, who retired as a professor of Eng lish at Vassar College in 1956 after 29 years of service, died yesterday at a nursing home in Seaford, Sussex, England. She was 79 years old.

title: Powerboat Racing Opens at Miami Beach
description: The world of powerboat racing opens its 1971 season next Saturday when two di visions of the American Power Boat Association classes race over the new Americas Cup circuit off Miami Beach.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Black Elected Student President at South Carolina U.
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., March 27 The election of a black stu dent president at the Unlverstty of South Carolina and the ap pointment of a black executive director of a recently named State Human Relations Com mission this week reflected con tinuing changes in Smith Caro lina's racial patterns.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Jeremy Potter's A TRAIL OF BLOOD (McCall, $5.95) belongs to the special subgenre of de tective fiction that deals with historical fact newly inter preted. Some years back, Jo sephine Tey wrote a mystery novel based on Richard III. She came to the conclusion that he was a maligned figure. Potter touches on Richard, but his book is about the two Princes in the Tower whom Richard is popularly supposed to have murdered. Tey had a 20thcen tury cop working on the evi dence. Potter has put his novel in the days of Henry VIII, and his detective is a truthseeking, intellectually hon est scholar Brother Thomas of the Croyland Abbey.

title: Austrian Men and Women Dominating Skibob Events
description: RENO, March 27 (UPI)  Austrians swept the woman's giant slalom and won two of the top three places in the men's giant slalom today in the third annual international ski bob championships at Mount Rose.

title: National Notes
description: Washington, they say, is really two cities: the affluent area west of Rock Creek Park, whicit in cludes Georgetown, most of the embassies and the homes of hun dreds of diplomats and Govern ment officialsand the other neighborhoods. Consider last week's election of the District of Columbia's first nonvoting Dele gate to Congress in a century.

title: Boatyard Isn't Garage; Advice: Rely on Dealer
description: When the question of fit tingout arises, many new owners make the mistake of comparing their new boat to their car. You can drive your car into any garage for serv ice with the reasonable ex pectation that you will get it.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: BERGDORF GOODMAN, the Fifth Avenue specialty store, has signed an agreement to be acquired by Broad wayHale Stores, Inc., the largest department store organi zation in the West. . . . Phelps Dodge, a major producer, raised basic copper prices about 5 per cent to 52.4 cents a pound. It was the first advance since last year's cuts.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Fitting Out Is a Laugh On Pacific
description: OCEANSIDE, Calif.Fit ting out? What's that?

title: The World
description: PARISAngry peasants were on the march throughout the Common Market last week. They drove their tractors out to the main roads and dumped produce to tie up traffic. They broke windows of police stations in Normandy, mailed 7,000 bags of potatoes to a Belgian minister, hanged and burned effigies of French and Common Market farm officials, and rioted in Brussels on Tuesday, leaving one dead and 140 injured.

title: Quiet Compromise Reflected by Cuite
description: Amid the stacks of official reports, memorandums and reams of material on city budgets in Thomas J. Cuite's City Hall office, there is a dogeared cardboard map.

title: Nuts before dessert
description: There are more ways with vegetables than one might suspect from a look at the average dinner table, whether it's set for family or for guests. One tastyand healthyvariation on the vegetable scene is the pairing of such standbys as green beans and cauli flower with seeds and nuts. The recipes below call for sunflower kernels and pumpkin seeds, both staples at the healthfood stores, as well as the more familiar almonds and pignolia nuts.

title: Television
description: TELEVISION, conserva tively speaking, is at least 90 per cent trash. Most people, outside and inside the Industry, will readily, almost eagerly, ad mit that much. But most peo ple will hesitate to admit that precisely the same can be said about theater, films re cordings, books and, yes, even newspapers.

title: National Notes
description: When Robert Sirilla was arrested in Minnesota a year ago, police were sure he had marijuana on him, so they con ducted a most thorough search. In the lining of his coat, their vacuum cleaner picked up 1/2800th of an ounce of a sub stance that was identified under a microscope as marijuana. Sirilla was convicted and sen tenced to an indeterminate, 20 year maximum sentence for pos session. He's out on probation now, but the Supreme Court has upheld his conviction.

title: Foreign Notes
description: David BenGurion is 84. He lives in the kibbutz of Sde Boker in the Negev desert, devoting his still considerable energy to the problem of irrigation and having little to say publicly of a politi cal nature. But that Israel's first Prime Minister still follows polit ical events closely was made clear last week on the release of an interview with author John McCook Roots to appear in this week's issue of The Saturday Re view. Regarded at one time as the most hawkish of Israel's leaders visvis the Arabs, Mr. BenGurion was reported to have taken a position that, in the present political context, placed him among Israel's foremost doves:

title: Dam Almost Completed in Laos Jungle
description: NAMNGUM, Laos March 27 (AP)Not all the news from Laos is warlike. Work on giant hydroelectric plant deep in the jungle is on schedule and nearing completion.

title: South Africa Executions Drop
description: CAPETOWN, March 27 Eighty people were hanged in South Africa in the year ending June 30. 1970, compared with 117 people in the yearearlier period, the Government dis closed.

title: Museum in Brooklyn to Double Number of Free Jazz Concerts
description: April is, officially, Jazz Month in New York City, so the normal monthly schedule of free jazz will be almost doubled at MUSE, the Bedford Lincoln Neighborhood Museum operated by the Brooklyn Chil dren's Museum.

title: Foe Blocks Cambodian Road
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 27 (Reuters)  The North Vietnamese have oc cupied a 10mile stretch of Route 4 linking Pnompenh with Cambodia's only deep water port of Kompong Som, the high command said today.

title: Art
description: THE news of the Edward Hopper bequest to the Whitney Museum of American Art is, like a great deal that passes for good news these days, not quite as good as it sounds at first hearing. At the very least, there is something disturbing in the way this extraordinary donation is going to be dealt with. We all know that art museums are changing, and the as sumption is often madethough not, to be sure, by the present writerthat they are changing in all ways for the better. But consider the implications of this affair.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: 4 on Faculty are Promoted At Downtown Medical Unit
description: Four faculty members at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn have been promoted to full professorships in the College of Medicine.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Benvenuti Says He'll Quit If Monzon Wins Rematch
description: TRIESTE, Italy, March 27 (UPI) Nino Benvenuti said today his May 8 return match with Carlos Monzon of Argentina for the world middleweight title would determine whether he quits boxing.

title: TUNA WAR NETS SOVIET DIPLOMAT
description: QUITO, Ecuador, March 23 The Soviet Ambassador to Ec uador, seeking to capitalize on the current chill in relations be tween Ecuador and the United States, brought on by the dis pute over offshore sovereignty, has inadvertently provoked strong criticism of himself from the local press.

title: South Bronx End Zone
description: Around the issue of future housing for a pro football team, the New York Giants swirl opinions, designs and goals that concern a new race track for New Jersey; the economic deterioration of the south Bronx; an arti ficial playing surface for Shea Stadium and the con tinued existence here of baseball team, the Yankees.

title: Funds Freed for Chicago
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)  More than $61million in frozen Federal funds is being released for the construction of Chicago's second Federal build ing, Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, has an nounced. The building will be constructed on the substructure completed in June, 1968, and will contain a post office and more than two million square feet of office space now leased by Federal agencies in scattered leased space round the city.

title: DEMOCRATS SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI)Senator Robert J. Dole of Kansas, the Republican Na tional Chairman, said today that the peace movement was led by politicians who pander to the warweariness of the American people.

title: 31 Never Bow Aqueduct Victor
description: Never Bow returned the sum of $35,580 to his new owner, Sigmund Sommer, in winning the Westchester at Aqueduct yesterday. Purchased only last Thursday from the Hobeau Farm, Never Bow increased his career earnings to $251,762 in beating 10 rivals in the one mile event.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe nation's mayors, it seems, turn out to be losers no matter what they do. For at least a decade, they have been trying without much suc cess to impress their plight of declining revenues and increas ing problems on the national conscience. Now their troubles have grown much worsesome of the great cities are in acute distress  but the mayors have lost political power to the grow ing suburbs, and to many their cries of alarm are not new, sim ply more shrill.

title: Magazine, yesanthology, no
description: Disassembling a mythdike de stroying any refugeis painful for everybody. Those who have used it are forced to live dangerously, pro tected loosely and only by skin. Those who have never needed it themselves miss its familiar place in the minds of those who did. Those who would destroy it are frequently trapped in the rubble of their destruction.

title: Coins
description: NUMISMATIC books are essential for experi enced collectors, who need them to keep pace with the many changes taking place in the money field, but reading (before buying) is even more im portant for the starting col lector, whether his chosen category be coins, paper monies, medals or tokens.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: GOVERNORS SEEK WIDER PARTY ROLE
description: ST. LOUIS, March 27The Democratic Governors, their ranks strengthened by the elec tions last fall, moved today to win a stronger voice in the direction of their party and in determining its positions on issues affecting their states.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: 127 Trotters Eligible
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 27 (UPI)The United States Trot ting Association announced to day a record 127 3yearold trotters were still eligible for the $131,770 Hambletonlan set for Sept. 1 at Du Quoin, Ill.

title: The World
description: BELFAST  On June 22, 1921, King George V rode through the cheering streets of Belfast to open the first Parliament of Northern Ire land. Britain had partitioned Ireland to placate the Prot estants of Belfast who feared the Roman Catholic south, and the first Prime Minis ter blithely called the new Legislature a Protestant Parliament for a Protestant people.

title: Newcombe, Ashe Advance To Final in $50,000 Tennis
description: EVANSTON, Ill., March 27 combo of Australia anr second seeded Arthur Ashe of Rich mond moved into the singles final in the. $50,000 Sportface tennis tournament tonight.

title: Leave Dock in Reverse
description: If you attempt to pull away from a dock in forward gear, your stern may bump against the dock. Instead back away slowly from the dock and shift to forward only when you're well clear.

title: Barbara Blank, H. W. Danser 3d To Be Married
description: SUMMIT, N.J., March 27 Miss Barbara Lane Blank, ?? systems analyst with the Mo bil Oil Corporation in New York, plans to be married there in June at St. Bar tholomew's Episcopal Church to Harold Wesley Denser 3d, also of New York. He is an assistant business and plan ning manager with Time Inc.

title: Boston Unit Gets Health Aid
description: BOSTON, March 27 (AP) Action for Boston Community Development, a social service agency, has been awarded a $1,479,088 grant by the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity for a comprehensive health service program, Senator Ed ward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, announced Wed nesday.

title: Jersey Legislature to Investigate Cable TV Awards
description: TRENTON, March 27A spe cial legislative investigation of the rapidly expanding cable television industry in New Jersey was announced this weekend following the indict ment Thursday of four present and former Trenton city offi cials on charges of extorting $50,000 in return for awarding an exclusive cable television franchise here in 1968.

title: The Return Of Stalin's Mustache On a Higher Level
description: IF the majority of the present Polit buro of the Soviet Communist party have their way, the 24th party Congress, due to open at the end of this month, may be outwardly even less dramatic than the last one, five years ago. This would not, of course, be due to an absence of policy conflicts, but to the peculiar manner in which the present collec tive leadership prefers to handle them. Scarred by the sudden and vio lent turns of the general line under Stalin and scared of their return, and irritated beyond endurance by the less violent, but equally brusque, improvisations of Nikita Khrushchev, these aging men are committed to maintaining a maximum of personal continuity in the ruling oligarchy and therefore at least the appearance of a similar continuity of policy. In fact, it is this very style of collec tivity and continuity, this deliberate avoidance of dramatic public con frontations and announcements of change, that has been their most re markable political innovation.

title: Sally Hubbard Becomes Bride Of James Cronk
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., March 27Miss Sally Margaret Hub bard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Alford Hubbard of Brookville and Londonderry, Vt., was married at her home here this afternoon to James Montgomery Cronk. The Rev. Charles Robert Harrah, minis ter of the Brookville Re formed Church, performed the ceremony.

title: Tubridy Makes Song Debut
description: Martin Tubridy, a New York bassbaritone, made his local debut in Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night with Mitchell Andrews at the piano. His per formance of two Purcell songs and Schumann's Liederkreis cycle was not up to profes sional standards, lacking tonal steadiness and adequate phras ing. He also sang works by Faur, Poldowski and Brahms and several folk songs.R.E.

title: Yacht Design Can Be Taught by Mail
description: In an age of such highly technical sciences as aero nautics and astronautics, the average man may be forgiven for harboring the assumption that technicians in the engi neeringdesign fields must be graduates of M.I.T., Cali fornia Tech or Carnegie In stitute.

title: Music
description: THE current series or Handel Society opera performances  Ari odante will be given tomorrow in Carnegie Hall and such presentations as the Clarion Concerts Olim piade by Hasse the other week once again bring atten tion to a problem involving baroque opera. There is at least one reason (among many others) why it is im possible to duplicate this kind of opera as it was done in the 18th century, and that is the disappearance of the singing machine for which many roles were created. I refer, of course, to the cas tratos. These evirati were, technically, the greatest singers who ever lived, these unfortunates with the lungs of a man and the voice of a woman.

title: Work List Of Priority Is Advised
description: At this time of year, many experienced boatmen are seen with pencils and notebooks listing things that need to be done on their boats and mo tors to get them ready for quick and easy launching on the first warm day.

title: FLORIDIANS HAND NETS 118104 LOSS
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 27 (AP)Larry Jones's final quarter shooting helped stave off a New York Net rally to night and give the Floridians a 118104 victory that increased their chances for an American Basketball Association East Division playoff berth.

title: Pro Basketball Draft: Agents Are Outnumbering the Prospects
description: When there was only one professional basketball league, the annual college draft followed a predictable pat tern. National Basketball As sociation scouts logged more than a million miles, seeking out players from big and little schools. On the scouts' recommendations, the teams drafted forwards, backcourt men and centers, who, hope fully, could cure their prob lems, and sometimes make winners out of losers.

title: Leagues Reported Close To a Merger Agreement
description: About Pro Basketball

title: Court Blocks Libel Suit Against Loeb, Publisher
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)A Federal judge has dis missed a libel suit brought by William Loeb, publisher of The Manchester, (N. H.) Union Leader against John Herling, a syndicated columnist.

title: Interior Department Urges End of Park Group Ticket
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)The Interior Department, reportedly under pressure by the Office of Management and Budget, has recommended re placing the Golden Eagle group ticket to national parks with a potentially more expensive sys tem of individual fees.

title: Exterminating the Whale
description: Secretary of Commerce Stans has laudably ordered an end to American participation in the tragic destruction of whales. These great mammals have become an increas ingly endangered species since the invention of the cannonfired harpoon which has an explosive tip that detonates inside the whale's body, guaranteeing a kill, often with excruciating agony to the victim. These lethal harpoons have removed all risk and romance and have transformed what was once an adventurous trade into commercial butchery.

title: Photography
description: ANEW, fully automatic 35mm single lens re flex camera with focal plane shutter and throughthelens metering has just been introduced by Pon der & Best, 11201 W. Pico Boulevard, Los Angeles, Calif. 90064. Called the Mamiya/ Sekor Auto XTL, this new model uses a CdS cell that includes both spot and aver age metering systems, and that automatically sets the aperture opening with either setting when the user sets the shutter speed.

title: Should We Have War Crime Trials?
description: The Book Review received the ac companying bibliography from Mr. Mark Sacharoff, assistant professor of English at Temple University, and sent the books to Neil Sheehan for review.

title: FIGHTING IN JORDAN REPORTED BY FATAH
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 27 (Reuters)An Al Fatah spokes man said here tonight that Jordanian troops had entered a refugee camp in the northern Jordanian town of Irbid and that there was fierce fighting.

title: SWEDISH UNIT ENDS U.N. WORK IN PERU
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. V., March 27A Swedish colonel has reported here on comple tion of a sixmonth Swedish Army peace mission in Peru that helped repair earthquake damage.

title: APRIL 15 IN BRAZIL IS TAX TIME, TOO
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 2  Income tax used to be a laughing matter in Brazil, but after four years of tax reform that have awakened the indo lent and frightened the evader, the days leading to April 15 have become serious for Brazil ian taxpayers, too.

title: First Ladies Honored
description: The White House Historical Association is sponsoring its first series of medals, an issue in honor of the 40 women who have served as First Ladies since the inauguration of George Wash ington.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, March 27This is the strangest thing. Who would have thought that it could have happened here? To us. Or, to be completely accurate about it, to the people who used to be us. If you want to be strict ly technical about it, I suppose we are now somebody different from those people we were. If, indeed, we can be said to be people at all . . . Ah, how inexpressible it all is . . . Perhaps one started at the beginning.

title: Baby Boom in Britain Linked to Pill Warnings
description: LONDON, March 27 (AP) Warnings against possible health hazards of the con traceptive pill led to a sharp increase in Britain's birth rate in the last two months of 1970, medical experts have reported today.

title: Et Al.
description: Practical directions to bus inessmen about complying with Equal Employment Opportunity legislation. The author sees these laws as benign, a practi cal, dollarwise, attempt to ex tend the use of our human resources, and offers guidelines to businessmen for setting up their own programs.

title: G.M. Trainee
description: ANDERSON, Ind. (AP) Dennis Ray Allen agrees with Vice President Agnew at least half the time, President Nixon most of the time and the president of General Mo tors all the time.

title: AMOR ARTIS SINGS BACH AND HAYDN
description: One of the best things that has come to music performance in the last quarter century has been the development of the small chorus as an instrument of superior musical quality.

title: Britain Hunting Gang In $1.Million Robbery
description: LONDON, March 27 (Reu ters)The British police to day searched for the armed gang that ambushed and robbed an armored security truck in a London suburb of nearly $1.1million yesterday.

title: L.I. Man Is a Farmer  of Butterflies
description: NORTHPORT, L. I., March 27  When August Schmitt moved here in 1940, it was wild and woollylike jungle, and he was able to stock his farm with speci mens caught in the field. Now, with the encroachment of suburbia, the open spaces are becoming closed and chemicals have become a threat.

title: Television
description: IT'S a nifty assignment, standing in the makeup room of the videotape studio used by NET for its weekly Great American Dream Machine, watching the aquamarine gunk (Bill Blass's Peel Off Pick Up Face Mask, $7.50) being applied all over Marshall Efron's face for his segment on male cosmetics. The makeup girl is really rubbing it around; kneading the stuff in, while Efron's producer, Penny Bern stein, goes over the moves he'll have to make for the cameras  lifting this tube, putting that jar aside, all the little stuff. Very professional. Efron sits in the barber chair like some sort of weird oil sheik receiving lesser digni taries. He is short (5 feet 5 inches) and very heavyhow heavy he won't say precisely. Just write that I'm sub stantially more than 206 pounds, he 206 is fighting weight.

title: Foreign Notes
description: When Soviet planners designed Did new city of Tchaikovsky decade ago, they thought they had taken care of everything. The economic basis of the indus trial community in the western Urals was to be provided by two giant plants. One, a silk mill, was to have mainly female workers. The other, a synthetic rubber complex, was to have mainly male workers.

title: Suicide Clinic is seeking to serve Youths
description: A suicide prevention clinic designed primarily to save the Lives of young people has begun operating here.

title: What Is Native American?
description: AMERICAN art history, in recent years; has been feeling the effects of something rather like a minor earthquake. The ini tial impact came with the Abstract Expressionists who achieved international fame and status in the midfifties. American artists no longer had to think of themselves as the colonials of the Europ ean tradition. American art, itself, began to appear a good deal less provincial than it once had seemed.

title: Randall Thompson Jr. Marries Miss Delia M C. Hayes in Rome
description: Miss Delia M. C. Hayes and Randall Thompson Jr. were married in Rome yester day afternoon in the chapel of the Villa Aurelia, once used for defense by Giuseppe Garibaldi, the Italian patriot and soldier. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Wilbur C. Woodhams of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Rome, followed a civil one performed earlier in Rome's City Hall.

title: Thyra Elizabeth Reed Is Engaged
description: Miss Thyra Elizabeth Reed and William M. Bramwell Jr., a senior counsel of the Inter national Telephone and Tele graph Corporation, at its world headquarters here, have announced their own engagement and plans for a May 22 wedding.

title: Pennsylvania Is Pressing Blue Cross to Curb Costs
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 27 Blue Cross executives and hos pital officials here have been jolted by a rapid succession of orders from a new, consumer oriented state insurance com missioner.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Shellfish From L.I. Thrive In West Indies Experiment
description: ST. CROIX, V.I., March 25 In a pioneering effort to exploit what has been called the world's most abundant resource the deep, cold, nutrientrich water found in certain parts of the oceansoysters and clams from Long Island Sound are being grown here in the sub tropical Virgin Islands.

title: Littering, Noise Bane Of Boating
description: There was a time, and not so very long ago, when yachting and good manners went together like eggs and ham.

title: Fordham Crew Is Victor In Race for Deering Cup
description: In weather that seemed more appropriate for iceboating, Fordham University's eight oared shell won the second annual Deering Cup yesterday over the 2,000meter course at the Orchard Beach Lagoon in the Bronx.

title: JEWISH CONGRESS FIGHTS SCHOOL AID
description: BOSTON, March 27The American Jewish Congress will start a nationwide drive of legal action and public infor mation to oppose growing pres sures for public funding of pri vate and parochial schools.

title: Chamberlain, N.I.T.'s Most Valuable Player, Called Unselfish Teammate
description: After North Carolina's bas ketball team destroyed Georgia Tech for the second time this season and won the National Invitation Tournament yester day, a proud Martin Chamber lain stood in a corridor at Madi son Square Garden talking about his son, Bill, the tourna ment's most valuable player.

title: John Wessler Fiance Of Ferdi A. Hurwitz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Hur witz of Brooklyn have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ferdi Anne Hurwitz, to John Stan ford Wessler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanford Wessler of St. Louis. The wedding is planned for June 29 at the home of the prospective bride's aunt, Mrs. Ned Curley, in South Orange, N. J.

title: The Cheapest, Slowest And Most Hip Way To Fly the Atlantic
description: REYIKJAVIK, Iceland  Pianist Glenn Gould, who has great res ervations about many things including the value of fresh air and the orthodox way to play Beethoven concertosonce remarked that he could only travel in propellerdriven aircraft because he could not tell by looking out the window of a jet whether the en gines were working or not. In addition to proving Mr. Gould rather funny, this reservation of his also indicates that if he contemplates flying to Europe be tween now and next December, he will go via Icelandic Airlines, the only sched uled passenger carrier on the North Atlantic still using some prop planes.

title: Demands for Day Care Rising Among the Affluent
description: ITHACA, N.Y. It used to be the view that only people in trouble or people neglecting their children wanted day care, according to Dr. Urie Bronfenbrenner, professor of psychology atid child develop ment at Cornell University. Now there is recognition that the need for day care is real and does not imply moral de ficiency in parents, or that the parents don't really care about their children.

title: Diverse Elements Unified by Dancers In a Winning Ballet
description: At one time it might have seemed incongruous to think that a unified dance could be constructed out of such diverse elements as two utterly charm ing little boys laughing and running, the prose from official notices and a cow bell, but Laura Foreman included all in her winning Signals II It was given on a program Friday night by the Choreoconcerts Repertory Company presented at the Washington Square Methodist Church in the WBAI Free Music Store Spring series.

title: National Notes
description: A twoyear extension of the draft was voted by the House Armed Services Committee last weekbut with a twist. Also approved was an increase in pay and allowances, nearly doubling the present scale, in the hope that such a raise would attract volunteers in suf ficient number to eliminate the draft before the two years are up. The chart above shows why an unskilled worker might choose to leave private industry for an Army career. President Nixon has said that he would like to end draft calls by July 1, 1973, and, as a first step, has called for a $987million increase in military pay and allowances. The committee nearly tripled this figure, to $2,687,000,000. However, F. Edward Hebert, the committee chairman, ex pressed some doubt about the idea. He said he still thought there was no way to get volunteer armyunless they draft it.

title: Brewers Rout Indians, 90
description: TEMPE, Ariz., March 27 (UPI)Rick Auerbach hit an inside the  park grand  slam homer and Marty Pattin yield ed five hits in seven innings today as the Milwaukee Brew ers whipped the Cleveland In dians, 90, in a Cactus League preseason game.

title: L.I. Highway Improvements to End Bottlenecks Await New Funds
description: Although some planning of ficials have predicted dire con sequences for Long Island un less emphasis is transferred from automobiles to mass transportation, even they agree that more highway improve ments are needed to, correct ex isting bottlenecks.

title: Sport of The Times
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 27 Fritz., Peterson was taking no chances, not even with the location of his hotel room. It was no time for tempting fate or risking a whammy. The Yankees were in Boston to finish their season last year and the most nervous of them was Peterson, because he had the most tantalizing of all pitching objectives allmost Within reach.

title: Oklahoma State Captures Its 27th National Collegiate Wrestling Crown
description: AUBURN, Ala., March 27 (AP) Oklahoma State's Keller twins broke even in a pair of Major upsets tonight as the Cowboys raced to their 27th National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling cham pionship.

title: American Rows for Cambridge In 10Length Defeat of Oxford
description: LONDON, March 27 (AP) Somerset Waters, a 23yearold economics student from Rye, N. Y., pulled the No. 7 oar for the Cambridge University eight in a crushing 10length victory over Oxford University today in the 117th race in the series.

title: FLORIDA MIGRANTS GET FEDERAL HELP
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., March 27 Thousands of jobless migrant workers here, ordered included Under the concept Of disaster relief by President Nixon, this week began receiving Federal unemployment compensation checks and food stamps.

title: Education
description: The grade equivalency tests by which American schools almost universally as sess children's classroom per formance in general, and their reading proficiency in particular, are so much a part of the warp and woof of American education that they are often taken for granted.

title: Generous Portion Rallies To Gain Dead Heat on Coast
description: ALBANY, Calif., March 27 (UPI)Generous Portion and Aladancer matched strides over the final half of the stretch and finished in a dead heat in the 21st running of the $30.000 added California Oaks at Golden Gate Fields today.

title: Connecticut Makes Bid For Trade
description: A guide to Connecticut marinas is being distributed free to outofstate boatmen by the Connecticut Develop ment Commission. The direc tory lists 185 marinas and 65 yacht clubs on the state's many lakes and rivers and on the Connecticut shoreline of Long Island Sound.

title: Pink and fading, in watermelon ink
description: One way of receiving Richard Brau tigan's new book is disarmingly sug gested by the novel itself: there ought to be somebody in clothes of welcome on duty all the time to accept and register everything that anybody wants or has to write. Log it in, describe it briefly, let the author put it on the shelf of his choice, on no account catalog it, and give the re lieved creator coffee and a cookie. Human rights for books!

title: National Notes
description: When the Nixon Administra tion last year asked the Senate to approve the 1925 Geneva pro tocol banning chemical and bio logical warfare, it was generally assumed that after 45 years the United States would finally get around to ratifying one of the original arms control measures of the 20th century. But now the treaty seems to be in trouble in the Senate.

title: Mayer Wins Twice, Gains RoundRobin Tennis Final
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., March 27 (UPI)Sandy Mayer of Woodmere, L. I., the East's top ranked junior, moved into the $5,000 Long Island champion ship tennis final by beating Antonio Palafox and Joaquin LoyoMayo of Mexico today.

title: Rogers, in Policy Report, Sees Preoccupation With Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 Secretary of State William P. Rogers told Congress today that the United States' national preoccupation with Vietnam has preempted our attention from other areas of concern in the world.

title: Jersey Bill Would Double the Cost of Boat Registration
description: If Assembly Bill 1159 be comes law in New Jersey, that state's boatmen and ma rine dealers will be unhappy'The bill, now before the state Senate, would more than double the cost of registering a boat.

title: Erosion Is Feared In Horseshoe Falls Because of Notch
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., March 27  A member of Cor nell University's Department of Geological Sciences said this week that a 110footwide notch in the lip of the Horse shoe Falls here might mean that rock collapses at the cataract could occur soon.

title: Allende, in Interview, Bars Any Base Imperiling U.S.
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 27  President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile has declared in an interview that his Govern ment will never permit the con struction of a foreign military base here that might he used against the United States.

title: Laotian Troops Retreat
description: LUANG PRABANG, Laos, March 27(AP)Government sol diers retreated to the outskirts of Luang Prabang today as enemy forces continued their advance on the royal Laotian capital 130 miles north of Vientiane. Attacking troops were reported as close as four miles to the city.

title: FASHIONS FOR FREE SPIRITS
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A species of virocracy, not a kleptocracy
description: This strangelytitled book  are the politics, the politicians, or is Haiti itself the butt?  was execut ed by two professors, one a political scientist and historian, the other an economist, charged with interpreting the development of the New World's second independent nation. Five re search assistants and two translators were employed; colloquia on relevant issues were held; 13 authorities read parts of the manuscript indraft; a severely selective bibliography in eludes nearly 500 references, and the text is rich in charts and tables. Yet the resulting work is disappointing, a mosaic constructed rather than written.

title: STEWART KEEPS POLE AT ONTARIO
description: ONTARIO, Calif., March 27 Jackie Stewart, world driving champion of 1969, easily stood off all challenges today to clinch the pole position for to morrow's running of the $278, 400 Questor Grand Prix. The nonchalant Scot felt so secure that he casually parked his own TyrellFord and, as a courtesy to a competitor and friend, tested A. J. Foyt's car.

title: Even by Palm Beach Standards, Their Home Is a Showplace
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.When Alvan T. Fuller Jr. and Lilly Glasser Crichton were mar ried, they had more than their share of residences.

title: Gateway Recreation Area Will Get Senate Hearings
description: NEWARK, March 27 (UPI) United States Senator Henry M. Jackson announced yester day that the Senate Interior Committee, of which he is chairman, would hold hearings on May 12 on legislation to es tablish the Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: Suppression in Pakistan Deplored by Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, March 27 (Reuters)Prime Minister In dira Gandhi today described the military imposition of mar tial law in East Pakistan as not merely suppression of a movement, but meeting un armed people with tanks.

title: CITY PUSHES BUS ON INVESTIGATIONS
description: ALBANY, March 27  Two New York City investigative agencies  the Department of Investigation and the Knapp Commission  are seeking passage of bills here that would give them a powerful investiga tive tool, the permission to grant immunity from prosecu tion to witnesses who appear before them.

title: Stamps
description: CARE, the Cooperative for American Relief Every where, and the United States space program provide the impetus for two additional commemorative stamps this year.

title: CANADIENS DOWN RED WINGS. BY 92
description: MONTREAL, March 27 (UPI) Two goals each by Pete Ma hovlich and Jean Beliveau paced the Montreal Canadiens to a 9.2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: The Border Wardens
description: A history of the U. S. Border Patrol along the Mexican line. The mission began as a one man effort to halt illegal Chi nese immigration but soon ex panded in its efforts to round up wetbacks and now, of course, to control drug traffic. There are many stories of bor der derringdo. The prose is as windy as the big outdoors; but, in his descriptions of the ex ploitation of braceros and pres sures applied to the Patrol by greedy growers, Mr. Myers does service.

title: Can We Give Up the Theater?
description: THE American theater? In 1971? Who cares? Broadway has long been ex isting on a diet of Neil Simon tran quilizers, musical anodynes, and an occasional pep pill from London, and Off Broadway is not offering much more in the way of stimulation these days. Most of the performance groups seem to be dividing, reorganizing, or disintegrating, while the theatrical avantgarde is boring us all to death with its arrogance, lunatic innovation, revdlutionary posturing, and mediacon scious provocations. Black theater has just about exhausted the audience's tol erance for racial insult and honkey baiting. Nudity has grown tedious, audi ence participation is a bust, and Lincoln Center . . . well, Lincoln Center. The American theater is presently without a major playwright, or even somebody claiming to be one, while most of its more talented actors and directors (not to mention its audiences) have deserted it for the movies. Who in his right mind would still be concerned about a form in such imminent danger of collapse?

title: FLATTOP'S ROLE STIRS CONFLICT
description: The aircraft carrier, for 30 years the United States Navy's queen of battles, is the focus of discussion in the Navy and in Congress with its effective ness, vulnerability and mount ing cost an issue.

title: BROOKLYN LIBRARY IS CUTTING HOURS
description: The job freeze ordered last October by Mayor Lindsay is forcing the Brooklyn Public Li brary to reduce the hours for 32 of its branches starting April 5.

title: U. S.Raised Barriers Cut Sales To Red Bloc
description: VIENNAsixty American companies and half a dozen of the largest American banks are set up here to do business with Communist countries, but their efforts are often frustrated by ex port clearance delays in Washington and foot drag ging at home headquarters.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Beyond the familiar and unending attentions of un counted anglers who faith fally line stream banks, piers, breakwaters, beaches, gun wales and afterdecks, there remain widely scattered hands whose livelihood is still hauled from waters in and around the United States.

title: Reader's Report
description: The people who are about in the world today don't have feelings that in any way re semble mine, thinks Arabella, who is 30 on her driver's li cense and 13 in her emotional development. I must learn to be casual and learn fast . . . by two o'clock. Two o'clock is when her married lover is com ing to lead her further into limbo. And, of course, Miss Tonks's heroine cannot learn to be casual with him any more than with her widowed father, for whom she is a gilded slavey, and with her younger with whom she is in love.

title: Two Movie Theaters Opened in Brooklyn Heights
description: Brooklyn Heights, which has been without a neighborhood movie house for nearly eight years, now has two.

title: Clam Fleet on Ecology Reef
description: WESTHAMPTON, L. I.  Lo, the vanishing clam digger.

title: Tenants Fight Surf side Park Rent Rise
description: You'll be driving some of the best people out of the city if you approve this, City Coun cilman Walter Ward, Democrat of Howard Beach, told the Board of Estimate last week as it grappled with a rent increase issue.

title: Movies
description: CHARLTON HESTON, who recently starred as Mark Antony in Julius Caesar, will soon be back wit?? the Ba??d. Once again, he'll be playing Antony, but this time it'll be Antony and Cleopatra. And, for the first time, Heston will also direct. His cast will include Hildegard Neil, of the Royal Shakespeare Company, as Cleo patra, John Castle as Caesar, and Eric Porter as Enobarbus. Peter Snell will produce the film, which begins rehear sals in London in May. The actual shooting will be done in Spain.

title: Black Swan Joins Listing of Marinas
description: Yachtsmen in the New YorktoMaine corridor seek ing a home port within min utes from the open water cruising area of eastern Long Island Sound can now plot a new marina and yacht club on Chart 1212.

title: The Romance Of Roses
description: THE most extraordinary thing about roses is the enormous variety available. Those of us who are cas ual rose growers, and who restrict ourselves to the annual spring catalogues, are only looking through a crack in the door of the total rose picture.

title: Medicine
description: The shortage of physicians in Americaa deficit often estima ted at 50,000is felt virtually throughout the nation, but most keenly in urban slums and thinly settled rural areas. The prob lem is not new; and pressures for a quick solution have in re cent years concentrated on the creation of a new group of health workersphysician's assistants or associateswho could take over the more routine medical duties.

title: Tops in Tomatoes
description: GREAT things have been happening in the to mato world as hybrid ists search for better tasting, more disease resist ant varieties. Some of the biggest strides have been taken tat the New York State Agricultural Experiment Sta tion in Geneva, N. Y.

title: Pakistan Protests to India
description: NEW DELHI, March 27 Pakistan protested to India to day against what she called India's interference in her internal affairs. The protest said that Indian news reports on East Pakistani developments had been exaggerated and designed to malign Pakistan.

title: '70 TAX REFUNDS FROM ALBANY LAG
description: ALBANY, March 27State incometax refunds to taxpay ers Vito claimed overpayments on their 1970 state tax re turns are rimming more than $40million behind the rate for last year.

title: Europe Offers Sport for All Seasons
description: The Great Escape. Europe's grand hotels. Summer skiing in the Alps. Tennis in St. Moritz. Sailing on Lac de Tignes. Skindiving in Italy.

title: Scofflaws Costing the Cities Millions of Dollars
description: The nation's cities are being shortchanged when it comes to collecting fines from thousands of motorists who have gotten traffic tickets.

title: HEALTH WARNING ON LIQUOR KILLED
description: AUGUSTA, Me., March 27 The Legislature has killed a proposal that would have re quired the posting of health hazard warnings on liquor bot tles sold in state liquor stores.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: GIBBON ALLOWS CLOUT IN RELIEF
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 27 (UPI)Byron Browne led off the ninth with a home run over the rightfield wall today to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 43 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in a preseason game.

title: Youth in FlagLike Shirt Freed by Florida Court
description: MIAMI, March 27 (UPI) Joseph Paul Forrester, 17 years old, the Cleveland youth who was jailed for appearing in Mu nicipal Court wearing a shirt with an American flag pattern, won his freedom Thursday.

title: Pincay's Mounts on Coast Top $1Million in Earnings
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 27 (UPI)Earnings of the mounts ridden by Laffit Pincay Jr., the leading rider at Santa Anita, passed the $1million mark to day when he won the fifth race with Harbor Point.

title: Army Expels 35 Foreign Newsmen From Pakistan
description: Military authorities expelled 35 foreign newsmen from East Pakistan yesterday after con fining them to a hotel in North Dacca for more than 48 hours.

title: Latin Fiasco
description: BUENOS AIRES  Calle Florida, once the center of fashion in South America, has been converted into a manmade swamp and retail er's nightmare in less than three months through a series of bureaucratic blunders.

title: DOUBLE CREAM, 301, WINS AT DONCASTER
description: DONCASTER, England, March 27 (AP)  A 301 shot, Double Cream, charged to a Lincoln Handicap victory in the final yards today, enabling 13 hold ers of Irish Sweepstakes tickets to win $120,000 each. The vic tory earned $15,686 for Double Cream's owner, R. F. Dennis.

title: Hawks Beat Flyers, 31
description: CHICAGO, March 27 (UPI) Pit Martin scored his 20th goal of the season tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 31 victory over the Philadel phia Flyers.

title: A Williamsburg That's Really Lived In
description: HARRISVILLE, N.H.The moun tainside road that leads from State Route 101 to this small village in southwestern New Hampshire is lined with pine, white birch and outcroppings of stern gray rock. After eight miles of it, you come to a town that may be unlike any other left in New England or perhaps any where else in the country.

title: Russians Said to Arrest Group Protesting Detention of 20 Jews
description: MOSCOW, March 27Jew ish sources reported today that the authorities had de tained a group of people deliv ering a petition on behalf of some 20 Jews awaiting trial in three cities on charges of anti Soviet activity.

title: Sandra S. Thornhill Plans
description: WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., March 27Miss Sandra Su sanne Thornhill, a senior at Vassar College, plans to be married June 12 in Edgar town to Thomas Marshall Brushart, a Harvard College senior.

title: Recordings
description: WHERE Life ends, the aging Wagner once wrote to a friend, Art be gins. In youth we turn to Art, we know not why; and only when we have gone through Art and come out the other side, we learn to our cost that we have missed Life itself. Wagner was not the first artist to be troubled about an apparent divorce between life and art, and not the last. Hans Werner Henze seems to have faced just such a di lemma, and to have thrown in with those who believe that an artist must try to be useful in his time, and let art take care of itself. Several years ago, Henze turned his back on a safe career that had been built on 19thcen tury ideals of opera and sym phonic music, and broke out aswell, some would say as an artist determined to find a place in his time; others would say as a Marxist prop agandist.

title: Marriage Held For Elsie Smith
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., March 27The marriage of Miss Elsie Stimson Smith to William Coffman Utter of Menlo Park, Calif., took place this afternoon at the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Everett Post, stepfather and mother of the bride.

title: PETRAGLIA WINS CARTER BOWLING
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 27 (AP)Johnny Petraglia, a 24 yearold left hander from Brooklyn, captured the $60,000 Don Carter Bowling Classic here today and became the first backtoback victor of the Professional Bowling Associa tion's winter tour.

title: For parent effectiveness onthejob training
description: ONE cold evening this winter I found myself crossing the George Washington Bridge in a micro bus with two other mothers bound for a Parent Effective ness Training class in Leonia, N. J.

title: IN THE NATION
description: JACKSON, Miss., March 26A new brick wall has gone up around the Governor's mansion here since the shootings last spring at Jackson State. Once it would have been typical, but that kind of fortification now seems to be against the trend in the South.

title: Miss Diane Lynn Rothman Is Engaged
description: Miss Diane Lynn Rothman, who is working for a master's degree at the New York Uni versity Institute of Fine Arts, plans to be married May 31 to Alan Steven Rosenthal, en gineering manager for the Compat Corporation of West bury, L. I., a computer pro graming company. The cere mony will be at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, where the future bridegroom is a member of the executive board.

title: BillPaying TimeMore Couples Now Are Facing It Together
description: Twice a month, sometimes on a Saturday, sometimes on a Sunday, Thomas Coonerty, an advertising execu tive, goes through a routine that starts when he lays out all his bills on the dining room table in his 10room colonial house in West Islip, L. I.

title: Dance
description: THE City Center Joffrey Ballet today ends its season at the New York City Center. It has given four premieres during the six weeks and, incidentally, if you go to both the matinee and the evening performance today you still can catch all four.

title: Foreign Minister Duties In China Filled by Aide
description: PEKING, March 27 (Agence FrancePresse) functions of Chinese Foreign Minister are currently being filled by Deputy Foreign Minister Chi Pengfei.

title: S. L. Senigo Weds Andrea Korothy
description: Miss Andrea Holly Korothy of New York was married, here yesterday afternoon to Stephen Lee Senigo in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd at the General Theological Seminary.

title: Administration Drafts New Bill That Would Give More Land to Alaska Natives
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 The Administration has liberal ized its proposals to settle the centuryold claims of Alaska's aborigines to their ancestral lands, and a new fight in Con gress appears certain.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians Will Return Hire Cars to Finland
description: Hertz has announced a new car rental service by which motorists can rent a car in Finland, drive to Lenin grad and Moscow and leave it. The car will be returned to Finland by Sovtransavto, the Soviet transportation agency.

title: South Dakota Post to Miller
description: VERMILLION, S. D., March 27 (AP)Dr. Carl Miller was named chairman today of the department of health, physical education and athletics at the University of South Dakota.

title: APARTHEID SPOOF IS A HIT IN DURBAN
description: DURBAN, South Africa, March 27 (AP)Producers of a revue spoofing apartheid have defeated the Government censors in court, and It's a Colorful World is back on the stage.

title: Ch. Alekai Luau, White Standard Poodle, Named Best in Bronx County Show
Katharine Smith Bride of Architect
description: Miss Katharine Mary Smith, an artist, and William Cha fee, chief architect of the Welfare Island Development Corporation, were married here yesterday afternoon.

title: The Nation
description: SAIGON  When South Viet namese troops moved across the border into Laos last month, many seemed nervous, but also jubilant and eager to show the North Vietnamese and the world that the pupils had learned their lessons well from teachers who were about to go home.

title: Reader's Report
