description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: David Ketcham Became Fiance Of Miss Tolles
description: SUMMIT, N. J. March 27 Miss Natalie Carleton Tolles and David Ross Ketcham Plan to be married this summer.

title: Library Plans a Concert In Forest Hills Wednesday
description: The Queens Borough Public Library will present a concert of 18th and 20thcentury music at its Vorest Hills branch on Wednesday at 8 P.M. Admis sion is free.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Proposal for HighRise Housing Is Criticized in Sheepshead Bay
description: Can the picturesque Sheeps head Bay area in Brooklyn be come a little Fishermen's Wharf along the lines of San Fran cisco's famed waterfront if new highrise housing is part of the picture?

title: GREEN TAKES 100 IN FLORIDA RELAYS
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 27 (AP)Jim Green of Ken tucky won the 100yard dash today in the Florida Relays, upsetting Ivory Crockett of Southern Illinois in the first facetoface meeting of the stellar sprinters this year.

title: Ecuador Leads in Tennis
description: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, March 27 (UPI)Ecuador took a 20 lead over Venezuela by cap turing the first two singles matches in their South Amer ican Zone Davis Cup tennis series today. Pancho Guzman defeated Jorge Andrews, 6.4, 62, 62, and Miguel Olvera beat Humphrey Hoes, 63, 61, 60.

title: Ox Ridge Hunt Club Finds Date on Crowded Calendar
description: DARIEN, CONN., March 27 The Ox Ridge Hunt Club's jun ior indoor horse show is sched uled for next Saturday, but it wasn't easy to find a date.

title: Jane O'Hara Wed to Terence Toal
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 27Miss Jane Mary O'Hara end Terence Peter Teal were married here at noon today in St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church.

title: FOE ATTACKS G.I.'S NEAR LAOS BORDER
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 27  Enemy gunners continued rocket and mortar attacks on United States troops, near the Laotian border today amid increasing signs that all major American units at this giant base would be pulled out soon.

title: David May, Store Heir, To Wed Doris Zakowski
description: Miss Doris Sabine Zakow ski and David Albert May, greatgrandson of David May, a founder of the May Depart ment Stores Company in St. Louis, plan to be married here on April 24.

title: The Nation
description: There is new desperation be hind the familiar solicitation, a new toughness in the cheerless smile. Manhattan's 2,000 street walkers need money more des perately than ever before, and are finding it ever harder to come by. The result: threats of violence on streetcorners, police crackdowns, the opening of new territories.

title: Kathe M. Boa, John S. Dyson Plan Marriage
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, March 27  Dr. and Mrs. George S. Bova have announced the en gagement of their daughter. Miss lathe Maria Bova, to John Stuart Dyson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Dyson of Scarsdale and Mill brook, N. Y.

title: The World
description: The script was so familiar that most Argentines seemed far more concerned with the beef shortage and the possible sus pension of one of the country's best soccer teams by the South American Football Federation. In fact, it was a repeat perform ance of a drama enacted only nine months earlier.

title: DELAWARE CHIEF WINS BOWIE DASH
description: BOWIE, Md., March 27 (AP) Denser Stable's Delaware Chief won the $22,000 added Vincentive Handicap in a photo finish today at Bowie Race Course.

title: U.S. SEXTET BOWS FOR 5TH TIME, 50
description: GENEVA, March 27  A revenge  hungry Czechoslovak squad proved that its first round loss to the United States was all a mistake by over whelming the American ama teurs, 50, in the opening game of the second and final round of the world ice hockey cham pionship here today.

title: Eakins Paces Squires
description: SALEM, Va., March 27 (AP) Jim Eakins tossed in a career high of 33 points and grabbed 17 rebounds tonight to spark the Virginia squires to a 137 129 victory over the Carolina Cougars.

title: When Is a Turkey Not a Turkey?
description: THE art of Norman Lear is not a subject that's likely to occupy a great deal of time at your next deep  think cocktail party, at least, not in con nection with his new filmlkm n kCold Turkey, which he wrote, directed and produced with his longtime partner, Bud Yorkin, as executive pro ducer, if Lear's name comes up at all, it will probably, be because of his C.B.S, tele vision series, All In The Family, which has been either hailed or condemned because it has a semihard hat hero named Archie, who uses words like spic, spook and polak to define his outlook on life.

title: Neighborhood Volunteers Clear Site for a Park on West Side
description: Hilda Vazquez, a young grandmother, and scores of her neighbors and friends lugged bricks, broken glass and gar bage out of a vacant lot on the West Side yesterday,hoping to shame the city to make good on a promise to build a vest pocket park on the lot.

title: Checking the PayPrice Spiral
description: No real victory can be won in the war against inflation without a curb on the breakneck pace of the wageprice spiral. The right place to begin putting on the brakes is the construction industry, not only because the leapfrog of pay and prices has been most extreme there but also because the large number of building trades workers in every major community makes their high settlements a source of envy and emulation for all other unions.

title: The Red and the Green The Divided I. R. A.
description: BELFAST. TWO men in dark raincoats creep along an alley in one of the Catholic ghettos of Belfast. One says: Joseph, let's pack up now. It's 1 o'clock in the morning, and we have to be at work at 8. The other nods, peering at the cold, damp night: Ah, well, it's beginning to rain anyhow. They move off quietly, lugging a beer crate containing what remains of their stock of gasoline bombs.

title: CITY SEEK TO GET SLUM CLEARING AID
description: The Federal Government has indicated that it may ease an embargo on money for new slum clearance in the city to al low funding in at least one urbanrenewal project here.

title: 3Way Merger Last July
description: The old Francis I. duPont & Co. joined last July 6 an ambitious threeway merger with Hirsch & Co. and Glore Forgan, William R. Staats, Inc., well known invest ment houses that realized there was a need for economies of scale to combat what seemed to be Incessantly rising costs.

title: A Little Paint, Little Wax Make Fiberglass Shipshape
description: Your boat has been stored under a canvas cover since Mast September and the win try weather has streaked the hull with mud and ice. You spot hairline crazing around the keel and you notice that the newboat sheen is missing.

title: Fixing Inflatable Is a Living Room Job
description: Your friends are at their windows, glum looks on their faces. The day is new and raw, but they know they'll just have to get out there and get those boats in shape despite numbed fingers and epoxy that won't harden.

title: Child the Feinsteins
description: A daughter was born on March 15 at Beth Israel Hos pital here to Mr. and Mrs. Roger Feinstein.

title: Pollution Post Filled
description: CINCINNATI March 27 (AP) Ira S. Latimer Jr., director of the West Virginia Depart ment of Natural Resources, has been elected vice chairman of the Ohio River Basin Commis sion as the 11state group held its first meeting here. The com mission was created to develop and protect water resources in the 11 states.

title: 1,700 Meet to Hear of Westchester County Planning
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 27  Nearly 1,700 people gathered here today to hear the Regional Plan Association's ideas about the future of Westchester County. Their reactions to broad range of proposals on how the county should cope with the challenges of rapid development were varied.

title: Nixon Wage Curb Will Delay Building Of Roads in State
description: ALBANY, March 27Presi dent Nixon's ban of the pay ment of prevailing local wages on federally aided construction jobs will delay work on 15 state highway projects costing $67million, including two on Staten Island.

title: Controversial Mural Is Obliterated at Paramus Shopping Center
description: PARAMUS, N.J., March 27 Frankly, said David DeGhet to, general manager of the Ber gen Mall here, I made a mis take in judgment. Promoting culture isn't our concern here.

title: BROOKLYN COLLEGE PLANS NEW SESSION
description: Brooklyn College, for the first time in its history, will offer an extended double sum mer session allowing students the opportunity to earn up to 16 academic credits.

title: Kenya Frees Odinga
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 27 (AP)Former Vice President Oginda Odinga, leader of the banned Kenya Peoples' Union, was released from detention to day by President Jomo Kenyat ta. Mr. Odinga has been held since October, 1969, accused of having incited bloody riots in Nyanza, his home province.

title: Miss Salzberg to Wed
description: FAIR LAWN, N. J., March 27The engagement of Miss Ellen Beth Salzberg to Stan ley McKennett Brand, son of Herbert Brand of Fair Lawn and Washington, and the late Mrs. Brand, has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Salzberg. Miss Salzberg's father is in the insurance business. Her fianc's father is administrator of the Trans portation Institute, a mari time research organization in Washington.

title: Crime Grant to Mississippi
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)The Law Enforcement Assistance Administration has approved a $3.6million grant to help finance a $6million crimefighting program in Mis sissippi, Senator James O. East land has announced. The grant program was set up under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968.

title: Miss Carol E. Werber
description: RUMSON, N. J., March 27 Miss Carol Elizabeth Wer ber,. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Werber, was married here this afternoon to John Hall Frost, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford R. Frost of Waterford, Conn. The ceremony was per formed in St. George'sby theRiver Episcopal Church by the Rev. Mellick Bellshaw.

title: Conservatives Warn L. I. Republicans That CrossEndorsement Ban Could Cost Control of the Assembly
description: ALBANI, March 27Con servative party officials, who are in the process of being frozen out of crossendorse ments by Long Island Repub lican and Democratic leaders, warned this week that the ban might cost the Repub licans control of the State Assembly next year.

title: Waterways Information Listed by Boating Club
description: There's wealth of informa tion about our waterways, but the boatowner planning his vacation often has rough time finding it, says the Outboard Boating Club of America.

title: IMPOUNDING RATE CALLED NORMAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 The Government's chief budget officer said today that the cur rent level of funds appropriated by Congress but held back from spending was normal and approximately the same per centage of the total budget as for every year since at least 1959.

title: West German Jumpers Rated Olympic Pick by U.S.E.T Pilot
description: Horse Show News

title: Woman With Kidney Implant Gives Birth to Twin Girls
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 27 (AP)  A woman who received a new kidney in a transplant operation less than two years ago has given birth to twin girls. Mrs. Lowell McNeal,, 27 years old, of St. James, Minn., is the first reported transplant recipient to give birth to twins, doctors said last Monday after checking a worldwide trans plant registry. She had a previ ous baby less than a year after her operation. Both the mother and the two infant girls were doing well.

title: Evelyn Ragland, Hollins Alumna, Affianced to John Henry Zink 3d
description: COLEBROOK, Conn., March 27Miss Evelyn Jack con Ragland plans to be mar ried here June 12 to John Henry Zink 3d, who is with the Baltimore law firm of Cook, Mudd, Murray & How ard.

title: Abortion Rap
description: An expanded brief for the case of Abramowicz v. Lefko witz, the concerted effort by a group of women lawyers, community organizations, doc tors and religious leaders, to nullify New York State's 1828 abortion law. The attempt, of course, became unnecessary by virtue of the new abortion law. The transcripts of testimony of girls who underwent illegal abortions are horrendous. Both authors served as lawyers for the plaintiffs.

title: Pare Moves to Semifinals In MidAtlantic Badminton
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 27 Yves Pare and Lane Bickel of Montreal, Tom Heden of New York and Hans Sandager of Copenhagen, Denmark, seeded in that order, gained the semi final round today in the Middle Atlantic badminton champion ships at the Wissahickon Bad minton Club.

title: Magazine, yesanthology, no
description: Within the past two years several black journals have emerged out of the new black awareness to take their places alongside the previously established ones. Two of these have appeared in book format: first Amistad, and now Black Review.Black Review is larger in size than the earlier publication, but they are similar in their attractive covers and in the photographic and graphic work inside. Here the resemblances end, for they differ significantly in editorial policy.

title: F.T.C. Eyes Planned Obsolescence
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 The Federal Trade Commission is seeking evidence of builtin or planned obsolescence of household appliances and other consumer products with a view to possible regulatory action.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Presi dent Nixon's almost desperate efforts to increase his public support recently, have resulted only in a decline in his standing in the popularity polls, and the reason is fairly obvious.

title: The Nation
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C.The first week of spring held special promise for many in this city that has been admired as a model of municipal progress in the modern South.

title: Education
description: Late each weekday after noon, New York School Chan cellor Harvey B. Scribner receives what he has come to call the crisis sheetthe daily log of untoward in cidents reported in the city's 1.1 millionpupil, 900school system. Lately the log has indicated a rise in violence in the schools.

title: Draina Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Pakistanis March at U.N.
description: Several dozen Pakistanis, mostly students, demonstrated in front of the United Nations Building yesterday, shouting slogans in support of East Pa kistan. They carried placards with slogans such as down with Yahya (Presiden Mo hammad Yahya Agha Khan) and Stop genocide in Paki stan. They sen a note to at tention of the Security Council.

title: De Gautle Memorial Set
description: PARIS, March 27 (AP)A monument in the shape of Cross of Lorraine will be built in memory of de Gaulle on a hill overlooking his grave at ColombeylesDeuxEglises.

title: Sharon Long Bride of Dr. Jerry Strong
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., March 27Miss Sharon Anne Long, daughter of Mrs. Thom as H. title: Cancer Controversy

That malignant disease strikes impartially Republicans and Democrats, capitalists and communists, black and white. Despite the unity on goal, however, controversy rages over how this objective should be pursued now that President Nixon has declared the conquest of cancer a major aim and promised to allocate $100 million as a first installment to finance the effort.

title: Cakes Decorated With Artistic Flair

They're so good, so beautiful, so professional that very few housewives can per suade people that they baked them themselves.

title: Melody' Focuses Brightly on the Young
description: As for "Melody"hallelujah! Here, at long last, is a truly endearing movie not so much for or about as of children. Any adult who can face this British color film without succumbing to its wisdom, sweetness and marvelous mischief, all held, for once, to the viewpoint of the youngsters themselves, had better watch out.Exquisitely directed by Waris Hussein, the picture has striking color photography that crisply squints at contemporary London and an anthill depiction of a public school like a precocious child, missing nothing. This regimented, impersonal milieu, compounded by shortsightedness at home, brings together two students, a rich lad and a brash cockney. Enter now a winsome little brunette student, and if you think you know what will happen after an 11-year-old boy and girl profess eternal love, you're in for a big surprise.As the two chums, Mark Lester and Jack Wild are simply wonderful, now reteamed after their "Oliver" and "Artful Dodger" roles. Tracy Hyde, a petite newcomer, is darling in the title role, and James Cossins as the school headmaster and Sheila Steafel, Roy Kinnear and Kate Williams as parents are all excellent.Here is a picture insisting that still another generation gapa preteen oneis simmering under adult noses. No filthy and even filthier-mouthed older rebels stripping down and stalking around in murderous petulance here, praise Britannia! Like fresh manna from heaven, this is a genuine children's hour. And if anbody, young or old, can resist the built-in warning and the movie itself, we don't know how.

title: Housing Paradox
description: New York City's housing shortage is widely recognized as a major source of distress in this beleaguered commu nity. The shortage reflects itself in the desperate attempt of squatters to seize almostcompleted apartment houses, the misery of poor people placed in grossly misnamed welfare hotels and the pressure on national corpora tions to flee the city because their employes find it so hard to locate decent homes at reasonable rents.

title: ' A Severed Head'
description: Perhaps there is a movie waiting to be realized in Iris Murdoch's novel "A Severed Head." If so, it must go on waiting, for it has not been touched in Dick Clement's plodding, faithful, doggedly unimaginative screen adaptation, which opened yesterday at the Baronet Theater."A Severed Head," Miss Murdoch's original play, draws heavily upon the conventional turns and expectations of urbane stage comedy  though it reworks those turns and expectations in the interest of its own semimystical conceits. But Mr. Clement has ignored the resources close at hand in favor of bringing the fiction around with its more arcane purposes acknowledged, but not its theatrical type. The result, whether by will or ineptness, seems like nothing so much as a collection of comic situations looking for a comic intention.Superficially a study in modern misalliance among the London well-to-do, "A Severed Head" belongs to that class of fiction in which the sum of a plot's surprises really is the substance of the work. It is all very circumstantial, but the circumstances affect some rather pleasantly civilized people. And in the figure of its dea ex machina, an inscrutable, Jewish, Cambridge don named Honor Klein, it means to introduce a source of agony and ecstasy (sexual, mostly) appropriate to a world that catches sight of its abysses only through an occasional crack in the teacup.All of this calls for something like high style. But in "A Severed Head" high style extends to some of the costumes and most of the locations  flats, townhouses, country houses  and nowhere else. To have elicited dull performances from Lee Remick, Claire Bloom and Jennie Linden may be an achievement, but not one that I should hope to see repeated.The men are as uninteresting, but fall short of lesser expectations, and only Richard Attenborough, because of his inflated reputation and a juicy role as the film's evil genius (a psychoanalyst, of course), seems a major disappointment.He is also a major piece of miscasting  as is Lee Remick, reduced to a cultivated British accent and a kind of flighty vacuity that may be one of of the few characterizations, fortunately, out of her range.Miss Bloom, as the mysterious East, is in a sense meant to be all presence and no performance. But the others must somehow interact. One of the charms of Iris Murdoch's novel is the articulate ease with which its people communicatetelling lies mostly, but telling them in a rush of great luminous sympathy. Under Mr. Clement's direction, however, nobody communicates, and there are lengthy scenes in which people ostensibly speak to one another, sometimes on matters of great intimacy, without ever making contact.I have rarely experienced such desolation in the midst of plenty at the movies, so little conviction, such a meager sense of good or even ill humor. It is as if the money were there for making a movie, a script written, a cast assembled, scenes blocked out, the whole thing shot and eidtedand nobody thought to ask what was going on, or why.

title: Shop Talk
description: Will you meet a tall, hand some stranger? Should you take a trip? Would you have more fun as a blonde? The computer knowsor should. The woman who is tired of reading magazines under the hairdryer is being offered a new amusement to help her pass the time at beauty sa lons. She can have her horo scope done at the same time as her hair, via a Tele type that feeds information to a computer. Latching on to the current fascination with astrology, the salons at Franklin Simon and Korvette's, at Fifth Ave nue and 47th Street, are of fering computerized horo scope services for a week starting today.

description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 28 (AP)Tom Gorman of Seattle and Julie Heldman of New York advanced today at the start of the annual Caribe Hilton inter national tennis tournament.

title: MORETTI FERRARI TAKES COASTRACE
description: ONTARIO, Calif., March 28  A promotional gimmick pro duced a boxoffice success but an artistic fiasco today as group of Formula One cars from the international Grand Prix circuit routed a sadsack collection of American Formula A machines. It was a case of men against boys.

title: F.B.I. File Theft Stirs: Anger and Joy Among the Residents of Media, Pa.
description: MEDIA, Pa., March 26  Too small to be incorporated as a city, this residential borough of 6,300 population some 10 miles southwest of Philadelphia is not too small to have a threeroom suite of offices for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Chess:
description: Modern Chess Brillian cies, 101 games selected and annotated by Larry Evans, a onetime United States chess champion, was published recently by Simon and Schuster. It is a collec tion of games to remember, mainly of the nineteen sixties, encompassing antag onists who have been in the forefront of the most power ful competitions.

title: Brookings Report on Welfare Backs Cash Assistance Mr Poor
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The nation continues to delude itself by thinking it can solve the welfare crisis with miracle cures like making welfare mothers work, according to a research study released today.

title: The Road to Peace: I
description: In 1953 I attended a reception that marked the conclusion of the seventh session of the General Assembly of the United Nations, a session that had been particularly stormy and frus trated. When one of the diplomats asked me to which delegation I be longed, I replied, only half in jest, To none. I am just a physician, but if you diplomats cannot achieve peace, perhaps we doctors will.

title: Canadiens on Top
description: CHICAGO, March 28 (UPI) Ken Dryden, playing in only his fifth game, excelled again in the nets as the Montreal Canadiens registered a 21 vic tory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

title: Charles Meisel, 79, Is Dead; Expert on Surrogate Law
description: Charles J. W. Meisel, a New York lawyer specializing in civil and surrogate practice, died Saturday in Rosary Hill, Hawthorne, N. Y. He was 79 years old and lived at 25 Rock ledge Road, Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: NEWCOMBE BEATS ASHE IN NET FINAL
description: EVANSTON, Ill., March 28, (Reuters)  John Newcombe, the Wimbledon champion, de feated Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., 46, 76, 62, 63, today to win the $10,000 top prize in the $50,000 Sportface tennis tournament.

title: To Reorganize the Government
description: It is not necessary to accept President Nixon's sweep ing indictment of the failure of the Federal Government in order to agree with him that any big organization can occasionally benefit from a thorough overhaul. His plan, spelled out In complex legislation submitted to Congress last week, would reorganize and consolidate seven of the Cabinetlevel departments into four new depart ments. It is the most ambitious reform of the Federal Government attempted since the unification of the armed services and the creation of the Defense Department in 1947.

title: Labor's Wrong Turn
description: Britain's Labor party has carried out a marathon parliamentary maneuver against the Conservative Gov ernment's industrial relations bill that was as totally negative and unsuccessful as the strikes and demonstra tions of its trade union allies. Some Labor members obviously enjoyed prolonging a House of Commons ses sion for nearly 22 hours and forcing no less than 63 voting divisions; but all this failed to improve the bill, and the spectacle is likely to hurt the party at the polls.

title: Advertising:
description: Countrywide Publications, which moved during its 14 years from oneshot ro mance and fan magazines to special interest magazines, is now ready to go for, the big onea monthly general in terest magazine.

title: Fire Union Warns City Against Provoking Job Action as Panel Prepares Settlement Terms
description: The head of the Uniformed Firefighters Association issued a warning yesterday to the city not to provoke the firemen into taking a job action by continued footdragging on a new contract.

title: ORDERS FOR TOOLS UP 9.4% IN MONTH
description: New orders for American machine tools in February rose 9.4 per cent above the January level as a slight dip in export bookings was more than cov ered by increased domestic or ders.

title: Laotians Report Foe Retreats
description: LUANG PRABANG, Laos, March 28 (AP) The Laotian command said today that Gov ernment troops had forced a North Vietnamese regiment back five miles from the em battled royal capital of Luang Prabang in two days of heavy fighting.

title: BARRY SCORES 51 AS NETS TOP STARS
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, LI., March 28  Rick Barry, cele brating his 27th birthday, scored a gamehigh 51 points today and led the New York Nets to a 133120 victory over Utah Stars in the Nets' last reg ular season home game at Is land Garden.

title: 2 PROSTAGLANDINS ARE SYNTHESIZED
description: LOS ANGELES, March 28 A Harvard University chemist announced today the labora tory synthesis of the last two of the body's primary prostaglan dins, a series Of hormonelike substances that may find wide use in birth control and the treatment of asthma, ulcers, high blood pressure and other ailments.

title: Policies of Paranoia
description: Without in any way condoning the theft of documents from an office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, one is tempted to ask: who watches the watchman? Little confidence is inspired by the security measures of a security agency whose files can be so easily burglarized.

title: Udall's Bill: One Sport for Each TV Season
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 Warning that professional athletics are about to be turned Into another Edsel, Representative Morris K. Udall will propose legislation tomorrow to limit the broad cast seasons of major sports.

title: Italian Police Track Leftist Terrorists
description: ROME, March 28The police are investigating what appear to be networks of ultraleftist terrorists in various parts of Italy. At the same time, comic opera aspects are beginning to come out of a judicial inquiry into what is described as a neo Fascist plot.

title: ERNEST. F. JESSEN, EDITOR IN ALASKA
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, March 28 (AP)Ernest F. Jessen, an Alaskan pioneer who untie here 65 years ago and stayed to publish one of the state's best known newspapers, died: Friday He was 80 years old.

title: Wings Down Maple Leafs, 21, On Delvecchio's 3d Period Goal
description: DETROIT, March 28 (UPI) Alex Delvecchio scored De troit's second unassisted goal of the game with 5:09 elapsed in the third period today and it gave the Red Wings a 21 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game.

title: McGovern Asks U.S. Funds To Offset SST Job Losses
description: Senator George S. McGovern said yesterday that the Federal Government should fund work on mass transit and other projects to help offset the loss of jobs caused by the canceling of the supersonic transport program, The Associated Press reported.

title: Manitoba Grows Skeptical on Pulp Deal
description: THE PAS, Manitoba  Ranging across a snow dusted timber concession of 40,000 square miles, some 400 men are cutting north ern spruce and jackpine and trucking the logs over frozen muskeg to The Pas, site of Manitoba's newest  and highly controversial  indus trial installation.

title: Tensions in Brezhnev's Realm
description: The power of positive thinking is likely to dominate this week's 24th Soviet Communist party congress, an event some Kremlinologists are al ready calling the coronation of Czar Leonid I.

title: Pnompenh FearRidden After One Year of War
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 25  Just a year ago Pnompenh slid from peace into war without missing a beat in the serene and smiling rhythm of its placid life. For a long time afterward even the grow ing realization that Cambodia was at war did not seem to diminish the city's pleasure in being alive.

title: Condors Sign Porter
description: PITTSBURGH, March 29 (AP) The Pittsburgh Condors of American Basketball Associa tion said early today they had signed Howard Porter, a 6foot 8inch Villanova star.

title: DoortoDoor Field Expanding Volume
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI)  The doortodoor sell ing industry, which about doubled in volume in the 1960's, appears to have benefited from the recession.

title: GARY PLAYER WINS BY 2 SHOTS ON 274
description: MIAMI, March 28Gary Player, whom Lee Trevino calls the man in black, won for the second straight week on the pro golf tour today as he took the $200,000 National Air lines open by two strokes with a 72hole total of 274.

title: Knicks Win, 11095, for 21 Edge
description: ATLANTA, March 28On the strength of a 6341 second half that displayed their famous de fense in top form, the New York Knicks took a 21 lead in their National Basketball Asso ciation firstround playoff series by beating the Atlanta Hawks, 11095, before a capacity crowd of 7,192 tonight.

title: INTRUDERS SEIZED IN HARLEM CHURCH
description: Fifteen persons, most of them teenagers, were arrested at a Harlem church yesterday after they tried to solicit funds to support a sitin protest against Model Cities relocation policies.

title: Overqualified L.I. Workers on Relief
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., March 24Overqualified, a term that connotes education, skill and experience, has become the bane of many engineers and scientists on Long Island who have been thrown out of work and onto the wel fare rolls.

title: Hong Kong Tabloid Competes in Chinatown
description: A newspaper from Hong Kong has been gaining ground steadily in Chinatown in re cent months, posing a threat to the four local Chinese dai lies and creating a real sense of competition for the first Mime among Chinese newspa pers here.

title: Miss Luellen Buell Bride of Irving Jaeger
description: Miss Luellen Buell, daugh ter of Mrs. Leon Buell of New York and the late Mr. Buell, was married here at noon yesterday to Irving J. Jaeger. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Jaeger of New York. Rabbi Arthur Schneier performed the ceremony at the Park East Synagogue. Miss Ca mille Sturniolo and Alfred Comford, a cousin of the bridegroom, attended the couple.

title: Advertising:
description: How's this for a meaning ful gas station premiuma coupon good for a ham burger?

title: State Legislators Start Nationwide Antiwar Drive
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)  More than a score of state legislators bearing peti tions signed by 627 lawmakers began today what they said was a statetostate campaign to end the war in Indochina.

title: 19,507 See Bombers Turn Back Pioneers In Derby at Garden
description: The Roller Derby, a sport that matches good against evil, made its final appearance of the season yesterday at Madi son Square Garden. As 19,507 people looked on, the good (the San Francisco Bay Bomb ers) defeated the evil (the Mid west Pioneers), 5248.

title: Steelworkers Aim for a Big Pay Rise
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 28  Gary Smith looked at a cardboard folder with cutouts for dimes that his church had sent him to fill up by Easter Sunday. It was still empty.

title: Cambodians Fight for Route 4
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 28 (Agence France  Presse) Cambodian Government troops were still fighting today to re open vital Route 4, cut by enemy troops yesterday. The route links the capital with the nation's only deep water port, Konipong Som.

title: A MISSILE FREEZE URGED BY JACKSON
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 Senator Henry M. Jackson pro posed today a oneyear agree ment with the Soviet Union freezing the deployment of most landbased missiles. He said this would arrest the de cline in the security of the United States nuclear deterrent.

title: LOUIS A. ROSETT
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 28Louis A. Rosett, retired manufacturing chemist, who formery headed the Flora synth Laboratories, died yester day in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 171 Norman Road.

title: ARTHUR A. BERARD
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 28 Arthur A. Berard, presi dent of the Ward Leonard El ectric Company here and a past president of the National Elec trical Manufacturers Associa tion, died today in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. He was 77 years old and lived at 39 Locust Lane.

title: Democrats Plan a New Policy Agency
description: ST. LOUIS, March 25Over two years after losing the White House, the Democratic party is still trying to figure out how to unify its diverse and occasionally jealous segments and speak with one voice.

title: On His Hilltop Farm, He Feels Alive Again
description: Weekends in a rural set ting have made such a change in 39yearold Norman Sun shine's whole existence that he can scarcely believe it.

title: Israelis Seek to Settle Feud Between Two Christian Sects
description: JERUSALEM, March 28The Government of Israel reluc tantly stepped in today to try to resolve a longsmoldering dispute between two Christian sects with rival claims to sacred places in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher.

title: AT SOUTH MALL, A NEW TIMETABLE
description: ALBANY, March 28  The story of the controversial South Mall state office building prof ect here is ea:panted in the checkered history of one of its smallest buildings, the nine story office building for the Legislature.

title: Lawyer Weds Barbara Share
description: SYRACUSE, March 28 Miss Barbara Suzanne Share, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan I. Share, was married here today to Donald Alan Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Kaplan of New Bruns wick, N.J. Rabbi Irwin Hy man, assisted by Cantor Harold Lerner, performed the ceremony at the Syracuse Hotel.

title: Divorce Foes Act in Italy
description: ROME, March 28 (UPI)Foes of Italy's new law permitting divorce began seeking signa tures today for a referendum to repeal it. They must produce half a million legally authenti cated signatures.

title: Wellington Management Co. Appoints Two Top Officers
description: The Wellington Management Company announced yesterday that W. Nicholas Thorndike has been named chairman of the board and that Robert W. Doren has been named to the new post of chief operating officer.

title: Crimmins Trial Fills Courtroom and the Corridor
description: They begin to arrive at 7 A.M. They stand outside the Queens Supreme Court Building, some times shivering in a cold mist. Some bring lunch. Others cups of coffee.

title: Sniper Fire Closes Highway
description: ST. LOUIS, March 28 (AP) Sniper fire hit three vehicles early today and forced the po lice to close temporarily a sec tion of Interstate 70 near Lam bertSt. Louis Airport. There were no injuries, and the sniper escaped a police chase, the po lice of suburban Berkeley said.

title: Sugarman Warns of Costs In Lower Medicaid Ceiling
description: New York City and other lo calities may wind up bearing millions of dollars more costs under Medicaid changes being proposed by state Republican legislative leaders.

title: Bridge: Landy Memorial Will Aid Multiple Sclerosis Fund
description: The annual Alvin Landy Memorial game, the biggest charity effort of the year by the Greater New York Bridge Association, will be played tonight at 15 locations in New York City and Long Is land. Almost all the proceeds will be channeled through the American Contract Bridge League's Charity Foundation to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Janet Stern Married to Lawyer
description: Miss Janet E. Stern was married here yesterday after noon to Lewis D. Solomon. Rabbi Mark Goldman per formed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: Blacks in House Seeking Negro Leadership Nationally
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The 13 black members of the House of Representatives are making a move to assume lead ership of blacks nationally, thus stepping in to fill what they see as a void left by the deaths of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. three years ago and Whitney M. Young Jr. earlier this month.

title: NonSocial Party Aids Playwrights Unit
description: It was Robin Kenmore's first social event In America, and he thought it was all right. His bright eyes darted around the crowded base ment room, taking in the short shorts, fringetrim suedes, animalprint evening jackets, Indian headbands and fur battle jackets.

title: Fire Captain Killed In Attempt to Save 4 Already Rescued
description: A 40yearold fire captain was burned to death yesterday in a Brooklyn tenement when he battled his way through flames to a thirdfloor apart ment, looking in vain for four children he had been told were trapped there.

title: TUGOFWAR SEEN OVER BOND YIELDS
description: Investment bankers pushed interest rates down sharply for more than two weeks in mid March, and then last week in vestors balked. Now the credit markets are headed for a tug ofwar to see whether the trend toward lower yields will resume.

title: 11 Are Rescued and 20 Missing As Tanker Sinks Gil Hatteras
description: A liberian tanker rescued 11 seamen in a liferaft 120 miles northeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C., yesterday afternoon, more than 36 hours after their ship, the tanker Texaco Oklahoma, broke apart in a storm.

title: N.B.C. Aide Fears F.C.C. Constraint
description: CHICAGO, March 28The breath between offical Wash ington and the television medi um widened here today when the general counsel of the Na tional Broadcasting Companycharged that the fairness doc trine of the Federal Commu nications Act had made the Government the ultimate editor of news on television.

title: MISS MARSEE SINGS ROSINA IN BARBER
description: Put Susanne Marsee's name on your list of Rosinas to hear and enjoy in the future. The young mezzosoprano took over the role of the marriageable girl in Rossini's I?? Barbiere di Siviglia for the first time in the New York City Opera per formance on Saturday after noon and showed that her voice, looks and personality make her highly suitable for the part.

title: BULLS TOP LAKERS IN RALLY, 10698
description: CHICAGO, March 28 (Al)  Fired by the ejection of Coach Dick Motta, the Chicago Bulls battled to a 10698 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers today in their National Basketball Asso ciation playoff series.

title: Fire at Farmingdale School
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I, March 28The Weldon E Howitt Jun ior High School will be closed tomorrow because of damage to the building caused by a fire last night. The fire, of undeter mined origin, broke out at 6 P.M and did considerable dam age to the gymnasium. School officials announced today that the school would reopen Tues day.

title: Belkin Tennis Victor
description: GREENVALE, L. I., March 28 Mike Belkin of Toronto won the $5,000 Dannon indoor tennis tournament today at C. W. Post College. Belkin totaled 17 points, defeating Clark Graebner of New York, 61, and losing to Cliff Richey of tennis roundrobin today at C. Angelo, Tex., 6.4, and earned $2,000. Richey finished second and Graebner third.

title: Rhodesia, Barred in '68, Invited to '72 Olympics
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 18 (AP)  Rhodesia, banned from the 1968 Olym pics in Mexico City because of its, racial policies, has re ceived an official invitation to take part in the 1972 Games at Munich.

title: Sticks and Spears Against Tanks
description: NEW DELHI, March 28 The people of East Pakistan, armed with sticks, spears and homemade rifles, are mount ing a resistance movement against a military force from West Pakistan that is armed with planes, bombs, tanks and heavy artillery.

title: The Screen: 'Taking Off':Milos Forman Directs a Charming Farce
description: "Taking Off," the first American film by Milos Forman, the young Czechoslovak director of "The Firemen's Ball" and "Loves of a Blonde," is about Jeannie Tyne but it gives most of its amused attention to Lynn and Larry Tyne, the parents Jeannie leaves behind in Forest Hills when she takes off for the East Village.It is not Jeannie (Linnea Heacock) who has the real adventures, but Lynn (Lynn Carlin) and Larry (Buck Henry), who find themselves at a black-tie dinner meeting of the Society for Parents of Fugitive Children (where everyone turns on with pot), who get drunk and play strip poker, who always seem to be behaving badly when Jeanniefrom time to timecomes home of her own accord.Mr. Forman's specialty is tender farce played out in what are, essentially, very bleak circumstances. The 86-year-old fire chief, who is being honored in the magnificent shambles of "The Firemen's Ball," is suffering from cancer. In "Loves of a Blonde," Andula, who is not only dear but so naive and romantic she appears to be almost dim-witted, falls in love with a musician who is a mama's boy and spectacularly unfaithful to everyone.When you stop to think about "Taking Off," the circumstances are almost as bleak. Lynn and Larry don't seem to have a clue as to what's going on in Jeannie's mind, and although they are decent enough, the house in which they live is a kind of memorial to their humdrum sensibilities: knotty pine paneling, lace doilies on the TV set and piano, and, on the wall, one of those "perspective" paintings that, depending on your angle of vision, is a clipper ship, the portrait of a 19th-century lady, or a still life of a bowl of flowers. "That," says a friend of theirs, "is what I call art."The circumstances are bleak, but the movie is not. It has as much affection for Jeannie's parents, even at their most foolish, as it has for Jeannie and the freshfaced innocentsthe acid heads, the drop-outs and would-be recording artistsshe meets in her Village wanderings.In terms of narrative and characterization, "Taking Off," on which no less than four writers collaborated, including Jean-Claude Carriere ("Belle de Jour," "The Milky Way"), is so slight it barely exists at all, being hardly more than a series of comic sketches.One of the joys of "The Firemen's Ball" was the manner in which the director constructed multilevel gags that unfolded out of each other, as when a couple were seen making love under the table from which the evening's raffle prizes were being stolen, one by one. There is nothing comparable to that comic density here; instead Mr. Forman resorts to the sort of tricky editing by which the action in a succeeding scene is made to seem a humorous comment on what's immediately preceded it, even though they are unrelated."Taking Off" has been so artfully constructed, however, that what I suspect to have been a certain barrenness of inspiration often looks a good deal more meaningful than it really is.One of Mr. Forman's great talents is in casting faces as well as real actors. Ths focal point of the film is Linnea Heacock's Jeannie, a girl who doesn't do very much, who hardly opens her mouth but whose eyeslarge, beautiful, and often downcastexpress quite enough.Buck Henry, who looks like a potentially dishonest bank teller, and Lynn Carlin ("Faces") both are legitimate actors who also happen to be very funny. I'm not quite sure what it is about themperhaps an intensely serious concentration, like that of children listening to music. Of the others, I especially liked Audra Lindley, one of the S.P.F.C.'s major boosters, and David Gittler, who plays a rock musician so shy he can hardly bring himself to focus his eyes on a person rather than a thing.Then, too, thero are all those other unnamed faces in the film, the faces of the young people whom Jeannie meets in the Villagefat, round, beautiful, depressed, aggressive, vulnerable. They literally surround the film (Mr. Forman keeps cutting back to them after their sequence is over) with a solemnity that is both touching and extremely funny. "Taking Off" is not a major movie experience, but it isa good deal of the timea charming one.

title: Jewish Women Debate Alienation of Their Children
description: BOSTON, March 28  We have to meet our Jewish kids where they're at, a group of Jewish mothers were told here today. They saw, long before many of their parents did, the evils of racism, the blight of urban poverty and the immo rality of the war in Vietnam.

title: 2 GIANT DRILLS USED IN BID TO AID MINERS
description: CARMICHAELS, Pa., March 28 (AP)Two giant experi mental drills bored today to ward a burning coal shaft where two miners have been trapped since Friday morning.

title: Army in Control
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 28 The Pakistani army took full control of Dacca today. Fight ing that lasted two nights and a day is believed to have taken the lives of 5,000 to 7,000 per sons in the area.

title: Women Honored by Jaycees
description: BOSTON, March 28 (UPI) There were three women among the 10 persons honored as out standing leaders by the Jaycees at their annual awards dinner last night. In the past, only men had been hnored. The women were Mrs. Ellen Jack son, executive director of a grassroots educational group; M. Patricia Morse, a biology professor at Northeastern Uni versity, and Mrs. Sylvia J. Sim mons director of financial aid at Radcliffe College.

title: Judith C. Anker, Richard D. Plotz Wed at Brandeis
description: WALTHAM, Mass., March 28  Miss Judith Constance Anker, a graduate student at the Simmons School of Li brary Science, was married here today to Richard Doug las Plotz, who expects to be graduated in June from Harvard College. Rabbi Ar thur Green performed the ceremony In the Berlin Chapel of Brandeis University, of which the bride is a gradu ate.

title: Miss Ann Bailinson Is Married
description: In the Brotherhood Syna gogue here yesterday after noon, Miss Ann E. Bailinson, daughter of Mrs. Jean Paas well Bailinson of New York and Frank Bailinson of Mont clair, N.J., was married to Jerome Alan Kleinman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Klein man of Beachwood, Ohio, Rabbi Irving J. Block per formed the ceremony.

title: SWEDES' RALLY TOPS U.S. SEXTET, 4 TO 3
description: GENEVA, March 28  The United States lost to Sweden, 43, in the world ice hockey championship tonight, but not before scaring the secondplace Scandinavians with the threat of a major upset.

title: Sherman Mills Fairchild Is Dead at 74; I. B. M. Heir Invented an Aerial Camera
description: Sherman Mills Fairchild, a restless inventor with the imag ination and personal wealth to develop major industries from his ideas, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived at Lloyd Neck, L. I.

title: HOTA TURNS BACK HOBOKEN, 5 TO 2
description: New York Rota routed Ho boken, 52 to maintain its lead in the North Group of the Ger manAmerican Soccer League yesterday, while Elizabeth and the GermanHungarians, bat tling for supremacy in the South Group, posted 11 ties.

title: News Analysis
description: ALBANY. March 27Gover nor Rockefeller's proposal for a oneyear residency require ment for welfare applicants is being viewed by critics as long on taxpayer sympathy but short on dollarsaving potential for the state. Welfare officials commenting privately on this aspect of the Governor's new concepts to hold down the welfare rise, note that as of last December it was estimated that only 11,000 people on the state weitare rots of 1.6 million had been in the state one year or less.

title: Argentina Curbs Domestic Beef Sale
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 28 Argentine waistlines will begin expanding tomorrow be cause the military Government has ordered a ban on the domestic sale of beef on al ternate weeks for the next three months. The ban is effec tive as of midnight tonight. With mutton, pork, poultry and fish, which Argentines consider fit only as side dishes or sand wich makings, priced out of ordinary family budgets, most people will be eating pasta in various forms during the ban.

title: Week's Votes In Congress
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 Following are the votes of dele gations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yes terday:

title: Flyers Are Victors Over Penguins, 31, Gain Playoff Spot
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 28 (UPI)  Bobby Clarke scored two goals as the Philadelphia Flyers registered a 31 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight and clinched the final spot in the National Hockey League's West Division play offs.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 28 Archibald Cox is a Harvard law pro fessor who served with great distinc tion as Solicitor General of the United States. His wellknown report on the troubles at Columbia University re fleeted a particullar sympathy for stu sons for their unrest. His person ex presses a New England sense of moral conviction.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Festive for Start of Congress Tomorrow
description: MOSCOW, March 28 Moscow, seemed in a holiday mood on this springlike day as it prepared for the 24th Congress of the Soviet Com munist party opening Tues day.

title: Truman Library Names Aide
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., March 28 (AP).John W. Snyder, for mer Secretary of the Treasury, was named yesterday by the hoard of directors of the Tru man Library Institute to head a drive to rake $1million for the institute's programs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Stage: All Over, Albee's Drama of Death, Arrives
description: A man is dying. Diminish ing into deathslowly, faint ly, like that last ebbing note where memory fades into si lence. We, the audience for this ritual, are waiting in the anteroom of his death, along with two professionalshis personal physician, himself calmly old and with deathly nostrils, and his private nurseand a group of ama teurs, his wife, his mistress, his two earlymiddleaged children and his best friend.

title: Holdup Man Is Wounded By Partner After Robbery
description: A holdup man was shot by his partner, apparently acciden tally, as the two left an East Side delicatessen they had robbed late last night, the po lice said.

title: Aussie Tennis Team Gains In Davis Cup Zone Play
description: HONG KONG, March 28 (AP) Australia moved into the second round of Davis Cup tennis play as Colin Dibley and Bob Giltinan beat Hong Kong's Ken Taui and Ling Fond, 62, 63, 6.4, in doubles.

title: Highest Attack Toll
description: SAIGON, March 29 (AP) Available United States com mand records dating back to the beginning of 1967 indicate the American death toll at the artillery base south of Danang was the highest in that time in any single attack on a United States installation, although more Americans have been killed in daylong running bat tles.

title: 1968 Effort for a Major G.I. BuildUp in Vietnam Is Reported
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 A former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen, G. Wheeler, reportedly encour aged Gen. William C. West moreland, then United States commander in Vietnam, to re quest largescale troop rein forcements during the Com munists. Lunar New Year of fensive in 1968.

title: F.B.I. SAYS CRIME ROSE 11% IN 1970
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The Federal Bureau of Investi gation said today that the grand total of criminal offenses known to the police was 11 per cent higher last year than in 1969.

title: Rookies Tie for Lead
description: BUFFALO, March 28 (AP) Gil Perreault of the Buffalo Sabres and Jude Drouin of the Minnesota North Stars moved into a tie in their race for Na tional Hockey League rookie point honors tonight as the Sabres defeated the North Stars, 42.

title: Hoffa Is Said to Bar Scheme on Parole
description: SAN CLEMENTE, March 28 Justice Department officials said today that James R. Hoffa, whose application for parole will be reviewed Wednesday, considered and apparently re jected a bizarre scheme to en list the support of the man who did as much as anyone else to put him in prison Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas.

title: Pearson Outraces Petty by 4 Seconds
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., March 28 (UPI)David Pearson of Spar tanburg, S.C., took the lead 63 laps from the finish today, held off a threat by Richard Petty and won the Southeastern 500 nascar race in a Ford.

title: CRUZ TAKES LEAD IN HONDURAN VOTE
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, March 28 (UPI)Ramon Ern esto Cruz, candidate of the gov erning National Party, took the lead tonight in Honduras's first peaceful presidential election in decades.

title: Productivity Gains Sought for Public
description: President Nixon says he wants business to pass future savings from productivity gains down the line to consumers.

title: Broyard Is Appointed A Times Book Critic
description: Anatole Broyard will join The New York Times as a daily book review critic on April 16, it was announced yesterday by A.M. Rosenthal, managing editor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Urged on Trading In Stock of Penn Central
description: Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking and Cur rency Committee, has called for an investigation by Con gress and by Federal regulatory agencies into the propriety of trading in the stock of the Penn Central Company by nine leading institutions during the period from April 1, 1970, to June 19, 1970.

title: Israel and Egypt Exchange 2 P.O.W.'s Injured at Suez
description: TEL AVIV, March 29 The United Arab Republic and Israel exchanged wounded prisoners of war today but Cairo con tinued to refuse a general ex change of 11 Israeli prisoners for 71 Egyptians.

title: Old Boston Church Looted
description: BOSTON, March 28 (UPI) The city's oldest church, First Parish in Dorchester, celebrated its 341st anniversary today while the police hunted thieves who took antiques valued at $10,000 from the building some time in the last month. The Rev. James K. Allen, pastor, discovered the theft yesterday while preparations were being made for the anniversary. The stolen items included a 1,000 yearold Ming vase.

title: Welfare Residency Law: Vetoed by Rockefeller in 1960, Advocated by Him in 1971
description: Elevn years ago this week, Governor Rockefeller, citing our state's heritage with its respect for the dignity and worth of each Individual, ve toed a bill establishing a resi dency requirement for welfare, recipients in New York.

title: Personal Finance
description: A major segment of the auto insurance industry, in move to separate the good drivers from the notsogood and the really bad ones, is attempting to introduce a new rateclassification system in New York that has long been in operation almost everywhere else. The industry tried to get approval for the plan here in the past but was rebuffed by the State Insurance Depart ment. Now it is making a new attempt.

title: Playing Games With Words
description: There's a new game being played In America. It goes like this: A gives B the official expressionor mediatermand B supplies the meaning.

title: 2 Oil Economists Agree Buyer's Market Is Over
description: EVANSTON, Ill., March 28 Two of the world's leading oil economists agreed today that the buyer's market in petroleum that existed for the last 15 years has come to a close.

title: No. 2 Rink of Riverside Wins in Mixed Bonspiel
description: DARIEN, Conn., March 28 The Riverside Curling Club No. 2 rink of St. John, New Bruns wick, Canada, skipped by John (Jock) Caskey, won the Nutmeg Curling Club's eighth annual Golden Handle International Mixed Bonspiel today by de feating Winchester, Mass., C. C. No. 1, skipped by George Whit ten, 117, at the Country Club of Darien.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Documenting Its Hudson Cleanup
description: Progress has been reported In plans for reducing pollution of the Hudson River from the Gen eral Motors plant at North Tar rytown, N.Y., with the pollution scheduled to stop completely by the end of the year.

title: Heidi Richardson of M.I.T. Wed To Lieut. Jeffrey C. Harrison
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., March 28  Miss Hildegard Anna Richardson and Lieut. Jeffrey Chisholm Harrison, U.S.M.C., were married here today in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer by the Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger.

title: Steel Companies Offer Views to Houthakker
description: A study of the American steel industry, ordered by the White House in January, has prompted the companies to sup ply an avalanche of informa tion, demonstration and per suasive argument.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 29, 1971 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Colonialism3 P.M.

title: BETTY CARTER CALLS MISS HOLIDAYTO MIND
description: For a long time, Betty Carter has obscured her vocal talents under a cumbersome set of mannerisms that were some times laid on so thick that whatever she might be singing disappeared completely. But she is beginning to use these vocal gambits to advantage and, in a concert Saturday night at Cami Hall, she re vealed a superb singing pres ence in several of her songs.

title: L. I. Man Is Found Guilty. Of Slaying Wife in 1964
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 28 A Suffolk County Court jury today convicted a Cold Spring Harbor man of murdering his wife seven years ago.

title: TalentLaden Romero GuitarPlaying Family Performs at Tully
description: The four Romeros may sound like an aerial team, but they are in fact a guitarplaying family of considerable talent. The talent, as well as Cele donio, Pepe, Celin and Angel, was prominently displayed yes terday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, where a chamber or chestra drawn from Washing ton's National Symphony pre sented what the program called a Baroque Festival.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: THREE BRIDGES, N.J., March 28Party Girl, a 5yearold brown mare owned and ridden by Ronnie Ann Oser of Dix Hills, L.I., captured all three classes to win the junior work ing hunter championship today at the Hunt Cap Farms horse show.

title: Stans Sets Up Ombudsman Office for Businessmen
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 Taking a leaf out, pf the con sumer advocate's notebook, Secretary Maurice H. Stans has appointed a businessman's om budsman in the Commerce De partment.

title: Devlin Scores as the Devil When Treigle Falls Ill
description: A sudden attack of appendi citis prevented Norman Trei gle from appearing as the devil in the New York City Opera performance of Mefis tofele yesterday afternoon. Fortunately, the company had a fine replacement on hand, Michael Devlin, who was singing the role for the first time, and the young bass made a resounding success of it.

title: Bulldog Best at Paramus Show
description: PARAMUS, N.J., March 28 A 23year quest was realized today when Dr. and Mrs. Al fred M. Freedman's bulldog, Ch. Bayside Doubloon, was named best in show at the 28th allbreed event of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey.

title: Books of The Times
description: M/F. By Anthony Burgess. 242 pages. Knopf. $5.95.

title: Agnew Invited to Holler
description: DUNN, N. C., March 28 (AP)  Vice President Agnew has been invited to take part in the third annual Hollerin' Contest scheduled June 19 at nearby Spivey's Corner. Ermon Godwin Jr., chairman of the event, told Mr. Agnew in a letter today that he could speak or holler, whichever he preferred. The contest attracted several thou sand persons last year.

title: Cavaliers May Select Wicks First in Draft
description: The Cleveland Cavalier will get first pick today when the National Basketball Association holds its annual draft. The Cavaliers, who fin ished with 1567 wonlost record, poorest in the league, won a coin flip with Port land, another expansion team, for the right to select first.

title: Bacallao Wins 3d U.S. Title In a Row in Squash Tennis,
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 28Dr. Pedro A. Bacallao of the Princeton Club won the United States national squash tennis championship today for the third straight year.

title: NEW YORK CAMERATA SHOWS FINE TALENT
description: Contemporary music was the primary, but not exclusive, con cern of the New York Camerata at their concert Saturday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Three of the scheduled works had, in fact, been composed specifically for this talented young trio of Anthony Pagano (flute), Charles Forbes (cello) and Glenn Jacob son (piano).

title: 2 Trainmen Die in Crash
description: SHERIDAN, Wyo., March 28 (AP)  Two trainmen were killed today when a Burlington Northern railroad train smashed into a string of boxcars sitting on the main track here. Killed were Richard G. Wood, 51 years old, the engineer, and Clifton Broombridge, 34, the fireman, both of Sheridan.

title: WRIGHT TRIUMPHS IN GIANT SLALOM
description: LINCOLN, N. H., March 28 In an unusual display of form consistency for a major eastern ski racing tournament, Wayne Wright of Wilmington, N. Y., and Brad Kennison, Essex Cen ter, Vt., were the two top fin ishers for the second straight day on Loon Mountain.

title: Rangers Top Brains Again, 21
description: Spinning past a leaderless, Boston defense and outmaneu vering wouldbe checkers, the Rangers last night continued their march to playoff form by handing the Boston Bruins their fourth straight defeat.

title: City Orders New Elections of Model Cities' Ruling Panels to Curb Power of Povertycrats
description: The Lindsay administration has ordered the election of new citizen committees in the three Model Cities neighborhoods under rules that attempt to reduce the influence of slum based antipoverty organizations over the Federal program.

title: Some Saigon Troops in Laos, But Activities Are Kept Secret
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 30  Some South Vietnamese troops con tinued operating inside Laos yesterday near the area from which a large Government task force withdrew last week.

title: Prevention of Illness Is Aim of New Computerized Testing Here
description: The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York yester day opened a computerized testing center that will check pecipfe.for more than 50 pos sible medical abnormalities without their being touched by a physician.

title: Burlington Industries Plans A Line of Home Furnishings
description: Burlington Industries, Inc., announced yesterday plans to produce a complete line of homefurnishings products un der one brandname, Burlington House. The line will range from sheets to furniture and will be allocated an advertising budget of more than $7million.

title: Alice Dougan Donovan, Wrote Poems and Plays
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 29 (AP)Mrs. Alice Dougan Dono van, a poet and playwright, who was the mother of Hedley Donovan, editor in chief of all Time Inc. publications, died here yesterday. She was 90 years old and the wife of Percy Donovan.

title: The Road to Peace: II
description: In the midfifties I drew up a six point program, which, in 1968, I sent to both Presidential candidates, being fully aware of the long and thorny road it would take to make an idea of this kind palatable. In the mean while, I have, learned that independ ently a bill about a Department of Peace has been introduced in Congress (HartkeHalpern).

title: Newsmen Hurt in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 29 (UPI)  Two news men were wounded on Route 4 about 60 miles southwest of Pnompenh today. They were Joseph Lee, a South Korean television cameraman, and Tea Kim Heang, a Cambodian free lance photographer on assign ment for United Press Interna tional and local newspapers.

title: JOSEPH MALFITANO PLAYS VIOLIN MUSIC
description: For over 25 years Tibor Serly has cultivated a compositional technique that he calls modus lascivus. In his violin recital Sunday night in Carnegie Hall, Joseph Malfitano gave the pre. miere of one of the composer's most recent works in the style, Rondo Fantasy in Stringomet rics for violin and harp. The Rondo was prefaced by an earlier piece, the solo Sonata in Modus Lascivus (1947).

title: Customs Official to Retire
description: Michael Stramiello Jr., re gional Commissioner of Cus toms for New York since 1966, will retire May 1, Commissioner of Customs Myles J. Ambrose announced yesterday. Mr. Stra miello plans to return to the private practiec of law with Barnes, Richardson & Colburn at 25 Broadway.

title: Mayor Will Press Legislature To Head Off Disastrous Cuts
description: Mayor Lindsay announced determined plan yesterday to press Albany to head off disastrous projected cutbacks in state aid, warning that the city was at the peril point.

title: Pacific Utility's Income Off
description: The Pacific Northwest Bell Telephone Company reported yesterday net income for the three months ended Feb. 28 to taled $12,017,000, or 32 cents a share, down from the $12, 791,000, or 34 cents a share, a year earlier. Operating reve nues rose to $109,984,000 from $107,691,000. Pacific North west is 89.2 per cent owned by American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Patterson Posts 9thRound Knockout
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 29 Eagerly but sympathetically, Floyd Patterson, the former two  time world heavyweight champion, took another short step tonight on his boxing comeback with a ninthround knockout of Roger Russell at the Arena.

title: The Plaint of Political Exiles in Europe: How Long?
description: PARIS, March 29  In his fiveroom apartment on the Rue Mirabeau, Constantine Mitso takis sits in his living room each morning and pores over Greek newspapers.

title: Six Liberman Statues At Sculpture Garden
description: Six large metal sculptures by Alexander Liberman will be open to public inspection for the next three months as part of the city's newest out door cultural facilitythe Hammarskjold sculpture gar den on the southeast corner of 47th Street and Second Avenue.

title: N.A.S.D. SUSPENDS 2 AND 1ST PRUDENTIAL
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers, the selfreg ulatory organization for the overthecounter market, has suspended the First Prudential Corporation from N.A.S.D. membership for 10 days start ing yesterday and has fined the New York securities firm $5,000 for violations of its fairprac tice rules.

title: The Members of the CourtMartial Jury
description: FORT KENNING, Ga., March 29 (AP)  Following are sketches of the six mem bers of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.'s courtmartial fury:

title: U.S. Forces in Vietnam Now Down to 306,500
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29 (UPI)  American troop strength in South Viet nam dropped by 6,400 last week, bringing it to a total of 306,500, the United States command said today.

title: Fund Holders Seek Social Commitment
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Two, shareholders in the Fidel ity Trend Fund, Inc., want it to consider the social policies of corporations before it in vests in their stocks. They have proposed that a resolution to that effect be brought before the annual meeting of the mu tual fund's shareholders June 10.

title: City Study Reports Alcoholism Is Major Ill Getting Minor Care
description: A new study by the city's Health Services Administration calls alcoholism here a major problem which is receiving only minor attention and says there may be as many as 300,000 alcoholics in the city.

title: N.Y. Bank's Deposits Climbl
description: The New York Bank for Sav ings announced yesterday that its deposits had crossed the $2billion mark for the first time, up $174million in the last 12 months.

title: U.S. Base Attacked Again
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 30 (AP)  Still stunned from Sunday's attack, the Americal Division's artil lery base south of Danang cameunder enemy mortar attack early yesterday.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES GO UP IN CHICAGO
description: Trading action on the Chicago Board of Trade was erratic yes terday and prices closed mixed.

title: Pamela Fairbanks Wed in France
description: DIJON, France, March 29 (AP)Miss Pamela Fairbanks of New York City and Aubert Gaudin do Villaine, son of the owner of the RomaneeConti vineyards in Burgundy, were married Saturday at the vil lage church at VosneRoma nee.

title: COURT ALLOWS SUIT AGAINST BIG BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)The Supreme Court to day let stand a decision allow ing a nonmember to seek a $21 million antitrust judgment from the New York Stock Exchange in the United States District Court in Milwaukee.

title: Maryland Workers Brawl
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 29 (AP)Some 400 state employes demanding higher pay stormed the main entrance of the Mary land State House tonight, bursting the revolving door and engaging in a fistswinging melee with the state police be fore the disorder was quelled. One person was arrested.

title: Police Officer Attacked While on Way to Work
description: A police sergeant on his way to work at the Police Headquarters Annex in Low er Manhattan was mugged last night by two men, one of whom he shot and wounded.

title: Brezhnev's Report Opens Party Congress in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 30The Soviet Communist party formally opened its 24th Congress this morning with 4,949 Soviet delegates and re presentatives from 101 foreign delegations present to hear the main report from Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party lea der.

title: Four Die in Rio Rainstorm
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 29 (AP)Floods brought on by in tense rains killed four persons and left 2,000 homeless today in Rio de Janeiro. The down pour last night lasted less than an hour but affected several districts of the city.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PICKETS FIGHT RISE IN CIGARETTE TAX
description: Several hundred cigarette dis tributors demonstrated here and in Albany yesterday to protest state and city proposals to in crease cigarette taxes 7 cents a pack over the present 12cent tax.

title: Calley, in Interview Before Verdict, Said He Hoped Mylai Would Help End Wars
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 29I hope Mylai isn't a trag edy but an eyeopener, even for people who say war is hell, said First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who was con victed today of the premedi tated murder of 22 Vietnamese civilians.

title: JEWS TOLD OF GAIN IN TIES TO BLACKS
description: BOSTON, March 29  The American Jewish Congress re ported today a significant number of projects in which blacks and Jews were working together to strengthen relations between the two groups.

title: Soviet Fiat Plant Opened
description: MOSCOW, March 28  The first section of the Fiat automo bile plant at Togliatti on the Volga River was formerly in augurated today. It has been producing cars since last fall. The section, with a capacity of 220,000 cars a year, is the first of three sections in the plant.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Secretary Laird states that the mili tary operation in Laos is proceeding according to plan. It is, indeed, pro ceeding according to plan: It just hap pens to be General Giap's plan, and not Mr. Laird's.

title: RICHEY TRIUMPHS IN TENNIS, 60, 60
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., March 29 (UPI)Cliff Richey triumphed over Morton Stern, 60, 60, to day in a firstround match of the 19th Caribe Hilton interna tional tennis tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernard P. McGuire Dead; Management Consultant,52
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 29Bernard P. McGuire, a partner in McGuire Associ ates, management consultants of New York, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in Moun tainside Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 102 Squire Hill Road.

title: PROF. OTTO LAPORTE, MICHIGAN PHYSICIST
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 29Otto Laporte, a pioneer in atomic spectroscopy and plas ma physics, died here yester day in University hospital. He was 68 years old, a member of the physics faculty at the University of Michigan for 45 years.

title: STOCKS ARE FIRM ON LONDON BOARD
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange were steady to slight ly firmer yesterday.

title: MISSILE SUBMARINE REPORTED TO GAIN
description: LONDON, March 29Mis siles launched from submarines are becoming increasingly im portant in the arsenals of the two superpowers as their land based missiles become more obsolete, according to the latest issue of Strategic Survey.

title: RETAILING CHAIN SETS RECORD NET
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation yesterday reported record sales and earnings for the fourth fiscal quarter, ended Jan. 30. The fullyear profit, however, was down 6 per cent from the previous year's level. The profit had been down 43 per cent at the end of the spring season, Lewis P. Seiler, chairman, said.

title: Poseidon Missile Tested
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 29 (AP)A multiwarhead Po seidon missile was launched to night from the submarine Ulysses S. Grant. It was the missile's 30th test flight.

title: Red Sox Demote Santiago
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 29 (AP)  The Boston Red Sox trimmed their squad to 29 play ers today by sending Jose San tiago, a pitcher; Tony Muser, first baseman, and Carlton Fisk, a catcher, to Louisville of the International League.

title: Gas Bomb Shuts School
description: George Westinghouse Tech. nical and Vocational High School was closed in midafter noon yesterday after a tear gas bomb was exploded in the school's cafeteria. A Board of Education spokesman said that there had been no injuries. School authorities reported that three suspects were being questioned about, the incident. The school, which is scheduled to reopen this morning, is at 105 Johnson Street, Brooklyn.

title: Zambian Building Bombed
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 29 (Agence France  Presse)  A bomb exploded here today at a building housing the headquar ters of several exiled southern African nationalist groups. One man was reported injured in the blast, which damaged the building extensively.

title: Americans in South Vietnam Attribute the Setback in Laos to Faulty Planning and Intelligence
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29United States Army advisers and other observers in the field are ascribing the South Vietnamese. Army's perform ance in Laos to difficulties the allies had failed to anticipate and to tactical challenges it had not been trained to meet.

title: .Court Backs Settlement Of Claims on Drug Pricing
description: A courtapproved settlement of overpricing claims against producers of broadspectrum antibiotics gained the support yesterday of the United State Court of Appeals for the second circuit, according to The Asso ciated Press.

title: BRONX HOUSE BLAZE BEING INVESTIGATED
description: Two separate investigations were under way yesterday into a fire that last week caused extensive damage to a Bronx building scheduled for use as a home for neglected and abandoned black and Puerto Rican children.

title: A Proposal for the Poor
description: I have been reading about the fami lies on welfare who are put up at the Waldorf Astoria and other expensive hotels because room could not be found for them in more modest estab lishments. No room at the inn is an ancient problem. If Joseph had been on welfare, he might have been allot ted a room in the Bethlehem Hilton of the day instead of a stable, and changed the lifestyle, if not the course of Christianity.

title: Buckley Ties Foreign Aid to Halt in Illegal Drugs
description: Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican, said yesterday that, as he promised lin his 1970 campaign, he would move to cut off economic aid to governments that 4'refuse to act against the illegal drug trade.

title: Phi Beta Kappa Picks Its Bicentennial Poet
description: Melville Cane, who has been a practicing lawyer for 68 years and a practicing poet for longer than that, has been commissioned to write the bicentennial poem for the 200th anniversary of Phi Beta Kappa in 1976.

title: NAN WYNN, SINGER OF FILMS AND STAGE
description: Nan Wynn, a popular night club, stage and screen Anger of the nineteenforties, in pri vate life the widow of John Small of York, Pa., died March 21 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. Her age was 55.

title: Mohawk Airlines in Talks
description: Merger News

title: BIG BOARD TO CHANGE MEMBERFIRMS UNIT
description: The New York Stock Ex change said yesterday that it was planning to reorganize its Department of Member Firms. which is the unit charged with enforcing the exchange's regu lations. Involved in the reorgan ization will be the reassignment of Robert M. Bishop, vice presi dent in charge of the depart ment, according to an exchange spokesman.

title: Men at Pentagon Decline To Comment on Verdict
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 The secondranking civilian in the Department.of Defense said tonight that the courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was a pretty, wrenching experience for the Army.

title: CHOCTAW WOMAN NAMED U. S. AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton appointed a 51 yearold Indian woman today as his special assistant to moni tor all Indian programs to provide a broader base of leadership in solving Indian problems.

title: Georg Jensen. Makes. Changes; TakeOver by Kenton Is Hinted
description: A new topmanagement change and the appointment of three newdirectors at Georg Jensen, Inc., the retailer and wholesaler of silver, chinaware and crystal, may result in the acquisition of the 48yearold company by the Kenton Cor poration.

title: Ford Recalls All of Its Pintos for Engine Defect
description: DETROIT, March 29  The Ford Motor Company recalled today all of its 220,000 small Pinto cars to correct a defect that has caused engine compart ment fires.

title: ARCHITECT NAMED L.I.U. CHANCELLOR
description: Albert BushBrown, an archi tect and former president of the Rhode Island School of De sign, was appointed chancellor of Long Island University last night. The university's third chancellor in the last two years, he is the first to assume .L.I.U.'s highest administrative office after being recommended by a committee of students, faculty and alumni.

title: Incorporation Is Planned By Goldman, Sachs & Co.
description: Goldman, Sachs & Co., one of the nation's oldest and largest investment  banking houses, announced plans yes terday to incorporate within the next few months. The firm has operated as a partner ship throughout its 101year history.

title: Robert A. W. Carleton, Engineer On Major Tunnels in City, Dies
