description: GARRISON, N. Y., March 29  Robert A. W. Carleton, a civil engineer, who built many of New York's subway and rail road tunnels, died Sunday in Butterfield Memorial Hospital, Cold Spring. He was 89 years old and lived here.

title: Indian Volunteers Sought to Go to Aid East Pakistanis
description: CALCUTTA, India, March 29  Private efforts were under way here today to organize groups of Indian volunteers to cross the border into embattled East Pakistan to aid liberation forces in resisting the Paki stan Army.

title: Man In the Newz
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 During the summer of 1968 the dean of the University of Washington's medical school in Seattle went into private practice for about two weeks in a small town called Omak not far from the Canadian border. The dean, Dr. John Rusten Hogness, Volunteered as a vacation re piacement for the doctor who serv ed that com munity of about 4,000 people in a rural part of the state.

title: C.C.N.Y. Picks Kaminer
description: City College announced yes terday the appointment of Jack Kaminer, 28 years old, as the fifth varsity basketball coach in the school's history.

title: CARL WARNECKE, ARCHITECT, DEAD
description: Carl I. Warnecke, a widely known architect, died of a heart attack Saturday in San Francisco. He was 80 years old and lived in Piedmont, Calif.

title: PANTHER PURSUES HER OWN DEFENSE
description: A former undercover agent was led back over the years yesterday by the woman who was his section leader while he was pretending to be a Black Panther.

title: DEMOCRATS FIGHT G.O.P.BUDGET PLAN
description: ALBANY, March 29The 71 Democratic members of the As sembly unanimously opposed today a plan by the Republican leadership to cut $703million from Governor Rockefeller's proposed $8.45billion budget, asserting that is was regres sive andassaults every com munity in the sate.

title: 2 MORE FROM TANKER SAVED
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., March 29 (UPI)  A merchant vessel pulled two crewmen from the Atlantic Ocean today to bring to 13 the number of survivors of a tanker that snapped in two in heavy seas with 44 men aboard.

title: Democratic Contenders
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The big gest news in the slowly developing contest for the Democratic Presiden tial nomination in 1972 is Hubert Humphrey's dramatic rise in the opin ion polls. From a position far back among the alsorans, he has now moved up to third place in the Gallup Poll as the choice of 21 per cent of Democratic voters, just behind front runners Edmund Muskie and Edward Kennedy.

title: Paper Aids Program
description: The New York Amsterdam News yesterday presented check for $1,000 to the New York Urban League street acad emies in memory of Whitney M. Young Jr., the late civil rights leader. Jesse H. Walker, execu tive editor of the Harlem week ly newspaper, said he hoped the gift would encourage other corporations to help the finan cially beleaguered program for high school dropouts.

title: The Economy's Woes
description: Economic Analysis

title: Abbie Hoffman's Conviction For Defiling Flag Is Upset
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)A Federal appeals court overturned today the conviction of Abbie Hoffman, the Yippie leader, for defiling the Ameri can flag.

title: Paris Gets Pessimistic Report
description: PARIS, March 29  The French Government got a pes simlstic report on the Middle East situation today from Mah moud Riad, Foreign Minister of the United Arab Republic.

title: BIAGGI ASSERTS CITY IS POLLUTING WATER
description: A Bronx Representative charged yesterday that New York City was polluting its own water supply with mer cury used in motoroperated sluice gates. The city denied it.

title: Screen:
description: Yesterday's double bill, running through tomorrow, is a good one at the Bijou Cin ema, which is now presenting a worthy series of Japanese features, old and new. The new Bride of the Andes is a purposeful sociological drama, with a fresh, exotic, background and one persis tent, nagging hitch. The beauty is Samurai Rebel lion, a quiet, powerful treat.

title: Produce Growers to Fight Move to Switch Contracts
description: SALINAS, Calif., March 29 (AP)  Representatives of 200 Salinas and Imperial Valley pro duce growers agreed today to fight any move to switch their teamsters union contracts to Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers Organizing Committee.

title: What Julie Eisenhower Thinks
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Julie Nixon Eisenhower is glad that she's finished with college. She's distressed over youngsters who take nar cotics. She respects consci entious objectors who stay within the law. And she thinks her sister, Tricia, will be able to handle herself ad mirably now that her forth coming wedding has pro jected her into the public spotlight.

title: ErieLackawanna Seeks 15% Increase in Fares
description: HOBOKEN, N. J. (AP)  The ErieLackawanna Railway an nounced yesterday that it had asked the New Jersey Depart ment of Transportation to ap prove a 15 per cent fare in crease.

title: Advertising:
description: To Be Alive! the beauti ful 18minute film that was one of the big hits of the last New York World's Fair, will start a fourweek run at the Community Center theater of the Menlo Park Mall Shop ping Center, Edison, N.J., on April 6.

title: WELFARE GROUPS ASSAIL GOVERNOR
description: A spokesman for a statewide coalition of private social wel fare and healthagencies be rated Governor Rockefeller yes terday, charging he had refused for the last three weeks to meet them on current fiscal and welfare crises.

title: MOVERS BARGAINING AS DEADLINE NEARS
description: Negotiations continued yes terday between representatives of the moving and storage in dustry and Local 814 of the In ternational Brotherhood of Teamsters, whose threeyear contract expires at midnight to morrow.

title: Zoning Authority for Counties Asked
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., March 29The Long Island Associa tion's bureau of government research recommended today that counties have authority to initiate zoning laws or en force certain zoning stand ards.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)  The Defense Depart ment announced today that the following servicemen from the New York area had been killed i naction in Southeast Asia:

title: Two Sentences Possible
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 29 (AP)The same jury that convicted Lieutenant Cagey of three counts of premeditated murder must choose between only two punishments, life in prison or death.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS WAGEPRICE CURES IN CONSTRUCTION
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., March 29  President Nixon ordered into effect today what he described as a largely self regulating system of con straints designed to halt the spiral of wages and prices in the construction industry.

title: SYRACUSE PAPERS FAN BUDGET FIGHT
description: ALBANY, March 29In an unusual demonstration of the political impact of newspaper editorials, two Syracuse news papers have played key roles in the state budget impasse in the Legislature less than 48 hours before the state's new fiscal year begins.

title: Bus and Subway Vandals Cost City 2.6 Million in '70
description: Vandalism on New York City's subways and buses last year cost the city's Transit Authorityand ultimately the riders and taxpayers  about $2.6million, or as much as 10 new airconditioned subway cars, the authority disclosed yesterday.

title: Court, in Shift, Rules a State Can Deny an Inheritance to Illegitimate Children
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  The Burger Court whittled away at another liberal doc trine of the Warren Court to day by ruling, 5 to 4, that a state can deny illegitimate children the same right as le gitimate children to inherit from their fathers.

title: Fire Unit Offers Reward For Arrest in Fatal Blaze
description: A $5,000 reward was offered yesterday by the Uniformed Fire Officers Association for the arrest and conviction of the person or persons who set the fire that killed Fire Captain John T. Dunne.

title: Urban Unit Chairman Named
description: ALBANY, March 29 (UPI) Governor Rockefeller named his secretary, Alton G. Marshall, as chairman of the Urban Develop ment Corporation today. Mr. Marshall, who left the Gov ernor's staff earlier this year to become president of Rockefeller Center, Inc., will succeed George Woods as chairman.

title: Delegates See Thant
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March, 29The representatives of Pakistan and India conferred separately with Secretary Gen eral Thant today but both said they had asked for no immedi ate move by the United Nations to end the fighting.

title: Symington Backs Soviet on ABM Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri called today for ac ceptance of the Soviet proposal for a freeze on antiballistic mis sile systems as the first step toward a comprehensive strate gicarmslimitation agreement.

title: GALLEY GUILTY OF MURDER OF 22 CIVILIANS AT MYLAI; SENTENCE EXPECTED TODAY
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 29  First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was found guilty to day of the premeditated murder of at least 22 South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai three years ago.

title: Met Put on Disabled List
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 (UPI)The New York Mets placed Ted Martinez, an infield er, on the disabled list today for a 21day period. Martinez underwent minor surgery in New York recently and is re cuperating at his home in the Dominican Republic.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Seeks Dismissal of Rankin Because of Conflict of Interest
description: Mayon Lindsay was ordered by a State Supreme Court jus tice yesterday to show cause why he should not dismiss Cor poration Counsel J. Lee Ran kin on the ground of conflict of interest.

title: ReadingKey to Learning
description: The New York State Education Department has ruled that, effective next January, all candidates for certifica tion as elementary school teachers must have completed at least the equivalent of a full year's course In the teach ing of reading. It is difficult to understand why it has taken the education authorities so long to comprehend that the mastery of reading is absolutely basic to learning.

title: Sculpture or Armor? Body Jewelry Can Be a Little of Both
description: Body jewelry may have come and gone as a fashion fad, but in the crafts world, where it all began, the trend is flourishing. And for that, hundreds of budding silver smiths and artisans have, in part, three women to thank.

title: JUSTICES TO WEIGH PRIVATECLUB BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 The Supreme Court agreed to day to consider whether private clubs that exclude Negroes as members or guests can hold licenses to serve liquor.

title: ALEX PRICES DROP As TRADING SLIPS
description: The American Stock Ex change ended slightly lower in slower trading yesterday after prices were mixed throughout most of the session.

title: Letter to the Editor 3
description: To the Editor: Now that the SST project has been banned, we must make sure not to allow foreign supersonic planes into the country, which would undo the goad that has been gained.

title: Student Playing All Bach's Organ Works (200 or So)
description: If you look up the date of Johann Sebastian Bach's birth in encyclopedias, you will find it given as March 21, 1685. But Joseph Kline, like others who have gone further into the matter, re alizes that Bach was really horn 286 years ago tomor row. A change of calendar since that time makes what used to be the 21st now the 31st.

title: Nasli M. Heeramaneck Dead; Dealer in Asian Art Objects
description: Nasli M. Heeramaneck, one of the world's leading dealer collectors of Asian art and an tiques, died yesterday in Roose velt Hospital after a short ill ness. He was 68 years old and lived at 23 East 83d Street.

title: SIMON TO AUCTION ABOUT 70 WORKS
description: Norton Simon, Los Angeles, industrialist and one of the country's most prominent art collectors, will sell about 70 impressionist and other 19th century works from his per sonal collection at auction May 5 in New York.

title: Democrats Express Doubts on Recovery in Economy
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Majority Democrats on the Congressional Joint Economic Committee expressed strong doubts today that the economy would recover as rapidly this year as the Nixon Administra tion had projected, but they stopped short of urging further economic stimulus through tax cuts or higher Government spending.

title: DEMOCRATIC WHIP ASKS U.S. PULLOUT
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Breaking with other members of the House Democratic lead ership, the Democratic whip, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massa chusetts, called today for with drawal of all United States military forces from Indochina by the end of the year.

title: Ex Governor of West Virginia. Pleads Guilty to Bribing Foreman of His Jury
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 29Former Governor William Wallace Barron pleaded guilty today to charges of bribing the foreman of a Federal jury that acquitted him in 1968 of wide ranging corruption during his administration.

title: U.S. MAY STEP UP OFFSHORE OIL WORK
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)A highranking Interior Department official says that offshore petroleum leasing will be stepped up as part of a longrange effort to make the nation more selfreliant in vital fuels.

title: Israel Bars a Meeting of Arabs To Plan WestBank University
description: JERUSALEM, March 29 Israel has vetoed a plan for Palestinian political leaders in the westbank area of Jordan to discuss among themselves, the formation of an Arab uni versity in the occupied terri tories.

title: Orioles Option Crowley
description: MIAMI, March 29 (AP)Terry Crowley, a 24yearold outfield er who was Baltimore's No. 1 pinch hitter last season, was optioned to Rochester of the International League today.

title: Campaigning Fills the Air Chile Prepares for Sunday Election
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 28 Mommy, what is a Commu nist? asks a childish voice on the radio.

title: BACHE CUTS LOSS IN A TURNAROUND
description: Bache & Co., the nation's secondlargest brokerage house, disclosed yesterday that its fi nancial performance had im proved dramatically in the sec ond half of its most recent fiscal year and called for a new method of charging investors for the services they receive.

title: Tryout was important to Adam Wilson, 12, who had been pretty perturbed spending two years in CAIN League. He made the minor, league this season.
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  The Little League tryouts were scheduled to start at 10 A,M. Saturday, but 12yearold Mark Neuner jumped out of the family station wagon 40 minutes earlier ready to go.

title: Foster Will race Anderson In Title Fight on April 24
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 26 (UPI) Bob Foster, the lightheavy, weight champion, signed today to face Ray Anderson here April 24, in a title bout that Will be nationally televised into homes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 ExStudents Charged by Harvard in Protest
description: CAMBRIDGE, March 29 Harvard University filed crim inal charges today against three former students for trespassing and disturbing an assembly of people in connection with the disruption of a prowar teach in at the university last Friday night.

title: Rail Freight Rises Sought
description: Railroads filed yesterday tar iffs for freight rate increases with the Interstate Commerce Commission averaging 11.8 per cent nationwide, effective April 12. For Eastern roads, the per manent rate rise will be up to 14 per cent, up to 6 per cent for Southern roads and up to 12 per cent for western roads and for interterritory traffic.

title: Berrigan Defense Asks Data
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 29 (UPI)Attorneys for the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and five other persons indicted in an alleged plot to kidnap a Presidential adviser asked a Federal court today to let them see all the Government's evidence in the case. The attorneys also asked for background information on the Federal grand jurors who indicted the six antiwar ac tivists on charges of conspiring to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger and blow up heating plants for Government buildings in Wash ington.

title: N.C.A.A. Pushes Probe Into Premature Signings
description: College Sports Notes

title: DOW IS UNCHANGED IN A DULL MARKET
description: The DowJones industrial av erage closed without change yesterday at 903.48, but indi vidual issues elsewhere on the New York Stock Exchange pro vided a fair share of fireworks.

title: Last Lion Bounty
description: The Arizona Legislature is now debating a measure repeal the nation's only remaining state bounty law on the mountain lion. A companion bill would change the lion's official status from predatory to biggame animal.

title: BUCKS TURN BACK WARRIORS, 104 TO 90
description: MADISON, Wis., March 29 (AP)  The explosive Milwau kee Bucks used a thirdperiod spurt tonight to fashion a 104 90 victory over the San Fran cisco Warriors in a National Basketball Association playoff game.

title: Four Cities Offer to Be Host For Democratic Convention
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)Miami Beach, Chicago, San Francisco and Houston made offers today to be the host for the 1972 Democratic National Convention. Louisville, Ky., the only other contending city, will formally extend its invitation tomorrow.

title: Text of the Calley Verdict
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 29Following is the text of the verdict in the courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., read by Col. Clifford H. Ford:

title: Mylai History: From Rumor to Verdict
description: The story of the military action at the hamlet of Mylai on March 16, 1968, which has stunned the national conscience and outraged world opinion, existed in a twilight zone of rumor and uncertainty for more than a year after it happened.

title: Red Cross Aiding Pakistanis
description: GENEVA, March 29Pierre Gaillard, one of the principal executives of the International Committee of the Red Cross, was named today to head the committee's operations in East Pakistan and will leave for Karachi tomorrow.

title: Copper Rise Widens
description: Price increases spread quick ly through the copper industry yesterday, helping to push the shares of some of the producing companies on the New York Stock Exchange to gains of as much as 2 points.

title: Mrs. Smith Denies Nixon Tried to Buy SST Vote
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) Senator Margaret Chase Smith defended President Nixon today against what she called extremely erroneous and un fair accusations that he had tried to buy her vote for the supersonic transport with letter rescinding a shipyard closure order.

title: British Plan Commercial Radio In 72, Ending B.B.C. Monopoly
description: LONDON, March 29Com mercial radio for Britain, com prising up to 60 local stations, was envisaged by the Conserva tive Government in a policy statement today

title: PAYMENTS POLICY WINS AGREEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Republican and Democratic members of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee agreed today on what the na tion's policy should be toward the balance of international payments. It had these main features:

title: Concern Sues Institutions Over Penn Central Notes
description: The Mallinckrodt Chemical Works brought a $1.5million damage suit yesterday in Fed eral District Court here against the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, Goldman, Sachs & Co. and Dun & Brad street, Inc. for losses it says it sustained on its purchase last year of two issues of promis sory notes of the Penn Central Transportation Company.

title: Unbeaten Soviet Six Routs Finland, 101
description: GENEVA, March 29  The Soviet Union continued its tri umphant glide toward a ninth consecutive world ice hockey championship by swamping Fin land today, 101, for its sixth victory and a tie in seven games.

title: Mad Dogs and Englishmen'
description: "Mad Dogs and Englishmen" is the filmed record of the American tour undertaken last year by Joe Cocker, the young extraordinarily talented, British blues singer, and the largely American entourage (band, choir, friends, wives, children, groupies and a single dog named Canina) that accompanied him. The entire group numbered almost 40 people, most of whom were on stage during most of the performances, making for what seems to have been extremely cheerful and friendly chaos.That, at least, is the spirit of this most satisfying, record-album of a movie, for which the group's off-stage experiencestraveling by bus and plane, radio interviews, picnics, getting up in the morningact as liner notes.Liner notes are seldom absolutely necessary, but they can be entertaining when one has nothing else to read. Those for "Mad Dogs and Englishmen" (the movie, not the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer soundtrack album) don't say very much about the driving genius of Mr. Cocker, which remains his own, quite private concern until his stage appearances, but they serve as necessary and often entertaining intermissions between the fine, galvanizing Cocker performances."Mad Dogs and Englishmen," the name Mr. Cocker gave to the group put together for this tour, is exactly what a cinema vrit concert film should be: music as recorded during lively performances, in this case in Dallas, San Francisco, Piattsburgh, N. Y.; Minneapolis and, finally, New York, at the Fillmore East.Mr. Cocker is not the spectacularly sinuous, sexually aggressive performer that Mick Jagger is. In his old undershirt, which is occasionally dressed up with a few sequins, he is hardly a sight that is immediately riveting. His equally talented No. 2 man, Leon Russell, arranger-guitarist-pianist-composer-what have you, with his long hair, 19th-century topper and white jeans with the flowers on the seat, is much more photogenic. It is, however, Mr. Cocker who provides the show, who sings most of the film's 15 numbers, with, from time to time, a little bit of help from such friends as Claudia Linnear and Mr. Russell.Mr. Cocker's style is post-Ray Charles, post-almost anybody I can think of, a gravelly voice that seems to have been pushed beyond its endurance, but that always retains reserve with which to maneuver through Mr. Russell's complex arrangements. Their rock-blues utilizing the large choir into which the children and Canina sometimes wander, are immensely elaborate without ever being fancy, principally, I suspect, because Mr. Cocker is not a fancy artist.He is simple, direct and great, as is the repertory that includes a lot of rock standards like "Honky Tonk Woman," "Space Captain," "Let It Be" and "Give Peace a Chance." Thus, people coming upon Mr. Cocker for the first time will not be lost.As in most films of this nature, it's difficult to tell who is responsible for what, but let me say that it was directed by Pierre Adidge, co-directed and edited by Sid Levin, with David Myers as director of photography, which includes the work of at least three cameras.The quality of the blow-up print from 16 millimeter to 35 millimeter that I saw at the Trans-Lux West (where it opened yesterday, as well as at the Trans-Lux East) was not perfect, but certainly adequate. The split-screen effects are sometimes lovely, and the sound recording seemed excellent."Mad Dogs and Englishmen" patronizes neither its audience nor its stars. Occasionally it lets peripheral characters make rather sober fools of themselves, such as the professorial disk jockey who tells Mr. Cocker how he could spend "two hours in the British Museum, just looking at all that stuff they ripped off the Egyptians." The film, however, is too good-natured, and too involved with the actual performance of a single star, to waste much time with this sort of thing, which is why it is so satisfactory, so pleasing. It is uncluttered, one of the best concert films so far.

title: Dr. Harold McCormick Dead; Board of Education Historian
description: Dr. Harold W. McCormick, a historian of the city's Board of Education who retired in 1967 as chief of publications for the Superintendent of Schools, died Saturday at his home, 11 Riverside Drive, of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

title: Market Place: Britain Facing Financial Crisis
description: Perhaps you've grown tired of our problems and are giv ing some thought to treking to England, where a small number of influential Ameri cans are settling.

title: Hospital Pledges Not to Evict Or Relocate East Side Tenants
description: The New York HospitalCor nell Medical Center pledged yesterday to refrain from evict ing or relocating tenants from housing it owns on Manhattan's East Side.

title: Wood, Field and stream
description: Some anglers shudder and many politicians quake at the. prospect of supporting it, but the concept of saltwater fish ing licenses is gaining advo cates.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION GAINS 1.7% IN WEEK
description: Steel production rose by 1.7 per cent last week, compared to output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Insti tute reported yesterday in Washington.

title: Resistance in Chittagong
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 29The port of Chittagong is the center of the stiffest resist ance to the Pakistani armed forces moving to suppress the rebellion in East Pakistan, ac cording to communiqus from the martiallaw authorities for the East.

title: FLAGGING GROWTH SEEN FOR EUROPE
description: GENEVA, March 29Western European industrial countries expect the private consumer to be the main support this year of their flagging rate of eco nomic growth, the United Na tions Economic Commission for Europe said today.

title: At John Dewey H.S., a Student Can Go at His Own Pace
description: Almost every school day, little groups of educators from around the country troop through the uncrowded halls of John Dewey High School in Coney Island to peer into the busy classrooms and see the city's Major ex periment in public education.

title: FLUTIST AND PIANIST IN CHAMBER RECITAL
description: Ingrid Dingfelder, flutist, and Sophie Goldblatt, pianist, are obviously welltrained musi cians seriously involved in their work, and each has plenty of technical capability.

title: Ulster Rightist Finds Bomb
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 29 (AP)  A gelignite bomb was found today In the home garden of William Craig, the Protestant militant defeated last week by Brian Faulkner in the election of Prime Minister of Northern Ireland.

title: Fun Filled, $6, Defeats Royal Fillet By HalfLength in Mile at Aqueduct
description: Fun Filled of the Hobeau Farm and Myra Cohen's Royal Fillet engaged in a rousing stretch duel in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, with the former prevailing by a half length. Bobby Woodhouse steered Fun Filled and Ron Turcotte was on Royal Fillet, in the mile test for older fil lies.

title: Philippine Airliner Is Hijacked To Hong Kong and Then China
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, March 30A Philippine Air Lines plane, hijacked by five persons armed with a carbine and pis tols, was reported to have landed at Canton in Communist China today after a refueling stop here.

title: Romney Says Nixon Doesn't Get Square Break on Network TV
description: CHICAGO, March 29George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, told a panel meeting of the National Association of Broadcasters late this afternoon that he didn't think President Nixon was get ting a square break on net work television.

title: $5.2Million Bond Issue Voted For a New High School in Rye
description: RYE TOWN, N.Y., March 29  The voters in Union Free School District No. 5 tonight narrowly approved a controver sial $5.2million bond issue to build a new senior high school on 26 acres held in trusteeship by the First National City Bank.

title: Change by Bonn Seen
description: PARIS, March 29  Official West German sources who said last week that West Ger many had acquired $500million of United States gold have been unavailable following denials of the transaction by both the American Treasury and the West German Central Bank.

title: Harris Memorial Tomorrow
description: The Memorial Committee of the New York Stock Exchange has announced a memorial serv ice tomorrow at 9 A.M. in Trinity Episcopal Church, Broad way and Wall Street, for George Upham Harris. He was former chairman and president of Harris, Upham & Co. and member of the exchange since 1924. He died on March 5.

title: Keino and Royster Triumph For 2d Time at Trinidad
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, March 29Kipchoge Keino of Trinidad captured the 1,500 meter run today in 3 minutes 40.6 seconds, the equivalent of a 3:57 mile, for his second vic tory in two days in the South ern Games. Yesterday, Keino won the 5,000meter run in 14:03.

title: Mrs. Crimmins's Outburst Halts Trial
description: A witness who said she watched Mrs. Alice Crimmins on the hot summer night six years ago when Mrs. Crimmins's two children were killed re constructed that scene in vivid detail yesterday in State Su preme Court in Queens.

title: Confident McGovern Stumps Here
description: Senator George S. McGovern of South Dakota, the only an nounced Democratic candidate for the Presidency, declared here yesterday that he had started his campaign so soon to get the kind of surging and meaningful dialogue that used to characterize our political campaigns.

title: Feminists Protest Arrests Of Prostitutes in the City
description: About 50 feminists demon strated for about an hour yesterday in front of the West 54th Street police station to protest what they called the steppedup police drive against prostitutes.

title: Health Department Expert Scores Use of Commercial Blood
description: A Health Department labora tory expert charged yesterday that it was a national shame that the United States was the only country in the civilized world that used blood sold and bought on the commercial market.

title: Lolita, My Love Delayed For Further Revisions
description: For the second time in as many months, Lolita, My Love, the new musical by Alan Jay Lerner and John Barry, has postponed its Broadway opening.

title: ALLYEAR SCHOOLS LOSE IN ASSEMBLY
description: ALBANY, March 29  The Assembly debated the socalled continuous learningyear bill for more than two hours today, and then took no action when its sponsor withdrew the meas ure, which faced almost certain defeat.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 30, 1971

title: EXDRUG ADDICTS START IN NEW JOBS
description: A messenger service tha employs former drug addict opened yesterday as an ex periment in rehabilitation.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Has any body else noticed that America is van ishing? The last Presidential campaign afforded some scary hints of what is going on. People who accompanied it all the way said afterward that they had not seen much of the country ex cept for an airport and a shopping center beside an expressway exit ramp.

title: Jury Votes Gas Chamber For Manson and 3 Women
description: LOS ANGELES, March 29The same jury that found Charles M. Manson and the three young women members of his hippie family guilty two months ago of the seven Tate LaBianca murders voted death in the gas chamber as their punishment today. The jurors returned with their verdict after 10 hours of deliberation.

title: SENATE IN JERSEY GETS STADIUM BILL
description: TRENTON, March 29Legis lation drafted by Gov. William T. Cahill and designed to attract the New York Football Giants to northern New Jersey was introduced this evening in the State Senate.

title: PEKING AND KUWAIT TO EXCHANGE ENVOYS
description: HONG KONG, March 29  Communist China and Kuwait have established diplomatic re lations, Hsinhua, the Peking press agency, reported today.

title: South Carolina Quits Atlantic Coast Circuit
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., March 29 (UPI) South Carolina an nounced today it was with drawing from the Atlantic Coast Conference until such time as the conference low ered its academic require ments for college enrollment of athletes.

title: Veterans Seeking Clemency In Nonhonorable Discharges
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)A predominantly black veterans' group began a cam paign today for special consid eration for some servicemen released with less than honor able discharges.

title: NEWARK AIDE GUILTY IN ALTERCATION HERE
description: A Newark City Councilman was found guilty yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court of charges of resisting arrest and disorderly conduct in connec tion with a dispute between him and a policeman in the Port Authority's midtown bus terminal.

title: CRUZ RULED WINNER IN HONDURAN VOTING
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, March 29 (Reuters)  Ramon Ernesto Cruz, a 68yearold in ternational lawyer, today was declared President of Honduras for the next six years.

title: PANEL GIVES PLAN FOR 3 CITY UNIONS
description: The threeman impasse panel in the city's fire, police and sanitation contract dispute yes terday presented an 80page report and recommendations for settlement terms to the city and the three uniformed services.

title: 14 Big Windows Broken At N.Y.U. Student Center
description: Vandals broke 14 large win dows at New York University's Loeb Student Center at about 2:00 A.M. yesterday.

title: Tito Makes Plea for Arabs in Talk With Pope
description: ROME, March 29In a 75 minute audience surrounded by Vatican pageantry, President Tito of Yugoslavia and Pope Paul VI today discussed the Middle East, EastWest affairs and other international prob lems.

title: 91Day Bill Rate Rises to 3.521% At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Treasury bill rates advanced sharply at today's auction from last week's levels, the Govern ment reported late this after noon.

title: PAKISTAN REPORTS OPPOSITION IN EAST HAS BEEN CRUSHED
description: The Pakistani Government asserted yesterday that its military forces were in control in East Pakistan, with the independence movement de feated. But broadcasts from radio stations identifying them selves as voices of the resist ance movement said there was heavy fighting in many cities.

title: PROSECUTOR'S PLEA SPARES MURDERER
description: TRENTON, March 29 (AP) The New Jersey Supreme Court has reduced a death sentence to life imprisonment for a con victed murderer at the recom mendation of the prosecutor

title: Savings Banks to Merge;
description: The Manhattan Savings Bank and the Brooklyn Savings Bank which together have assets of about $1.5billionannounced yesterday that they had agreed to merge.

title: An Ecumenical Concert
description: There was an expansive air of ecumenism about the program that Abraham Kap lan conducted at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday night. His Camerata Singers and Sym phony Orchestra followed Schubert's Roman Catholic Mass No. 2 in G with Ger shon Kingsley's Talmudically inspired oratorio What Is Man? Furthermore, in an at tempt to bridge the gap be tween instrumental genera tions, Mr. Kingsley's work employed not only voices and traditional instruments but also an electric guitar and two Moog sound synthesizers.

title: Theater Friends to Pay Burns Tribute April 6
description: A memorial tribute to David Burns will be held at the 46th Street Theater next Tuesday starting at 2:30 P.M.

title: TV: Tony Awards Will Be a Tough Act to Follow
description: Welcome to the theater, sang Lauren Bacall and, in one of those rare occasions on television, the fierce pride bubbling out of that invita tion was solidly justified. The setting was the Palace The atre, and the event was the 25th Annual Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards, broadcast live over the American Brodcasting Company's net work Sunday evening.

title: RUSSELL PETTENGILL
description: NEW HOPE, Pa., March 29 Russell A. Pettengill, an indus trial engineer, consultant in graphic arts and antiques col lector, died March 19 at his home here. He also lived at 140 East 39th Street, New York. His age was 83.

description: Hot pants and sarsapa rilla, birch beer and bikinis ere among the disparate wares for sale at the recent ly opened Agora Ice Cream Parlor and Boutique, 1550 Third Avenue (87th Street).

The book lists organizations, busi nesses, agencies and other in stitutions serving two million Spanishspeaking residents of the New YorkNew Jersey Connecticut metropolitan area.

title: Dodge Listing Gains
description: Heavy construction projects and a substantial rise in resi dential building lifted the Dodge index of construction in February to 126 per cent of the 1967 base period, the McGraw Hill Information Systems Com pany reported yesterday.

title: Theater: How the Other Half Loves Begins Run
description: Sex, in its most surpris ingly diluted form, is the bas ic constituent of Broadway farce. Alan Ayckbourn's play How the Other Half Loves, which opened last night at the Royale Theater, is to comedy what bouillon is to rare steak. But a lot of peo ple like bouillon, and I imag ine a lot of people will relish, in a gently massaging way, How the Other Half Loves.

title: Woman Seized in Kidnapping Charged in Another Case
description: A 51yearold woman arrested last week in the kidnapping of 2monthold infant was rear rested and charged with the kid napping last Dec. 18 of the 3 monthold son of a city fireman. Mrs. Frances Andrews of 338 14th Street in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn was charged yesterday with taking Gregory

title: Chrysler Financial Pressed In Selling Corporate Paper
description: The Chrysler Financial Cor porationwhich last week was stripped of its prime credit rating by the National Credit Office, a Dun & Bradstreet di visioncontinued yesterday to experience difficulty in selling its unsecured corporate notes to replace those that are com ing due.

description: News Analysis

title: A Chapter XI Reorganization Is Sought by Bermec Corp.
description: The Bermec Corporation said yesterday it was seeking per mission to reorganize under Chapter XI of the Federal bank ruptcy law.

title: Pennsylvania Sued on Tax
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 29 (AP)State Senator Richard A. Tilghman, a Republican, filed a suit today challenging the legality of Pennsylvania's new ly enacted income tax. The suit attacked the administra tion's 18month financing plan, charging that it was enacted before a balanced budget for the period was submitted. As a class action, the suit was on behalf of all taxpayers in the state.

title: Nixon's Aides Insist Drive In Laos Was Worth Price
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 President Nixon has begun to review the postmortem studies of the South Vietnamese inva sion of Laos, which cover some serious military misjudgments as well as claims of strategic benefit,
