description: BALTIMORE, March 29  Earl Monroe, one of the win ners and also one of the casualties, described yester day's National Basketball As sociation playoff game between the Bullets and the Philadelphia 76ers like this:

title: Judgment at Fort Benning
description: The Government prosecutor in his summary remarks told the sixofficer jury trying First Lieut. William Calley: You gentlemen are the conscience of the United States Army. You are the conscience of this country, Your duty is clear... to find the accused guilty as charged.

title: Occidental Petroleum Says Suit is Won Over Armour
description: LOS ANGELES, March 29 (UPI)  Occidental Petro leum Corporation said today it has won a victory in the law suit filed against it in 1964 by Armour & Co. of Chicago charging pirating of trade secrets in the chemical fer tilizer business.

title: Heavy Killing Reported
description: NEW DELHI, March 29In its battle to put down the inde pendence movement in East Pakistan, the Pakistani army has resorted to widespread kill ings of civilians, according to reports reaching here today from unimpeachable foreign diplomatic sources in Dacca.

title: 4 Dead and 5 Missing in a Fire That Destroys the Canandaigua Inn
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., March 28At least four per sons were dead and five oth ers missing after fire raged through the 117yearold Can andaigua Inn in this Finger Lakes community today.

title: Yankees Defeat Braves, 31, as Bahnsen Shuts Out Atlanta for six Innings
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 29While the Yankees were beating the Atlanta Braves, 3I, today, they an nounced that they had no win ner of the James P. Dawson Memorial Award.

title: RAYMOND POSTGATE, FOUNDED FOOD GUIDE
description: LONDON, March 29Ray mond Postgate, founder and editor of The Good Food Guide, died today in Canterbury, Kent. He was 74 years old.

title: Reagan Plans Asian Trip
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 29 (UPI)Gov. Ronald Reagan disclosed today that he intends to pay an official visit to Japan this fall and is thinking about extending the trip to Vietnam.

title: CHEMIST QUERIES AN ATOMIC THEORY
description: LOS ANGELES, March 29  A fundamental assumption of nuclear physics  the predict able decay rates of radioactive materials  has been opened to question on the basis of re search reported here today at the national meeting of the American Chemical Society.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 29 Nationalist China declared to day that it had severed diplo matic relations with Kuwait be cause of that country's most unfriendly act in recognizing Communist China.

title: Calley Family Gathers
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 29 (AP)Lieutenant Galley's family gathered today at the home of a sister, Mrs. Mary Keesling

title: ROBERT W. LOCKE OF M'GRAWHILL
description: Robert W. Locke, since 1968 executive vice president of the McGrawHill Book Company, died Sunday of a cerebral hemorrhage while vacationing with his family in Los Angeles. He was 44 years old and lived at Larger Cross Roads, Far Hills, N. J.

title: Industrial Guaranty Sued Stockholders for Fraud
description: MIAMI, March 29 (AP) Charging fraud by misrepre sentation, a group of stock holders has sued the Industrial Guaranty Bancorporation  a Florida bank stock holding company  and its principal officers for more than $1.15 million.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation announced yesterday in Houston the election of George F. Kirby as pres ident, succeeding B. D. Goodrich, who was made chairman and continues as chief executive offi cer. Mr. Goodrich suc ceeds George R. Brown, who retired from the chairmanship after serv ing continuously in the post since the company was founded in 1947. Mr. Brown will remain on the board of directors and will continue as chair man of the executive committee. Mr. Kirby, 54 years old, served as president of the Ethyl Corporation from June, 1964, till he joined Texas Eastern in January, 1970. Mr. Good rich, 57, has been associated with the diversified pipe line and transmission company since 1947 when he joined as vice president and chief engineer. He was made senior vice president in charge of all gas activities in 1958, became executive vice presi dent in 1963, and was elected president and chief executive officer in 1965.

title: Squash Racquets Winner
description: John Murphy of the Yale Club won the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association B cham pionship yesterday by defeating William. Miller of the Harvard, Club, 915, 1513, 1613, 156, at the New York Athletic Club.

title: State Narcotics Control Funds Among Targets of Budget Cuts
description: ALBANY, March, 29  State aid for narcotics control, a ma jor theme of last year's political campaign, would be sharply re duced under the Legislature's current budgetpruning plans.

title: The Dishonorable Budget
description: The State of New York has proposed don'tgivea damn budgets before, budgets which fail adequately fund programs essential to the urban welfare. It has even proposed doubledon'tgiveadamn budgets, budgets which neglect urban needs and also, rely so heavily on bonded indebtedness as to be profligate and unsound.

title: Europe's Farmers and the U.S.
description: The Common Market decision, after mass demonstra tions by farmers, to raise farm support prices and reform backward European agriculture contains a warning for the United States. The Administration has been seeking unrealistically to get the sixnation European Economic Community (E.E.C.) to reduce its prices and its Import duties on American farm products. Nothing is less likely. Other solutions must be sought.

title: New School Policy Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)Senator Henry M. Jack son, Democrat of Washington, proposed today that Indian schools be taken away from the Bureau of Indian Affairs and that Indian parents be given more say in how they are run.

title: CHANDLER ENTERS RACE IN KENTUCKY
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 29 A. B. Chandler, twice Governor of Kentucky, filed today to run in the gubernatorial election in November. He promised to cut taxes.

title: Egyptians End Their EightMonth Ban on Broadcasts by Palestinian Guerrillas
description: CAIRO, March 29 Unit ed Arab Republic restored radio broadcasting rights to the Pal estinian commando movement today, ending an eightmonth suspension during diplomatic efforts for a peaceful settle ment of the Arab conflict with Israel.

title: Bridge: Miracle Helps Dallas Team To Capture Vanderbilt Title
description: The most dramatic moment in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship in At lanta earlier this month occurred in the quarterfinal round. The world champion Dallas Aces seemed to be coasting into the semifinal round when they led by 27 international match points into the final session of 18 deals, but they were due for a shock.

title: Carr Top Choice
description: The National Basketball As sociation did not select the best players for the first round of its college draft yesterday, but picked rather those it was rea sonably sure would join the league.

title: ART STUDENT HELD WITH OPIUM CACHE
description: A 20yearold art student was arrested last night in his par ents Upper West Side brown stone with a kilo (2.2 pounds) of pure opium, 10 pounds of marijuana, a pound of hashish and a loaded pistol.

title: Sports of The Times
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29At one stop along the banquet circuit last winter Joe Torre of the Cardinals found himself on the same dais as Brooks Robinson of the Orioles. Naturally, they talked shop.

title: Advertising:
description: Has the new militancy of the Federal Trade Commis sion had an effect on adver tising agencies? You bet it has.

title: Knicks Draft Meminger;
description: ATLANTA, March 29  A satisfying draft session, all things considered, provided the New York Knicks with a pleas ing distraction from the more immediate tensions of the Na tional Basketball Association playoffs today.

title: Bigart Wins Award Of Reporter Group; Newsday Honored
description: Homer Bigart of The New York Times was among the 1970 awardwinners announced yesterday by the Newspaper Re porters Association.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Hurt in Flight Turbulence
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 29 (UPI)Two stewardesses and passenger aboard American Air lines Flight 276 from Nashville to Columbus were injured to day when the plane struck severe air turbulence. The stewardesses were Barbara Ki janka, 25 years old, and Lonnie Mervis, 25, both of Springfield, Va., and the passenger was Carie Sloss, 23, of Nashville.

title: Shift in Oil Industry Roles Seen
description: EVANSTON, Ill., March 29 Both oilproducing and oil consuming nations will play a greater direct role in the international petroleum busi ness in the years to conic, ac cording to a panel of noted economists, energy consul tants and corporate execu tives meeting today at North western University's trans portation center.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICES OF BONDS RETREAT BROADLY
description: Bond prices retreated across a broad front yesterday as the market awaited the first of this week's large new offerings. Trading activity was generally light.

title: HARRY L. WELKER
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 29Harry L. Welker, past pres ident of the Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood, died Friday in the Casey Nurs ing Home, Montclair. He was 88 years old.

title: RUSSIAN MOVE OPENS WAY FOR BIOLOGICAL ARMS BAN;
description: GENEVA, March 30In an unexpected turnabout, the Soviet Union announced a concession at the disarmament conference here today that could. lead to an early agreement on an international convention banning biological weapons.

title: Budgetary Idiocy in Albany
description: It is a measure of the confusion in Albany that the state's fiscal year runs out at midnight tonight, with no one sure what, if anything, Governor Rockefeller and the leaders of the Republican majority in the Legislature have agreed on in the way of a new budget and new taxes. There was a flurry of activity yesterday, with the Big Six mayors arriving in Albany. Republican county leaders were also called in. Rumors flourished in the absence of facts.

title: About Motor Sports
description: The Questor Grand Prix gratified its promoters and sponsors, but as a race it was a bit of con, a ruse that was aggravated by inept television coverage. The race, run Sunday at Ontario (Calif,) Motor Speedway, even raises a question whether an authentic Grand Prix for Formula One cars can prosper in Southern California. Already the marketers are cast ing about for something to flesh out the Grand Prix championship race scheduled for April 9, 1972, at Ontario a doubleheader, a prelimnary, anything to distract the customers from the fact that a small number of tiny cars are lost in that vast infield of the oval track. Moreover, Sundays race did not do Formula A racing any good.

title: BLUES SINE KINGS ON LATE GOAL, 43
description: ST. LOUIS, March 30 (AP)Garry Unger's 27th goat of the season at 17:44 of the third period lifted the St. Louis Blues to a 43 victory over the Los Angeles Kings in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: Economic Analysis
description: A major problem facing Government policy makers today is, how to induce consumers and businessmen to shift their demand for more liquid assets toward a demand for more real goods and services. The financial communityand many

title: AGREEMENTS AVERT GAS COMPANY STRIKE
description: A strike against the Brooklyn Union Gas Company was averted last night when members of two unions voted to accept a new contract.

title: U.S. ACTOR IN ITALY FREED ON DRUCCOUNT
description: SALERNO, Italy, March 30A court here acquitted William Berger, a 42yearold actor from the United States, of a charge of narcotics possession today and ordered him released after almost eight months in detention.

title: Text of Draft Convention Proposed at Geneva Talks
description: GENEVA, March 30 (Reuters)Following, in official translation, is the text of a draft convention on biological weapons proposed at the Geneva Disarmament Conference today by Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Rumania, and the Soviet Union:

title: 2 Seized Detergents to Bear Warning Label for Public
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration announced today that EcoloG and Bohack nophosphate laundry detergents, seized by a Federal marshal on March 8, could be returned to the market with a warning label.

title: Jackson Killed in Crash
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 30 (UPI)Charles N. Jackson, a former chief mechanic for Jim Hurtubise when the latter was on the Grand National stock car circuit, was killed today when a car he was driving struck a railroad overpass support. It was Jackson's 42d birthday. He had been working at a garage and on the car that he was driving.

title: Protest by Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 30  For the second time in three days, the Pakistani Government today protested to the Indian Government over reports and actions in India that were considered here to be favorable to East Pakistani forces.

title: Budget Vote Roundup Starts in Albany
description: ALBANY, March 30After days, of mathematics, Republican legislative leaders turned to psychology tonight in their effort to pass a budget by midnight tomorrow.

title: EXPLUMBER ADDS TO 1HORSE STABLE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., March 30 A journeyman plumber earns about $8, an hour. A journeyman conditioner of trotters and pacers charges about $3 as a daily training fee plus 5 per cent of all earnings for each standardbred under his charge.

title: 2 Robbed of $8,600 Payroll
description: Three armed men escaped with an $8,600 payroll yesterday morning after holding up two employes of the Federal Distributing Corporation ah 503 Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn.

title: Stewart to Give Eulogy For Hayward on Friday
description: A memorial service for Leland Hayward, the Broadway and Hollywood showman, will be held on Friday noon in St. James' Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street.

title: RAY DONLEY, 40, DIES; ACOUSTICS ENGINEER
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 30  Ray Donley an acoustical engineer, died Saturday of a sudden illness at his home, 672 Valley Road. He was 40 years old.

title: Review of Powers Asked
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)Bills to establish a Joint Committee on Impoundment of Funds were introduced today by Representative Charles E. Bennett, Democrat of Florida, and Senator Sam J. Ervin, Democrat of North Carolina. The committee would review the President's power to terminate Federal projects for which appropriations had been made or withhold funds from programs.

title: Debuts Are Made By Three Singers. In Met's Giovanni
description: The Metropolitan Opera's production of Don Giovanni is one of the jewels of its repertory. When three of the major roles are taken by singers who have never done them before with the company, one feels a great sense of anticipation.

title: A MUSIC PREMIERE AT TRINITY CHURCH
description: The weekday noontime concerts in Trinity Church at Broadway and Wall Street, usually devoted to organ recitals or chamber music, turned up an impressive world premiere yesterday. It was Epitaph for This World and Time, a work for three choirs and three organs by lain Hamilton, a Scottish composer who has taught at Duke University. His piece was commissioned for the university chapel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rotz Returns to Risking Spills Again
description: John Rotz returned to work at Aqueduct yesterday, equipped with the same crash helmet that may have saved his life in a spill here two weeks ago.

title: TATSCASE JURORS FIRM ON DECISION Death Penalty for Manson and Women Called Fair
description: LOS ANGELES, March 30Jurors who voted the death penalty yesterday for Charles M. Manson and the young women who were convicted of the seven TateLabianca murders with him explained today their reasoning on the decision.

title: Police Seek to Better Tenant Safety
description: When the burglar alarm rang on the penthouse floor of 710 West End Avenue the other night, a tenant in his underwear peered into the hallway, an iron bar in his hands.

title: General Tire Lifts Earnings in Quarter
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company showed a recovery in its first fiscal quarter, ended Feb. 28, with sales and earnings well ahead of a year earlier, reflecting improved results of some divisions. The company is an important factor in rubber fabricating, a leader in rockets and propellants through AerojetGeneral, a producer of plastics and chemicals and an operator of broadcasting stations through RKO General.

title: Penn Central Asks Court to Bar Strike
description: The Penn Central railroad moved yesterday to block a strike threatened by five marine unions opposed to the handling of cargo by a new type of ship.

title: 2 KEY BOND TYPES GET HIGHER RATES
description: Interest rates were increased yesterday for two key types of bonds  Bell System tripleA corporate issues and doubleA taxexempt state bonds.

title: RORY BLOCK MIXES THE BLUES AND RAGS
description: An unusual mixture of country blues and piano rags transposed to acoustical guitar was played and sung by a slim, young, darkhaired girl named Rory Block on Monday evening at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth. Street.

title: Canadian Diplomat, Born in China, Gets Envoy's Job There
description: OTTAWA, March 30Ralph E. Collins, a senior career dipJomat who was born in China and speaks Chinese, will be Canada's first Ambassador to the Peking Government.

title: STARS DOWN NETS IN 11597 CONTEST
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 30, (AP)The Utah Stars scored 38 points in the final quarter tonight to end their American Basketball Association regularseason competition with a, 11597 victory over the New York Nets.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a working newsman, I'm all for freedom of the press. Better yet, press both free and responsible. Criticism, to be sure; but constructive criticism  and rational alternatives. No publication or network, however dominant its position, can long deserve public trust if its bias and prejudice keep showing through.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It would serve no useful purpose at this late date to revert to the timeworn argument about the justification of our intervention in Vietnam in the first instance. Whether justified or not, events seem to have proved that this war was a tragic mistake. And the issue with which we are squarely confronted today is haw long we are to remain prisoners of this mistake.

title: Councilman Shows A Gaming Machine To Revive Fun City
description: A City Councilman displayed a gaming machine in the rotunda of City Hall yesterday as the type of device he would like to have installed in bars, tobacco shops and eventually his proposed Las Vegas of the East on North Brother Island in the East River.

title: Man in the News
description: MOSCOW, March 30Leonid I. Brezhnev, who delivered the main report to the opening session of the 24th Soviet Communist party Congress today, is clearly the most important man in the world Communist movement and first among equals in the Kremlin leadership. Ex cept for the small core privy to the secret world of higher party politics, however, few know with cer tainty whether Mr. Brezhnev should be regarded more as the first or more as an equal in the Politburo, the 11man body that controls the more than 14 million Soviet Communist party members and, through them, the life of the country's 241 million people.

title: HOUSE MAY PASS SERVICE PAY RISE
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The House of Representatives began debate today on the draft law, and there was no evidence of strong opposition from the Nixon Administration to substantial increases in military pay and allowances.

title: BREZHNEV STATES PROGRAM
description: MOSCOW, March 30Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, asserted today that the Soviet Union was determined to ease world tensions and promised the Soviet people that further steps would be taken to improve their standard of living.

title: Ashe Is Upset by El Shafei In $50,000 Tennis, 63, 63
description: MIAMI, March 30 (AP) Ismail El Shafei of Egypt used a strong backhand to score a dramatic upset of Arthur Ashe, 63, 63, in the first round of the $50,000 Aventura world tennis classic tonight.

title: WEST COAST STRIKE BY TEACHERS GROWS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 (APThe Classroom Teachers Association voted 779 to 479 tonight to join the weekold strike by the San Francisco Federation of Teachers.

title: U.S. Is Cool to Brezhnev's Call For a 5Power Nuclear Parley
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The United States indicated today that it sees more promise in the disarmament talks in Vienna and Geneva than in a conference of five nuclear powers proposed by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.

title: Jack Cohn Grant Is Set Up
description: A twoyear grant of $15,000 has been made by the Motion Picture Pioneers, a group of filmindustry veterans, to the American. Film Institute for the creation of a Jack Cohn Fellowship in memory of the late chairman of Columbia Pictures. Edna Gipson, 23, of Los Angeles, is the winner of the first fellowship. A writer now working on her first novel, about her own coming of age in Los Angeles's Watts section, Miss Gipson will use her, fellowship for screen writing at the A.F.I. Center for Advanced Studies in Los Angeles.

title: New Orders in February Rose as Inventories Fell
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Manufacturers' new orders rose moderately in February and inventories declined, the Commerce Department reported to day.

title: Bill on TaxExempt Status
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)  Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, introduced a bill today permitting public interest law firms, consumer and environmental groups, civil rights organizations and similar groups to present their views to Congress without risking loss of their taxexempt status.

title: Two Fined for Obscenity
description: The publisher and editor of Screw magazine were fined $1,500 each yesterday for publishing obscene material. The publisher, Jim Buckley, 27 years old, and the editor, Al Goldstein, 35, chose to pay the fines rather than serve six months in jail.

title: Bridge: Unusual 2 NoTrump Overcall Has Supporters and Objectors
description: Accurate descriptive bidding often helps a partnership to reach the best final contract, but it can recoil when the play starts by giving an opponent a blueprint for his operations. This objection is often leveled against the unusual two notrump overcall, used to show minorsuit length when an opponent has opened the bidding in a major.

title: Rabbi Albert Mandelbaum Dies; Led Rabbinical Council of U.S.
description: Rabbi Albert N. Mandelbaum, formerly chairman of the executive board of the Rabbinical Council of America, died yesterday at the Abraham Jacobi Hospital of the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 3593 Bainbridge Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Theater: The Red White and Black
description: The enormous problem with political theater is that one never knows whether it ought to be more political than theater, or more theater than political. Eric Bentley's musical rollcall, The Red White and Black, which opened last night at the Players Theater in Macdougal Street, is a perfect example of unalloyed political commitment.

title: Yelverton's NewCareer: Switch to the Backcourt
description: A new basketball life starts tonight for Charlie Yelverton.

title: Amman Accuses Fedayeen
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 30, (Reuters)The Jordanian Government today accused the fedayeen of more acts of sabotage and denied charges by Yasir Arafat that it had carried out a massacre in Amman.

title: Ariodante Performed
description: There is no entirely satisfactory way today to put on the Handel operas that were written for castratos, those neutered male altos whose feats fathered great musical legends, if nothing else. But such an opera as Ariodente, which the Handel Society of New York presented in concert form on Monday night at Carnegie Hall, contains too many gorgeous pages to be allowed to sit on the shelf forever, no matter what vocal expedients must be resorted to in reviving it.

title: Congress Is Asked For $97.3Million To Eliminate SST
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)The Transportation Department asked Congress today for $97.3million with which to terminate its supersonic transport development program.

title: John Rockefeller 3d Tours Fort Carson And Hires Draftee
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, March 30  John D. Rockefeller 3d today made a oneday tour of Fart Carson, said he had found the new Army encouraging and announced that he had hired one of the commanding general's advisers, William J. Rosendahl, a draftee.

title: Knicks Win, 113107, and Take 31 Lead
description: ATLANTA, March 30Winning another fourthquarter showdown by pulling away from a tie in the last four minutes, the New York Knicks took a 31 lead in their fourofsevengame National Basketball Association playoff series tonight by beating the Atlanta Hawks, 113107.

title: City Plans AntiCar Booth At Auto Show in Coliseum
description: The city's Environmental Protection Administration is taking its campaign against automobiles right into what Jerome Kretehmer, the Administrator of the agency, calls the lion's denthe auto show.

title: A Gentleman's Gentleman's Car
description: REMSENBURG, L.I.If the late Henry Francis Lyte (17931857) wrote that wellknown line Change and decay in all around I see in the eighteenfifties (which he did), how even more forcibly would he have expressed himself if he had managed to survive till 1971. It is my considered opinion, and my opinions ere not to be sneezed at, especially when considered, that change and decay have hit par. Change? How about that decimal stuff in England? Thank goodness I am not writing this piece for an English editor. If I were, he would take advantage of my shakiness in mathematics and pay me three pennies, kidding me that that was an excellent price under the new coinage.

title: Campaign Spending Reform
description: The Nixon Administration is either inefficient obstructive in its approach to the important problem of excessive spending in political campaigns.

title: Market Place: Margin Woes With Javelin
description: If you are a shareholder in Canadian Javelin and you have the shares in a margin account, you are no doubt deeply concerned.

title: Merger News
description: Directors' of Wilson & Co., Inc., the meatpacking company, have approved a proposal to acquire 1.15 million shares of its common stock from LingTemcoVought, Inc., for $15million. The deal is subject to acceptance by LTV directors.

title: Many in U.S. Perturbed By Conviction of Calley
description: The reaction yesterday of public officials and private citizens around the country to the conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. indicated that many Americans were perturbed and for a variety of reasons.

title: Executive Changes
description: Baker, Weeks & Co., Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the appointment of Arthur A. McLaughlin as chairman and chief executive officer. Charles H. Mott, currently executive vice president and chairman of the executive committee, succeeds Mr. McLaughlin as president. John J. Henneberry, formerly chairman has become chairman emeritus and continues as member of the executive committee after serving as the chief executive officer for the past five years. Dillard P. Spriggs, continues as executive vice president and Dugald A. Fletcher, now senior vice president, has been named treasurer.

title: 10 SINGERS WILL VIE IN AUDITIONS AT MET
description: Ten young singers have been selected to compete in the finals of the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions to be held at the opera house on Sunday at 2 P.M.

title: Thurmond, 68, a Father
description: GREENWOOD. S. C., March 30 (AP)Strom Thurmond, 68yearold Republican Senator from South Carolina, and his wife, Nancy, a 24yearold former South Carolina beauty queen, became the parents of A 7pound 11ounce girl today.

title: Delegate Works Hard On Job and for Party
description: MOSCOW, March 30Aleksandr V. Lebedev, an oilrefinery foreman in Moscow, is one of some 5,000 delegates who gathered today in the Kremlin for the 24th Congress of the Soviet Communist party.

title: Bonn Aide Flies to Prague
description: BONN, March 30 (Reuters)Paul Frank, State Secretary at the West German Foreign Ministry, flew to Prague today to begin preliminary talks on a treaty to establish normal relations with Czechoslovakia. He was to stay for about 48 hours and to confer with Deputy Foreign Minister Milan Klusak.

title: Dr. Geroid Robinson, 78, Dies; Began Russian Institute Here
description: Dr. Geroid T. Robinson, founder and first director of the Russian Institute of Columbia University, died of cancer yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Police and Fire Raises of $1,900 Urged
description: The special impasse panel in the contract dispute between the city and the uniformed services has recommended a $1,900 pay increase over 27 months for police and firemen on top of a new salary base of $12,150.

title: Excerpts From Brezhnev's Report to the 24th Soviet Communist Party Congress
description: Following, as distributed in English by, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, are excerpts front the report presented to the 24th Soviet Communist party Congress at its opening yesterday in Moscow Leonid I. Brezhnev, General Secretary of the party:

title: In the Name of Pakistan
description: Acting in the name of God and a united Pakistan, forces of the West Pakistandominated military government of President Yahya Khan have dishonored both by their ruthless crackdown on the Bengali majority seeking a large measure of autonomy for their homeland in the country's eastern region.

title: BANK OF AMERICA HELPS OLYMPICS
description: The Bank of America said yesterday that part of the commission it receeived on domestic sales of its travelers checks during the next 18 months would go to the Olympic Committee fund for the 1972 games.

title: 2 Blasts Damage Communist and U.S.Cuban offices
description: Bombs went off here yesterday at the Communist party headquarters and the United StatesCuba Health. Exchange office in what the police called apparently, unrelated explosions.

title: COPPER FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Prices of copper futures rose yesterday for the second, day in a row on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., here.

title: Nixon to Announce New Cut in Troops on April 7
description: SAN CLEMENTE Calif., March 30  President Nixon plans to announce the next round of American troop withdrawals from Indochina in a live television address the evening of April 7.

title: At the Pakistan Border, Dust and an Eerie Quiet
description: TUNGI, India, March 30The ground is flat and parched here. Dry, gray, barren riceland, punctuated by clumps of bushes and trees with leaves coated with dust, waits for the monsoon due sometime next month to bring it back to life.

title: Hijacked Filipino Airliner, Freed by Red China, Arrives in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, March 31Communist China today released the Philippine Air Lines aircraft that was diverted to Canton yesterday by five young Filipino hijackers.

title: Brezhnev speaks
description: Those who expected major surprises or dramatic changes in policy from Leonid I. Brezhnev's keynote address to the Soviet Communist party Congress yesterday were disappointed. The biggest surprise was that the speech was televised live, a fact probably attributable to Mr. Brezhnev's interest in enhancing his image with the Soviet masses. But there was no reinstatement of Stalin or other comparable major change in the party line.

title: Japan Acts on Auto Deals
description: TOKYO, March 30 (UPI)The Japanese Cabinet today made the formal decision to allow foreign investment in the automobile manufacturing field in Japan effective Thursday. The move, long anticipated, will allow foreign car makers to engage in joint automobile manufacturing enterprises in Japan in which the foreign investors can hold up to 50 per cent of the stock.

title: DR. DAVID ALLMAN, SURGEON, 79, DIES
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 30 Dr. David B. Allman, a prominent surgeon who served a term as the 11th president of the American Medical Association in 1957.58, died today in Atlantic City Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Brigantine.

title: Advertising:
description: Like the swallows returning to Capistrano, the staff of New York magazine and their friends will flock back to the Four Seasons tomorrow for the annual birthday breakfast.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: March 30, 1971

title: Senate Rejects Plan to Extend Jobless Benefits for 13 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The Senate turned down today a proposal to pay 13 weeks of additional unemployment compensation to workers who have been laid off and have exhausted their benefits.

title: Sugar Beet Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)The House Rules Committee cleared for the House today a bill to allow sugar beet growers in three Western states to come under the feed grain subsidy program. The vote was 7 to 6, and it signaled a tough fight ahead in the House.

title: Thieu Reports a Raid on Base in Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 31 (AP)President Nguyen Van Thieu announced that South Vietnamese commandos raided a North Vietnamese base area on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos today

title: Common Market to End Duties for Poorer Lands
description: BRUSSELS, March 30Hoping to spur similar action by other affluent nations, the six Governments of the European Economic Community decided today to give generalized trade preferences to developing countries beginning July 1.

title: MUSKIE REGRETS SILENCE ON WAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 Senator Edmund S. Muskie is sorry now that he did not make public as far back as 1965 his real doubts about our involvement in the Vietnam war. Instead, he said, he voiced his concerns privately to President Johnson.

title: Legislature Receives Measures Implementing Governor's Welfare Reforms
description: ALBANY, March 30Moving quickly to implement his welfare reform program, Governor Rockefeller had a bill submitted to the Legislature today to prohibit welfare payments to anyone who voluntarily left his Job or reduced his earnings to qualify for welfare or for higher payments than he was getting.

title: Steelworkers Link Demands to Can Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 30I. W. Abel, president of the, United Steelworkers of America, said today that two days of talks with 600 local presidents had convinced him that he could not come back with a contract that offered less than that won by workers in the can industry.

title: BULLS TOP LAKERS FOR 22 SERIES TIE
description: CHICAGO, March 30 (AP)Bob Love, scoring 17 of his 36 points in the final period, lifted Chicago to a 112102 victory over Los Angeles tonight. The triumph sent the Bulls into a tie with the Lakers in their National Basketball Association Western Conference semifinal playoff series at two games each.

title: Text of Calley Statement
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 30Following is the text of a statement to the court today by First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.:

title: STOCKS IN LONDON RISE 20.5 POINTS
description: The Financial Times Index of 30 industrial stocks traded on the London Stock Exchange rose 20.5 points to 352.2 in afterhour trading yesterday following news of the new budget.

title: Welfare Reform Coalition Urges More Liberal Bill Than Mills's
description: WASHINGTON, March 30A broad range of civic and religious groups called today for a welfare reform program that would provide more help for poor people and poor states than the one developed by Representative Wilbur D. Mills in the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: PROF. JOHN STORCK, ONCE AT COLUMBIA
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 30 Dr. John Storck, a versatile scholar who taught at Columbia University and later at Sarah Lawrence College, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 74 years old.

title: Emile L. Rimbault Jr. Is Dead; Mining Company Execaiive, 51
description: Emile L. Rimbault Jr., a career executive of the American Smelting and Refining Company, died yesterday at Morristown (N. J.) Memorial Hospital, after an illness of several months.

title: Yankees Lose to enators, 9 to 7, in a Windy Florida Farewell
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 30  The Carolina Fast Freight Company took Fritz Peterson's bicycle, Mike Kekich's motorcycle and, various high chairs, strollers and playpens back to New York, but it left the Florida wind behind and that was the cause of the Yankees' zany farewell to their spring training camp today.

title: Canucks Down Stars, 21
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn. March 30 (UPI)Rosey Paiment'vsneondperiod goal from 20 feet out gave the Vancouver Canucks a 21 victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

title: Satellite Operation For Gauging Earth Ends After 4 Years
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)  The Commerce Department announced today the completion of what it described as the most accurate measurement ever made to determine the earth's size and shape.

title: U.S. Bombs Guns in DMZ
description: SAIGON, Wednesday, March 31Four American warplanes bombed a North Vietnamese artillery site in the northern half of the demilitarized zone yesterday, the United States command reported.

title: EqualizationTax Extension Is Passed by the Congress
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The House and the Senate completed action today on a bill to extend for two more years the interestequalization tax on the purchase of foreign securities.

title: Part of Route 4 seized
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, March 31 (AP)North Vietnamese troops yesterday reportedly seized a 10mile stretch of Route 4, Cambodia's principal road link between the capital and the deepwater port of Kompong Som.

title: Brezhnev Says Economic Policy Is an Emphatic Turn in Favor of the Consumer
description: MOSCOW, March 30Leonid I, Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, told the nation today that Moscow's current economic policy represented an emphatic turn in favor of the consumer and he warned officials that they would have to adapt to the new line or go.

title: Lockheed and Britain Agree on Rolls
description: The British Government and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation conditionally agreed yesterday on terms for keeping alive the RollsRoyce jet engine developed for Lockheed's threejet airbus.

title: No Decision on Airlift
description: WASHINGTON. March United States officials day that the Administraion had made no final decision on the recommendation by Mr. Blood, the consul general, that American women, children and some of the men be evacuated from East Pakistan.

title: Bucks Take 3.0 Lead
description: MADISON, Wis., March 30 (AP)Two San Francisco turnovers late in the game helped the Milwaukee Bucks grab a 114102 playoff victory over the Warriors tonight.

title: NEW ARK TO SUSPEND 347 IN SCHOOL STRIKE
description: NEWARK, March 30The Board of Education announced today that it was suspending 347 of the teachers participating the strike by the Newark Teachers Union, now in its ninth week.

title: Impact of Calley Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Mar 30Historically, war crimes trials have been the business of victors. The United. States has broken with the tradition by convicting in midwar one of its own men, First Lieut. William L. Caney Jr., of murder. ing Vietnamese civilians, and thus has confronted its footsoldiers and its commanders with a series of legal conflicts. As so often happens, the pinch appears tobe primarily upon the foot soldiers. Lieutenant Calley's conviction demonstrated, if there was any doubt, that the excuse that I was just following orders will not work. He contended that he had been ordered to waste the villagers at Mylai, but the Uniform Code of Military. Justice says that this is no defense if a man of ordinary sense and understanding would know [the order] to be illegal.

title: Profits Cheer 2 Bank Meetings
description: The two largest banking concerns in New York City held their annual stockholders' meetings yesterday. Both the First National City Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation told their stockholders that profits in the last three months were up sharply from the comparable period last year.

title: ANTIWAR TEACHIN ON AGAIN AT N.Y.U.
description: With frequent allusions to gloom and frustration and with just as frequent calls for a revivified broadbased, antiAdministration effort, the Vietnam antiwar teachin returned yesterday to New York University.

title: State Budget Cuts Held a Threat To City's New Rent Program
description: Albert A. Walsh, the city's Housing and Development Administrator, warned yesterday that state budget cuts proposed by legislative leaders in Albany would prevent the city from implementing its new rent law.

title: $3MILLION ERROR CORRECTED BY CITY
description: City auditors have discovered $3.7million in city funds improperly deposited in a bank account of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the quasiindependent agency that operates the city's 18 public hospitals.

title: Miss Streisand Signed
description: Barbra Streisand has been signed to star in A Glimpse of Tiger for Warner Bros. The screenplay by Herman Rancher, is a black comedy about two New Yorkers and their battles with the Establishment. It originally starred Elliott Gould, and was directed by Anthony Harvey, but was halted several wee's ago. In reactivating the project, the studio said filming would start within the next three months.

title: 7 Are Killed in Boston Fire; Officials Fear Toll Will Rise
description: BOSTON, Wednesday, March 31 (AP)Seven persons died in a fivealarm fire early today in a fivestory brick apartment building, and fire officials said they feared the death count may rise to 13.

title: Saigon G.I.'s Indignant Over Galley Ruling
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 30The immediate reaction of many G.I.'s here to the conviction yesterday of First Lieut. William Calley Jr. wit indignation.

title: Sterling Question Is Raised by France
description: BRUSSELS, March 30France succeeded today in injecting the question of the reserve role of the pound sterling into the European Economic Community's membership negotiations with Britain.

title: RED SOX ACQUIRE HITTING CATCHER
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 30 (AP)The Boston Red Sox acquired a herdhitting catcher, Duanajosephson, from the Chicago White Sox today and promptly announced they were not through wheeling and dealing.

title: CHARLES C. HIGHLEY
description: GLEN RIDGE, N. J., March 30Charles C. Highley, who retired in 1966 as head of the Highley Fuel Company in Newark, died today in his home at 349 Ridgewood Avenue, after long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: South Africa Bank Rate Up
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 30 (Reuters) South Africa today raised the bank rate from 5 per cent to 6 per cent.

title: Some Budget Cuts Listed
description: ALBANY, March 30The following table shows the impact of budget cuts recommended by Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders. In many cases, department budgets or state aid to localities are still higher, even after the reductions, than the current rate of spending.

title: Books of The Times
description: BOSS. Richard J. Daley of Chicago. By Mike Royko. 215 pages. Dutton. $5.95.

title: Calley Pleads for Understanding
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 30Gasping for breath, First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. made a final plea for understanding today as he faced the military jury that convicted him yesterday of the premeditated murder of at least 22 South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai.

title: Class 44: Weekly Study at Local Parochial School
description: Once a week six members of Class 44 leave school an hour early and cross Lexington Avenue to St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic School where they are led, gently but firmly, into discussions of feelings that wax and wane inside them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In these times when New York City faces crises in the areas of finances and pollution, why isn't a massive campaign instituted to fine litterbugs? A similar campaign to combat illegally parked cars proved most successful. Certainly the necessity for such programs as these cannot be denied, and the effort of implementation would be minimal.

title: BRONSON RAGAN, 56, A CHURCH ORGANIST
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., March 30 Bronson Ragan, organist for the Church of the Holy Trinity (Episcopal), 316 East 88th Street, New York, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 56 years old and lived at 215 Rahway Avenue.

title: Haywood, Rockets Settle Out of Court And Suit ls Dropped
description: LOS ANGELES, March 30 (AP)The Denver Rockets of the American Basketball Association and their former star, Spencer Haywood, settled their breachofcontract suit today. A Federal jury trying the case was dismissed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The charade in the negotiations with the city's uniformed personnel continues. The curtain on the final act is now raised, and the show will end with a resounding smash hita hit for the unions and a smash for the taxpayers, who will undoubtedly pay through the nose for the privilege of enjoying the pleasures of Fun City.

title: Baruch College Honors Tony, the Elevator Man
description: The students jammed into the small lounge, and still more came between classes, to honor Anthony J. Ermilio, who for 23 years, they said, has made riding the old, cramped elevators at Bernard Baruch College bearable.

title: JOHNSON STOPPED ON CUT EYE IN 3D
description: Harold Johnson's aging skin sabotaged the former world lightheavyweight champion's comeback appearance last night at Sunnyside Garden.

title: Shannon Resigns as Coach
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., March 30 (AP)Howie Shannon, the Virginia Tech basketball coach. resigned today to become a member of the physical education faculty.

title: MISS BEALS SHOWS WARMTH IN DANCE
description: Improvisation when it is on target has the look of inevitability and when it is not, benevolently marks time for the special moment. Margaret Beals presented a program of dance and music improvisation Monday evening at the Cubiculo that struck fire with rewarding frequency. She was assisted by the musicians Carol Tenney, Gwendolyn Watson, Bill Wood and Collin Walcott, and her lighting designs were prepared by Gary Harris, David Segal and Ken Billington.

title: Correction Chief Ousted
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 30 (AP)The Arkansas Board of Correction, bowing to legislative pressure, voted 3 to 1 last night to dismiss Robert Sarver from the correction commissioner post he had held since Nov. 15, 1968. John Haley of Little Rock, chairman of the board, said legislative intransigience was the dominate factor, rather than professional deficiences on Mr. Sarvar's part.

title: Rangers Adopt Plan to Aid Fans and Foil Scalpers
description: In an effort to keep Ranger playoff tickets out of the hands of scalpers and avoid the fiasco that surrounded the Knicks' playoff sale, the Rangers will offer Stanley Cup seats to the public tomorrow morning only through telephone orders and Ticketron outlets.

title: Victories at Lake Michigan
description: In what might be called an environmental drama three acts, a determined group of conservationists and the Environmental Protection Agency have gone far keep Lake Michigan from going the way of Lake Erie.

title: SENATOR DENIES OIL IS ISSUE IN VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Senator Philip A. Hart said today that recent articles raising the possibility that oil reserves off the coast of South Vietnam are the real reason for American involvement in Southeast Asia were inaccurate and misleading.

title: Month's End
description: Today is the end of Red Cross monththe month in which the Red Cross conducts its annual community appeal to supplement funds raised in the business community through the United Fund of Greater New York. Your contributions will help the Red Cross develop new services and continue to provide emergency assistance to the victims of fires, explosions and other disasters; collect blood; help servicemen and veterans; provide firstaid, watersafety and homenursing training and conduct youth programs.

title: Army Orders the Seizure of Antiwar Mail Sent to G.I.'s in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, March 30A confidential Army directive obtained from Vietnam shows that Army commanders have been ordered to intercept and confiscate personal, firstclass mail containing antiwar or other dissident publications sent to soldiers there.

title: Shortage of Trout Linked to Shortage of Money
description: Fewer dollars in Albany will mean fewer fish in Westchester tomorrow when the trout fishing season opens. Because of lack of manpower, the Department of Environmental Conservation has been unable to stock Westchester streams with hatchery trout this spring.

title: BALANCE IS URGED IN GAS REGULATION
description: EVANSTON, Ill., March 30Federal Power Commissioner John A. Carver Jr. said today that any price relief to secure increased supplies of natural gas must be undertaken in the context of continued regulation.

title: Ousted Vice President of Iraq Is Slain by 2 Gunmen in Kuwait
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 30 A former Iraqi Vice President and air marshal, Hardan Takriti, was assassinated today in Kuwait, the Kuwait radio announced.

title: TV: An Imaginative Tour Through Scotland Yard
description: One convenient way of getting from the Louvre in Paris to Scotland Yard in London would be to join the agreeable company of television producer Lucy Jarvis and writer Sidney Carroll, Their special on the French museum has already garnered several industry awards, and last night at 8 o'clock they came up with a rare inside tour of the extraordinary British police unit, also presented as a National Broadcasting Company news special.

title: Bullets Rout 76ers, 120105, for 31 Playoff Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 30The closely officiated game that Coach Jack Ramsay of the Philadelphia 76ers had been hoping for materialized tonight, but the bulk of the fouls were called on his team in a 120105 loss to the Baltimore Bullets at the Spectrum.

title: Humphrey to Decide This Year on '72
description: WASHINGTON, March 30senator Hubert H. Humphrey told a group of college students today that he would reach a decision on whether to run for the Presidency towards the end of the year, after he sees how the other Democratic candidates are faring.

title: Former A.B.C. Executive Given 5 Years' Probation
description: Thomas G. Sullivan, a former executive with American Broadcasting CompanyTelevision, was sentenced to five years on probation yesterday after being found guilty of attempting to extort $6,500 from a fellow executive.

title: Mexico and U.S. Say Cooperation in Drive on Narcotics Is at Highest Level
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The chief law enforcement officers of the United States and Mexico agreed today that cooperation between their Governments has reached its highest level in the war on illegal narcotics, dangerous drugs and marijuana.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Once again, The Times lashes out at the city's firefighters in an attempt to find a convenient scapegoat for the city's financial plight. In an editorial of March 13, excoriating the attempts of the Uniformed Firefighters Association to secure fair and equitable pay and pension benefits for the only group whose workload has increased to a staggering level, nothing is mentioned of the great chunk taken out of our city's budget by its ancillary forces.

title: Grant Aids Fight on Drugs
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., March 30 The Union County Prosecutor's office here today announced the receipt of a $110,632 grant from the United States Department of Justice to form a narcotics control strike force under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. The Prosecutor, Karl Asch, said the funds would enable the purchase of a mobile laboratory to aid in drug identification and to speed processing of cases.

title: Israeli, Here, Bids Soviet Permit Jews to Emigrate
description: Menahem Begin, leader of Israel's Gahal bloc, a hardline opposition group, said here last night that the question of permitting Soviet Jews to go to Israel was the great historic issue facing the Soviet Union, the Jewish people and the free world.

title: SPECIALTY STOCKS DOMINATE MARKET
description: It was a market of specialty stocks yesterday as the broad indicators continued to display only token changes.

title: Horses and Carriages For Waterloo Benefit
description: An expensively mounted parade of privately owned show horses, antique carriages and their owners proceeded down Seventh Avenue to Times Square last night on behalf of the movie Waterloo and the restoration of Waterloo, N. J.

title: Laotians Reported Checked
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 30, (AP)A Laotian drive against enemy troops menacing Luang Prabang was reported checked today by North Vietnamese dug in three miles north of the royal capital in northern Laos.

title: Council Approves Corona Compromise
description: King Solomon would have been befuddled by the problem of Corona, Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. said yesterday as the City Council voted approval of the socalled Corona compromise.

title: Mother Tells of Warning
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)  The mother of an American prisoner of war in Vietnam said today that an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation warned her to have nothing to do with the pacifist group that relays mail between the prisoners and their families.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 31, 1971

title: SIX MAYORS WARN OF MASS LAYOFFS
description: ALBANY, March 30The Mayors of the state's six largest cities warned the Governor and the Legislature yesterday that there would be mass layoffs of city employes If the level of aid to the cities was, reduced from the 21 per cent of state incometax revenues stipulated by the Legisiature last year.

title: Senate Committee Backs '48 Treaty Against Genocide
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today approved the 22yearold United Nations treaty making it an international crime to attempt the destruction of entire national, ethnic, racial or religious groups. The vote was 10 to 4.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I should like to congratulate the House Armed Services Committee for recommending a $2.6billion military pay raise. The low wages which presently exist consign our military men to poverty and decidedly deter volunteers. Not only is it just that recruits should receive higher pay, but higher pay will reduce this country's need to rely on conscription. The House of Representatives, the Senate and the President should affirm this action.

title: I.D.S. Says It Did Not Act On Information on Pennsy
description: Investors Diversified Services, Inc., categorically denied yesterday that it or any of the mutual funds for which it acts as investment adviser traded on inside information in Penn Central Company stock.

title: REDS BEAT METS; LEE MAY INJURED
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30The Cincinnati Reds lost another key player tonight when Lee May damaged the ligaments in his left knee in a collision with Tim Foli of the New York Mets and was sent back to Cincinnati for extended treatment.

title: Charles Wheeler Is Elected Mayor of Kansas City, Mo.
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 30 (AP)Dr. Charles B. Wheeler Jr. won the Mayor's office today over Dutton Brookfield in the city's nonpartisan election.

title: Officer to Be Released
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., March 30 (AP)Judge Alexander Lawrence of Federal District Court here announced today that he would order the release from the Army of Second Lieut. Richard W. Smith, 24 years old, of Boston, who insists he is a conscientitnis objector. Judge Lawrence announced his decision during a hearing on Lieutenant Smith's plea for dismissal from the Army.

title: Chairman of Arlan Stores Sells CommonStock Block
description: Herbert Palestine, chairman of Arlan's Department Stores, a leading discountstore chain, said yesterday that he had sold a block of his common stock in Arlan's to Richard M. Cohen, an industrialist and realestate developer. The amount of shares involved was not disclosed.

title: Taft Asks End to Rails' Weak Branches; Eastern Air Lines Seeks Employes' Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Senator Robert Taft Jr. told a Senate Commerce subcommittee today that in his judgment the way to cure the financial plight of the nation's railroads was to relieve the carriers of the operation of unproductive branch lines and to divest the Interstate Commerce Commission of all railroad ratemaking authority.

title: U.S. Welcomes Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, March 30A State Department spokesman said today that the United States welcomed the Soviet proposal at Geneva and considered it a suitable basis for negotiating a convention banning the use of bacteriological weapons.

title: CRIMMINS WITNESS TELLS OF BEING ILL
description: A key witness for the prosecution conceded under intensive crossexamination yesterday that she was suffering from dizziness, headaches, nervousness, lack of coordination, anxiety and spells at the time that she said she watched Mrs. Alice Crimmins walking with her son on the night he and his sister disappeared in July, 1965.

title: Judge Rules Rackley Case Raid Legal
description: NEW HAVEN, March 30Everything confiscated by the police at Black Panther headquarters here in the early hours of May 22, 1969, was declared legally seized today by the judge in the trial here of Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins.

title: U.S. DEFEATED, 75, IN WORLD HOCKEY
description: GENEVA, March 30 (UPI)The United States put up a valiant battle for a perlod and a half tonight against the Soviet Union, leading twice, but lost, 75, in a world ice hockey championship game.

title: $6,902 Double Breaks Oakland Park Record
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 30 (AP)A record daily double for Oaklawn Park of $6,902 was set today when Faithful Win took the first race and Trouble In Court won the second.

title: Redford Gets Film Role
description: Robert Redford will be featured in The Hot Rock, a comedyadventure movie about four thieves involved in four jewel robberies, which 20th CenturyFox will start filming here in May. Peter Yates will direct for Hal Landers and Bobby Roberts, the producers, from a script by William Goldman and the novel by Donald Westlake. The project will reunite Mr. Redford, who starred with Paul Newman in Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, and Mr. Goldman, who won an Oscar for his screenplay for that film.

title: Shop Talk
description: The women who jammed the third floor of Bergdorf Goodman yesterday for a show of Tiktiner spring and summer fashions came in all sizes and shapes. When the models had finished parading down the runway, some of the women sprinted to the back of the floor where the Tiktiner shop is located. The rest probably headed for the nearesst gym or reducing salon. The current Tiktiner collection, an exclusive French import to the store, is meant primarily for lean, lithe and supple bodies. Age is apparently no criterion, but the number of sleeveless dresses, bare midriffs and short shorts exhibited tactfully suggest at least a vestige of youth.

title: S. Waters Contain 7 Toxic Metals
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The Unitet States Geological Survey reported today that small amounts of seven toxic metals had been found in many of the nation's streams and takes but that, dangerous concentrations were apparently rare.

title: DR. LEONARD M. LIBASCI
description: Dr. Leonard M. Libasci, of 14111 59th Avenue in the Flushing section of Queens, where he had been a general practitioner since 1943, died Sunday after a short illness at his summer home in Beach Haven, N.J. He was 63 years old.

title: Nixon Message to Broadcasters Stresses Local Stations' Value
description: CHICAGO, March 30President Nixon extended special praise today to the individual television and radio stations of the country, and stressed the view that the local outlets were as important as the more publicized national networks.

title: MRS. JOSEPH SANDEMAN
description: Mrs. Eleanor Brady Sandeman, who was an actress before her marriage to the late Joseph Sandeman, an insurance executive, died Friday at the home of her son, Brady Sandeman, in Washington. She was 73 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PAUL COLLINS, 79, AIRLINES FOUNDER
description: BOSTON, March 30 (AP)Paul F. Collins, a cofounder of Northeast Airlines, died in California Saturday of a heart attack. He moved west a year ago from his home in suburban Winchester. He was 79 years old.

title: JEWISH WOMEN WIDEN CHILD CARE
description: DETROIT, March 30What began as a modest effort by a national women's organization to help working mothers has grown into a small network of child care centers throughout the countryand is constantly expanding.

title: Brooklyn Man Dies in Fall
description: A 70yearold Brooklyn man fell to his death from the roof of his home yesterday afternoon while checking the roof for possible winter damage. The victim, Louis Barbusca of 1604 70th Street, in the Bensonhurst seotion of the borough, had gone to the roof after painters had set up a scaffold on the house next door, at 1602 70th Street.

title: Yamashita Precedent
description: Twentyfive years ago the first American warcrimes trial resulted in the hanging of Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita. I was one of his defense counsel before the American Military Commission in Manila and before the Supreme Court in Washington.

title: In a Jordanian Town, a 9YearOld Boy Falls Victim to the Fighting Between Troops and Commandos
description: IRBID, Jordan, March 28It was not antiIsraeli fury or a Palestinian commando riot that set the women of Kuteba Street to wailing today and the police to firing their guns.

title: Vorster to Invite Black Nations To Talks on Apartheid Policies
description: CAPETOWN, March 30 Prime Minister John Vorster said today that he was willing to discuss South Africa's policies of racial separation with leaders of the black nations of Africa.

title: Marlboro Group Excels In Quartet by Messiaen
description: MUSIC FROM MARLBORO. With Craig Sheppard, piano; Isidore Cohen, violin; Nobuko Imai, viola; Nathaniel Rosen, cello; Richard Stoltzman, clarinet. At Tully Hall.

title: Lisbon Finds 9 Guilty of Aid to Angolan Rebels
description: LISBON, March 30An Angolan priest and eight other persons from Portuguese Africa were convicted here today on charges of supporting the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola.

title: I.B.M. Is Sued by Competitors; $400Million Damages Sought
description: Three dataprocessing companies filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court here against the International Business Machines Corporation alleging violation of antimonopoly provisions of the antitrust laws.

title: Perfect Pride Pays $108.20
description: Perfect Pride, driven by Vernon Dancer, defeated Hat Band, steered by Frank Tagariello, by a nose in 2:05 4/5 in Tuesday night's fifth race. The $2 win payoff for this onemile pace was $108.20, the highest of the meeting. The 7, 2 exacta paid $717.40, which was second high, topped by a $726.20 on March 13.

title: Parade and Panache Ring in 101st Circus
description: Lightning almost struck again last night at Madison Square Garden. But the 101st edition of the circusyes, good old Ringling Bros and Barnum & Baileydoesn't quite match last year's cornucopia. See for yourself, with the May 1831 revival of the preceding centennial edition, same place, on the heels of the new show.

title: Brooklyn Museum Feels Pinch, Too
description: The current recession has thrown museums, like everything else, under the financial harrow, and the Brooklyn Museum is suffering as much as any, maybe even more.

title: Chavez Son's Trial Set
description: FRESNO, Calif., March 30 (UPI)Fernando Chavez, son of the farm labor leader Cesar Chavez, will go on trial July 27 in Federal court here on charges of failure to submit to induction into the armed services. Federal Judge M. D. Crocker set the date yesterday. The 21yearold Mr. Chavez said that he was morally opposed to war and could not bring himself to kill another human being.

title: Britain to Reduce Taxes Under Tory Reform Plan
description: LONDON, March 30A program of tax reform to reduce and simplify Britain's onerous tax burden was announced by the Government today in the first budget since the Conservative party came to power.

title: Crop Prices Hold Steady
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)Prices received by farmers for their raw products remained unchanged in March, marking the end a twomonth rise, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30Hopefully, I've learned a lesson, said Tom Seaver, the boy philosopher the New York Mets. Although the cost of the lesson may have seemed painfully exorbitant at the time, it really wasn't that expensive, and Tom is even reaching the grudging conclusion that it may have been a bargain.

title: Building Inspectors Reject Recommended Pact Here
description: The leadership of the building inspectors' union here rejected last night an impasse panel's recommendations for contract settlement. The recommendations were not made public.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SANTIAGO, ChileThe importance of Salvador Allende Gossens, Chile's new Marxist President, is that he is trying to introduce an entirely novel aspect to the idea of revolution. The revolution in the revolution that he sponsors could prove far more significant than the violent processes advocated in a book bearing that title by the young French intellectual friend of Castro and Guevara, Regis Debray.

title: Who Else Would Call Hamburgers the Enemy?
description: PHILADELPHIAThe pizza people met here Monday to map their latest strategy against the enemy: The hamburger.

title: Peggy Lee Gives Model Performance
description: The sleek and subtle Peggy Lee machine is purring smoothly at the Empire Room of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Brezhnev's World View
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev's speech to the 24th Communist party Congress in Moscow is a little like President Nixon's recent State of the World Message to the U.S. Congress. It is long, vague and hopefula little something for everybodybut essentially (it is an exercise in public relations rather than a practical basis for serious negotiation.

title: WENDELL PHILLIPS WINS OIL CONCESSION
description: LONDON, March 30 (Ruters) One of the biggest offshore oil concessions ever awarded in the Middle East has been won by an American, Wendell Phillips, according to authoritative sources here today.

title: Smith Leads Advance
description: SAN JUAN, March 30 (UPI)Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif, ranked No. 2 in the United States and seeded second in the 19th international Caribe Hilton tennis tournament, won his openinground match today with a 60, 61 triumph over Lenny Scholoss of Baltimore.

title: LOEB CHALLENGES RATE PROCEDURE
description: A major dispute among Wall Street leaders appeared to be taking shape yesterday over the issue of negotiated commission rates, which are scheduled to take effect Monday on certain large stock transactions.

title: Soviet Plans to Hold Congress Every 5 Years
description: MOSCOW, March 30The Soviet leadership disclosed today that it planned to change the Communist party rules to convene congresses every five years instead of every four years, as they now are.

title: CORNELIUS DONAHUE, A LAWYER HERE, 70
description: Cornelius O'Connell Donahue, a former partner in the law firm of Hawkins, Delafield & Wood, 67 Wall Street, died yesterday in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 70 years old and lived at 1818 Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: COLOMBO TO START JAM TERM TODAY
description: A State Supreme Court justice refined Yesterday to delay the scheduled surrender today of Joseph Colombo Sr., who is to start serving a prison sentence of one to two and a half years on a perjury conviction.

title: CONSUL URGES U.S. START EVACUATION IN EAST PAKISTAN
description: NEW DELHI, March 30The United States consul general in East Pakistan has asked Washington to evacuate all American women and children and some of the men from the province, where the Pakistani armed forces are fighting an independence movement.

title: Council Votes HomeRule Message Seeking Permission to Issue Bonds to Buy Stadium
description: The City Council gave first round approval yesterday for the city's purchase of Yankee Stadium for $24million but not before telling the Football Giants that if they did not want to sign a lease to get out.

title: CORNBREAD PLAYERS TO GIVE DOUBLE BILL
description: Two plays under the collective title of Underground will be presented on April 13 by the Cornbread Players, a black group, at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Other Stage in the Public.Theaters 425 Lafayette Street.

title: $488MILLION RISE IN STATE'S TAXES IS ASKED BY G.O.P.
description: ALBANY, March 30Republican legislative leaders proposed today a $488million package of state tax increases built around a rise of 1 cent on the dollar in the state sales tax.

title: Advertising:
description: There's a new kind of drink sweeping the nation. It's a sort of beer but not a beermore like an alcoholic soda pop.

title: Objectors Dominate Hearing Here on Proposed Increase in Phone Rates
description: An uproarious audience interrupted a New York Telephone Company's presentation of its request for a 29.1 per cent rate increase yesterday, and for the rest of a long day a Public Service Commission hearing listened to a barrage by opponents of the increase.

title: ALLENDE AFFIRMS. DESIRE FOR AMITY
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 30  President Salvador Allende Gossens, said at a political rally of 40,000 people tonight that Chile's interest and desire was to maintain very good relations with the United States.

title: Delay in Enquirer Sale
description: CINCINNATI, March 30 (AP) The eighth delay in the deadline for the E. W. Scripps Company to sell its majority interest in The Enquirer to avoid antitrust prosecution was granted yesterday by United States District Judge David S. Porter. The delay was granted until May 7.

title: Party Congresses Have Reflected Russians' History
description: MOSCOW, March 30  On March 13, 1898, a band of nine men who had avoided the Czarist police met for three days in Minsk to discuss the formation of a revolutionary party, the Russian Social Democratic Workers party. Although the meeting accomplished little, it is remembered as the first congress of what is now the Soviet Communist party.

title: Building Unions Will Fight Nixon's WageCurb Order
description: WASHINGTON, March 30A spokesman for the nation's construction unions declared today that President Nixon had imposed full controls on construction industry wages, although the Administration had characterized the move as something less.

title: I.B.M., After 10 Years, Elects An Executive Vice President
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday, elected Frank T. Cary as executive vice president, a post that has not been filled for 10 years. The former senior vice president is a director of the company and now also becomes the eighth member of the executive committee. He continues as a member of the corporate office and the management review committee.

title: AMEX STOCKS DIP AS VOLUME RISES
description: Prices on the Aitiericail Stock Exchange finished mostly low er Yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: TAPE USE ARMED AT PANTHER TRIAL
description: A surprise prosecution witness here yesterday set the stage for the playing of the recording of a conversation between an assistant district attorney and a Black Panther who fled to Algeria.

title: FULBRICHT PLANS HEARINGS ON WAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, signaling an end to the truce in the Indochina debate, decided today to push ahead with public hearings on how to end the war.
